author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the eleven years that separated the Declaration of the Independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States from the completion of that act in the ordination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of our written Constitution, the great minds of America were bent upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the study of the principles of government that were essential to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preservation of the liberties which had been won at great cost and with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heroic labors and sacrifices. Their studies were conducted in view of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the imperfections that experience had developed in the government of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Confederation, and they were, therefore, practical and thorough.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the Constitution was thus perfected and established, a new form of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government was created, but it was neither speculative nor experimental
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to the principles on which it was based. If they were true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles, as they were, the government founded upon them was destined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a life and an influence that would continue while the liberties it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was intended to preserve should be valued by the human family. Those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties had been wrung from reluctant monarchs in many contests,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in many countries, and were grouped into creeds and established in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinances sealed with blood, in many great struggles of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They were not new to the people. They were consecrated theories, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no government had been previously established for the great purpose of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their preservation and enforcement. That which was experimental in our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plan of government was the question whether democratic rule could be so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: organized and conducted that it would not degenerate into license and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: result in the tyranny of absolutism, without saving to the people the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power so often found necessary of repressing or destroying their enemy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when he was found in the person of a single despot.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When, in 1831, Alexis de Tocqueville came to study Democracy in America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the trial of nearly a half-century of the working of our system had been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made, and it had been proved, by many crucial tests, to be a government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of "liberty regulated by law," with such results in the development of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength, in population, wealth, and military and commercial power, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no age had ever witnessed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [See Alexis De Tocqueville]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: De Tocqueville had a special inquiry to prosecute, in his visit to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, in which his generous and faithful soul and the powers of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great intellect were engaged in the patriotic effort to secure to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people of France the blessings that Democracy in America had ordained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and established throughout nearly the entire Western Hemisphere. He had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: read the story of the French Revolution, much of which had been recently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: written in the blood of men and women of great distinction who were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his progenitors; and had witnessed the agitations and terrors of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Restoration and of the Second Republic, fruitful in crime and sacrifice,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and barren of any good to mankind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He had just witnessed the spread of republican government through all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the vast continental possessions of Spain in America, and the loss of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her great colonies. He had seen that these revolutions were accomplished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost without the shedding of blood, and he was filled with anxiety to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learn the causes that had placed republican government, in France, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such contrast with Democracy in America.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: De Tocqueville was scarcely thirty years old when he began his studies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Democracy in America. It was a bold effort for one who had no special
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: training in government, or in the study of political economy, but he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had the example of Lafayette in establishing the military foundation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these liberties, and of Washington, Jefferson, Madison, and Hamilton,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all of whom were young men, in building upon the Independence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States that wisest and best plan of general government that was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever devised for a free people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He found that the American people, through their chosen representatives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who were instructed by their wisdom and experience and were supported
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their virtues--cultivated, purified and ennobled by self-reliance and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the love of God--had matured, in the excellent wisdom of their counsels,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a new plan of government, which embraced every security for their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties and equal rights and privileges to all in the pursuit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happiness. He came as an honest and impartial student and his great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commentary, like those of Paul, was written for the benefit of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations and people and in vindication of truths that will stand for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their deliverance from monarchical rule, while time shall last.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A French aristocrat of the purest strain of blood and of the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honorable lineage, whose family influence was coveted by crowned heads;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who had no quarrel with the rulers of the nation, and was secure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against want by his inherited estates; was moved by the agitations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that compelled France to attempt to grasp suddenly the liberties and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happiness we had gained in our revolution and, by his devout love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of France, to search out and subject to the test of reason the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: basic principles of free government that had been embodied in our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution. This was the mission of De Tocqueville, and no mission
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was ever more honorably or justly conducted, or concluded with greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eclat, or better results for the welfare of mankind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: His researches were logical and exhaustive. They included every phase of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every question that then seemed to be apposite to the great inquiry he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was making.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The judgment of all who have studied his commentaries seems to have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unanimous, that his talents and learning were fully equal to his task.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He began with the physical geography of this country, and examined the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics of the people, of all races and conditions, their social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and religious sentiments, their education and tastes; their industries,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their commerce, their local governments, their passions and prejudices,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their ethics and literature; leaving nothing unnoticed that might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afford an argument to prove that our plan and form of government was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or was not adapted especially to a peculiar people, or that it would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impracticable in any different country, or among any different people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The pride and comfort that the American people enjoy in the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commentaries of De Tocqueville are far removed from the selfish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adulation that comes from a great and singular success. It is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consciousness of victory over a false theory of government which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afflicted mankind for many ages, that gives joy to the true American, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it did to De Tocqueville in his great triumph.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When De Tocqueville wrote, we had lived less than fifty years under our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution. In that time no great national commotion had occurred that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tested its strength, or its power of resistance to internal strife, such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as had converted his beloved France into fields of slaughter torn by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tempests of wrath.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He had a strong conviction that no government could be ordained that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could resist these internal forces, when, they are directed to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destruction by bad men, or unreasoning mobs, and many then believed, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some yet believe, that our government is unequal to such pressure, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the assault is thoroughly desperate.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Had De Tocqueville lived to examine the history of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from 1860 to 1870, his misgivings as to this power of self-preservation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would, probably, have been cleared off. He would have seen that, at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the end of the most destructive civil war that ever occurred, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animosities of the bitterest sort had banished all good feeling from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hearts of our people, the States of the American Union, still in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complete organization and equipped with all their official entourage,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aligned themselves in their places and took up the powers and duties of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: local government in perfect order and without embarrassment. This would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have dispelled his apprehensions, if he had any, about the power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States to withstand the severest shocks of civil war. Could he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have traced the further course of events until they open the portals of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the twentieth century, he would have cast away his fears of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ability to restore peace, order, and prosperity, in the face of any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulties, and would have rejoiced to find in the Constitution of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States the remedy that is provided for the healing of the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: De Tocqueville examined, with the care that is worthy the importance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the subject, the nature and value of the system of "local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self-government," as we style this most important feature of our plan,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and (as has often happened) when this or any subject has become a matter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of anxious concern, his treatment of the questions is found to have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: masterly and his preconceptions almost prophetic.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We are frequently indebted to him for able expositions and true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doctrines relating to subjects that have slumbered in the minds of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people until they were suddenly forced on our attention by unexpected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: events.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In his introductory chapter, M. De Tocqueville says: "Amongst the novel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects that attracted my attention during my stay in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, nothing struck me more forcibly than the general equality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions." He referred, doubtless, to social and political conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: among the people of the white race, who are described as "We, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people," in the opening sentence of the Constitution. The last three
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amendments of the Constitution have so changed this, that those who were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then negro slaves are clothed with the rights of citizenship, including
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the right of suffrage. This was a political party movement, intended to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be radical and revolutionary, but it will, ultimately, react because it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has not the sanction of public opinion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If M. De Tocqueville could now search for a law that would negative this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provision in its effect upon social equality, he would fail to find it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But he would find it in the unwritten law of the natural aversion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: races. He would find it in public opinion, which is the vital force in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every law in a free government. This is a subject that our Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: failed to regulate, because it was not contemplated by its authors. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is a question that will settle itself, without serious difficulty. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality in the suffrage, thus guaranteed to the negro race, alone--for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it was not intended to include other colored races--creates a new phase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of political conditions that M. De Tocqueville could not foresee.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Yet, in his commendation of the local town and county governments,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he applauds and sustains that elementary feature of our political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: organization which, in the end, will render harmless this wide departure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the original plan and purpose of American Democracy. "Local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Self-Government," independent of general control, except for general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purposes, is the root and origin of all free republican government, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the antagonist of all great political combinations that threaten the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights of minorities. It is the public opinion formed in the independent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expressions of towns and other small civil districts that is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: real conservatism of free government. It is equally the enemy of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous evil, the corruption of the ballot-box, from which it is now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apprehended that one of our greatest troubles is to arise.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The voter is selected, under our laws, because he has certain physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: qualifications--age and sex. His disqualifications, when any are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imposed, relate to his education or property, and to the fact that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has not been convicted of crime. Of all men he should be most directly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amenable to public opinion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The test of moral character and devotion to the duties of good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizenship are ignored in the laws, because the courts can seldom deal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with such questions in a uniform and satisfactory way, under rules that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apply alike to all. Thus the voter, selected by law to represent himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and four other non-voting citizens, is often a person who is unfit for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any public duty or trust. In a town government, having a small area of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction, where the voice of the majority of qualified voters is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conclusive, the fitness of the person who is to exercise that high
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative privilege can be determined by his neighbors and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquaintances, and, in the great majority of cases, it will be decided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honestly and for the good of the country. In such meetings, there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always a spirit of loyalty to the State, because that is loyalty to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people, and a reverence for God that gives weight to the duties and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsibilities of citizenship.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: M. De Tocqueville found in these minor local jurisdictions the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theoretical conservatism which, in the aggregate, is the safest reliance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the State. So we have found them, in practice, the true protectors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the purity of the ballot, without which all free government will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degenerate into absolutism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the future of the Republic, we must encounter many difficult and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous situations, but the principles established in the Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the check upon hasty or inconsiderate legislation, and upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive action, and the supreme arbitrament of the courts, will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found sufficient for the safety of personal rights, and for the safety
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the government, and the prophetic outlook of M. De Tocqueville will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be fully realized through the influence of Democracy in America. Each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeeding generation of Americans will find in the pure and impartial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reflections of De Tocqueville a new source of pride in our institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of government, and sound reasons for patriotic effort to preserve
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them and to inculcate their teachings. They have mastered the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchical rule in the American Hemisphere, freeing religion from all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shackles, and will spread, by a quiet but resistless influence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through the islands of the seas to other lands, where the appeals of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: De Tocqueville for human rights and liberties have already inspired the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: souls of the people.

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nearly two-thirds of a century has elapsed since the appearance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Democracy in America," by Alexis Charles Henri Clerel de Tocqueville, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French nobleman, born at Paris, July 29, 1805.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Bred to the law, he exhibited an early predilection for philosophy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political economy, and at twenty-two was appointed judge-auditor at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribunal of Versailles.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1831, commissioned ostensibly to investigate the penitentiary system
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States, he visited this country, with his friend, Gustave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: de Beaumont, travelling extensively through those parts of the Republic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then subdued to settlement, studying the methods of local, State, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national administration, and observing the manners and habits, the daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life, the business, the industries and occupations of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Democracy in America," the first of four volumes upon "American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Institutions and their Influence," was published in 1835. It was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: received at once by the scholars and thinkers of Europe as a profound,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impartial, and entertaining exposition of the principles of popular,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative self-government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Napoleon, "The mighty somnambulist of a vanished dream," had abolished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feudalism and absolutism, made monarchs and dynasties obsolete, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: substituted for the divine right of kings the sovereignty of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although by birth and sympathies an aristocrat, M. de Tocqueville
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: saw that the reign of tradition and privilege at last was ended. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceived that civilization, after many bloody centuries, had entered a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: new epoch. He beheld, and deplored, the excesses that had attended the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genesis of the democratic spirit in France, and while he loved liberty,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he detested the crimes that had been committed in its name. Belonging
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neither to the class which regarded the social revolution as an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innovation to be resisted, nor to that which considered political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality the universal panacea for the evils of humanity, he resolved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by personal observation of the results of democracy in the New World
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to ascertain its natural consequences, and to learn what the nations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe had to hope or fear from its final supremacy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: That a youth of twenty-six should entertain a design so broad and bold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: implies singular intellectual intrepidity. He had neither model
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor precedent. The vastness and novelty of the undertaking increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admiration for the remarkable ability with which the task was performed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Were literary excellence the sole claim of "Democracy in America" to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinction, the splendor of its composition alone would entitle it to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: high place among the masterpieces of the century. The first chapter,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the exterior form of North America, as the theatre upon which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great drama is to be enacted, for graphic and picturesque description
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the physical characteristics of the continent is not surpassed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in literature: nor is there any subdivision of the work in which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severest philosophy is not invested with the grace of poetry, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: driest statistics with the charm of romance. Western emigration seemed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonplace and prosaic till M. de Tocqueville said, "This gradual and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continuous progress of the European race toward the Rocky Mountains has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the solemnity of a providential event; it is like a deluge of men rising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unabatedly, and daily driven onward by the hand of God!"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The mind of M. de Tocqueville had the candor of the photographic camera.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It recorded impressions with the impartiality of nature. The image was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes distorted, and the perspective was not always true, but he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was neither a panegyrist, nor an advocate, nor a critic. He observed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American phenomena as illustrations, not as proof nor arguments; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although it is apparent that the tendency of his mind was not wholly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to the democratic principle, yet those who dissent from his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conclusions must commend the ability and courage with which they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expressed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Though not originally written for Americans, "Democracy in America" must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always remain a work of engrossing and constantly increasing interest to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens of the United States as the first philosophic and comprehensive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: view of our society, institutions, and destiny. No one can rise even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the most cursory perusal without clearer insight and more patriotic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appreciation of the blessings of liberty protected by law, nor without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encouragement for the stability and perpetuity of the Republic. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes which appeared to M. de Tocqueville to menace both, have gone.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The despotism of public opinion, the tyranny of majorities, the absence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of intellectual freedom which seemed to him to degrade administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and bring statesmanship, learning, and literature to the level of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lowest, are no longer considered. The violence of party spirit has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been mitigated, and the judgment of the wise is not subordinated to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudices of the ignorant.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Other dangers have come. Equality of conditions no longer exists.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Prophets of evil predict the downfall of democracy, but the student
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of M. de Tocqueville will find consolation and encouragement in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reflection that the same spirit which has vanquished the perils of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the past, which he foresaw, will be equally prepared for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsibilities of the present and the future.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The last of the four volumes of M. de Tocqueville's work upon American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions appeared in 1840.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1838 he was chosen member of the Academy of Moral and Political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Sciences. In 1839 he was elected to the Chamber of Deputies. He became
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a member of the French Academy in 1841. In 1848 he was in the Assembly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and from June 2nd to October 31st he was Minister of Foreign Affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The coup d'etat of December 2, 1851 drove him from the public service.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1856 he published "The Old Regime and the Revolution." He died at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Cannes, April 15, 1859, at the age of fifty-four.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hon. John J. Ingalls
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Introductory Chapter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst the novel objects that attracted my attention during my stay
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States, nothing struck me more forcibly than the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality of conditions. I readily discovered the prodigious influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which this primary fact exercises on the whole course of society, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: giving a certain direction to public opinion, and a certain tenor to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws; by imparting new maxims to the governing powers, and peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits to the governed. I speedily perceived that the influence of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact extends far beyond the political character and the laws of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, and that it has no less empire over civil society than over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Government; it creates opinions, engenders sentiments, suggests the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinary practices of life, and modifies whatever it does not produce.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The more I advanced in the study of American society, the more I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceived that the equality of conditions is the fundamental fact from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which all others seem to be derived, and the central point at which all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my observations constantly terminated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I then turned my thoughts to our own hemisphere, where I imagined that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I discerned something analogous to the spectacle which the New World
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: presented to me. I observed that the equality of conditions is daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progressing towards those extreme limits which it seems to have reached
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States, and that the democracy which governs the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities appears to be rapidly rising into power in Europe. I hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceived the idea of the book which is now before the reader.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is evident to all alike that a great democratic revolution is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: going on amongst us; but there are two opinions as to its nature and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences. To some it appears to be a novel accident, which as such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may still be checked; to others it seems irresistible, because it is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most uniform, the most ancient, and the most permanent tendency which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be found in history. Let us recollect the situation of France seven
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hundred years ago, when the territory was divided amongst a small number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of families, who were the owners of the soil and the rulers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inhabitants; the right of governing descended with the family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inheritance from generation to generation; force was the only means by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which man could act on man, and landed property was the sole source of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. Soon, however, the political power of the clergy was founded, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: began to exert itself: the clergy opened its ranks to all classes, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the poor and the rich, the villein and the lord; equality penetrated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the Government through the Church, and the being who as a serf must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have vegetated in perpetual bondage took his place as a priest in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: midst of nobles, and not infrequently above the heads of kings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The different relations of men became more complicated and more numerous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as society gradually became more stable and more civilized. Thence the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: want of civil laws was felt; and the order of legal functionaries soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rose from the obscurity of the tribunals and their dusty chambers, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appear at the court of the monarch, by the side of the feudal barons in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their ermine and their mail. Whilst the kings were ruining themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their great enterprises, and the nobles exhausting their resources
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by private wars, the lower orders were enriching themselves by commerce.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The influence of money began to be perceptible in State affairs. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transactions of business opened a new road to power, and the financier
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rose to a station of political influence in which he was at once
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flattered and despised. Gradually the spread of mental acquirements, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the increasing taste for literature and art, opened chances of success
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to talent; science became a means of government, intelligence led to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social power, and the man of letters took a part in the affairs of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State. The value attached to the privileges of birth decreased in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exact proportion in which new paths were struck out to advancement. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the eleventh century nobility was beyond all price; in the thirteenth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it might be purchased; it was conferred for the first time in 1270;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and equality was thus introduced into the Government by the aristocracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the course of these seven hundred years it sometimes happened that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to resist the authority of the Crown, or to diminish the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their rivals, the nobles granted a certain share of political rights to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people. Or, more frequently, the king permitted the lower orders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to enjoy a degree of power, with the intention of repressing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy. In France the kings have always been the most active and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most constant of levellers. When they were strong and ambitious they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spared no pains to raise the people to the level of the nobles; when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they were temperate or weak they allowed the people to rise above
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves. Some assisted the democracy by their talents, others by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their vices. Louis XI and Louis XIV reduced every rank beneath the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: throne to the same subjection; Louis XV descended, himself and all his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Court, into the dust.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As soon as land was held on any other than a feudal tenure, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal property began in its turn to confer influence and power, every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: improvement which was introduced in commerce or manufacture was a fresh
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: element of the equality of conditions. Henceforward every new discovery,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every new want which it engendered, and every new desire which craved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfaction, was a step towards the universal level. The taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: luxury, the love of war, the sway of fashion, and the most superficial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as well as the deepest passions of the human heart, co-operated to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enrich the poor and to impoverish the rich.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From the time when the exercise of the intellect became the source of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength and of wealth, it is impossible not to consider every addition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to science, every fresh truth, and every new idea as a germ of power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: placed within the reach of the people. Poetry, eloquence, and memory,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the grace of wit, the glow of imagination, the depth of thought, and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the gifts which are bestowed by Providence with an equal hand, turned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the advantage of the democracy; and even when they were in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of its adversaries they still served its cause by throwing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into relief the natural greatness of man; its conquests spread,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, with those of civilization and knowledge, and literature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became an arsenal where the poorest and the weakest could always find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weapons to their hand.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In perusing the pages of our history, we shall scarcely meet with a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single great event, in the lapse of seven hundred years, which has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turned to the advantage of equality. The Crusades and the wars of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English decimated the nobles and divided their possessions; the erection
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of communities introduced an element of democratic liberty into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bosom of feudal monarchy; the invention of fire-arms equalized the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: villein and the noble on the field of battle; printing opened the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources to the minds of all classes; the post was organized so as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bring the same information to the door of the poor man's cottage and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the gate of the palace; and Protestantism proclaimed that all men are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike able to find the road to heaven. The discovery of America offered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a thousand new paths to fortune, and placed riches and power within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the reach of the adventurous and the obscure. If we examine what has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happened in France at intervals of fifty years, beginning with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eleventh century, we shall invariably perceive that a twofold revolution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has taken place in the state of society. The noble has gone down on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social ladder, and the roturier has gone up; the one descends as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other rises. Every half century brings them nearer to each other, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will very shortly meet.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nor is this phenomenon at all peculiar to France. Whithersoever we turn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our eyes we shall witness the same continual revolution throughout the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole of Christendom. The various occurrences of national existence have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everywhere turned to the advantage of democracy; all men have aided it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their exertions: those who have intentionally labored in its cause,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and those who have served it unwittingly; those who have fought for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it and those who have declared themselves its opponents, have all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been driven along in the same track, have all labored to one end, some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorantly and some unwillingly; all have been blind instruments in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands of God.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The gradual development of the equality of conditions is therefore a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: providential fact, and it possesses all the characteristics of a divine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decree: it is universal, it is durable, it constantly eludes all human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interference, and all events as well as all men contribute to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress. Would it, then, be wise to imagine that a social impulse which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dates from so far back can be checked by the efforts of a generation? Is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it credible that the democracy which has annihilated the feudal system
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and vanquished kings will respect the citizen and the capitalist? Will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it stop now that it has grown so strong and its adversaries so weak?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: None can say which way we are going, for all terms of comparison are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wanting: the equality of conditions is more complete in the Christian
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries of the present day than it has been at any time or in any part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the world; so that the extent of what already exists prevents us from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreseeing what may be yet to come.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The whole book which is here offered to the public has been written
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under the impression of a kind of religious dread produced in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: author's mind by the contemplation of so irresistible a revolution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has advanced for centuries in spite of such amazing obstacles, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is still proceeding in the midst of the ruins it has made. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not necessary that God himself should speak in order to disclose to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: us the unquestionable signs of His will; we can discern them in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitual course of nature, and in the invariable tendency of events: I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know, without a special revelation, that the planets move in the orbits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traced by the Creator's finger. If the men of our time were led by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attentive observation and by sincere reflection to acknowledge that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradual and progressive development of social equality is at once the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: past and future of their history, this solitary truth would confer the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sacred character of a Divine decree upon the change. To attempt to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: check democracy would be in that case to resist the will of God; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nations would then be constrained to make the best of the social lot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: awarded to them by Providence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Christian nations of our age seem to me to present a most alarming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spectacle; the impulse which is bearing them along is so strong that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be stopped, but it is not yet so rapid that it cannot be guided:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their fate is in their hands; yet a little while and it may be so no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer. The first duty which is at this time imposed upon those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direct our affairs is to educate the democracy; to warm its faith,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if that be possible; to purify its morals; to direct its energies;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to substitute a knowledge of business for its inexperience, and an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquaintance with its true interests for its blind propensities; to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adapt its government to time and place, and to modify it in compliance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the occurrences and the actors of the age. A new science of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics is indispensable to a new world. This, however, is what we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: think of least; launched in the middle of a rapid stream, we obstinately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fix our eyes on the ruins which may still be described upon the shore we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have left, whilst the current sweeps us along, and drives us backwards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: towards the gulf.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In no country in Europe has the great social revolution which I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been describing made such rapid progress as in France; but it has always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been borne on by chance. The heads of the State have never had any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forethought for its exigencies, and its victories have been obtained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without their consent or without their knowledge. The most powerful, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most intelligent, and the most moral classes of the nation have never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempted to connect themselves with it in order to guide it. The people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has consequently been abandoned to its wild propensities, and it has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grown up like those outcasts who receive their education in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public streets, and who are unacquainted with aught but the vices and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wretchedness of society. The existence of a democracy was seemingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unknown, when on a sudden it took possession of the supreme power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Everything was then submitted to its caprices; it was worshipped as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idol of strength; until, when it was enfeebled by its own excesses, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator conceived the rash project of annihilating its power, instead
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of instructing it and correcting its vices; no attempt was made to fit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it to govern, but all were bent on excluding it from the government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The consequence of this has been that the democratic revolution has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effected only in the material parts of society, without that concomitant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change in laws, ideas, customs, and manners which was necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: render such a revolution beneficial. We have gotten a democracy, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without the conditions which lessen its vices and render its natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages more prominent; and although we already perceive the evils it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brings, we are ignorant of the benefits it may confer.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: While the power of the Crown, supported by the aristocracy, peaceably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed the nations of Europe, society possessed, in the midst of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wretchedness, several different advantages which can now scarcely be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appreciated or conceived. The power of a part of his subjects was an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insurmountable barrier to the tyranny of the prince; and the monarch,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who felt the almost divine character which he enjoyed in the eyes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the multitude, derived a motive for the just use of his power from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect which he inspired. High as they were placed above the people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nobles could not but take that calm and benevolent interest in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its fate which the shepherd feels towards his flock; and without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledging the poor as their equals, they watched over the destiny of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those whose welfare Providence had entrusted to their care. The people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never having conceived the idea of a social condition different from its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own, and entertaining no expectation of ever ranking with its chiefs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: received benefits from them without discussing their rights. It grew
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attached to them when they were clement and just, and it submitted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without resistance or servility to their exactions, as to the inevitable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: visitations of the arm of God. Custom, and the manners of the time,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had moreover created a species of law in the midst of violence, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established certain limits to oppression. As the noble never suspected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that anyone would attempt to deprive him of the privileges which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he believed to be legitimate, and as the serf looked upon his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferiority as a consequence of the immutable order of nature, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easy to imagine that a mutual exchange of good-will took place between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two classes so differently gifted by fate. Inequality and wretchedness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were then to be found in society; but the souls of neither rank of men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were degraded. Men are not corrupted by the exercise of power or debased
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the habit of obedience, but by the exercise of a power which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe to be illegal and by obedience to a rule which they consider
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be usurped and oppressive. On one side was wealth, strength, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leisure, accompanied by the refinements of luxury, the elegance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taste, the pleasures of wit, and the religion of art. On the other was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor and a rude ignorance; but in the midst of this coarse and ignorant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude it was not uncommon to meet with energetic passions, generous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sentiments, profound religious convictions, and independent virtues. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body of a State thus organized might boast of its stability, its power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and, above all, of its glory.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the scene is now changed, and gradually the two ranks mingle; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divisions which once severed mankind are lowered, property is divided,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power is held in common, the light of intelligence spreads, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capacities of all classes are equally cultivated; the State becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic, and the empire of democracy is slowly and peaceably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced into the institutions and the manners of the nation. I can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceive a society in which all men would profess an equal attachment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and respect for the laws of which they are the common authors; in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the authority of the State would be respected as necessary, though not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as divine; and the loyalty of the subject to its chief magistrate would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not be a passion, but a quiet and rational persuasion. Every individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being in the possession of rights which he is sure to retain, a kind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manly reliance and reciprocal courtesy would arise between all classes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike removed from pride and meanness. The people, well acquainted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with its true interests, would allow that in order to profit by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages of society it is necessary to satisfy its demands. In this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of things the voluntary association of the citizens might supply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the individual exertions of the nobles, and the community would be alike
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protected from anarchy and from oppression.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I admit that, in a democratic State thus constituted, society will not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be stationary; but the impulses of the social body may be regulated and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directed forwards; if there be less splendor than in the halls of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy, the contrast of misery will be less frequent also; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures of enjoyment may be less excessive, but those of comfort will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be more general; the sciences may be less perfectly cultivated, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorance will be less common; the impetuosity of the feelings will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repressed, and the habits of the nation softened; there will be more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vices and fewer crimes. In the absence of enthusiasm and of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ardent faith, great sacrifices may be obtained from the members of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonwealth by an appeal to their understandings and their experience;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each individual will feel the same necessity for uniting with his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-citizens to protect his own weakness; and as he knows that if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are to assist he must co-operate, he will readily perceive that his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal interest is identified with the interest of the community. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, taken as a whole, will be less brilliant, less glorious, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps less strong; but the majority of the citizens will enjoy a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater degree of prosperity, and the people will remain quiet, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because it despairs of amelioration, but because it is conscious of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages of its condition. If all the consequences of this state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things were not good or useful, society would at least have appropriated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all such as were useful and good; and having once and for ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: renounced the social advantages of aristocracy, mankind would enter into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of all the benefits which democracy can afford.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But here it may be asked what we have adopted in the place of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions, those ideas, and those customs of our forefathers which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we have abandoned. The spell of royalty is broken, but it has not been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeeded by the majesty of the laws; the people has learned to despise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all authority, but fear now extorts a larger tribute of obedience than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that which was formerly paid by reverence and by love.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I perceive that we have destroyed those independent beings which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able to cope with tyranny single-handed; but it is the Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that has inherited the privileges of which families, corporations, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals have been deprived; the weakness of the whole community has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore succeeded that influence of a small body of citizens, which,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if it was sometimes oppressive, was often conservative. The division
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of property has lessened the distance which separated the rich from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: poor; but it would seem that the nearer they draw to each other, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater is their mutual hatred, and the more vehement the envy and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dread with which they resist each other's claims to power; the notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Right is alike insensible to both classes, and Force affords to both the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only argument for the present, and the only guarantee for the future.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The poor man retains the prejudices of his forefathers without their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faith, and their ignorance without their virtues; he has adopted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the doctrine of self-interest as the rule of his actions, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understanding the science which controls it, and his egotism is no less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blind than his devotedness was formerly. If society is tranquil, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not because it relies upon its strength and its well-being, but because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it knows its weakness and its infirmities; a single effort may cost it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its life; everybody feels the evil, but no one has courage or energy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enough to seek the cure; the desires, the regret, the sorrows, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: joys of the time produce nothing that is visible or permanent, like the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions of old men which terminate in impotence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We have, then, abandoned whatever advantages the old state of things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afforded, without receiving any compensation from our present condition;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we have destroyed an aristocracy, and we seem inclined to survey its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ruins with complacency, and to fix our abode in the midst of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The phenomena which the intellectual world presents are not less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deplorable. The democracy of France, checked in its course or abandoned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to its lawless passions, has overthrown whatever crossed its path, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has shaken all that it has not destroyed. Its empire on society has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not been gradually introduced or peaceably established, but it has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly advanced in the midst of disorder and the agitation of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conflict. In the heat of the struggle each partisan is hurried beyond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the limits of his opinions by the opinions and the excesses of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opponents, until he loses sight of the end of his exertions, and holds a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language which disguises his real sentiments or secret instincts. Hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arises the strange confusion which we are witnessing. I cannot recall to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my mind a passage in history more worthy of sorrow and of pity than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scenes which are happening under our eyes; it is as if the natural bond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which unites the opinions of man to his tastes and his actions to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his principles was now broken; the sympathy which has always been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledged between the feelings and the ideas of mankind appears to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be dissolved, and all the laws of moral analogy to be abolished.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Zealous Christians may be found amongst us whose minds are nurtured in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the love and knowledge of a future life, and who readily espouse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the cause of human liberty as the source of all moral greatness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christianity, which has declared that all men are equal in the sight of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: God, will not refuse to acknowledge that all citizens are equal in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eye of the law. But, by a singular concourse of events, religion is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entangled in those institutions which democracy assails, and it is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unfrequently brought to reject the equality it loves, and to curse that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause of liberty as a foe which it might hallow by its alliance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: By the side of these religious men I discern others whose looks are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turned to the earth more than to Heaven; they are the partisans of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty, not only as the source of the noblest virtues, but more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially as the root of all solid advantages; and they sincerely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desire to extend its sway, and to impart its blessings to mankind. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is natural that they should hasten to invoke the assistance of religion,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for they must know that liberty cannot be established without morality,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor morality without faith; but they have seen religion in the ranks of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their adversaries, and they inquire no further; some of them attack it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: openly, and the remainder are afraid to defend it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In former ages slavery has been advocated by the venal and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavish-minded, whilst the independent and the warm-hearted were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggling without hope to save the liberties of mankind. But men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: high and generous characters are now to be met with, whose opinions are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at variance with their inclinations, and who praise that servility which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have themselves never known. Others, on the contrary, speak in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the name of liberty, as if they were able to feel its sanctity and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majesty, and loudly claim for humanity those rights which they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always disowned. There are virtuous and peaceful individuals whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pure morality, quiet habits, affluence, and talents fit them to be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leaders of the surrounding population; their love of their country is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sincere, and they are prepared to make the greatest sacrifices to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: welfare, but they confound the abuses of civilization with its benefits,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the idea of evil is inseparable in their minds from that of novelty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not far from this class is another party, whose object is to materialize
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind, to hit upon what is expedient without heeding what is just,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to acquire knowledge without faith, and prosperity apart from virtue;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assuming the title of the champions of modern civilization, and placing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves in a station which they usurp with insolence, and from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they are driven by their own unworthiness. Where are we then?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The religionists are the enemies of liberty, and the friends of liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attack religion; the high-minded and the noble advocate subjection,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the meanest and most servile minds preach independence; honest and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlightened citizens are opposed to all progress, whilst men without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patriotism and without principles are the apostles of civilization and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of intelligence. Has such been the fate of the centuries which have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preceded our own? and has man always inhabited a world like the present,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where nothing is linked together, where virtue is without genius, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genius without honor; where the love of order is confounded with a taste
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for oppression, and the holy rites of freedom with a contempt of law;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the light thrown by conscience on human actions is dim, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where nothing seems to be any longer forbidden or allowed, honorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or shameful, false or true? I cannot, however, believe that the Creator
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made man to leave him in an endless struggle with the intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: miseries which surround us: God destines a calmer and a more certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future to the communities of Europe; I am unacquainted with His designs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but I shall not cease to believe in them because I cannot fathom them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and I had rather mistrust my own capacity than His justice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is a country in the world where the great revolution which I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speaking of seems nearly to have reached its natural limits; it has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been effected with ease and simplicity, say rather that this country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has attained the consequences of the democratic revolution which we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are undergoing without having experienced the revolution itself. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emigrants who fixed themselves on the shores of America in the beginning
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the seventeenth century severed the democratic principle from all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principles which repressed it in the old communities of Europe, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transplanted it unalloyed to the New World. It has there been allowed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spread in perfect freedom, and to put forth its consequences in the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by influencing the manners of the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It appears to me beyond a doubt that sooner or later we shall arrive,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like the Americans, at an almost complete equality of conditions. But I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not conclude from this that we shall ever be necessarily led to draw
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same political consequences which the Americans have derived from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a similar social organization. I am far from supposing that they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chosen the only form of government which a democracy may adopt; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: identity of the efficient cause of laws and manners in the two countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is sufficient to account for the immense interest we have in becoming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquainted with its effects in each of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not, then, merely to satisfy a legitimate curiosity that I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examined America; my wish has been to find instruction by which we may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ourselves profit. Whoever should imagine that I have intended to write a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: panegyric will perceive that such was not my design; nor has it been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my object to advocate any form of government in particular, for I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of opinion that absolute excellence is rarely to be found in any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation; I have not even affected to discuss whether the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution, which I believe to be irresistible, is advantageous or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudicial to mankind; I have acknowledged this revolution as a fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already accomplished or on the eve of its accomplishment; and I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: selected the nation, from amongst those which have undergone it, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which its development has been the most peaceful and the most complete,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to discern its natural consequences, and, if it be possible, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguish the means by which it may be rendered profitable. I confess
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in America I saw more than America; I sought the image of democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself, with its inclinations, its character, its prejudices, and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions, in order to learn what we have to fear or to hope from its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the first part of this work I have attempted to show the tendency
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: given to the laws by the democracy of America, which is abandoned almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without restraint to its instinctive propensities, and to exhibit the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course it prescribes to the Government and the influence it exercises on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs. I have sought to discover the evils and the advantages which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it produces. I have examined the precautions used by the Americans to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direct it, as well as those which they have not adopted, and I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertaken to point out the causes which enable it to govern society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not know whether I have succeeded in making known what I saw in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, but I am certain that such has been my sincere desire, and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have never, knowingly, moulded facts to ideas, instead of ideas to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whenever a point could be established by the aid of written documents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have had recourse to the original text, and to the most authentic and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approved works. I have cited my authorities in the notes, and anyone may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refer to them. Whenever an opinion, a political custom, or a remark on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manners of the country was concerned, I endeavored to consult the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most enlightened men I met with. If the point in question was important
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or doubtful, I was not satisfied with one testimony, but I formed my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion on the evidence of several witnesses. Here the reader must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessarily believe me upon my word. I could frequently have quoted names
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are either known to him, or which deserve to be so, in proof of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what I advance; but I have carefully abstained from this practice. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stranger frequently hears important truths at the fire-side of his host,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the latter would perhaps conceal from the ear of friendship;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he consoles himself with his guest for the silence to which he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restricted, and the shortness of the traveller's stay takes away all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fear of his indiscretion. I carefully noted every conversation of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature as soon as it occurred, but these notes will never leave my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: writing-case; I had rather injure the success of my statements than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: add my name to the list of those strangers who repay the generous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hospitality they have received by subsequent chagrin and annoyance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am aware that, notwithstanding my care, nothing will be easier than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to criticise this book, if anyone ever chooses to criticise it. Those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readers who may examine it closely will discover the fundamental idea
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which connects the several parts together. But the diversity of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjects I have had to treat is exceedingly great, and it will not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult to oppose an isolated fact to the body of facts which I quote,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or an isolated idea to the body of ideas I put forth. I hope to be read
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the spirit which has guided my labors, and that my book may be judged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the general impression it leaves, as I have formed my own judgment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not on any single reason, but upon the mass of evidence. It must not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forgotten that the author who wishes to be understood is obliged to push
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all his ideas to their utmost theoretical consequences, and often to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the verge of what is false or impracticable; for if it be necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
