text: sometimes to quit the rules of logic in active life, such is not the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case in discourse, and a man finds that almost as many difficulties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spring from inconsistency of language as usually arise from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconsistency of conduct.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I conclude by pointing out myself what many readers will consider
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principal defect of the work. This book is written to favor no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular views, and in composing it I have entertained no designs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of serving or attacking any party; I have undertaken not to see
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differently, but to look further than parties, and whilst they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: busied for the morrow I have turned my thoughts to the Future.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter I: Exterior Form Of North America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North America divided into two vast regions, one inclining towards the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Pole, the other towards the Equator--Valley of the Mississippi--Traces
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Revolutions of the Globe--Shore of the Atlantic Ocean where the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English Colonies were founded--Difference in the appearance of North
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of South America at the time of their Discovery--Forests of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North America--Prairies--Wandering Tribes of Natives--Their outward
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appearance, manners, and language--Traces of an unknown people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Exterior Form Of North America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North America presents in its external form certain general features
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it is easy to discriminate at the first glance. A sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: methodical order seems to have regulated the separation of land and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: water, mountains and valleys. A simple, but grand, arrangement is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discoverable amidst the confusion of objects and the prodigious variety
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of scenes. This continent is divided, almost equally, into two vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regions, one of which is bounded on the north by the Arctic Pole, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the two great oceans on the east and west. It stretches towards the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: south, forming a triangle whose irregular sides meet at length below
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great lakes of Canada. The second region begins where the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: terminates, and includes all the remainder of the continent. The one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slopes gently towards the Pole, the other towards the Equator.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The territory comprehended in the first region descends towards the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: north with so imperceptible a slope that it may almost be said to form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a level plain. Within the bounds of this immense tract of country there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are neither high mountains nor deep valleys. Streams meander through it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irregularly: great rivers mix their currents, separate and meet again,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disperse and form vast marshes, losing all trace of their channels
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the labyrinth of waters they have themselves created; and thus, at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: length, after innumerable windings, fall into the Polar Seas. The great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lakes which bound this first region are not walled in, like most of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those in the Old World, between hills and rocks. Their banks are flat,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and rise but a few feet above the level of their waters; each of them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus forming a vast bowl filled to the brim. The slightest change in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: structure of the globe would cause their waters to rush either towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Pole or to the tropical sea.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The second region is more varied on its surface, and better suited for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the habitation of man. Two long chains of mountains divide it from one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extreme to the other; the Alleghany ridge takes the form of the shores
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Atlantic Ocean; the other is parallel with the Pacific. The space
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which lies between these two chains of mountains contains 1,341,649
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: square miles. *a Its surface is therefore about six times as great as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of France. This vast territory, however, forms a single valley,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one side of which descends gradually from the rounded summits of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Alleghanies, while the other rises in an uninterrupted course towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tops of the Rocky Mountains. At the bottom of the valley flows an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense river, into which the various streams issuing from the mountains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fall from all parts. In memory of their native land, the French formerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called this river the St. Louis. The Indians, in their pompous language,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have named it the Father of Waters, or the Mississippi.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: Darby's "View of the United States."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Mississippi takes its source above the limit of the two great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regions of which I have spoken, not far from the highest point of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: table-land where they unite. Near the same spot rises another river, *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which empties itself into the Polar seas. The course of the Mississippi
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is at first dubious: it winds several times towards the north, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whence it rose; and at length, after having been delayed in lakes and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: marshes, it flows slowly onwards to the south. Sometimes quietly gliding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: along the argillaceous bed which nature has assigned to it, sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: swollen by storms, the Mississippi waters 2,500 miles in its course.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *c At the distance of 1,364 miles from its mouth this river attains an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: average depth of fifteen feet; and it is navigated by vessels of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 300 tons burden for a course of nearly 500 miles. Fifty-seven large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: navigable rivers contribute to swell the waters of the Mississippi;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst others, the Missouri, which traverses a space of 2,500 miles;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Arkansas of 1,300 miles, the Red River 1,000 miles, four whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course is from 800 to 1,000 miles in length, viz., the Illinois, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: St. Peter's, the St. Francis, and the Moingona; besides a countless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of rivulets which unite from all parts their tributary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: streams.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: The Red River.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: Warden's "Description of the United States."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The valley which is watered by the Mississippi seems formed to be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bed of this mighty river, which, like a god of antiquity, dispenses both
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good and evil in its course. On the shores of the stream nature displays
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an inexhaustible fertility; in proportion as you recede from its banks,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the powers of vegetation languish, the soil becomes poor, and the plants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that survive have a sickly growth. Nowhere have the great convulsions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the globe left more evident traces than in the valley of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mississippi; the whole aspect of the country shows the powerful effects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of water, both by its fertility and by its barrenness. The waters of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the primeval ocean accumulated enormous beds of vegetable mould in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: valley, which they levelled as they retired. Upon the right shore of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: river are seen immense plains, as smooth as if the husbandman had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passed over them with his roller. As you approach the mountains the soil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes more and more unequal and sterile; the ground is, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pierced in a thousand places by primitive rocks, which appear like the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bones of a skeleton whose flesh is partly consumed. The surface of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: earth is covered with a granite sand and huge irregular masses of stone,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: among which a few plants force their growth, and give the appearance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a green field covered with the ruins of a vast edifice. These stones and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this sand discover, on examination, a perfect analogy with those which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compose the arid and broken summits of the Rocky Mountains. The flood
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of waters which washed the soil to the bottom of the valley afterwards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carried away portions of the rocks themselves; and these, dashed and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bruised against the neighboring cliffs, were left scattered like wrecks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at their feet. *d The valley of the Mississippi is, upon the whole, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most magnificent dwelling-place prepared by God for man's abode; and yet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may be said that at present it is but a mighty desert.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: See Appendix, A.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the eastern side of the Alleghanies, between the base of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mountains and the Atlantic Ocean, there lies a long ridge of rocks and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sand, which the sea appears to have left behind as it retired. The mean
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: breadth of this territory does not exceed one hundred miles; but it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about nine hundred miles in length. This part of the American continent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has a soil which offers every obstacle to the husbandman, and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vegetation is scanty and unvaried.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Upon this inhospitable coast the first united efforts of human industry
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were made. The tongue of arid land was the cradle of those English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: colonies which were destined one day to become the United States of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America. The centre of power still remains here; whilst in the backwoods
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the true elements of the great people to whom the future control of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent belongs are gathering almost in secrecy together.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the Europeans first landed on the shores of the West Indies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and afterwards on the coast of South America, they thought themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transported into those fabulous regions of which poets had sung. The sea
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sparkled with phosphoric light, and the extraordinary transparency of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its waters discovered to the view of the navigator all that had hitherto
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been hidden in the deep abyss. *e Here and there appeared little islands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfumed with odoriferous plants, and resembling baskets of flowers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: floating on the tranquil surface of the ocean. Every object which met
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sight, in this enchanting region, seemed prepared to satisfy the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants or contribute to the pleasures of man. Almost all the trees were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: loaded with nourishing fruits, and those which were useless as food
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delighted the eye by the brilliancy and variety of their colors. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: groves of fragrant lemon-trees, wild figs, flowering myrtles, acacias,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and oleanders, which were hung with festoons of various climbing plants,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: covered with flowers, a multitude of birds unknown in Europe displayed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their bright plumage, glittering with purple and azure, and mingled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their warbling with the harmony of a world teeming with life and motion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *f Underneath this brilliant exterior death was concealed. But the air
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these climates had so enervating an influence that man, absorbed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present enjoyment, was rendered regardless of the future.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: Malte Brun tells us (vol. v. p. 726) that the water of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Caribbean Sea is so transparent that corals and fish are discernible at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a depth of sixty fathoms. The ship seemed to float in air, the navigator
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became giddy as his eye penetrated through the crystal flood, and beheld
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submarine gardens, or beds of shells, or gilded fishes gliding among
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tufts and thickets of seaweed.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: See Appendix, B.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North America appeared under a very different aspect; there everything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was grave, serious, and solemn: it seemed created to be the domain of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligence, as the South was that of sensual delight. A turbulent and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foggy ocean washed its shores. It was girt round by a belt of granite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rocks, or by wide tracts of sand. The foliage of its woods was dark and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gloomy, for they were composed of firs, larches, evergreen oaks, wild
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: olive-trees, and laurels. Beyond this outer belt lay the thick shades
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the central forest, where the largest trees which are produced in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the two hemispheres grow side by side. The plane, the catalpa, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sugar-maple, and the Virginian poplar mingled their branches with those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the oak, the beech, and the lime. In these, as in the forests of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Old World, destruction was perpetually going on. The ruins of vegetation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were heaped upon each other; but there was no laboring hand to remove
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them, and their decay was not rapid enough to make room for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continual work of reproduction. Climbing plants, grasses, and other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: herbs forced their way through the mass of dying trees; they crept along
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their bending trunks, found nourishment in their dusty cavities, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a passage beneath the lifeless bark. Thus decay gave its assistance to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life, and their respective productions were mingled together. The depths
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these forests were gloomy and obscure, and a thousand rivulets,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undirected in their course by human industry, preserved in them a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constant moisture. It was rare to meet with flowers, wild fruits, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: birds beneath their shades. The fall of a tree overthrown by age,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rushing torrent of a cataract, the lowing of the buffalo, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: howling of the wind were the only sounds which broke the silence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To the east of the great river, the woods almost disappeared; in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stead were seen prairies of immense extent. Whether Nature in her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infinite variety had denied the germs of trees to these fertile plains,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or whether they had once been covered with forests, subsequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destroyed by the hand of man, is a question which neither tradition nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scientific research has been able to resolve.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These immense deserts were not, however, devoid of human inhabitants.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Some wandering tribes had been for ages scattered among the forest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shades or the green pastures of the prairie. From the mouth of the St.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lawrence to the delta of the Mississippi, and from the Atlantic to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Pacific Ocean, these savages possessed certain points of resemblance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which bore witness of their common origin; but at the same time they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differed from all other known races of men: *g they were neither white
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like the Europeans, nor yellow like most of the Asiatics, nor black like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the negroes. Their skin was reddish brown, their hair long and shining,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their lips thin, and their cheekbones very prominent. The languages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spoken by the North American tribes are various as far as regarded their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words, but they were subject to the same grammatical rules. These rules
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differed in several points from such as had been observed to govern the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: origin of language. The idiom of the Americans seemed to be the product
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of new combinations, and bespoke an effort of the understanding of which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Indians of our days would be incapable. *h
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: With the progress of discovery some resemblance has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found to exist between the physical conformation, the language, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the habits of the Indians of North America, and those of the Tongous,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mantchous, Mongols, Tartars, and other wandering tribes of Asia. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: land occupied by these tribes is not very distant from Behring's Strait,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which allows of the supposition, that at a remote period they gave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants to the desert continent of America. But this is a point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has not yet been clearly elucidated by science. See Malte Brun,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vol. v.; the works of Humboldt; Fischer, "Conjecture sur l'Origine des
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americains"; Adair, "History of the American Indians."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: See Appendix, C.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The social state of these tribes differed also in many respects from all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that was seen in the Old World. They seemed to have multiplied freely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of their deserts without coming in contact with other races
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more civilized than their own. Accordingly, they exhibited none of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indistinct, incoherent notions of right and wrong, none of that deep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corruption of manners, which is usually joined with ignorance and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rudeness among nations which, after advancing to civilization, have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relapsed into a state of barbarism. The Indian was indebted to no one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but himself; his virtues, his vices, and his prejudices were his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: work; he had grown up in the wild independence of his nature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If, in polished countries, the lowest of the people are rude and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncivil, it is not merely because they are poor and ignorant, but that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being so, they are in daily contact with rich and enlightened men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The sight of their own hard lot and of their weakness, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: daily contrasted with the happiness and power of some of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-creatures, excites in their hearts at the same time the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sentiments of anger and of fear: the consciousness of their inferiority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of their dependence irritates while it humiliates them. This state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of mind displays itself in their manners and language; they are at once
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insolent and servile. The truth of this is easily proved by observation;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people are more rude in aristocratic countries than elsewhere, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opulent cities than in rural districts. In those places where the rich
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and powerful are assembled together the weak and the indigent feel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves oppressed by their inferior condition. Unable to perceive a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single chance of regaining their equality, they give up to despair, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allow themselves to fall below the dignity of human nature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This unfortunate effect of the disparity of conditions is not observable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in savage life: the Indians, although they are ignorant and poor, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal and free. At the period when Europeans first came among them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the natives of North America were ignorant of the value of riches, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indifferent to the enjoyments which civilized man procures to himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their means. Nevertheless there was nothing coarse in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demeanor; they practised an habitual reserve and a kind of aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politeness. Mild and hospitable when at peace, though merciless in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: war beyond any known degree of human ferocity, the Indian would expose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself to die of hunger in order to succor the stranger who asked
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admittance by night at the door of his hut; yet he could tear in pieces
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with his hands the still quivering limbs of his prisoner. The famous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republics of antiquity never gave examples of more unshaken courage,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more haughty spirits, or more intractable love of independence than were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hidden in former times among the wild forests of the New World. *i The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europeans produced no great impression when they landed upon the shores
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of North America; their presence engendered neither envy nor fear. What
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence could they possess over such men as we have described? The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indian could live without wants, suffer without complaint, and pour out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his death-song at the stake. *j Like all the other members of the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human family, these savages believed in the existence of a better world,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and adored under different names, God, the creator of the universe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Their notions on the great intellectual truths were in general simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and philosophical. *k
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: We learn from President Jefferson's "Notes upon Virginia,"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: p. 148, that among the Iroquois, when attacked by a superior force, aged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men refused to fly or to survive the destruction of their country; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they braved death like the ancient Romans when their capital was sacked
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Gauls. Further on, p. 150, he tells us that there is no example
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an Indian who, having fallen into the hands of his enemies, begged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for his life; on the contrary, the captive sought to obtain death at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands of his conquerors by the use of insult and provocation.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: See "Histoire de la Louisiane," by Lepage Dupratz;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Charlevoix, "Histoire de la Nouvelle France"; "Lettres du Rev. G.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hecwelder;" "Transactions of the American Philosophical Society," v. I;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jefferson's "Notes on Virginia," pp. 135-190. What is said by Jefferson
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is of especial weight, on account of the personal merit of the writer,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his peculiar position, and of the matter-of-fact age in which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lived.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: See Appendix, D.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although we have here traced the character of a primitive people, yet it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be doubted that another people, more civilized and more advanced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all respects, had preceded it in the same regions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An obscure tradition which prevailed among the Indians to the north of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Atlantic informs us that these very tribes formerly dwelt on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the west side of the Mississippi. Along the banks of the Ohio, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: throughout the central valley, there are frequently found, at this day,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tumuli raised by the hands of men. On exploring these heaps of earth to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their centre, it is usual to meet with human bones, strange instruments,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arms and utensils of all kinds, made of metal, or destined for purposes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unknown to the present race. The Indians of our time are unable to give
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any information relative to the history of this unknown people. Neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: did those who lived three hundred years ago, when America was first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discovered, leave any accounts from which even an hypothesis could be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed. Tradition--that perishable, yet ever renewed monument of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pristine world--throws no light upon the subject. It is an undoubted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact, however, that in this part of the globe thousands of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-beings had lived. When they came hither, what was their origin,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their destiny, their history, and how they perished, no one can tell.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: How strange does it appear that nations have existed, and afterwards so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely disappeared from the earth that the remembrance of their very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: names is effaced; their languages are lost; their glory is vanished like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a sound without an echo; though perhaps there is not one which has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: left behind it some tomb in memory of its passage! The most durable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monument of human labor is that which recalls the wretchedness and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothingness of man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although the vast country which we have been describing was inhabited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by many indigenous tribes, it may justly be said at the time of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discovery by Europeans to have formed one great desert. The Indians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occupied without possessing it. It is by agricultural labor that man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appropriates the soil, and the early inhabitants of North America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lived by the produce of the chase. Their implacable prejudices, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncontrolled passions, their vices, and still more perhaps their savage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtues, consigned them to inevitable destruction. The ruin of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations began from the day when Europeans landed on their shores; it has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceeded ever since, and we are now witnessing the completion of it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They seem to have been placed by Providence amidst the riches of the New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: World to enjoy them for a season, and then surrender them. Those coasts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so admirably adapted for commerce and industry; those wide and deep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rivers; that inexhaustible valley of the Mississippi; the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent, in short, seemed prepared to be the abode of a great nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet unborn.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In that land the great experiment was to be made, by civilized man, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the attempt to construct society upon a new basis; and it was there, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the first time, that theories hitherto unknown, or deemed impracticable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were to exhibit a spectacle for which the world had not been prepared by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the history of the past.

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Future Condition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: After the birth of a human being his early years are obscurely spent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the toils or pleasures of childhood. As he grows up the world receives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him, when his manhood begins, and he enters into contact with his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellows. He is then studied for the first time, and it is imagined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the germ of the vices and the virtues of his maturer years is then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed. This, if I am not mistaken, is a great error. We must begin
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: higher up; we must watch the infant in its mother's arms; we must see
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the first images which the external world casts upon the dark mirror
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his mind; the first occurrences which he witnesses; we must hear the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first words which awaken the sleeping powers of thought, and stand by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his earliest efforts, if we would understand the prejudices, the habits,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the passions which will rule his life. The entire man is, so to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speak, to be seen in the cradle of the child.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The growth of nations presents something analogous to this: they all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bear some marks of their origin; and the circumstances which accompanied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their birth and contributed to their rise affect the whole term of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being. If we were able to go back to the elements of states, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examine the oldest monuments of their history, I doubt not that we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should discover the primal cause of the prejudices, the habits, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ruling passions, and, in short, of all that constitutes what is called
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the national character; we should then find the explanation of certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customs which now seem at variance with the prevailing manners; of such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws as conflict with established principles; and of such incoherent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions as are here and there to be met with in society, like those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fragments of broken chains which we sometimes see hanging from the vault
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an edifice, and supporting nothing. This might explain the destinies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of certain nations, which seem borne on by an unknown force to ends of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they themselves are ignorant. But hitherto facts have been wanting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to researches of this kind: the spirit of inquiry has only come upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities in their latter days; and when they at length contemplated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their origin, time had already obscured it, or ignorance and pride
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adorned it with truth-concealing fables.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America is the only country in which it has been possible to witness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the natural and tranquil growth of society, and where the influences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercised on the future condition of states by their origin is clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguishable. At the period when the peoples of Europe landed in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New World their national characteristics were already completely formed;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each of them had a physiognomy of its own; and as they had already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attained that stage of civilization at which men are led to study
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, they have transmitted to us a faithful picture of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions, their manners, and their laws. The men of the sixteenth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: century are almost as well known to us as our contemporaries. America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently, exhibits in the broad light of day the phenomena which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorance or rudeness of earlier ages conceals from our researches.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Near enough to the time when the states of America were founded, to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accurately acquainted with their elements, and sufficiently removed from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that period to judge of some of their results, the men of our own day
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem destined to see further than their predecessors into the series of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human events. Providence has given us a torch which our forefathers did
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not possess, and has allowed us to discern fundamental causes in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: history of the world which the obscurity of the past concealed from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. If we carefully examine the social and political state of America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after having studied its history, we shall remain perfectly convinced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that not an opinion, not a custom, not a law, I may even say not an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: event, is upon record which the origin of that people will not explain.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The readers of this book will find the germ of all that is to follow in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present chapter, and the key to almost the whole work.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The emigrants who came, at different periods to occupy the territory now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: covered by the American Union differed from each other in many respects;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their aim was not the same, and they governed themselves on different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles. These men had, however, certain features in common, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they were all placed in an analogous situation. The tie of language is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps the strongest and the most durable that can unite mankind. All
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the emigrants spoke the same tongue; they were all offsets from the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. Born in a country which had been agitated for centuries by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggles of faction, and in which all parties had been obliged in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their turn to place themselves under the protection of the laws, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political education had been perfected in this rude school, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were more conversant with the notions of right and the principles of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true freedom than the greater part of their European contemporaries. At
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the period of their first emigrations the parish system, that fruitful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: germ of free institutions, was deeply rooted in the habits of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English; and with it the doctrine of the sovereignty of the people had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been introduced into the bosom of the monarchy of the House of Tudor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The religious quarrels which have agitated the Christian world were then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rife. England had plunged into the new order of things with headlong
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vehemence. The character of its inhabitants, which had always been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sedate and reflective, became argumentative and austere. General
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: information had been increased by intellectual debate, and the mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had received a deeper cultivation. Whilst religion was the topic of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discussion, the morals of the people were reformed. All these national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: features are more or less discoverable in the physiognomy of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adventurers who came to seek a new home on the opposite shores of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Atlantic.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Another remark, to which we shall hereafter have occasion to recur, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applicable not only to the English, but to the French, the Spaniards,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and all the Europeans who successively established themselves in the New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: World. All these European colonies contained the elements, if not the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: development, of a complete democracy. Two causes led to this result. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may safely be advanced, that on leaving the mother-country the emigrants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had in general no notion of superiority over one another. The happy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the powerful do not go into exile, and there are no surer guarantees of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality among men than poverty and misfortune. It happened, however,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on several occasions, that persons of rank were driven to America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by political and religious quarrels. Laws were made to establish a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradation of ranks; but it was soon found that the soil of America was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposed to a territorial aristocracy. To bring that refractory land into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivation, the constant and interested exertions of the owner himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were necessary; and when the ground was prepared, its produce was found
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be insufficient to enrich a master and a farmer at the same time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The land was then naturally broken up into small portions, which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proprietor cultivated for himself. Land is the basis of an aristocracy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which clings to the soil that supports it; for it is not by privileges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alone, nor by birth, but by landed property handed down from generation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to generation, that an aristocracy is constituted. A nation may present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense fortunes and extreme wretchedness, but unless those fortunes are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territorial there is no aristocracy, but simply the class of the rich
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that of the poor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the British colonies had then a great degree of similarity at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: epoch of their settlement. All of them, from their first beginning,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seemed destined to witness the growth, not of the aristocratic liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their mother-country, but of that freedom of the middle and lower
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orders of which the history of the world had as yet furnished no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complete example.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In this general uniformity several striking differences were however
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discernible, which it is necessary to point out. Two branches may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguished in the Anglo-American family, which have hitherto grown
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up without entirely commingling; the one in the South, the other in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Virginia received the first English colony; the emigrants took
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of it in 1607. The idea that mines of gold and silver are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sources of national wealth was at that time singularly prevalent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe; a fatal delusion, which has done more to impoverish the nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which adopted it, and has cost more lives in America, than the united
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of war and bad laws. The men sent to Virginia *a were seekers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of gold, adventurers, without resources and without character, whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turbulent and restless spirit endangered the infant colony, *b and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rendered its progress uncertain. The artisans and agriculturists arrived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afterwards; and, although they were a more moral and orderly race of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, they were in nowise above the level of the inferior classes in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England. *c No lofty conceptions, no intellectual system, directed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foundation of these new settlements. The colony was scarcely established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when slavery was introduced, *d and this was the main circumstance which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has exercised so prodigious an influence on the character, the laws, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the future prospects of the South. Slavery, as we shall afterwards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: show, dishonors labor; it introduces idleness into society, and with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idleness, ignorance and pride, luxury and distress. It enervates the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers of the mind, and benumbs the activity of man. The influence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery, united to the English character, explains the manners and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social condition of the Southern States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: The charter granted by the Crown of England in 1609
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stipulated, amongst other conditions, that the adventurers should pay
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the Crown a fifth of the produce of all gold and silver mines. See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Marshall's "Life of Washington," vol. i. pp. 18-66.] [Footnote b: A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large portion of the adventurers, says Stith ("History of Virginia"),
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were unprincipled young men of family, whom their parents were glad to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ship off, discharged servants, fraudulent bankrupts, or debauchees; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others of the same class, people more apt to pillage and destroy than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to assist the settlement, were the seditious chiefs, who easily led this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: band into every kind of extravagance and excess. See for the history of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Virginia the following works:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "History of Virginia, from the First Settlements in the year 1624," by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Smith.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "History of Virginia," by William Stith.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "History of Virginia, from the Earliest Period," by Beverley.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: It was not till some time later that a certain number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich English capitalists came to fix themselves in the colony.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: Slavery was introduced about the year 1620 by a Dutch
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vessel which landed twenty negroes on the banks of the river James. See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chalmer.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the North, the same English foundation was modified by the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposite shades of character; and here I may be allowed to enter into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some details. The two or three main ideas which constitute the basis
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the social theory of the United States were first combined in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Northern English colonies, more generally denominated the States of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New England. *e The principles of New England spread at first to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighboring states; they then passed successively to the more distant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ones; and at length they imbued the whole Confederation. They now extend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their influence beyond its limits over the whole American world. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization of New England has been like a beacon lit upon a hill,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which, after it has diffused its warmth around, tinges the distant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: horizon with its glow.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: The States of New England are those situated to the east of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Hudson; they are now six in number: 1, Connecticut; 2, Rhode Island;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 3, Massachusetts; 4, Vermont; 5, New Hampshire; 6, Maine.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The foundation of New England was a novel spectacle, and all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances attending it were singular and original. The large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority of colonies have been first inhabited either by men without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: education and without resources, driven by their poverty and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misconduct from the land which gave them birth, or by speculators
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and adventurers greedy of gain. Some settlements cannot even boast so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honorable an origin; St. Domingo was founded by buccaneers; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: criminal courts of England originally supplied the population of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Australia.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The settlers who established themselves on the shores of New England all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belonged to the more independent classes of their native country. Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: union on the soil of America at once presented the singular phenomenon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a society containing neither lords nor common people, neither rich
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor poor. These men possessed, in proportion to their number, a greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mass of intelligence than is to be found in any European nation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our own time. All, without a single exception, had received a good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: education, and many of them were known in Europe for their talents and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their acquirements. The other colonies had been founded by adventurers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without family; the emigrants of New England brought with them the best
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elements of order and morality--they landed in the desert accompanied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their wives and children. But what most especially distinguished them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was the aim of their undertaking. They had not been obliged by necessity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to leave their country; the social position they abandoned was one to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be regretted, and their means of subsistence were certain. Nor did
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they cross the Atlantic to improve their situation or to increase their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth; the call which summoned them from the comforts of their homes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was purely intellectual; and in facing the inevitable sufferings of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exile their object was the triumph of an idea.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The emigrants, or, as they deservedly styled themselves, the Pilgrims,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belonged to that English sect the austerity of whose principles had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquired for them the name of Puritans. Puritanism was not merely a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious doctrine, but it corresponded in many points with the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absolute democratic and republican theories. It was this tendency which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had aroused its most dangerous adversaries. Persecuted by the Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the mother-country, and disgusted by the habits of a society opposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the rigor of their own principles, the Puritans went forth to seek
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some rude and unfrequented part of the world, where they could live
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: according to their own opinions, and worship God in freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A few quotations will throw more light upon the spirit of these pious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adventures than all we can say of them. Nathaniel Morton, *f the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: historian of the first years of the settlement, thus opens his subject:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: "New England's Memorial," p. 13; Boston, 1826. See also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Hutchinson's History," vol. ii. p. 440.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Gentle Reader,--I have for some length of time looked upon it as a duty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incumbent, especially on the immediate successors of those that have had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so large experience of those many memorable and signal demonstrations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of God's goodness, viz., the first beginners of this Plantation in New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England, to commit to writing his gracious dispensations on that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: behalf; having so many inducements thereunto, not onely otherwise but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so plentifully in the Sacred Scriptures: that so, what we have seen,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and what our fathers have told us (Psalm lxxviii. 3, 4), we may not hide
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from our children, showing to the generations to come the praises of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lord; that especially the seed of Abraham his servant, and the children
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Jacob his chosen (Psalm cv. 5, 6), may remember his marvellous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: works in the beginning and progress of the planting of New England, his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wonders and the judgments of his mouth; how that God brought a vine into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this wilderness; that he cast out the heathen, and planted it; that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made room for it and caused it to take deep root; and it filled the land
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (Psalm lxxx. 8, 9). And not onely so, but also that he hath guided his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people by his strength to his holy habitation and planted them in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mountain of his inheritance in respect of precious Gospel enjoyments:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that as especially God may have the glory of all unto whom it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is most due; so also some rays of glory may reach the names of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blessed Saints that were the main instruments and the beginning of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happy enterprise."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is impossible to read this opening paragraph without an involuntary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feeling of religious awe; it breathes the very savor of Gospel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: antiquity. The sincerity of the author heightens his power of language.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The band which to his eyes was a mere party of adventurers gone forth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to seek their fortune beyond seas appears to the reader as the germ of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great nation wafted by Providence to a predestined shore.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The author thus continues his narrative of the departure of the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pilgrims:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "So they left that goodly and pleasant city of Leyden, *g which had been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their resting-place for above eleven years; but they knew that they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pilgrims and strangers here below, and looked not much on these things,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but lifted up their eyes to Heaven, their dearest country, where God
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hath prepared for them a city (Heb. xi. 16), and therein quieted their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirits. When they came to Delfs-Haven they found the ship and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things ready; and such of their friends as could not come with them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: followed after them, and sundry came from Amsterdam to see them shipt,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to take their leaves of them. One night was spent with little sleep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the most, but with friendly entertainment and Christian discourse,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and other real expressions of true Christian love. The next day they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: went on board, and their friends with them, where truly doleful was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sight of that sad and mournful parting, to hear what sighs and sobs and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prayers did sound amongst them; what tears did gush from every eye,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and pithy speeches pierced each other's heart, that sundry of the Dutch
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strangers that stood on the Key as spectators could not refrain from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tears. But the tide (which stays for no man) calling them away, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were thus loth to depart, their Reverend Pastor falling down on his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knees, and they all with him, with watery cheeks commended them with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most fervent prayers unto the Lord and his blessing; and then, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mutual embraces and many tears they took their leaves one of another,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which proved to be the last leave to many of them."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: The emigrants were, for the most part, godly Christians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the North of England, who had quitted their native country because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they were "studious of reformation, and entered into covenant to walk
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with one another according to the primitive pattern of the Word of God."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They emigrated to Holland, and settled in the city of Leyden in 1610,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where they abode, being lovingly respected by the Dutch, for many years:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they left it in 1620 for several reasons, the last of which was, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their posterity would in a few generations become Dutch, and so lose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their interest in the English nation; they being desirous rather
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to enlarge His Majesty's dominions, and to live under their natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prince.--Translator's Note.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The emigrants were about 150 in number, including the women and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: children. Their object was to plant a colony on the shores of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hudson; but after having been driven about for some time in the Atlantic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ocean, they were forced to land on that arid coast of New England which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is now the site of the town of Plymouth. The rock is still shown on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the pilgrims disembarked. *h
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: This rock is become an object of veneration in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. I have seen bits of it carefully preserved in several towns of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union. Does not this sufficiently show how entirely all human power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and greatness is in the soul of man? Here is a stone which the feet of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a few outcasts pressed for an instant, and this stone becomes famous; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is treasured by a great nation, its very dust is shared as a relic: and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what is become of the gateways of a thousand palaces?]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "But before we pass on," continues our historian, "let the reader
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with me make a pause and seriously consider this poor people's present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition, the more to be raised up to admiration of God's goodness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: towards them in their preservation: for being now passed the vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ocean, and a sea of troubles before them in expectation, they had now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no friends to welcome them, no inns to entertain or refresh them, no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: houses, or much less towns to repair unto to seek for succour: and for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the season it was winter, and they that know the winters of the country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know them to be sharp and violent, subject to cruel and fierce storms,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous to travel to known places, much more to search unknown coasts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Besides, what could they see but a hideous and desolate wilderness, full
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of wilde beasts, and wilde men? and what multitudes of them there were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they then knew not: for which way soever they turned their eyes (save
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upward to Heaven) they could have but little solace or content in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect of any outward object; for summer being ended, all things stand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in appearance with a weather-beaten face, and the whole country full of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: woods and thickets, represented a wild and savage hew; if they looked
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: behind them, there was the mighty ocean which they had passed, and was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: now as a main bar or gulph to separate them from all the civil parts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must not be imagined that the piety of the Puritans was of a merely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speculative kind, or that it took no cognizance of the course of worldly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs. Puritanism, as I have already remarked, was scarcely less a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political than a religious doctrine. No sooner had the emigrants landed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the barren coast described by Nathaniel Morton than it was their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first care to constitute a society, by passing the following Act:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "In the name of God. Amen. We, whose names are underwritten, the loyal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjects of our dread Sovereign Lord King James, etc., etc., Having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertaken for the glory of God, and advancement of the Christian Faith,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the honour of our King and country, a voyage to plant the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: colony in the northern parts of Virginia; Do by these presents solemnly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and mutually, in the presence of God and one another, covenant and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combine ourselves together into a civil body politick, for our better
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordering and preservation, and furtherance of the ends aforesaid: and by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtue hereof do enact, constitute and frame such just and equal laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinances, acts, constitutions, and officers, from time to time, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall be thought most meet and convenient for the general good of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Colony: unto which we promise all due submission and obedience," etc. *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: The emigrants who founded the State of Rhode Island in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1638, those who landed at New Haven in 1637, the first settlers in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Connecticut in 1639, and the founders of Providence in 1640, began in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like manner by drawing up a social contract, which was acceded to by all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the interested parties. See "Pitkin's History," pp. 42 and 47.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This happened in 1620, and from that time forwards the emigration went
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on. The religious and political passions which ravaged the British
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Empire during the whole reign of Charles I drove fresh crowds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sectarians every year to the shores of America. In England the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stronghold of Puritanism was in the middle classes, and it was from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: middle classes that the majority of the emigrants came. The population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of New England increased rapidly; and whilst the hierarchy of rank
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotically classed the inhabitants of the mother-country, the colony
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continued to present the novel spectacle of a community homogeneous in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all its parts. A democracy, more perfect than any which antiquity had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dreamt of, started in full size and panoply from the midst of an ancient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feudal society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter II: Origin Of The Anglo-Americans--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The English Government was not dissatisfied with an emigration which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removed the elements of fresh discord and of further revolutions. On the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, everything was done to encourage it, and great exertions were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made to mitigate the hardships of those who sought a shelter from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rigor of their country's laws on the soil of America. It seemed as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if New England was a region given up to the dreams of fancy and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unrestrained experiments of innovators.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The English colonies (and this is one of the main causes of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity) have always enjoyed more internal freedom and more political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence than the colonies of other nations; but this principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty was nowhere more extensively applied than in the States of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It was generally allowed at that period that the territories of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New World belonged to that European nation which had been the first to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discover them. Nearly the whole coast of North America thus became a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: British possession towards the end of the sixteenth century. The means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: used by the English Government to people these new domains were of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several kinds; the King sometimes appointed a governor of his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choice, who ruled a portion of the New World in the name and under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediate orders of the Crown; *j this is the colonial system adopted by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other countries of Europe. Sometimes grants of certain tracts were made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Crown to an individual or to a company, *k in which case all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil and political power fell into the hands of one or more persons,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who, under the inspection and control of the Crown, sold the lands and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed the inhabitants. Lastly, a third system consisted in allowing a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain number of emigrants to constitute a political society under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protection of the mother-country, and to govern themselves in whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not contrary to her laws. This mode of colonization, so remarkably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to liberty, was only adopted in New England. *l
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: This was the case in the State of New York.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: Maryland, the Carolinas, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this situation. See "Pitkin's History," vol. i. pp. 11-31.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: See the work entitled "Historical Collection of State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Papers and other authentic Documents intended as materials for a History
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States of America, by Ebenezer Hasard. Philadelphia,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1792," for a great number of documents relating to the commencement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the colonies, which are valuable from their contents and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authenticity: amongst them are the various charters granted by the King
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of England, and the first acts of the local governments.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See also the analysis of all these charters given by Mr. Story, Judge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Supreme Court of the United States, in the Introduction to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Commentary on the Constitution of the United States." It results from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these documents that the principles of representative government and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the external forms of political liberty were introduced into all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: colonies at their origin. These principles were more fully acted upon in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the North than in the South, but they existed everywhere.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1628 *m a charter of this kind was granted by Charles I to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emigrants who went to form the colony of Massachusetts. But, in general,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: charters were not given to the colonies of New England till they had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquired a certain existence. Plymouth, Providence, New Haven, the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Connecticut, and that of Rhode Island *n were founded without the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operation and almost without the knowledge of the mother-country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The new settlers did not derive their incorporation from the seat of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the empire, although they did not deny its supremacy; they constituted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a society of their own accord, and it was not till thirty or forty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years afterwards, under Charles II. that their existence was legally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recognized by a royal charter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: See "Pitkin's History," p, 35. See the "History of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Colony of Massachusetts Bay," by Hutchinson, vol. i. p. 9.] [Footnote n:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See "Pitkin's History," pp. 42, 47.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This frequently renders its it difficult to detect the link which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connected the emigrants with the land of their forefathers in studying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the earliest historical and legislative records of New England. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercised the rights of sovereignty; they named their magistrates,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concluded peace or declared war, made police regulations, and enacted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws as if their allegiance was due only to God. *o Nothing can be more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curious and, at the same time more instructive, than the legislation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that period; it is there that the solution of the great social problem
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the United States now present to the world is to be found.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: The inhabitants of Massachusetts had deviated from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forms which are preserved in the criminal and civil procedure of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England; in 1650 the decrees of justice were not yet headed by the royal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: style. See Hutchinson, vol. i. p. 452.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst these documents we shall notice, as especially characteristic,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the code of laws promulgated by the little State of Connecticut in 1650.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *p The legislators of Connecticut *q begin with the penal laws, and,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strange to say, they borrow their provisions from the text of Holy Writ.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Whosoever shall worship any other God than the Lord," says the preamble
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Code, "shall surely be put to death." This is followed by ten or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: twelve enactments of the same kind, copied verbatim from the books of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Exodus, Leviticus, and Deuteronomy. Blasphemy, sorcery, adultery, *r
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and rape were punished with death; an outrage offered by a son to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parents was to be expiated by the same penalty. The legislation of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rude and half-civilized people was thus applied to an enlightened and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral community. The consequence was that the punishment of death was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never more frequently prescribed by the statute, and never more rarely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enforced towards the guilty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: Code of 1650, p. 28; Hartford, 1830.]
