author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: See also in "Hutchinson's History," vol. i. pp. 435,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 456, the analysis of the penal code adopted in 1648 by the Colony of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts: this code is drawn up on the same principles as that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Connecticut.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: Adultery was also punished with death by the law of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts: and Hutchinson, vol. i. p. 441, says that several persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actually suffered for this crime. He quotes a curious anecdote on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this subject, which occurred in the year 1663. A married woman had had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: criminal intercourse with a young man; her husband died, and she married
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the lover. Several years had elapsed, when the public began to suspect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the previous intercourse of this couple: they were thrown into prison,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: put upon trial, and very narrowly escaped capital punishment.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The chief care of the legislators, in this body of penal laws, was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of orderly conduct and good morals in the community: they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly invaded the domain of conscience, and there was scarcely a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sin which was not subject to magisterial censure. The reader is aware of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rigor with which these laws punished rape and adultery; intercourse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between unmarried persons was likewise severely repressed. The judge was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empowered to inflict a pecuniary penalty, a whipping, or marriage *s on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the misdemeanants; and if the records of the old courts of New Haven may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be believed, prosecutions of this kind were not unfrequent. We find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a sentence bearing date the first of May, 1660, inflicting a fine and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reprimand on a young woman who was accused of using improper language,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of allowing herself to be kissed. *t The Code of 1650 abounds in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preventive measures. It punishes idleness and drunkenness with severity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *u Innkeepers are forbidden to furnish more than a certain quantity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liquor to each consumer; and simple lying, whenever it may be injurious,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *v is checked by a fine or a flogging. In other places, the legislator,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely forgetting the great principles of religious toleration which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he had himself upheld in Europe, renders attendance on divine service
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compulsory, *w and goes so far as to visit with severe punishment, **
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and even with death, the Christians who chose to worship God according
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a ritual differing from his own. *x Sometimes indeed the zeal of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enactments induces him to descend to the most frivolous particulars:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus a law is to be found in the same Code which prohibits the use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of tobacco. *y It must not be forgotten that these fantastical and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vexatious laws were not imposed by authority, but that they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freely voted by all the persons interested, and that the manners of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community were even more austere and more puritanical than the laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1649 a solemn association was formed in Boston to check the worldly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: luxury of long hair. *z
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote s: Code of 1650, p. 48. It seems sometimes to have happened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the judges superadded these punishments to each other, as is seen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a sentence pronounced in 1643 (p. 114, "New Haven Antiquities"), by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which Margaret Bedford, convicted of loose conduct, was condemned to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whipped, and afterwards to marry Nicholas Jemmings, her accomplice.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote t: "New Haven Antiquities," p. 104. See also "Hutchinson's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: History," for several causes equally extraordinary.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote u: Code of 1650, pp. 50, 57.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote v: Ibid., p. 64.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote w: Ibid., p. 44.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote *: This was not peculiar to Connecticut. See, for instance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the law which, on September 13, 1644, banished the Anabaptists from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State of Massachusetts. ("Historical Collection of State Papers," vol.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: i. p. 538.) See also the law against the Quakers, passed on October 14,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1656: "Whereas," says the preamble, "an accursed race of heretics called
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Quakers has sprung up," etc. The clauses of the statute inflict a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heavy fine on all captains of ships who should import Quakers into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country. The Quakers who may be found there shall be whipped and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imprisoned with hard labor. Those members of the sect who should defend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their opinions shall be first fined, then imprisoned, and finally driven
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out of the province.--"Historical Collection of State Papers," vol. i.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote x: By the penal law of Massachusetts, any Catholic priest who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should set foot in the colony after having been once driven out of it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was liable to capital punishment.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote y: Code of 1650, p. 96.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote z: "New England's Memorial," p. 316. See Appendix, E.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These errors are no doubt discreditable to human reason; they attest the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferiority of our nature, which is incapable of laying firm hold upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what is true and just, and is often reduced to the alternative of two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excesses. In strict connection with this penal legislation, which bears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such striking marks of a narrow sectarian spirit, and of those religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions which had been warmed by persecution and were still fermenting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: among the people, a body of political laws is to be found, which, though
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: written two hundred years ago, is still ahead of the liberties of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our age. The general principles which are the groundwork of modern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitutions--principles which were imperfectly known in Europe, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not completely triumphant even in Great Britain, in the seventeenth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: century--were all recognized and determined by the laws of New England:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the intervention of the people in public affairs, the free voting of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taxes, the responsibility of authorities, personal liberty, and trial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by jury, were all positively established without discussion. From these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fruitful principles consequences have been derived and applications have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been made such as no nation in Europe has yet ventured to attempt.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Connecticut the electoral body consisted, from its origin, of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole number of citizens; and this is readily to be understood, *a when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we recollect that this people enjoyed an almost perfect equality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune, and a still greater uniformity of opinions. *b In Connecticut,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at this period, all the executive functionaries were elected, including
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Governor of the State. *c The citizens above the age of sixteen were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to bear arms; they formed a national militia, which appointed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its own officers, and was to hold itself at all times in readiness to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: march for the defence of the country. *d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: Constitution of 1638, p. 17.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: In 1641 the General Assembly of Rhode Island unanimously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declared that the government of the State was a democracy, and that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power was vested in the body of free citizens, who alone had the right
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to make the laws and to watch their execution.--Code of 1650, p. 70.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: "Pitkin's History," p. 47.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: Constitution of 1638, p. 12.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the laws of Connecticut, as well as in all those of New England,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we find the germ and gradual development of that township independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is the life and mainspring of American liberty at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day. The political existence of the majority of the nations of Europe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commenced in the superior ranks of society, and was gradually and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperfectly communicated to the different members of the social body.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America, on the other hand, it may be said that the township was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: organized before the county, the county before the State, the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before the Union. In New England townships were completely and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: definitively constituted as early as 1650. The independence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township was the nucleus round which the local interests, passions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights, and duties collected and clung. It gave scope to the activity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a real political life most thoroughly democratic and republican. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: colonies still recognized the supremacy of the mother-country; monarchy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was still the law of the State; but the republic was already established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in every township. The towns named their own magistrates of every kind,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rated themselves, and levied their own taxes. *e In the parish of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England the law of representation was not adopted, but the affairs of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community were discussed, as at Athens, in the market-place, by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general assembly of the citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: Code of 1650, p. 80.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In studying the laws which were promulgated at this first era of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American republics, it is impossible not to be struck by the remarkable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquaintance with the science of government and the advanced theory of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation which they display. The ideas there formed of the duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society towards its members are evidently much loftier and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comprehensive than those of the European legislators at that time:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obligations were there imposed which were elsewhere slighted. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States of New England, from the first, the condition of the poor was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provided for; *f strict measures were taken for the maintenance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: roads, and surveyors were appointed to attend to them; *g registers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were established in every parish, in which the results of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deliberations, and the births, deaths, and marriages of the citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were entered; *h clerks were directed to keep these registers; *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers were charged with the administration of vacant inheritances,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and with the arbitration of litigated landmarks; and many others were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: created whose chief functions were the maintenance of public order in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community. *j The law enters into a thousand useful provisions for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a number of social wants which are at present very inadequately felt in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France. [Footnote f: Ibid., p. 78.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: Ibid., p. 49.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: See "Hutchinson's History," vol. i. p. 455.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: Code of 1650, p. 86.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: Ibid., p. 40.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But it is by the attention it pays to Public Education that the original
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character of American civilization is at once placed in the clearest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: light. "It being," says the law, "one chief project of Satan to keep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men from the knowledge of the Scripture by persuading from the use of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tongues, to the end that learning may not be buried in the graves of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our forefathers, in church and commonwealth, the Lord assisting our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavors. . . ." *k Here follow clauses establishing schools in every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township, and obliging the inhabitants, under pain of heavy fines, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: support them. Schools of a superior kind were founded in the same manner
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the more populous districts. The municipal authorities were bound to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enforce the sending of children to school by their parents; they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empowered to inflict fines upon all who refused compliance; and in case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of continued resistance society assumed the place of the parent, took
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of the child, and deprived the father of those natural rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which he used to so bad a purpose. The reader will undoubtedly have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarked the preamble of these enactments: in America religion is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: road to knowledge, and the observance of the divine laws leads man to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: Ibid., p. 90.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If, after having cast a rapid glance over the state of American society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in 1650, we turn to the condition of Europe, and more especially to that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Continent, at the same period, we cannot fail to be struck
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with astonishment. On the Continent of Europe, at the beginning of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seventeenth century, absolute monarchy had everywhere triumphed over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ruins of the oligarchical and feudal liberties of the Middle Ages. Never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were the notions of right more completely confounded than in the midst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the splendor and literature of Europe; never was there less political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: activity among the people; never were the principles of true freedom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less widely circulated; and at that very time those principles, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were scorned or unknown by the nations of Europe, were proclaimed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the deserts of the New World, and were accepted as the future creed of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great people. The boldest theories of the human reason were put into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practice by a community so humble that not a statesman condescended to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attend to it; and a legislation without a precedent was produced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offhand by the imagination of the citizens. In the bosom of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obscure democracy, which had as yet brought forth neither generals, nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophers, nor authors, a man might stand up in the face of a free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people and pronounce the following fine definition of liberty. *l
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: Mather's "Magnalia Christi Americana," vol. ii. p. 13.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This speech was made by Winthrop; he was accused of having committed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arbitrary actions during his magistracy, but after having made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the speech of which the above is a fragment, he was acquitted by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acclamation, and from that time forwards he was always re-elected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governor of the State. See Marshal, vol. i. p. 166.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Nor would I have you to mistake in the point of your own liberty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is a liberty of a corrupt nature which is effected both by men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and beasts to do what they list, and this liberty is inconsistent with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, impatient of all restraint; by this liberty 'sumus omnes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deteriores': 'tis the grand enemy of truth and peace, and all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinances of God are bent against it. But there is a civil, a moral, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal liberty which is the proper end and object of authority; it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a liberty for that only which is just and good: for this liberty you are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to stand with the hazard of your very lives and whatsoever crosses it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not authority, but a distemper thereof. This liberty is maintained in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: way of subjection to authority; and the authority set over you will, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all administrations for your good, be quietly submitted unto by all but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such as have a disposition to shake off the yoke and lose their true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty, by their murmuring at the honor and power of authority."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The remarks I have made will suffice to display the character of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-American civilization in its true light. It is the result (and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this should be constantly present to the mind of two distinct elements),
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which in other places have been in frequent hostility, but which in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America have been admirably incorporated and combined with one another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I allude to the spirit of Religion and the spirit of Liberty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The settlers of New England were at the same time ardent sectarians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and daring innovators. Narrow as the limits of some of their religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions were, they were entirely free from political prejudices. Hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arose two tendencies, distinct but not opposite, which are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discernible in the manners as well as in the laws of the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It might be imagined that men who sacrificed their friends, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: family, and their native land to a religious conviction were absorbed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the pursuit of the intellectual advantages which they purchased at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so dear a rate. The energy, however, with which they strove for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquirement of wealth, moral enjoyment, and the comforts as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties of the world, is scarcely inferior to that with which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: devoted themselves to Heaven.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Political principles and all human laws and institutions were moulded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and altered at their pleasure; the barriers of the society in which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were born were broken down before them; the old principles which had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed the world for ages were no more; a path without a turn and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a field without an horizon were opened to the exploring and ardent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curiosity of man: but at the limits of the political world he checks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his researches, he discreetly lays aside the use of his most formidable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faculties, he no longer consents to doubt or to innovate, but carefully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abstaining from raising the curtain of the sanctuary, he yields with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submissive respect to truths which he will not discuss. Thus, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral world everything is classed, adapted, decided, and foreseen; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the political world everything is agitated, uncertain, and disputed:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the one is a passive, though a voluntary, obedience; in the other an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence scornful of experience and jealous of authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These two tendencies, apparently so discrepant, are far from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conflicting; they advance together, and mutually support each other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Religion perceives that civil liberty affords a noble exercise to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faculties of man, and that the political world is a field prepared by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Creator for the efforts of the intelligence. Contented with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom and the power which it enjoys in its own sphere, and with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place which it occupies, the empire of religion is never more surely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established than when it reigns in the hearts of men unsupported by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aught beside its native strength. Religion is no less the companion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty in all its battles and its triumphs; the cradle of its infancy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the divine source of its claims. The safeguard of morality is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion, and morality is the best security of law and the surest pledge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of freedom. *m
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: See Appendix, F.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Reasons Of Certain Anomalies Which The Laws And Customs Of The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans Present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Remains of aristocratic institutions in the midst of a complete
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy--Why?--Distinction carefully to be drawn between what is of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Puritanical and what is of English origin.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The reader is cautioned not to draw too general or too absolute an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inference from what has been said. The social condition, the religion,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the manners of the first emigrants undoubtedly exercised an immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence on the destiny of their new country. Nevertheless they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not in a situation to found a state of things solely dependent on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves: no man can entirely shake off the influence of the past, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the settlers, intentionally or involuntarily, mingled habits and notions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derived from their education and from the traditions of their country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with those habits and notions which were exclusively their own. To form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a judgment on the Anglo-Americans of the present day it is therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary to distinguish what is of Puritanical and what is of English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: origin.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Laws and customs are frequently to be met with in the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which contrast strongly with all that surrounds them. These laws seem to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be drawn up in a spirit contrary to the prevailing tenor of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation; and these customs are no less opposed to the tone of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society. If the English colonies had been founded in an age of darkness,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or if their origin was already lost in the lapse of years, the problem
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be insoluble.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall quote a single example to illustrate what I advance. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil and criminal procedure of the Americans has only two means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action--committal and bail. The first measure taken by the magistrate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to exact security from the defendant, or, in case of refusal, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incarcerate him: the ground of the accusation and the importance of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: charges against him are then discussed. It is evident that a legislation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this kind is hostile to the poor man, and favorable only to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich. The poor man has not always a security to produce, even in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil cause; and if he is obliged to wait for justice in prison, he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speedily reduced to distress. The wealthy individual, on the contrary,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always escapes imprisonment in civil causes; nay, more, he may readily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elude the punishment which awaits him for a delinquency by breaking his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bail. So that all the penalties of the law are, for him, reducible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to fines. *n Nothing can be more aristocratic than this system of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation. Yet in America it is the poor who make the law, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usually reserve the greatest social advantages to themselves. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explanation of the phenomenon is to be found in England; the laws of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I speak are English, *o and the Americans have retained them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however repugnant they may be to the tenor of their legislation and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mass of their ideas. Next to its habits, the thing which a nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is least apt to change is its civil legislation. Civil laws are only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: familiarly known to legal men, whose direct interest it is to maintain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them as they are, whether good or bad, simply because they themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are conversant with them. The body of the nation is scarcely acquainted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with them; it merely perceives their action in particular cases; but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has some difficulty in seizing their tendency, and obeys them without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: premeditation. I have quoted one instance where it would have been easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to adduce a great number of others. The surface of American society is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if I may use the expression, covered with a layer of democracy, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beneath which the old aristocratic colors sometimes peep.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: Crimes no doubt exist for which bail is inadmissible, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are few in number.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: See Blackstone; and Delolme, book I chap. x.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter III: Social Conditions Of The Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A Social condition is commonly the result of circumstances, sometimes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws, oftener still of these two causes united; but wherever it exists,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may justly be considered as the source of almost all the laws, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usages, and the ideas which regulate the conduct of nations; whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it does not produce it modifies. It is therefore necessary, if we would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become acquainted with the legislation and the manners of a nation, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: begin by the study of its social condition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Striking Characteristic Of The Social Condition Of The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans In Its Essential Democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first emigrants of New England--Their equality--Aristocratic laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced in the South--Period of the Revolution--Change in the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of descent--Effects produced by this change--Democracy carried to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: utmost limits in the new States of the West--Equality of education.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Many important observations suggest themselves upon the social condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Anglo-Americans, but there is one which takes precedence of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rest. The social condition of the Americans is eminently democratic;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this was its character at the foundation of the Colonies, and is still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more strongly marked at the present day. I have stated in the preceding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chapter that great equality existed among the emigrants who settled on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the shores of New England. The germ of aristocracy was never planted in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that part of the Union. The only influence which obtained there was that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of intellect; the people were used to reverence certain names as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emblems of knowledge and virtue. Some of their fellow-citizens acquired
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a power over the rest which might truly have been called aristocratic,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if it had been capable of transmission from father to son.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This was the state of things to the east of the Hudson: to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: south-west of that river, and in the direction of the Floridas, the case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was different. In most of the States situated to the south-west of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hudson some great English proprietors had settled, who had imported
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with them aristocratic principles and the English law of descent. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explained the reasons why it was impossible ever to establish a powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy in America; these reasons existed with less force to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: south-west of the Hudson. In the South, one man, aided by slaves, could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivate a great extent of country: it was therefore common to see rich
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: landed proprietors. But their influence was not altogether aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as that term is understood in Europe, since they possessed no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges; and the cultivation of their estates being carried on by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slaves, they had no tenants depending on them, and consequently no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patronage. Still, the great proprietors south of the Hudson constituted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a superior class, having ideas and tastes of its own, and forming the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centre of political action. This kind of aristocracy sympathized with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the body of the people, whose passions and interests it easily embraced;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it was too weak and too short-lived to excite either love or hatred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for itself. This was the class which headed the insurrection in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South, and furnished the best leaders of the American revolution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the period of which we are now speaking society was shaken to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its centre: the people, in whose name the struggle had taken place,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceived the desire of exercising the authority which it had acquired;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its democratic tendencies were awakened; and having thrown off the yoke
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the mother-country, it aspired to independence of every kind. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of individuals gradually ceased to be felt, and custom and law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: united together to produce the same result.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the law of descent was the last step to equality. I am surprised
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that ancient and modern jurists have not attributed to this law a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater influence on human affairs. *a It is true that these laws belong
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to civil affairs; but they ought nevertheless to be placed at the head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all political institutions; for, whilst political laws are only the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: symbol of a nation's condition, they exercise an incredible influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon its social state. They have, moreover, a sure and uniform manner of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: operating upon society, affecting, as it were, generations yet unborn.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: I understand by the law of descent all those laws whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal object is to regulate the distribution of property after the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: death of its owner. The law of entail is of this number; it certainly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevents the owner from disposing of his possessions before his death;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but this is solely with the view of preserving them entire for the heir.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principal object, therefore, of the law of entail is to regulate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descent of property after the death of its owner: its other provisions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are merely means to this end.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Through their means man acquires a kind of preternatural power over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future lot of his fellow-creatures. When the legislator has regulated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the law of inheritance, he may rest from his labor. The machine once put
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in motion will go on for ages, and advance, as if self-guided, towards a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: given point. When framed in a particular manner, this law unites, draws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together, and vests property and power in a few hands: its tendency is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clearly aristocratic. On opposite principles its action is still more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapid; it divides, distributes, and disperses both property and power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Alarmed by the rapidity of its progress, those who despair of arresting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its motion endeavor to obstruct it by difficulties and impediments;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they vainly seek to counteract its effect by contrary efforts; but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually reduces or destroys every obstacle, until by its incessant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: activity the bulwarks of the influence of wealth are ground down to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fine and shifting sand which is the basis of democracy. When the law of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inheritance permits, still more when it decrees, the equal division of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a father's property amongst all his children, its effects are of two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kinds: it is important to distinguish them from each other, although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they tend to the same end.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In virtue of the law of partible inheritance, the death of every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proprietor brings about a kind of revolution in property; not only do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his possessions change hands, but their very nature is altered, since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are parcelled into shares, which become smaller and smaller at each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: division. This is the direct and, as it were, the physical effect of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law. It follows, then, that in countries where equality of inheritance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is established by law, property, and especially landed property, must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have a tendency to perpetual diminution. The effects, however, of such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation would only be perceptible after a lapse of time, if the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was abandoned to its own working; for supposing the family to consist of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two children (and in a country people as France is the average number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not above three), these children, sharing amongst them the fortune of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: both parents, would not be poorer than their father or mother.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the law of equal division exercises its influence not merely upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the property itself, but it affects the minds of the heirs, and brings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their passions into play. These indirect consequences tend powerfully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the destruction of large fortunes, and especially of large domains.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Among nations whose law of descent is founded upon the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: primogeniture landed estates often pass from generation to generation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without undergoing division, the consequence of which is that family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feeling is to a certain degree incorporated with the estate. The family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represents the estate, the estate the family; whose name, together with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its origin, its glory, its power, and its virtues, is thus perpetuated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in an imperishable memorial of the past and a sure pledge of the future.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the equal partition of property is established by law, the intimate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connection is destroyed between family feeling and the preservation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the paternal estate; the property ceases to represent the family; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as it must inevitably be divided after one or two generations, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has evidently a constant tendency to diminish, and must in the end be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely dispersed. The sons of the great landed proprietor, if they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are few in number, or if fortune befriends them, may indeed entertain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hope of being as wealthy as their father, but not that of possessing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same property as he did; the riches must necessarily be composed of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elements different from his.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Now, from the moment that you divest the landowner of that interest in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the preservation of his estate which he derives from association, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tradition, and from family pride, you may be certain that sooner or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: later he will dispose of it; for there is a strong pecuniary interest in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favor of selling, as floating capital produces higher interest than real
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property, and is more readily available to gratify the passions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Great landed estates which have once been divided never come together
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: again; for the small proprietor draws from his land a better revenue, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion, than the large owner does from his, and of course he sells
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it at a higher rate. *b The calculations of gain, therefore, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decide the rich man to sell his domain will still more powerfully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence him against buying small estates to unite them into a large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: I do not mean to say that the small proprietor cultivates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his land better, but he cultivates it with more ardor and care; so that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he makes up by his labor for his want of skill.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What is called family pride is often founded upon an illusion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self-love. A man wishes to perpetuate and immortalize himself, as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were, in his great-grandchildren. Where the esprit de famille ceases
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to act individual selfishness comes into play. When the idea of family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes vague, indeterminate, and uncertain, a man thinks of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present convenience; he provides for the establishment of his succeeding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generation, and no more. Either a man gives up the idea of perpetuating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his family, or at any rate he seeks to accomplish it by other means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than that of a landed estate. Thus not only does the law of partible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inheritance render it difficult for families to preserve their ancestral
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: domains entire, but it deprives them of the inclination to attempt it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and compels them in some measure to co-operate with the law in their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extinction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The law of equal distribution proceeds by two methods: by acting upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things, it acts upon persons; by influencing persons, it affects things.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: By these means the law succeeds in striking at the root of landed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property, and dispersing rapidly both families and fortunes. *c
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: Land being the most stable kind of property, we find, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time to time, rich individuals who are disposed to make great sacrifices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to obtain it, and who willingly forfeit a considerable part of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their income to make sure of the rest. But these are accidental cases.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The preference for landed property is no longer found habitually in any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class but among the poor. The small landowner, who has less information,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less imagination, and fewer passions than the great one, is generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occupied with the desire of increasing his estate: and it often happens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that by inheritance, by marriage, or by the chances of trade, he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually furnished with the means. Thus, to balance the tendency which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leads men to divide their estates, there exists another, which incites
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them to add to them. This tendency, which is sufficient to prevent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estates from being divided ad infinitum, is not strong enough to create
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great territorial possessions, certainly not to keep them up in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: family.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Most certainly it is not for us Frenchmen of the nineteenth century,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who daily witness the political and social changes which the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of partition is bringing to pass, to question its influence. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually conspicuous in our country, overthrowing the walls of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dwellings and removing the landmarks of our fields. But although it has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produced great effects in France, much still remains for it to do. Our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recollections, opinions, and habits present powerful obstacles to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States it has nearly completed its work of destruction,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and there we can best study its results. The English laws concerning the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transmission of property were abolished in almost all the States at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the time of the Revolution. The law of entail was so modified as not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to interrupt the free circulation of property. *d The first generation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having passed away, estates began to be parcelled out, and the change
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became more and more rapid with the progress of time. At this moment,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after a lapse of a little more than sixty years, the aspect of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is totally altered; the families of the great landed proprietors are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all commingled with the general mass. In the State of New York,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which formerly contained many of these, there are but two who still keep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their heads above the stream, and they must shortly disappear. The sons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these opulent citizens are become merchants, lawyers, or physicians.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Most of them have lapsed into obscurity. The last trace of hereditary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranks and distinctions is destroyed--the law of partition has reduced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all to one level. [Footnote d: See Appendix, G.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not mean that there is any deficiency of wealthy individuals in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States; I know of no country, indeed, where the love of money has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken stronger hold on the affections of men, and where the profounder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contempt is expressed for the theory of the permanent equality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property. But wealth circulates with inconceivable rapidity, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience shows that it is rare to find two succeeding generations in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the full enjoyment of it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This picture, which may perhaps be thought to be overcharged, still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gives a very imperfect idea of what is taking place in the new States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the West and South-west. At the end of the last century a few bold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adventurers began to penetrate into the valleys of the Mississippi, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mass of the population very soon began to move in that direction:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities unheard of till then were seen to emerge from the wilds:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States whose names were not in existence a few years before claimed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their place in the American Union; and in the Western settlements we may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: behold democracy arrived at its utmost extreme. In these States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: founded off-hand, and, as it were, by chance, the inhabitants are but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of yesterday. Scarcely known to one another, the nearest neighbors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are ignorant of each other's history. In this part of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent, therefore, the population has not experienced the influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of great names and great wealth, nor even that of the natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy of knowledge and virtue. None are there to wield that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respectable power which men willingly grant to the remembrance of a life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spent in doing good before their eyes. The new States of the West are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already inhabited, but society has no existence among them. *e
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: This may have been true in 1832, but is not so in 1874,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when great cities like Chicago and San Francisco have sprung up in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Western States. But as yet the Western States exert no powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence on American society.---Translator's Note.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not only the fortunes of men which are equal in America; even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their requirements partake in some degree of the same uniformity. I do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not believe that there is a country in the world where, in proportion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the population, there are so few uninstructed and at the same time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so few learned individuals. Primary instruction is within the reach of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everybody; superior instruction is scarcely to be obtained by any. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not surprising; it is in fact the necessary consequence of what we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have advanced above. Almost all the Americans are in easy circumstances,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and can therefore obtain the first elements of human knowledge.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America there are comparatively few who are rich enough to live
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without a profession. Every profession requires an apprenticeship, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limits the time of instruction to the early years of life. At fifteen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they enter upon their calling, and thus their education ends at the age
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when ours begins. Whatever is done afterwards is with a view to some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: special and lucrative object; a science is taken up as a matter of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: business, and the only branch of it which is attended to is such as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admits of an immediate practical application. In America most of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich men were formerly poor; most of those who now enjoy leisure were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absorbed in business during their youth; the consequence of which is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that when they might have had a taste for study they had no time for it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and when time is at their disposal they have no longer the inclination.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is no class, then, in America, in which the taste for intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures is transmitted with hereditary fortune and leisure, and by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the labors of the intellect are held in honor. Accordingly there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is an equal want of the desire and the power of application to these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A middle standard is fixed in America for human knowledge. All approach
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as near to it as they can; some as they rise, others as they descend.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of course, an immense multitude of persons are to be found who entertain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same number of ideas on religion, history, science, political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: economy, legislation, and government. The gifts of intellect proceed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directly from God, and man cannot prevent their unequal distribution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in consequence of the state of things which we have here represented
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it happens that, although the capacities of men are widely different, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Creator has doubtless intended they should be, they are submitted to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same method of treatment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the aristocratic element has always been feeble from its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: birth; and if at the present day it is not actually destroyed, it is at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any rate so completely disabled that we can scarcely assign to it any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degree of influence in the course of affairs. The democratic principle,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the contrary, has gained so much strength by time, by events, and by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation, as to have become not only predominant but all-powerful.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is no family or corporate authority, and it is rare to find even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the influence of individual character enjoy any durability.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, then, exhibits in her social state a most extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: phenomenon. Men are there seen on a greater equality in point of fortune
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and intellect, or, in other words, more equal in their strength, than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in any other country of the world, or in any age of which history has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preserved the remembrance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Political Consequences Of The Social Condition Of The Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The political consequences of such a social condition as this are easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deducible. It is impossible to believe that equality will not eventually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find its way into the political world as it does everywhere else. To
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceive of men remaining forever unequal upon one single point, yet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal on all others, is impossible; they must come in the end to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal upon all. Now I know of only two methods of establishing equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the political world; every citizen must be put in possession of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his rights, or rights must be granted to no one. For nations which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrived at the same stage of social existence as the Anglo-Americans, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is therefore very difficult to discover a medium between the sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all and the absolute power of one man: and it would be vain to deny
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the social condition which I have been describing is equally liable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to each of these consequences.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is, in fact, a manly and lawful passion for equality which excites
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men to wish all to be powerful and honored. This passion tends to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elevate the humble to the rank of the great; but there exists also in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the human heart a depraved taste for equality, which impels the weak
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to attempt to lower the powerful to their own level, and reduces men to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prefer equality in slavery to inequality with freedom. Not that those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations whose social condition is democratic naturally despise liberty;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the contrary, they have an instinctive love of it. But liberty is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chief and constant object of their desires; equality is their idol:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they make rapid and sudden efforts to obtain liberty, and if they miss
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their aim resign themselves to their disappointment; but nothing can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfy them except equality, and rather than lose it they resolve to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perish.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, in a State where the citizens are nearly on an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality, it becomes difficult for them to preserve their independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the aggressions of power. No one among them being strong
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enough to engage in the struggle with advantage, nothing but a general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combination can protect their liberty. And such a union is not always to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be found.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From the same social position, then, nations may derive one or the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of two great political results; these results are extremely different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from each other, but they may both proceed from the same cause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Anglo-Americans are the first nations who, having been exposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to this formidable alternative, have been happy enough to escape
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the dominion of absolute power. They have been allowed by their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances, their origin, their intelligence, and especially by their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral feeling, to establish and maintain the sovereignty of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IV: The Principle Of The Sovereignty Of The People In America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It predominates over the whole of society in America--Application
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made of this principle by the Americans even before their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Revolution--Development given to it by that Revolution--Gradual and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible extension of the elective qualification.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Principle Of The Sovereignty Of The People In America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whenever the political laws of the United States are to be discussed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is with the doctrine of the sovereignty of the people that we must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: begin. The principle of the sovereignty of the people, which is to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found, more or less, at the bottom of almost all human institutions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally remains concealed from view. It is obeyed without being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recognized, or if for a moment it be brought to light, it is hastily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cast back into the gloom of the sanctuary. "The will of the nation" is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one of those expressions which have been most profusely abused by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wily and the despotic of every age. To the eyes of some it has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represented by the venal suffrages of a few of the satellites of power;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to others by the votes of a timid or an interested minority; and some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have even discovered it in the silence of a people, on the supposition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the fact of submission established the right of command.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the principle of the sovereignty of the people is not either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barren or concealed, as it is with some other nations; it is recognized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the customs and proclaimed by the laws; it spreads freely, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrives without impediment at its most remote consequences. If there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be a country in the world where the doctrine of the sovereignty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people can be fairly appreciated, where it can be studied in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: application to the affairs of society, and where its dangers and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages may be foreseen, that country is assuredly America.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already observed that, from their origin, the sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people was the fundamental principle of the greater number of British
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: colonies in America. It was far, however, from then exercising as much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence on the government of society as it now does. Two obstacles,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the one external, the other internal, checked its invasive progress. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could not ostensibly disclose itself in the laws of colonies which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still constrained to obey the mother-country: it was therefore obliged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to spread secretly, and to gain ground in the provincial assemblies, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially in the townships.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American society was not yet prepared to adopt it with all its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences. The intelligence of New England, and the wealth of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country to the south of the Hudson (as I have shown in the preceding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chapter), long exercised a sort of aristocratic influence, which tended
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to retain the exercise of social authority in the hands of a few. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public functionaries were not universally elected, and the citizens were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not all of them electors. The electoral franchise was everywhere placed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within certain limits, and made dependent on a certain qualification,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which was exceedingly low in the North and more considerable in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American revolution broke out, and the doctrine of the sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the people, which had been nurtured in the townships and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: municipalities, took possession of the State: every class was enlisted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in its cause; battles were fought, and victories obtained for it, until
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it became the law of laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A no less rapid change was effected in the interior of society, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the law of descent completed the abolition of local influences.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the very time when this consequence of the laws and of the revolution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was apparent to every eye, victory was irrevocably pronounced in favor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the democratic cause. All power was, in fact, in its hands, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resistance was no longer possible. The higher orders submitted without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a murmur and without a struggle to an evil which was thenceforth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inevitable. The ordinary fate of falling powers awaited them; each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their several members followed his own interests; and as it was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible to wring the power from the hands of a people which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: did not detest sufficiently to brave, their only aim was to secure its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good-will at any price. The most democratic laws were consequently voted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the very men whose interests they impaired; and thus, although the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: higher classes did not excite the passions of the people against their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order, they accelerated the triumph of the new state of things; so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that by a singular change the democratic impulse was found to be most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible in the very States where the aristocracy had the firmest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hold. The State of Maryland, which had been founded by men of rank,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was the first to proclaim universal suffrage, and to introduce the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic forms into the conduct of its government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a nation modifies the elective qualification, it may easily be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreseen that sooner or later that qualification will be entirely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolished. There is no more invariable rule in the history of society:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the further electoral rights are extended, the greater is the need of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extending them; for after each concession the strength of the democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases, and its demands increase with its strength. The ambition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who are below the appointed rate is irritated in exact proportion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the great number of those who are above it. The exception at last
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes the rule, concession follows concession, and no stop can be made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: short of universal suffrage.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the present day the principle of the sovereignty of the people has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquired, in the United States, all the practical development which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination can conceive. It is unencumbered by those fictions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been thrown over it in other countries, and it appears in every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possible form according to the exigency of the occasion. Sometimes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws are made by the people in a body, as at Athens; and sometimes its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives, chosen by universal suffrage, transact business in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: name, and almost under its immediate control.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In some countries a power exists which, though it is in a degree foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the social body, directs it, and forces it to pursue a certain track.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In others the ruling force is divided, being partly within and partly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without the ranks of the people. But nothing of the kind is to be seen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States; there society governs itself for itself. All power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centres in its bosom; and scarcely an individual is to be meet with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who would venture to conceive, or, still less, to express, the idea of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seeking it elsewhere. The nation participates in the making of its laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the choice of its legislators, and in the execution of them by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choice of the agents of the executive government; it may almost be said
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to govern itself, so feeble and so restricted is the share left to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration, so little do the authorities forget their popular origin
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the power from which they emanate. *a [Footnote a: See Appendix, H.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter V: Necessity Of Examining The Condition Of The States--Part I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Necessity Of Examining The Condition Of The States Before That Of The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union At Large.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is proposed to examine in the following chapter what is the form of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government established in America on the principle of the sovereignty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people; what are its resources, its hindrances, its advantages, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its dangers. The first difficulty which presents itself arises from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complex nature of the constitution of the United States, which consists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of two distinct social structures, connected and, as it were, encased
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one within the other; two governments, completely separate and almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent, the one fulfilling the ordinary duties and responding to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the daily and indefinite calls of a community, the other circumscribed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within certain limits, and only exercising an exceptional authority over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the general interests of the country. In short, there are twenty-four
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small sovereign nations, whose agglomeration constitutes the body of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union. To examine the Union before we have studied the States would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be to adopt a method filled with obstacles. The form of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of the United States was the last which was adopted; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is in fact nothing more than a modification or a summary of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republican principles which were current in the whole community before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it existed, and independently of its existence. Moreover, the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government is, as I have just observed, the exception; the Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States is the rule. The author who should attempt to exhibit the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: picture as a whole before he had explained its details would necessarily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fall into obscurity and repetition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great political principles which govern American society at this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day undoubtedly took their origin and their growth in the State. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is therefore necessary to become acquainted with the State in order to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possess a clue to the remainder. The States which at present compose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American Union all present the same features, as far as regards the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: external aspect of their institutions. Their political or administrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence is centred in three focuses of action, which may not inaptly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be compared to the different nervous centres which convey motion to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human body. The township is the lowest in order, then the county, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lastly the State; and I propose to devote the following chapter to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examination of these three divisions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American System Of Townships And Municipal Bodies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Why the Author begins the examination of the political institutions with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the township--Its existence in all nations--Difficulty of establishing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and preserving municipal independence--Its importance--Why the Author
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has selected the township system of New England as the main topic of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discussion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not undesignedly that I begin this subject with the Township.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
