text: The village or township is the only association which is so perfectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural that wherever a number of men are collected it seems to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitute itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The town, or tithing, as the smallest division of a community, must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessarily exist in all nations, whatever their laws and customs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be: if man makes monarchies and establishes republics, the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association of mankind seems constituted by the hand of God. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although the existence of the township is coeval with that of man, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties are not the less rarely respected and easily destroyed. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation is always able to establish great political assemblies, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it habitually contains a certain number of individuals fitted by their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talents, if not by their habits, for the direction of affairs. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township is, on the contrary, composed of coarser materials, which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less easily fashioned by the legislator. The difficulties which attend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the consolidation of its independence rather augment than diminish with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the increasing enlightenment of the people. A highly civilized community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spurns the attempts of a local independence, is disgusted at its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numerous blunders, and is apt to despair of success before the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experiment is completed. Again, no immunities are so ill protected from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the encroachments of the supreme power as those of municipal bodies in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general: they are unable to struggle, single-handed, against a strong
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or an enterprising government, and they cannot defend their cause with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: success unless it be identified with the customs of the nation and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supported by public opinion. Thus until the independence of townships is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amalgamated with the manners of a people it is easily destroyed, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is only after a long existence in the laws that it can be thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amalgamated. Municipal freedom is not the fruit of human device; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is rarely created; but it is, as it were, secretly and spontaneously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engendered in the midst of a semi-barbarous state of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The constant action of the laws and the national habits, peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances, and above all time, may consolidate it; but there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certainly no nation on the continent of Europe which has experienced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its advantages. Nevertheless local assemblies of citizens constitute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the strength of free nations. Town-meetings are to liberty what primary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: schools are to science; they bring it within the people's reach, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: teach men how to use and how to enjoy it. A nation may establish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a system of free government, but without the spirit of municipal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions it cannot have the spirit of liberty. The transient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions and the interests of an hour, or the chance of circumstances,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may have created the external forms of independence; but the despotic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency which has been repelled will, sooner or later, inevitably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reappear on the surface.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In order to explain to the reader the general principles on which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political organization of the counties and townships of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States rests, I have thought it expedient to choose one of the States of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New England as an example, to examine the mechanism of its constitution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and then to cast a general glance over the country. The township and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: county are not organized in the same manner in every part of the Union;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is, however, easy to perceive that the same principles have guided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the formation of both of them throughout the Union. I am inclined to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe that these principles have been carried further in New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than elsewhere, and consequently that they offer greater facilities to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the observations of a stranger. The institutions of New England form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a complete and regular whole; they have received the sanction of time,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have the support of the laws, and the still stronger support of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners of the community, over which they exercise the most prodigious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence; they consequently deserve our attention on every account.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Limits Of The Township
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The township of New England is a division which stands between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commune and the canton of France, and which corresponds in general to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the English tithing, or town. Its average population is from two to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: three thousand; *a so that, on the one hand, the interests of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants are not likely to conflict, and, on the other, men capable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conducting its affairs are always to be found among its citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: In 1830 there were 305 townships in the State of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts, and 610,014 inhabitants, which gives an average of about
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 2,000 inhabitants to each township.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Authorities Of The Township In New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The people the source of all power here as elsewhere--Manages its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs--No corporation--The greater part of the authority vested in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands of the Selectmen--How the Selectmen act--Town-meeting--Enumeration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the public officers of the township--Obligatory and remunerated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the township, as well as everywhere else, the people is the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: source of power; but in no stage of government does the body of citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise a more immediate influence. In America the people is a master
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whose exigencies demand obedience to the utmost limits of possibility.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In New England the majority acts by representatives in the conduct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the public business of the State; but if such an arrangement be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary in general affairs, in the townships, where the legislative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and administrative action of the government is in more immediate contact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the subject, the system of representation is not adopted. There is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no corporation; but the body of electors, after having designated its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrates, directs them in everything that exceeds the simple and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinary executive business of the State. *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: The same rules are not applicable to the great towns, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally have a mayor, and a corporation divided into two bodies; this,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however, is an exception which requires the sanction of a law.--See the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Act of February 22, 1822, for appointing the authorities of the city
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Boston. It frequently happens that small towns as well as cities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are subject to a peculiar administration. In 1832, 104 townships in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State of New York were governed in this manner.--Williams' Register.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This state of things is so contrary to our ideas, and so different from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our customs, that it is necessary for me to adduce some examples to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explain it thoroughly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The public duties in the township are extremely numerous and minutely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divided, as we shall see further on; but the larger proportion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administrative power is vested in the hands of a small number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals, called "the Selectmen." *c The general laws of the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impose a certain number of obligations on the selectmen, which they may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fulfil without the authorization of the body they represent, but which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they can only neglect on their own responsibility. The law of the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliges them, for instance, to draw up the list of electors in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: townships; and if they omit this part of their functions, they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guilty of a misdemeanor. In all the affairs, however, which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determined by the town-meeting, the selectmen are the organs of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular mandate, as in France the Maire executes the decree of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: municipal council. They usually act upon their own responsibility, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merely put in practice principles which have been previously recognized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the majority. But if any change is to be introduced in the existing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of things, or if they wish to undertake any new enterprise, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are obliged to refer to the source of their power. If, for instance, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: school is to be established, the selectmen convoke the whole body of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the electors on a certain day at an appointed place; they explain the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: urgency of the case; they give their opinion on the means of satisfying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it, on the probable expense, and the site which seems to be most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable. The meeting is consulted on these several points; it adopts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principle, marks out the site, votes the rate, and confides the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: execution of its resolution to the selectmen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: Three selectmen are appointed in the small townships, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nine in the large ones. See "The Town-Officer," p. 186. See also the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal laws of the State of Massachusetts relative to the selectmen:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Act of February 20, 1786, vol. i. p. 219; February 24, 1796, vol. i. p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 488; March 7, 1801, vol. ii. p. 45; June 16, 1795, vol. i. p. 475; March
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 12, 1808, vol. ii. p. 186; February 28, 1787, vol. i. p. 302; June 22,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The selectmen have alone the right of calling a town-meeting, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be requested to do so: if ten citizens are desirous of submitting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a new project to the assent of the township, they may demand a general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convocation of the inhabitants; the selectmen are obliged to comply, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have only the right of presiding at the meeting. *d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: See Laws of Massachusetts, vol. i. p. 150, Act of March 25,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The selectmen are elected every year in the month of April or of May.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The town-meeting chooses at the same time a number of other municipal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrates, who are entrusted with important administrative functions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The assessors rate the township; the collectors receive the rate. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constable is appointed to keep the peace, to watch the streets, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forward the execution of the laws; the town-clerk records all the town
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: votes, orders, grants, births, deaths, and marriages; the treasurer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: keeps the funds; the overseer of the poor performs the difficult task of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superintending the action of the poor-laws; committee-men are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appointed to attend to the schools and to public instruction; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: road-surveyors, who take care of the greater and lesser thoroughfares
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the township, complete the list of the principal functionaries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They are, however, still further subdivided; and amongst the municipal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers are to be found parish commissioners, who audit the expenses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of public worship; different classes of inspectors, some of whom are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to direct the citizens in case of fire; tithing-men, listers, haywards,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chimney-viewers, fence-viewers to maintain the bounds of property,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: timber-measurers, and sealers of weights and measures. *e
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: All these magistrates actually exist; their different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions are all detailed in a book called "The Town-Officer," by Isaac
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Goodwin, Worcester, 1827; and in the "Collection of the General Laws of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts," 3 vols., Boston, 1823.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are nineteen principal officers in a township. Every inhabitant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is constrained, on the pain of being fined, to undertake these different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions; which, however, are almost all paid, in order that the poorer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens may be able to give up their time without loss. In general the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American system is not to grant a fixed salary to its functionaries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Every service has its price, and they are remunerated in proportion to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what they have done.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Existence Of The Township
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Every one the best judge of his own interest--Corollary of the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the sovereignty of the people--Application of those doctrines in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: townships of America--The township of New England is sovereign in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all that concerns itself alone: subject to the State in all other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: matters--Bond of the township and the State--In France the Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lends its agent to the Commune--In America the reverse occurs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already observed that the principle of the sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people governs the whole political system of the Anglo-Americans. Every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: page of this book will afford new instances of the same doctrine. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nations by which the sovereignty of the people is recognized every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual possesses an equal share of power, and participates alike in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the government of the State. Every individual is, therefore, supposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be as well informed, as virtuous, and as strong as any of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-citizens. He obeys the government, not because he is inferior to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the authorities which conduct it, or that he is less capable than his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighbor of governing himself, but because he acknowledges the utility
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an association with his fellow-men, and because he knows that no such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association can exist without a regulating force. If he be a subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all that concerns the mutual relations of citizens, he is free and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsible to God alone for all that concerns himself. Hence arises the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maxim that every one is the best and the sole judge of his own private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest, and that society has no right to control a man's actions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unless they are prejudicial to the common weal, or unless the common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weal demands his co-operation. This doctrine is universally admitted in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States. I shall hereafter examine the general influence which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it exercises on the ordinary actions of life; I am now speaking of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature of municipal bodies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The township, taken as a whole, and in relation to the government of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, may be looked upon as an individual to whom the theory I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have just alluded to is applied. Municipal independence is therefore a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural consequence of the principle of the sovereignty of the people in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States: all the American republics recognize it more or less;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but circumstances have peculiarly favored its growth in New England.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In this part of the Union the impulsion of political activity was given
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the townships; and it may almost be said that each of them originally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed an independent nation. When the Kings of England asserted their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supremacy, they were contented to assume the central power of the State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The townships of New England remained as they were before; and although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are now subject to the State, they were at first scarcely dependent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon it. It is important to remember that they have not been invested
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with privileges, but that they have, on the contrary, forfeited a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portion of their independence to the State. The townships are only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subordinate to the State in those interests which I shall term social,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as they are common to all the citizens. They are independent in all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that concerns themselves; and amongst the inhabitants of New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe that not a man is to be found who would acknowledge that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State has any right to interfere in their local interests. The towns
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of New England buy and sell, sue or are sued, augment or diminish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their rates, without the slightest opposition on the part of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administrative authority of the State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They are bound, however, to comply with the demands of the community. If
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State is in need of money, a town can neither give nor withhold the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supplies. If the State projects a road, the township cannot refuse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: let it cross its territory; if a police regulation is made by the State,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it must be enforced by the town. A uniform system of instruction is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: organized all over the country, and every town is bound to establish the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: schools which the law ordains. In speaking of the administration of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States I shall have occasion to point out the means by which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: townships are compelled to obey in these different cases: I here merely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: show the existence of the obligation. Strict as this obligation is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the government of the State imposes it in principle only, and in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: performance the township resumes all its independent rights. Thus,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taxes are voted by the State, but they are levied and collected by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township; the existence of a school is obligatory, but the township
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: builds, pays, and superintends it. In France the State-collector
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: receives the local imposts; in America the town-collector receives the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taxes of the State. Thus the French Government lends its agents to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commune; in America the township is the agent of the Government. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact alone shows the extent of the differences which exist between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Public Spirit Of The Townships Of New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: How the township of New England wins the affections of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants--Difficulty of creating local public spirit in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe--The rights and duties of the American township favorable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it--Characteristics of home in the United States--Manifestations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public spirit in New England--Its happy effects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America, not only do municipal bodies exist, but they are kept alive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and supported by public spirit. The township of New England possesses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two advantages which infallibly secure the attentive interest of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind, namely, independence and authority. Its sphere is indeed small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and limited, but within that sphere its action is unrestrained; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its independence gives to it a real importance which its extent and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population may not always ensure.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is to be remembered that the affections of men generally lie on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: side of authority. Patriotism is not durable in a conquered nation. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New Englander is attached to his township, not only because he was born
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in it, but because it constitutes a social body of which he is a member,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and whose government claims and deserves the exercise of his sagacity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Europe the absence of local public spirit is a frequent subject of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regret to those who are in power; everyone agrees that there is no surer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guarantee of order and tranquility, and yet nothing is more difficult to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: create. If the municipal bodies were made powerful and independent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the authorities of the nation might be disunited and the peace of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country endangered. Yet, without power and independence, a town may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contain good subjects, but it can have no active citizens. Another
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important fact is that the township of New England is so constituted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to excite the warmest of human affections, without arousing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambitious passions of the heart of man. The officers of the country are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not elected, and their authority is very limited. Even the State is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only a second-rate community, whose tranquil and obscure administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offers no inducement sufficient to draw men away from the circle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their interests into the turmoil of public affairs. The federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government confers power and honor on the men who conduct it; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these individuals can never be very numerous. The high station of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Presidency can only be reached at an advanced period of life, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other federal functionaries are generally men who have been favored
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by fortune, or distinguished in some other career. Such cannot be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanent aim of the ambitious. But the township serves as a centre for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the desire of public esteem, the want of exciting interests, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the taste for authority and popularity, in the midst of the ordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relations of life; and the passions which commonly embroil society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change their character when they find a vent so near the domestic hearth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the family circle.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the American States power has been disseminated with admirable skill
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the purpose of interesting the greatest possible number of persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the common weal. Independently of the electors who are from time to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time called into action, the body politic is divided into innumerable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functionaries and officers, who all, in their several spheres, represent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same powerful whole in whose name they act. The local administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus affords an unfailing source of profit and interest to a vast number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of individuals.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American system, which divides the local authority among so many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens, does not scruple to multiply the functions of the town
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers. For in the United States it is believed, and with truth,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that patriotism is a kind of devotion which is strengthened by ritual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observance. In this manner the activity of the township is continually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceptible; it is daily manifested in the fulfilment of a duty or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise of a right, and a constant though gentle motion is thus kept up
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in society which animates without disturbing it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American attaches himself to his home as the mountaineer clings to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his hills, because the characteristic features of his country are there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more distinctly marked than elsewhere. The existence of the townships
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of New England is in general a happy one. Their government is suited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to their tastes, and chosen by themselves. In the midst of the profound
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace and general comfort which reign in America the commotions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: municipal discord are unfrequent. The conduct of local business is easy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The political education of the people has long been complete; say rather
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it was complete when the people first set foot upon the soil. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New England no tradition exists of a distinction of ranks; no portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community is tempted to oppress the remainder; and the abuses which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may injure isolated individuals are forgotten in the general contentment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which prevails. If the government is defective (and it would no doubt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be easy to point out its deficiencies), the fact that it really emanates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from those it governs, and that it acts, either ill or well, casts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the protecting spell of a parental pride over its faults. No term of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparison disturbs the satisfaction of the citizen: England formerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed the mass of the colonies, but the people was always sovereign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the township where its rule is not only an ancient but a primitive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The native of New England is attached to his township because it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent and free: his co-operation in its affairs ensures his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attachment to its interest; the well-being it affords him secures his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affection; and its welfare is the aim of his ambition and of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future exertions: he takes a part in every occurrence in the place; he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practises the art of government in the small sphere within his reach;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he accustoms himself to those forms which can alone ensure the steady
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress of liberty; he imbibes their spirit; he acquires a taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order, comprehends the union or the balance of powers, and collects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clear practical notions on the nature of his duties and the extent of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his rights.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Counties Of New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The division of the countries in America has considerable analogy with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of the arrondissements of France. The limits of the counties are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arbitrarily laid down, and the various districts which they contain have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no necessary connection, no common tradition or natural sympathy; their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object is simply to facilitate the administration of justice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The extent of the township was too small to contain a system of judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions; each county has, however, a court of justice, *f a sheriff
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to execute its decrees, and a prison for criminals. There are certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants which are felt alike by all the townships of a county; it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore natural that they should be satisfied by a central authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the State of Massachusetts this authority is vested in the hands of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several magistrates, who are appointed by the Governor of the State,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the advice *g of his council. *h The officers of the county have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only a limited and occasional authority, which is applicable to certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predetermined cases. The State and the townships possess all the power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: requisite to conduct public business. The budget of the county is drawn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up by its officers, and is voted by the legislature, but there is no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assembly which directly or indirectly represents the county. It has,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, properly speaking, no political existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: See the Act of February 14, 1821, Laws of Massachusetts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: See the Act of February 20, 1819, Laws of Massachusetts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vol. ii. p. 494.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: The council of the Governor is an elective body.] A twofold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency may be discerned in the American constitutions, which impels
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legislator to centralize the legislative and to disperse the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive power. The township of New England has in itself an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indestructible element of independence; and this distinct existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could only be fictitiously introduced into the county, where its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: utility has not been felt. But all the townships united have but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one representation, which is the State, the centre of the national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority: beyond the action of the township and that of the nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing can be said to exist but the influence of individual exertion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Administration In New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Administration not perceived in America--Why?--The Europeans believe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that liberty is promoted by depriving the social authority of some of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its rights; the Americans, by dividing its exercise--Almost all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration confined to the township, and divided amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: town-officers--No trace of an administrative body to be perceived,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either in the township or above it--The reason of this--How it happens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the administration of the State is uniform--Who is empowered to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enforce the obedience of the township and the county to the law--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduction of judicial power into the administration--Consequence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the extension of the elective principle to all functionaries--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Justice of the Peace in New England--By whom appointed--County officer:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ensures the administration of the townships--Court of Sessions--Its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action--Right of inspection and indictment disseminated like the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administrative functions--Informers encouraged by the division of fines.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing is more striking to an European traveller in the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the absence of what we term the Government, or the Administration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Written laws exist in America, and one sees that they are daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executed; but although everything is in motion, the hand which gives the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impulse to the social machine can nowhere be discovered. Nevertheless,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as all peoples are obliged to have recourse to certain grammatical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forms, which are the foundation of human language, in order to express
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their thoughts; so all communities are obliged to secure their existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by submitting to a certain dose of authority, without which they fall a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prey to anarchy. This authority may be distributed in several ways, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it must always exist somewhere.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are two methods of diminishing the force of authority in a nation:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first is to weaken the supreme power in its very principle, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forbidding or preventing society from acting in its own defence under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain circumstances. To weaken authority in this manner is what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally termed in Europe to lay the foundations of freedom. The second
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner of diminishing the influence of authority does not consist in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stripping society of any of its rights, nor in paralyzing its efforts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but in distributing the exercise of its privileges in various hands,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in multiplying functionaries, to each of whom the degree of power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary for him to perform his duty is entrusted. There may be nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whom this distribution of social powers might lead to anarchy; but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself it is not anarchical. The action of authority is indeed thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rendered less irresistible and less perilous, but it is not totally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suppressed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The revolution of the United States was the result of a mature and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dignified taste for freedom, and not of a vague or ill-defined craving
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for independence. It contracted no alliance with the turbulent passions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of anarchy; but its course was marked, on the contrary, by an attachment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to whatever was lawful and orderly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It was never assumed in the United States that the citizen of a free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country has a right to do whatever he pleases; on the contrary, social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obligations were there imposed upon him more various than anywhere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: else. No idea was ever entertained of attacking the principles or of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contesting the rights of society; but the exercise of its authority was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divided, to the end that the office might be powerful and the officer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insignificant, and that the community should be at once regulated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and free. In no country in the world does the law hold so absolute a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language as in America, and in no country is the right of applying it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vested in so many hands. The administrative power in the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: presents nothing either central or hierarchical in its constitution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which accounts for its passing, unperceived. The power exists, but its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative is not to be perceived.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We have already seen that the independent townships of New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protect their own private interests; and the municipal magistrates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are the persons to whom the execution of the laws of the State is most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently entrusted. *i Besides the general laws, the State sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passes general police regulations; but more commonly the townships and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: town officers, conjointly with justices of the peace, regulate the minor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: details of social life, according to the necessities of the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: localities, and promulgate such enactments as concern the health of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, and the peace as well as morality of the citizens. *j Lastly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these municipal magistrates provide, of their own accord and without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any delegated powers, for those unforeseen emergencies which frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occur in society. *k
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: See "The Town-Officer," especially at the words Selectmen,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Assessors, Collectors, Schools, Surveyors of Highways. I take one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: example in a thousand: the State prohibits travelling on the Sunday; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tything-men, who are town-officers, are specially charged to keep watch
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to execute the law. See the Laws of Massachusetts, vol. i. p. 410.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The selectmen draw up the lists of electors for the election of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Governor, and transmit the result of the ballot to the Secretary of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State. See Act of February 24, 1796: Id., vol. i. p. 488.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: Thus, for instance, the selectmen authorize the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: construction of drains, point out the proper sites for slaughter-houses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and other trades which are a nuisance to the neighborhood. See the Act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of June 7, 1785: Id., vol. i. p. 193.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: The selectmen take measures for the security of the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in case of contagious diseases, conjointly with the justices of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace. See Act of June 22, 1797, vol. i. p. 539.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It results from what we have said that in the State of Massachusetts the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administrative authority is almost entirely restricted to the township,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *l but that it is distributed among a great number of individuals.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the French commune there is properly but one official functionary,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: namely, the Maire; and in New England we have seen that there are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nineteen. These nineteen functionaries do not in general depend upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one another. The law carefully prescribes a circle of action to each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these magistrates; and within that circle they have an entire right to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perform their functions independently of any other authority. Above the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township scarcely any trace of a series of official dignitaries is to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found. It sometimes happens that the county officers alter a decision of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the townships or town magistrates, *m but in general the authorities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the county have no right to interfere with the authorities of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township, *n except in such matters as concern the county.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: I say almost, for there are various circumstances in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annals of a township which are regulated by the justice of the peace in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his individual capacity, or by the justices of the peace assembled in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chief town of the county; thus licenses are granted by the justices.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See the Act of February 28, 1787, vol. i. p. 297.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: Thus licenses are only granted to such persons as can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produce a certificate of good conduct from the selectmen. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: selectmen refuse to give the certificate, the party may appeal to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justices assembled in the Court of Sessions, and they may grant the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: license. See Act of March 12, 1808, vol. ii. p. 186.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The townships have the right to make by-laws, and to enforce them by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fines which are fixed by law; but these by-laws must be approved by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Court of Sessions. See Act of March 23, 1786, vol. i. p. 254.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: In Massachusetts the county magistrates are frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called upon to investigate the acts of the town magistrates; but it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be shown further on that this investigation is a consequence, not of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their administrative, but of their judicial power.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The magistrates of the township, as well as those of the county, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bound to communicate their acts to the central government in a very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small number of predetermined cases. *o But the central government is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not represented by an individual whose business it is to publish police
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulations and ordinances enforcing the execution of the laws; to keep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up a regular communication with the officers of the township and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the county; to inspect their conduct, to direct their actions, or to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reprimand their faults. There is no point which serves as a centre to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the radii of the administration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: The town committees of schools are obliged to make an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annual report to the Secretary of the State on the condition of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: school. See Act of March 10, 1827, vol. iii. p. 183.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter V: Necessity Of Examining The Condition Of The States--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What, then, is the uniform plan on which the government is conducted,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and how is the compliance of the counties and their magistrates or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: townships and their officers enforced? In the States of New England the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative authority embraces more subjects than it does in France; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator penetrates to the very core of the administration; the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descends to the most minute details; the same enactment prescribes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principle and the method of its application, and thus imposes a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of strict and rigorously defined obligations on the secondary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functionaries of the State. The consequence of this is that if all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the secondary functionaries of the administration conform to the law,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society in all its branches proceeds with the greatest uniformity: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty remains of compelling the secondary functionaries of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration to conform to the law. It may be affirmed that, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general, society has only two methods of enforcing the execution of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws at its disposal: a discretionary power may be entrusted to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior functionary of directing all the others, and of cashiering them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in case of disobedience; or the courts of justice may be authorized to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inflict judicial penalties on the offender: but these two methods are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not always available.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The right of directing a civil officer presupposes that of cashiering
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him if he does not obey orders, and of rewarding him by promotion if he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fulfils his duties with propriety. But an elected magistrate can neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be cashiered nor promoted. All elective functions are inalienable until
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their term is expired. In fact, the elected magistrate has nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either to expect or to fear from his constituents; and when all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public offices are filled by ballot there can be no series of official
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dignities, because the double right of commanding and of enforcing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience can never be vested in the same individual, and because the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of issuing an order can never be joined to that of inflicting a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: punishment or bestowing a reward.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The communities therefore in which the secondary functionaries of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the government are elected are perforce obliged to make great use of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judicial penalties as a means of administration. This is not evident at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first sight; for those in power are apt to look upon the institution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of elective functionaries as one concession, and the subjection of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the elected magistrate to the judges of the land as another. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are equally averse to both these innovations; and as they are more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pressingly solicited to grant the former than the latter, they accede
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the election of the magistrate, and leave him independent of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judicial power. Nevertheless, the second of these measures is the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing that can possibly counterbalance the first; and it will be found
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that an elective authority which is not subject to judicial power will,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sooner or later, either elude all control or be destroyed. The courts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice are the only possible medium between the central power and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administrative bodies; they alone can compel the elected functionary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to obey, without violating the rights of the elector. The extension of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judicial power in the political world ought therefore to be in the exact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ratio of the extension of elective offices: if these two institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not go hand in hand, the State must fall into anarchy or into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjection.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has always been remarked that habits of legal business do not render
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men apt to the exercise of administrative authority. The Americans have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: borrowed from the English, their fathers, the idea of an institution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is unknown upon the continent of Europe: I allude to that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Justices of the Peace. The Justice of the Peace is a sort of mezzo
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: termine between the magistrate and the man of the world, between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil officer and the judge. A justice of the peace is a well-informed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen, though he is not necessarily versed in the knowledge of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws. His office simply obliges him to execute the police regulations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society; a task in which good sense and integrity are of more avail than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legal science. The justice introduces into the administration a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taste for established forms and publicity, which renders him a most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unserviceable instrument of despotism; and, on the other hand, he is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blinded by those superstitions which render legal officers unfit members
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a government. The Americans have adopted the system of the English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justices of the peace, but they have deprived it of that aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character which is discernible in the mother-country. The Governor of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts *p appoints a certain number of justices of the peace in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every county, whose functions last seven years. *q He further designates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: three individuals from amongst the whole body of justices who form in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each county what is called the Court of Sessions. The justices take a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal share in public business; they are sometimes entrusted with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administrative functions in conjunction with elected officers, *r they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes constitute a tribunal, before which the magistrates summarily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosecute a refractory citizen, or the citizens inform against the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abuses of the magistrate. But it is in the Court of Sessions that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise their most important functions. This court meets twice a year
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the county town; in Massachusetts it is empowered to enforce the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience of the greater number *s of public officers. *t It must be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observed, that in the State of Massachusetts the Court of Sessions is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the same time an administrative body, properly so called, and a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political tribunal. It has been asserted that the county is a purely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administrative division. The Court of Sessions presides over that small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of affairs which, as they concern several townships, or all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: townships of the county in common, cannot be entrusted to any one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them in particular. *u In all that concerns county business the duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Court of Sessions are purely administrative; and if in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: investigations it occasionally borrows the forms of judicial procedure,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is only with a view to its own information, *v or as a guarantee to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community over which it presides. But when the administration of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township is brought before it, it always acts as a judicial body, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some few cases as an official assembly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: We shall hereafter learn what a Governor is: I shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: content myself with remarking in this place that he represents the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive power of the whole State.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: See the Constitution of Massachusetts, chap. II. sect. 1.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 9; chap. III. Section 3.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: Thus, for example, a stranger arrives in a township from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a country where a contagious disease prevails, and he falls ill. Two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justices of the peace can, with the assent of the selectmen, order the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sheriff of the county to remove and take care of him.--Act of June 22,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In general the justices interfere in all the important acts of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration, and give them a semi-judicial character.] [Footnote s: I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: say the greater number, because certain administrative misdemeanors are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brought before ordinary tribunals. If, for instance, a township
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refuses to make the necessary expenditure for its schools or to name
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a school-committee, it is liable to a heavy fine. But this penalty is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pronounced by the Supreme Judicial Court or the Court of Common Pleas.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See Act of March 10, 1827, Laws of Massachusetts, vol. iii. p. 190. Or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when a township neglects to provide the necessary war-stores.--Act of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: February 21, 1822: Id., vol. ii. p. 570.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote t: In their individual capacity the justices of the peace
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take a part in the business of the counties and townships.] [Footnote u:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These affairs may be brought under the following heads:--1. The erection
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of prisons and courts of justice. 2. The county budget, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afterwards voted by the State. 3. The distribution of the taxes so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: voted. 4. Grants of certain patents. 5. The laying down and repairs of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country roads.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote v: Thus, when a road is under consideration, almost all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulties are disposed of by the aid of the jury.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first difficulty is to procure the obedience of an authority as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely independent of the general laws of the State as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township is. We have stated that assessors are annually named by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: town-meetings to levy the taxes. If a township attempts to evade the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: payment of the taxes by neglecting to name its assessors, the Court of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Sessions condemns it to a heavy penalty. *w The fine is levied on each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the inhabitants; and the sheriff of the county, who is the officer of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice, executes the mandate. Thus it is that in the United States the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the Government is mysteriously concealed under the forms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a judicial sentence; and its influence is at the same time fortified by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that irresistible power with which men have invested the formalities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote w: See Act of February 20, 1786, Laws of Massachusetts, vol.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These proceedings are easy to follow and to understand. The demands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made upon a township are in general plain and accurately defined; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consist in a simple fact without any complication, or in a principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without its application in detail. *x But the difficulty increases when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is not the obedience of the township, but that of the town officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is to be enforced. All the reprehensible actions of which a public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functionary may be guilty are reducible to the following heads:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote x: There is an indirect method of enforcing the obedience of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a township. Suppose that the funds which the law demands for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of the roads have not been voted, the town surveyor is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then authorized, ex officio, to levy the supplies. As he is personally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsible to private individuals for the state of the roads, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indictable before the Court of Sessions, he is sure to employ the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary right which the law gives him against the township. Thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by threatening the officer the Court of Sessions exacts compliance from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the town. See Act of March 5, 1787, Id., vol. i. p. 305.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He may execute the law without energy or zeal;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He may neglect to execute the law;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He may do what the law enjoins him not to do.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The last two violations of duty can alone come under the cognizance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a tribunal; a positive and appreciable fact is the indispensable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foundation of an action at law. Thus, if the selectmen omit to fulfil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legal formalities usual at town elections, they may be condemned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to pay a fine; *y but when the public officer performs his duty without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ability, and when he obeys the letter of the law without zeal or energy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he is at least beyond the reach of judicial interference. The Court of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Sessions, even when it is invested with its official powers, is in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case unable to compel him to a more satisfactory obedience. The fear of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removal is the only check to these quasi-offences; and as the Court
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Sessions does not originate the town authorities, it cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remove functionaries whom it does not appoint. Moreover, a perpetual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: investigation would be necessary to convict the officer of negligence or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lukewarmness; and the Court of Sessions sits but twice a year and then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only judges such offences as are brought before its notice. The only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: security of that active and enlightened obedience which a court of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice cannot impose upon public officers lies in the possibility of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their arbitrary removal. In France this security is sought for in powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercised by the heads of the administration; in America it is sought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for in the principle of election.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote y: Laws of Massachusetts, vol. ii. p. 45.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, to recapitulate in a few words what I have been showing: If a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public officer in New England commits a crime in the exercise of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions, the ordinary courts of justice are always called upon to pass
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sentence upon him. If he commits a fault in his official capacity, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purely administrative tribunal is empowered to punish him; and, if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affair is important or urgent, the judge supplies the omission of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functionary. *z Lastly, if the same individual is guilty of one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those intangible offences of which human justice has no cognizance, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annually appears before a tribunal from which there is no appeal, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can at once reduce him to insignificance and deprive him of his charge.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This system undoubtedly possesses great advantages, but its execution is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attended with a practical difficulty which it is important to point out.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote z: If, for instance, a township persists in refusing to name
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its assessors, the Court of Sessions nominates them; and the magistrates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus appointed are invested with the same authority as elected officers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See the Act quoted above, February 20, 1787.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already observed that the administrative tribunal, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called the Court of Sessions, has no right of inspection over the town
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers. It can only interfere when the conduct of a magistrate is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: specially brought under its notice; and this is the delicate part of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system. The Americans of New England are unacquainted with the office
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of public prosecutor in the Court of Sessions, *a and it may readily be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceived that it could not have been established without difficulty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If an accusing magistrate had merely been appointed in the chief town of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each county, and if he had been unassisted by agents in the townships,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he would not have been better acquainted with what was going on in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: county than the members of the Court of Sessions. But to appoint agents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in each township would have been to centre in his person the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formidable of powers, that of a judicial administration. Moreover,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws are the children of habit, and nothing of the kind exists in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation of England. The Americans have therefore divided the offices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of inspection and of prosecution, as well as all the other functions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the administration. Grand jurors are bound by the law to apprise the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: court to which they belong of all the misdemeanors which may have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: committed in their county. *b There are certain great offences which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officially prosecuted by the States; *c but more frequently the task of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: punishing delinquents devolves upon the fiscal officer, whose province
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is to receive the fine: thus the treasurer of the township is charged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the prosecution of such administrative offences as fall under his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notice. But a more special appeal is made by American legislation to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the private interest of the citizen; *d and this great principle is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly to be met with in studying the laws of the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American legislators are more apt to give men credit for intelligence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than for honesty, and they rely not a little on personal cupidity for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the execution of the laws. When an individual is really and sensibly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: injured by an administrative abuse, it is natural that his personal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest should induce him to prosecute. But if a legal formality be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: required, which, however advantageous to the community, is of small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance to individuals, plaintiffs may be less easily found; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus, by a tacit agreement, the laws may fall into disuse. Reduced by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their system to this extremity, the Americans are obliged to encourage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: informers by bestowing on them a portion of the penalty in certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases, *e and to insure the execution of the laws by the dangerous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expedient of degrading the morals of the people. The only administrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority above the county magistrates is, properly speaking, that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: I say the Court of Sessions, because in common courts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there is a magistrate who exercises some of the functions of a public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosecutor.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: The grand-jurors are, for instance, bound to inform the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: court of the bad state of the roads.--Laws of Massachusetts, vol. i. p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: If, for instance, the treasurer of the county holds back
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his accounts.--Laws of Massachusetts, vol. i. p. 406.] [Footnote d:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, if a private individual breaks down or is wounded in consequence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the badness of a road, he can sue the township or the county for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: damages at the sessions.--Laws of Massachusetts, vol. i. p. 309.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: In cases of invasion or insurrection, if the town-officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neglect to furnish the necessary stores and ammunition for the militia,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the township may be condemned to a fine of from $200 to $500. It may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily be imagined that in such a case it might happen that no one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cared to prosecute; hence the law adds that all the citizens may indict
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offences of this kind, and that half of the fine shall belong to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plaintiff. See Act of March 6, 1810, vol. ii. p. 236. The same clause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is frequently to be met with in the law of Massachusetts. Not only are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private individuals thus incited to prosecute the public officers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the public officers are encouraged in the same manner to bring the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disobedience of private individuals to justice. If a citizen refuses to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perform the work which has been assigned to him upon a road, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: road surveyor may prosecute him, and he receives half the penalty for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself. See the Laws above quoted, vol. i. p. 308.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General Remarks On The Administration Of The United States Differences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States of the Union in their system of administration--Activity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and perfection of the local authorities decrease towards the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South--Power of the magistrate increases; that of the elector
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diminishes--Administration passes from the township to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: county--States of New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania--Principles of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration applicable to the whole Union--Election of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers, and inalienability of their functions--Absence of gradation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranks--Introduction of judicial resources into the administration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already premised that, after having examined the constitution of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the township and the county of New England in detail, I should take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a general view of the remainder of the Union. Townships and a local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: activity exist in every State; but in no part of the confederation is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: township to be met with precisely similar to those of New England. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more we descend towards the South, the less active does the business of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the township or parish become; the number of magistrates, of functions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of rights decreases; the population exercises a less immediate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence on affairs; town meetings are less frequent, and the subjects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of debate less numerous. The power of the elected magistrate is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augmented and that of the elector diminished, whilst the public spirit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the local communities is less awakened and less influential. *f These
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differences may be perceived to a certain extent in the State of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: York; they are very sensible in Pennsylvania; but they become less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: striking as we advance to the northwest. The majority of the emigrants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who settle in the northwestern States are natives of New England, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they carry the habits of their mother country with them into that which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
