text: they adopt. A township in Ohio is by no means dissimilar from a township
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in Massachusetts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: For details see the Revised Statutes of the State of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: York, part i. chap. xi. vol. i. pp. 336-364, entitled, "Of the Powers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Duties, and Privileges of Towns."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See in the Digest of the Laws of Pennsylvania, the words Assessors,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Collector, Constables, Overseer of the Poor, Supervisors of Highways;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in the Acts of a general nature of the State of Ohio, the Act of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: February 25, 1834, relating to townships, p. 412; besides the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dispositions relating to divers town-officers, such as Township's Clerk,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Trustees, Overseers of the Poor, Fence Viewers, Appraisers of Property,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Township's Treasurer, Constables, Supervisors of Highways.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We have seen that in Massachusetts the mainspring of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration lies in the township. It forms the common centre of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests and affections of the citizens. But this ceases to be the case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as we descend to States in which knowledge is less generally diffused,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and where the township consequently offers fewer guarantees of a wise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and active administration. As we leave New England, therefore, we find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the importance of the town is gradually transferred to the county,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which becomes the centre of administration, and the intermediate power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the Government and the citizen. In Massachusetts the business of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the county is conducted by the Court of Sessions, which is composed of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a quorum named by the Governor and his council; but the county has no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative assembly, and its expenditure is voted by the national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislature. In the great State of New York, on the contrary, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those of Ohio and Pennsylvania, the inhabitants of each county choose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a certain number of representatives, who constitute the assembly of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: county. *g The county assembly has the right of taxing the inhabitants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a certain extent; and in this respect it enjoys the privileges of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: real legislative body: at the same time it exercises an executive power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the county, frequently directs the administration of the townships,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and restricts their authority within much narrower bounds than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: See the Revised Statutes of the State of New York, part i.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chap. xi. vol. i. p. 340. Id. chap. xii. p. 366; also in the Acts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State of Ohio, an act relating to county commissioners, February 25,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1824, p. 263. See the Digest of the Laws of Pennsylvania, at the words
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: County-rates and Levies, p. 170. In the State of New York each township
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elects a representative, who has a share in the administration of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: county as well as in that of the township.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such are the principal differences which the systems of county and town
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration present in the Federal States. Were it my intention to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examine the provisions of American law minutely, I should have to point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out still further differences in the executive details of the several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities. But what I have already said may suffice to show the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general principles on which the administration of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rests. These principles are differently applied; their consequences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are more or less numerous in various localities; but they are always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: substantially the same. The laws differ, and their outward features
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change, but their character does not vary. If the township and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: county are not everywhere constituted in the same manner, it is at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true that in the United States the county and the township are always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: based upon the same principle, namely, that everyone is the best judge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of what concerns himself alone, and the most proper person to supply his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private wants. The township and the county are therefore bound to take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: care of their special interests: the State governs, but it does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interfere with their administration. Exceptions to this rule may be met
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with, but not a contrary principle.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first consequence of this doctrine has been to cause all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrates to be chosen either by or at least from amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens. As the officers are everywhere elected or appointed for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain period, it has been impossible to establish the rules of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependent series of authorities; there are almost as many independent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functionaries as there are functions, and the executive power is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disseminated in a multitude of hands. Hence arose the indispensable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessity of introducing the control of the courts of justice over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration, and the system of pecuniary penalties, by which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secondary bodies and their representatives are constrained to obey the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws. This system obtains from one end of the Union to the other. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of punishing the misconduct of public officers, or of performing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the part of the executive in urgent cases, has not, however, been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bestowed on the same judges in all the States. The Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derived the institution of justices of the peace from a common source;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but although it exists in all the States, it is not always turned to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same use. The justices of the peace everywhere participate in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration of the townships and the counties, *h either as public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers or as the judges of public misdemeanors, but in most of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States the more important classes of public offences come under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cognizance of the ordinary tribunals.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: In some of the Southern States the county courts are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: charged with all the details of the administration. See the Statutes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State of Tennessee, arts. Judiciary, Taxes, etc.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The election of public officers, or the inalienability of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions, the absence of a gradation of powers, and the introduction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a judicial control over the secondary branches of the administration,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are the universal characteristics of the American system from Maine to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Floridas. In some States (and that of New York has advanced most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this direction) traces of a centralized administration begin to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be discernible. In the State of New York the officers of the central
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government exercise, in certain cases, a sort of inspection or control
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over the secondary bodies. *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: For instance, the direction of public instruction centres
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the hands of the Government. The legislature names the members of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the University, who are denominated Regents; the Governor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and Lieutentant-Governor of the State are necessarily of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number.--Revised Statutes, vol. i. p. 455. The Regents of the University
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annually visit the colleges and academies, and make their report to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legislature. Their superintendence is not inefficient, for several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reasons: the colleges in order to become corporations stand in need of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a charter, which is only granted on the recommendation of the Regents;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every year funds are distributed by the State for the encouragement of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learning, and the Regents are the distributors of this money. See chap.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: xv. "Instruction," Revised Statutes, vol. i. p. 455.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The school-commissioners are obliged to send an annual report to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Superintendent of the Republic.--Id. p. 488.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A similar report is annually made to the same person on the number and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of the poor.--Id. p. 631.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At other times they constitute a court of appeal for the decision of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs. *j In the State of New York judicial penalties are less used
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than in other parts as a means of administration, and the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosecuting the offences of public officers is vested in fewer hands. *k
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same tendency is faintly observable in some other States; *l but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general the prominent feature of the administration in the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is its excessive local independence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: If any one conceives himself to be wronged by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: school-commissioners (who are town-officers), he can appeal to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superintendent of the primary schools, whose decision is final.--Revised
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Statutes, vol. i. p. 487.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Provisions similar to those above cited are to be met with from time to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time in the laws of the State of New York; but in general these attempts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at centralization are weak and unproductive. The great authorities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State have the right of watching and controlling the subordinate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agents, without that of rewarding or punishing them. The same individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is never empowered to give an order and to punish disobedience; he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has therefore the right of commanding, without the means of exacting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compliance. In 1830 the Superintendent of Schools complained in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his Annual Report addressed to the legislature that several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: school-commissioners had neglected, notwithstanding his application,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to furnish him with the accounts which were due. He added that if this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: omission continued he should be obliged to prosecute them, as the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directs, before the proper tribunals.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: Thus the district-attorney is directed to recover all fines
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: below the sum of fifty dollars, unless such a right has been specially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: awarded to another magistrate.--Revised Statutes, vol. i. p. 383.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: Several traces of centralization may be discovered in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts; for instance, the committees of the town-schools are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directed to make an annual report to the Secretary of State. See Laws of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts, vol. i. p. 367.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of The State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have described the townships and the administration; it now remains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for me to speak of the State and the Government. This is ground I may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pass over rapidly, without fear of being misunderstood; for all I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to say is to be found in written forms of the various constitutions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are easily to be procured. These constitutions rest upon a simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and rational theory; their forms have been adopted by all constitutional
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, and are become familiar to us. In this place, therefore, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is only necessary for me to give a short analysis; I shall endeavor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afterwards to pass judgment upon what I now describe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter V: Necessity Of Examining The Condition Of The States--Part III
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Legislative Power Of The State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Division of the Legislative Body into two Houses--Senate--House of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives--Different functions of these two Bodies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The legislative power of the State is vested in two assemblies, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first of which generally bears the name of the Senate. The Senate is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonly a legislative body; but it sometimes becomes an executive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and judicial one. It takes a part in the government in several ways,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: according to the constitution of the different States; *m but it is in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nomination of public functionaries that it most commonly assumes an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive power. It partakes of judicial power in the trial of certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political offences, and sometimes also in the decision of certain civil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases. *n The number of its members is always small. The other branch of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legislature, which is usually called the House of Representatives,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has no share whatever in the administration, and only takes a part in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the judicial power inasmuch as it impeaches public functionaries before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Senate. The members of the two Houses are nearly everywhere subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the same conditions of election. They are chosen in the same manner,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and by the same citizens. The only difference which exists between them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is, that the term for which the Senate is chosen is in general longer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than that of the House of Representatives. The latter seldom remain in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: office longer than a year; the former usually sit two or three years.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: By granting to the senators the privilege of being chosen for several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years, and being renewed seriatim, the law takes care to preserve in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative body a nucleus of men already accustomed to public business,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and capable of exercising a salutary influence upon the junior members.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: In Massachusetts the Senate is not invested with any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administrative functions.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: As in the State of New York.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans, plainly, did not desire, by this separation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative body into two branches, to make one house hereditary and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other elective; one aristocratic and the other democratic. It was not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their object to create in the one a bulwark to power, whilst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other represented the interests and passions of the people. The only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages which result from the present constitution of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States are the division of the legislative power and the consequent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: check upon political assemblies; with the creation of a tribunal of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeal for the revision of the laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Time and experience, however, have convinced the Americans that if these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are its only advantages, the division of the legislative power is still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a principle of the greatest necessity. Pennsylvania was the only one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States which at first attempted to establish a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: House of Assembly, and Franklin himself was so far carried away by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary consequences of the principle of the sovereignty of the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to have concurred in the measure; but the Pennsylvanians were soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to change the law, and to create two Houses. Thus the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the division of the legislative power was finally established, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its necessity may henceforward be regarded as a demonstrated truth. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theory, which was nearly unknown to the republics of antiquity--which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was introduced into the world almost by accident, like so many other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great truths--and misunderstood by several modern nations, is at length
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become an axiom in the political science of the present age.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [See Benjamin Franklin]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Executive Power Of The State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Office of Governor in an American State--The place he occupies in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relation to the Legislature--His rights and his duties--His dependence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The executive power of the State may with truth be said to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represented by the Governor, although he enjoys but a portion of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights. The supreme magistrate, under the title of Governor, is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: official moderator and counsellor of the legislature. He is armed with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a veto or suspensive power, which allows him to stop, or at least to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retard, its movements at pleasure. He lays the wants of the country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before the legislative body, and points out the means which he thinks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be usefully employed in providing for them; he is the natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executor of its decrees in all the undertakings which interest the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation at large. *o In the absence of the legislature, the Governor is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bound to take all necessary steps to guard the State against violent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shocks and unforeseen dangers. The whole military power of the State is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the disposal of the Governor. He is the commander of the militia, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: head of the armed force. When the authority, which is by general consent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: awarded to the laws, is disregarded, the Governor puts himself at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the head of the armed force of the State, to quell resistance, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restore order. Lastly, the Governor takes no share in the administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of townships and counties, except it be indirectly in the nomination of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Justices of the Peace, which nomination he has not the power to cancel.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *p The Governor is an elected magistrate, and is generally chosen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for one or two years only; so that he always continues to be strictly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependent upon the majority who returned him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: Practically speaking, it is not always the Governor who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executes the plans of the Legislature; it often happens that the latter,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in voting a measure, names special agents to superintend the execution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of it.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: In some of the States the justices of the peace are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elected by the Governor.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Political Effects Of The System Of Local Administration In The United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Necessary distinction between the general centralization of Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the centralization of the local administration--Local administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not centralized in the United States: great general centralization of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Government--Some bad consequences resulting to the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the local administration--Administrative advantages attending
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this order of things--The power which conducts the Government is less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regular, less enlightened, less learned, but much greater than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe--Political advantages of this order of things--In the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States the interests of the country are everywhere kept in view--Support
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: given to the Government by the community--Provincial institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more necessary in proportion as the social condition becomes more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic--Reason of this.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Centralization is become a word of general and daily use, without any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precise meaning being attached to it. Nevertheless, there exist two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinct kinds of centralization, which it is necessary to discriminate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with accuracy. Certain interests are common to all parts of a nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such as the enactment of its general laws and the maintenance of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign relations. Other interests are peculiar to certain parts of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation; such, for instance, as the business of different townships. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power which directs the general interests is centred in one place,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or vested in the same persons, it constitutes a central government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In like manner the power of directing partial or local interests,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when brought together into one place, constitutes what may be termed a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central administration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Upon some points these two kinds of centralization coalesce; but by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classifying the objects which fall more particularly within the province
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of each of them, they may easily be distinguished. It is evident that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central government acquires immense power when united to administrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralization. Thus combined, it accustoms men to set their own will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitually and completely aside; to submit, not only for once, or upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one point, but in every respect, and at all times. Not only, therefore,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does this union of power subdue them compulsorily, but it affects them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the ordinary habits of life, and influences each individual, first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separately and then collectively.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These two kinds of centralization mutually assist and attract each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other; but they must not be supposed to be inseparable. It is impossible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to imagine a more completely central government than that which existed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in France under Louis XIV.; when the same individual was the author and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the interpreter of the laws, and the representative of France at home
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and abroad, he was justified in asserting that the State was identified
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with his person. Nevertheless, the administration was much less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralized under Louis XIV. than it is at the present day.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In England the centralization of the government is carried to great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfection; the State has the compact vigor of a man, and by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sole act of its will it puts immense engines in motion, and wields or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collects the efforts of its authority. Indeed, I cannot conceive that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a nation can enjoy a secure or prosperous existence without a powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralization of government. But I am of opinion that a central
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration enervates the nations in which it exists by incessantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diminishing their public spirit. If such an administration succeeds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in condensing at a given moment, on a given point, all the disposable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources of a people, it impairs at least the renewal of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources. It may ensure a victory in the hour of strife, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually relaxes the sinews of strength. It may contribute admirably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the transient greatness of a man, but it cannot ensure the durable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity of a nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If we pay proper attention, we shall find that whenever it is said
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that a State cannot act because it has no central point, it is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralization of the government in which it is deficient. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently asserted, and we are prepared to assent to the proposition,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the German empire was never able to bring all its powers into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action. But the reason was, that the State was never able to enforce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience to its general laws, because the several members of that great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body always claimed the right, or found the means, of refusing their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operation to the representatives of the common authority, even in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs which concerned the mass of the people; in other words, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there was no centralization of government. The same remark is applicable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the Middle Ages; the cause of all the confusion of feudal society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was that the control, not only of local but of general interests, was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divided amongst a thousand hands, and broken up in a thousand different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ways; the absence of a central government prevented the nations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe from advancing with energy in any straightforward course.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We have shown that in the United States no central administration and no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependent series of public functionaries exist. Local authority has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carried to lengths which no European nation could endure without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great inconvenience, and which has even produced some disadvantageous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences in America. But in the United States the centralization
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Government is complete; and it would be easy to prove that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national power is more compact than it has ever been in the old nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe. Not only is there but one legislative body in each State;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only does there exist but one source of political authority;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but district assemblies and county courts have not in general been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multiplied, lest they should be tempted to exceed their administrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duties, and interfere with the Government. In America the legislature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of each State is supreme; nothing can impede its authority; neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges, nor local immunities, nor personal influence, nor even the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empire of reason, since it represents that majority which claims to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sole organ of reason. Its own determination is, therefore, the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limit to this action. In juxtaposition to it, and under its immediate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: control, is the representative of the executive power, whose duty it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to constrain the refractory to submit by superior force. The only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: symptom of weakness lies in certain details of the action of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government. The American republics have no standing armies to intimidate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a discontented minority; but as no minority has as yet been reduced to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declare open war, the necessity of an army has not been felt. *q The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State usually employs the officers of the township or the county to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deal with the citizens. Thus, for instance, in New England, the assessor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fixes the rate of taxes; the collector receives them; the town-treasurer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transmits the amount to the public treasury; and the disputes which may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arise are brought before the ordinary courts of justice. This method of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collecting taxes is slow as well as inconvenient, and it would prove a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetual hindrance to a Government whose pecuniary demands were large.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is desirable that, in whatever materially affects its existence, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government should be served by officers of its own, appointed by itself,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removable at pleasure, and accustomed to rapid methods of proceeding.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But it will always be easy for the central government, organized as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is in America, to introduce new and more efficacious modes of action,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportioned to its wants. [Footnote q: [The Civil War of 1860-65
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cruelly belied this statement, and in the course of the struggle the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North alone called two millions and a half of men to arms; but to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor of the United States it must be added that, with the cessation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the contest, this army disappeared as rapidly as it had been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raised.--Translator's Note.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The absence of a central government will not, then, as has often been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asserted, prove the destruction of the republics of the New World;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: far from supposing that the American governments are not sufficiently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralized, I shall prove hereafter that they are too much so. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative bodies daily encroach upon the authority of the Government,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their tendency, like that of the French Convention, is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appropriate it entirely to themselves. Under these circumstances the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social power is constantly changing hands, because it is subordinate to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of the people, which is too apt to forget the maxims of wisdom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of foresight in the consciousness of its strength: hence arises its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: danger; and thus its vigor, and not its impotence, will probably be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause of its ultimate destruction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The system of local administration produces several different effects in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America. The Americans seem to me to have outstepped the limits of sound
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: policy in isolating the administration of the Government; for order,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even in second-rate affairs, is a matter of national importance. *r As
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State has no administrative functionaries of its own, stationed on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different points of its territory, to whom it can give a common impulse,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the consequence is that it rarely attempts to issue any general police
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulations. The want of these regulations is severely felt, and is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently observed by Europeans. The appearance of disorder which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevails on the surface leads him at first to imagine that society is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a state of anarchy; nor does he perceive his mistake till he has gone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deeper into the subject. Certain undertakings are of importance to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole State; but they cannot be put in execution, because there is no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national administration to direct them. Abandoned to the exertions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the towns or counties, under the care of elected or temporary agents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they lead to no result, or at least to no durable benefit.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: The authority which represents the State ought not, I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: think, to waive the right of inspecting the local administration, even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when it does not interfere more actively. Suppose, for instance, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an agent of the Government was stationed at some appointed spot in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, to prosecute the misdemeanors of the town and county officers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would not a more uniform order be the result, without in any way
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compromising the independence of the township? Nothing of the kind,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however, exists in America: there is nothing above the county-courts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which have, as it were, only an incidental cognizance of the offences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are meant to repress.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The partisans of centralization in Europe are wont to maintain that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government directs the affairs of each locality better than the citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could do it for themselves; this may be true when the central power is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlightened, and when the local districts are ignorant; when it is as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alert as they are slow; when it is accustomed to act, and they to obey.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indeed, it is evident that this double tendency must augment with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase of centralization, and that the readiness of the one and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incapacity of the others must become more and more prominent. But I deny
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that such is the case when the people is as enlightened, as awake to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests, and as accustomed to reflect on them, as the Americans are. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am persuaded, on the contrary, that in this case the collective strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the citizens will always conduce more efficaciously to the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: welfare than the authority of the Government. It is difficult to point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out with certainty the means of arousing a sleeping population, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: giving it passions and knowledge which it does not possess; it is, I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am well aware, an arduous task to persuade men to busy themselves about
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own affairs; and it would frequently be easier to interest them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the punctilios of court etiquette than in the repairs of their common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dwelling. But whenever a central administration affects to supersede
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the persons most interested, I am inclined to suppose that it is either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misled or desirous to mislead. However enlightened and however skilful a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central power may be, it cannot of itself embrace all the details of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of a great nation. Such vigilance exceeds the powers of man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And when it attempts to create and set in motion so many complicated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: springs, it must submit to a very imperfect result, or consume itself in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bootless efforts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Centralization succeeds more easily, indeed, in subjecting the external
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions of men to a certain uniformity, which at least commands our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regard, independently of the objects to which it is applied, like those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: devotees who worship the statue and forget the deity it represents.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Centralization imparts without difficulty an admirable regularity to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: routine of business; provides for the details of the social police
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with sagacity; represses the smallest disorder and the most petty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misdemeanors; maintains society in a status quo alike secure from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: improvement and decline; and perpetuates a drowsy precision in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conduct of affairs, which is hailed by the heads of the administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a sign of perfect order and public tranquillity: *s in short, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excels more in prevention than in action. Its force deserts it when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society is to be disturbed or accelerated in its course; and if once the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operation of private citizens is necessary to the furtherance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its measures, the secret of its impotence is disclosed. Even whilst it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invokes their assistance, it is on the condition that they shall act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exactly as much as the Government chooses, and exactly in the manner it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appoints. They are to take charge of the details, without aspiring to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guide the system; they are to work in a dark and subordinate sphere, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only to judge the acts in which they have themselves cooperated by their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results. These, however, are not conditions on which the alliance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the human will is to be obtained; its carriage must be free and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions responsible, or (such is the constitution of man) the citizen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had rather remain a passive spectator than a dependent actor in schemes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with which he is unacquainted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote s: China appears to me to present the most perfect instance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that species of well-being which a completely central administration may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: furnish to the nations among which it exists. Travellers assure us that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Chinese have peace without happiness, industry without improvement,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stability without strength, and public order without public morality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The condition of society is always tolerable, never excellent. I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convinced that, when China is opened to European observation, it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be found to contain the most perfect model of a central administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which exists in the universe.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is undeniable that the want of those uniform regulations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: control the conduct of every inhabitant of France is not unfrequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: felt in the United States. Gross instances of social indifference and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neglect are to be met with, and from time to time disgraceful blemishes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are seen in complete contrast with the surrounding civilization. Useful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings which cannot succeed without perpetual attention and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rigorous exactitude are very frequently abandoned in the end; for in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, as well as in other countries, the people is subject to sudden
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impulses and momentary exertions. The European who is accustomed to find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a functionary always at hand to interfere with all he undertakes has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some difficulty in accustoming himself to the complex mechanism of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration of the townships. In general it may be affirmed that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lesser details of the police, which render life easy and comfortable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are neglected in America; but that the essential guarantees of man in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society are as strong there as elsewhere. In America the power which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conducts the Government is far less regular, less enlightened, and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learned, but an hundredfold more authoritative than in Europe. In no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country in the world do the citizens make such exertions for the common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weal; and I am acquainted with no people which has established schools
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as numerous and as efficacious, places of public worship better suited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the wants of the inhabitants, or roads kept in better repair.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Uniformity or permanence of design, the minute arrangement of details,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *t and the perfection of an ingenious administration, must not be sought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for in the United States; but it will be easy to find, on the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand, the symptoms of a power which, if it is somewhat barbarous, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least robust; and of an existence which is checkered with accidents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indeed, but cheered at the same time by animation and effort.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote t: A writer of talent, who, in the comparison which he has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: drawn between the finances of France and those of the United States, has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proved that ingenuity cannot always supply the place of a knowledge of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facts, very justly reproaches the Americans for the sort of confusion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which exists in the accounts of the expenditure in the townships; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after giving the model of a departmental budget in France, he adds:--"We
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are indebted to centralization, that admirable invention of a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man, for the uniform order and method which prevail alike in all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: municipal budgets, from the largest town to the humblest commune."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whatever may be my admiration of this result, when I see the communes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of France, with their excellent system of accounts, plunged into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the grossest ignorance of their true interests, and abandoned to so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incorrigible an apathy that they seem to vegetate rather than to live;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when, on the other hand, I observe the activity, the information, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the spirit of enterprise which keep society in perpetual labor, in those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American townships whose budgets are drawn up with small method and with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still less uniformity, I am struck by the spectacle; for to my mind the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: end of a good government is to ensure the welfare of a people, and not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to establish order and regularity in the midst of its misery and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distress. I am therefore led to suppose that the prosperity of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American townships and the apparent confusion of their accounts, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distress of the French communes and the perfection of their budget,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be attributable to the same cause. At any rate I am suspicious of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: benefit which is united to so many evils, and I am not averse to an evil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is compensated by so many benefits.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Granting for an instant that the villages and counties of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States would be more usefully governed by a remote authority which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they had never seen than by functionaries taken from the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them--admitting, for the sake of argument, that the country would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more secure, and the resources of society better employed, if the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration centred in a single arm--still the political advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the Americans derive from their system would induce me to prefer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it to the contrary plan. It profits me but little, after all, that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vigilant authority should protect the tranquillity of my pleasures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and constantly avert all dangers from my path, without my care or my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concern, if this same authority is the absolute mistress of my liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of my life, and if it so monopolizes all the energy of existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that when it languishes everything languishes around it, that when it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sleeps everything must sleep, that when it dies the State itself must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perish.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In certain countries of Europe the natives consider themselves as a kind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of settlers, indifferent to the fate of the spot upon which they live.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greatest changes are effected without their concurrence and (unless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chance may have apprised them of the event) without their knowledge; nay
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more, the citizen is unconcerned as to the condition of his village, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: police of his street, the repairs of the church or of the parsonage; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he looks upon all these things as unconnected with himself, and as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property of a powerful stranger whom he calls the Government. He has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only a life-interest in these possessions, and he entertains no notions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of ownership or of improvement. This want of interest in his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs goes so far that, if his own safety or that of his children is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endangered, instead of trying to avert the peril, he will fold his arms,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and wait till the nation comes to his assistance. This same individual,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who has so completely sacrificed his own free will, has no natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensity to obedience; he cowers, it is true, before the pettiest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officer; but he braves the law with the spirit of a conquered foe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as soon as its superior force is removed: his oscillations between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servitude and license are perpetual. When a nation has arrived at this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state it must either change its customs and its laws or perish: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: source of public virtue is dry, and, though it may contain subjects,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the race of citizens is extinct. Such communities are a natural prey to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign conquests, and if they do not disappear from the scene of life,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is because they are surrounded by other nations similar or inferior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to themselves: it is because the instinctive feeling of their country's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: claims still exists in their hearts; and because an involuntary pride in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the name it bears, or a vague reminiscence of its bygone fame, suffices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to give them the impulse of self-preservation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nor can the prodigious exertions made by tribes in the defence of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country to which they did not belong be adduced in favor of such a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system; for it will be found that in these cases their main incitement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was religion. The permanence, the glory, or the prosperity of the nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were become parts of their faith, and in defending the country they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabited they defended that Holy City of which they were all citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Turkish tribes have never taken an active share in the conduct of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the affairs of society, but they accomplished stupendous enterprises as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long as the victories of the Sultan were the triumphs of the Mohammedan
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faith. In the present age they are in rapid decay, because their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion is departing, and despotism only remains. Montesquieu, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attributed to absolute power an authority peculiar to itself, did it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as I conceive, an undeserved honor; for despotism, taken by itself,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can produce no durable results. On close inspection we shall find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that religion, and not fear, has ever been the cause of the long-lived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity of an absolute government. Whatever exertions may be made, no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true power can be founded among men which does not depend upon the free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: union of their inclinations; and patriotism and religion are the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two motives in the world which can permanently direct the whole of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body politic to one end.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Laws cannot succeed in rekindling the ardor of an extinguished faith,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but men may be interested in the fate of their country by the laws. By
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this influence the vague impulse of patriotism, which never abandons the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human heart, may be directed and revived; and if it be connected with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the thoughts, the passions, and the daily habits of life, it may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consolidated into a durable and rational sentiment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Let it not be said that the time for the experiment is already past; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the old age of nations is not like the old age of men, and every fresh
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generation is a new people ready for the care of the legislator.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not the administrative but the political effects of the local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system that I most admire in America. In the United States the interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the country are everywhere kept in view; they are an object of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solicitude to the people of the whole Union, and every citizen is as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: warmly attached to them as if they were his own. He takes pride in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glory of his nation; he boasts of its success, to which he conceives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself to have contributed, and he rejoices in the general prosperity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by which he profits. The feeling he entertains towards the State is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: analogous to that which unites him to his family, and it is by a kind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: egotism that he interests himself in the welfare of his country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The European generally submits to a public officer because he represents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a superior force; but to an American he represents a right. In America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may be said that no one renders obedience to man, but to justice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to law. If the opinion which the citizen entertains of himself is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exaggerated, it is at least salutary; he unhesitatingly confides in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own powers, which appear to him to be all-sufficient. When a private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual meditates an undertaking, however directly connected it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be with the welfare of society, he never thinks of soliciting the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operation of the Government, but he publishes his plan, offers to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: execute it himself, courts the assistance of other individuals, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggles manfully against all obstacles. Undoubtedly he is often less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: successful than the State might have been in his position; but in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: end the sum of these private undertakings far exceeds all that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government could have done.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the administrative authority is within the reach of the citizens,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whom it in some degree represents, it excites neither their jealousy nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their hatred; as its resources are limited, every one feels that he must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not rely solely on its assistance. Thus, when the administration thinks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fit to interfere, it is not abandoned to itself as in Europe; the duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the private citizens are not supposed to have lapsed because the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State assists in their fulfilment, but every one is ready, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, to guide and to support it. This action of individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions, joined to that of the public authorities, frequently performs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what the most energetic central administration would be unable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: execute. It would be easy to adduce several facts in proof of what I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advance, but I had rather give only one, with which I am more thoroughly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquainted. *u In America the means which the authorities have at their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disposal for the discovery of crimes and the arrest of criminals are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: few. The State police does not exist, and passports are unknown. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: criminal police of the United States cannot be compared to that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France; the magistrates and public prosecutors are not numerous, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examinations of prisoners are rapid and oral. Nevertheless in no country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does crime more rarely elude punishment. The reason is, that every one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceives himself to be interested in furnishing evidence of the act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: committed, and in stopping the delinquent. During my stay in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States I witnessed the spontaneous formation of committees for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit and prosecution of a man who had committed a great crime in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a certain county. In Europe a criminal is an unhappy being who is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggling for his life against the ministers of justice, whilst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population is merely a spectator of the conflict; in America he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: looked upon as an enemy of the human race, and the whole of mankind is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote u: See Appendix, I.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe that provincial institutions are useful to all nations, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nowhere do they appear to me to be more indispensable than amongst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people. In an aristocracy order can always be maintained in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the midst of liberty, and as the rulers have a great deal to lose order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to them a first-rate consideration. In like manner an aristocracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protects the people from the excesses of despotism, because it always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possesses an organized power ready to resist a despot. But a democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without provincial institutions has no security against these evils. How
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can a populace, unaccustomed to freedom in small concerns, learn to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: use it temperately in great affairs? What resistance can be offered to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tyranny in a country where every private individual is impotent, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the citizens are united by no common tie? Those who dread the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: license of the mob, and those who fear the rule of absolute power, ought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike to desire the progressive growth of provincial liberties.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, I am convinced that democratic nations are most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exposed to fall beneath the yoke of a central administration, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several reasons, amongst which is the following. The constant tendency
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these nations is to concentrate all the strength of the Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the hands of the only power which directly represents the people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because beyond the people nothing is to be perceived but a mass of equal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals confounded together. But when the same power is already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in possession of all the attributes of the Government, it can scarcely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refrain from penetrating into the details of the administration, and an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opportunity of doing so is sure to present itself in the end, as was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the case in France. In the French Revolution there were two impulses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in opposite directions, which must never be confounded--the one was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to liberty, the other to despotism. Under the ancient monarchy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the King was the sole author of the laws, and below the power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign certain vestiges of provincial institutions, half destroyed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were still distinguishable. These provincial institutions were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incoherent, ill compacted, and frequently absurd; in the hands of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the aristocracy they had sometimes been converted into instruments of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppression. The Revolution declared itself the enemy of royalty and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provincial institutions at the same time; it confounded all that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had preceded it--despotic power and the checks to its abuses--in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indiscriminate hatred, and its tendency was at once to overthrow and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to centralize. This double character of the French Revolution is a fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has been adroitly handled by the friends of absolute power. Can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they be accused of laboring in the cause of despotism when they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defending that central administration which was one of the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innovations of the Revolution? *v In this manner popularity may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conciliated with hostility to the rights of the people, and the secret
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slave of tyranny may be the professed admirer of freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote v: See Appendix K.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have visited the two nations in which the system of provincial liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has been most perfectly established, and I have listened to the opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of different parties in those countries. In America I met with men who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secretly aspired to destroy the democratic institutions of the Union; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England I found others who attacked the aristocracy openly, but I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know of no one who does not regard provincial independence as a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: benefit. In both countries I have heard a thousand different causes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assigned for the evils of the State, but the local system was never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mentioned amongst them. I have heard citizens attribute the power and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity of their country to a multitude of reasons, but they all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: placed the advantages of local institutions in the foremost rank. Am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I to suppose that when men who are naturally so divided on religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions and on political theories agree on one point (and that one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of which they have daily experience), they are all in error? The only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations which deny the utility of provincial liberties are those which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have fewest of them; in other words, those who are unacquainted with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institution are the only persons who pass a censure upon it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VI: Judicial Power In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Anglo-Americans have retained the characteristics of judicial power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are common to all nations--They have, however, made it a powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political organ--How--In what the judicial system of the Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differs from that of all other nations--Why the American judges have the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of declaring the laws to be unconstitutional--How they use this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right--Precautions taken by the legislator to prevent its abuse.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Judicial Power In The United States And Its Influence On Political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have thought it essential to devote a separate chapter to the judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authorities of the United States, lest their great political importance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be lessened in the reader's eyes by a merely incidental mention
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them. Confederations have existed in other countries beside America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and republics have not been established upon the shores of the New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: World alone; the representative system of government has been adopted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in several States of Europe, but I am not aware that any nation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the globe has hitherto organized a judicial power on the principle now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adopted by the Americans. The judicial organization of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the institution which a stranger has the greatest difficulty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in understanding. He hears the authority of a judge invoked in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political occurrences of every day, and he naturally concludes that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States the judges are important political functionaries;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless, when he examines the nature of the tribunals, they offer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing which is contrary to the usual habits and privileges of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bodies, and the magistrates seem to him to interfere in public affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of chance, but by a chance which recurs every day.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the Parliament of Paris remonstrated, or refused to enregister an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: edict, or when it summoned a functionary accused of malversation to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bar, its political influence as a judicial body was clearly visible; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing of the kind is to be seen in the United States. The Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have retained all the ordinary characteristics of judicial authority,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and have carefully restricted its action to the ordinary circle of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first characteristic of judicial power in all nations is the duty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of arbitration. But rights must be contested in order to warrant the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interference of a tribunal; and an action must be brought to obtain the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decision of a judge. As long, therefore, as the law is uncontested, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judicial authority is not called upon to discuss it, and it may exist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without being perceived. When a judge in a given case attacks a law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relating to that case, he extends the circle of his customary duties,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without however stepping beyond it; since he is in some measure obliged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to decide upon the law in order to decide the case. But if he pronounces
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon a law without resting upon a case, he clearly steps beyond his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere, and invades that of the legislative authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The second characteristic of judicial power is that it pronounces on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: special cases, and not upon general principles. If a judge in deciding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a particular point destroys a general principle, by passing a judgment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which tends to reject all the inferences from that principle, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently to annul it, he remains within the ordinary limits of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions. But if he directly attacks a general principle without having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a particular case in view, he leaves the circle in which all nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have agreed to confine his authority, he assumes a more important, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps a more useful, influence than that of the magistrate, but he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceases to be a representative of the judicial power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The third characteristic of the judicial power is its inability to act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unless it is appealed to, or until it has taken cognizance of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affair. This characteristic is less general than the other two; but,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding the exceptions, I think it may be regarded as essential.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The judicial power is by its nature devoid of action; it must be put in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: motion in order to produce a result. When it is called upon to repress a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crime, it punishes the criminal; when a wrong is to be redressed, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ready to redress it; when an act requires interpretation, it is prepared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to interpret it; but it does not pursue criminals, hunt out wrongs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or examine into evidence of its own accord. A judicial functionary who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should open proceedings, and usurp the censorship of the laws, would in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some measure do violence to the passive nature of his authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans have retained these three distinguishing characteristics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the judicial power; an American judge can only pronounce a decision
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when litigation has arisen, he is only conversant with special cases,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and he cannot act until the cause has been duly brought before the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: court. His position is therefore perfectly similar to that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrate of other nations; and he is nevertheless invested with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense political power. If the sphere of his authority and his means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action are the same as those of other judges, it may be asked whence he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derives a power which they do not possess. The cause of this difference
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lies in the simple fact that the Americans have acknowledged the right
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the judges to found their decisions on the constitution rather than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
