text: on the laws. In other words, they have left them at liberty not to apply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such laws as may appear to them to be unconstitutional.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am aware that a similar right has been claimed--but claimed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vain--by courts of justice in other countries; but in America it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recognized by all authorities; and not a party, nor so much as an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual, is found to contest it. This fact can only be explained by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principles of the American constitution. In France the constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is (or at least is supposed to be) immutable; and the received theory is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that no power has the right of changing any part of it. In England the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Parliament has an acknowledged right to modify the constitution; as,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, the constitution may undergo perpetual changes, it does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not in reality exist; the Parliament is at once a legislative and a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constituent assembly. The political theories of America are more simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more rational. An American constitution is not supposed to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immutable as in France, nor is it susceptible of modification by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinary powers of society as in England. It constitutes a detached
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole, which, as it represents the determination of the whole people, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no less binding on the legislator than on the private citizen, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which may be altered by the will of the people in predetermined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases, according to established rules. In America the constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may therefore vary, but as long as it exists it is the origin of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, and the sole vehicle of the predominating force. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: [The fifth article of the original Constitution of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States provides the mode in which amendments of the Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be made. Amendments must be proposed by two-thirds of both Houses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Congress, and ratified by the Legislatures of three-fourths of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several States. Fifteen amendments of the Constitution have been made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at different times since 1789, the most important of which are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth, framed and ratified after the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Civil War. The original Constitution of the United States, followed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by these fifteen amendments, is printed at the end of this edition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: --Translator's Note, 1874.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is easy to perceive in what manner these differences must act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the position and the rights of the judicial bodies in the three
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries I have cited. If in France the tribunals were authorized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to disobey the laws on the ground of their being opposed to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution, the supreme power would in fact be placed in their hands,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since they alone would have the right of interpreting a constitution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the clauses of which can be modified by no authority. They would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore take the place of the nation, and exercise as absolute a sway
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over society as the inherent weakness of judicial power would allow them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to do. Undoubtedly, as the French judges are incompetent to declare a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law to be unconstitutional, the power of changing the constitution is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indirectly given to the legislative body, since no legal barrier would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppose the alterations which it might prescribe. But it is better to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grant the power of changing the constitution of the people to men who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represent (however imperfectly) the will of the people, than to men who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represent no one but themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would be still more unreasonable to invest the English judges with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the right of resisting the decisions of the legislative body, since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Parliament which makes the laws also makes the constitution; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently a law emanating from the three powers of the State can in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no case be unconstitutional. But neither of these remarks is applicable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to America.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the constitution governs the legislator as much as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the private citizen; as it is the first of laws it cannot be modified
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a law, and it is therefore just that the tribunals should obey the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution in preference to any law. This condition is essential to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of the judicature, for to select that legal obligation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by which he is most strictly bound is the natural right of every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrate.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In France the constitution is also the first of laws, and the judges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have the same right to take it as the ground of their decisions, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were they to exercise this right they must perforce encroach on rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more sacred than their own, namely, on those of society, in whose name
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are acting. In this case the State-motive clearly prevails over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: motives of an individual. In America, where the nation can always reduce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its magistrates to obedience by changing its constitution, no danger of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this kind is to be feared. Upon this point, therefore, the political and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the logical reasons agree, and the people as well as the judges preserve
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their privileges.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whenever a law which the judge holds to be unconstitutional is argued
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a tribunal of the United States he may refuse to admit it as a rule;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this power is the only one which is peculiar to the American magistrate,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it gives rise to immense political influence. Few laws can escape
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the searching analysis of the judicial power for any length of time,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for there are few which are not prejudicial to some private interest or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, and none which may not be brought before a court of justice by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the choice of parties, or by the necessity of the case. But from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time that a judge has refused to apply any given law in a case, that law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: loses a portion of its moral cogency. The persons to whose interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is prejudicial learn that means exist of evading its authority, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: similar suits are multiplied, until it becomes powerless. One of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two alternatives must then be resorted to: the people must alter the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution, or the legislature must repeal the law. The political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power which the Americans have intrusted to their courts of justice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is therefore immense, but the evils of this power are considerably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diminished by the obligation which has been imposed of attacking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws through the courts of justice alone. If the judge had been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empowered to contest the laws on the ground of theoretical generalities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if he had been enabled to open an attack or to pass a censure on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator, he would have played a prominent part in the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere; and as the champion or the antagonist of a party, he would have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrayed the hostile passions of the nation in the conflict. But when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a judge contests a law applied to some particular case in an obscure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceeding, the importance of his attack is concealed from the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gaze, his decision bears upon the interest of an individual, and if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the law is slighted it is only collaterally. Moreover, although it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: censured, it is not abolished; its moral force may be diminished, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its cogency is by no means suspended, and its final destruction can only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be accomplished by the reiterated attacks of judicial functionaries. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will readily be understood that by connecting the censorship of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws with the private interests of members of the community, and by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intimately uniting the prosecution of the law with the prosecution of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an individual, legislation is protected from wanton assailants, and from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the daily aggressions of party spirit. The errors of the legislator are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exposed whenever their evil consequences are most felt, and it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always a positive and appreciable fact which serves as the basis of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosecution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am inclined to believe this practice of the American courts to be at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once the most favorable to liberty as well as to public order. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judge could only attack the legislator openly and directly, he would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes be afraid to oppose any resistance to his will; and at other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moments party spirit might encourage him to brave it at every turn.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The laws would consequently be attacked when the power from which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emanate is weak, and obeyed when it is strong. That is to say, when it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be useful to respect them they would be contested, and when it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be easy to convert them into an instrument of oppression they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be respected. But the American judge is brought into the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arena independently of his own will. He only judges the law because he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is obliged to judge a case. The political question which he is called
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon to resolve is connected with the interest of the suitors, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot refuse to decide it without abdicating the duties of his post.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He performs his functions as a citizen by fulfilling the precise duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which belong to his profession as a magistrate. It is true that upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this system the judicial censorship which is exercised by the courts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice over the legislation cannot extend to all laws indiscriminately,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inasmuch as some of them can never give rise to that exact species
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of contestation which is termed a lawsuit; and even when such a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contestation is possible, it may happen that no one cares to bring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it before a court of justice. The Americans have often felt this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disadvantage, but they have left the remedy incomplete, lest they should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: give it an efficacy which might in some cases prove dangerous. Within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these limits the power vested in the American courts of justice of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pronouncing a statute to be unconstitutional forms one of the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful barriers which has ever been devised against the tyranny of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political assemblies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Other Powers Granted To American Judges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The United States all the citizens have the right of indicting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public functionaries before the ordinary tribunals--How they use this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right--Art. 75 of the French Constitution of the An VIII--The Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the English cannot understand the purport of this clause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is perfectly natural that in a free country like America all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens should have the right of indicting public functionaries before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ordinary tribunals, and that all the judges should have the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: punishing public offences. The right granted to the courts of justice of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judging the agents of the executive government, when they have violated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws, is so natural a one that it cannot be looked upon as an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary privilege. Nor do the springs of government appear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me to be weakened in the United States by the custom which renders all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public officers responsible to the judges of the land. The Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem, on the contrary, to have increased by this means that respect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is due to the authorities, and at the same time to have rendered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who are in power more scrupulous of offending public opinion. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was struck by the small number of political trials which occur in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States, but I had no difficulty in accounting for this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstance. A lawsuit, of whatever nature it may be, is always a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult and expensive undertaking. It is easy to attack a public man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a journal, but the motives which can warrant an action at law must be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: serious. A solid ground of complaint must therefore exist to induce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an individual to prosecute a public officer, and public officers are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: careful not to furnish these grounds of complaint when they are afraid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of being prosecuted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This does not depend upon the republican form of American institutions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the same facts present themselves in England. These two nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not regard the impeachment of the principal officers of State as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficient guarantee of their independence. But they hold that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of minor prosecutions, which are within the reach of the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, is a better pledge of freedom than those great judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions which are rarely employed until it is too late.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the Middle Ages, when it was very difficult to overtake offenders,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the judges inflicted the most dreadful tortures on the few who were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrested, which by no means diminished the number of crimes. It has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since been discovered that when justice is more certain and more mild,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is at the same time more efficacious. The English and the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hold that tyranny and oppression are to be treated like any other crime,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by lessening the penalty and facilitating conviction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the year VIII of the French Republic a constitution was drawn up in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the following clause was introduced: "Art. 75. All the agents of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the government below the rank of ministers can only be prosecuted for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offences relating to their several functions by virtue of a decree of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Conseil d'Etat; in which the case the prosecution takes place before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ordinary tribunals." This clause survived the "Constitution de l'An
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: VIII," and it is still maintained in spite of the just complaints of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nation. I have always found the utmost difficulty in explaining its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: meaning to Englishmen or Americans. They were at once led to conclude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the Conseil d'Etat in France was a great tribunal, established in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the centre of the kingdom, which exercised a preliminary and somewhat
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tyrannical jurisdiction in all political causes. But when I told them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the Conseil d'Etat was not a judicial body, in the common sense of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the term, but an administrative council composed of men dependent on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Crown, so that the king, after having ordered one of his servants,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called a Prefect, to commit an injustice, has the power of commanding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another of his servants, called a Councillor of State, to prevent the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former from being punished; when I demonstrated to them that the citizen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who has been injured by the order of the sovereign is obliged to solicit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the sovereign permission to obtain redress, they refused to credit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so flagrant an abuse, and were tempted to accuse me of falsehood or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of ignorance. It frequently happened before the Revolution that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Parliament issued a warrant against a public officer who had committed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an offence, and sometimes the proceedings were stopped by the authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Crown, which enforced compliance with its absolute and despotic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will. It is painful to perceive how much lower we are sunk than our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forefathers, since we allow things to pass under the color of justice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the sanction of the law which violence alone could impose upon them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VII: Political Jurisdiction In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Definition of political jurisdiction--What is understood by political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction in France, in England, and in the United States--In America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the political judge can only pass sentence on public officers--He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more frequently passes a sentence of removal from office than a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penalty--Political jurisdiction as it exists in the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is, notwithstanding its mildness, and perhaps in consequence of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mildness, a most powerful instrument in the hands of the majority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Political Jurisdiction In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I understand, by political jurisdiction, that temporary right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pronouncing a legal decision with which a political body may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invested.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In absolute governments no utility can accrue from the introduction of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary forms of procedure; the prince in whose name an offender
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is prosecuted is as much the sovereign of the courts of justice as of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything else, and the idea which is entertained of his power is of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself a sufficient security. The only thing he has to fear is, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the external formalities of justice should be neglected, and that his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority should be dishonored from a wish to render it more absolute.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in most free countries, in which the majority can never exercise the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same influence upon the tribunals as an absolute monarch, the judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power has occasionally been vested for a time in the representatives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation. It has been thought better to introduce a temporary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confusion between the functions of the different authorities than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violate the necessary principle of the unity of government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England, France, and the United States have established this political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction by law; and it is curious to examine the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adaptations which these three great nations have made of the principle.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In England and in France the House of Lords and the Chambre des Paris *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitute the highest criminal court of their respective nations, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although they do not habitually try all political offences, they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: competent to try them all. Another political body enjoys the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impeachment before the House of Lords: the only difference which exists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the two countries in this respect is, that in England the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Commons may impeach whomsoever they please before the Lords, whilst in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France the Deputies can only employ this mode of prosecution against the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ministers of the Crown.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: [As it existed under the constitutional monarchy down to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In both countries the Upper House may make use of all the existing penal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws of the nation to punish the delinquents.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, as well as in Europe, one branch of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislature is authorized to impeach and another to judge: the House
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Representatives arraigns the offender, and the Senate awards his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sentence. But the Senate can only try such persons as are brought before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it by the House of Representatives, and those persons must belong to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class of public functionaries. Thus the jurisdiction of the Senate is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less extensive than that of the Peers of France, whilst the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impeachment by the Representatives is more general than that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Deputies. But the great difference which exists between Europe and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America is, that in Europe political tribunals are empowered to inflict
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the dispositions of the penal code, while in America, when they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have deprived the offender of his official rank, and have declared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him incapable of filling any political office for the future, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction terminates and that of the ordinary tribunals begins.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Suppose, for instance, that the President of the United States has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: committed the crime of high treason; the House of Representatives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impeaches him, and the Senate degrades him; he must then be tried by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a jury, which alone can deprive him of his liberty or his life. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accurately illustrates the subject we are treating. The political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction which is established by the laws of Europe is intended to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: try great offenders, whatever may be their birth, their rank, or their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers in the State; and to this end all the privileges of the courts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of justice are temporarily extended to a great political assembly. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator is then transformed into the magistrate; he is called upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to admit, to distinguish, and to punish the offence; and as he exercises
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the authority of a judge, the law restricts him to the observance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all the duties of that high office, and of all the formalities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice. When a public functionary is impeached before an English or a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French political tribunal, and is found guilty, the sentence deprives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him ipso facto of his functions, and it may pronounce him to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incapable of resuming them or any others for the future. But in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case the political interdict is a consequence of the sentence, and not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sentence itself. In Europe the sentence of a political tribunal is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be regarded as a judicial verdict rather than as an administrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measure. In the United States the contrary takes place; and although the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decision of the Senate is judicial in its form, since the Senators
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are obliged to comply with the practices and formalities of a court of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice; although it is judicial in respect to the motives on which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is founded, since the Senate is in general obliged to take an offence at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common law as the basis of its sentence; nevertheless the object of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceeding is purely administrative. If it had been the intention of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American legislator to invest a political body with great judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, its action would not have been limited to the circle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public functionaries, since the most dangerous enemies of the State may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be in the possession of no functions at all; and this is especially true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in republics, where party influence is the first of authorities, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the strength of many a reader is increased by his exercising no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legal power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If it had been the intention of the American legislator to give
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society the means of repressing State offences by exemplary punishment,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: according to the practice of ordinary justice, the resources of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penal code would all have been placed at the disposal of the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribunals. But the weapon with which they are intrusted is an imperfect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one, and it can never reach the most dangerous offenders, since men who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aim at the entire subversion of the laws are not likely to murmur at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political interdict.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The main object of the political jurisdiction which obtains in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States is, therefore, to deprive the ill-disposed citizen of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an authority which he has used amiss, and to prevent him from ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquiring it again. This is evidently an administrative measure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sanctioned by the formalities of a judicial decision. In this matter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans have created a mixed system; they have surrounded the act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which removes a public functionary with the securities of a political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trial; and they have deprived all political condemnations of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severest penalties. Every link of the system may easily be traced from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this point; we at once perceive why the American constitutions subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the civil functionaries to the jurisdiction of the Senate, whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the military, whose crimes are nevertheless more formidable, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exempted from that tribunal. In the civil service none of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functionaries can be said to be removable; the places which some of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them occupy are inalienable, and the others are chosen for a term which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be shortened. It is therefore necessary to try them all in order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to deprive them of their authority. But military officers are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependent on the chief magistrate of the State, who is himself a civil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functionary, and the decision which condemns him is a blow upon them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If we now compare the American and the European systems, we shall meet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with differences no less striking in the different effects which each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them produces or may produce. In France and in England the jurisdiction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of political bodies is looked upon as an extraordinary resource, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is only to be employed in order to rescue society from unwonted dangers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not to be denied that these tribunals, as they are constituted in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe, are apt to violate the conservative principle of the balance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power in the State, and to threaten incessantly the lives and liberties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the subject. The same political jurisdiction in the United States is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only indirectly hostile to the balance of power; it cannot menace the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lives of the citizens, and it does not hover, as in Europe, over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heads of the community, since those only who have submitted to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority on accepting office are exposed to the severity of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: investigations. It is at the same time less formidable and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efficacious; indeed, it has not been considered by the legislators of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States as a remedy for the more violent evils of society, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as an ordinary means of conducting the government. In this respect it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: probably exercises more real influence on the social body in America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than in Europe. We must not be misled by the apparent mildness of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American legislation in all that relates to political jurisdiction. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to be observed, in the first place, that in the United States the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribunal which passes sentence is composed of the same elements,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and subject to the same influences, as the body which impeaches the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offender, and that this uniformity gives an almost irresistible impulse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the vindictive passions of parties. If political judges in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States cannot inflict such heavy penalties as those of Europe, there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the less chance of their acquitting a prisoner; and the conviction,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if it is less formidable, is more certain. The principal object of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political tribunals of Europe is to punish the offender; the purpose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those in America is to deprive him of his authority. A political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condemnation in the United States may, therefore, be looked upon as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preventive measure; and there is no reason for restricting the judges to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the exact definitions of criminal law. Nothing can be more alarming than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the excessive latitude with which political offences are described in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws of America. Article II., Section 4, of the Constitution of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States runs thus:--"The President, Vice-President, and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil officers of the United States shall be removed from office on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impeachment for, and conviction of, treason, bribery, or other high
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crimes and misdemeanors." Many of the Constitutions of the States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are even less explicit. "Public officers," says the Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Massachusetts, *b "shall be impeached for misconduct or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maladministration;" the Constitution of Virginia declares that all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the civil officers who shall have offended against the State, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maladministration, corruption, or other high crimes, may be impeached by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the House of Delegates; in some constitutions no offences are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: specified, in order to subject the public functionaries to an unlimited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsibility. *c But I will venture to affirm that it is precisely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their mildness which renders the American laws most formidable in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect. We have shown that in Europe the removal of a functionary and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his political interdiction are the consequences of the penalty he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to undergo, and that in America they constitute the penalty itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The consequence is that in Europe political tribunals are invested with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights which they are afraid to use, and that the fear of punishing too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much hinders them from punishing at all. But in America no one hesitates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to inflict a penalty from which humanity does not recoil. To condemn a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political opponent to death, in order to deprive him of his power, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to commit what all the world would execrate as a horrible assassination;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but to declare that opponent unworthy to exercise that authority, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deprive him of it, and to leave him uninjured in life and limb, may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judged to be the fair issue of the struggle. But this sentence, which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is so easy to pronounce, is not the less fatally severe to the majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those upon whom it is inflicted. Great criminals may undoubtedly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brave its intangible rigor, but ordinary offenders will dread it as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condemnation which destroys their position in the world, casts a blight
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon their honor, and condemns them to a shameful inactivity worse than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: death. The influence exercised in the United States upon the progress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society by the jurisdiction of political bodies may not appear to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formidable, but it is only the more immense. It does not directly coerce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the subject, but it renders the majority more absolute over those in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power; it does not confer an unbounded authority on the legislator which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can be exerted at some momentous crisis, but it establishes a temperate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and regular influence, which is at all times available. If the power is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decreased, it can, on the other hand, be more conveniently employed and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more easily abused. By preventing political tribunals from inflicting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judicial punishments the Americans seem to have eluded the worst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences of legislative tyranny, rather than tyranny itself; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am not sure that political jurisdiction, as it is constituted in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States, is not the most formidable weapon which has ever been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: placed in the rude grasp of a popular majority. When the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republics begin to degenerate it will be easy to verify the truth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this observation, by remarking whether the number of political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impeachments augments.*d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: Chap. I. sect. ii. Section 8.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: See the constitutions of Illinois, Maine, Connecticut, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Georgia.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: See Appendix, N.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [The impeachment of President Andrew Johnson in 1868--which was resorted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to by his political opponents solely as a means of turning him out of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: office, for it could not be contended that he had been guilty of high
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crimes and misdemeanors, and he was in fact honorably acquitted and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reinstated in office--is a striking confirmation of the truth of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remark.--Translator's Note, 1874.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: The Federal Constitution--Part I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have hitherto considered each State as a separate whole, and I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explained the different springs which the people sets in motion, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different means of action which it employs. But all the States which I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have considered as independent are forced to submit, in certain cases,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the supreme authority of the Union. The time is now come for me to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examine separately the supremacy with which the Union has been invested,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to cast a rapid glance over the Federal Constitution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Origin of the first Union--Its weakness--Congress appeals to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constituent authority--Interval of two years between this appeal and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promulgation of the new Constitution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: History Of The Federal Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The thirteen colonies which simultaneously threw off the yoke of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England towards the end of the last century professed, as I have already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observed, the same religion, the same language, the same customs, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost the same laws; they were struggling against a common enemy; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these reasons were sufficiently strong to unite them one to another, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to consolidate them into one nation. But as each of them had enjoyed a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separate existence and a government within its own control, the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests and customs which resulted from this system were opposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a compact and intimate union which would have absorbed the individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance of each in the general importance of all. Hence arose two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposite tendencies, the one prompting the Anglo-Americans to unite,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other to divide their strength. As long as the war with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mother-country lasted the principle of union was kept alive by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessity; and although the laws which constituted it were defective,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the common tie subsisted in spite of their imperfections. *a But no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sooner was peace concluded than the faults of the legislation became
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manifest, and the State seemed to be suddenly dissolved. Each colony
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became an independent republic, and assumed an absolute sovereignty. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal government, condemned to impotence by its constitution, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no longer sustained by the presence of a common danger, witnessed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: outrages offered to its flag by the great nations of Europe, whilst it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was scarcely able to maintain its ground against the Indian tribes, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to pay the interest of the debt which had been contracted during the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: war of independence. It was already on the verge of destruction, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it officially proclaimed its inability to conduct the government, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appealed to the constituent authority of the nation. *b If America ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approached (for however brief a time) that lofty pinnacle of glory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to which the fancy of its inhabitants is wont to point, it was at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solemn moment at which the power of the nation abdicated, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the empire of the land. All ages have furnished the spectacle of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people struggling with energy to win its independence; and the efforts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Americans in throwing off the English yoke have been considerably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exaggerated. Separated from their enemies by three thousand miles of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ocean, and backed by a powerful ally, the success of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be more justly attributed to their geographical position than to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: valor of their armies or the patriotism of their citizens. It would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be ridiculous to compare the American was to the wars of the French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Revolution, or the efforts of the Americans to those of the French when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they were attacked by the whole of Europe, without credit and without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allies, yet capable of opposing a twentieth part of their population to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world, and of bearing the torch of revolution beyond their frontiers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst they stifled its devouring flame within the bosom of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country. But it is a novelty in the history of society to see a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people turn a calm and scrutinizing eye upon itself, when apprised by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legislature that the wheels of government are stopped; to see it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carefully examine the extent of the evil, and patiently wait for two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole years until a remedy was discovered, which it voluntarily adopted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without having wrung a tear or a drop of blood from mankind. At the time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when the inadequacy of the first constitution was discovered America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed the double advantage of that calm which had succeeded the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effervescence of the revolution, and of those great men who had led the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution to a successful issue. The assembly which accepted the task
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of composing the second constitution was small; *c but George Washington
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was its President, and it contained the choicest talents and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: noblest hearts which had ever appeared in the New World. This national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commission, after long and mature deliberation, offered to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acceptance of the people the body of general laws which still rules
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union. All the States adopted it successively. *d The new Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government commenced its functions in 1789, after an interregnum of two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years. The Revolution of America terminated when that of France began.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: See the articles of the first confederation formed in 1778.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This constitution was not adopted by all the States until 1781. See also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the analysis given of this constitution in "The Federalist" from No. 15
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to No. 22, inclusive, and Story's "Commentaries on the Constitution of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States," pp. 85-115.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: Congress made this declaration on February 21, 1787.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: It consisted of fifty-five members; Washington, Madison,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hamilton, and the two Morrises were amongst the number.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: It was not adopted by the legislative bodies, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives were elected by the people for this sole purpose;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the new constitution was discussed at length in each of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assemblies.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Summary Of The Federal Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Division of authority between the Federal Government and the States--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of the States is the rule, the Federal Government the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exception.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first question which awaited the Americans was intricate, and by no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means easy of solution: the object was so to divide the authority of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the different States which composed the Union that each of them should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continue to govern itself in all that concerned its internal prosperity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst the entire nation, represented by the Union, should continue to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form a compact body, and to provide for the general exigencies of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. It was as impossible to determine beforehand, with any degree
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of accuracy, the share of authority which each of two governments was to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoy, as to foresee all the incidents in the existence of a nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The obligations and the claims of the Federal Government were simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and easily definable, because the Union had been formed with the express
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purpose of meeting the general exigencies of the people; but the claims
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and obligations of the States were, on the other hand, complicated and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: various, because those Governments had penetrated into all the details
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of social life. The attributes of the Federal Government were therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carefully enumerated and all that was not included amongst them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was declared to constitute a part of the privileges of the several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Governments of the States. Thus the government of the States remained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rule, and that of the Confederation became the exception. *e
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: See the Amendment to the Federal Constitution;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Federalist," No. 32; Story, p. 711; Kent's "Commentaries," vol. i. p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is to be observed that whenever the exclusive right of regulating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain matters is not reserved to Congress by the Constitution, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States may take up the affair until it is brought before the National
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Assembly. For instance, Congress has the right of making a general law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on bankruptcy, which, however, it neglects to do. Each State is then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at liberty to make a law for itself. This point has been established by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discussion in the law-courts, and may be said to belong more properly to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisprudence.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But as it was foreseen that, in practice, questions might arise as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the exact limits of this exceptional authority, and that it would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous to submit these questions to the decision of the ordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courts of justice, established in the States by the States themselves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a high Federal court was created, *f which was destined, amongst other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions, to maintain the balance of power which had been established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Constitution between the two rival Governments. *g
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: The action of this court is indirect, as we shall hereafter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: show.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: It is thus that "The Federalist," No. 45, explains the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: division of supremacy between the Union and the States: "The powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delegated by the Constitution to the Federal Government are few and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defined. Those which are to remain in the State Governments are numerous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and indefinite. The former will be exercised principally on external
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects, as war, peace, negotiation, and foreign commerce. The powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reserved to the several States will extend to all the objects which,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the ordinary course of affairs, concern the internal order and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity of the State." I shall often have occasion to quote "The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federalist" in this work. When the bill which has since become the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution of the United States was submitted to the approval of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people, and the discussions were still pending, three men, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had already acquired a portion of that celebrity which they have since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyed--John Jay, Hamilton, and Madison--formed an association with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the intention of explaining to the nation the advantages of the measure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which was proposed. With this view they published a series of articles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the shape of a journal, which now form a complete treatise. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entitled their journal "The Federalist," a name which has been retained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the work. "The Federalist" is an excellent book, which ought to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be familiar to the statesmen of all countries, although it especially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concerns America.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Prerogative Of The Federal Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Power of declaring war, making peace, and levying general taxes vested
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the Federal Government--What part of the internal policy of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country it may direct--The Government of the Union in some respects more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central than the King's Government in the old French monarchy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The external relations of a people may be compared to those of private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals, and they cannot be advantageously maintained without the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agency of a single head of a Government. The exclusive right of making
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace and war, of concluding treaties of commerce, of raising armies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and equipping fleets, was granted to the Union. *h The necessity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a national Government was less imperiously felt in the conduct of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: internal policy of society; but there are certain general interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which can only be attended to with advantage by a general authority. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union was invested with the power of controlling the monetary system, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directing the post office, and of opening the great roads which were to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: establish a communication between the different parts of the country. *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The independence of the Government of each State was formally recognized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in its sphere; nevertheless, the Federal Government was authorized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to interfere in the internal affairs of the States *j in a few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predetermined cases, in which an indiscreet abuse of their independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might compromise the security of the Union at large. Thus, whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of modifying and changing their legislation at pleasure was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preserved in all the republics, they were forbidden to enact ex post
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facto laws, or to create a class of nobles in their community. *k
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lastly, as it was necessary that the Federal Government should be able
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to fulfil its engagements, it was endowed with an unlimited power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: levying taxes. *l
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as that which empowers the Union to legislate on bankruptcy, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grant patents, and other matters in which its intervention is clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: Even in these cases its interference is indirect. The Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interferes by means of the tribunals, as will be hereafter shown.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: Federal Constitution, sect. 10, art. I.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In examining the balance of power as established by the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution; in remarking on the one hand the portion of sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has been reserved to the several States, and on the other the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: share of power which the Union has assumed, it is evident that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal legislators entertained the clearest and most accurate notions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the nature of the centralization of government. The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form not only a republic, but a confederation; nevertheless the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the nation is more central than it was in several of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchies of Europe when the American Constitution was formed. Take,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for instance, the two following examples.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thirteen supreme courts of justice existed in France, which, generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speaking, had the right of interpreting the law without appeal; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those provinces which were styled pays d'etats were authorized to refuse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their assent to an impost which had been levied by the sovereign who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represented the nation. In the Union there is but one tribunal to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interpret, as there is one legislature to make the laws; and an impost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: voted by the representatives of the nation is binding upon all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens. In these two essential points, therefore, the Union exercises
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more central authority than the French monarchy possessed, although the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union is only an assemblage of confederate republics.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Spain certain provinces had the right of establishing a system of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: custom-house duties peculiar to themselves, although that privilege
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belongs, by its very nature, to the national sovereignty. In America the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Congress alone has the right of regulating the commercial relations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States. The government of the Confederation is therefore more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralized in this respect than the kingdom of Spain. It is true that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of the Crown in France or in Spain was always able to obtain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by force whatever the Constitution of the country denied, and that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ultimate result was consequently the same; but I am here discussing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theory of the Constitution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: After having settled the limits within which the Federal Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was to act, the next point was to determine the powers which it was to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exert.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Legislative Powers *m
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: [In this chapter the author points out the essence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conflict between the seceding States and the Union which caused the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Civil War of 1861.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Division of the Legislative Body into two branches--Difference in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner of forming the two Houses--The principle of the independence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States predominates in the formation of the Senate--The principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the sovereignty of the nation in the composition of the House of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives--Singular effects of the fact that a Constitution can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only be logical in the early stages of a nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The plan which had been laid down beforehand for the Constitutions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the several States was followed, in many points, in the organization
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the powers of the Union. The Federal legislature of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was composed of a Senate and a House of Representatives. A spirit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conciliation prescribed the observance of distinct principles in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the formation of these two assemblies. I have already shown that two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary interests were opposed to each other in the establishment of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal Constitution. These two interests had given rise to two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions. It was the wish of one party to convert the Union into a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: league of independent States, or a sort of congress, at which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives of the several peoples would meet to discuss certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: points of their common interests. The other party desired to unite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inhabitants of the American colonies into one sole nation, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: establish a Government which should act as the sole representative of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nation, as far as the limited sphere of its authority would permit.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The practical consequences of these two theories were exceedingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The question was, whether a league was to be established instead of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national Government; whether the majority of the State, instead of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority of the inhabitants of the Union, was to give the law: for every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State, the small as well as the great, would then remain in the full
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyment of its independence, and enter the Union upon a footing of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfect equality. If, however, the inhabitants of the United States were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be considered as belonging to one and the same nation, it would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: just that the majority of the citizens of the Union should prescribe the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law. Of course the lesser States could not subscribe to the application
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this doctrine without, in fact, abdicating their existence in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relation to the sovereignty of the Confederation; since they would have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passed from the condition of a co-equal and co-legislative authority to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of an insignificant fraction of a great people. But if the former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system would have invested them with an excessive authority, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter would have annulled their influence altogether. Under these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances the result was, that the strict rules of logic were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evaded, as is usually the case when interests are opposed to arguments.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A middle course was hit upon by the legislators, which brought together
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by force two systems theoretically irreconcilable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principle of the independence of the States prevailed in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formation of the Senate, and that of the sovereignty of the nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predominated in the composition of the House of Representatives. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was decided that each State should send two senators to Congress, and a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of representatives proportioned to its population. *n It results
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from this arrangement that the State of New York has at the present day
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forty representatives and only two senators; the State of Delaware
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has two senators and only one representative; the State of Delaware
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is therefore equal to the State of New York in the Senate, whilst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter has forty times the influence of the former in the House of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives. Thus, if the minority of the nation preponderates in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Senate,. it may paralyze the decisions of the majority represented
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the other House, which is contrary to the spirit of constitutional
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: Every ten years Congress fixes anew the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives which each State is to furnish. The total number was 69
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in 1789, and 240 in 1833. (See "American Almanac," 1834, p. 194.)
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Constitution decided that there should not be more than one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative for every 30,000 persons; but no minimum was fixed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on. The Congress has not thought fit to augment the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives in proportion to the increase of population. The first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Act which was passed on the subject (April 14, 1792: see "Laws of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States," by Story, vol. i. p. 235) decided that there should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one representative for every 33,000 inhabitants. The last Act, which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passed in 1832, fixes the proportion at one for 48,000. The population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represented is composed of all the free men and of three-fifths of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slaves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [The last Act of apportionment, passed February 2, 1872, fixes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representation at one to 134,684 inhabitants. There are now (1875) 283
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the lower House of Congress, and 9 for the States at large,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: making in all 292 members. The old States have of course lost the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives which the new States have gained.--Translator's Note.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These facts show how rare and how difficult it is rationally and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: logically to combine all the several parts of legislation. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course of time different interests arise, and different principles are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sanctioned by the same people; and when a general constitution is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be established, these interests and principles are so many natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obstacles to the rigorous application of any political system, with all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its consequences. The early stages of national existence are the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: periods at which it is possible to maintain the complete logic of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation; and when we perceive a nation in the enjoyment of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantage, before we hasten to conclude that it is wise, we should do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well to remember that it is young. When the Federal Constitution was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed, the interests of independence for the separate States, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest of union for the whole people, were the only two conflicting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests which existed amongst the Anglo-Americans, and a compromise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was necessarily made between them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is, however, just to acknowledge that this part of the Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has not hitherto produced those evils which might have been feared. All
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States are young and contiguous; their customs, their ideas, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their exigencies are not dissimilar; and the differences which result
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from their size or inferiority do not suffice to set their interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at variance. The small States have consequently never been induced to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: league themselves together in the Senate to oppose the designs of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: larger ones; and indeed there is so irresistible an authority in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legitimate expression of the will of a people that the Senate could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offer but a feeble opposition to the vote of the majority of the House
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Representatives.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must not be forgotten, on the other hand, that it was not in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of the American legislators to reduce to a single nation the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people for whom they were making laws. The object of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution was not to destroy the independence of the States, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to restrain it. By acknowledging the real authority of these secondary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities (and it was impossible to deprive them of it), they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disavowed beforehand the habitual use of constraint in enforcing g the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decisions of the majority. Upon this principle the introduction of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of the States into the mechanism of the Federal Government was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by no means to be wondered at, since it only attested the existence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an acknowledged power, which was to be humored and not forcibly checked.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A Further Difference Between The Senate And The House Of Representatives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Senate named by the provincial legislators, the Representatives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the people--Double election of the former; single election of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter--Term of the different offices--Peculiar functions of each House.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Senate not only differs from the other House in the principle which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it represents, but also in the mode of its election, in the term for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it is chosen, and in the nature of its functions. The House of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives is named by the people, the Senate by the legislators of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each State; the former is directly elected, the latter is elected by an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elected body; the term for which the representatives are chosen is only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two years, that of the senators is six. The functions of the House of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives are purely legislative, and the only share it takes in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the judicial power is in the impeachment of public officers. The Senate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operates in the work of legislation, and tries those political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offences which the House of Representatives submits to its decision.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It also acts as the great executive council of the nation; the treaties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are concluded by the President must be ratified by the Senate,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the appointments he may make must be definitely approved by the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body. *o
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: See "The Federalist," Nos. 52-56, inclusive; Story,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pp. 199-314; Constitution of the United States, sects. 2 and 3.] The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
