text: Executive Power *p
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: See "The Federalist," Nos. 67-77; Constitution of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States, art. 2; Story, p. 315, pp. 615-780; Kent's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Commentaries," p. 255.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Dependence of the President--He is elective and responsible--He is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free to act in his own sphere under the inspection, but not under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the direction, of the Senate--His salary fixed at his entry into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: office--Suspensive veto.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American legislators undertook a difficult task in attempting to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: create an executive power dependent on the majority of the people, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless sufficiently strong to act without restraint in its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere. It was indispensable to the maintenance of the republican form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of government that the representative of the executive power should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject to the will of the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The President is an elective magistrate. His honor, his property, his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty, and his life are the securities which the people has for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temperate use of his power. But in the exercise of his authority he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be said to be perfectly independent; the Senate takes cognizance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his relations with foreign powers, and of the distribution of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appointments, so that he can neither be bribed nor can he employ the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means of corruption. The legislators of the Union acknowledged that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive power would be incompetent to fulfil its task with dignity and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: utility, unless it enjoyed a greater degree of stability and of strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than had been granted to it in the separate States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The President is chosen for four years, and he may be reelected; so that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chances of a prolonged administration may inspire him with hopeful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings for the public good, and with the means of carrying them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into execution. The President was made the sole representative of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive power of the Union, and care was taken not to render his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decisions subordinate to the vote of a council--a dangerous measure,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which tends at the same time to clog the action of the Government and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to diminish its responsibility. The Senate has the right of annulling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: g certain acts of the President; but it cannot compel him to take any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: steps, nor does it participate in the exercise of the executive power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The action of the legislature on the executive power may be direct; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we have just shown that the Americans carefully obviated this influence;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it may, on the other hand, be indirect. Public assemblies which have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of depriving an officer of state of his salary encroach upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his independence; and as they are free to make the laws, it is to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feared lest they should gradually appropriate to themselves a portion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of that authority which the Constitution had vested in his hands. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependence of the executive power is one of the defects inherent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republican constitutions. The Americans have not been able to counteract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tendency which legislative assemblies have to get possession of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, but they have rendered this propensity less irresistible.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The salary of the President is fixed, at the time of his entering
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon office, for the whole period of his magistracy. The President is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moreover, provided with a suspensive veto, which allows him to oppose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the passing of such laws as might destroy the portion of independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the Constitution awards him. The struggle between the President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the legislature must always be an unequal one, since the latter is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain of bearing down all resistance by persevering in its plans; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the suspensive veto forces it at least to reconsider the matter, and,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if the motion be persisted in, it must then be backed by a majority of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two-thirds of the whole house. The veto is, in fact, a sort of appeal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the people. The executive power, which, without this security, might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been secretly oppressed, adopts this means of pleading its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause and stating its motives. But if the legislature is certain of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overpowering all resistance by persevering in its plans, I reply, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the constitutions of all nations, of whatever kind they may be, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain point exists at which the legislator is obliged to have recourse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the good sense and the virtue of his fellow-citizens. This point is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more prominent and more discoverable in republics, whilst it is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remote and more carefully concealed in monarchies, but it always exists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: somewhere. There is no country in the world in which everything can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provided for by the laws, or in which political institutions can prove a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: substitute for common sense and public morality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Differences Between The Position Of The President Of The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And That Of A Constitutional King Of France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Executive power in the Northern States as limited and as partial as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supremacy which it represents--Executive power in France as universal as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the supremacy it represents--The King a branch of the legislature--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President the mere executor of the law--Other differences resulting from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the duration of the two powers--The President checked in the exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the executive authority--The King independent in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise--Notwithstanding these discrepancies France is more akin to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a republic than the Union to a monarchy--Comparison of the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public officers depending upon the executive power in the two countries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The executive power has so important an influence on the destinies of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations that I am inclined to pause for an instant at this portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my subject, in order more clearly to explain the part it sustains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in America. In order to form an accurate idea of the position of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President of the United States, it may not be irrelevant to compare it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to that of one of the constitutional kings of Europe. In this comparison
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall pay but little attention to the external signs of power, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are more apt to deceive the eye of the observer than to guide his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: researches. When a monarchy is being gradually transformed into a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republic, the executive power retains the titles, the honors, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: etiquette, and even the funds of royalty long after its authority has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disappeared. The English, after having cut off the head of one king
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and expelled another from his throne, were accustomed to accost the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: successor of those princes upon their knees. On the other hand, when a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republic falls under the sway of a single individual, the demeanor of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sovereign is simple and unpretending, as if his authority was not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet paramount. When the emperors exercised an unlimited control over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the fortunes and the lives of their fellow-citizens, it was customary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: call them Caesar in conversation, and they were in the habit of supping
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without formality at their friends' houses. It is therefore necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: look below the surface.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The sovereignty of the United States is shared between the Union and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, whilst in France it is undivided and compact: hence arises the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first and the most notable difference which exists between the President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States and the King of France. In the United States the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive power is as limited and partial as the sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union in whose name it acts; in France it is as universal as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the State. The Americans have a federal and the French a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national Government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: The Federal Constitution--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This cause of inferiority results from the nature of things, but it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not the only one; the second in importance is as follows: Sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be defined to be the right of making laws: in France, the King
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: really exercises a portion of the sovereign power, since the laws have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no weight till he has given his assent to them; he is, moreover, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executor of all they ordain. The President is also the executor of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws, but he does not really co-operate in their formation, since the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refusal of his assent does not annul them. He is therefore merely to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considered as the agent of the sovereign power. But not only does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the King of France exercise a portion of the sovereign power, he also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contributes to the nomination of the legislature, which exercises the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other portion. He has the privilege of appointing the members of one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chamber, and of dissolving the other at his pleasure; whereas the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President of the United States has no share in the formation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative body, and cannot dissolve any part of it. The King has the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same right of bringing forward measures as the Chambers; a right which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the President does not possess. The King is represented in each assembly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by his ministers, who explain his intentions, support his opinions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and maintain the principles of the Government. The President and his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ministers are alike excluded from Congress; so that his influence and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his opinions can only penetrate indirectly into that great body. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: King of France is therefore on an equal footing with the legislature,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which can no more act without him than he can without it. The President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercises an authority inferior to, and depending upon, that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Even in the exercise of the executive power, properly so called--the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point upon which his position seems to be most analogous to that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the King of France--the President labors under several causes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferiority. The authority of the King, in France, has, in the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place, the advantage of duration over that of the President, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: durability is one of the chief elements of strength; nothing is either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: loved or feared but what is likely to endure. The President of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States is a magistrate elected for four years; the King, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France, is an hereditary sovereign. In the exercise of the executive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power the President of the United States is constantly subject to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jealous scrutiny. He may make, but he cannot conclude, a treaty; he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may designate, but he cannot appoint, a public officer. *q The King of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France is absolute within the limits of his authority. The President of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States is responsible for his actions; but the person of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: King is declared inviolable by the French Charter. *r
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: The Constitution had left it doubtful whether the President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was obliged to consult the Senate in the removal as well as in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appointment of Federal officers. "The Federalist" (No. 77) seemed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: establish the affirmative; but in 1789 Congress formally decided that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the President was responsible for his actions, he ought not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be forced to employ agents who had forfeited his esteem. See Kent's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Commentaries", vol. i. p. 289.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: [This comparison applied to the Constitutional King of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France and to the powers he held under the Charter of 1830, till the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overthrow of the monarchy in 1848.--Translator's Note.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, the supremacy of public opinion is no less above the head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the one than of the other. This power is less definite, less evident,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and less sanctioned by the laws in France than in America, but in fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it exists. In America, it acts by elections and decrees; in France it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceeds by revolutions; but notwithstanding the different constitutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these two countries, public opinion is the predominant authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in both of them. The fundamental principle of legislation--a principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: essentially republican--is the same in both countries, although its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences may be different, and its results more or less extensive.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whence I am led to conclude that France with its King is nearer akin to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a republic than the Union with its President is to a monarchy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In what I have been saying I have only touched upon the main points
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of distinction; and if I could have entered into details, the contrast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would have been rendered still more striking. I have remarked that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the President in the United States is only exercised within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the limits of a partial sovereignty, whilst that of the King in France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is undivided. I might have gone on to show that the power of the King's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government in France exceeds its natural limits, however extensive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they may be, and penetrates in a thousand different ways into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration of private interests. Amongst the examples of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence may be quoted that which results from the great number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of public functionaries, who all derive their appointments from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government. This number now exceeds all previous limits; it amounts to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 138,000 *s nominations, each of which may be considered as an element of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. The President of the United States has not the exclusive right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: making any public appointments, and their whole number scarcely exceeds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote s: The sums annually paid by the State to these officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote t: This number is extracted from the "National Calendar" for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1833. The "National Calendar" is an American almanac which contains the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: names of all the Federal officers. It results from this comparison that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the King of France has eleven times as many places at his disposal as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the President, although the population of France is not much more than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: double that of the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [I have not the means of ascertaining the number of appointments now at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the disposal of the President of the United States, but his patronage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the abuse of it have largely increased since 1833.--Translator's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Accidental Causes Which May Increase The Influence Of The Executive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: External security of the Union--Army of six thousand men--Few ships--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President has no opportunity of exercising his great prerogatives--In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the prerogatives he exercises he is weak.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the executive government is feebler in America than in France, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause is more attributable to the circumstances than to the laws of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is chiefly in its foreign relations that the executive power of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation is called upon to exert its skill and its vigor. If the existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union were perpetually threatened, and if its chief interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were in daily connection with those of other powerful nations, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive government would assume an increased importance in proportion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the measures expected of it, and those which it would carry into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effect. The President of the United States is the commander-in-chief of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the army, but of an army composed of only six thousand men; he commands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the fleet, but the fleet reckons but few sail; he conducts the foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relations of the Union, but the United States are a nation without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighbors. Separated from the rest of the world by the ocean, and too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weak as yet to aim at the dominion of the seas, they have no enemies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their interests rarely come into contact with those of any other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation of the globe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The practical part of a Government must not be judged by the theory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its constitution. The President of the United States is in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of almost royal prerogatives, which he has no opportunity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercising; and those privileges which he can at present use are very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumscribed. The laws allow him to possess a degree of influence which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances do not permit him to employ.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, the great strength of the royal prerogative in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France arises from circumstances far more than from the laws. There
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the executive government is constantly struggling against prodigious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obstacles, and exerting all its energies to repress them; so that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases by the extent of its achievements, and by the importance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the events it controls, without modifying its constitution. If the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had made it as feeble and as circumscribed as it is in the Union, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence would very soon become still more preponderant.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Why The President Of The United States Does Not Require The Majority Of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Two Houses In Order To Carry On The Government It is an established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: axiom in Europe that a constitutional King cannot persevere in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system of government which is opposed by the two other branches of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislature. But several Presidents of the United States have been known
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to lose the majority in the legislative body without being obliged to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandon the supreme power, and without inflicting a serious evil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon society. I have heard this fact quoted as an instance of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence and the power of the executive government in America: a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moment's reflection will convince us, on the contrary, that it is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proof of its extreme weakness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A King in Europe requires the support of the legislature to enable him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to perform the duties imposed upon him by the Constitution, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those duties are enormous. A constitutional King in Europe is not merely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the executor of the law, but the execution of its provisions devolves so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely upon him that he has the power of paralyzing its influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if it opposes his designs. He requires the assistance of the legislative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assemblies to make the law, but those assemblies stand in need of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aid to execute it: these two authorities cannot subsist without each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, and the mechanism of government is stopped as soon as they are at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: variance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the President cannot prevent any law from being passed, nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can he evade the obligation of enforcing it. His sincere and zealous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operation is no doubt useful, but it is not indispensable, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carrying on of public affairs. All his important acts are directly or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indirectly submitted to the legislature, and of his own free authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he can do but little. It is therefore his weakness, and not his power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which enables him to remain in opposition to Congress. In Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harmony must reign between the Crown and the other branches of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislature, because a collision between them may prove serious; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, this harmony is not indispensable, because such a collision is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Election Of The President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Dangers of the elective system increase in proportion to the extent of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the prerogative--This system possible in America because no powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive authority is required--What circumstances are favorable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the elective system--Why the election of the President does not cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a deviation from the principles of the Government--Influence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: election of the President on secondary functionaries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The dangers of the system of election applied to the head of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive government of a great people have been sufficiently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exemplified by experience and by history, and the remarks I am about
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to make refer to America alone. These dangers may be more or less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formidable in proportion to the place which the executive power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occupies, and to the importance it possesses in the State; and they may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vary according to the mode of election and the circumstances in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the electors are placed. The most weighty argument against the election
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a chief magistrate is, that it offers so splendid a lure to private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition, and is so apt to inflame men in the pursuit of power, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when legitimate means are wanting force may not unfrequently seize what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right denied.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is clear that the greater the privileges of the executive authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are, the greater is the temptation; the more the ambition of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: candidates is excited, the more warmly are their interests espoused by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a throng of partisans who hope to share the power when their patron has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: won the prize. The dangers of the elective system increase, therefore,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the exact ratio of the influence exercised by the executive power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the affairs of State. The revolutions of Poland were not solely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attributable to the elective system in general, but to the fact that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elected monarch was the sovereign of a powerful kingdom. Before we can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discuss the absolute advantages of the elective system we must make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preliminary inquiries as to whether the geographical position, the laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the habits, the manners, and the opinions of the people amongst whom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is to be introduced will admit of the establishment of a weak
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and dependent executive government; for to attempt to render the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative of the State a powerful sovereign, and at the same time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elective, is, in my opinion, to entertain two incompatible designs. To
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reduce hereditary royalty to the condition of an elective authority, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only means that I am acquainted with are to circumscribe its sphere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of action beforehand, gradually to diminish its prerogatives, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustom the people to live without its protection. Nothing, however, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: further from the designs of the republicans of Europe than this course:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as many of them owe their hatred of tyranny to the sufferings which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have personally undergone, it is oppression, and not the extent of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive power, which excites their hostility, and they attack the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former without perceiving how nearly it is connected with the latter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hitherto no citizen has shown any disposition to expose his honor and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his life in order to become the President of the United States; because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of that office is temporary, limited, and subordinate. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prize of fortune must be great to encourage adventurers in so desperate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a game. No candidate has as yet been able to arouse the dangerous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enthusiasm or the passionate sympathies of the people in his favor, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the very simple reason that when he is at the head of the Government he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has but little power, but little wealth, and but little glory to share
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst his friends; and his influence in the State is too small for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the success or the ruin of a faction to depend upon the elevation of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual to power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great advantage of hereditary monarchies is, that as the private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest of a family is always intimately connected with the interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the State, the executive government is never suspended for a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instant; and if the affairs of a monarchy are not better conducted than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those of a republic, at least there is always some one to conduct them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well or ill, according to his capacity. In elective States, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, the wheels of government cease to act, as it were, of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own accord at the approach of an election, and even for some time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: previous to that event. The laws may indeed accelerate the operation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the election, which may be conducted with such simplicity and rapidity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the seat of power will never be left vacant; but, notwithstanding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these precautions, a break necessarily occurs in the minds of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the approach of an election the head of the executive government is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wholly occupied by the coming struggle; his future plans are doubtful;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he can undertake nothing new, and the he will only prosecute with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indifference those designs which another will perhaps terminate. "I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so near the time of my retirement from office," said President Jefferson
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the 21st of January, 1809 (six weeks before the election), "that I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feel no passion, I take no part, I express no sentiment. It appears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to me just to leave to my successor the commencement of those measures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which he will have to prosecute, and for which he will be responsible."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, the eyes of the nation are centred on a single point;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all are watching the gradual birth of so important an event. The wider
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the influence of the executive power extends, the greater and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more necessary is its constant action, the more fatal is the term of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suspense; and a nation which is accustomed to the government, or, still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more, one used to the administrative protection of a powerful executive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority would be infallibly convulsed by an election of this kind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the action of the Government may be slackened with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impunity, because it is always weak and circumscribed. *u
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote u: [This, however, may be a great danger. The period during
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which Mr. Buchanan retained office, after the election of Mr. Lincoln,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from November, 1860, to March, 1861, was that which enabled the seceding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States of the South to complete their preparations for the Civil War,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the Executive Government was paralyzed. No greater evil could befall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a nation.--Translator's Note.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: One of the principal vices of the elective system is that it always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduces a certain degree of instability into the internal and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: external policy of the State. But this disadvantage is less sensibly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: felt if the share of power vested in the elected magistrate is small. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Rome the principles of the Government underwent no variation, although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Consuls were changed every year, because the Senate, which was an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereditary assembly, possessed the directing authority. If the elective
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system were adopted in Europe, the condition of most of the monarchical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States would be changed at every new election. In America the President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercises a certain influence on State affairs, but he does not conduct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; the preponderating power is vested in the representatives of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole nation. The political maxims of the country depend therefore on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mass of the people, not on the President alone; and consequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in America the elective system has no very prejudicial influence on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fixed principles of the Government. But the want of fixed principles is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an evil so inherent in the elective system that it is still extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceptible in the narrow sphere to which the authority of the President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extends.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans have admitted that the head of the executive power, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has to bear the whole responsibility of the duties he is called upon to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fulfil, ought to be empowered to choose his own agents, and to remove
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them at pleasure: the legislative bodies watch the conduct of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President more than they direct it. The consequence of this arrangement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is, that at every new election the fate of all the Federal public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers is in suspense. Mr. Quincy Adams, on his entry into office,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discharged the majority of the individuals who had been appointed by his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predecessor: and I am not aware that General Jackson allowed a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removable functionary employed in the Federal service to retain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his place beyond the first year which succeeded his election. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is sometimes made a subject of complaint that in the constitutional
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchies of Europe the fate of the humbler servants of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Administration depends upon that of the Ministers. But in elective
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Governments this evil is far greater. In a constitutional monarchy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: successive ministries are rapidly formed; but as the principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative of the executive power does not change, the spirit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innovation is kept within bounds; the changes which take place are in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the details rather than in the principles of the administrative system;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but to substitute one system for another, as is done in America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every four years, by law, is to cause a sort of revolution. As to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misfortunes which may fall upon individuals in consequence of this state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things, it must be allowed that the uncertain situation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public officers is less fraught with evil consequences in America than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere. It is so easy to acquire an independent position in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States that the public officer who loses his place may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deprived of the comforts of life, but not of the means of subsistence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I remarked at the beginning of this chapter that the dangers of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elective system applied to the head of the State are augmented or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decreased by the peculiar circumstances of the people which adopts it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: However the functions of the executive power may be restricted, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must always exercise a great influence upon the foreign policy of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, for a negotiation cannot be opened or successfully carried
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on otherwise than by a single agent. The more precarious and the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perilous the position of a people becomes, the more absolute is the want
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a fixed and consistent external policy, and the more dangerous does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the elective system of the Chief Magistrate become. The policy of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans in relation to the whole world is exceedingly simple; for it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may almost be said that no country stands in need of them, nor do they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: require the co-operation of any other people. Their independence is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never threatened. In their present condition, therefore, the functions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the executive power are no less limited by circumstances than by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws; and the President may frequently change his line of policy without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: involving the State in difficulty or destruction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whatever the prerogatives of the executive power may be, the period
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which immediately precedes an election and the moment of its duration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must always be considered as a national crisis, which is perilous in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion to the internal embarrassments and the external dangers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country. Few of the nations of Europe could escape the calamities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of anarchy or of conquest every time they might have to elect a new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign. In America society is so constituted that it can stand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without assistance upon its own basis; nothing is to be feared from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pressure of external dangers, and the election of the President is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause of agitation, but not of ruin.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mode Of Election
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Skill of the American legislators shown in the mode of election adopted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by them--Creation of a special electoral body--Separate votes of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: electors--Case in which the House of Representatives is called upon to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choose the President--Results of the twelve elections which have taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place since the Constitution has been established.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Besides the dangers which are inherent in the system, many other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulties may arise from the mode of election, which may be obviated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the precaution of the legislator. When a people met in arms on some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public spot to choose its head, it was exposed to all the chances of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil war resulting from so martial a mode of proceeding, besides
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the dangers of the elective system in itself. The Polish laws, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjected the election of the sovereign to the veto of a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual, suggested the murder of that individual or prepared the way
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to anarchy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the examination of the institutions and the political as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social condition of the United States, we are struck by the admirable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harmony of the gifts of fortune and the efforts of man. The nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed two of the main causes of internal peace; it was a new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, but it was inhabited by a people grown old in the exercise of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom. America had no hostile neighbors to dread; and the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislators, profiting by these favorable circumstances, created a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weak and subordinate executive power which could without danger be made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elective.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It then only remained for them to choose the least dangerous of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: various modes of election; and the rules which they laid down upon this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point admirably correspond to the securities which the physical and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political constitution of the country already afforded. Their object was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to find the mode of election which would best express the choice of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people with the least possible excitement and suspense. It was admitted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the first place that the simple majority should be decisive; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the difficulty was to obtain this majority without an interval of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delay which it was most important to avoid. It rarely happens that an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual can at once collect the majority of the suffrages of a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people; and this difficulty is enhanced in a republic of confederate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, where local influences are apt to preponderate. The means by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it was proposed to obviate this second obstacle was to delegate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the electoral powers of the nation to a body of representatives. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mode of election rendered a majority more probable; for the fewer the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: electors are, the greater is the chance of their coming to a final
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decision. It also offered an additional probability of a judicious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choice. It then remained to be decided whether this right of election
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was to be entrusted to a legislative body, the habitual representative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assembly of the nation, or whether an electoral assembly should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed for the express purpose of proceeding to the nomination of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President. The Americans chose the latter alternative, from a belief
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the individuals who were returned to make the laws were incompetent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to represent the wishes of the nation in the election of its chief
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrate; and that, as they are chosen for more than a year, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constituency they represent might have changed its opinion in that time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It was thought that if the legislature was empowered to elect the head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the executive power, its members would, for some time before the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: election, be exposed to the manoeuvres of corruption and the tricks of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intrigue; whereas the special electors would, like a jury, remain mixed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up with the crowd till the day of action, when they would appear for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sole purpose of giving their votes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It was therefore established that every State should name a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of electors, *v who in their turn should elect the President;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and as it had been observed that the assemblies to which the choice of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a chief magistrate had been entrusted in elective countries inevitably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became the centres of passion and of cabal; that they sometimes usurped
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an authority which did not belong to them; and that their proceedings,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or the uncertainty which resulted from them, were sometimes prolonged so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much as to endanger the welfare of the State, it was determined that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: electors should all vote upon the same day, without being convoked to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same place. *w This double election rendered a majority probable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: though not certain; for it was possible that as many differences might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist between the electors as between their constituents. In this case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it was necessary to have recourse to one of three measures; either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to appoint new electors, or to consult a second time those already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appointed, or to defer the election to another authority. The first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two of these alternatives, independently of the uncertainty of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results, were likely to delay the final decision, and to perpetuate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an agitation which must always be accompanied with danger. The third
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expedient was therefore adopted, and it was agreed that the votes should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be transmitted sealed to the President of the Senate, and that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be opened and counted in the presence of the Senate and the House
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Representatives. If none of the candidates has a majority, the House
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Representatives then proceeds immediately to elect a President, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the condition that it must fix upon one of the three candidates who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have the highest numbers. *x
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote v: As many as it sends members to Congress. The number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: electors at the election of 1833 was 288. (See "The National Calendar,"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote w: The electors of the same State assemble, but they transmit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the central government the list of their individual votes, and not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mere result of the vote of the majority.] [Footnote x: In this case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is the majority of the States, and not the majority of the members,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which decides the question; so that New York has not more influence in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the debate than Rhode Island. Thus the citizens of the Union are first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consulted as members of one and the same community; and, if they cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agree, recourse is had to the division of the States, each of which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a separate and independent vote. This is one of the singularities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal Constitution which can only be explained by the jar of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conflicting interests.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus it is only in case of an event which cannot often happen, and which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can never be foreseen, that the election is entrusted to the ordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives of the nation; and even then they are obliged to choose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a citizen who has already been designated by a powerful minority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: special electors. It is by this happy expedient that the respect which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is due to the popular voice is combined with the utmost celerity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: execution and those precautions which the peace of the country demands.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the decision of the question by the House of Representatives does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not necessarily offer an immediate solution of the difficulty, for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority of that assembly may still be doubtful, and in this case the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution prescribes no remedy. Nevertheless, by restricting the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of candidates to three, and by referring the matter to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judgment of an enlightened public body, it has smoothed all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obstacles *y which are not inherent in the elective system.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote y: Jefferson, in 1801, was not elected until the thirty-sixth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time of balloting.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the forty-four years which have elapsed since the promulgation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal Constitution the United States have twelve times chosen a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President. Ten of these elections took place simultaneously by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: votes of the special electors in the different States. The House of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives has only twice exercised its conditional privilege of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deciding in cases of uncertainty; the first time was at the election of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mr. Jefferson in 1801; the second was in 1825, when Mr. Quincy Adams was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: named. *z
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote z: [General Grant is now (1874) the eighteenth President of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Crises Of The Election
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Election may be considered as a national crisis--Why?--Passions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people--Anxiety of the President--Calm which succeeds the agitation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the election.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown what the circumstances are which favored the adoption of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the elective system in the United States, and what precautions were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken by the legislators to obviate its dangers. The Americans are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitually accustomed to all kinds of elections, and they know by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience the utmost degree of excitement which is compatible with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: security. The vast extent of the country and the dissemination of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants render a collision between parties less probable and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous there than elsewhere. The political circumstances under which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the elections have hitherto been carried on have presented no real
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: embarrassments to the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, the epoch of the election of a President of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States may be considered as a crisis in the affairs of the nation. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence which he exercises on public business is no doubt feeble and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indirect; but the choice of the President, which is of small importance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to each individual citizen, concerns the citizens collectively; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however trifling an interest may be, it assumes a great degree of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance as soon as it becomes general. The President possesses but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: few means of rewarding his supporters in comparison to the kings of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe, but the places which are at his disposal are sufficiently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numerous to interest, directly or indirectly, several thousand electors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in his success. Political parties in the United States are led to rally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: round an individual, in order to acquire a more tangible shape in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eyes of the crowd, and the name of the candidate for the Presidency is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: put forward as the symbol and personification of their theories. For
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these reasons parties are strongly interested in gaining the election,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not so much with a view to the triumph of their principles under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the auspices of the President-elect as to show by the majority which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: returned him, the strength of the supporters of those principles.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: For a long while before the appointed time is at hand the election
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes the most important and the all-engrossing topic of discussion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The ardor of faction is redoubled; and all the artificial passions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the imagination can create in the bosom of a happy and peaceful land
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are agitated and brought to light. The President, on the other hand,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is absorbed by the cares of self-defence. He no longer governs for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest of the State, but for that of his re-election; he does homage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the majority, and instead of checking its passions, as his duty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commands him to do, he frequently courts its worst caprices. As the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: election draws near, the activity of intrigue and the agitation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: populace increase; the citizens are divided into hostile camps, each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which assumes the name of its favorite candidate; the whole nation glows
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with feverish excitement; the election is the daily theme of the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: papers, the subject of private conversation, the end of every thought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and every action, the sole interest of the present. As soon as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choice is determined, this ardor is dispelled; and as a calmer season
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: returns, the current of the State, which had nearly broken its banks,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sinks to its usual level: *a but who can refrain from astonishment at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the causes of the storm.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: [Not always. The election of President Lincoln was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: signal of civil war.--Translator's Note.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: The Federal Constitution--Part III
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Re-election Of The President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the head of the executive power is re-eligible, it is the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is the source of intrigue and corruption--The desire of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being re-elected the chief aim of a President of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States--Disadvantage of the system peculiar to America--The natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evil of democracy is that it subordinates all authority to the slightest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires of the majority--The re-election of the President encourages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this evil.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may be asked whether the legislators of the United States did right
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or wrong in allowing the re-election of the President. It seems at first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sight contrary to all reason to prevent the head of the executive power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from being elected a second time. The influence which the talents and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the character of a single individual may exercise upon the fate of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole people, in critical circumstances or arduous times, is well known:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a law preventing the re-election of the chief magistrate would deprive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens of the surest pledge of the prosperity and the security
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the commonwealth; and, by a singular inconsistency, a man would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excluded from the government at the very time when he had shown his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ability in conducting its affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But if these arguments are strong, perhaps still more powerful reasons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be advanced against them. Intrigue and corruption are the natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defects of elective government; but when the head of the State can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: re-elected these evils rise to a great height, and compromise the very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of the country. When a simple candidate seeks to rise by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intrigue, his manoeuvres must necessarily be limited to a narrow sphere;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but when the chief magistrate enters the lists, he borrows the strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the government for his own purposes. In the former case the feeble
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources of an individual are in action; in the latter, the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself, with all its immense influence, is busied in the work of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corruption and cabal. The private citizen, who employs the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immoral practices to acquire power, can only act in a manner indirectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudicial to the public prosperity. But if the representative of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive descends into the combat, the cares of government dwindle into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: second-rate importance, and the success of his election is his first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concern. All laws and all the negotiations he undertakes are to him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing more than electioneering schemes; places become the reward
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of services rendered, not to the nation, but to its chief; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of the government, if not injurious to the country, is at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: least no longer beneficial to the community for which it was created.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is impossible to consider the ordinary course of affairs in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States without perceiving that the desire of being re-elected is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chief aim of the President; that his whole administration, and even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his most indifferent measures, tend to this object; and that, as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crisis approaches, his personal interest takes the place of his interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the public good. The principle of re-eligibility renders the corrupt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of elective government still more extensive and pernicious.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America it exercises a peculiarly fatal influence on the sources of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national existence. Every government seems to be afflicted by some evil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is inherent in its nature, and the genius of the legislator is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shown in eluding its attacks. A State may survive the influence of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: host of bad laws, and the mischief they cause is frequently exaggerated;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but a law which encourages the growth of the canker within must prove
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fatal in the end, although its bad consequences may not be immediately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceived.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principle of destruction in absolute monarchies lies in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excessive and unreasonable extension of the prerogative of the crown;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and a measure tending to remove the constitutional provisions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: counterbalance this influence would be radically bad, even if its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediate consequences were unattended with evil. By a parity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reasoning, in countries governed by a democracy, where the people is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually drawing all authority to itself, the laws which increase or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accelerate its action are the direct assailants of the very principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greatest proof of the ability of the American legislators is, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they clearly discerned this truth, and that they had the courage to act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up to it. They conceived that a certain authority above the body of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people was necessary, which should enjoy a degree of independence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without, however, being entirely beyond the popular control;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an authority which would be forced to comply with the permanent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determinations of the majority, but which would be able to resist its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: caprices, and to refuse its most dangerous demands. To this end they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centred the whole executive power of the nation in a single arm; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: granted extensive prerogatives to the President, and they armed him with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the veto to resist the encroachments of the legislature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But by introducing the principle of re-election they partly destroyed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their work; and they rendered the President but little inclined to exert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great power they had vested in his hands. If ineligible a second
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, the President would be far from independent of the people, for his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsibility would not be lessened; but the favor of the people would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not be so necessary to him as to induce him to court it by humoring its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires. If re-eligible (and this is more especially true at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day, when political morality is relaxed, and when great men are rare),
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the President of the United States becomes an easy tool in the hands of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the majority. He adopts its likings and its animosities, he hastens to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anticipate its wishes, he forestalls its complaints, he yields to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idlest cravings, and instead of guiding it, as the legislature intended
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that he should do, he is ever ready to follow its bidding. Thus, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order not to deprive the State of the talents of an individual, those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talents have been rendered almost useless; and to reserve an expedient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for extraordinary perils, the country has been exposed to daily dangers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Courts *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: See chap. VI, entitled "Judicial Power in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States." This chapter explains the general principles of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theory of judicial institutions. See also the Federal Constitution, Art.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 3. See "The Federalists," Nos. 78-83, inclusive; and a work entitled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Constitutional Law," being a view of the practice and jurisdiction of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the courts of the United States, by Thomas Sergeant. See Story, pp. 134,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 162, 489, 511, 581, 668; and the organic law of September 24, 1789, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the "Collection of the Laws of the United States," by Story, vol. i. p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Political importance of the judiciary in the United States--Difficulty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of treating this subject--Utility of judicial power in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederations--What tribunals could be introduced into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union--Necessity of establishing federal courts of justice--Organization
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the national judiciary--The Supreme Court--In what it differs from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all known tribunals.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have inquired into the legislative and executive power of the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the judicial power now remains to be examined; but in this place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I cannot conceal my fears from the reader. Their judicial institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise a great influence on the condition of the Anglo-Americans, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they occupy a prominent place amongst what are probably called political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions: in this respect they are peculiarly deserving of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention. But I am at a loss to explain the political action of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American tribunals without entering into some technical details of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their constitution and their forms of proceeding; and I know not how to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descend to these minutiae without wearying the curiosity of the reader
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the natural aridity of the subject, or without risking to fall into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obscurity through a desire to be succinct. I can scarcely hope to escape
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these various evils; for if I appear too lengthy to a man of the world,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a lawyer may on the other hand complain of my brevity. But these are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural disadvantages of my subject, and more especially of the point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I am about to discuss.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great difficulty was, not to devise the Constitution to the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government, but to find out a method of enforcing its laws. Governments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have in general but two means of overcoming the opposition of the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they govern, viz., the physical force which is at their own disposal,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the moral force which they derive from the decisions of the courts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of justice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A government which should have no other means of exacting obedience than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: open war must be very near its ruin, for one of two alternatives would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then probably occur: if its authority was small and its character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temperate, it would not resort to violence till the last extremity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it would connive at a number of partial acts of insubordination,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in which case the State would gradually fall into anarchy; if it was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enterprising and powerful, it would perpetually have recourse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its physical strength, and would speedily degenerate into a military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotism. So that its activity would not be less prejudicial to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community than its inaction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great end of justice is to substitute the notion of right for that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of violence, and to place a legal barrier between the power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government and the use of physical force. The authority which is awarded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the intervention of a court of justice by the general opinion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind is so surprisingly great that it clings to the mere formalities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of justice, and gives a bodily influence to the shadow of the law. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral force which courts of justice possess renders the introduction of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: physical force exceedingly rare, and is very frequently substituted for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it; but if the latter proves to be indispensable, its power is doubled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the association of the idea of law.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A federal government stands in greater need of the support of judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions than any other, because it is naturally weak and exposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to formidable opposition. *c If it were always obliged to resort to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violence in the first instance, it could not fulfil its task. The Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, required a national judiciary to enforce the obedience of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens to the laws, and to repeal the attacks which might be directed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against them. The question then remained as to what tribunals were to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise these privileges; were they to be entrusted to the courts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice which were already organized in every State? or was it necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to create federal courts? It may easily be proved that the Union could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not adapt the judicial power of the States to its wants. The separation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the judiciary from the administrative power of the State no doubt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affects the security of every citizen and the liberty of all. But it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is no less important to the existence of the nation that these several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers should have the same origin, should follow the same principles,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and act in the same sphere; in a word, that they should be correlative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and homogeneous. No one, I presume, ever suggested the advantage of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trying offences committed in France by a foreign court of justice, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to secure the impartiality of the judges. The Americans form one
