author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people in relation to their Federal Government; but in the bosom of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people divers political bodies have been allowed to subsist which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependent on the national Government in a few points, and independent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all the rest; which have all a distinct origin, maxims peculiar to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, and special means of carrying on their affairs. To entrust
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the execution of the laws of the Union to tribunals instituted by these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political bodies would be to allow foreign judges to preside over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation. Nay, more; not only is each State foreign to the Union at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large, but it is in perpetual opposition to the common interests, since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever authority the Union loses turns to the advantage of the States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus to enforce the laws of the Union by means of the tribunals of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States would be to allow not only foreign but partial judges to preside
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: Federal laws are those which most require courts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice, and those at the same time which have most rarely established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. The reason is that confederations have usually been formed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent States, which entertained no real intention of obeying the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central Government, and which very readily ceded the right of command
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the federal executive, and very prudently reserved the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: non-compliance to themselves.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the number, still more than the mere character, of the tribunals of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States rendered them unfit for the service of the nation. When the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Constitution was formed there were already thirteen courts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice in the United States which decided causes without appeal. That
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number is now increased to twenty-four. To suppose that a State can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsist when its fundamental laws may be subjected to four-and-twenty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different interpretations at the same time is to advance a proposition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike contrary to reason and to experience.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American legislators therefore agreed to create a federal judiciary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power to apply the laws of the Union, and to determine certain questions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affecting general interests, which were carefully determined beforehand.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The entire judicial power of the Union was centred in one tribunal,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which was denominated the Supreme Court of the United States. But, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facilitate the expedition of business, inferior courts were appended to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it, which were empowered to decide causes of small importance without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeal, and with appeal causes of more magnitude. The members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Supreme Court are named neither by the people nor the legislature, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the President of the United States, acting with the advice of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Senate. In order to render them independent of the other authorities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their office was made inalienable; and it was determined that their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: salary, when once fixed, should not be altered by the legislature. *d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It was easy to proclaim the principle of a Federal judiciary, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulties multiplied when the extent of its jurisdiction was to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determined.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: The Union was divided into districts, in each of which a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resident Federal judge was appointed, and the court in which he presided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was termed a "District Court." Each of the judges of the Supreme Court
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annually visits a certain portion of the Republic, in order to try the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most important causes upon the spot; the court presided over by this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrate is styled a "Circuit Court." Lastly, all the most serious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases of litigation are brought before the Supreme Court, which holds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a solemn session once a year, at which all the judges of the Circuit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Courts must attend. The jury was introduced into the Federal Courts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the same manner, and in the same cases, as into the courts of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It will be observed that no analogy exists between the Supreme Court
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States and the French Cour de Cassation, since the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only hears appeals on questions of law. The Supreme Court decides upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the evidence of the fact as well as upon the law of the case, whereas
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Cour de Cassation does not pronounce a decision of its own, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refers the cause to the arbitration of another tribunal. See the law of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: September 24, 1789, "Laws of the United States," by Story, vol. i. p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Means Of Determining The Jurisdiction Of The Federal Courts Difficulty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of determining the jurisdiction of separate courts of justice in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederations--The courts of the Union obtained the right of fixing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own jurisdiction--In what respect this rule attacks the portion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of sovereignty reserved to the several States--The sovereignty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these States restricted by the laws, and the interpretation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws--Consequently, the danger of the several States is more apparent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than real.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the Constitution of the United States recognized two distinct powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in presence of each other, represented in a judicial point of view by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two distinct classes of courts of justice, the utmost care which could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be taken in defining their separate jurisdictions would have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insufficient to prevent frequent collisions between those tribunals. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: question then arose to whom the right of deciding the competency of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: court was to be referred.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In nations which constitute a single body politic, when a question is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: debated between two courts relating to their mutual jurisdiction, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: third tribunal is generally within reach to decide the difference;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and this is effected without difficulty, because in these nations the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: questions of judicial competency have no connection with the privileges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the national supremacy. But it was impossible to create an arbiter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between a superior court of the Union and the superior court of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separate State which would not belong to one of these two classes. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was, therefore, necessary to allow one of these courts to judge its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own cause, and to take or to retain cognizance of the point which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contested. To grant this privilege to the different courts of the States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would have been to destroy the sovereignty of the Union de facto
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after having established it de jure; for the interpretation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution would soon have restored that portion of independence to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States of which the terms of that act deprived them. The object
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the creation of a Federal tribunal was to prevent the courts of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States from deciding questions affecting the national interests in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own department, and so to form a uniform body of jurisprudene for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interpretation of the laws of the Union. This end would not have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accomplished if the courts of the several States had been competent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to decide upon cases in their separate capacities from which they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to abstain as Federal tribunals. The Supreme Court of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States was therefore invested with the right of determining all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: questions of jurisdiction. *e
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: In order to diminish the number of these suits, it was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decided that in a great many Federal causes the courts of the States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be empowered to decide conjointly with those of the Union, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: losing party having then a right of appeal to the Supreme Court of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States. The Supreme Court of Virginia contested the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Supreme Court of the United States to judge an appeal from its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decisions, but unsuccessfully. See "Kent's Commentaries," vol. i. p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 300, pp. 370 et seq.; Story's "Commentaries," p. 646; and "The Organic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Law of the United States," vol. i. p. 35.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This was a severe blow upon the independence of the States, which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus restricted not only by the laws, but by the interpretation of them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by one limit which was known, and by another which was dubious; by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rule which was certain, and a rule which was arbitrary. It is true the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution had laid down the precise limits of the Federal supremacy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but whenever this supremacy is contested by one of the States, a Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribunal decides the question. Nevertheless, the dangers with which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence of the States was threatened by this mode of proceeding are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less serious than they appeared to be. We shall see hereafter that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America the real strength of the country is vested in the provincial far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more than in the Federal Government. The Federal judges are conscious of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the relative weakness of the power in whose name they act, and they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more inclined to abandon a right of jurisdiction in cases where it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justly their own than to assert a privilege to which they have no legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: claim.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Different Cases Of Jurisdiction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The matter and the party are the first conditions of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction--Suits in which ambassadors are engaged--Suits of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union--Of a separate State--By whom tried--Causes resulting from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws of the Union--Why judged by the Federal tribunals--Causes relating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the performance of contracts tried by the Federal courts--Consequence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this arrangement.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: After having appointed the means of fixing the competency of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courts, the legislators of the Union defined the cases which should come
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within their jurisdiction. It was established, on the one hand, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain parties must always be brought before the Federal courts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without any regard to the special nature of the cause; and, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, that certain causes must always be brought before the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courts, without any regard to the quality of the parties in the suit.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These distinctions were therefore admitted to be the basis of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal jurisdiction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ambassadors are the representatives of nations in a state of amity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the Union, and whatever concerns these personages concerns in some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degree the whole Union. When an ambassador is a party in a suit, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suit affects the welfare of the nation, and a Federal tribunal is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally called upon to decide it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Union itself may be invoked in legal proceedings, and in this case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it would be alike contrary to the customs of all nations and to common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sense to appeal to a tribunal representing any other sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than its own; the Federal courts, therefore, take cognizance of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When two parties belonging to two different States are engaged in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suit, the case cannot with propriety be brought before a court of either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State. The surest expedient is to select a tribunal like that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union, which can excite the suspicions of neither party, and which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offers the most natural as well as the most certain remedy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the two parties are not private individuals, but States, an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important political consideration is added to the same motive of equity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The quality of the parties in this case gives a national importance to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all their disputes; and the most trifling litigation of the States may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be said to involve the peace of the whole Union. *f
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: The Constitution also says that the Federal courts shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decide "controversies between a State and the citizens of another
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State." And here a most important question of a constitutional nature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arose, which was, whether the jurisdiction given by the Constitution in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases in which a State is a party extended to suits brought against a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State as well as by it, or was exclusively confined to the latter. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: question was most elaborately considered in the case of Chisholm v.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Georgia, and was decided by the majority of the Supreme Court in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affirmative. The decision created general alarm among the States, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an amendment was proposed and ratified by which the power was entirely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken away, so far as it regards suits brought against a State. See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Story's "Commentaries," p. 624, or in the large edition Section 1677.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The nature of the cause frequently prescribes the rule of competency.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus all the questions which concern maritime commerce evidently fall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under the cognizance of the Federal tribunals. *g Almost all these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: questions are connected with the interpretation of the law of nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in this respect they essentially interest the Union in relation to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign powers. Moreover, as the sea is not included within the limits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of any peculiar jurisdiction, the national courts can only hear causes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which originate in maritime affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: As for instance, all cases of piracy.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Constitution comprises under one head almost all the cases which by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their very nature come within the limits of the Federal courts. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rule which it lays down is simple, but pregnant with an entire system of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideas, and with a vast multitude of facts. It declares that the judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of the Supreme Court shall extend to all cases in law and equity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arising under the laws of the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Two examples will put the intention of the legislator in the clearest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: light:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Constitution prohibits the States from making laws on the value
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and circulation of money: If, notwithstanding this prohibition, a State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passes a law of this kind, with which the interested parties refuse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comply because it is contrary to the Constitution, the case must come
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before a Federal court, because it arises under the laws of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. Again, if difficulties arise in the levying of import duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which have been voted by Congress, the Federal court must decide the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case, because it arises under the interpretation of a law of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This rule is in perfect accordance with the fundamental principles of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal Constitution. The Union, as it was established in 1789,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possesses, it is true, a limited supremacy; but it was intended that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within its limits it should form one and the same people. *h Within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those limits the Union is sovereign. When this point is established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and admitted, the inference is easy; for if it be acknowledged that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States constitute one and the same people within the bounds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prescribed by their Constitution, it is impossible to refuse them the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights which belong to other nations. But it has been allowed, from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: origin of society, that every nation has the right of deciding by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own courts those questions which concern the execution of its own laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To this it is answered that the Union is in so singular a position
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in relation to some matters it constitutes a people, and that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relation to all the rest it is a nonentity. But the inference to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: drawn is, that in the laws relating to these matters the Union possesses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the rights of absolute sovereignty. The difficulty is to know what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these matters are; and when once it is resolved (and we have shown
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: how it was resolved, in speaking of the means of determining the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction of the Federal courts) no further doubt can arise; for as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soon as it is established that a suit is Federal--that is to say, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it belongs to the share of sovereignty reserved by the Constitution of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union--the natural consequence is that it should come within the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction of a Federal court.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: This principle was in some measure restricted by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduction of the several States as independent powers into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Senate, and by allowing them to vote separately in the House of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives when the President is elected by that body. But these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are exceptions, and the contrary principle is the rule.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whenever the laws of the United States are attacked, or whenever they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are resorted to in self-defence, the Federal courts must be appealed to.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the jurisdiction of the tribunals of the Union extends and narrows
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its limits exactly in the same ratio as the sovereignty of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augments or decreases. We have shown that the principal aim of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislators of 1789 was to divide the sovereign authority into two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parts. In the one they placed the control of all the general interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union, in the other the control of the special interests of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its component States. Their chief solicitude was to arm the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government with sufficient power to enable it to resist, within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its sphere, the encroachments of the several States. As for these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities, the principle of independence within certain limits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own was adopted in their behalf; and they were concealed from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inspection, and protected from the control, of the central Government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In speaking of the division of authority, I observed that this latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle had not always been held sacred, since the States are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevented from passing certain laws which apparently belong to their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular sphere of interest. When a State of the Union passes a law of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this kind, the citizens who are injured by its execution can appeal to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal courts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the jurisdiction of the Federal courts extends not only to all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases which arise under the laws of the Union, but also to those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which arise under laws made by the several States in opposition to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution. The States are prohibited from making ex post facto laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in criminal cases, and any person condemned by virtue of a law of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind can appeal to the judicial power of the Union. The States are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: likewise prohibited from making laws which may have a tendency to impair
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the obligations of contracts. *i If a citizen thinks that an obligation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this kind is impaired by a law passed in his State, he may refuse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obey it, and may appeal to the Federal courts. *j
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: It is perfectly clear, says Mr. Story ("Commentaries," p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 503, or in the large edition Section 1379), that any law which enlarges,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abridges, or in any manner changes the intention of the parties,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resulting from the stipulations in the contract, necessarily impairs it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He gives in the same place a very long and careful definition of what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood by a contract in Federal jurisprudence. A grant made by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State to a private individual, and accepted by him, is a contract, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be revoked by any future law. A charter granted by the State to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a company is a contract, and equally binding to the State as to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grantee. The clause of the Constitution here referred to insures,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, the existence of a great part of acquired rights, but not of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all. Property may legally be held, though it may not have passed into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the possessor's hands by means of a contract; and its possession is an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquired right, not guaranteed by the Federal Constitution.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: A remarkable instance of this is given by Mr. Story (p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 508, or in the large edition Section 1388): "Dartmouth College in New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hampshire had been founded by a charter granted to certain individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before the American Revolution, and its trustees formed a corporation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under this charter. The legislature of New Hampshire had, without the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consent of this corporation, passed an act changing the organization of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the original provincial charter of the college, and transferring all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights, privileges, and franchises from the old charter trustees to new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trustees appointed under the act. The constitutionality of the act was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contested, and, after solemn arguments, it was deliberately held by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Supreme Court that the provincial charter was a contract within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the meaning of the Constitution (Art. I. Section 10), and that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emendatory act was utterly void, as impairing the obligation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that charter. The college was deemed, like other colleges of private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foundation, to be a private eleemosynary institution, endowed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its charter with a capacity to take property unconnected with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government. Its funds were bestowed upon the faith of the charter, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those funds consisted entirely of private donations. It is true that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uses were in some sense public, that is, for the general benefit, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not for the mere benefit of the corporators; but this did not make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the corporation a public corporation. It was a private institution for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general charity. It was not distinguishable in principle from a private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: donation, vested in private trustees, for a public charity, or for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a particular purpose of beneficence. And the State itself, if it had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bestowed funds upon a charity of the same nature, could not resume those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: funds."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This provision appears to me to be the most serious attack upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence of the States. The rights awarded to the Federal Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for purposes of obvious national importance are definite and easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comprehensible; but those with which this last clause invests it are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not either clearly appreciable or accurately defined. For there are vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numbers of political laws which influence the existence of obligations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of contracts, which may thus furnish an easy pretext for the aggressions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the central authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: The Federal Constitution--Part IV
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Procedure Of The Federal Courts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Natural weakness of the judiciary power in confederations--Legislators
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought to strive as much as possible to bring private individuals, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not States, before the Federal Courts--How the Americans have succeeded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this--Direct prosecution of private individuals in the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Courts--Indirect prosecution of the States which violate the laws of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union--The decrees of the Supreme Court enervate but do not destroy the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provincial laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown what the privileges of the Federal courts are, and it is no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less important to point out the manner in which they are exercised. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible authority of justice in countries in which the sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in undivided is derived from the fact that the tribunals of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries represent the entire nation at issue with the individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against whom their decree is directed, and the idea of power is thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced to corroborate the idea of right. But this is not always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the case in countries in which the sovereignty is divided; in them the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judicial power is more frequently opposed to a fraction of the nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than to an isolated individual, and its moral authority and physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength are consequently diminished. In federal States the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the judge is naturally decreased, and that of the justiciable parties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is augmented. The aim of the legislator in confederate States ought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore to be to render the position of the courts of justice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: analogous to that which they occupy in countries where the sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is undivided; in other words, his efforts ought constantly to tend to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintain the judicial power of the confederation as the representative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation, and the justiciable party as the representative of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual interest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Every government, whatever may be its constitution, requires the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of constraining its subjects to discharge their obligations, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protecting its privileges from their assaults. As far as the direct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action of the Government on the community is concerned, the Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States contrived, by a master-stroke of policy, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the federal courts, acting in the name of the laws, should only take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cognizance of parties in an individual capacity. For, as it had been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declared that the Union consisted of one and the same people within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the limits laid down by the Constitution, the inference was that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government created by this Constitution, and acting within these limits,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was invested with all the privileges of a national government, one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principal of which is the right of transmitting its injunctions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directly to the private citizen. When, for instance, the Union votes an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impost, it does not apply to the States for the levying of it, but to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every American citizen in proportion to his assessment. The Supreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Court, which is empowered to enforce the execution of this law of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union, exerts its influence not upon a refractory State, but upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private taxpayer; and, like the judicial power of other nations, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposed to the person of an individual. It is to be observed that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union chose its own antagonist; and as that antagonist is feeble, he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally worsted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the difficulty increases when the proceedings are not brought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forward by but against the Union. The Constitution recognizes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative power of the States; and a law so enacted may impair the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges of the Union, in which case a collision in unavoidable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between that body and the State which has passed the law: and it only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains to select the least dangerous remedy, which is very clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deducible from the general principles I have before established. *k
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: See Chapter VI. on "Judicial Power in America."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may be conceived that, in the case under consideration, the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might have used the State before a Federal court, which would have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annulled the act, and by this means it would have adopted a natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course of proceeding; but the judicial power would have been placed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in open hostility to the State, and it was desirable to avoid this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predicament as much as possible. The Americans hold that it is nearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible that a new law should not impair the interests of some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private individual by its provisions: these private interests are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assumed by the American legislators as the ground of attack against such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures as may be prejudicial to the Union, and it is to these cases
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the protection of the Supreme Court is extended.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Suppose a State vends a certain portion of its territory to a company,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that a year afterwards it passes a law by which the territory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is otherwise disposed of, and that clause of the Constitution which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prohibits laws impairing the obligation of contracts violated. When the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purchaser under the second act appears to take possession, the possessor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under the first act brings his action before the tribunals of the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and causes the title of the claimant to be pronounced null and void. *l
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, in point of fact, the judicial power of the Union is contesting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the claims of the sovereignty of a State; but it only acts indirectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and upon a special application of detail: it attacks the law in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences, not in its principle, and it rather weakens than destroys
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: See Kent's "Commentaries," vol. i. p. 387.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The last hypothesis that remained was that each State formed a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corporation enjoying a separate existence and distinct civil rights, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it could therefore sue or be sued before a tribunal. Thus a State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could bring an action against another State. In this instance the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not called upon to contest a provincial law, but to try a suit in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which a State was a party. This suit was perfectly similar to any other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause, except that the quality of the parties was different; and here
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the danger pointed out at the beginning of this chapter exists with less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chance of being avoided. The inherent disadvantage of the very essence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Federal constitutions is that they engender parties in the bosom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation which present powerful obstacles to the free course of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: High Rank Of The Supreme Court Amongst The Great Powers Of State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No nation ever constituted so great a judicial power as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans--Extent of its prerogative--Its political influence--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tranquillity and the very existence of the Union depend on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discretion of the seven Federal Judges.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When we have successively examined in detail the organization of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Supreme Court, and the entire prerogatives which it exercises, we shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily admit that a more imposing judicial power was never constituted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by any people. The Supreme Court is placed at the head of all known
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribunals, both by the nature of its rights and the class of justiciable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parties which it controls.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In all the civilized countries of Europe the Government has always shown
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the greatest repugnance to allow the cases to which it was itself a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: party to be decided by the ordinary course of justice. This repugnance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally attains its utmost height in an absolute Government; and, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other hand, the privileges of the courts of justice are extended
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the increasing liberties of the people: but no European nation has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at present held that all judicial controversies, without regard to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: origin, can be decided by the judges of common law.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America this theory has been actually put in practice, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Supreme Court of the United States is the sole tribunal of the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Its power extends to all the cases arising under laws and treaties made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the executive and legislative authorities, to all cases of admiralty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and maritime jurisdiction, and in general to all points which affect the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law of nations. It may even be affirmed that, although its constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is essentially judicial, its prerogatives are almost entirely political.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Its sole object is to enforce the execution of the laws of the Union;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the Union only regulates the relations of the Government with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens, and of the nation with Foreign Powers: the relations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens amongst themselves are almost exclusively regulated by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereignty of the States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A second and still greater cause of the preponderance of this court
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be adduced. In the nations of Europe the courts of justice are only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called upon to try the controversies of private individuals; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Supreme Court of the United States summons sovereign powers to its bar.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the clerk of the court advances on the steps of the tribunal, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simply says, "The State of New York versus the State of Ohio," it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible not to feel that the Court which he addresses is no ordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body; and when it is recollected that one of these parties represents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one million, and the other two millions of men, one is struck by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsibility of the seven judges whose decision is about to satisfy or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to disappoint so large a number of their fellow-citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The peace, the prosperity, and the very existence of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are vested in the hands of the seven judges. Without their active
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operation the Constitution would be a dead letter: the Executive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeals to them for assistance against the encroachments of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative powers; the Legislature demands their protection from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: designs of the Executive; they defend the Union from the disobedience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States, the States from the exaggerated claims of the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the public interest against the interests of private citizens, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the conservative spirit of order against the fleeting innovations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy. Their power is enormous, but it is clothed in the authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of public opinion. They are the all-powerful guardians of a people which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respects law, but they would be impotent against popular neglect or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular contempt. The force of public opinion is the most intractable of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agents, because its exact limits cannot be defined; and it is not less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous to exceed than to remain below the boundary prescribed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal judges must not only be good citizens, and men possessed of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that information and integrity which are indispensable to magistrates,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they must be statesmen--politicians, not unread in the signs of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: times, not afraid to brave the obstacles which can be subdued, nor slow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to turn aside such encroaching elements as may threaten the supremacy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union and the obedience which is due to the laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The President, who exercises a limited power, may err without causing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great mischief in the State. Congress may decide amiss without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destroying the Union, because the electoral body in which Congress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originates may cause it to retract its decision by changing its members.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But if the Supreme Court is ever composed of imprudent men or bad
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens, the Union may be plunged into anarchy or civil war.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The real cause of this danger, however, does not lie in the constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the tribunal, but in the very nature of Federal Governments. We
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have observed that in confederate peoples it is especially necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consolidate the judicial authority, because in no other nations do those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent persons who are able to cope with the social body exist in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater power or in a better condition to resist the physical strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Government. But the more a power requires to be strengthened, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more extensive and independent it must be made; and the dangers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which its abuse may create are heightened by its independence and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength. The source of the evil is not, therefore, in the constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the power, but in the constitution of those States which render its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence necessary.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In What Respects The Federal Constitution Is Superior To That Of The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In what respects the Constitution of the Union can be compared to that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States--Superiority of the Constitution of the Union attributable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the wisdom of the Federal legislators--Legislature of the Union less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependent on the people than that of the States--Executive power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more independent in its sphere--Judicial power less subjected to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclinations of the majority--Practical consequence of these facts--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers inherent in a democratic government eluded by the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislators, and increased by the legislators of the States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal Constitution differs essentially from that of the States in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ends which it is intended to accomplish, but in the means by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these ends are promoted a greater analogy exists between them. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects of the Governments are different, but their forms are the same;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in this special point of view there is some advantage in comparing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them together.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am of opinion that the Federal Constitution is superior to all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitutions of the States, for several reasons.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The present Constitution of the Union was formed at a later period
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than those of the majority of the States, and it may have derived some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ameliorations from past experience. But we shall be led to acknowledge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that this is only a secondary cause of its superiority, when we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recollect that eleven new States *n have been added to the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Confederation since the promulgation of the Federal Constitution, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that these new republics have always rather exaggerated than avoided the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defects which existed in the former Constitutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: [The number of States has now risen to 46 (1874), besides
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the District of Columbia.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The chief cause of the superiority of the Federal Constitution lay in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the character of the legislators who composed it. At the time when it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was formed the dangers of the Confederation were imminent, and its ruin
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seemed inevitable. In this extremity the people chose the men who most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deserved the esteem, rather than those who had gained the affections,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the country. I have already observed that distinguished as almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the legislators of the Union were for their intelligence, they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still more so for their patriotism. They had all been nurtured at a time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when the spirit of liberty was braced by a continual struggle against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a powerful and predominant authority. When the contest was terminated,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst the excited passions of the populace persisted in warring with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers which had ceased to threaten them, these men stopped short in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their career; they cast a calmer and more penetrating look upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country which was now their own; they perceived that the war of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence was definitely ended, and that the only dangers which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America had to fear were those which might result from the abuse of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom she had won. They had the courage to say what they believed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be true, because they were animated by a warm and sincere love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty; and they ventured to propose restrictions, because they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resolutely opposed to destruction. *o
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: At this time Alexander Hamilton, who was one of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal founders of the Constitution, ventured to express the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: following sentiments in "The Federalist," No. 71:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "There are some who would be inclined to regard the servile pliancy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Executive to a prevailing current, either in the community or in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Legislature, as its best recommendation. But such men entertain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very crude notions, as well of the purposes for which government was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instituted as of the true means by which the public happiness may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promoted. The Republican principle demands that the deliberative sense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community should govern the conduct of those to whom they entrust
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the management of their affairs; but it does not require an unqualified
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complaisance to every sudden breeze of passion, or to every transient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impulse which the people may receive from the arts of men who flatter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their prejudices to betray their interests. It is a just observation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the people commonly intend the public good. This often applies to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their very errors. But their good sense would despise the adulator
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who should pretend that they always reason right about the means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promoting it. They know from experience that they sometimes err; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wonder is that they so seldom err as they do, beset, as they continually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are, by the wiles of parasites and sycophants; by the snares of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambitious, the avaricious, the desperate; by the artifices of men who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possess their confidence more than they deserve it, and of those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seek to possess rather than to deserve it. When occasions present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves in which the interests of the people are at variance with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their inclinations, it is the duty of persons whom they have appointed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be the guardians of those interests to withstand the temporary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delusion, in order to give them time and opportunity for more cool and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sedate reflection. Instances might be cited in which a conduct of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind has saved the people from very fatal consequences of their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mistakes, and has procured lasting monuments of their gratitude to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men who had courage and magnanimity enough to serve them at the peril of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their displeasure."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greater number of the Constitutions of the States assign one year
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the duration of the House of Representatives, and two years for that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Senate; so that members of the legislative body are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and narrowly tied down by the slightest desires of their constituents.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The legislators of the Union were of opinion that this excessive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependence of the Legislature tended to alter the nature of the main
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences of the representative system, since it vested the source,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only of authority, but of government, in the people. They increased
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the length of the time for which the representatives were returned, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to give them freer scope for the exercise of their own judgment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal Constitution, as well as the Constitutions of the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, divided the legislative body into two branches. But in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States these two branches were composed of the same elements, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elected in the same manner. The consequence was that the passions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and inclinations of the populace were as rapidly and as energetically
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represented in one chamber as in the other, and that laws were made with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the characteristics of violence and precipitation. By the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution the two houses originate in like manner in the choice of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people; but the conditions of eligibility and the mode of election
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were changed, to the end that, if, as is the case in certain nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one branch of the Legislature represents the same interests as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, it may at least represent a superior degree of intelligence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and discretion. A mature age was made one of the conditions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: senatorial dignity, and the Upper House was chosen by an elected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assembly of a limited number of members.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To concentrate the whole social force in the hands of the legislative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body is the natural tendency of democracies; for as this is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power which emanates the most directly from the people, it is made to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: participate most fully in the preponderating authority of the multitude,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it is naturally led to monopolize every species of influence. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concentration is at once prejudicial to a well-conducted administration,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and favorable to the despotism of the majority. The legislators of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States frequently yielded to these democratic propensities, which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invariably and courageously resisted by the founders of the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the States the executive power is vested in the hands of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrate, who is apparently placed upon a level with the Legislature,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but who is in reality nothing more than the blind agent and the passive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instrument of its decisions. He can derive no influence from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duration of his functions, which terminate with the revolving year, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the exercise of prerogatives which can scarcely be said to exist.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Legislature can condemn him to inaction by intrusting the execution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the laws to special committees of its own members, and can annul
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his temporary dignity by depriving him of his salary. The Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution vests all the privileges and all the responsibility of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive power in a single individual. The duration of the Presidency
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is fixed at four years; the salary of the individual who fills that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: office cannot be altered during the term of his functions; he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protected by a body of official dependents, and armed with a suspensive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: veto. In short, every effort was made to confer a strong and independent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position upon the executive authority within the limits which had been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prescribed to it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the Constitutions of all the States the judicial power is that which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains the most independent of the legislative authority; nevertheless,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all the States the Legislature has reserved to itself the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulating the emoluments of the judges, a practice which necessarily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjects these magistrates to its immediate influence. In some States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the judges are only temporarily appointed, which deprives them of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great portion of their power and their freedom. In others the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative and judicial powers are entirely confounded; thus the Senate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of New York, for instance, constitutes in certain cases the Superior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Court of the State. The Federal Constitution, on the other hand,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carefully separates the judicial authority from all external influences;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it provides for the independence of the judges, by declaring that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their salary shall not be altered, and that their functions shall be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inalienable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The practical consequences of these different systems may easily be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceived. An attentive observer will soon remark that the business of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union is incomparably better conducted than that of any individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State. The conduct of the Federal Government is more fair and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temperate than that of the States, its designs are more fraught with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wisdom, its projects are more durable and more skilfully combined, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures are put into execution with more vigor and consistency.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I recapitulate the substance of this chapter in a few words: The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of democracies is threatened by two dangers, viz., the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complete subjection of the legislative body to the caprices of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the electoral body, and the concentration of all the powers of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government in the legislative authority. The growth of these evils has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been encouraged by the policy of the legislators of the States, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has been resisted by the legislators of the Union by every means which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lay within their control.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Characteristics Which Distinguish The Federal Constitution Of The United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States Of America From All Other Federal Constitutions American Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appears to resemble all other confederations--Nevertheless its effects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are different--Reason of this--Distinctions between the Union and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other confederations--The American Government not a federal but an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperfect national Government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The United States of America do not afford either the first or the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instance of confederate States, several of which have existed in modern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe, without adverting to those of antiquity. Switzerland, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Germanic Empire, and the Republic of the United Provinces either have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been or still are confederations. In studying the constitutions of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different countries, the politician is surprised to observe that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers with which they invested the Federal Government are nearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: identical with the privileges awarded by the American Constitution to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Government of the United States. They confer upon the central power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same rights of making peace and war, of raising money and troops,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of providing for the general exigencies and the common interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation. Nevertheless the Federal Government of these different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peoples has always been as remarkable for its weakness and inefficiency
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as that of the Union is for its vigorous and enterprising spirit. Again,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the first American Confederation perished through the excessive weakness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its Government; and this weak Government was, notwithstanding, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of rights even more extensive than those of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of the present day. But the more recent Constitution of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States contains certain principles which exercise a most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important influence, although they do not at once strike the observer.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This Constitution, which may at first sight be confounded with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal constitutions which preceded it, rests upon a novel theory,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which may be considered as a great invention in modern political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: science. In all the confederations which had been formed before the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American Constitution of 1789 the allied States agreed to obey the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: injunctions of a Federal Government; but they reserved to themselves the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of ordaining and enforcing the execution of the laws of the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American States which combined in 1789 agreed that the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government should not only dictate the laws, but that it should execute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it own enactments. In both cases the right is the same, but the exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the right is different; and this alteration produced the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: momentous consequences.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In all the confederations which had been formed before the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union the Federal Government demanded its supplies at the hands of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separate Governments; and if the measure it prescribed was onerous to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any one of those bodies means were found to evade its claims: if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State was powerful, it had recourse to arms; if it was weak, it connived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the resistance which the law of the Union, its sovereign, met with,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and resorted to inaction under the plea of inability. Under these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances one of the two alternatives has invariably occurred;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either the most preponderant of the allied peoples has assumed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges of the Federal authority and ruled all the States in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: name, *p or the Federal Government has been abandoned by its natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supporters, anarchy has arisen between the confederates, and the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has lost all powers of action. *q
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: This was the case in Greece, when Philip undertook to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: execute the decree of the Amphictyons; in the Low Countries, where the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: province of Holland always gave the law; and, in our own time, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Germanic Confederation, in which Austria and Prussia assume a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degree of influence over the whole country, in the name of the Diet.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: Such has always been the situation of the Swiss
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Confederation, which would have perished ages ago but for the mutual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jealousies of its neighbors.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the subjects of the Union are not States, but private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens: the national Government levies a tax, not upon the State of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts, but upon each inhabitant of Massachusetts. All former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederate governments presided over communities, but that of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules individuals; its force is not borrowed, but self-derived; and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is served by its own civil and military officers, by its own army, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its own courts of justice. It cannot be doubted that the spirit of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, the passions of the multitude, and the provincial prejudices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of each State tend singularly to diminish the authority of a Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority thus constituted, and to facilitate the means of resistance to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its mandates; but the comparative weakness of a restricted sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is an evil inherent in the Federal system. In America, each State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has fewer opportunities of resistance and fewer temptations to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: non-compliance; nor can such a design be put in execution (if indeed it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be entertained) without an open violation of the laws of the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a direct interruption of the ordinary course of justice, and a bold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declaration of revolt; in a word, without taking a decisive step which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men hesitate to adopt.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In all former confederations the privileges of the Union furnished more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elements of discord than of power, since they multiplied the claims
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation without augmenting the means of enforcing them: and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accordance with this fact it may be remarked that the real weakness of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal governments has almost always been in the exact ratio of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nominal power. Such is not the case in the American Union, in which,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as in ordinary governments, the Federal Government has the means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enforcing all it is empowered to demand.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The human understanding more easily invents new things than new words,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and we are thence constrained to employ a multitude of improper and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inadequate expressions. When several nations form a permanent league
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and establish a supreme authority, which, although it has not the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence over the members of the community as a national government,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acts upon each of the Confederate States in a body, this Government,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is so essentially different from all others, is denominated a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal one. Another form of society is afterwards discovered, in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several peoples are fused into one and the same nation with regard to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain common interests, although they remain distinct, or at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only confederate, with regard to all their other concerns. In this case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the central power acts directly upon those whom it governs, whom it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules, and whom it judges, in the same manner, as, but in a more limited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circle than, a national government. Here the term Federal Government is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clearly no longer applicable to a state of things which must be styled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an incomplete national Government: a form of government has been found
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out which is neither exactly national nor federal; but no further
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress has been made, and the new word which will one day designate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this novel invention does not yet exist.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The absence of this new species of confederation has been the cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has brought all Unions to Civil War, to subjection, or to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stagnant apathy, and the peoples which formed these leagues have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either too dull to discern, or too pusillanimous to apply this great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remedy. The American Confederation perished by the same defects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the Confederate States of America had been long accustomed to form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a portion of one empire before they had won their independence; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had not contracted the habit of governing themselves, and their national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudices had not taken deep root in their minds. Superior to the rest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the world in political knowledge, and sharing that knowledge equally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst themselves, they were little agitated by the passions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally oppose the extension of federal authority in a nation, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those passions were checked by the wisdom of the chief citizens. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans applied the remedy with prudent firmness as soon as they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conscious of the evil; they amended their laws, and they saved their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: The Federal Constitution--Part V
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Advantages Of The Federal System In General, And Its Special Utility In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Happiness and freedom of small nations--Power of great nations--Great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empires favorable to the growth of civilization--Strength often the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first element of national prosperity--Aim of the Federal system to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unite the twofold advantages resulting from a small and from a large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory--Advantages derived by the United States from this system--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
