text: law adapts itself to the exigencies of the population; population does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not conform to the exigencies of the law--Activity, amelioration, love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and enjoyment of freedom in the American communities--Public spirit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union the abstract of provincial patriotism--Principles and things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circulate freely over the territory of the United States--The Union is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happy and free as a little nation, and respected as a great empire.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In small nations the scrutiny of society penetrates into every part, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the spirit of improvement enters into the most trifling details; as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition of the people is necessarily checked by its weakness, all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efforts and resources of the citizens are turned to the internal benefit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community, and are not likely to evaporate in the fleeting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: breath of glory. The desires of every individual are limited, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary faculties are rarely to be met with. The gifts of an equal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune render the various conditions of life uniform, and the manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the inhabitants are orderly and simple. Thus, if one estimate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradations of popular morality and enlightenment, we shall generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find that in small nations there are more persons in easy circumstances,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a more numerous population, and a more tranquil state of society, than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in great empires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When tyranny is established in the bosom of a small nation, it is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: galling than elsewhere, because, as it acts within a narrow circle,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every point of that circle is subject to its direct influence. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supplies the place of those great designs which it cannot entertain by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a violent or an exasperating interference in a multitude of minute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: details; and it leaves the political world, to which it properly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belongs, to meddle with the arrangements of domestic life. Tastes as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well as actions are to be regulated at its pleasure; and the families of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens as well as the affairs of the State are to be governed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its decisions. This invasion of rights occurs, however, but seldom,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and freedom is in truth the natural state of small communities. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temptations which the Government offers to ambition are too weak, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the resources of private individuals are too slender, for the sovereign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power easily to fall within the grasp of a single citizen; and should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such an event have occurred, the subjects of the State can without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty overthrow the tyrant and his oppression by a simultaneous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effort.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Small nations have therefore ever been the cradle of political liberty;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the fact that many of them have lost their immunities by extending
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their dominion shows that the freedom they enjoyed was more a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence of the inferior size than of the character of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The history of the world affords no instance of a great nation retaining
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the form of republican government for a long series of years, *r
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and this has led to the conclusion that such a state of things is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impracticable. For my own part, I cannot but censure the imprudence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempting to limit the possible and to judge the future on the part of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a being who is hourly deceived by the most palpable realities of life,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and who is constantly taken by surprise in the circumstances with which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he is most familiar. But it may be advanced with confidence that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of a great republic will always be exposed to far greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perils than that of a small one.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: I do not speak of a confederation of small republics, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a great consolidated Republic.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the passions which are most fatal to republican institutions spread
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with an increasing territory, whilst the virtues which maintain their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dignity do not augment in the same proportion. The ambition of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens increases with the power of the State; the strength of parties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the importance of the ends they have in view; but that devotion to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the common weal which is the surest check on destructive passions is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not stronger in a large than in a small republic. It might, indeed, be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proved without difficulty that it is less powerful and less sincere. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrogance of wealth and the dejection of wretchedness, capital cities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unwonted extent, a lax morality, a vulgar egotism, and a great confusion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of interests, are the dangers which almost invariably arise from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magnitude of States. But several of these evils are scarcely prejudicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a monarchy, and some of them contribute to maintain its existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In monarchical States the strength of the government is its own; it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: use, but it does not depend on, the community, and the authority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prince is proportioned to the prosperity of the nation; but the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: security which a republican government possesses against these evils
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lies in the support of the majority. This support is not, however,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportionably greater in a large republic than it is in a small one;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and thus, whilst the means of attack perpetually increase both in number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in influence, the power of resistance remains the same, or it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather be said to diminish, since the propensities and interests of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people are diversified by the increase of the population, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty of forming a compact majority is constantly augmented. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has been observed, moreover, that the intensity of human passions is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heightened, not only by the importance of the end which they propose to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attain, but by the multitude of individuals who are animated by them at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same time. Every one has had occasion to remark that his emotions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of a sympathizing crowd are far greater than those which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would have felt in solitude. In great republics the impetus of political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passion is irresistible, not only because it aims at gigantic purposes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but because it is felt and shared by millions of men at the same time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may therefore be asserted as a general proposition that nothing is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more opposed to the well-being and the freedom of man than vast empires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless it is important to acknowledge the peculiar advantages of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great States. For the very reason which renders the desire of power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more intense in these communities than amongst ordinary men, the love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glory is also more prominent in the hearts of a class of citizens,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who regard the applause of a great people as a reward worthy of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions, and an elevating encouragement to man. If we would learn why
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is that great nations contribute more powerfully to the spread of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human improvement than small States, we shall discover an adequate cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the rapid and energetic circulation of ideas, and in those great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cities which are the intellectual centres where all the rays of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genius are reflected and combined. To this it may be added that most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important discoveries demand a display of national power which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of a small State is unable to make; in great nations the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government entertains a greater number of general notions, and is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely disengaged from the routine of precedent and the egotism
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of local prejudice; its designs are conceived with more talent, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executed with more boldness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In time of peace the well-being of small nations is undoubtedly more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general and more complete, but they are apt to suffer more acutely from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the calamities of war than those great empires whose distant frontiers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may for ages avert the presence of the danger from the mass of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, which is therefore more frequently afflicted than ruined by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evil.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in this matter, as in many others, the argument derived from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessity of the case predominates over all others. If none but small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations existed, I do not doubt that mankind would be more happy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more free; but the existence of great nations is unavoidable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This consideration introduces the element of physical strength as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of national prosperity. It profits a people but little to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be affluent and free if it is perpetually exposed to be pillaged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or subjugated; the number of its manufactures and the extent of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commerce are of small advantage if another nation has the empire of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seas and gives the law in all the markets of the globe. Small nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are often impoverished, not because they are small, but because they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weak; the great empires prosper less because they are great than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they are strong. Physical strength is therefore one of the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions of the happiness and even of the existence of nations. Hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it occurs that, unless very peculiar circumstances intervene, small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations are always united to large empires in the end, either by force
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or by their own consent: yet I am unacquainted with a more deplorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spectacle than that of a people unable either to defend or to maintain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its independence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal system was created with the intention of combining the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different advantages which result from the greater and the lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent of nations; and a single glance over the United States of America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suffices to discover the advantages which they have derived from its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adoption.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In great centralized nations the legislator is obliged to impart a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character of uniformity to the laws which does not always suit the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diversity of customs and of districts; as he takes no cognizance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: special cases, he can only proceed upon general principles; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population is obliged to conform to the exigencies of the legislation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since the legislation cannot adapt itself to the exigencies and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customs of the population, which is the cause of endless trouble and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misery. This disadvantage does not exist in confederations. Congress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulates the principal measures of the national Government, and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the details of the administration are reserved to the provincial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislatures. It is impossible to imagine how much this division of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereignty contributes to the well-being of each of the States which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compose the Union. In these small communities, which are never agitated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the desire of aggrandizement or the cares of self-defence, all public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority and private energy is employed in internal amelioration. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central government of each State, which is in immediate juxtaposition to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens, is daily apprised of the wants which arise in society; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: new projects are proposed every year, which are discussed either at town
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: meetings or by the legislature of the State, and which are transmitted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the press to stimulate the zeal and to excite the interest of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens. This spirit of amelioration is constantly alive in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American republics, without compromising their tranquillity; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition of power yields to the less refined and less dangerous love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comfort. It is generally believed in America that the existence and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanence of the republican form of government in the New World depend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the existence and the permanence of the Federal system; and it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not unusual to attribute a large share of the misfortunes which have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: befallen the new States of South America to the injudicious erection of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great republics, instead of a divided and confederate sovereignty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is incontestably true that the love and the habits of republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government in the United States were engendered in the townships and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the provincial assemblies. In a small State, like that of Connecticut
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for instance, where cutting a canal or laying down a road is a momentous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political question, where the State has no army to pay and no wars to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carry on, and where much wealth and much honor cannot be bestowed upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chief citizens, no form of government can be more natural or more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appropriate than that of a republic. But it is this same republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit, it is these manners and customs of a free people, which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engendered and nurtured in the different States, to be afterwards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applied to the country at large. The public spirit of the Union is, so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to speak, nothing more than an abstract of the patriotic zeal of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provinces. Every citizen of the United States transfuses his attachment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to his little republic in the common store of American patriotism. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defending the Union he defends the increasing prosperity of his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: district, the right of conducting its affairs, and the hope of causing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures of improvement to be adopted which may be favorable to his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest; and these are motives which are wont to stir men more readily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the general interests of the country and the glory of the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, if the temper and the manners of the inhabitants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially fitted them to promote the welfare of a great republic, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal system smoothed the obstacles which they might have encountered.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The confederation of all the American States presents none of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinary disadvantages resulting from great agglomerations of men. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union is a great republic in extent, but the paucity of objects for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which its Government provides assimilates it to a small State. Its acts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are important, but they are rare. As the sovereignty of the Union is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limited and incomplete, its exercise is not incompatible with liberty;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for it does not excite those insatiable desires of fame and power which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have proved so fatal to great republics. As there is no common centre to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country, vast capital cities, colossal wealth, abject poverty, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sudden revolutions are alike unknown; and political passion, instead
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of spreading over the land like a torrent of desolation, spends its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength against the interests and the individual passions of every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, all commodities and ideas circulate throughout the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as freely as in a country inhabited by one people. Nothing checks the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit of enterprise. Government avails itself of the assistance of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who have talents or knowledge to serve it. Within the frontiers of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union the profoundest peace prevails, as within the heart of some great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empire; abroad, it ranks with the most powerful nations of the earth;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two thousand miles of coast are open to the commerce of the world; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as it possesses the keys of the globe, its flags is respected in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most remote seas. The Union is as happy and as free as a small people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and as glorious and as strong as a great nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Why The Federal System Is Not Adapted To All Peoples, And How The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans Were Enabled To Adopt It.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Every Federal system contains defects which baffle the efforts of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator--The Federal system is complex--It demands a daily exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of discretion on the part of the citizens--Practical knowledge of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government common amongst the Americans--Relative weakness of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of the Union, another defect inherent in the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system--The Americans have diminished without remedying it--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereignty of the separate States apparently weaker, but really
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stronger, than that of the Union--Why?--Natural causes of union must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist between confederate peoples besides the laws--What these causes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are amongst the Anglo-Americans--Maine and Georgia, separated by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distance of a thousand miles, more naturally united than Normandy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Brittany--War, the main peril of confederations--This proved even by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the example of the United States--The Union has no great wars to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fear--Why?--Dangers to which Europeans would be exposed if they adopted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal system of the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a legislator succeeds, after persevering efforts, in exercising an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indirect influence upon the destiny of nations, his genius is lauded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by mankind, whilst, in point of fact, the geographical position of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country which he is unable to change, a social condition which arose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without his co-operation, manners and opinions which he cannot trace to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their source, and an origin with which he is unacquainted, exercise so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible an influence over the courses of society that he is himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: borne away by the current, after an ineffectual resistance. Like the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: navigator, he may direct the vessel which bears him along, but he can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neither change its structure, nor raise the winds, nor lull the waters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which swell beneath him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown the advantages which the Americans derive from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal system; it remains for me to point out the circumstances which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rendered that system practicable, as its benefits are not to be enjoyed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by all nations. The incidental defects of the Federal system which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originate in the laws may be corrected by the skill of the legislator,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but there are further evils inherent in the system which cannot be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: counteracted by the peoples which adopt it. These nations must therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find the strength necessary to support the natural imperfections of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their Government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The most prominent evil of all Federal systems is the very complex
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature of the means they employ. Two sovereignties are necessarily in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: presence of each other. The legislator may simplify and equalize the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action of these two sovereignties, by limiting each of them to a sphere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of authority accurately defined; but he cannot combine them into one, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevent them from coming into collision at certain points. The Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system therefore rests upon a theory which is necessarily complicated,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and which demands the daily exercise of a considerable share of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discretion on the part of those it governs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A proposition must be plain to be adopted by the understanding of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. A false notion which is clear and precise will always meet with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a greater number of adherents in the world than a true principle which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is obscure or involved. Hence it arises that parties, which are like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small communities in the heart of the nation, invariably adopt some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle or some name as a symbol, which very inadequately represents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the end they have in view and the means which are at their disposal, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without which they could neither act nor subsist. The governments which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are founded upon a single principle or a single feeling which is easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defined are perhaps not the best, but they are unquestionably the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strongest and the most durable in the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In examining the Constitution of the United States, which is the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfect federal constitution that ever existed, one is startled, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other hand, at the variety of information and the excellence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discretion which it presupposes in the people whom it is meant to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: govern. The government of the Union depends entirely upon legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fictions; the Union is an ideal nation which only exists in the mind,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and whose limits and extent can only be discerned by the understanding.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When once the general theory is comprehended, numberless difficulties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain to be solved in its application; for the sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union is so involved in that of the States that it is impossible to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguish its boundaries at the first glance. The whole structure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Government is artificial and conventional; and it would be ill
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adapted to a people which has not been long accustomed to conduct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its own affairs, or to one in which the science of politics has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descended to the humblest classes of society. I have never been more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struck by the good sense and the practical judgment of the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than in the ingenious devices by which they elude the numberless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulties resulting from their Federal Constitution. I scarcely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever met with a plain American citizen who could not distinguish, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surprising facility, the obligations created by the laws of Congress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from those created by the laws of his own State; and who, after having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discriminated between the matters which come under the cognizance of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union and those which the local legislature is competent to regulate,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could not point out the exact limit of the several jurisdictions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal courts and the tribunals of the State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Constitution of the United States is like those exquisite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productions of human industry which ensure wealth and renown to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inventors, but which are profitless in any other hands. This truth is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exemplified by the condition of Mexico at the present time. The Mexicans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were desirous of establishing a federal system, and they took the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Constitution of their neighbors, the Anglo-Americans, as their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: model, and copied it with considerable accuracy. *s But although they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had borrowed the letter of the law, they were unable to create or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to introduce the spirit and the sense which give it life. They were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: involved in ceaseless embarrassments between the mechanism of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: double government; the sovereignty of the States and that of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually exceeded their respective privileges, and entered into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collision; and to the present day Mexico is alternately the victim of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anarchy and the slave of military despotism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote s: See the Mexican Constitution of 1824.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The second and the most fatal of all the defects I have alluded to,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that which I believe to be inherent in the federal system, is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relative weakness of the government of the Union. The principle upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which all confederations rest is that of a divided sovereignty. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator may render this partition less perceptible, he may even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceal it for a time from the public eye, but he cannot prevent it from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existing, and a divided sovereignty must always be less powerful than an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entire supremacy. The reader has seen in the remarks I have made on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Constitution of the United States that the Americans have displayed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: singular ingenuity in combining the restriction of the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union within the narrow limits of a federal government with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: semblance and, to a certain extent, with the force of a national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government. By this means the legislators of the Union have succeeded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in diminishing, though not in counteracting the natural danger of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has been remarked that the American Government does not apply itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the States, but that it immediately transmits its injunctions to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens, and compels them as isolated individuals to comply with its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demands. But if the Federal law were to clash with the interests and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudices of a State, it might be feared that all the citizens of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that State would conceive themselves to be interested in the cause of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single individual who should refuse to obey. If all the citizens of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State were aggrieved at the same time and in the same manner by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the Union, the Federal Government would vainly attempt to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subdue them individually; they would instinctively unite in a common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defence, and they would derive a ready-prepared organization from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: share of sovereignty which the institution of their State allows them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to enjoy. Fiction would give way to reality, and an organized portion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the territory might then contest the central authority. *t The same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observation holds good with regard to the Federal jurisdiction. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courts of the Union violated an important law of a State in a private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case, the real, if not the apparent, contest would arise between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aggrieved State represented by a citizen and the Union represented by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its courts of justice. *u
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote t: [This is precisely what occurred in 1862, and the following
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: paragraph describes correctly the feelings and notions of the South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General Lee held that his primary allegiance was due, not to the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but to Virginia.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote u: For instance, the Union possesses by the Constitution the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of selling unoccupied lands for its own profit. Supposing that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State of Ohio should claim the same right in behalf of certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territories lying within its boundaries, upon the plea that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution refers to those lands alone which do not belong to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction of any particular State, and consequently should choose to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dispose of them itself, the litigation would be carried on in the names
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the purchasers from the State of Ohio and the purchasers from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union, and not in the names of Ohio and the Union. But what would become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this legal fiction if the Federal purchaser was confirmed in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right by the courts of the Union, whilst the other competitor was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordered to retain possession by the tribunals of the State of Ohio?]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He would have but a partial knowledge of the world who should imagine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it is possible, by the aid of legal fictions, to prevent men from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: finding out and employing those means of gratifying their passions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been left open to them; and it may be doubted whether the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislators, when they rendered a collision between the two sovereigns
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less probable, destroyed the cause of such a misfortune. But it may even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be affirmed that they were unable to ensure the preponderance of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal element in a case of this kind. The Union is possessed of money
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of troops, but the affections and the prejudices of the people are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the bosom of the States. The sovereignty of the Union is an abstract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being, which is connected with but few external objects; the sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States is hourly perceptible, easily understood, constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: active; and if the former is of recent creation, the latter is coeval
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the people itself. The sovereignty of the Union is factitious, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States is natural, and derives its existence from its own simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence, like the authority of a parent. The supreme power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nation only affects a few of the chief interests of society; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represents an immense but remote country, and claims a feeling of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patriotism which is vague and ill defined; but the authority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States controls every individual citizen at every hour and in all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances; it protects his property, his freedom, and his life; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when we recollect the traditions, the customs, the prejudices of local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and familiar attachment with which it is connected, we cannot doubt of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the superiority of a power which is interwoven with every circumstance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that renders the love of one's native country instinctive in the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heart.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Since legislators are unable to obviate such dangerous collisions as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occur between the two sovereignties which coexist in the federal system,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their first object must be, not only to dissuade the confederate States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from warfare, but to encourage such institutions as may promote the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of peace. Hence it results that the Federal compact cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be lasting unless there exists in the communities which are leagued
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together a certain number of inducements to union which render their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common dependence agreeable, and the task of the Government light,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that system cannot succeed without the presence of favorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances added to the influence of good laws. All the peoples which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have ever formed a confederation have been held together by a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of common interests, which served as the intellectual ties of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the sentiments and the principles of man must be taken into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consideration as well as his immediate interests. A certain uniformity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of civilization is not less necessary to the durability of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederation than a uniformity of interests in the States which compose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. In Switzerland the difference which exists between the Canton of Uri
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the Canton of Vaud is equal to that between the fifteenth and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nineteenth centuries; and, properly speaking, Switzerland has never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed a federal government. The union between these two cantons only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsists upon the map, and their discrepancies would soon be perceived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if an attempt were made by a central authority to prescribe the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws to the whole territory.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: One of the circumstances which most powerfully contribute to support the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Government in America is that the States have not only similar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests, a common origin, and a common tongue, but that they are also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrived at the same stage of civilization; which almost always renders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a union feasible. I do not know of any European nation, how small soever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may be, which does not present less uniformity in its different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provinces than the American people, which occupies a territory as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extensive as one-half of Europe. The distance from the State of Maine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to that of Georgia is reckoned at about one thousand miles; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difference between the civilization of Maine and that of Georgia is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slighter than the difference between the habits of Normandy and those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Brittany. Maine and Georgia, which are placed at the opposite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremities of a great empire, are consequently in the natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of more real inducements to form a confederation than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Normandy and Brittany, which are only separated by a bridge.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The geographical position of the country contributed to increase the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facilities which the American legislators derived from the manners and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customs of the inhabitants; and it is to this circumstance that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the adoption and the maintenance of the Federal system are mainly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attributable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The most important occurrence which can mark the annals of a people is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the breaking out of a war. In war a people struggles with the energy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a single man against foreign nations in the defence of its very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence. The skill of a government, the good sense of the community,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the natural fondness which men entertain for their country, may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suffice to maintain peace in the interior of a district, and to favor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its internal prosperity; but a nation can only carry on a great war at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the cost of more numerous and more painful sacrifices; and to suppose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that a great number of men will of their own accord comply with these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exigencies of the State is to betray an ignorance of mankind. All the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peoples which have been obliged to sustain a long and serious warfare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have consequently been led to augment the power of their government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Those which have not succeeded in this attempt have been subjugated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A long war almost always places nations in the wretched alternative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of being abandoned to ruin by defeat or to despotism by success. War
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore renders the symptoms of the weakness of a government most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: palpable and most alarming; and I have shown that the inherent defeat of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal governments is that of being weak.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal system is not only deficient in every kind of centralized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration, but the central government itself is imperfectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: organized, which is invariably an influential cause of inferiority when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nation is opposed to other countries which are themselves governed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a single authority. In the Federal Constitution of the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by which the central government possesses more real force, this evil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is still extremely sensible. An example will illustrate the case to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reader.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Constitution confers upon Congress the right of calling forth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: militia to execute the laws of the Union, suppress insurrections, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repel invasions; and another article declares that the President of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States is the commander-in-chief of the militia. In the war of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1812 the President ordered the militia of the Northern States to march
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the frontiers; but Connecticut and Massachusetts, whose interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were impaired by the war, refused to obey the command. They argued that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Constitution authorizes the Federal Government to call forth the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: militia in case of insurrection or invasion, but that in the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instance there was neither invasion nor insurrection. They added,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the same Constitution which conferred upon the Union the right
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of calling forth the militia reserved to the States that of naming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the officers; and that consequently (as they understood the clause) no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officer of the Union had any right to command the militia, even during
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: war, except the President in person; and in this case they were ordered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to join an army commanded by another individual. These absurd and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pernicious doctrines received the sanction not only of the governors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the legislative bodies, but also of the courts of justice in both
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States; and the Federal Government was constrained to raise elsewhere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the troops which it required. *v
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote v: Kent's "Commentaries," vol. i. p. 244. I have selected an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: example which relates to a time posterior to the promulgation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present Constitution. If I had gone back to the days of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Confederation, I might have given still more striking instances. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole nation was at that time in a state of enthusiastic excitement; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Revolution was represented by a man who was the idol of the people; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at that very period Congress had, to say the truth, no resources at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all at its disposal. Troops and supplies were perpetually wanting. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: best-devised projects failed in the execution, and the Union, which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly on the verge of destruction, was saved by the weakness of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enemies far more than by its own strength. [All doubt as to the powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Federal Executive was, however, removed by its efforts in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Civil War, and those powers were largely extended.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The only safeguard which the American Union, with all the relative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfection of its laws, possesses against the dissolution which would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be produced by a great war, lies in its probable exemption from that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calamity. Placed in the centre of an immense continent, which offers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a boundless field for human industry, the Union is almost as much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insulated from the world as if its frontiers were girt by the ocean.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Canada contains only a million of inhabitants, and its population is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divided into two inimical nations. The rigor of the climate limits the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extension of its territory, and shuts up its ports during the six months
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of winter. From Canada to the Gulf of Mexico a few savage tribes are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be met with, which retire, perishing in their retreat, before six
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thousand soldiers. To the South, the Union has a point of contact with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the empire of Mexico; and it is thence that serious hostilities may one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day be expected to arise. But for a long while to come the uncivilized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of the Mexican community, the depravity of its morals, and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extreme poverty, will prevent that country from ranking high amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations. *w As for the Powers of Europe, they are too distant to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formidable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote w: [War broke out between the United States and Mexico in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1846, and ended in the conquest of an immense territory, including
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: California.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great advantage of the United States does not, then, consist in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Constitution which allows them to carry on great wars, but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a geographical position which renders such enterprises extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: improbable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No one can be more inclined than I am myself to appreciate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages of the federal system, which I hold to be one of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combinations most favorable to the prosperity and freedom of man. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: envy the lot of those nations which have been enabled to adopt it; but I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot believe that any confederate peoples could maintain a long or an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal contest with a nation of similar strength in which the government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be centralized. A people which should divide its sovereignty into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fractional powers, in the presence of the great military monarchies of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe, would, in my opinion, by that very act, abdicate its power, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps its existence and its name. But such is the admirable position
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the New World that man has no other enemy than himself; and that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to be happy and to be free, it suffices to seek the gifts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity and the knowledge of freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IX: Why The People May Strictly Be Said To Govern In The United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have hitherto examined the institutions of the United States; I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passed their legislation in review, and I have depicted the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics of political society in that country. But a sovereign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power exists above these institutions and beyond these characteristic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: features which may destroy or modify them at its pleasure--I mean that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the people. It remains to be shown in what manner this power, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulates the laws, acts: its propensities and its passions remain to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pointed out, as well as the secret springs which retard, accelerate,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or direct its irresistible course; and the effects of its unbounded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, with the destiny which is probably reserved for it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the people appoints the legislative and the executive power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and furnishes the jurors who punish all offences against the laws. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American institutions are democratic, not only in their principle but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all their consequences; and the people elects its representatives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directly, and for the most part annually, in order to ensure their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependence. The people is therefore the real directing power; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although the form of government is representative, it is evident that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the opinions, the prejudices, the interests, and even the passions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community are hindered by no durable obstacles from exercising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a perpetual influence on society. In the United States the majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governs in the name of the people, as is the case in all the countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in which the people is supreme. The majority is principally composed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of peaceful citizens who, either by inclination or by interest, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sincerely desirous of the welfare of their country. But they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surrounded by the incessant agitation of parties, which attempt to gain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their co-operation and to avail themselves of their support.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter X: Parties In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Great distinction to be made between parties--Parties which are to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other as rival nations--Parties properly so called--Difference
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between great and small parties--Epochs which produce them--Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics--America has had great parties--They are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extinct--Federalists--Republicans--Defeat of the Federalists--Difficulty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of creating parties in the United States--What is done with this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intention--Aristocratic or democratic character to be met with in all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parties--Struggle of General Jackson against the Bank.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Parties In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A great distinction must be made between parties. Some countries are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so large that the different populations which inhabit them have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contradictory interests, although they are the subjects of the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government, and they may thence be in a perpetual state of opposition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In this case the different fractions of the people may more properly be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considered as distinct nations than as mere parties; and if a civil war
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: breaks out, the struggle is carried on by rival peoples rather than by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: factions in the State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But when the citizens entertain different opinions upon subjects which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affect the whole country alike, such, for instance, as the principles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon which the government is to be conducted, then distinctions arise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which may correctly be styled parties. Parties are a necessary evil in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free governments; but they have not at all times the same character and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same propensities.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At certain periods a nation may be oppressed by such insupportable evils
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to conceive the design of effecting a total change in its political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution; at other times the mischief lies still deeper, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of society itself is endangered. Such are the times of great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions and of great parties. But between these epochs of misery and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of confusion there are periods during which human society seems to rest,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and mankind to make a pause. This pause is, indeed, only apparent, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time does not stop its course for nations any more than for men; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are all advancing towards a goal with which they are unacquainted; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we only imagine them to be stationary when their progress escapes our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observation, as men who are going at a foot-pace seem to be standing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still to those who run.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But however this may be, there are certain epochs at which the changes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that take place in the social and political constitution of nations are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so slow and so insensible that men imagine their present condition to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a final state; and the human mind, believing itself to be firmly based
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon certain foundations, does not extend its researches beyond the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: horizon which it descries. These are the times of small parties and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intrigue.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The political parties which I style great are those which cling to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles more than to their consequences; to general, and not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especial cases; to ideas, and not to men. These parties are usually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguished by a nobler character, by more generous passions, more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genuine convictions, and a more bold and open conduct than the others.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In them private interest, which always plays the chief part in political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions, is more studiously veiled under the pretext of the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good; and it may even be sometimes concealed from the eyes of the very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons whom it excites and impels.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Minor parties are, on the other hand, generally deficient in political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faith. As they are not sustained or dignified by a lofty purpose, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ostensibly display the egotism of their character in their actions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They glow with a factitious zeal; their language is vehement, but their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conduct is timid and irresolute. The means they employ are as wretched
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the end at which they aim. Hence it arises that when a calm state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things succeeds a violent revolution, the leaders of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem suddenly to disappear, and the powers of the human mind to lie
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concealed. Society is convulsed by great parties, by minor ones it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agitated; it is torn by the former, by the latter it is degraded; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if these sometimes save it by a salutary perturbation, those invariably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disturb it to no good end.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America has already lost the great parties which once divided the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation; and if her happiness is considerably increased, her morality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has suffered by their extinction. When the War of Independence was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: terminated, and the foundations of the new Government were to be laid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: down, the nation was divided between two opinions--two opinions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are as old as the world, and which are perpetually to be met with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under all the forms and all the names which have ever obtained in free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities--the one tending to limit, the other to extend indefinitely,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of the people. The conflict of these two opinions never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assumed that degree of violence in America which it has frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: displayed elsewhere. Both parties of the Americans were, in fact, agreed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the most essential points; and neither of them had to destroy a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traditionary constitution, or to overthrow the structure of society, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to ensure its own triumph. In neither of them, consequently, were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great number of private interests affected by success or by defeat;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but moral principles of a high order, such as the love of equality and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of independence, were concerned in the struggle, and they sufficed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kindle violent passions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The party which desired to limit the power of the people endeavored to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apply its doctrines more especially to the Constitution of the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whence it derived its name of Federal. The other party, which affected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be more exclusively attached to the cause of liberty, took that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Republican. America is a land of democracy, and the Federalists were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always in a minority; but they reckoned on their side almost all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great men who had been called forth by the War of Independence, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their moral influence was very considerable. Their cause was, moreover,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favored by circumstances. The ruin of the Confederation had impressed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people with a dread of anarchy, and the Federalists did not fail to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profit by this transient disposition of the multitude. For ten or twelve
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years they were at the head of affairs, and they were able to apply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some, though not all, of their principles; for the hostile current was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becoming from day to day too violent to be checked or stemmed. In 1801
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Republicans got possession of the Government; Thomas Jefferson was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: named President; and he increased the influence of their party by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weight of his celebrity, the greatness of his talents, and the immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent of his popularity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The means by which the Federalists had maintained their position were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: artificial, and their resources were temporary; it was by the virtues
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or the talents of their leaders that they had risen to power. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Republicans attained to that lofty station, their opponents were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overwhelmed by utter defeat. An immense majority declared itself against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the retiring party, and the Federalists found themselves in so small a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minority that they at once despaired of their future success. From that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moment the Republican or Democratic party *a has proceeded from conquest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to conquest, until it has acquired absolute supremacy in the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federalists, perceiving that they were vanquished without resource,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and isolated in the midst of the nation, fell into two divisions, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which one joined the victorious Republicans, and the other abandoned its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rallying-point and its name. Many years have already elapsed since they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceased to exist as a party.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: [It is scarcely necessary to remark that in more recent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: times the signification of these terms has changed. The Republicans are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the representatives of the old Federalists, and the Democrats of the old
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Republicans.--Trans. Note (1861).]] The accession of the Federalists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to power was, in my opinion, one of the most fortunate incidents which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accompanied the formation of the great American Union; they resisted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inevitable propensities of their age and of the country. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whether their theories were good or bad, they had the effect of being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inapplicable, as a system, to the society which they professed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: govern, and that which occurred under the auspices of Jefferson must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore have taken place sooner or later. But their Government gave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the new republic time to acquire a certain stability, and afterwards to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: support the rapid growth of the very doctrines which they had combated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A considerable number of their principles were in point of fact embodied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the political creed of their opponents; and the Federal Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which subsists at the present day is a lasting monument of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patriotism and their wisdom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Great political parties are not, then, to be met with in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States at the present time. Parties, indeed, may be found which threaten
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the future tranquillity of the Union; but there are none which seem to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contest the present form of Government or the present course of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The parties by which the Union is menaced do not rest upon abstract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles, but upon temporal interests. These interests, disseminated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the provinces of so vast an empire, may be said to constitute rival
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations rather than parties. Thus, upon a recent occasion, the North
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contended for the system of commercial prohibition, and the South
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: took up arms in favor of free trade, simply because the North is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturing and the South an agricultural district; and that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restrictive system which was profitable to the one was prejudicial to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other. *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: [The divisions of North and South have since acquired a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: far greater degree of intensity, and the South, though conquered,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still presents a formidable spirit of opposition to Northern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government.--Translator's Note, 1875.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the absence of great parties, the United States abound with lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: controversies; and public opinion is divided into a thousand minute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shades of difference upon questions of very little moment. The pains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are taken to create parties are inconceivable, and at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day it is no easy task. In the United States there is no religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animosity, because all religion is respected, and no sect is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predominant; there is no jealousy of rank, because the people is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything, and none can contest its authority; lastly, there is no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public indigence to supply the means of agitation, because the physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position of the country opens so wide a field to industry that man is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able to accomplish the most surprising undertakings with his own native
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources. Nevertheless, ambitious men are interested in the creation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parties, since it is difficult to eject a person from authority upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mere ground that his place is coveted by others. The skill of the actors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the political world lies therefore in the art of creating parties. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political aspirant in the United States begins by discriminating his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest, and by calculating upon those interests which may be collected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: around and amalgamated with it; he then contrives to discover some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doctrine or some principle which may suit the purposes of this new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association, and which he adopts in order to bring forward his party and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to secure his popularity; just as the imprimatur of a King was in former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: days incorporated with the volume which it authorized, but to which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nowise belonged. When these preliminaries are terminated, the new party
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is ushered into the political world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the domestic controversies of the Americans at first appear to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stranger to be so incomprehensible and so puerile that he is at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: loss whether to pity a people which takes such arrant trifles in good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: earnest, or to envy the happiness which enables it to discuss them. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when he comes to study the secret propensities which govern the factions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of America, he easily perceives that the greater part of them are more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or less connected with one or the other of those two divisions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have always existed in free communities. The deeper we penetrate into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the working of these parties, the more do we perceive that the object
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the one is to limit, and that of the other to extend, the popular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority. I do not assert that the ostensible end, or even that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secret aim, of American parties is to promote the rule of aristocracy or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy in the country; but I affirm that aristocratic or democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions may easily be detected at the bottom of all parties, and that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although they escape a superficial observation, they are the main point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the very soul of every faction in the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To quote a recent example. When the President attacked the Bank, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country was excited and parties were formed; the well-informed classes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rallied round the Bank, the common people round the President. But it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must not be imagined that the people had formed a rational opinion upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a question which offers so many difficulties to the most experienced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: statesmen. The Bank is a great establishment which enjoys an independent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence, and the people, accustomed to make and unmake whatsoever it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleases, is startled to meet with this obstacle to its authority. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: midst of the perpetual fluctuation of society the community is irritated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by so permanent an institution, and is led to attack it in order to see
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whether it can be shaken and controlled, like all the other institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Remains Of The Aristocratic Party In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Secret opposition of wealthy individuals to democracy--Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retirement--Their taste for exclusive pleasures and for luxury at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: home--Their simplicity abroad--Their affected condescension towards the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It sometimes happens in a people amongst which various opinions prevail
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the balance of the several parties is lost, and one of them obtains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an irresistible preponderance, overpowers all obstacles, harasses its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opponents, and appropriates all the resources of society to its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purposes. The vanquished citizens despair of success and they conceal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their dissatisfaction in silence and in general apathy. The nation seems
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be governed by a single principle, and the prevailing party assumes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the credit of having restored peace and unanimity to the country. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this apparent unanimity is merely a cloak to alarming dissensions and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetual opposition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
