text: This is precisely what occurred in America; when the democratic party
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: got the upper hand, it took exclusive possession of the conduct of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs, and from that time the laws and the customs of society have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been adapted to its caprices. At the present day the more affluent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes of society are so entirely removed from the direction of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political affairs in the United States that wealth, far from conferring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a right to the exercise of power, is rather an obstacle than a means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attaining to it. The wealthy members of the community abandon the lists,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through unwillingness to contend, and frequently to contend in vain,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the poorest classes of their fellow citizens. They concentrate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all their enjoyments in the privacy of their homes, where they occupy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a rank which cannot be assumed in public; and they constitute a private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society in the State, which has its own tastes and its own pleasures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They submit to this state of things as an irremediable evil, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are careful not to show that they are galled by its continuance; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is even not uncommon to hear them laud the delights of a republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, and the advantages of democratic institutions when they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are in public. Next to hating their enemies, men are most inclined to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flatter them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mark, for instance, that opulent citizen, who is as anxious as a Jew of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Middle Ages to conceal his wealth. His dress is plain, his demeanor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unassuming; but the interior of his dwelling glitters with luxury, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: none but a few chosen guests whom he haughtily styles his equals are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allowed to penetrate into this sanctuary. No European noble is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusive in his pleasures, or more jealous of the smallest advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which his privileged station confers upon him. But the very same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual crosses the city to reach a dark counting-house in the centre
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of traffic, where every one may accost him who pleases. If he meets his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cobbler upon the way, they stop and converse; the two citizens discuss
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the affairs of the State in which they have an equal interest, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shake hands before they part.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But beneath this artificial enthusiasm, and these obsequious attentions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the preponderating power, it is easy to perceive that the wealthy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community entertain a hearty distaste to the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions of their country. The populace is at once the object
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their scorn and of their fears. If the maladministration of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy ever brings about a revolutionary crisis, and if monarchical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions ever become practicable in the United States, the truth of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what I advance will become obvious.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The two chief weapons which parties use in order to ensure success are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the public press and the formation of associations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XI: Liberty Of The Press In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Difficulty of restraining the liberty of the press--Particular reasons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which some nations have to cherish this liberty--The liberty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: press a necessary consequence of the sovereignty of the people as it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood in America--Violent language of the periodical press in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States--Propensities of the periodical press--Illustrated by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States--Opinion of the Americans upon the repression of the abuse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the liberty of the press by judicial prosecutions--Reasons for which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the press is less powerful in America than in France.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Liberty Of The Press In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The influence of the liberty of the press does not affect political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions alone, but it extends to all the opinions of men, and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: modifies customs as well as laws. In another part of this work I shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempt to determinate the degree of influence which the liberty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the press has exercised upon civil society in the United States, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point out the direction which it has given to the ideas, as well as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tone which it has imparted to the character and the feelings, of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans, but at present I purpose simply to examine the effects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produced by the liberty of the press in the political world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I confess that I do not entertain that firm and complete attachment to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the liberty of the press which things that are supremely good in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very nature are wont to excite in the mind; and I approve of it more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from a recollection of the evils it prevents than from a consideration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the advantages it ensures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If any one could point out an intermediate and yet a tenable position
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the complete independence and the entire subjection of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public expression of opinion, I should perhaps be inclined to adopt it;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the difficulty is to discover this position. If it is your intention
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to correct the abuses of unlicensed printing and to restore the use of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orderly language, you may in the first instance try the offender by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a jury; but if the jury acquits him, the opinion which was that of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single individual becomes the opinion of the country at large. Too much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and too little has therefore hitherto been done. If you proceed, you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must bring the delinquent before a court of permanent judges. But even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: here the cause must be heard before it can be decided; and the very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles which no book would have ventured to avow are blazoned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forth in the pleadings, and what was obscurely hinted at in a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composition is then repeated in a multitude of other publications.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The language in which a thought is embodied is the mere carcass of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought, and not the idea itself; tribunals may condemn the form, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sense and spirit of the work is too subtle for their authority. Too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much has still been done to recede, too little to attain your end; you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must therefore proceed. If you establish a censorship of the press, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tongue of the public speaker will still make itself heard, and you have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only increased the mischief. The powers of thought do not rely, like the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers of physical strength, upon the number of their mechanical agents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor can a host of authors be reckoned like the troops which compose an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army; on the contrary, the authority of a principle is often increased
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the smallness of the number of men by whom it is expressed. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words of a strong-minded man, which penetrate amidst the passions of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: listening assembly, have more power than the vociferations of a thousand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orators; and if it be allowed to speak freely in any public place,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the consequence is the same as if free speaking was allowed in every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: village. The liberty of discourse must therefore be destroyed as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the liberty of the press; this is the necessary term of your efforts;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but if your object was to repress the abuses of liberty, they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brought you to the feet of a despot. You have been led from the extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of independence to the extreme of subjection without meeting with a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single tenable position for shelter or repose.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are certain nations which have peculiar reasons for cherishing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty of the press, independently of the general motives which I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: just pointed out. For in certain countries which profess to enjoy the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges of freedom every individual agent of the Government may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violate the laws with impunity, since those whom he oppresses cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosecute him before the courts of justice. In this case the liberty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the press is not merely a guarantee, but it is the only guarantee, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their liberty and their security which the citizens possess. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rulers of these nations propose to abolish the independence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: press, the people would be justified in saying: Give us the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosecuting your offences before the ordinary tribunals, and perhaps we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may then waive our right of appeal to the tribunal of public opinion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in the countries in which the doctrine of the sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people ostensibly prevails, the censorship of the press is not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous, but it is absurd. When the right of every citizen to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operate in the government of society is acknowledged, every citizen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be presumed to possess the power of discriminating between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different opinions of his contemporaries, and of appreciating the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different facts from which inferences may be drawn. The sovereignty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people and the liberty of the press may therefore be looked upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as correlative institutions; just as the censorship of the press and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: universal suffrage are two things which are irreconcilably opposed, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which cannot long be retained among the institutions of the same people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not a single individual of the twelve millions who inhabit the territory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States has as yet dared to propose any restrictions to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the liberty of the press. The first newspaper over which I cast my eyes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon my arrival in America, contained the following article:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In all this affair the language of Jackson has been that of a heartless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despot, solely occupied with the preservation of his own authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ambition is his crime, and it will be his punishment too: intrigue is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his native element, and intrigue will confound his tricks, and will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deprive him of his power: he governs by means of corruption, and his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immoral practices will redound to his shame and confusion. His conduct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the political arena has been that of a shameless and lawless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gamester. He succeeded at the time, but the hour of retribution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approaches, and he will be obliged to disgorge his winnings, to throw
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aside his false dice, and to end his days in some retirement, where he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may curse his madness at his leisure; for repentance is a virtue with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which his heart is likely to remain forever unacquainted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not uncommonly imagined in France that the virulence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: press originates in the uncertain social condition, in the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excitement, and the general sense of consequent evil which prevail in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that country; and it is therefore supposed that as soon as society has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resumed a certain degree of composure the press will abandon its present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vehemence. I am inclined to think that the above causes explain the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason of the extraordinary ascendency it has acquired over the nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but that they do not exercise much influence upon the tone of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language. The periodical press appears to me to be actuated by passions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and propensities independent of the circumstances in which it is placed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the present position of America corroborates this opinion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America is perhaps, at this moment, the country of the whole world
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which contains the fewest germs of revolution; but the press is not less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destructive in its principles than in France, and it displays the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violence without the same reasons for indignation. In America, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in France, it constitutes a singular power, so strangely composed of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mingled good and evil that it is at the same time indispensable to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of freedom, and nearly incompatible with the maintenance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public order. Its power is certainly much greater in France than in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States; though nothing is more rare in the latter country than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hear of a prosecution having been instituted against it. The reason
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this is perfectly simple: the Americans, having once admitted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the doctrine of the sovereignty of the people, apply it with perfect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consistency. It was never their intention to found a permanent state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things with elements which undergo daily modifications; and there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is consequently nothing criminal in an attack upon the existing laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provided it be not attended with a violent infraction of them. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are moreover of opinion that courts of justice are unable to check
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the abuses of the press; and that as the subtilty of human language
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually eludes the severity of judicial analysis, offences of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature are apt to escape the hand which attempts to apprehend them. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hold that to act with efficacy upon the press it would be necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find a tribunal, not only devoted to the existing order of things, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capable of surmounting the influence of public opinion; a tribunal which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should conduct its proceedings without publicity, which should pronounce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its decrees without assigning its motives, and punish the intentions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even more than the language of an author. Whosoever should have the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of creating and maintaining a tribunal of this kind would waste
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his time in prosecuting the liberty of the press; for he would be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supreme master of the whole community, and he would be as free to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rid himself of the authors as of their writings. In this question,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, there is no medium between servitude and extreme license; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to enjoy the inestimable benefits which the liberty of the press
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ensures, it is necessary to submit to the inevitable evils which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engenders. To expect to acquire the former and to escape the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to cherish one of those illusions which commonly mislead nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in their times of sickness, when, tired with faction and exhausted by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effort, they attempt to combine hostile opinions and contrary principles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the same soil.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The small influence of the American journals is attributable to several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reasons, amongst which are the following:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The liberty of writing, like all other liberty, is most formidable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when it is a novelty; for a people which has never been accustomed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operate in the conduct of State affairs places implicit confidence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the first tribune who arouses its attention. The Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have enjoyed this liberty ever since the foundation of the settlements;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moreover, the press cannot create human passions by its own power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however skillfully it may kindle them where they exist. In America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics are discussed with animation and a varied activity, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rarely touch those deep passions which are excited whenever the positive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest of a part of the community is impaired: but in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States the interests of the community are in a most prosperous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition. A single glance upon a French and an American newspaper is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficient to show the difference which exists between the two nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on this head. In France the space allotted to commercial advertisements
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is very limited, and the intelligence is not considerable, but the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: essential part of the journal is that which contains the discussion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the politics of the day. In America three-quarters of the enormous sheet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is set before the reader are filled with advertisements, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remainder is frequently occupied by political intelligence or trivial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anecdotes: it is only from time to time that one finds a corner devoted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to passionate discussions like those with which the journalists of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France are wont to indulge their readers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has been demonstrated by observation, and discovered by the innate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sagacity of the pettiest as well as the greatest of despots, that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of a power is increased in proportion as its direction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is rendered more central. In France the press combines a twofold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralization; almost all its power is centred in the same spot, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vested in the same hands, for its organs are far from numerous. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of a public press thus constituted, upon a sceptical nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be unbounded. It is an enemy with which a Government may sign an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occasional truce, but which it is difficult to resist for any length of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Neither of these kinds of centralization exists in America. The United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States have no metropolis; the intelligence as well as the power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country are dispersed abroad, and instead of radiating from a point,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they cross each other in every direction; the Americans have established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no central control over the expression of opinion, any more than over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the conduct of business. These are circumstances which do not depend on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human foresight; but it is owing to the laws of the Union that there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are no licenses to be granted to printers, no securities demanded from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: editors as in France, and no stamp duty as in France and formerly in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England. The consequence of this is that nothing is easier than to set
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up a newspaper, and a small number of readers suffices to defray the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expenses of the editor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The number of periodical and occasional publications which appears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States actually surpasses belief. The most enlightened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans attribute the subordinate influence of the press to this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excessive dissemination; and it is adopted as an axiom of political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: science in that country that the only way to neutralize the effect of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public journals is to multiply them indefinitely. I cannot conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that a truth which is so self-evident should not already have been more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally admitted in Europe; it is comprehensible that the persons who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hope to bring about revolutions by means of the press should be desirous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of confining its action to a few powerful organs, but it is perfectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incredible that the partisans of the existing state of things, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural supporters of the law, should attempt to diminish the influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the press by concentrating its authority. The Governments of Europe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem to treat the press with the courtesy of the knights of old; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are anxious to furnish it with the same central power which they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found to be so trusty a weapon, in order to enhance the glory of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resistance to its attacks.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America there is scarcely a hamlet which has not its own newspaper.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may readily be imagined that neither discipline nor unity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: design can be communicated to so multifarious a host, and each one is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently led to fight under his own standard. All the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: journals of the United States are indeed arrayed on the side of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration or against it; but they attack and defend in a thousand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different ways. They cannot succeed in forming those great currents of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion which overwhelm the most solid obstacles. This division of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of the press produces a variety of other consequences which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are scarcely less remarkable. The facility with which journals can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established induces a multitude of individuals to take a part in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; but as the extent of competition precludes the possibility of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerable profit, the most distinguished classes of society are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rarely led to engage in these undertakings. But such is the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the public prints that, even if they were a source of wealth, writers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of ability could not be found to direct them all. The journalists of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States are usually placed in a very humble position, with a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scanty education and a vulgar turn of mind. The will of the majority is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most general of laws, and it establishes certain habits which form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the characteristics of each peculiar class of society; thus it dictates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the etiquette practised at courts and the etiquette of the bar. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics of the French journalist consist in a violent, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently an eloquent and lofty, manner of discussing the politics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the day; and the exceptions to this habitual practice are only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occasional. The characteristics of the American journalist consist in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an open and coarse appeal to the passions of the populace; and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitually abandons the principles of political science to assail the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characters of individuals, to track them into private life, and disclose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all their weaknesses and errors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing can be more deplorable than this abuse of the powers of thought;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall have occasion to point out hereafter the influence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: newspapers upon the taste and the morality of the American people, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my present subject exclusively concerns the political world. It cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be denied that the effects of this extreme license of the press tend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indirectly to the maintenance of public order. The individuals who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are already in the possession of a high station in the esteem of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-citizens are afraid to write in the newspapers, and they are thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deprived of the most powerful instrument which they can use to excite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the passions of the multitude to their own advantage. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: They only write in the papers when they choose to address
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people in their own name; as, for instance, when they are called
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon to repel calumnious imputations, and to correct a misstatement of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facts.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The personal opinions of the editors have no kind of weight in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eyes of the public: the only use of a journal is, that it imparts the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge of certain facts, and it is only by altering or distorting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those facts that a journalist can contribute to the support of his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: views.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But although the press is limited to these resources, its influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in America is immense. It is the power which impels the circulation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political life through all the districts of that vast territory. Its eye
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is constantly open to detect the secret springs of political designs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to summon the leaders of all parties to the bar of public opinion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It rallies the interests of the community round certain principles, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it draws up the creed which factions adopt; for it affords a means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intercourse between parties which hear, and which address each other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without ever having been in immediate contact. When a great number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the organs of the press adopt the same line of conduct, their influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes irresistible; and public opinion, when it is perpetually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assailed from the same side, eventually yields to the attack. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States each separate journal exercises but little authority, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of the periodical press is only second to that of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: See Appendix, P.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The opinions established in the United States under the empire of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty of the press are frequently more firmly rooted than those which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are formed elsewhere under the sanction of a censor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the democracy perpetually raises fresh individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the conduct of public affairs; and the measures of the administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are consequently seldom regulated by the strict rules of consistency or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of order. But the general principles of the Government are more stable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the opinions most prevalent in society are generally more durable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than in many other countries. When once the Americans have taken up an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idea, whether it be well or ill founded, nothing is more difficult than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to eradicate it from their minds. The same tenacity of opinion has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observed in England, where, for the last century, greater freedom of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conscience and more invincible prejudices have existed than in all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other countries of Europe. I attribute this consequence to a cause which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may at first sight appear to have a very opposite tendency, namely, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the liberty of the press. The nations amongst which this liberty exists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are as apt to cling to their opinions from pride as from conviction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They cherish them because they hold them to be just, and because they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercised their own free-will in choosing them; and they maintain them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only because they are true, but because they are their own. Several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other reasons conduce to the same end.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It was remarked by a man of genius that "ignorance lies at the two ends
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of knowledge." Perhaps it would have been more correct to have said,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that absolute convictions are to be met with at the two extremities, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that doubt lies in the middle; for the human intellect may be considered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in three distinct states, which frequently succeed one another. A man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believes implicitly, because he adopts a proposition without inquiry. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doubts as soon as he is assailed by the objections which his inquiries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may have aroused. But he frequently succeeds in satisfying these doubts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and then he begins to believe afresh: he no longer lays hold on a truth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in its most shadowy and uncertain form, but he sees it clearly before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him, and he advances onwards by the light it gives him. *c
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: It may, however, be doubted whether this rational
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and self-guiding conviction arouses as much fervor or enthusiastic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: devotedness in men as their first dogmatical belief.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the liberty of the press acts upon men who are in the first of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these three states, it does not immediately disturb their habit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believing implicitly without investigation, but it constantly modifies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the objects of their intuitive convictions. The human mind continues
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to discern but one point upon the whole intellectual horizon, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that point is in continual motion. Such are the symptoms of sudden
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions, and of the misfortunes which are sure to befall those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generations which abruptly adopt the unconditional freedom of the press.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The circle of novel ideas is, however, soon terminated; the touch
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of experience is upon them, and the doubt and mistrust which their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncertainty produces become universal. We may rest assured that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority of mankind will either believe they know not wherefore, or will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not know what to believe. Few are the beings who can ever hope to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attain to that state of rational and independent conviction which true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge can beget in defiance of the attacks of doubt.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has been remarked that in times of great religious fervor men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes change their religious opinions; whereas in times of general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scepticism everyone clings to his own persuasion. The same thing takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place in politics under the liberty of the press. In countries where all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the theories of social science have been contested in their turn, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens who have adopted one of them stick to it, not so much because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are assured of its excellence, as because they are not convinced of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the superiority of any other. In the present age men are not very ready
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to die in defence of their opinions, but they are rarely inclined to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change them; and there are fewer martyrs as well as fewer apostates.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Another still more valid reason may yet be adduced: when no abstract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions are looked upon as certain, men cling to the mere propensities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and external interests of their position, which are naturally more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tangible and more permanent than any opinions in the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not a question of easy solution whether aristocracy or democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is most fit to govern a country. But it is certain that democracy annoys
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one part of the community, and that aristocracy oppresses another part.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the question is reduced to the simple expression of the struggle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between poverty and wealth, the tendency of each side of the dispute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes perfectly evident without further controversy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XII: Political Associations In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Daily use which the Anglo-Americans make of the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association--Three kinds of political associations--In what manner
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans apply the representative system to associations--Dangers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resulting to the State--Great Convention of 1831 relative to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Tariff--Legislative character of this Convention--Why the unlimited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise of the right of association is less dangerous in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States than elsewhere--Why it may be looked upon as necessary--Utility
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of associations in a democratic people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Political Associations In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In no country in the world has the principle of association been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more successfully used, or more unsparingly applied to a multitude of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different objects, than in America. Besides the permanent associations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are established by law under the names of townships, cities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and counties, a vast number of others are formed and maintained by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agency of private individuals.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The citizen of the United States is taught from his earliest infancy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to rely upon his own exertions in order to resist the evils and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulties of life; he looks upon social authority with an eye of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mistrust and anxiety, and he only claims its assistance when he is quite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unable to shift without it. This habit may even be traced in the schools
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the rising generation, where the children in their games are wont to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submit to rules which they have themselves established, and to punish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misdemeanors which they have themselves defined. The same spirit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pervades every act of social life. If a stoppage occurs in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thoroughfare, and the circulation of the public is hindered, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighbors immediately constitute a deliberative body; and this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extemporaneous assembly gives rise to an executive power which remedies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inconvenience before anybody has thought of recurring to an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority superior to that of the persons immediately concerned. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public pleasures are concerned, an association is formed to provide
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the splendor and the regularity of the entertainment. Societies are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed to resist enemies which are exclusively of a moral nature, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diminish the vice of intemperance: in the United States associations are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established to promote public order, commerce, industry, morality, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion; for there is no end which the human will, seconded by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collective exertions of individuals, despairs of attaining.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall hereafter have occasion to show the effects of association upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the course of society, and I must confine myself for the present to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political world. When once the right of association is recognized, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens may employ it in several different ways.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An association consists simply in the public assent which a number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals give to certain doctrines, and in the engagement which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contract to promote the spread of those doctrines by their exertions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The right of association with these views is very analogous to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty of unlicensed writing; but societies thus formed possess more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority than the press. When an opinion is represented by a society,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it necessarily assumes a more exact and explicit form. It numbers its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: partisans, and compromises their welfare in its cause: they, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other hand, become acquainted with each other, and their zeal is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increased by their number. An association unites the efforts of minds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which have a tendency to diverge in one single channel, and urges them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vigorously towards one single end which it points out.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The second degree in the right of association is the power of meeting.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When an association is allowed to establish centres of action at certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important points in the country, its activity is increased and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence extended. Men have the opportunity of seeing each other; means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of execution are more readily combined, and opinions are maintained with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a degree of warmth and energy which written language cannot approach.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lastly, in the exercise of the right of political association, there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is a third degree: the partisans of an opinion may unite in electoral
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bodies, and choose delegates to represent them in a central assembly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is, properly speaking, the application of the representative system
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a party.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, in the first instance, a society is formed between individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: professing the same opinion, and the tie which keeps it together is of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a purely intellectual nature; in the second case, small assemblies are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed which only represent a fraction of the party. Lastly, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: third case, they constitute a separate nation in the midst of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, a government within the Government. Their delegates, like the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: real delegates of the majority, represent the entire collective force
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their party; and they enjoy a certain degree of that national dignity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and great influence which belong to the chosen representatives of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. It is true that they have not the right of making the laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they have the power of attacking those which are in being, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of drawing up beforehand those which they may afterwards cause to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adopted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If, in a people which is imperfectly accustomed to the exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of freedom, or which is exposed to violent political passions, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deliberating minority, which confines itself to the contemplation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future laws, be placed in juxtaposition to the legislative majority, I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot but believe that public tranquillity incurs very great risks in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that nation. There is doubtless a very wide difference between proving
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that one law is in itself better than another and proving that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former ought to be substituted for the latter. But the imagination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the populace is very apt to overlook this difference, which is so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apparent to the minds of thinking men. It sometimes happens that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation is divided into two nearly equal parties, each of which affects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to represent the majority. If, in immediate contiguity to the directing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power, another power be established, which exercises almost as much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral authority as the former, it is not to be believed that it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long be content to speak without acting; or that it will always be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restrained by the abstract consideration of the nature of associations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are meant to direct but not to enforce opinions, to suggest but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not to make the laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The more we consider the independence of the press in its principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences, the more are we convinced that it is the chief and, so to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speak, the constitutive element of freedom in the modern world. A nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is determined to remain free is therefore right in demanding the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unrestrained exercise of this independence. But the unrestrained liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of political association cannot be entirely assimilated to the liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the press. The one is at the same time less necessary and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous than the other. A nation may confine it within certain limits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without forfeiting any part of its self-control; and it may sometimes be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to do so in order to maintain its own authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the liberty of association for political purposes is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unbounded. An example will show in the clearest light to what an extent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this privilege is tolerated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The question of the tariff, or of free trade, produced a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manifestation of party feeling in America; the tariff was not only a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject of debate as a matter of opinion, but it exercised a favorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or a prejudicial influence upon several very powerful interests of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. The North attributed a great portion of its prosperity, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South all its sufferings, to this system; insomuch that for a long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time the tariff was the sole source of the political animosities which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agitated the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1831, when the dispute was raging with the utmost virulence, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private citizen of Massachusetts proposed to all the enemies of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tariff, by means of the public prints, to send delegates to Philadelphia
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to consult together upon the means which were most fitted to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promote freedom of trade. This proposal circulated in a few days from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Maine to New Orleans by the power of the printing-press: the opponents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the tariff adopted it with enthusiasm; meetings were formed on all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sides, and delegates were named. The majority of these individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were well known, and some of them had earned a considerable degree of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: celebrity. South Carolina alone, which afterwards took up arms in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same cause, sent sixty-three delegates. On October 1, 1831, this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assembly, which according to the American custom had taken the name of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a Convention, met at Philadelphia; it consisted of more than two hundred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members. Its debates were public, and they at once assumed a legislative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character; the extent of the powers of Congress, the theories of free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trade, and the different clauses of the tariff, were discussed in turn.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the end of ten days' deliberation the Convention broke up, after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having published an address to the American people, in which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declared:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I. That Congress had not the right of making a tariff, and that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existing tariff was unconstitutional;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: II. That the prohibition of free trade was prejudicial to the interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all nations, and to that of the American people in particular.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must be acknowledged that the unrestrained liberty of political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association has not hitherto produced, in the United States, those fatal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences which might perhaps be expected from it elsewhere. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of association was imported from England, and it has always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existed in America; so that the exercise of this privilege is now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amalgamated with the manners and customs of the people. At the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time the liberty of association is become a necessary guarantee against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tyranny of the majority. In the United States, as soon as a party is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become preponderant, all public authority passes under its control; its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private supporters occupy all the places, and have all the force of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration at their disposal. As the most distinguished partisans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the other side of the question are unable to surmount the obstacles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which exclude them from power, they require some means of establishing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves upon their own basis, and of opposing the moral authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the minority to the physical power which domineers over it. Thus a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous expedient is used to obviate a still more formidable danger.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The omnipotence of the majority appears to me to present such extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perils to the American Republics that the dangerous measure which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: used to repress it seems to be more advantageous than prejudicial. And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: here I am about to advance a proposition which may remind the reader
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of what I said before in speaking of municipal freedom: There are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no countries in which associations are more needed, to prevent the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotism of faction or the arbitrary power of a prince, than those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are democratically constituted. In aristocratic nations the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body of the nobles and the more opulent part of the community are in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves natural associations, which act as checks upon the abuses of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. In countries in which these associations do not exist, if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private individuals are unable to create an artificial and a temporary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: substitute for them, I can imagine no permanent protection against the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most galling tyranny; and a great people may be oppressed by a small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faction, or by a single individual, with impunity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The meeting of a great political Convention (for there are Conventions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all kinds), which may frequently become a necessary measure, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always a serious occurrence, even in America, and one which is never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: looked forward to, by the judicious friends of the country, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alarm. This was very perceptible in the Convention of 1831, at which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions of all the most distinguished members of the Assembly tended
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to moderate its language, and to restrain the subjects which it treated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within certain limits. It is probable, in fact, that the Convention of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1831 exercised a very great influence upon the minds of the malcontents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and prepared them for the open revolt against the commercial laws of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union which took place in 1832.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It cannot be denied that the unrestrained liberty of association
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for political purposes is the privilege which a people is longest in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learning how to exercise. If it does not throw the nation into anarchy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it perpetually augments the chances of that calamity. On one point,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however, this perilous liberty offers a security against dangers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another kind; in countries where associations are free, secret
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: societies are unknown. In America there are numerous factions, but no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conspiracies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Different ways in which the right of association is understood in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe and in the United States--Different use which is made of it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The most natural privilege of man, next to the right of acting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for himself, is that of combining his exertions with those of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-creatures, and of acting in common with them. I am therefore led
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to conclude that the right of association is almost as inalienable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the right of personal liberty. No legislator can attack it without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impairing the very foundations of society. Nevertheless, if the liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of association is a fruitful source of advantages and prosperity to some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, it may be perverted or carried to excess by others, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the element of life may be changed into an element of destruction. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparison of the different methods which associations pursue in those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries in which they are managed with discretion, as well as in those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where liberty degenerates into license, may perhaps be thought useful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: both to governments and to parties.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greater part of Europeans look upon an association as a weapon which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to be hastily fashioned, and immediately tried in the conflict.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A society is formed for discussion, but the idea of impending action
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevails in the minds of those who constitute it: it is, in fact, an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army; and the time given to parley serves to reckon up the strength and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to animate the courage of the host, after which they direct their march
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the enemy. Resources which lie within the bounds of the law may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suggest themselves to the persons who compose it as means, but never as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the only means, of success.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such, however, is not the manner in which the right of association is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood in the United States. In America the citizens who form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the minority associate, in order, in the first place, to show their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numerical strength, and so to diminish the moral authority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority; and, in the second place, to stimulate competition, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discover those arguments which are most fitted to act upon the majority;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for they always entertain hopes of drawing over their opponents to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own side, and of afterwards disposing of the supreme power in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: name. Political associations in the United States are therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peaceable in their intentions, and strictly legal in the means which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they employ; and they assert with perfect truth that they only aim at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: success by lawful expedients.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The difference which exists between the Americans and ourselves depends
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on several causes. In Europe there are numerous parties so diametrically
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposed to the majority that they can never hope to acquire its support,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and at the same time they think that they are sufficiently strong in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to struggle and to defend their cause. When a party of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind forms an association, its object is, not to conquer, but to fight.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the individuals who hold opinions very much opposed to those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the majority are no sort of impediment to its power, and all other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parties hope to win it over to their own principles in the end. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise of the right of association becomes dangerous in proportion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the impossibility which excludes great parties from acquiring the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority. In a country like the United States, in which the differences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of opinion are mere differences of hue, the right of association may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain unrestrained without evil consequences. The inexperience of many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the European nations in the enjoyment of liberty leads them only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to look upon the liberty of association as a right of attacking the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government. The first notion which presents itself to a party, as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to an individual, when it has acquired a consciousness of its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength, is that of violence: the notion of persuasion arises at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: later period and is only derived from experience. The English, who are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divided into parties which differ most essentially from each other,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rarely abuse the right of association, because they have long been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustomed to exercise it. In France the passion for war is so intense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that there is no undertaking so mad, or so injurious to the welfare of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State, that a man does not consider himself honored in defending it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the risk of his life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But perhaps the most powerful of the causes which tend to mitigate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excesses of political association in the United States is Universal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Suffrage. In countries in which universal suffrage exists the majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is never doubtful, because neither party can pretend to represent that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portion of the community which has not voted. The associations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are formed are aware, as well as the nation at large, that they do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represent the majority: this is, indeed, a condition inseparable from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their existence; for if they did represent the preponderating power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they would change the law instead of soliciting its reform. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence of this is that the moral influence of the Government which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they attack is very much increased, and their own power is very much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enfeebled.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Europe there are few associations which do not affect to represent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the majority, or which do not believe that they represent it. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conviction or this pretension tends to augment their force amazingly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and contributes no less to legalize their measures. Violence may seem to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be excusable in defence of the cause of oppressed right. Thus it is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the vast labyrinth of human laws, that extreme liberty sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corrects the abuses of license, and that extreme democracy obviates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the dangers of democratic government. In Europe, associations consider
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, in some degree, as the legislative and executive councils of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people, which is unable to speak for itself. In America, where they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only represent a minority of the nation, they argue and they petition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The means which the associations of Europe employ are in accordance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the end which they propose to obtain. As the principal aim of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bodies is to act, and not to debate, to fight rather than to persuade,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are naturally led to adopt a form of organization which differs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the ordinary customs of civil bodies, and which assumes the habits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the maxims of military life. They centralize the direction of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources as much as possible, and they intrust the power of the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: party to a very small number of leaders.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The members of these associations respond to a watchword, like soldiers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on duty; they profess the doctrine of passive obedience; say rather,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in uniting together they at once abjure the exercise of their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judgment and free will; and the tyrannical control which these societies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise is often far more insupportable than the authority possessed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over society by the Government which they attack. Their moral force is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much diminished by these excesses, and they lose the powerful interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is always excited by a struggle between oppressors and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppressed. The man who in given cases consents to obey his fellows with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servility, and who submits his activity and even his opinions to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: control, can have no claim to rank as a free citizen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans have also established certain forms of government which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are applied to their associations, but these are invariably borrowed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the forms of the civil administration. The independence of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual is formally recognized; the tendency of the members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association points, as it does in the body of the community, towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same end, but they are not obliged to follow the same track. No
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one abjures the exercise of his reason and his free will; but every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one exerts that reason and that will for the benefit of a common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertaking.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIII: Government Of The Democracy In America--Part I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am well aware of the difficulties which attend this part of my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject, but although every expression which I am about to make use of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may clash, upon some one point, with the feelings of the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parties which divide my country, I shall speak my opinion with the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfect openness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Europe we are at a loss how to judge the true character and the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanent propensities of democracy, because in Europe two conflicting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles exist, and we do not know what to attribute to the principles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, and what to refer to the passions which they bring into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collision. Such, however, is not the case in America; there the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reigns without any obstacle, and it has no perils to dread and no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: injuries to avenge. In America, democracy is swayed by its own free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities; its course is natural and its activity is unrestrained;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States consequently afford the most favorable opportunity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: studying its real character. And to no people can this inquiry be more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vitally interesting than to the French nation, which is blindly driven
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: onwards by a daily and irresistible impulse towards a state of things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which may prove either despotic or republican, but which will assuredly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be democratic.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Universal Suffrage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already observed that universal suffrage has been adopted in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the States of the Union; it consequently occurs amongst different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: populations which occupy very different positions in the scale of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society. I have had opportunities of observing its effects in different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: localities, and amongst races of men who are nearly strangers to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other by their language, their religion, and their manner of life; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Louisiana as well as in New England, in Georgia and in Canada. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarked that Universal Suffrage is far from producing in America either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the good or all the evil consequences which are assigned to it in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe, and that its effects differ very widely from those which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usually attributed to it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Choice Of The People, And Instinctive Preferences Of The American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the most able men are rarely placed at the head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of affairs--Reason of this peculiarity--The envy which prevails in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lower orders of France against the higher classes is not a French, but a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purely democratic sentiment--For what reason the most distinguished men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in America frequently seclude themselves from public affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Many people in Europe are apt to believe without saying it, or to say
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without believing it, that one of the great advantages of universal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suffrage is, that it entrusts the direction of public affairs to men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are worthy of the public confidence. They admit that the people is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unable to govern for itself, but they aver that it is always sincerely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disposed to promote the welfare of the State, and that it instinctively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: designates those persons who are animated by the same good wishes, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are the most fit to wield the supreme authority. I confess that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observations I made in America by no means coincide with these opinions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On my arrival in the United States I was surprised to find so much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguished talent among the subjects, and so little among the heads
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Government. It is a well-authenticated fact, that at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day the most able men in the United States are very rarely placed at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the head of affairs; and it must be acknowledged that such has been the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: result in proportion as democracy has outstepped all its former limits.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The race of American statesmen has evidently dwindled most remarkably in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the course of the last fifty years.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Several causes may be assigned to this phenomenon. It is impossible,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding the most strenuous exertions, to raise the intelligence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the people above a certain level. Whatever may be the facilities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquiring information, whatever may be the profusion of easy methods and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of cheap science, the human mind can never be instructed and educated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without devoting a considerable space of time to those objects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greater or the lesser possibility of subsisting without labor is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore the necessary boundary of intellectual improvement. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: boundary is more remote in some countries and more restricted in others;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it must exist somewhere as long as the people is constrained to work
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to procure the means of physical subsistence, that is to say,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as long as it retains its popular character. It is therefore quite as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult to imagine a State in which all the citizens should be very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well informed as a State in which they should all be wealthy; these two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulties may be looked upon as correlative. It may very readily be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admitted that the mass of the citizens are sincerely disposed to promote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the welfare of their country; nay more, it may even be allowed that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lower classes are less apt to be swayed by considerations of personal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
