text: interest than the higher orders: but it is always more or less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible for them to discern the best means of attaining the end which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they desire with sincerity. Long and patient observation, joined to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of different notions, is required to form a just estimate of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the character of a single individual; and can it be supposed that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vulgar have the power of succeeding in an inquiry which misleads the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penetration of genius itself? The people has neither the time nor the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means which are essential to the prosecution of an investigation of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind: its conclusions are hastily formed from a superficial inspection
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the more prominent features of a question. Hence it often assents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the clamor of a mountebank who knows the secret of stimulating its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tastes, while its truest friends frequently fail in their exertions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Moreover, the democracy is not only deficient in that soundness of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judgment which is necessary to select men really deserving of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confidence, but it has neither the desire nor the inclination to find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them out. It cannot be denied that democratic institutions have a very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strong tendency to promote the feeling of envy in the human heart; not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so much because they afford to every one the means of rising to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: level of any of his fellow-citizens, as because those means perpetually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disappoint the persons who employ them. Democratic institutions awaken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and foster a passion for equality which they can never entirely satisfy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This complete equality eludes the grasp of the people at the very moment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at which it thinks to hold it fast, and "flies," as Pascal says, "with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eternal flight"; the people is excited in the pursuit of an advantage,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is more precious because it is not sufficiently remote to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unknown, or sufficiently near to be enjoyed. The lower orders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are agitated by the chance of success, they are irritated by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncertainty; and they pass from the enthusiasm of pursuit to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exhaustion of ill-success, and lastly to the acrimony of disappointment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whatever transcends their own limits appears to be an obstacle to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires, and there is no kind of superiority, however legitimate it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be, which is not irksome in their sight.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has been supposed that the secret instinct which leads the lower
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orders to remove their superiors as much as possible from the direction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of public affairs is peculiar to France. This, however, is an error; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensity to which I allude is not inherent in any particular nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but in democratic institutions in general; and although it may have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heightened by peculiar political circumstances, it owes its origin to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: higher cause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the people is not disposed to hate the superior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes of society; but it is not very favorably inclined towards them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it carefully excludes them from the exercise of authority. It does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not entertain any dread of distinguished talents, but it is rarely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: captivated by them; and it awards its approbation very sparingly to such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as have risen without the popular support.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whilst the natural propensities of democracy induce the people to reject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most distinguished citizens as its rulers, these individuals are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no less apt to retire from a political career in which it is almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible to retain their independence, or to advance without degrading
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves. This opinion has been very candidly set forth by Chancellor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Kent, who says, in speaking with great eulogiums of that part of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution which empowers the Executive to nominate the judges: "It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indeed probable that the men who are best fitted to discharge the duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this high office would have too much reserve in their manners, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: too much austerity in their principles, for them to be returned by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority at an election where universal suffrage is adopted." Such were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the opinions which were printed without contradiction in America in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: year 1830!
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I hold it to be sufficiently demonstrated that universal suffrage is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by no means a guarantee of the wisdom of the popular choice, and that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever its advantages may be, this is not one of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Causes Which May Partly Correct These Tendencies Of The Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Contrary effects produced on peoples as well as on individuals by great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers--Why so many distinguished men stood at the head of affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in America fifty years ago--Influence which the intelligence and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manners of the people exercise upon its choice--Example of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England--States of the Southwest--Influence of certain laws upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choice of the people--Election by an elected body--Its effects upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composition of the Senate.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a State is threatened by serious dangers, the people frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeeds in selecting the citizens who are the most able to save it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has been observed that man rarely retains his customary level in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: presence of very critical circumstances; he rises above or he sinks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: below his usual condition, and the same thing occurs in nations at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large. Extreme perils sometimes quench the energy of a people instead of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stimulating it; they excite without directing its passions, and instead
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of clearing they confuse its powers of perception. The Jews deluged the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: smoking ruins of their temple with the carnage of the remnant of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: host. But it is more common, both in the case of nations and in that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of individuals, to find extraordinary virtues arising from the very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imminence of the danger. Great characters are then thrown into relief,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as edifices which are concealed by the gloom of night are illuminated by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the glare of a conflagration. At those dangerous times genius no longer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abstains from presenting itself in the arena; and the people, alarmed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the perils of its situation, buries its envious passions in a short
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oblivion. Great names may then be drawn from the balloting-box.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already observed that the American statesmen of the present day
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are very inferior to those who stood at the head of affairs fifty years
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ago. This is as much a consequence of the circumstances as of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws of the country. When America was struggling in the high cause of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence to throw off the yoke of another country, and when it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was about to usher a new nation into the world, the spirits of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants were roused to the height which their great efforts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: required. In this general excitement the most distinguished men were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ready to forestall the wants of the community, and the people clung
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them for support, and placed them at its head. But events of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magnitude are rare, and it is from an inspection of the ordinary course
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of affairs that our judgment must be formed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If passing occurrences sometimes act as checks upon the passions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy, the intelligence and the manners of the community exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an influence which is not less powerful and far more permanent. This is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely perceptible in the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In New England the education and the liberties of the communities were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engendered by the moral and religious principles of their founders.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Where society has acquired a sufficient degree of stability to enable it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to hold certain maxims and to retain fixed habits, the lower orders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are accustomed to respect intellectual superiority and to submit to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it without complaint, although they set at naught all those privileges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which wealth and birth have introduced among mankind. The democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in New England consequently makes a more judicious choice than it does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But as we descend towards the South, to those States in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the constitution of society is more modern and less strong, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instruction is less general, and where the principles of morality, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion, and of liberty are less happily combined, we perceive that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talents and the virtues of those who are in authority become more and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more rare.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lastly, when we arrive at the new South-western States, in which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution of society dates but from yesterday, and presents an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agglomeration of adventurers and speculators, we are amazed at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons who are invested with public authority, and we are led to ask by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what force, independent of the legislation and of the men who direct it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State can be protected, and society be made to flourish.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are certain laws of a democratic nature which contribute,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless, to correct, in some measure, the dangerous tendencies of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy. On entering the House of Representatives of Washington one is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struck by the vulgar demeanor of that great assembly. The eye frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not discover a man of celebrity within its walls. Its members are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all obscure individuals whose names present no associations to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mind: they are mostly village lawyers, men in trade, or even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons belonging to the lower classes of society. In a country in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: education is very general, it is said that the representatives of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people do not always know how to write correctly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At a few yards' distance from this spot is the door of the Senate, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contains within a small space a large proportion of the celebrated men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of America. Scarcely an individual is to be perceived in it who does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not recall the idea of an active and illustrious career: the Senate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is composed of eloquent advocates, distinguished generals, wise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrates, and statesmen of note, whose language would at all times do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor to the most remarkable parliamentary debates of Europe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What then is the cause of this strange contrast, and why are the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able citizens to be found in one assembly rather than in the other?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Why is the former body remarkable for its vulgarity and its poverty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talent, whilst the latter seems to enjoy a monopoly of intelligence and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of sound judgment? Both of these assemblies emanate from the people;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: both of them are chosen by universal suffrage; and no voice has hitherto
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been heard to assert in America that the Senate is hostile to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests of the people. From what cause, then, does so startling a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difference arise? The only reason which appears to me adequately to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: account for it is, that the House of Representatives is elected by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: populace directly, and that the Senate is elected by elected bodies. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole body of the citizens names the legislature of each State, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Constitution converts these legislatures into so many electoral
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bodies, which return the members of the Senate. The senators are elected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by an indirect application of universal suffrage; for the legislatures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which name them are not aristocratic or privileged bodies which exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the electoral franchise in their own right; but they are chosen by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: totality of the citizens; they are generally elected every year, and new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members may constantly be chosen who will employ their electoral rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in conformity with the wishes of the public. But this transmission of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the popular authority through an assembly of chosen men operates an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important change in it, by refining its discretion and improving the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forms which it adopts. Men who are chosen in this manner accurately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represent the majority of the nation which governs them; but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represent the elevated thoughts which are current in the community,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the propensities which prompt its nobler actions, rather than the petty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions which disturb or the vices which disgrace it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The time may be already anticipated at which the American Republics will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be obliged to introduce the plan of election by an elected body more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently into their system of representation, or they will incur no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small risk of perishing miserably amongst the shoals of democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And here I have no scruple in confessing that I look upon this peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system of election as the only means of bringing the exercise of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political power to the level of all classes of the people. Those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thinkers who regard this institution as the exclusive weapon of a party,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and those who fear, on the other hand, to make use of it, seem to me to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fall into as great an error in the one case as in the other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Influence Which The American Democracy Has Exercised On The Laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Relating To Elections
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When elections are rare, they expose the State to a violent crisis--When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are frequent, they keep up a degree of feverish excitement--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans have preferred the second of these two evils--Mutability of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws--Opinions of Hamilton and Jefferson on this subject.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When elections recur at long intervals the State is exposed to violent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agitation every time they take place. Parties exert themselves to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: utmost in order to gain a prize which is so rarely within their reach;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and as the evil is almost irremediable for the candidates who fail, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences of their disappointed ambition may prove most disastrous;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if, on the other hand, the legal struggle can be repeated within a short
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: space of time, the defeated parties take patience. When elections occur
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently, their recurrence keeps society in a perpetual state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feverish excitement, and imparts a continual instability to public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, on the one hand the State is exposed to the perils of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution, on the other to perpetual mutability; the former system
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: threatens the very existence of the Government, the latter is an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obstacle to all steady and consistent policy. The Americans have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preferred the second of these evils to the first; but they were led to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this conclusion by their instinct much more than by their reason; for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taste for variety is one of the characteristic passions of democracy. An
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary mutability has, by this means, been introduced into their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation. Many of the Americans consider the instability of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws as a necessary consequence of a system whose general results are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beneficial. But no one in the United States affects to deny the fact of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this instability, or to contend that it is not a great evil.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hamilton, after having demonstrated the utility of a power which might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevent, or which might at least impede, the promulgation of bad laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adds: "It might perhaps be said that the power of preventing bad laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: includes that of preventing good ones, and may be used to the one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purpose as well as to the other. But this objection will have little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weight with those who can properly estimate the mischiefs of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconstancy and mutability in the laws which form the greatest blemish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the character and genius of our governments." (Federalist, No. 73.)
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And again in No. 62 of the same work he observes: "The facility and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excess of law-making seem to be the diseases to which our governments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are most liable. . . . The mischievous effects of the mutability in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public councils arising from a rapid succession of new members would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fill a volume: every new election in the States is found to change
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one-half of the representatives. From this change of men must proceed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a change of opinions and of measures, which forfeits the respect and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confidence of other nations, poisons the blessings of liberty itself,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and diminishes the attachment and reverence of the people toward a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political system which betrays so many marks of infirmity."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jefferson himself, the greatest Democrat whom the democracy of America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has yet produced, pointed out the same evils. "The instability of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our laws," said he in a letter to Madison, "is really a very serious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconvenience. I think that we ought to have obviated it by deciding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that a whole year should always be allowed to elapse between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bringing in of a bill and the final passing of it. It should afterward
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be discussed and put to the vote without the possibility of making any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alteration in it; and if the circumstances of the case required a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more speedy decision, the question should not be decided by a simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority, but by a majority of at least two-thirds of both houses."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Public Officers Under The Control Of The Democracy In America Simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exterior of the American public officers--No official costume--All
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public officers are remunerated--Political consequences of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system--No public career exists in America--Result of this.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Public officers in the United States are commingled with the crowd
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of citizens; they have neither palaces, nor guards, nor ceremonial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: costumes. This simple exterior of the persons in authority is connected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only with the peculiarities of the American character, but with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the fundamental principles of that society. In the estimation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy a government is not a benefit, but a necessary evil. A certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degree of power must be granted to public officers, for they would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of no use without it. But the ostensible semblance of authority is by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no means indispensable to the conduct of affairs, and it is needlessly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offensive to the susceptibility of the public. The public officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves are well aware that they only enjoy the superiority over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their fellow-citizens which they derive from their authority upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of putting themselves on a level with the whole community by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their manners. A public officer in the United States is uniformly civil,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accessible to all the world, attentive to all requests, and obliging
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in his replies. I was pleased by these characteristics of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government; and I was struck by the manly independence of the citizens,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who respect the office more than the officer, and who are less attached
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the emblems of authority than to the man who bears them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am inclined to believe that the influence which costumes really
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise, in an age like that in which we live, has been a good deal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exaggerated. I never perceived that a public officer in America was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less respected whilst he was in the discharge of his duties because his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own merit was set off by no adventitious signs. On the other hand, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very doubtful whether a peculiar dress contributes to the respect which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public characters ought to have for their own position, at least when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are not otherwise inclined to respect it. When a magistrate (and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in France such instances are not rare) indulges his trivial wit at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expense of the prisoner, or derides the predicament in which a culprit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is placed, it would be well to deprive him of his robes of office,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to see whether he would recall some portion of the natural dignity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind when he is reduced to the apparel of a private citizen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A democracy may, however, allow a certain show of magisterial pomp, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clothe its officers in silks and gold, without seriously compromising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its principles. Privileges of this kind are transitory; they belong to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the place, and are distinct from the individual: but if public officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not uniformly remunerated by the State, the public charges must be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entrusted to men of opulence and independence, who constitute the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: basis of an aristocracy; and if the people still retains its right
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of election, that election can only be made from a certain class of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens. When a democratic republic renders offices which had formerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been remunerated gratuitous, it may safely be believed that the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is advancing to monarchical institutions; and when a monarchy begins to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remunerate such officers as had hitherto been unpaid, it is a sure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sign that it is approaching toward a despotic or a republican form of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government. The substitution of paid for unpaid functionaries is of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself, in my opinion, sufficient to constitute a serious revolution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I look upon the entire absence of gratuitous functionaries in America as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one of the most prominent signs of the absolute dominion which democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercises in that country. All public services, of whatsoever nature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they may be, are paid; so that every one has not merely the right, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: also the means of performing them. Although, in democratic States, all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens are qualified to occupy stations in the Government, all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not tempted to try for them. The number and the capacities of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: candidates are more apt to restrict the choice of electors than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connections of the candidateship.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In nations in which the principle of election extends to every place in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State no political career can, properly speaking, be said to exist.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men are promoted as if by chance to the rank which they enjoy, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are by no means sure of retaining it. The consequence is that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tranquil times public functions offer but few lures to ambition. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States the persons who engage in the perplexities of political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life are individuals of very moderate pretensions. The pursuit of wealth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally diverts men of great talents and of great passions from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit of power, and it very frequently happens that a man does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertake to direct the fortune of the State until he has discovered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his incompetence to conduct his own affairs. The vast number of very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinary men who occupy public stations is quite as attributable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these causes as to the bad choice of the democracy. In the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, I am not sure that the people would return the men of superior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abilities who might solicit its support, but it is certain that men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this description do not come forward.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Arbitrary Power Of Magistrates Under The Rule Of The American Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: For what reason the arbitrary power of Magistrates is greater in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absolute monarchies and in democratic republics than it is in limited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchies--Arbitrary power of the Magistrates in New England.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In two different kinds of government the magistrates *a exercise a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerable degree of arbitrary power; namely, under the absolute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government of a single individual, and under that of a democracy. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: identical result proceeds from causes which are nearly analogous.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: I here use the word magistrates in the widest sense in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it can be taken; I apply it to all the officers to whom the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: execution of the laws is intrusted.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In despotic States the fortune of no citizen is secure; and public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers are not more safe than private individuals. The sovereign, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has under his control the lives, the property, and sometimes the honor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the men whom he employs, does not scruple to allow them a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latitude of action, because he is convinced that they will not use it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to his prejudice. In despotic States the sovereign is so attached to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise of his power, that he dislikes the constraint even of his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulations; and he is well pleased that his agents should follow a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: somewhat fortuitous line of conduct, provided he be certain that their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions will never counteract his desires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democracies, as the majority has every year the right of depriving
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the officers whom it has appointed of their power, it has no reason
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to fear any abuse of their authority. As the people is always able
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to signify its wishes to those who conduct the Government, it prefers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leaving them to make their own exertions to prescribing an invariable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rule of conduct which would at once fetter their activity and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may even be observed, on attentive consideration, that under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rule of a democracy the arbitrary power of the magistrate must be still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater than in despotic States. In the latter the sovereign has the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of punishing all the faults with which he becomes acquainted, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it would be vain for him to hope to become acquainted with all those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are committed. In the former the sovereign power is not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supreme, but it is universally present. The American functionaries are,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in point of fact, much more independent in the sphere of action which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the law traces out for them than any public officer in Europe. Very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently the object which they are to accomplish is simply pointed out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them, and the choice of the means is left to their own discretion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In New England, for instance, the selectmen of each township are bound
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to draw up the list of persons who are to serve on the jury; the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rule which is laid down to guide them in their choice is that they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to select citizens possessing the elective franchise and enjoying a fair
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reputation. *b In France the lives and liberties of the subjects would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be thought to be in danger if a public officer of any kind was entrusted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with so formidable a right. In New England the same magistrates are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empowered to post the names of habitual drunkards in public-houses, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to prohibit the inhabitants of a town from supplying them with liquor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *c A censorial power of this excessive kind would be revolting to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the population of the most absolute monarchies; here, however, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submitted to without difficulty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: See the Act of February 27, 1813. "General Collection of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Laws of Massachusetts," vol. ii. p. 331. It should be added that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurors are afterwards drawn from these lists by lot.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: See Act of February 28, 1787. "General Collection of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Laws of Massachusetts," vol. i. p. 302.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nowhere has so much been left by the law to the arbitrary determination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the magistrate as in democratic republics, because this arbitrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power is unattended by any alarming consequences. It may even be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asserted that the freedom of the magistrate increases as the elective
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: franchise is extended, and as the duration of the time of office
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is shortened. Hence arises the great difficulty which attends the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conversion of a democratic republic into a monarchy. The magistrate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceases to be elective, but he retains the rights and the habits of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elected officer, which lead directly to despotism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is only in limited monarchies that the law, which prescribes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere in which public officers are to act, superintends all their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures. The cause of this may be easily detected. In limited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchies the power is divided between the King and the people, both
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of whom are interested in the stability of the magistrate. The King
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not venture to place the public officers under the control of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, lest they should be tempted to betray his interests; on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other hand, the people fears lest the magistrates should serve to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppress the liberties of the country, if they were entirely dependent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the Crown; they cannot therefore be said to depend on either one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or the other. The same cause which induces the king and the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to render public officers independent suggests the necessity of such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: securities as may prevent their independence from encroaching upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the authority of the former and the liberties of the latter. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently agree as to the necessity of restricting the functionary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a line of conduct laid down beforehand, and they are interested in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confining him by certain regulations which he cannot evade.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIII: Government Of The Democracy In America--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Instability Of The Administration In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the public acts of a community frequently leave fewer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traces than the occurrences of a family--Newspapers the only historical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains--Instability of the administration prejudicial to the art of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The authority which public men possess in America is so brief, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are so soon commingled with the ever-changing population of the country,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the acts of a community frequently leave fewer traces than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurrences of a private family. The public administration is, so to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speak, oral and traditionary. But little is committed to writing, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that little is wafted away forever, like the leaves of the Sibyl, by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: smallest breeze.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The only historical remains in the United States are the newspapers; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if a number be wanting, the chain of time is broken, and the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is severed from the past. I am convinced that in fifty years it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be more difficult to collect authentic documents concerning the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of the Americans at the present day than it is to find remains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the administration of France during the Middle Ages; and if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States were ever invaded by barbarians, it would be necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have recourse to the history of other nations in order to learn anything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the people which now inhabits them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The instability of the administration has penetrated into the habits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people: it even appears to suit the general taste, and no one cares
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for what occurred before his time. No methodical system is pursued; no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: archives are formed; and no documents are brought together when it would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be very easy to do so. Where they exist, little store is set upon them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and I have amongst my papers several original public documents which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were given to me in answer to some of my inquiries. In America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society seems to live from hand to mouth, like an army in the field.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, the art of administration may undoubtedly be ranked as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a science, and no sciences can be improved if the discoveries and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observations of successive generations are not connected together in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the order in which they occur. One man, in the short space of his life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarks a fact; another conceives an idea; the former invents a means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of execution, the latter reduces a truth to a fixed proposition; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind gathers the fruits of individual experience upon its way
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and gradually forms the sciences. But the persons who conduct the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration in America can seldom afford any instruction to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other; and when they assume the direction of society, they simply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possess those attainments which are most widely disseminated in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, and no experience peculiar to themselves. Democracy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carried to its furthest limits, is therefore prejudicial to the art of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government; and for this reason it is better adapted to a people already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: versed in the conduct of an administration than to a nation which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uninitiated in public affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This remark, indeed, is not exclusively applicable to the science of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration. Although a democratic government is founded upon a very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simple and natural principle, it always presupposes the existence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a high degree of culture and enlightenment in society. *d At the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glance it may be imagined to belong to the earliest ages of the world;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but maturer observation will convince us that it could only come last in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the succession of human history.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: It is needless to observe that I speak here of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic form of government as applied to a people, not merely to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribe.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Charges Levied By The State Under The Rule Of The American Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In all communities citizens divisible into three classes--Habits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each of these classes in the direction of public finances--Why public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expenditure must tend to increase when the people governs--What renders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the extravagance of a democracy less to be feared in America--Public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expenditure under a democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Before we can affirm whether a democratic form of government is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: economical or not, we must establish a suitable standard of comparison.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The question would be one of easy solution if we were to attempt to draw
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a parallel between a democratic republic and an absolute monarchy. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public expenditure would be found to be more considerable under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former than under the latter; such is the case with all free States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compared to those which are not so. It is certain that despotism ruins
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals by preventing them from producing wealth, much more than by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: depriving them of the wealth they have produced; it dries up the source
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of riches, whilst it usually respects acquired property. Freedom, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, engenders far more benefits than it destroys; and the nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are favored by free institutions invariably find that their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources increase even more rapidly than their taxes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: My present object is to compare free nations to each other, and to point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out the influence of democracy upon the finances of a State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Communities, as well as organic bodies, are subject to certain fixed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules in their formation which they cannot evade. They are composed of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain elements which are common to them at all times and under all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances. The people may always be mentally divided into three
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinct classes. The first of these classes consists of the wealthy;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the second, of those who are in easy circumstances; and the third is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed of those who have little or no property, and who subsist more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially by the work which they perform for the two superior orders.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The proportion of the individuals who are included in these three
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divisions may vary according to the condition of society, but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divisions themselves can never be obliterated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is evident that each of these classes will exercise an influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar to its own propensities upon the administration of the finances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the State. If the first of the three exclusively possesses the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative power, it is probable that it will not be sparing of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public funds, because the taxes which are levied on a large fortune only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tend to diminish the sum of superfluous enjoyment, and are, in point of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact, but little felt. If the second class has the power of making the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws, it will certainly not be lavish of taxes, because nothing is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so onerous as a large impost which is levied upon a small income.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The government of the middle classes appears to me to be the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: economical, though perhaps not the most enlightened, and certainly not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most generous, of free governments.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But let us now suppose that the legislative authority is vested in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the lowest orders: there are two striking reasons which show that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency of the expenditure will be to increase, not to diminish. As the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great majority of those who create the laws are possessed of no property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon which taxes can be imposed, all the money which is spent for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community appears to be spent to their advantage, at no cost of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own; and those who are possessed of some little property readily find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means of regulating the taxes so that they are burdensome to the wealthy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and profitable to the poor, although the rich are unable to take the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same advantage when they are in possession of the Government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In countries in which the poor *e should be exclusively invested with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power of making the laws no great economy of public expenditure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought to be expected: that expenditure will always be considerable;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either because the taxes do not weigh upon those who levy them, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they are levied in such a manner as not to weigh upon those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes. In other words, the government of the democracy is the only one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under which the power which lays on taxes escapes the payment of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: The word poor is used here, and throughout the remainder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this chapter, in a relative, not in an absolute sense. Poor men in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America would often appear rich in comparison with the poor of Europe;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they may with propriety by styled poor in comparison with their more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affluent countrymen.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may be objected (but the argument has no real weight) that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true interest of the people is indissolubly connected with that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealthier portion of the community, since it cannot but suffer by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severe measures to which it resorts. But is it not the true interest of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kings to render their subjects happy, and the true interest of nobles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to admit recruits into their order on suitable grounds? If remote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages had power to prevail over the passions and the exigencies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the moment, no such thing as a tyrannical sovereign or an exclusive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy could ever exist.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Again, it may be objected that the poor are never invested with the sole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of making the laws; but I reply, that wherever universal suffrage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has been established the majority of the community unquestionably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercises the legislative authority; and if it be proved that the poor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always constitute the majority, it may be added, with perfect truth,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in the countries in which they possess the elective franchise they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possess the sole power of making laws. But it is certain that in all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations of the world the greater number has always consisted of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons who hold no property, or of those whose property is insufficient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to exempt them from the necessity of working in order to procure an easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsistence. Universal suffrage does therefore, in point of fact, invest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the poor with the government of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The disastrous influence which popular authority may sometimes exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the finances of a State was very clearly seen in some of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic republics of antiquity, in which the public treasure was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exhausted in order to relieve indigent citizens, or to supply the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: games and theatrical amusements of the populace. It is true that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative system was then very imperfectly known, and that, at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present time, the influence of popular passion is less felt in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conduct of public affairs; but it may be believed that the delegate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will in the end conform to the principles of his constituents, and favor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their propensities as much as their interests.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The extravagance of democracy is, however, less to be dreaded in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion as the people acquires a share of property, because on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one hand the contributions of the rich are then less needed, and, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other, it is more difficult to lay on taxes which do not affect the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests of the lower classes. On this account universal suffrage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be less dangerous in France than in England, because in the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country the property on which taxes may be levied is vested in fewer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands. America, where the great majority of the citizens possess some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune, is in a still more favorable position than France.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are still further causes which may increase the sum of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expenditure in democratic countries. When the aristocracy governs, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals who conduct the affairs of State are exempted by their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: station in society from every kind of privation; they are contented with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their position; power and renown are the objects for which they strive;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and, as they are placed far above the obscurer throng of citizens, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not always distinctly perceive how the well-being of the mass of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people ought to redound to their own honor. They are not indeed callous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the sufferings of the poor, but they cannot feel those miseries as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acutely as if they were themselves partakers of them. Provided that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people appear to submit to its lot, the rulers are satisfied, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demand nothing further from the Government. An aristocracy is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intent upon the means of maintaining its influence than upon the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of improving its condition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When, on the contrary, the people is invested with the supreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, the perpetual sense of their own miseries impels the rulers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society to seek for perpetual ameliorations. A thousand different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects are subjected to improvement; the most trivial details are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sought out as susceptible of amendment; and those changes which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accompanied with considerable expense are more especially advocated,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since the object is to render the condition of the poor more tolerable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who cannot pay for themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Moreover, all democratic communities are agitated by an ill-defined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excitement and by a kind of feverish impatience, that engender a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of innovations, almost all of which are attended with expense.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In monarchies and aristocracies the natural taste which the rulers have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for power and for renown is stimulated by the promptings of ambition,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they are frequently incited by these temptations to very costly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings. In democracies, where the rulers labor under privations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they can only be courted by such means as improve their well-being, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these improvements cannot take place without a sacrifice of money. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a people begins to reflect upon its situation, it discovers a multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of wants to which it had not before been subject, and to satisfy these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exigencies recourse must be had to the coffers of the State. Hence it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arises that the public charges increase in proportion as civilization
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spreads, and that imposts are augmented as knowledge pervades the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The last cause which frequently renders a democratic government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dearer than any other is, that a democracy does not always succeed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moderating its expenditure, because it does not understand the art of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being economical. As the designs which it entertains are frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changed, and the agents of those designs are still more frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removed, its undertakings are often ill conducted or left unfinished: in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the former case the State spends sums out of all proportion to the end
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it proposes to accomplish; in the second, the expense itself is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unprofitable. *f
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: The gross receipts of the Treasury of the United States in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1832 were about $28,000,000; in 1870 they had risen to $411,000,000. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Tendencies Of The American Democracy As Regards The Salaries Of Public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the democracies those who establish high salaries have no chance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profiting by them--Tendency of the American democracy to increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the salaries of subordinate officers and to lower those of the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important functionaries--Reason of this--Comparative statement of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: salaries of public officers in the United States and in France.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is a powerful reason which usually induces democracies to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: economize upon the salaries of public officers. As the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens who dispense the remuneration is extremely large in democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries, so the number of persons who can hope to be benefited by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: receipt of it is comparatively small. In aristocratic countries, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, the individuals who fix high salaries have almost always a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vague hope of profiting by them. These appointments may be looked upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a capital which they create for their own use, or at least as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resource for their children.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must, however, be allowed that a democratic State is most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parsimonious towards its principal agents. In America the secondary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers are much better paid, and the dignitaries of the administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much worse, than they are elsewhere.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These opposite effects result from the same cause; the people fixes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the salaries of the public officers in both cases; and the scale of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remuneration is determined by the consideration of its own wants. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: held to be fair that the servants of the public should be placed in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same easy circumstances as the public itself; *g but when the question
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turns upon the salaries of the great officers of State, this rule
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fails, and chance alone can guide the popular decision. The poor have no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adequate conception of the wants which the higher classes of society may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feel. The sum which is scanty to the rich appears enormous to the poor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man whose wants do not extend beyond the necessaries of life; and in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estimation the Governor of a State, with his twelve or fifteen hundred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dollars a year, is a very fortunate and enviable being. *h If you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertake to convince him that the representative of a great people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought to be able to maintain some show of splendor in the eyes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign nations, he will perhaps assent to your meaning; but when he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reflects on his own humble dwelling, and on the hard-earned produce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his wearisome toil, he remembers all that he could do with a salary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which you say is insufficient, and he is startled or almost frightened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the sight of such uncommon wealth. Besides, the secondary public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officer is almost on a level with the people, whilst the others are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raised above it. The former may therefore excite his interest, but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter begins to arouse his envy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: The easy circumstances in which secondary functionaries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are placed in the United States result also from another cause, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is independent of the general tendencies of democracy; every kind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private business is very lucrative, and the State would not be served at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all if it did not pay its servants. The country is in the position of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a commercial undertaking, which is obliged to sustain an expensive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: competition, notwithstanding its tastes for economy.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: The State of Ohio, which contains a million of inhabitants,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gives its Governor a salary of only $1,200 a year.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is very clearly seen in the United States, where the salaries seem
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to decrease as the authority of those who receive them augments *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: To render this assertion perfectly evident, it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suffice to examine the scale of salaries of the agents of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government. I have added the salaries attached to the corresponding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers in France under the constitutional monarchy to complete the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparison.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Treasury Department
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Clerk with lowest salary .............  1,000
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Clerk with highest salary ............  1,600
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Secretary of State ...................  6,000
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ministere des Finances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Clerk with lowest salary,  1,000 to 1,800 fr.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Clerk with highest salary  3,200 to 8,600 fr.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Secretaire-general ................20,000 fr.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have perhaps done wrong in selecting France as my standard of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparison. In France the democratic tendencies of the nation exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an ever-increasing influence upon the Government, and the Chambers show
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a disposition to raise the low salaries and to lower the principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ones. Thus, the Minister of Finance, who received 160,000 fr. under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Empire, receives 80,000 fr. in 1835: the Directeurs-generaux of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Finance, who then received 50,000 fr. now receive only 20,000 fr. [This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparison is based on the state of things existing in France and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States in 1831. It has since materially altered in both
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries, but not so much as to impugn the truth of the author's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observation.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Under the rule of an aristocracy it frequently happens, on the contrary,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that whilst the high officers are receiving munificent salaries, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferior ones have not more than enough to procure the necessaries of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life. The reason of this fact is easily discoverable from causes very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: analogous to those to which I have just alluded. If a democracy is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unable to conceive the pleasures of the rich or to witness them without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: envy, an aristocracy is slow to understand, or, to speak more correctly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is unacquainted with, the privations of the poor. The poor man is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (if we use the term aright) the fellow of the rich one; but he is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being of another species. An aristocracy is therefore apt to care but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little for the fate of its subordinate agents; and their salaries are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only raised when they refuse to perform their service for too scanty a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remuneration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is the parsimonious conduct of democracy towards its principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers which has countenanced a supposition of far more economical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities than any which it really possesses. It is true that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scarcely allows the means of honorable subsistence to the individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who conduct its affairs; but enormous sums are lavished to meet the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exigencies or to facilitate the enjoyments of the people. *j The money
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raised by taxation may be better employed, but it is not saved. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general, democracy gives largely to the community, and very sparingly to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who govern it. The reverse is the case in aristocratic countries,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the money of the State is expended to the profit of the persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are at the head of affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: See the American budgets for the cost of indigent citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and gratuitous instruction. In 1831 $250,000 were spent in the State of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New York for the maintenance of the poor, and at least $1,000,000
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were devoted to gratuitous instruction. (William's "New York Annual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Register," 1832, pp. 205 and 243.) The State of New York contained only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1,900,000 inhabitants in the year 1830, which is not more than double
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the amount of population in the Department du Nord in France.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Difficulty of Distinguishing The Causes Which Contribute To The Economy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of The American Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We are liable to frequent errors in the research of those facts which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise a serious influence upon the fate of mankind, since nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is more difficult than to appreciate their real value. One people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is naturally inconsistent and enthusiastic; another is sober and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calculating; and these characteristics originate in their physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution or in remote causes with which we are unacquainted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These are nations which are fond of parade and the bustle of festivity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and which do not regret the costly gaieties of an hour. Others, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contrary, are attached to more retiring pleasures, and seem almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ashamed of appearing to be pleased. In some countries the highest value
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is set upon the beauty of public edifices; in others the productions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: art are treated with indifference, and everything which is unproductive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is looked down upon with contempt. In some renown, in others money, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ruling passion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Independently of the laws, all these causes concur to exercise a very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful influence upon the conduct of the finances of the State. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans never spend the money of the people in galas, it is not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because the imposition of taxes is under the control of the people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but because the people takes no delight in public rejoicings. If they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repudiate all ornament from their architecture, and set no store on any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the more practical and homely advantages, it is not only because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they live under democratic institutions, but because they are a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commercial nation. The habits of private life are continued in public;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and we ought carefully to distinguish that economy which depends upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their institutions from that which is the natural result of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners and customs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whether The Expenditure Of The United States Can Be Compared To That Of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Two points to be established in order to estimate the extent of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public charges, viz., the national wealth and the rate of taxation--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth and the charges of France not accurately known--Why the wealth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and charges of the Union cannot be accurately known--Researches of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the author with a view to discover the amount of taxation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Pennsylvania--General symptoms which may serve to indicate the amount of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the public charges in a given nation--Result of this investigation for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Many attempts have recently been made in France to compare the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expenditure of that country with the expenditure of the United States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all these attempts have, however, been unattended by success, and a few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words will suffice to show that they could not have had a satisfactory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: result.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In order to estimate the amount of the public charges of a people two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preliminaries are indispensable: it is necessary, in the first place, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know the wealth of that people; and in the second, to learn what portion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of that wealth is devoted to the expenditure of the State. To show the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amount of taxation without showing the resources which are destined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to meet the demand, is to undertake a futile labor; for it is not the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expenditure, but the relation of the expenditure to the revenue, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is desirable to know.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same rate of taxation which may easily be supported by a wealthy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contributor will reduce a poor one to extreme misery. The wealth of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations is composed of several distinct elements, of which population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the first, real property the second, and personal property the third.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first of these three elements may be discovered without difficulty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst civilized nations it is easy to obtain an accurate census of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inhabitants; but the two others cannot be determined with so much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
