text: facility. It is difficult to take an exact account of all the lands in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a country which are under cultivation, with their natural or their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquired value; and it is still more impossible to estimate the entire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal property which is at the disposal of a nation, and which eludes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the strictest analysis by the diversity and the number of shapes under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it may occur. And, indeed, we find that the most ancient civilized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations of Europe, including even those in which the administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is most central, have not succeeded, as yet, in determining the exact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of their wealth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the attempt has never been made; for how would such an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: investigation be possible in a country where society has not yet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settled into habits of regularity and tranquillity; where the national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government is not assisted by a multiple of agents whose exertions it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can command and direct to one sole end; and where statistics are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: studied, because no one is able to collect the necessary documents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or to find time to peruse them? Thus the primary elements of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calculations which have been made in France cannot be obtained in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union; the relative wealth of the two countries is unknown; the property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the former is not accurately determined, and no means exist of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: computing that of the latter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I consent, therefore, for the sake of the discussion, to abandon this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary term of the comparison, and I confine myself to a computation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the actual amount of taxation, without investigating the relation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which subsists between the taxation and the revenue. But the reader will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceive that my task has not been facilitated by the limits which I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: here lay down for my researches.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It cannot be doubted that the central administration of France, assisted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by all the public officers who are at its disposal, might determine with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exactitude the amount of the direct and indirect taxes levied upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens. But this investigation, which no private individual can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertake, has not hitherto been completed by the French Government, or,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least, its results have not been made public. We are acquainted with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sum total of the charges of the State; we know the amount of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: departmental expenditure; but the expenses of the communal divisions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have not been computed, and the amount of the public expenses of France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is consequently unknown.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If we now turn to America, we shall perceive that the difficulties are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multiplied and enhanced. The Union publishes an exact return of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amount of its expenditure; the budgets of the four and twenty States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: furnish similar returns of their revenues; but the expenses incident to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the affairs of the counties and the townships are unknown. *k
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: The Americans, as we have seen, have four separate budgets,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union, the States, the Counties, and the Townships having each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severally their own. During my stay in America I made every endeavor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to discover the amount of the public expenditure in the townships and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: counties of the principal States of the Union, and I readily obtained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the budget of the larger townships, but I found it quite impossible to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: procure that of the smaller ones. I possess, however, some documents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relating to county expenses, which, although incomplete, are still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curious. I have to thank Mr. Richards, Mayor of Philadelphia, for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: budgets of thirteen of the counties of Pennsylvania, viz., Lebanon,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Centre, Franklin, Fayette, Montgomery, Luzerne, Dauphin, Butler,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Alleghany, Columbia, Northampton, Northumberland, and Philadelphia,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the year 1830. Their population at that time consisted of 495,207
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants. On looking at the map of Pennsylvania, it will be seen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that these thirteen counties are scattered in every direction, and so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally affected by the causes which usually influence the condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a country, that they may easily be supposed to furnish a correct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: average of the financial state of the counties of Pennsylvania in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general; and thus, upon reckoning that the expenses of these counties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amounted in the year 1830 to about $361,650, or nearly 75 cents for each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitant, and calculating that each of them contributed in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: year about $2.55 towards the Union, and about 75 cents to the State of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Pennsylvania, it appears that they each contributed as their share
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all the public expenses (except those of the townships) the sum of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: $4.05. This calculation is doubly incomplete, as it applies only to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single year and to one part of the public charges; but it has at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the merit of not being conjectural.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The authority of the Federal government cannot oblige the provincial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments to throw any light upon this point; and even if these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments were inclined to afford their simultaneous co-operation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may be doubted whether they possess the means of procuring a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfactory answer. Independently of the natural difficulties of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: task, the political organization of the country would act as a hindrance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the success of their efforts. The county and town magistrates are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appointed by the authorities of the State, and they are not subjected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to their control. It is therefore very allowable to suppose that, if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State was desirous of obtaining the returns which we require, its design
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be counteracted by the neglect of those subordinate officers whom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it would be obliged to employ. *l It is, in point of fact, useless to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquire what the Americans might do to forward this inquiry, since it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is certain that they have hitherto done nothing at all. There does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist a single individual at the present day, in America or in Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who can inform us what each citizen of the Union annually contributes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the public charges of the nation. *m [Footnote l: Those who have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempted to draw a comparison between the expenses of France and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America have at once perceived that no such comparison could be drawn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the total expenditure of the two countries; but they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavored to contrast detached portions of this expenditure. It may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily be shown that this second system is not at all less defective
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the first. If I attempt to compare the French budget with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: budget of the Union, it must be remembered that the latter embraces much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fewer objects than then central Government of the former country, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the expenditure must consequently be much smaller. If I contrast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the budgets of the Departments with those of the States which constitute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union, it must be observed that, as the power and control exercised
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the States is much greater than that which is exercised by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Departments, their expenditure is also more considerable. As for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: budgets of the counties, nothing of the kind occurs in the French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system of finances; and it is, again, doubtful whether the corresponding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expenses should be referred to the budget of the State or to those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the municipal divisions. Municipal expenses exist in both countries,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they are not always analogous. In America the townships discharge a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: variety of offices which are reserved in France to the Departments or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the State. It may, moreover, be asked what is to be understood by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: municipal expenses of America. The organization of the municipal bodies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or townships differs in the several States. Are we to be guided by what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurs in New England or in Georgia, in Pennsylvania or in the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Illinois? A kind of analogy may very readily be perceived between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain budgets in the two countries; but as the elements of which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are composed always differ more or less, no fair comparison can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be instituted between them. [The same difficulty exists, perhaps to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater degree at the present time, when the taxation of America has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: largely increased.--1874.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: Even if we knew the exact pecuniary contributions of every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French and American citizen to the coffers of the State, we should only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: come at a portion of the truth. Governments do not only demand supplies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of money, but they call for personal services, which may be looked upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as equivalent to a given sum. When a State raises an army, besides the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pay of the troops, which is furnished by the entire nation, each soldier
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must give up his time, the value of which depends on the use he might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make of it if he were not in the service. The same remark applies to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: militia; the citizen who is in the militia devotes a certain portion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of valuable time to the maintenance of the public peace, and he does in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reality surrender to the State those earnings which he is prevented from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gaining. Many other instances might be cited in addition to these. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments of France and of America both levy taxes of this kind,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which weigh upon the citizens; but who can estimate with accuracy their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relative amount in the two countries?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This, however, is not the last of the difficulties which prevent us from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparing the expenditure of the Union with that of France. The French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government contracts certain obligations which do not exist in America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and vice versa. The French Government pays the clergy; in America the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: voluntary principle prevails. In America there is a legal provision for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the poor; in France they are abandoned to the charity of the public. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French public officers are paid by a fixed salary; in America they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allowed certain perquisites. In France contributions in kind take place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on very few roads; in America upon almost all the thoroughfares: in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the former country the roads are free to all travellers; in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter turnpikes abound. All these differences in the manner in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contributions are levied in the two countries enhance the difficulty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparing their expenditure; for there are certain expenses which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens would not be subject to, or which would at any rate be much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less considerable, if the State did not take upon itself to act in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: name of the public.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hence we must conclude that it is no less difficult to compare the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social expenditure than it is to estimate the relative wealth of France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and America. I will even add that it would be dangerous to attempt this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparison; for when statistics are not based upon computations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are strictly accurate, they mislead instead of guiding aright. The mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is easily imposed upon by the false affectation of exactness, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevails even in the misstatements of science, and it adopts with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confidence errors which are dressed in the forms of mathematical truth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We abandon, therefore, our numerical investigation, with the hope of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: meeting with data of another kind. In the absence of positive documents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we may form an opinion as to the proportion which the taxation of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people bears to its real prosperity, by observing whether its external
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appearance is flourishing; whether, after having discharged the calls of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State, the poor man retains the means of subsistence, and the rich
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the means of enjoyment; and whether both classes are contented with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their position, seeking, however, to ameliorate it by perpetual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions, so that industry is never in want of capital, nor capital
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unemployed by industry. The observer who draws his inferences from these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: signs will, undoubtedly, be led to the conclusion that the American of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States contributes a much smaller portion of his income to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State than the citizen of France. Nor, indeed, can the result be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: otherwise.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A portion of the French debt is the consequence of two successive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invasions; and the Union has no similar calamity to fear. A nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: placed upon the continent of Europe is obliged to maintain a large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: standing army; the isolated position of the Union enables it to have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only 6,000 soldiers. The French have a fleet of 300 sail; the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have 52 vessels. *n How, then, can the inhabitants of the Union be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called upon to contribute as largely as the inhabitants of France?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No parallel can be drawn between the finances of two countries so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differently situated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: See the details in the Budget of the French Minister of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Marine; and for America, the National Calendar of 1833, p. 228. [But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the public debt of the United States in 1870, caused by the Civil War,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amounted to $2,480,672,427; that of France was more than doubled by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extravagance of the Second Empire and by the war of 1870.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is by examining what actually takes place in the Union, and not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by comparing the Union with France, that we may discover whether the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American Government is really economical. On casting my eyes over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different republics which form the confederation, I perceive that their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Governments lack perseverance in their undertakings, and that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise no steady control over the men whom they employ. Whence I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally infer that they must often spend the money of the people to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no purpose, or consume more of it than is really necessary to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings. Great efforts are made, in accordance with the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: origin of society, to satisfy the exigencies of the lower orders, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: open the career of power to their endeavors, and to diffuse knowledge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and comfort amongst them. The poor are maintained, immense sums are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annually devoted to public instruction, all services whatsoever are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remunerated, and the most subordinate agents are liberally paid. If
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this kind of government appears to me to be useful and rational, I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless constrained to admit that it is expensive.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Wherever the poor direct public affairs and dispose of the national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources, it appears certain that, as they profit by the expenditure of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State, they are apt to augment that expenditure.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I conclude, therefore, without having recourse to inaccurate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: computations, and without hazarding a comparison which might prove
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incorrect, that the democratic government of the Americans is not a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cheap government, as is sometimes asserted; and I have no hesitation in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predicting that, if the people of the United States is ever involved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in serious difficulties, its taxation will speedily be increased to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rate of that which prevails in the greater part of the aristocracies and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the monarchies of Europe. *o
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: [That is precisely what has since occurred.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIII: Government Of The Democracy In America--Part III
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Corruption And Vices Of The Rulers In A Democracy, And Consequent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Effects Upon Public Morality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocracies rulers sometimes endeavor to corrupt the people--In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies rulers frequently show themselves to be corrupt--In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former their vices are directly prejudicial to the morality of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people--In the latter their indirect influence is still more pernicious.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A distinction must be made, when the aristocratic and the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles mutually inveigh against each other, as tending to facilitate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corruption. In aristocratic governments the individuals who are placed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the head of affairs are rich men, who are solely desirous of power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democracies statesmen are poor, and they have their fortunes to make.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The consequence is that in aristocratic States the rulers are rarely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accessible to corruption, and have very little craving for money; whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the reverse is the case in democratic nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in aristocracies, as those who are desirous of arriving at the head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of affairs are possessed of considerable wealth, and as the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons by whose assistance they may rise is comparatively small, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government is, if I may use the expression, put up to a sort of auction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democracies, on the contrary, those who are covetous of power are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very seldom wealthy, and the number of citizens who confer that power is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely great. Perhaps in democracies the number of men who might be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bought is by no means smaller, but buyers are rarely to be met with;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and, besides, it would be necessary to buy so many persons at once that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the attempt is rendered nugatory.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Many of the men who have been in the administration in France during
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the last forty years have been accused of making their fortunes at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the expense of the State or of its allies; a reproach which was rarely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: addressed to the public characters of the ancient monarchy. But in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France the practice of bribing electors is almost unknown, whilst it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notoriously and publicly carried on in England. In the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I never heard a man accused of spending his wealth in corrupting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the populace; but I have often heard the probity of public officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: questioned; still more frequently have I heard their success attributed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to low intrigues and immoral practices.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If, then, the men who conduct the government of an aristocracy sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavor to corrupt the people, the heads of a democracy are themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corrupt. In the former case the morality of the people is directly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assailed; in the latter an indirect influence is exercised upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people which is still more to be dreaded.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the rulers of democratic nations are almost always exposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the suspicion of dishonorable conduct, they in some measure lend the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the Government to the base practices of which they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accused. They thus afford an example which must prove discouraging
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the struggles of virtuous independence, and must foster the secret
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calculations of a vicious ambition. If it be asserted that evil passions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are displayed in all ranks of society, that they ascend the throne by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereditary right, and that despicable characters are to be met with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the head of aristocratic nations as well as in the sphere of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy, this objection has but little weight in my estimation. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corruption of men who have casually risen to power has a coarse and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vulgar infection in it which renders it contagious to the multitude. On
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contrary, there is a kind of aristocratic refinement and an air of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grandeur in the depravity of the great, which frequently prevent it from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spreading abroad.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The people can never penetrate into the perplexing labyrinth of court
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intrigue, and it will always have difficulty in detecting the turpitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which lurks under elegant manners, refined tastes, and graceful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language. But to pillage the public purse, and to vend the favors of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State, are arts which the meanest villain may comprehend, and hope to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practice in his turn.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In reality it is far less prejudicial to witness the immorality of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great than to witness that immorality which leads to greatness. In a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy private citizens see a man of their own rank in life, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rises from that obscure position, and who becomes possessed of riches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of power in a few years; the spectacle excites their surprise and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their envy, and they are led to inquire how the person who was yesterday
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their equal is to-day their ruler. To attribute his rise to his talents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or his virtues is unpleasant; for it is tacitly to acknowledge that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are themselves less virtuous and less talented than he was. They are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore led (and not unfrequently their conjecture is a correct one)
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to impute his success mainly to some one of his defects; and an odious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mixture is thus formed of the ideas of turpitude and power, unworthiness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and success, utility and dishonor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Efforts Of Which A Democracy Is Capable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Union has only had one struggle hitherto for its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence--Enthusiasm at the commencement of the war--Indifference
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: towards its close--Difficulty of establishing military conscription
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or impressment of seamen in America--Why a democratic people is less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capable of sustained effort than another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I here warn the reader that I speak of a government which implicitly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: follows the real desires of a people, and not of a government which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simply commands in its name. Nothing is so irresistible as a tyrannical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power commanding in the name of the people, because, whilst it exercises
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that moral influence which belongs to the decision of the majority, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acts at the same time with the promptitude and the tenacity of a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is difficult to say what degree of exertion a democratic government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be capable of making a crisis in the history of the nation. But no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great democratic republic has hitherto existed in the world. To style
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the oligarchy which ruled over France in 1793 by that name would be to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offer an insult to the republican form of government. The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afford the first example of the kind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American Union has now subsisted for half a century, in the course
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of which time its existence has only once been attacked, namely, during
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the War of Independence. At the commencement of that long war, various
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurrences took place which betokened an extraordinary zeal for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: service of the country. *p But as the contest was prolonged, symptoms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private egotism began to show themselves. No money was poured into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public treasury; few recruits could be raised to join the army; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people wished to acquire independence, but was very ill-disposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undergo the privations by which alone it could be obtained. "Tax
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws," says Hamilton in the "Federalist" (No. 12), "have in vain been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multiplied; new methods to enforce the collection have in vain been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tried; the public expectation has been uniformly disappointed and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: treasuries of the States have remained empty. The popular system of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration inherent in the nature of popular government, coinciding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the real scarcity of money incident to a languid and mutilated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of trade, has hitherto defeated every experiment for extensive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collections, and has at length taught the different legislatures the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: folly of attempting them."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: One of the most singular of these occurrences was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resolution which the Americans took of temporarily abandoning the use of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tea. Those who know that men usually cling more to their habits than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to their life will doubtless admire this great though obscure sacrifice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which was made by a whole people.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The United States have not had any serious war to carry on ever since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that period. In order, therefore, to appreciate the sacrifices which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations may impose upon themselves, we must wait until the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American people is obliged to put half its entire income at the disposal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Government, as was done by the English; or until it sends forth a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: twentieth part of its population to the field of battle, as was done by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France. *q
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: [The Civil War showed that when the necessity arose the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American people, both in the North and in the South, are capable of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: making the most enormous sacrifices, both in money and in men.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the use of conscription is unknown, and men are induced to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlist by bounties. The notions and habits of the people of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States are so opposed to compulsory enlistment that I do not imagine it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can ever be sanctioned by the laws. What is termed the conscription
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in France is assuredly the heaviest tax upon the population of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country; yet how could a great continental war be carried on without it?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans have not adopted the British impressment of seamen, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have nothing which corresponds to the French system of maritime
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conscription; the navy, as well as the merchant service, is supplied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by voluntary service. But it is not easy to conceive how a people can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sustain a great maritime war without having recourse to one or the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these two systems. Indeed, the Union, which has fought with some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor upon the seas, has never possessed a very numerous fleet, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the equipment of the small number of American vessels has always been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excessively expensive.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have heard American statesmen confess that the Union will have great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty in maintaining its rank on the seas without adopting the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system of impressment or of maritime conscription; but the difficulty is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to induce the people, which exercises the supreme authority, to submit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to impressment or any compulsory system.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is incontestable that in times of danger a free people displays far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more energy than one which is not so. But I incline to believe that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this is more especially the case in those free nations in which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic element preponderates. Democracy appears to me to be much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: better adapted for the peaceful conduct of society, or for an occasional
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effort of remarkable vigor, than for the hardy and prolonged endurance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the storms which beset the political existence of nations. The reason
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is very evident; it is enthusiasm which prompts men to expose themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to dangers and privations, but they will not support them long without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reflection. There is more calculation, even in the impulses of bravery,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than is generally attributed to them; and although the first efforts are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suggested by passion, perseverance is maintained by a distinct regard of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the purpose in view. A portion of what we value is exposed, in order to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: save the remainder.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But it is this distinct perception of the future, founded upon a sound
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judgment and an enlightened experience, which is most frequently wanting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democracies. The populace is more apt to feel than to reason; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if its present sufferings are great, it is to be feared that the still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater sufferings attendant upon defeat will be forgotten.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Another cause tends to render the efforts of a democratic government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less persevering than those of an aristocracy. Not only are the lower
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes less awakened than the higher orders to the good or evil chances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the future, but they are liable to suffer far more acutely from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present privations. The noble exposes his life, indeed, but the chance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of glory is equal to the chance of harm. If he sacrifices a large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portion of his income to the State, he deprives himself for a time of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the pleasures of affluence; but to the poor man death is embellished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by no pomp or renown, and the imposts which are irksome to the rich are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fatal to him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This relative impotence of democratic republics is, perhaps, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greatest obstacle to the foundation of a republic of this kind in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe. In order that such a State should subsist in one country of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Old World, it would be necessary that similar institutions should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced into all the other nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am of opinion that a democratic government tends in the end to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase the real strength of society; but it can never combine, upon a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single point and at a given time, so much power as an aristocracy or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a monarchy. If a democratic country remained during a whole century
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject to a republican government, it would probably at the end of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that period be more populous and more prosperous than the neighboring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotic States. But it would have incurred the risk of being conquered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much oftener than they would in that lapse of years.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Self-Control Of The American Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American people acquiesces slowly, or frequently does not acquiesce,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in what is beneficial to its interests--The faults of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy are for the most part reparable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The difficulty which a democracy has in conquering the passions and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subduing the exigencies of the moment, with a view to the future, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conspicuous in the most trivial occurrences of the United States. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, which is surrounded by flatterers, has great difficulty in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surmounting its inclinations, and whenever it is solicited to undergo a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privation or any kind of inconvenience, even to attain an end which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sanctioned by its own rational conviction, it almost always refuses to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comply at first. The deference of the Americans to the laws has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been very justly applauded; but it must be added that in America the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation is made by the people and for the people. Consequently, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States the law favors those classes which are most interested
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in evading it elsewhere. It may therefore be supposed that an offensive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law, which should not be acknowledged to be one of immediate utility,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would either not be enacted or would not be obeyed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America there is no law against fraudulent bankruptcies; not because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are few, but because there are a great number of bankruptcies. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dread of being prosecuted as a bankrupt acts with more intensity upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mind of the majority of the people than the fear of being involved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in losses or ruin by the failure of other parties, and a sort of guilty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tolerance is extended by the public conscience to an offence which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everyone condemns in his individual capacity. In the new States of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Southwest the citizens generally take justice into their own hands,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and murders are of very frequent occurrence. This arises from the rude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners and the ignorance of the inhabitants of those deserts, who do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not perceive the utility of investing the law with adequate force, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who prefer duels to prosecutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Someone observed to me one day, in Philadelphia, that almost all crimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in America are caused by the abuse of intoxicating liquors, which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lower classes can procure in great abundance, from their excessive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cheapness. "How comes it," said I, "that you do not put a duty upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brandy?" "Our legislators," rejoined my informant, "have frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought of this expedient; but the task of putting it in operation is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult one; a revolt might be apprehended, and the members who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should vote for a law of this kind would be sure of losing their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seats." "Whence I am to infer," replied I, "that the drinking population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitutes the majority in your country, and that temperance is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: somewhat unpopular."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When these things are pointed out to the American statesmen, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: content themselves with assuring you that time will operate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary change, and that the experience of evil will teach the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its true interests. This is frequently true, although a democracy is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more liable to error than a monarch or a body of nobles; the chances of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its regaining the right path when once it has acknowledged its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mistake, are greater also; because it is rarely embarrassed by internal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests, which conflict with those of the majority, and resist the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of reason. But a democracy can only obtain truth as the result
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of experience, and many nations may forfeit their existence whilst they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are awaiting the consequences of their errors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great privilege of the Americans does not simply consist in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being more enlightened than other nations, but in their being able to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repair the faults they may commit. To which it must be added, that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy cannot derive substantial benefit from past experience, unless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it be arrived at a certain pitch of knowledge and civilization. There
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are tribes and peoples whose education has been so vicious, and whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character presents so strange a mixture of passion, of ignorance, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: erroneous notions upon all subjects, that they are unable to discern the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes of their own wretchedness, and they fall a sacrifice to ills with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they are unacquainted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have crossed vast tracts of country that were formerly inhabited by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful Indian nations which are now extinct; I have myself passed some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time in the midst of mutilated tribes, which witness the daily decline
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their numerical strength and of the glory of their independence; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have heard these Indians themselves anticipate the impending doom of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their race. Every European can perceive means which would rescue
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these unfortunate beings from inevitable destruction. They alone are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insensible to the expedient; they feel the woe which year after year
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heaps upon their heads, but they will perish to a man without accepting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the remedy. It would be necessary to employ force to induce them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submit to the protection and the constraint of civilization.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The incessant revolutions which have convulsed the South American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provinces for the last quarter of a century have frequently been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adverted to with astonishment, and expectations have been expressed that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those nations would speedily return to their natural state. But can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it be affirmed that the turmoil of revolution is not actually the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural state of the South American Spaniards at the present time? In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that country society is plunged into difficulties from which all its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efforts are insufficient to rescue it. The inhabitants of that fair
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portion of the Western Hemisphere seem obstinately bent on pursuing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the work of inward havoc. If they fall into a momentary repose from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effects of exhaustion, that repose prepares them for a fresh state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frenzy. When I consider their condition, which alternates between misery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and crime, I should be inclined to believe that despotism itself would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be a benefit to them, if it were possible that the words despotism and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: benefit could ever be united in my mind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Conduct Of Foreign Affairs By The American Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Direction given to the foreign policy of the United States by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Washington and Jefferson--Almost all the defects inherent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic institutions are brought to light in the conduct of foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs--Their advantages are less perceptible.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We have seen that the Federal Constitution entrusts the permanent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direction of the external interests of the nation to the President and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Senate, *r which tends in some degree to detach the general foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: policy of the Union from the control of the people. It cannot therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be asserted with truth that the external affairs of State are conducted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: "The President," says the Constitution, Art. II, sect. 2,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 2, "shall have power, by and with the advice and consent of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Senate, to make treaties, provided two-thirds of the senators present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concur." The reader is reminded that the senators are returned for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: term of six years, and that they are chosen by the legislature of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The policy of America owes its rise to Washington, and after him to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jefferson, who established those principles which it observes at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present day. Washington said in the admirable letter which he addressed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to his fellow-citizens, and which may be looked upon as his political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bequest to the country: "The great rule of conduct for us in regard to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign nations is, in extending our commercial relations, to have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with them as little political connection as possible. So far as we have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already formed engagements, let them be fulfilled with perfect good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faith. Here let us stop. Europe has a set of primary interests which to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: us have none, or a very remote relation. Hence, she must be engaged in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequent controversies, the causes of which are essentially foreign to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our concerns. Hence, therefore, it must be unwise in us to implicate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ourselves, by artificial ties, in the ordinary vicissitudes of her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics, or the ordinary combinations and collisions of her friendships
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or enmities. Our detached and distant situation invites and enables
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: us to pursue a different course. If we remain one people, under an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efficient government, the period is not far off when we may defy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: material injury from external annoyance; when we may take such an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attitude as will cause the neutrality we may at any time resolve upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be scrupulously respected; when belligerent nations, under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossibility of making acquisitions upon us, will not lightly hazard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the giving us provocation; when we may choose peace or war, as our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest, guided by justice, shall counsel. Why forego the advantages of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so peculiar a situation? Why quit our own to stand upon foreign ground?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Why, by interweaving our destiny with that of any part of Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entangle our peace and prosperity in the toils of European ambition,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rivalship, interest, humor, or caprice? It is our true policy to steer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clear of permanent alliances with any portion of the foreign world;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so far, I mean, as we are now at liberty to do it; for let me not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood as capable of patronizing infidelity to existing engagements.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I hold the maxim no less applicable to public than to private affairs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that honesty is always the best policy. I repeat it; therefore, let
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those engagements be observed in their genuine sense; but in my opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is unnecessary, and would be unwise, to extend them. Taking care
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always to keep ourselves, by suitable establishments, in a respectable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defensive posture, we may safely trust to temporary alliances for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary emergencies." In a previous part of the same letter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Washington makes the following admirable and just remark: "The nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which indulges towards another an habitual hatred or an habitual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fondness is in some degree a slave. It is a slave to its animosity or to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its affection, either of which is sufficient to lead it astray from its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duty and its interest."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The political conduct of Washington was always guided by these maxims.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He succeeded in maintaining his country in a state of peace whilst all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other nations of the globe were at war; and he laid it down as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fundamental doctrine, that the true interest of the Americans consisted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a perfect neutrality with regard to the internal dissensions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European Powers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jefferson went still further, and he introduced a maxim into the policy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union, which affirms that "the Americans ought never to solicit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any privileges from foreign nations, in order not to be obliged to grant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: similar privileges themselves."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These two principles, which were so plain and so just as to be adapted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the capacity of the populace, have greatly simplified the foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: policy of the United States. As the Union takes no part in the affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe, it has, properly speaking, no foreign interests to discuss,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since it has at present no powerful neighbors on the American continent.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The country is as much removed from the passions of the Old World by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position as by the line of policy which it has chosen, and it is neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called upon to repudiate nor to espouse the conflicting interests of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe; whilst the dissensions of the New World are still concealed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within the bosom of the future.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Union is free from all pre-existing obligations, and it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently enabled to profit by the experience of the old nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe, without being obliged, as they are, to make the best of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: past, and to adapt it to their present circumstances; or to accept
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that immense inheritance which they derive from their forefathers--an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inheritance of glory mingled with calamities, and of alliances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conflicting with national antipathies. The foreign policy of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States is reduced by its very nature to await the chances of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future history of the nation, and for the present it consists more in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abstaining from interference than in exerting its activity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is therefore very difficult to ascertain, at present, what degree
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of sagacity the American democracy will display in the conduct of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign policy of the country; and upon this point its adversaries, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well as its advocates, must suspend their judgment. As for myself I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no hesitation in avowing my conviction, that it is most especially in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the conduct of foreign relations that democratic governments appear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me to be decidedly inferior to governments carried on upon different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles. Experience, instruction, and habit may almost always succeed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in creating a species of practical discretion in democracies, and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: science of the daily occurrences of life which is called good sense.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Good sense may suffice to direct the ordinary course of society; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst a people whose education has been provided for, the advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democratic liberty in the internal affairs of the country may more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than compensate for the evils inherent in a democratic government. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such is not always the case in the mutual relations of foreign nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Foreign politics demand scarcely any of those qualities which a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy possesses; and they require, on the contrary, the perfect use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of almost all those faculties in which it is deficient. Democracy is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to the increase of the internal resources of the State; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tends to diffuse a moderate independence; it promotes the growth of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public spirit, and fortifies the respect which is entertained for law in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all classes of society; and these are advantages which only exercise an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indirect influence over the relations which one people bears to another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But a democracy is unable to regulate the details of an important
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertaking, to persevere in a design, and to work out its execution in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the presence of serious obstacles. It cannot combine its measures with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secrecy, and it will not await their consequences with patience. These
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are qualities which more especially belong to an individual or to an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy; and they are precisely the means by which an individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people attains to a predominant position.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If, on the contrary, we observe the natural defects of aristocracy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we shall find that their influence is comparatively innoxious in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direction of the external affairs of a State. The capital fault of which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic bodies may be accused is that they are more apt to contrive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own advantage than that of the mass of the people. In foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics it is rare for the interest of the aristocracy to be in any way
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinct from that of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The propensity which democracies have to obey the impulse of passion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather than the suggestions of prudence, and to abandon a mature design
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the gratification of a momentary caprice, was very clearly seen in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America on the breaking out of the French Revolution. It was then as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evident to the simplest capacity as it is at the present time that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest of the Americans forbade them to take any part in the contest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which was about to deluge Europe with blood, but which could by no means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: injure the welfare of their own country. Nevertheless the sympathies of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people declared themselves with so much violence in behalf of France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that nothing but the inflexible character of Washington, and the immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popularity which he enjoyed, could have prevented the Americans from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declaring war against England. And even then, the exertions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the austere reason of that great man made to repress the generous but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imprudent passions of his fellow-citizens, very nearly deprived him of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sole recompense which he had ever claimed--that of his country's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: love. The majority then reprobated the line of policy which he adopted,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and which has since been unanimously approved by the nation. *s If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution and the favor of the public had not entrusted the direction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the foreign affairs of the country to Washington, it is certain that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American nation would at that time have taken the very measures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it now condemns.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote s: See the fifth volume of Marshall's "Life of Washington." In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a government constituted like that of the United States, he says,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "it is impossible for the chief magistrate, however firm he may be, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppose for any length of time the torrent of popular opinion; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevalent opinion of that day seemed to incline to war. In fact, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the session of Congress held at the time, it was frequently seen that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Washington had lost the majority in the House of Representatives." The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violence of the language used against him in public was extreme, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a political meeting they did not scruple to compare him indirectly to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the treacherous Arnold. "By the opposition," says Marshall, "the friends
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the administration were declared to be an aristocratic and corrupt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faction, who, from a desire to introduce monarchy, were hostile to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France and under the influence of Britain; that they were a paper
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nobility, whose extreme sensibility at every measure which threatened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the funds, induced a tame submission to injuries and insults, which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests and honor of the nation required them to resist."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Almost all the nations which have ever exercised a powerful influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the destinies of the world by conceiving, following up, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executing vast designs--from the Romans to the English--have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed by aristocratic institutions. Nor will this be a subject of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wonder when we recollect that nothing in the world has so absolute a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fixity of purpose as an aristocracy. The mass of the people may be led
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: astray by ignorance or passion; the mind of a king may be biased, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his perseverance in his designs may be shaken--besides which a king is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not immortal--but an aristocratic body is too numerous to be led astray
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the blandishments of intrigue, and yet not numerous enough to yield
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily to the intoxicating influence of unreflecting passion: it has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the energy of a firm and enlightened individual, added to the power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it derives from perpetuity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIV: Advantages American Society Derive From Democracy--Part I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What The Real Advantages Are Which American Society Derives From The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government Of The Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Before I enter upon the subject of the present chapter I am induced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to remind the reader of what I have more than once adverted to in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course of this book. The political institutions of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appear to me to be one of the forms of government which a democracy may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adopt; but I do not regard the American Constitution as the best, or as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the only one, which a democratic people may establish. In showing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages which the Americans derive from the government of democracy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am therefore very far from meaning, or from believing, that similar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages can only be obtained from the same laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General Tendency Of The Laws Under The Rule Of The American Democracy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And Habits Of Those Who Apply Them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Defects of a democratic government easy to be discovered--Its advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only to be discerned by long observation--Democracy in America often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inexpert, but the general tendency of the laws advantageous--In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American democracy public officers have no permanent interests distinct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from those of the majority--Result of this state of things.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The defects and the weaknesses of a democratic government may very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily be discovered; they are demonstrated by the most flagrant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instances, whilst its beneficial influence is less perceptibly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercised. A single glance suffices to detect its evil consequences, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its good qualities can only be discerned by long observation. The laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the American democracy are frequently defective or incomplete; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes attack vested rights, or give a sanction to others which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous to the community; but even if they were good, the frequent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changes which they undergo would be an evil. How comes it, then, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American republics prosper and maintain their position?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the consideration of laws a distinction must be carefully observed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the end at which they aim and the means by which they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directed to that end, between their absolute and their relative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excellence. If it be the intention of the legislator to favor the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests of the minority at the expense of the majority, and if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures he takes are so combined as to accomplish the object he has in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: view with the least possible expense of time and exertion, the law may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be well drawn up, although its purpose be bad; and the more efficacious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is, the greater is the mischief which it causes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic laws generally tend to promote the welfare of the greatest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possible number; for they emanate from the majority of the citizens, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are subject to error, but who cannot have an interest opposed to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own advantage. The laws of an aristocracy tend, on the contrary, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concentrate wealth and power in the hands of the minority, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an aristocracy, by its very nature, constitutes a minority. It may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore be asserted, as a general proposition, that the purpose of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democracy in the conduct of its legislation is useful to a greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of citizens than that of an aristocracy. This is, however, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sum total of its advantages.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Aristocracies are infinitely more expert in the science of legislation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than democracies ever can be. They are possessed of a self-control which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protects them from the errors of temporary excitement, and they form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lasting designs which they mature with the assistance of favorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opportunities. Aristocratic government proceeds with the dexterity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: art; it understands how to make the collective force of all its laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: converge at the same time to a given point. Such is not the case with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies, whose laws are almost always ineffective or inopportune.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The means of democracy are therefore more imperfect than those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy, and the measures which it unwittingly adopts are frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposed to its own cause; but the object it has in view is more useful.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Let us now imagine a community so organized by nature, or by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution, that it can support the transitory action of bad laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that it can await, without destruction, the general tendency of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legislation: we shall then be able to conceive that a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, notwithstanding its defects, will be most fitted to conduce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the prosperity of this community. This is precisely what has occurred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States; and I repeat, what I have before remarked, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great advantage of the Americans consists in their being able to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commit faults which they may afterward repair.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An analogous observation may be made respecting public officers. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is easy to perceive that the American democracy frequently errs in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the choice of the individuals to whom it entrusts the power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration; but it is more difficult to say why the State prospers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under their rule. In the first place it is to be remarked, that if in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic State the governors have less honesty and less capacity than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere, the governed, on the other hand, are more enlightened and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more attentive to their interests. As the people in democracies is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incessantly vigilant in its affairs and more jealous of its rights,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it prevents its representatives from abandoning that general line of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conduct which its own interest prescribes. In the second place, it must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be remembered that if the democratic magistrate is more apt to misuse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his power, he possesses it for a shorter period of time. But there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet another reason which is still more general and conclusive. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no doubt of importance to the welfare of nations that they should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed by men of talents and virtue; but it is perhaps still more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important that the interests of those men should not differ from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests of the community at large; for, if such were the case, virtues
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a high order might become useless, and talents might be turned to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a bad account. I say that it is important that the interests of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons in authority should not conflict with or oppose the interests of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community at large; but I do not insist upon their having the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests as the whole population, because I am not aware that such a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of things ever existed in any country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No political form has hitherto been discovered which is equally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to the prosperity and the development of all the classes into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which society is divided. These classes continue to form, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a certain number of distinct nations in the same nation; and experience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has shown that it is no less dangerous to place the fate of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes exclusively in the hands of any one of them than it is to make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one people the arbiter of the destiny of another. When the rich alone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: govern, the interest of the poor is always endangered; and when the poor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make the laws, that of the rich incurs very serious risks. The advantage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democracy does not consist, therefore, as has sometimes been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
