text: asserted, in favoring the prosperity of all, but simply in contributing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the well-being of the greatest possible number.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The men who are entrusted with the direction of public affairs in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States are frequently inferior, both in point of capacity and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: morality, to those whom aristocratic institutions would raise to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. But their interest is identified and confounded with that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority of their fellow-citizens. They may frequently be faithless and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently mistaken, but they will never systematically adopt a line of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conduct opposed to the will of the majority; and it is impossible that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they should give a dangerous or an exclusive tendency to the government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The mal-administration of a democratic magistrate is a mere isolated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact, which only occurs during the short period for which he is elected.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Corruption and incapacity do not act as common interests, which may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connect men permanently with one another. A corrupt or an incapable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrate will not concert his measures with another magistrate, simply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because that individual is as corrupt and as incapable as himself; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these two men will never unite their endeavors to promote the corruption
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and inaptitude of their remote posterity. The ambition and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manoeuvres of the one will serve, on the contrary, to unmask the other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The vices of a magistrate, in democratic states, are usually peculiar to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his own person.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But under aristocratic governments public men are swayed by the interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their order, which, if it is sometimes confounded with the interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the majority, is very frequently distinct from them. This interest is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the common and lasting bond which unites them together; it induces them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to coalesce, and to combine their efforts in order to attain an end
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which does not always ensure the greatest happiness of the greatest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number; and it serves not only to connect the persons in authority,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but to unite them to a considerable portion of the community, since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a numerous body of citizens belongs to the aristocracy, without being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invested with official functions. The aristocratic magistrate is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore constantly supported by a portion of the community, as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Government of which he is a member.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The common purpose which connects the interest of the magistrates in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies with that of a portion of their contemporaries identifies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it with that of future generations; their influence belongs to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future as much as to the present. The aristocratic magistrate is urged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the same time toward the same point by the passions of the community,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by his own, and I may almost add by those of his posterity. Is it, then,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wonderful that he does not resist such repeated impulses? And indeed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies are often carried away by the spirit of their order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without being corrupted by it; and they unconsciously fashion society to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own ends, and prepare it for their own descendants.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The English aristocracy is perhaps the most liberal which ever existed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and no body of men has ever, uninterruptedly, furnished so many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honorable and enlightened individuals to the government of a country. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot, however, escape observation that in the legislation of England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the good of the poor has been sacrificed to the advantage of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich, and the rights of the majority to the privileges of the few. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence is, that England, at the present day, combines the extremes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of fortune in the bosom of her society, and her perils and calamities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are almost equal to her power and her renown. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: [The legislation of England for the forty years is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certainly not fairly open to this criticism, which was written before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Reform Bill of 1832, and accordingly Great Britain has thus far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: escaped and surmounted the perils and calamities to which she seemed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be exposed.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, where the public officers have no interests to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promote connected with their caste, the general and constant influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Government is beneficial, although the individuals who conduct it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are frequently unskilful and sometimes contemptible. There is indeed a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secret tendency in democratic institutions to render the exertions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the citizens subservient to the prosperity of the community,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding their private vices and mistakes; whilst in aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions there is a secret propensity which, notwithstanding the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talents and the virtues of those who conduct the government, leads them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to contribute to the evils which oppress their fellow-creatures. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic governments public men may frequently do injuries which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they do not intend, and in democratic states they produce advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they never thought of.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Public Spirit In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Patriotism of instinct--Patriotism of reflection--Their different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics--Nations ought to strive to acquire the second when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first has disappeared--Efforts of the Americans to it--Interest of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual intimately connected with that of the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is one sort of patriotic attachment which principally arises from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that instinctive, disinterested, and undefinable feeling which connects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the affections of man with his birthplace. This natural fondness is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: united to a taste for ancient customs, and to a reverence for ancestral
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traditions of the past; those who cherish it love their country as they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: love the mansions of their fathers. They enjoy the tranquillity which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it affords them; they cling to the peaceful habits which they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contracted within its bosom; they are attached to the reminiscences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it awakens, and they are even pleased by the state of obedience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in which they are placed. This patriotism is sometimes stimulated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by religious enthusiasm, and then it is capable of making the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prodigious efforts. It is in itself a kind of religion; it does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason, but it acts from the impulse of faith and of sentiment. By
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some nations the monarch has been regarded as a personification of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country; and the fervor of patriotism being converted into the fervor of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: loyalty, they took a sympathetic pride in his conquests, and gloried in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his power. At one time, under the ancient monarchy, the French felt a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sort of satisfaction in the sense of their dependence upon the arbitrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasure of their king, and they were wont to say with pride, "We are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the subjects of the most powerful king in the world."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But, like all instinctive passions, this kind of patriotism is more apt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to prompt transient exertion than to supply the motives of continuous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavor. It may save the State in critical circumstances, but it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not unfrequently allow the nation to decline in the midst of peace.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whilst the manners of a people are simple and its faith unshaken, whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society is steadily based upon traditional institutions whose legitimacy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has never been contested, this instinctive patriotism is wont to endure.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But there is another species of attachment to a country which is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rational than the one we have been describing. It is perhaps less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generous and less ardent, but it is more fruitful and more lasting; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is coeval with the spread of knowledge, it is nurtured by the laws, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grows by the exercise of civil rights, and, in the end, it is confounded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the personal interest of the citizen. A man comprehends the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence which the prosperity of his country has upon his own welfare;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he is aware that the laws authorize him to contribute his assistance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to that prosperity, and he labors to promote it as a portion of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest in the first place, and as a portion of his right in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: second.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But epochs sometimes occur, in the course of the existence of a nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at which the ancient customs of a people are changed, public morality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destroyed, religious belief disturbed, and the spell of tradition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: broken, whilst the diffusion of knowledge is yet imperfect, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil rights of the community are ill secured, or confined within very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: narrow limits. The country then assumes a dim and dubious shape in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eyes of the citizens; they no longer behold it in the soil which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabit, for that soil is to them a dull inanimate clod; nor in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usages of their forefathers, which they have been taught to look upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a debasing yoke; nor in religion, for of that they doubt; nor in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws, which do not originate in their own authority; nor in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator, whom they fear and despise. The country is lost to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: senses, they can neither discover it under its own nor under borrowed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: features, and they entrench themselves within the dull precincts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a narrow egotism. They are emancipated from prejudice without having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledged the empire of reason; they are neither animated by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instinctive patriotism of monarchical subjects nor by the thinking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patriotism of republican citizens; but they have stopped halfway between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the two, in the midst of confusion and of distress.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In this predicament, to retreat is impossible; for a people cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restore the vivacity of its earlier times, any more than a man can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: return to the innocence and the bloom of childhood; such things may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be regretted, but they cannot be renewed. The only thing, then, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains to be done is to proceed, and to accelerate the union of private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with public interests, since the period of disinterested patriotism is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gone by forever.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am certainly very far from averring that, in order to obtain this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: result, the exercise of political rights should be immediately granted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to all the members of the community. But I maintain that the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful, and perhaps the only, means of interesting men in the welfare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their country which we still possess is to make them partakers in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government. At the present time civic zeal seems to me to be inseparable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the exercise of political rights; and I hold that the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens will be found to augment or to decrease in Europe in proportion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as those rights are extended.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the inhabitants were thrown but as yesterday upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the soil which they now occupy, and they brought neither customs nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traditions with them there; they meet each other for the first time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with no previous acquaintance; in short, the instinctive love of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country can scarcely exist in their minds; but everyone takes as zealous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an interest in the affairs of his township, his county, and of the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State, as if they were his own, because everyone, in his sphere, takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an active part in the government of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The lower orders in the United States are alive to the perception of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence exercised by the general prosperity upon their own welfare;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and simple as this observation is, it is one which is but too rarely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made by the people. But in America the people regards this prosperity as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the result of its own exertions; the citizen looks upon the fortune of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the public as his private interest, and he co-operates in its success,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not so much from a sense of pride or of duty, as from what I shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: venture to term cupidity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is unnecessary to study the institutions and the history of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans in order to discover the truth of this remark, for their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners render it sufficiently evident. As the American participates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all that is done in his country, he thinks himself obliged to defend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever may be censured; for it is not only his country which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attacked upon these occasions, but it is himself. The consequence is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that his national pride resorts to a thousand artifices, and to all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: petty tricks of individual vanity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing is more embarrassing in the ordinary intercourse of life than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this irritable patriotism of the Americans. A stranger may be very well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclined to praise many of the institutions of their country, but he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: begs permission to blame some of the peculiarities which he observes--a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permission which is, however, inexorably refused. America is therefore a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free country, in which, lest anybody should be hurt by your remarks, you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not allowed to speak freely of private individuals, or of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State, of the citizens or of the authorities, of public or of private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings, or, in short, of anything at all, except it be of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: climate and the soil; and even then Americans will be found ready to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defend either the one or the other, as if they had been contrived by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In our times option must be made between the patriotism of all and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government of a few; for the force and activity which the first confers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are irreconcilable with the guarantees of tranquillity which the second
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: furnishes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Notion Of Rights In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No great people without a notion of rights--How the notion of rights can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be given to people--Respect of rights in the United States--Whence it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arises.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: After the idea of virtue, I know no higher principle than that of right;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or, to speak more accurately, these two ideas are commingled in one.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The idea of right is simply that of virtue introduced into the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world. It is the idea of right which enabled men to define anarchy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tyranny; and which taught them to remain independent without arrogance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as well as to obey without servility. The man who submits to violence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is debased by his compliance; but when he obeys the mandate of one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who possesses that right of authority which he acknowledges in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-creature, he rises in some measure above the person who delivers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the command. There are no great men without virtue, and there are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no great nations--it may almost be added that there would be no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society--without the notion of rights; for what is the condition of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mass of rational and intelligent beings who are only united together by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bond of force?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am persuaded that the only means which we possess at the present time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of inculcating the notion of rights, and of rendering it, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: palpable to the senses, is to invest all the members of the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the peaceful exercise of certain rights: this is very clearly seen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in children, who are men without the strength and the experience of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manhood. When a child begins to move in the midst of the objects which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surround him, he is instinctively led to turn everything which he can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lay his hands upon to his own purposes; he has no notion of the property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of others; but as he gradually learns the value of things, and begins
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to perceive that he may in his turn be deprived of his possessions, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes more circumspect, and he observes those rights in others which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he wishes to have respected in himself. The principle which the child
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derives from the possession of his toys is taught to the man by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects which he may call his own. In America those complaints against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property in general which are so frequent in Europe are never heard,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because in America there are no paupers; and as everyone has property of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his own to defend, everyone recognizes the principle upon which he holds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same thing occurs in the political world. In America the lowest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes have conceived a very high notion of political rights, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they exercise those rights; and they refrain from attacking those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other people, in order to ensure their own from attack. Whilst in Europe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same classes sometimes recalcitrate even against the supreme power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American submits without a murmur to the authority of the pettiest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrate.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This truth is exemplified by the most trivial details of national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiarities. In France very few pleasures are exclusively reserved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the higher classes; the poor are admitted wherever the rich are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: received, and they consequently behave with propriety, and respect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever contributes to the enjoyments in which they themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: participate. In England, where wealth has a monopoly of amusement as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well as of power, complaints are made that whenever the poor happen to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: steal into the enclosures which are reserved for the pleasures of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich, they commit acts of wanton mischief: can this be wondered at,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since care has been taken that they should have nothing to lose? *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: [This, too, has been amended by much larger provisions for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the amusements of the people in public parks, gardens, museums, etc.;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the conduct of the people in these places of amusement has improved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the same proportion.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The government of democracy brings the notion of political rights to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the level of the humblest citizens, just as the dissemination of wealth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brings the notion of property within the reach of all the members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community; and I confess that, to my mind, this is one of its greatest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages. I do not assert that it is easy to teach men to exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political rights; but I maintain that, when it is possible, the effects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which result from it are highly important; and I add that, if there ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was a time at which such an attempt ought to be made, that time is our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own. It is clear that the influence of religious belief is shaken, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the notion of divine rights is declining; it is evident that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public morality is vitiated, and the notion of moral rights is also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disappearing: these are general symptoms of the substitution of argument
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for faith, and of calculation for the impulses of sentiment. If, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: midst of this general disruption, you do not succeed in connecting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the notion of rights with that of personal interest, which is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only immutable point in the human heart, what means will you have of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governing the world except by fear? When I am told that, since the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are weak and the populace is wild, since passions are excited and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of virtue is paralyzed, no measures must be taken to increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rights of the democracy, I reply, that it is for these very reasons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that some measures of the kind must be taken; and I am persuaded that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments are still more interested in taking them than society at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large, because governments are liable to be destroyed and society cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perish.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am not, however, inclined to exaggerate the example which America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: furnishes. In those States the people are invested with political rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at a time when they could scarcely be abused, for the citizens were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: few in number and simple in their manners. As they have increased, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans have not augmented the power of the democracy, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have, if I may use the expression, extended its dominions. It cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be doubted that the moment at which political rights are granted to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people that had before been without them is a very critical, though it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be a necessary one. A child may kill before he is aware of the value
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of life; and he may deprive another person of his property before he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aware that his own may be taken away from him. The lower orders, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first they are invested with political rights, stand, in relation to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those rights, in the same position as the child does to the whole of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature, and the celebrated adage may then be applied to them, Homo puer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: robustus. This truth may even be perceived in America. The States in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the citizens have enjoyed their rights longest are those in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they make the best use of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It cannot be repeated too often that nothing is more fertile in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prodigies than the art of being free; but there is nothing more arduous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the apprenticeship of liberty. Such is not the case with despotic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions: despotism often promises to make amends for a thousand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: previous ills; it supports the right, it protects the oppressed, and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintains public order. The nation is lulled by the temporary prosperity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which accrues to it, until it is roused to a sense of its own misery.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Liberty, on the contrary, is generally established in the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agitation, it is perfected by civil discord, and its benefits cannot be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appreciated until it is already old.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIV: Advantages American Society Derive From Democracy--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Respect For The Law In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Respect of the Americans for the law--Parental affection which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertain for it--Personal interest of everyone to increase the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the law.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not always feasible to consult the whole people, either directly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or indirectly, in the formation of the law; but it cannot be denied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, when such a measure is possible the authority of the law is very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much augmented. This popular origin, which impairs the excellence and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the wisdom of legislation, contributes prodigiously to increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its power. There is an amazing strength in the expression of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determination of a whole people, and when it declares itself the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination of those who are most inclined to contest it is overawed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its authority. The truth of this fact is very well known by parties, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they consequently strive to make out a majority whenever they can. If
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have not the greater number of voters on their side, they assert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the true majority abstained from voting; and if they are foiled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even there, they have recourse to the body of those persons who had no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: votes to give.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, except slaves, servants, and paupers in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: receipt of relief from the townships, there is no class of persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who do not exercise the elective franchise, and who do not indirectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contribute to make the laws. Those who design to attack the laws must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently either modify the opinion of the nation or trample upon its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decision.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A second reason, which is still more weighty, may be further adduced;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States everyone is personally interested in enforcing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience of the whole community to the law; for as the minority may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shortly rally the majority to its principles, it is interested in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: professing that respect for the decrees of the legislator which it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soon have occasion to claim for its own. However irksome an enactment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be, the citizen of the United States complies with it, not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because it is the work of the majority, but because it originates in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own authority, and he regards it as a contract to which he is himself a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: party.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, then, that numerous and turbulent multitude does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not exist which always looks upon the law as its natural enemy, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accordingly surveys it with fear and with fear and with distrust. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible, on the other hand, not to perceive that all classes display
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the utmost reliance upon the legislation of their country, and that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are attached to it by a kind of parental affection.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am wrong, however, in saying all classes; for as in America the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European scale of authority is inverted, the wealthy are there placed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a position analogous to that of the poor in the Old World, and it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the opulent classes which frequently look upon the law with suspicion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already observed that the advantage of democracy is not, as has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been sometimes asserted, that it protects the interests of the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, but simply that it protects those of the majority. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States, where the poor rule, the rich have always some reason to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dread the abuses of their power. This natural anxiety of the rich may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produce a sullen dissatisfaction, but society is not disturbed by it;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the same reason which induces the rich to withhold their confidence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the legislative authority makes them obey its mandates; their wealth,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which prevents them from making the law, prevents them from withstanding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. Amongst civilized nations revolts are rarely excited, except by such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons as have nothing to lose by them; and if the laws of a democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not always worthy of respect, at least they always obtain it; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who usually infringe the laws have no excuse for not complying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the enactments they have themselves made, and by which they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves benefited, whilst the citizens whose interests might be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promoted by the infraction of them are induced, by their character and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their stations, to submit to the decisions of the legislature, whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they may be. Besides which, the people in America obeys the law not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only because it emanates from the popular authority, but because that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority may modify it in any points which may prove vexatory; a law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is observed because it is a self-imposed evil in the first place, and an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evil of transient duration in the second.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Activity Which Pervades All The Branches Of The Body Politic In The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States; Influence Which It Exercises Upon Society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: More difficult to conceive the political activity which pervades the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States than the freedom and equality which reign there--The great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: activity which perpetually agitates the legislative bodies is only an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: episode to the general activity--Difficult for an American to confine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself to his own business--Political agitation extends to all social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intercourse--Commercial activity of the Americans partly attributable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this cause--Indirect advantages which society derives from a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On passing from a country in which free institutions are established to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one where they do not exist, the traveller is struck by the change; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the former all is bustle and activity, in the latter everything is calm
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and motionless. In the one, amelioration and progress are the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: topics of inquiry; in the other, it seems as if the community only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aspired to repose in the enjoyment of the advantages which it has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquired. Nevertheless, the country which exerts itself so strenuously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to promote its welfare is generally more wealthy and more prosperous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than that which appears to be so contented with its lot; and when we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compare them together, we can scarcely conceive how so many new wants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are daily felt in the former, whilst so few seem to occur in the latter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If this remark is applicable to those free countries in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchical and aristocratic institutions subsist, it is still more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: striking with regard to democratic republics. In these States it is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only a portion of the people which is busied with the amelioration of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its social condition, but the whole community is engaged in the task;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it is not the exigencies and the convenience of a single class for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which a provision is to be made, but the exigencies and the convenience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all ranks of life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not impossible to conceive the surpassing liberty which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans enjoy; some idea may likewise be formed of the extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality which subsists amongst them, but the political activity which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pervades the United States must be seen in order to be understood. No
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sooner do you set foot upon the American soil than you are stunned by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind of tumult; a confused clamor is heard on every side; and a thousand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simultaneous voices demand the immediate satisfaction of their social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants. Everything is in motion around you; here, the people of one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quarter of a town are met to decide upon the building of a church;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there, the election of a representative is going on; a little further
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the delegates of a district are posting to the town in order to consult
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon some local improvements; or in another place the laborers of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: village quit their ploughs to deliberate upon the project of a road or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a public school. Meetings are called for the sole purpose of declaring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their disapprobation of the line of conduct pursued by the Government;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst in other assemblies the citizens salute the authorities of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day as the fathers of their country. Societies are formed which regard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: drunkenness as the principal cause of the evils under which the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labors, and which solemnly bind themselves to give a constant example of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temperance. *c
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: At the time of my stay in the United States the temperance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: societies already consisted of more than 270,000 members, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effect had been to diminish the consumption of fermented liquors by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 500,000 gallons per annum in the State of Pennsylvania alone.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great political agitation of the American legislative bodies, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the only kind of excitement that attracts the attention of foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries, is a mere episode or a sort of continuation of that universal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: movement which originates in the lowest classes of the people and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extends successively to all the ranks of society. It is impossible to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spend more efforts in the pursuit of enjoyment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The cares of political life engross a most prominent place in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occupation of a citizen in the United States, and almost the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasure of which an American has any idea is to take a part in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government, and to discuss the part he has taken. This feeling pervades
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most trifling habits of life; even the women frequently attend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public meetings and listen to political harangues as a recreation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after their household labors. Debating clubs are to a certain extent a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: substitute for theatrical entertainments: an American cannot converse,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but he can discuss; and when he attempts to talk he falls into a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dissertation. He speaks to you as if he was addressing a meeting; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if he should chance to warm in the course of the discussion, he will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infallibly say, "Gentlemen," to the person with whom he is conversing.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In some countries the inhabitants display a certain repugnance to avail
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves of the political privileges with which the law invests them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it would seem that they set too high a value upon their time to spend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it on the interests of the community; and they prefer to withdraw within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the exact limits of a wholesome egotism, marked out by four sunk fences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and a quickset hedge. But if an American were condemned to confine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his activity to his own affairs, he would be robbed of one half of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his existence; he would feel an immense void in the life which he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustomed to lead, and his wretchedness would be unbearable. *d I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persuaded that, if ever a despotic government is established in America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it will find it more difficult to surmount the habits which free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions have engendered than to conquer the attachment of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens to freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: The same remark was made at Rome under the first Caesars.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Montesquieu somewhere alludes to the excessive despondency of certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Roman citizens who, after the excitement of political life, were all at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once flung back into the stagnation of private life.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This ceaseless agitation which democratic government has introduced into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the political world influences all social intercourse. I am not sure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that upon the whole this is not the greatest advantage of democracy. And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am much less inclined to applaud it for what it does than for what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it causes to be done. It is incontestable that the people frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conducts public business very ill; but it is impossible that the lower
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orders should take a part in public business without extending the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circle of their ideas, and without quitting the ordinary routine of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their mental acquirements. The humblest individual who is called upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to co-operate in the government of society acquires a certain degree of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self-respect; and as he possesses authority, he can command the services
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of minds much more enlightened than his own. He is canvassed by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of applicants, who seek to deceive him in a thousand different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ways, but who instruct him by their deceit. He takes a part in political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings which did not originate in his own conception, but which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: give him a taste for undertakings of the kind. New ameliorations are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: daily pointed out in the property which he holds in common with others,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and this gives him the desire of improving that property which is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiarly his own. He is perhaps neither happier nor better than those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who came before him, but he is better informed and more active. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no doubt that the democratic institutions of the United States, joined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the physical constitution of the country, are the cause (not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the direct, as is so often asserted, but the indirect cause) of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prodigious commercial activity of the inhabitants. It is not engendered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the laws, but the people learns how to promote it by the experience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derived from legislation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the opponents of democracy assert that a single individual performs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the duties which he undertakes much better than the government of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community, it appears to me that they are perfectly right. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government of an individual, supposing an equality of instruction on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either side, is more consistent, more persevering, and more accurate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than that of a multitude, and it is much better qualified judiciously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to discriminate the characters of the men it employs. If any deny what I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advance, they have certainly never seen a democratic government, or have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed their opinion upon very partial evidence. It is true that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even when local circumstances and the disposition of the people allow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic institutions to subsist, they never display a regular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and methodical system of government. Democratic liberty is far from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accomplishing all the projects it undertakes, with the skill of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adroit despotism. It frequently abandons them before they have borne
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their fruits, or risks them when the consequences may prove dangerous;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but in the end it produces more than any absolute government, and if it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do fewer things well, it does a greater number of things. Under its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sway the transactions of the public administration are not nearly so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important as what is done by private exertion. Democracy does not confer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most skilful kind of government upon the people, but it produces
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that which the most skilful governments are frequently unable to awaken,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: namely, an all-pervading and restless activity, a superabundant force,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and an energy which is inseparable from it, and which may, under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable circumstances, beget the most amazing benefits. These are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true advantages of democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the present age, when the destinies of Christendom seem to be in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suspense, some hasten to assail democracy as its foe whilst it is yet in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its early growth; and others are ready with their vows of adoration for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this new deity which is springing forth from chaos: but both parties are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very imperfectly acquainted with the object of their hatred or of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires; they strike in the dark, and distribute their blows by mere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We must first understand what the purport of society and the aim of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government is held to be. If it be your intention to confer a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elevation upon the human mind, and to teach it to regard the things of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this world with generous feelings, to inspire men with a scorn of mere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temporal advantage, to give birth to living convictions, and to keep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alive the spirit of honorable devotedness; if you hold it to be a good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing to refine the habits, to embellish the manners, to cultivate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arts of a nation, and to promote the love of poetry, of beauty, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: renown; if you would constitute a people not unfitted to act with power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon all other nations, nor unprepared for those high enterprises which,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever be the result of its efforts, will leave a name forever famous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in time--if you believe such to be the principal object of society, you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must avoid the government of democracy, which would be a very uncertain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guide to the end you have in view.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But if you hold it to be expedient to divert the moral and intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: activity of man to the production of comfort, and to the acquirement of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the necessaries of life; if a clear understanding be more profitable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to man than genius; if your object be not to stimulate the virtues of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heroism, but to create habits of peace; if you had rather witness vices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than crimes and are content to meet with fewer noble deeds, provided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offences be diminished in the same proportion; if, instead of living
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of a brilliant state of society, you are contented to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have prosperity around you; if, in short, you are of opinion that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal object of a Government is not to confer the greatest possible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: share of power and of glory upon the body of the nation, but to ensure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the greatest degree of enjoyment and the least degree of misery to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the individuals who compose it--if such be your desires, you can have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no surer means of satisfying them than by equalizing the conditions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, and establishing democratic institutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But if the time be passed at which such a choice was possible, and if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some superhuman power impel us towards one or the other of these two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments without consulting our wishes, let us at least endeavor to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make the best of that which is allotted to us; and let us so inquire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into its good and its evil propensities as to be able to foster the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former and repress the latter to the utmost.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XV: Unlimited Power Of Majority, And Its Consequences--Part I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Natural strength of the majority in democracies--Most of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitutions have increased this strength by artificial means--How this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has been done--Pledged delegates--Moral power of the majority--Opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to its infallibility--Respect for its rights, how augmented in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Unlimited Power Of The Majority In The United States, And Its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Consequences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The very essence of democratic government consists in the absolute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereignty of the majority; for there is nothing in democratic States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is capable of resisting it. Most of the American Constitutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have sought to increase this natural strength of the majority by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: artificial means. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: We observed, in examining the Federal Constitution, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the efforts of the legislators of the Union had been diametrically
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposed to the present tendency. The consequence has been that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Government is more independent in its sphere than that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. But the Federal Government scarcely ever interferes in any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but external affairs; and the governments of the State are in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments of the States are in reality the authorities which direct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society in America.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The legislature is, of all political institutions, the one which is most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easily swayed by the wishes of the majority. The Americans determined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the members of the legislature should be elected by the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediately, and for a very brief term, in order to subject them, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only to the general convictions, but even to the daily passion, of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constituents. The members of both houses are taken from the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class in society, and are nominated in the same manner; so that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: modifications of the legislative bodies are almost as rapid and quite as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible as those of a single assembly. It is to a legislature thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constituted that almost all the authority of the government has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entrusted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But whilst the law increased the strength of those authorities which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of themselves were strong, it enfeebled more and more those which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally weak. It deprived the representatives of the executive of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stability and independence, and by subjecting them completely to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: caprices of the legislature, it robbed them of the slender influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the nature of a democratic government might have allowed them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retain. In several States the judicial power was also submitted to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elective discretion of the majority, and in all of them its existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was made to depend on the pleasure of the legislative authority, since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the representatives were empowered annually to regulate the stipend of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the judges.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Custom, however, has done even more than law. A proceeding which will in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the end set all the guarantees of representative government at naught
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is becoming more and more general in the United States; it frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happens that the electors, who choose a delegate, point out a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: line of conduct to him, and impose upon him a certain number of positive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obligations which he is pledged to fulfil. With the exception of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tumult, this comes to the same thing as if the majority of the populace
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: held its deliberations in the market-place.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Several other circumstances concur in rendering the power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority in America not only preponderant, but irresistible. The moral
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the majority is partly based upon the notion that there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is more intelligence and more wisdom in a great number of men collected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together than in a single individual, and that the quantity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislators is more important than their quality. The theory of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is in fact applied to the intellect of man: and human pride is thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assailed in its last retreat by a doctrine which the minority hesitate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to admit, and in which they very slowly concur. Like all other powers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and perhaps more than all other powers, the authority of the many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: requires the sanction of time; at first it enforces obedience by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constraint, but its laws are not respected until they have long been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintained.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The right of governing society, which the majority supposes itself to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derive from its superior intelligence, was introduced into the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States by the first settlers, and this idea, which would be sufficient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of itself to create a free nation, has now been amalgamated with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners of the people and the minor incidents of social intercourse.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The French, under the old monarchy, held it for a maxim (which is still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a fundamental principle of the English Constitution) that the King
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could do no wrong; and if he did do wrong, the blame was imputed to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advisers. This notion was highly favorable to habits of obedience, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it enabled the subject to complain of the law without ceasing to love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and honor the lawgiver. The Americans entertain the same opinion with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect to the majority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The moral power of the majority is founded upon yet another principle,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is, that the interests of the many are to be preferred to those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the few. It will readily be perceived that the respect here professed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the rights of the majority must naturally increase or diminish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: according to the state of parties. When a nation is divided into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several irreconcilable factions, the privilege of the majority is often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overlooked, because it is intolerable to comply with its demands.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If there existed in America a class of citizens whom the legislating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority sought to deprive of exclusive privileges which they had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed for ages, and to bring down from an elevated station to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: level of the ranks of the multitude, it is probable that the minority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be less ready to comply with its laws. But as the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were colonized by men holding equal rank amongst themselves, there is as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet no natural or permanent source of dissension between the interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its different inhabitants.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are certain communities in which the persons who constitute the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minority can never hope to draw over the majority to their side, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they must then give up the very point which is at issue between them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, an aristocracy can never become a majority whilst it retains its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusive privileges, and it cannot cede its privileges without ceasing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be an aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States political questions cannot be taken up in so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general and absolute a manner, and all parties are willing to recognize
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the right of the majority, because they all hope to turn those rights to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own advantage at some future time. The majority therefore in that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country exercises a prodigious actual authority, and a moral influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is scarcely less preponderant; no obstacles exist which can impede
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or so much as retard its progress, or which can induce it to heed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complaints of those whom it crushes upon its path. This state of things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is fatal in itself and dangerous for the future.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: How The Unlimited Power Of The Majority Increases In America The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Instability Of Legislation And Administration Inherent In Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans increase the mutability of the laws which is inherent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy by changing the legislature every year, and by investing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it with unbounded authority--The same effect is produced upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration--In America social amelioration is conducted more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: energetically but less perseveringly than in Europe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already spoken of the natural defects of democratic institutions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they all of them increase at the exact ratio of the power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority. To begin with the most evident of them all; the mutability
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the laws is an evil inherent in democratic government, because it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural to democracies to raise men to power in very rapid succession.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But this evil is more or less sensible in proportion to the authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the means of action which the legislature possesses.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the authority exercised by the legislative bodies is supreme;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing prevents them from accomplishing their wishes with celerity, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with irresistible power, whilst they are supplied by new representatives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every year. That is to say, the circumstances which contribute most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerfully to democratic instability, and which admit of the free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: application of caprice to every object in the State, are here in full
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: operation. In conformity with this principle, America is, at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day, the country in the world where laws last the shortest time. Almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the American constitutions have been amended within the course of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thirty years: there is therefore not a single American State which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not modified the principles of its legislation in that lapse of time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As for the laws themselves, a single glance upon the archives of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different States of the Union suffices to convince one that in America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the activity of the legislator never slackens. Not that the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy is naturally less stable than any other, but that it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allowed to follow its capricious propensities in the formation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws. *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: The legislative acts promulgated by the State of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts alone, from the year 1780 to the present time, already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fill three stout volumes; and it must not be forgotten that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collection to which I allude was published in 1823, when many old laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which had fallen into disuse were omitted. The State of Massachusetts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is not more populous than a department of France, may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considered as the most stable, the most consistent, and the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sagacious in its undertakings of the whole Union.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The omnipotence of the majority, and the rapid as well as absolute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner in which its decisions are executed in the United States, has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only the effect of rendering the law unstable, but it exercises the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence upon the execution of the law and the conduct of the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration. As the majority is the only power which it is important
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to court, all its projects are taken up with the greatest ardor, but no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sooner is its attention distracted than all this ardor ceases; whilst in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the free States of Europe the administration is at once independent and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secure, so that the projects of the legislature are put into execution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although its immediate attention may be directed to other objects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America certain ameliorations are undertaken with much more zeal and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: activity than elsewhere; in Europe the same ends are promoted by much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less social effort, more continuously applied.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Some years ago several pious individuals undertook to ameliorate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of the prisons. The public was excited by the statements
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they put forward, and the regeneration of criminals became a very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular undertaking. New prisons were built, and for the first time the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idea of reforming as well as of punishing the delinquent formed a part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of prison discipline. But this happy alteration, in which the public had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken so hearty an interest, and which the exertions of the citizens had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistibly accelerated, could not be completed in a moment. Whilst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: new penitentiaries were being erected (and it was the pleasure of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority that they should be terminated with all possible celerity), the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: old prisons existed, which still contained a great number of offenders.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These jails became more unwholesome and more corrupt in proportion as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the new establishments were beautified and improved, forming a contrast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which may readily be understood. The majority was so eagerly employed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in founding the new prisons that those which already existed were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forgotten; and as the general attention was diverted to a novel object,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the care which had hitherto been bestowed upon the others ceased. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: salutary regulations of discipline were first relaxed, and afterwards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: broken; so that in the immediate neighborhood of a prison which bore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: witness to the mild and enlightened spirit of our time, dungeons might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be met with which reminded the visitor of the barbarity of the Middle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ages.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XV: Unlimited Power Of Majority, And Its Consequences--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Tyranny Of The Majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: How the principle of the sovereignty of the people is to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood--Impossibility of conceiving a mixed government--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign power must centre somewhere--Precautions to be taken to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: control its action--These precautions have not been taken in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States--Consequences.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I hold it to be an impious and an execrable maxim that, politically
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speaking, a people has a right to do whatsoever it pleases, and yet I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have asserted that all authority originates in the will of the majority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Am I then, in contradiction with myself?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A general law--which bears the name of Justice--has been made and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sanctioned, not only by a majority of this or that people, but by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a majority of mankind. The rights of every people are consequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confined within the limits of what is just. A nation may be considered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the light of a jury which is empowered to represent society at large,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to apply the great and general law of justice. Ought such a jury,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which represents society, to have more power than the society in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws it applies originate?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When I refuse to obey an unjust law, I do not contest the right which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the majority has of commanding, but I simply appeal from the sovereignty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the people to the sovereignty of mankind. It has been asserted that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a people can never entirely outstep the boundaries of justice and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason in those affairs which are more peculiarly its own, and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently, full power may fearlessly be given to the majority by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it is represented. But this language is that of a slave.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A majority taken collectively may be regarded as a being whose opinions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and most frequently whose interests, are opposed to those of another
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being, which is styled a minority. If it be admitted that a man,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessing absolute power, may misuse that power by wronging his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adversaries, why should a majority not be liable to the same reproach?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men are not apt to change their characters by agglomeration; nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does their patience in the presence of obstacles increase with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consciousness of their strength. *c And for these reasons I can never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: willingly invest any number of my fellow-creatures with that unlimited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority which I should refuse to any one of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: No one will assert that a people cannot forcibly wrong
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another people; but parties may be looked upon as lesser nations within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a greater one, and they are aliens to each other: if, therefore, it be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admitted that a nation can act tyrannically towards another nation, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be denied that a party may do the same towards another party.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not think that it is possible to combine several principles in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same government, so as at the same time to maintain freedom, and really
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
