text: to oppose them to one another. The form of government which is usually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: termed mixed has always appeared to me to be a mere chimera. Accurately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speaking there is no such thing as a mixed government (with the meaning
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usually given to that word), because in all communities some one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of action may be discovered which preponderates over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others. England in the last century, which has been more especially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cited as an example of this form of Government, was in point of fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an essentially aristocratic State, although it comprised very powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elements of democracy; for the laws and customs of the country were such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the aristocracy could not but preponderate in the end, and subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the direction of public affairs to its own will. The error arose from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: too much attention being paid to the actual struggle which was going
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on between the nobles and the people, without considering the probable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: issue of the contest, which was in reality the important point. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a community really has a mixed government, that is to say, when it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equally divided between two adverse principles, it must either pass
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through a revolution or fall into complete dissolution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am therefore of opinion that some one social power must always be made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to predominate over the others; but I think that liberty is endangered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when this power is checked by no obstacles which may retard its course,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and force it to moderate its own vehemence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Unlimited power is in itself a bad and dangerous thing; human beings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not competent to exercise it with discretion, and God alone can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: omnipotent, because His wisdom and His justice are always equal to His
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. But no power upon earth is so worthy of honor for itself, or of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reverential obedience to the rights which it represents, that I would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consent to admit its uncontrolled and all-predominant authority. When I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: see that the right and the means of absolute command are conferred on a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people or upon a king, upon an aristocracy or a democracy, a monarchy or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a republic, I recognize the germ of tyranny, and I journey onward to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: land of more hopeful institutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In my opinion the main evil of the present democratic institutions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States does not arise, as is often asserted in Europe, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their weakness, but from their overpowering strength; and I am not so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much alarmed at the excessive liberty which reigns in that country as at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the very inadequate securities which exist against tyranny.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When an individual or a party is wronged in the United States, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whom can he apply for redress? If to public opinion, public opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitutes the majority; if to the legislature, it represents the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority, and implicitly obeys its injunctions; if to the executive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power, it is appointed by the majority, and remains a passive tool in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its hands; the public troops consist of the majority under arms; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jury is the majority invested with the right of hearing judicial cases;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in certain States even the judges are elected by the majority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: However iniquitous or absurd the evil of which you complain may be, you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must submit to it as well as you can. *d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: A striking instance of the excesses which may be occasioned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the despotism of the majority occurred at Baltimore in the year 1812.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At that time the war was very popular in Baltimore. A journal which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had taken the other side of the question excited the indignation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inhabitants by its opposition. The populace assembled, broke the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: printing-presses, and attacked the houses of the newspaper editors. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: militia was called out, but no one obeyed the call; and the only means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of saving the poor wretches who were threatened by the frenzy of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mob was to throw them into prison as common malefactors. But even this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precaution was ineffectual; the mob collected again during the night,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the magistrates again made a vain attempt to call out the militia, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prison was forced, one of the newspaper editors was killed upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spot, and the others were left for dead; the guilty parties were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquitted by the jury when they were brought to trial.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I said one day to an inhabitant of Pennsylvania, "Be so good as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explain to me how it happens that in a State founded by Quakers, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: celebrated for its toleration, freed blacks are not allowed to exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil rights. They pay the taxes; is it not fair that they should have a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vote?"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "You insult us," replied my informant, "if you imagine that our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislators could have committed so gross an act of injustice and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intolerance."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "What! then the blacks possess the right of voting in this county?"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Without the smallest doubt."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "How comes it, then, that at the polling-booth this morning I did not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceive a single negro in the whole meeting?"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "This is not the fault of the law: the negroes have an undisputed right
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of voting, but they voluntarily abstain from making their appearance."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "A very pretty piece of modesty on their parts!" rejoined I.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Why, the truth is, that they are not disinclined to vote, but they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afraid of being maltreated; in this country the law is sometimes unable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to maintain its authority without the support of the majority. But in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this case the majority entertains very strong prejudices against the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blacks, and the magistrates are unable to protect them in the exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their legal privileges."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "What! then the majority claims the right not only of making the laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but of breaking the laws it has made?"]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If, on the other hand, a legislative power could be so constituted as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to represent the majority without necessarily being the slave of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions; an executive, so as to retain a certain degree of uncontrolled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority; and a judiciary, so as to remain independent of the two other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers; a government would be formed which would still be democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without incurring any risk of tyrannical abuse.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not say that tyrannical abuses frequently occur in America at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present day, but I maintain that no sure barrier is established against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them, and that the causes which mitigate the government are to be found
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the circumstances and the manners of the country more than in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Effects Of The Unlimited Power Of The Majority Upon The Arbitrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Authority Of The American Public Officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Liberty left by the American laws to public officers within a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere--Their power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A distinction must be drawn between tyranny and arbitrary power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Tyranny may be exercised by means of the law, and in that case it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not arbitrary; arbitrary power may be exercised for the good of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community at large, in which case it is not tyrannical. Tyranny usually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: employs arbitrary means, but, if necessary, it can rule without them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the unbounded power of the majority, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to the legal despotism of the legislature, is likewise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to the arbitrary authority of the magistrate. The majority has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an entire control over the law when it is made and when it is executed;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and as it possesses an equal authority over those who are in power and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community at large, it considers public officers as its passive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agents, and readily confides the task of serving its designs to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vigilance. The details of their office and the privileges which they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to enjoy are rarely defined beforehand; but the majority treats them as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a master does his servants when they are always at work in his sight,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and he has the power of directing or reprimanding them at every instant.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In general the American functionaries are far more independent than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French civil officers within the sphere which is prescribed to them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Sometimes, even, they are allowed by the popular authority to exceed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those bounds; and as they are protected by the opinion, and backed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the co-operation, of the majority, they venture upon such manifestations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their power as astonish a European. By this means habits are formed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the heart of a free country which may some day prove fatal to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Power Exercised By The Majority In America Upon Opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America, when the majority has once irrevocably decided a question,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all discussion ceases--Reason of this--Moral power exercised by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority upon opinion--Democratic republics have deprived despotism of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its physical instruments--Their despotism sways the minds of men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is in the examination of the display of public opinion in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States that we clearly perceive how far the power of the majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surpasses all the powers with which we are acquainted in Europe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Intellectual principles exercise an influence which is so invisible, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often so inappreciable, that they baffle the toils of oppression. At the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present time the most absolute monarchs in Europe are unable to prevent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain notions, which are opposed to their authority, from circulating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in secret throughout their dominions, and even in their courts. Such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not the case in America; as long as the majority is still undecided,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discussion is carried on; but as soon as its decision is irrevocably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pronounced, a submissive silence is observed, and the friends, as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the opponents, of the measure unite in assenting to its propriety.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The reason of this is perfectly clear: no monarch is so absolute as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combine all the powers of society in his own hands, and to conquer all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposition with the energy of a majority which is invested with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of making and of executing the laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The authority of a king is purely physical, and it controls the actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the subject without subduing his private will; but the majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possesses a power which is physical and moral at the same time; it acts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the will as well as upon the actions of men, and it represses not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only all contest, but all controversy. I know no country in which there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is so little true independence of mind and freedom of discussion as in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America. In any constitutional state in Europe every sort of religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and political theory may be advocated and propagated abroad; for there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is no country in Europe so subdued by any single authority as not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contain citizens who are ready to protect the man who raises his voice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the cause of truth from the consequences of his hardihood. If he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unfortunate enough to live under an absolute government, the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is upon his side; if he inhabits a free country, he may find a shelter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: behind the authority of the throne, if he require one. The aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of society supports him in some countries, and the democracy in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others. But in a nation where democratic institutions exist, organized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like those of the United States, there is but one sole authority, one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single element of strength and of success, with nothing beyond it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the majority raises very formidable barriers to the liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of opinion: within these barriers an author may write whatever he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleases, but he will repent it if he ever step beyond them. Not that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is exposed to the terrors of an auto-da-fe, but he is tormented by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the slights and persecutions of daily obloquy. His political career is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: closed forever, since he has offended the only authority which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able to promote his success. Every sort of compensation, even that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of celebrity, is refused to him. Before he published his opinions he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagined that he held them in common with many others; but no sooner has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he declared them openly than he is loudly censured by his overbearing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opponents, whilst those who think without having the courage to speak,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like him, abandon him in silence. He yields at length, oppressed by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: daily efforts he has been making, and he subsides into silence, as if he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was tormented by remorse for having spoken the truth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Fetters and headsmen were the coarse instruments which tyranny formerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: employed; but the civilization of our age has refined the arts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotism which seemed, however, to have been sufficiently perfected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before. The excesses of monarchical power had devised a variety of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: physical means of oppression: the democratic republics of the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day have rendered it as entirely an affair of the mind as that will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it is intended to coerce. Under the absolute sway of an individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despot the body was attacked in order to subdue the soul, and the soul
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: escaped the blows which were directed against it and rose superior to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the attempt; but such is not the course adopted by tyranny in democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republics; there the body is left free, and the soul is enslaved. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign can no longer say, "You shall think as I do on pain of death;"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but he says, "You are free to think differently from me, and to retain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: your life, your property, and all that you possess; but if such be your
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determination, you are henceforth an alien among your people. You may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retain your civil rights, but they will be useless to you, for you will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never be chosen by your fellow-citizens if you solicit their suffrages,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they will affect to scorn you if you solicit their esteem. You will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain among men, but you will be deprived of the rights of mankind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Your fellow-creatures will shun you like an impure being, and those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are most persuaded of your innocence will abandon you too, lest they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be shunned in their turn. Go in peace! I have given you your
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life, but it is an existence in comparably worse than death."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Monarchical institutions have thrown an odium upon despotism; let us
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beware lest democratic republics should restore oppression, and should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: render it less odious and less degrading in the eyes of the many, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: making it still more onerous to the few.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Works have been published in the proudest nations of the Old World
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expressly intended to censure the vices and deride the follies of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: times; Labruyere inhabited the palace of Louis XIV when he composed his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chapter upon the Great, and Moliere criticised the courtiers in the very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pieces which were acted before the Court. But the ruling power in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States is not to be made game of; the smallest reproach irritates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its sensibility, and the slightest joke which has any foundation in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: truth renders it indignant; from the style of its language to the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solid virtues of its character, everything must be made the subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of encomium. No writer, whatever be his eminence, can escape from this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribute of adulation to his fellow-citizens. The majority lives in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetual practice of self-applause, and there are certain truths which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans can only learn from strangers or from experience.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If great writers have not at present existed in America, the reason
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is very simply given in these facts; there can be no literary genius
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without freedom of opinion, and freedom of opinion does not exist in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America. The Inquisition has never been able to prevent a vast number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of anti-religious books from circulating in Spain. The empire of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority succeeds much better in the United States, since it actually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removes the wish of publishing them. Unbelievers are to be met with in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, but, to say the truth, there is no public organ of infidelity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Attempts have been made by some governments to protect the morality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations by prohibiting licentious books. In the United States no one is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: punished for this sort of works, but no one is induced to write them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not because all the citizens are immaculate in their manners, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because the majority of the community is decent and orderly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In these cases the advantages derived from the exercise of this power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are unquestionable, and I am simply discussing the nature of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power itself. This irresistible authority is a constant fact, and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judicious exercise is an accidental occurrence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Effects Of The Tyranny Of The Majority Upon The National Character Of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Effects of the tyranny of the majority more sensibly felt hitherto in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manners than in the conduct of society--They check the development
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of leading characters--Democratic republics organized like the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States bring the practice of courting favor within the reach of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many--Proofs of this spirit in the United States--Why there is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patriotism in the people than in those who govern in its name.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The tendencies which I have just alluded to are as yet very slightly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceptible in political society, but they already begin to exercise an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unfavorable influence upon the national character of the Americans. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am inclined to attribute the singular paucity of distinguished political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characters to the ever-increasing activity of the despotism of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority in the United States. When the American Revolution broke out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they arose in great numbers, for public opinion then served, not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tyrannize over, but to direct the exertions of individuals. Those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: celebrated men took a full part in the general agitation of mind common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at that period, and they attained a high degree of personal fame, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was reflected back upon the nation, but which was by no means borrowed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In absolute governments the great nobles who are nearest to the throne
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flatter the passions of the sovereign, and voluntarily truckle to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his caprices. But the mass of the nation does not degrade itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by servitude: it often submits from weakness, from habit, or from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorance, and sometimes from loyalty. Some nations have been known to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sacrifice their own desires to those of the sovereign with pleasure and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with pride, thus exhibiting a sort of independence in the very act of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submission. These peoples are miserable, but they are not degraded.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is a great difference between doing what one does not approve and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feigning to approve what one does; the one is the necessary case of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weak person, the other befits the temper of a lackey.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In free countries, where everyone is more or less called upon to give
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his opinion in the affairs of state; in democratic republics, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public life is incessantly commingled with domestic affairs, where the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign authority is accessible on every side, and where its attention
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can almost always be attracted by vociferation, more persons are to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be met with who speculate upon its foibles and live at the cost of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions than in absolute monarchies. Not because men are naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: worse in these States than elsewhere, but the temptation is stronger,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of easier access at the same time. The result is a far more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extensive debasement of the characters of citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic republics extend the practice of currying favor with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many, and they introduce it into a greater number of classes at once:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this is one of the most serious reproaches that can be addressed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. In democratic States organized on the principles of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republics, this is more especially the case, where the authority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority is so absolute and so irresistible that a man must give up his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights as a citizen, and almost abjure his quality as a human being, if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: te intends to stray from the track which it lays down.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In that immense crowd which throngs the avenues to power in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States I found very few men who displayed any of that manly candor and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that masculine independence of opinion which frequently distinguished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans in former times, and which constitutes the leading feature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in distinguished characters, wheresoever they may be found. It seems, at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first sight, as if all the minds of the Americans were formed upon one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: model, so accurately do they correspond in their manner of judging. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stranger does, indeed, sometimes meet with Americans who dissent from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these rigorous formularies; with men who deplore the defects of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws, the mutability and the ignorance of democracy; who even go so far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to observe the evil tendencies which impair the national character,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to point out such remedies as it might be possible to apply; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no one is there to hear these things besides yourself, and you, to whom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these secret reflections are confided, are a stranger and a bird of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passage. They are very ready to communicate truths which are useless to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: you, but they continue to hold a different language in public.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If ever these lines are read in America, I am well assured of two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things: in the first place, that all who peruse them will raise their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: voices to condemn me; and in the second place, that very many of them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will acquit me at the bottom of their conscience.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have heard of patriotism in the United States, and it is a virtue
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which may be found among the people, but never among the leaders of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people. This may be explained by analogy; despotism debases the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppressed much more than the oppressor: in absolute monarchies the king
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has often great virtues, but the courtiers are invariably servile. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true that the American courtiers do not say "Sire," or "Your Majesty"--a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinction without a difference. They are forever talking of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural intelligence of the populace they serve; they do not debate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: question as to which of the virtues of their master is pre-eminently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: worthy of admiration, for they assure him that he possesses all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtues under heaven without having acquired them, or without caring to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquire them; they do not give him their daughters and their wives to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be raised at his pleasure to the rank of his concubines, but, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sacrificing their opinions, they prostitute themselves. Moralists and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophers in America are not obliged to conceal their opinions under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the veil of allegory; but, before they venture upon a harsh truth,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they say, "We are aware that the people which we are addressing is too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior to all the weaknesses of human nature to lose the command of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its temper for an instant; and we should not hold this language if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we were not speaking to men whom their virtues and their intelligence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: render more worthy of freedom than all the rest of the world." It would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been impossible for the sycophants of Louis XIV to flatter more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dexterously. For my part, I am persuaded that in all governments,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever their nature may be, servility will cower to force, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adulation will cling to power. The only means of preventing men from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degrading themselves is to invest no one with that unlimited authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is the surest method of debasing them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Greatest Dangers Of The American Republics Proceed From The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Unlimited Power Of The Majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic republics liable to perish from a misuse of their power, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not by impotence--The Governments of the American republics are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more centralized and more energetic than those of the monarchies of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe--Dangers resulting from this--Opinions of Hamilton and Jefferson
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon this point.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Governments usually fall a sacrifice to impotence or to tyranny. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the former case their power escapes from them; it is wrested from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grasp in the latter. Many observers, who have witnessed the anarchy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic States, have imagined that the government of those States was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally weak and impotent. The truth is, that when once hostilities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are begun between parties, the government loses its control over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society. But I do not think that a democratic power is naturally without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: force or without resources: say, rather, that it is almost always by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the abuse of its force and the misemployment of its resources that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic government fails. Anarchy is almost always produced by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tyranny or its mistakes, but not by its want of strength.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is important not to confound stability with force, or the greatness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a thing with its duration. In democratic republics, the power which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directs *e society is not stable; for it often changes hands and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assumes a new direction. But whichever way it turns, its force is almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible. The Governments of the American republics appear to me to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be as much centralized as those of the absolute monarchies of Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more energetic than they are. I do not, therefore, imagine that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will perish from weakness. *f
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: This power may be centred in an assembly, in which case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it will be strong without being stable; or it may be centred in an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual, in which case it will be less strong, but more stable.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: I presume that it is scarcely necessary to remind the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reader here, as well as throughout the remainder of this chapter, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am speaking, not of the Federal Government, but of the several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments of each State, which the majority controls at its pleasure.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If ever the free institutions of America are destroyed, that event may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be attributed to the unlimited authority of the majority, which may at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some future time urge the minorities to desperation, and oblige them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have recourse to physical force. Anarchy will then be the result, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will have been brought about by despotism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mr. Hamilton expresses the same opinion in the "Federalist," No. 51.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "It is of great importance in a republic not only to guard the society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the oppression of its rulers, but to guard one part of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society against the injustice of the other part. Justice is the end of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government. It is the end of civil society. It ever has been, and ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be, pursued until it be obtained, or until liberty be lost in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit. In a society, under the forms of which the stronger faction can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily unite and oppress the weaker, anarchy may as truly be said
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to reign as in a state of nature, where the weaker individual is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secured against the violence of the stronger: and as in the latter state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even the stronger individuals are prompted by the uncertainty of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition to submit to a government which may protect the weak as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as themselves, so in the former state will the more powerful factions be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually induced by a like motive to wish for a government which will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protect all parties, the weaker as well as the more powerful. It can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little doubted that, if the State of Rhode Island was separated from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Confederacy and left to itself, the insecurity of right under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular form of government within such narrow limits would be displayed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by such reiterated oppressions of the factious majorities, that some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power altogether independent of the people would soon be called for by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the voice of the very factions whose misrule had proved the necessity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jefferson has also thus expressed himself in a letter to Madison: *g
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The executive power in our Government is not the only, perhaps not even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principal, object of my solicitude. The tyranny of the Legislature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is really the danger most to be feared, and will continue to be so for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many years to come. The tyranny of the executive power will come in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turn, but at a more distant period." I am glad to cite the opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Jefferson upon this subject rather than that of another, because I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider him to be the most powerful advocate democracy has ever sent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: March 15, 1789.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVI: Causes Mitigating Tyranny In The United States--Part I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter Summary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The national majority does not pretend to conduct all business--Is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to employ the town and county magistrates to execute its supreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decisions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already pointed out the distinction which is to be made between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a centralized government and a centralized administration. The former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exists in America, but the latter is nearly unknown there. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directing power of the American communities had both these instruments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of government at its disposal, and united the habit of executing its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commands to the right of commanding; if, after having established the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general principles of government, it descended to the details of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: business; and if, having regulated the great interests of the country,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it could penetrate into the privacy of individual interests, freedom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would soon be banished from the New World.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in the United States the majority, which so frequently displays the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tastes and the propensities of a despot, is still destitute of the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfect instruments of tyranny. In the American republics the activity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the central Government has never as yet been extended beyond a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limited number of objects sufficiently prominent to call forth its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention. The secondary affairs of society have never been regulated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by its authority, and nothing has hitherto betrayed its desire of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interfering in them. The majority is become more and more absolute, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it has not increased the prerogatives of the central government; those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great prerogatives have been confined to a certain sphere; and although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the despotism of the majority may be galling upon one point, it cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be said to extend to all. However the predominant party in the nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be carried away by its passions, however ardent it may be in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit of its projects, it cannot oblige all the citizens to comply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with its desires in the same manner and at the same time throughout the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country. When the central Government which represents that majority has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: issued a decree, it must entrust the execution of its will to agents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over whom it frequently has no control, and whom it cannot perpetually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direct. The townships, municipal bodies, and counties may therefore be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: looked upon as concealed break-waters, which check or part the tide of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular excitement. If an oppressive law were passed, the liberties of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people would still be protected by the means by which that law would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be put in execution: the majority cannot descend to the details and (as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I will venture to style them) the puerilities of administrative tyranny.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nor does the people entertain that full consciousness of its authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which would prompt it to interfere in these matters; it knows the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent of its natural powers, but it is unacquainted with the increased
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources which the art of government might furnish.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This point deserves attention, for if a democratic republic similar to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of the United States were ever founded in a country where the power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a single individual had previously subsisted, and the effects of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralized administration had sunk deep into the habits and the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the people, I do not hesitate to assert, that in that country a more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insufferable despotism would prevail than any which now exists in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchical States of Europe, or indeed than any which could be found on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this side of the confines of Asia.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Profession Of The Law In The United States Serves To Counterpoise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Utility of discriminating the natural propensities of the members of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legal profession--These men called upon to act a prominent part in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future society--In what manner the peculiar pursuits of lawyers give an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic turn to their ideas--Accidental causes which may check this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency--Ease with which the aristocracy coalesces with legal men--Use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of lawyers to a despot--The profession of the law constitutes the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic element with which the natural elements of democracy will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combine--Peculiar causes which tend to give an aristocratic turn of mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the English and American lawyers--The aristocracy of America is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the bench and at the bar--Influence of lawyers upon American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society--Their peculiar magisterial habits affect the legislature, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration, and even the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In visiting the Americans and in studying their laws we perceive that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the authority they have entrusted to members of the legal profession,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the influence which these individuals exercise in the Government, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most powerful existing security against the excesses of democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This effect seems to me to result from a general cause which it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: useful to investigate, since it may produce analogous consequences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The members of the legal profession have taken an important part in all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the vicissitudes of political society in Europe during the last five
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hundred years. At one time they have been the instruments of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who were invested with political authority, and at another they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeeded in converting political authorities into their instrument. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Middle Ages they afforded a powerful support to the Crown, and since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that period they have exerted themselves to the utmost to limit the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: royal prerogative. In England they have contracted a close alliance with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the aristocracy; in France they have proved to be the most dangerous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enemies of that class. It is my object to inquire whether, under all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these circumstances, the members of the legal profession have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: swayed by sudden and momentary impulses; or whether they have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impelled by principles which are inherent in their pursuits, and which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will always recur in history. I am incited to this investigation by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reflecting that this particular class of men will most likely play a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prominent part in that order of things to which the events of our time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are giving birth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men who have more especially devoted themselves to legal pursuits derive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from those occupations certain habits of order, a taste for formalities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and a kind of instinctive regard for the regular connection of ideas,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which naturally render them very hostile to the revolutionary spirit and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the unreflecting passions of the multitude.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The special information which lawyers derive from their studies ensures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them a separate station in society, and they constitute a sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileged body in the scale of intelligence. This notion of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superiority perpetually recurs to them in the practice of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession: they are the masters of a science which is necessary, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is not very generally known; they serve as arbiters between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens; and the habit of directing the blind passions of parties in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: litigation to their purpose inspires them with a certain contempt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the judgment of the multitude. To this it may be added that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally constitute a body, not by any previous understanding, or by an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agreement which directs them to a common end; but the analogy of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: studies and the uniformity of their proceedings connect their minds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together, as much as a common interest could combine their endeavors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A portion of the tastes and of the habits of the aristocracy may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently be discovered in the characters of men in the profession of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the law. They participate in the same instinctive love of order and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formalities; and they entertain the same repugnance to the actions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the multitude, and the same secret contempt of the government of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. I do not mean to say that the natural propensities of lawyers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are sufficiently strong to sway them irresistibly; for they, like most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other men, are governed by their private interests and the advantages of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the moment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In a state of society in which the members of the legal profession are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevented from holding that rank in the political world which they enjoy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in private life, we may rest assured that they will be the foremost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agents of revolution. But it must then be inquired whether the cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which induces them to innovate and to destroy is accidental, or whether
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it belongs to some lasting purpose which they entertain. It is true that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lawyers mainly contributed to the overthrow of the French monarchy in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1789; but it remains to be seen whether they acted thus because they had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: studied the laws, or because they were prohibited from co-operating in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the work of legislation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Five hundred years ago the English nobles headed the people, and spoke
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in its name; at the present time the aristocracy supports the throne,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and defends the royal prerogative. But aristocracy has, notwithstanding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this, its peculiar instincts and propensities. We must be careful not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to confound isolated members of a body with the body itself. In all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free governments, of whatsoever form they may be, members of the legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession will be found at the head of all parties. The same remark
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is also applicable to the aristocracy; for almost all the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convulsions which have agitated the world have been directed by nobles.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A privileged body can never satisfy the ambition of all its members; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has always more talents and more passions to content and to employ than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it can find places; so that a considerable number of individuals are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usually to be met with who are inclined to attack those very privileges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they find it impossible to turn to their own account.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not, then, assert that all the members of the legal profession are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at all times the friends of order and the opponents of innovation, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merely that most of them usually are so. In a community in which lawyers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are allowed to occupy, without opposition, that high station which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally belongs to them, their general spirit will be eminently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conservative and anti-democratic. When an aristocracy excludes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leaders of that profession from its ranks, it excites enemies which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are the more formidable to its security as they are independent of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nobility by their industrious pursuits; and they feel themselves to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its equal in point of intelligence, although they enjoy less opulence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and less power. But whenever an aristocracy consents to impart some of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its privileges to these same individuals, the two classes coalesce very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily, and assume, as it were, the consistency of a single order of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: family interests.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am, in like manner, inclined to believe that a monarch will always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be able to convert legal practitioners into the most serviceable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instruments of his authority. There is a far greater affinity between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this class of individuals and the executive power than there is between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them and the people; just as there is a greater natural affinity between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nobles and the monarch than between the nobles and the people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although the higher orders of society have occasionally resisted the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prerogative of the Crown in concert with the lower classes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lawyers are attached to public order beyond every other consideration,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the best security of public order is authority. It must not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forgotten that, if they prize the free institutions of their country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much, they nevertheless value the legality of those institutions far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more: they are less afraid of tyranny than of arbitrary power; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provided that the legislature take upon itself to deprive men of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence, they are not dissatisfied.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am therefore convinced that the prince who, in presence of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encroaching democracy, should endeavor to impair the judicial authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in his dominions, and to diminish the political influence of lawyers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would commit a great mistake. He would let slip the substance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of authority to grasp at the shadow. He would act more wisely in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introducing men connected with the law into the government; and if he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entrusted them with the conduct of a despotic power, bearing some marks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of violence, that power would most likely assume the external features
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of justice and of legality in their hands.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The government of democracy is favorable to the political power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lawyers; for when the wealthy, the noble, and the prince are excluded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the government, they are sure to occupy the highest stations, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own right, as it were, since they are the only men of information
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and sagacity, beyond the sphere of the people, who can be the object of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the popular choice. If, then, they are led by their tastes to combine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the aristocracy and to support the Crown, they are naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brought into contact with the people by their interests. They like the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government of democracy, without participating in its propensities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and without imitating its weaknesses; whence they derive a twofold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, from it and over it. The people in democratic states does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mistrust the members of the legal profession, because it is well known
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they are interested in serving the popular cause; and it listens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them without irritation, because it does not attribute to them any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sinister designs. The object of lawyers is not, indeed, to overthrow the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions of democracy, but they constantly endeavor to give it an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impulse which diverts it from its real tendency, by means which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign to its nature. Lawyers belong to the people by birth and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest, to the aristocracy by habit and by taste, and they may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: looked upon as the natural bond and connecting link of the two great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The profession of the law is the only aristocratic element which can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amalgamated without violence with the natural elements of democracy, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which can be advantageously and permanently combined with them. I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not unacquainted with the defects which are inherent in the character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of that body of men; but without this admixture of lawyer-like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sobriety with the democratic principle, I question whether democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions could long be maintained, and I cannot believe that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republic could subsist at the present time if the influence of lawyers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in public business did not increase in proportion to the power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This aristocratic character, which I hold to be common to the legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession, is much more distinctly marked in the United States and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England than in any other country. This proceeds not only from the legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: studies of the English and American lawyers, but from the nature of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legislation, and the position which those persons occupy in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two countries. The English and the Americans have retained the law of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precedents; that is to say, they continue to found their legal opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the decisions of their courts upon the opinions and the decisions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their forefathers. In the mind of an English or American lawyer a taste
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and a reverence for what is old is almost always united to a love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regular and lawful proceedings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This predisposition has another effect upon the character of the legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession and upon the general course of society. The English and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American lawyers investigate what has been done; the French advocate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquires what should have been done; the former produce precedents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the latter reasons. A French observer is surprised to hear how often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an English dr an American lawyer quotes the opinions of others, and how
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little he alludes to his own; whilst the reverse occurs in France. There
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most trifling litigation is never conducted without the introduction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an entire system of ideas peculiar to the counsel employed; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fundamental principles of law are discussed in order to obtain a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perch of land by the decision of the court. This abnegation of his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion, and this implicit deference to the opinion of his forefathers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are common to the English and American lawyer, this subjection of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought which he is obliged to profess, necessarily give him more timid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits and more sluggish inclinations in England and America than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The French codes are often difficult of comprehension, but they can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: read by every one; nothing, on the other hand, can be more impenetrable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the uninitiated than a legislation founded upon precedents. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indispensable want of legal assistance which is felt in England and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States, and the high opinion which is generally entertained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the ability of the legal profession, tend to separate it more and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more from the people, and to place it in a distinct class. The French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lawyer is simply a man extensively acquainted with the statutes of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country; but the English or American lawyer resembles the hierophants of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Egypt, for, like them, he is the sole interpreter of an occult science.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The station which lawyers occupy in England and America exercises no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less an influence upon their habits and their opinions. The English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy, which has taken care to attract to its sphere whatever is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at all analogous to itself, has conferred a high degree of importance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of authority upon the members of the legal profession. In English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society lawyers do not occupy the first rank, but they are contented
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the station assigned to them; they constitute, as it were, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: younger branch of the English aristocracy, and they are attached to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their elder brothers, although they do not enjoy all their privileges.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The English lawyers consequently mingle the taste and the ideas of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic circles in which they move with the aristocratic interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their profession.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And indeed the lawyer-like character which I am endeavoring to depict is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most distinctly to be met with in England: there laws are esteemed not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so much because they are good as because they are old; and if it be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary to modify them in any respect, or to adapt them the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changes which time operates in society, recourse is had to the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconceivable contrivances in order to uphold the traditionary fabric,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to maintain that nothing has been done which does not square with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the intentions and complete the labors of former generations. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very individuals who conduct these changes disclaim all intention of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innovation, and they had rather resort to absurd expedients than plead
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guilty to so great a crime. This spirit appertains more especially to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the English lawyers; they seem indifferent to the real meaning of what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they treat, and they direct all their attention to the letter, seeming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclined to infringe the rules of common sense and of humanity rather
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than to swerve one title from the law. The English legislation may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compared to the stock of an old tree, upon which lawyers have engrafted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most various shoots, with the hope that, although their fruits may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differ, their foliage at least will be confounded with the venerable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trunk which supports them all.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America there are no nobles or men of letters, and the people is apt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to mistrust the wealthy; lawyers consequently form the highest political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class, and the most cultivated circle of society. They have therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing to gain by innovation, which adds a conservative interest to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their natural taste for public order. If I were asked where I place the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American aristocracy, I should reply without hesitation that it is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed of the rich, who are united together by no common tie, but that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it occupies the judicial bench and the bar.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The more we reflect upon all that occurs in the United States the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall we be persuaded that the lawyers as a body form the most powerful,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if not the only, counterpoise to the democratic element. In that country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we perceive how eminently the legal profession is qualified by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers, and even by its defects, to neutralize the vices which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inherent in popular government. When the American people is intoxicated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by passion, or carried away by the impetuosity of its ideas, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: checked and stopped by the almost invisible influence of its legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: counsellors, who secretly oppose their aristocratic propensities to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic instincts, their superstitious attachment to what is antique
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to its love of novelty, their narrow views to its immense designs, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their habitual procrastination to its ardent impatience.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The courts of justice are the most visible organs by which the legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession is enabled to control the democracy. The judge is a lawyer,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who, independently of the taste for regularity and order which he has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contracted in the study of legislation, derives an additional love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stability from his own inalienable functions. His legal attainments have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already raised him to a distinguished rank amongst his fellow-citizens;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his political power completes the distinction of his station, and gives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him the inclinations natural to privileged classes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Armed with the power of declaring the laws to be unconstitutional, *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American magistrate perpetually interferes in political affairs. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot force the people to make laws, but at least he can oblige it not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to disobey its own enactments; or to act inconsistently with its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles. I am aware that a secret tendency to diminish the judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power exists in the United States, and by most of the constitutions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the several States the Government can, upon the demand of the two houses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the legislature, remove the judges from their station. By some other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitutions the members of the tribunals are elected, and they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even subjected to frequent re-elections. I venture to predict that these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innovations will sooner or later be attended with fatal consequences,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that it will be found out at some future period that the attack
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is made upon the judicial power has affected the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republic itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: See chapter VI. on the "Judicial Power in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must not, however, be supposed that the legal spirit of which I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been speaking has been confined, in the United States, to the courts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice; it extends far beyond them. As the lawyers constitute the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlightened class which the people does not mistrust, they are naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called upon to occupy most of the public stations. They fill the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislative assemblies, and they conduct the administration; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently exercise a powerful influence upon the formation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law, and upon its execution. The lawyers are, however, obliged to yield
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the current of public opinion, which is too strong for them to resist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it, but it is easy to find indications of what their conduct would be if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they were free to act as they chose. The Americans, who have made such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: copious innovations in their political legislation, have introduced very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sparing alterations in their civil laws, and that with great difficulty,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although those laws are frequently repugnant to their social condition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The reason of this is, that in matters of civil law the majority is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to defer to the authority of the legal profession, and that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American lawyers are disinclined to innovate when they are left to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own choice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is curious for a Frenchman, accustomed to a very different state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things, to hear the perpetual complaints which are made in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States against the stationary propensities of legal men, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudices in favor of existing institutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The influence of the legal habits which are common in America extends
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beyond the limits I have just pointed out. Scarcely any question arises
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States which does not become, sooner or later, a subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of judicial debate; hence all parties are obliged to borrow the ideas,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and even the language, usual in judicial proceedings in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: daily controversies. As most public men are, or have been, legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practitioners, they introduce the customs and technicalities of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession into the affairs of the country. The jury extends this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitude to all classes. The language of the law thus becomes, in some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measure, a vulgar tongue; the spirit of the law, which is produced in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the schools and courts of justice, gradually penetrates beyond their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: walls into the bosom of society, where it descends to the lowest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes, so that the whole people contracts the habits and the tastes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the magistrate. The lawyers of the United States form a party which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but little feared and scarcely perceived, which has no badge peculiar to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself, which adapts itself with great flexibility to the exigencies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the time, and accommodates itself to all the movements of the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body; but this party extends over the whole community, and it penetrates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into all classes of society; it acts upon the country imperceptibly, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it finally fashions it to suit its purposes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVI: Causes Mitigating Tyranny In The United States--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Trial By Jury In The United States Considered As A Political Institution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Trial by jury, which is one of the instruments of the sovereignty of the
