author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, deserves to be compared with the other laws which establish that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereignty--Composition of the jury in the United States--Effect of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trial by jury upon the national character--It educates the people--It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tends to establish the authority of the magistrates and to extend a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge of law among the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Since I have been led by my subject to recur to the administration of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice in the United States, I will not pass over this point without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adverting to the institution of the jury. Trial by jury may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considered in two separate points of view, as a judicial and as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political institution. If it entered into my present purpose to inquire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: how far trial by jury (more especially in civil cases) contributes to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insure the best administration of justice, I admit that its utility
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might be contested. As the jury was first introduced at a time when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society was in an uncivilized state, and when courts of justice were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merely called upon to decide on the evidence of facts, it is not an easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: task to adapt it to the wants of a highly civilized community when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mutual relations of men are multiplied to a surprising extent, and have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assumed the enlightened and intellectual character of the age. *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: The investigation of trial by jury as a judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institution, and the appreciation of its effects in the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together with the advantages the Americans have derived from it, would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suffice to form a book, and a book upon a very useful and curious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject. The State of Louisiana would in particular afford the curious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: phenomenon of a French and English legislation, as well as a French and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English population, which are gradually combining with each other. See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the "Digeste des Lois de la Louisiane," in two volumes; and the "Traite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sur les Regles des Actions civiles," printed in French and English at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New Orleans in 1830.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: My present object is to consider the jury as a political institution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and any other course would divert me from my subject. Of trial by jury,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considered as a judicial institution, I shall here say but very few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words. When the English adopted trial by jury they were a semi-barbarous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people; they are become, in course of time, one of the most enlightened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations of the earth; and their attachment to this institution seems
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to have increased with their increasing cultivation. They soon spread
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beyond their insular boundaries to every corner of the habitable globe;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some have formed colonies, others independent states; the mother-country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has maintained its monarchical constitution; many of its offspring have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: founded powerful republics; but wherever the English have been they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: boasted of the privilege of trial by jury. *c They have established it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or hastened to re-establish it, in all their settlements. A judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institution which obtains the suffrages of a great people for so long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a series of ages, which is zealously renewed at every epoch of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization, in all the climates of the earth and under every form of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human government, cannot be contrary to the spirit of justice. *d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: All the English and American jurists are unanimous upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this head. Mr. Story, judge of the Supreme Court of the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speaks, in his "Treatise on the Federal Constitution," of the advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of trial by jury in civil cases:--"The inestimable privilege of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trial by jury in civil cases--a privilege scarcely inferior to that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in criminal cases, which is counted by all persons to be essential to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political and civil liberty. . . ." (Story, book iii., chap. xxxviii.)]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: If it were our province to point out the utility of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jury as a judicial institution in this place, much might be said, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the following arguments might be brought forward amongst others:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: By introducing the jury into the business of the courts you are enabled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to diminish the number of judges, which is a very great advantage. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judges are very numerous, death is perpetually thinning the ranks of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the judicial functionaries, and laying places vacant for newcomers. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition of the magistrates is therefore continually excited, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are naturally made dependent upon the will of the majority, or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual who fills up the vacant appointments; the officers of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: court then rise like the officers of an army. This state of things is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely contrary to the sound administration of justice, and to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intentions of the legislator. The office of a judge is made inalienable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order that he may remain independent: but of what advantage is it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that his independence should be protected if he be tempted to sacrifice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it of his own accord? When judges are very numerous many of them must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessarily be incapable of performing their important duties, for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great magistrate is a man of no common powers; and I am inclined to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe that a half-enlightened tribunal is the worst of all instruments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for attaining those objects which it is the purpose of courts of justice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to accomplish. For my own part, I had rather submit the decision of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case to ignorant jurors directed by a skilful judge than to judges a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority of whom are imperfectly acquainted with jurisprudence and with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I turn, however, from this part of the subject. To look upon the jury as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a mere judicial institution is to confine our attention to a very narrow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: view of it; for however great its influence may be upon the decisions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the law courts, that influence is very subordinate to the powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effects which it produces on the destinies of the community at large.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The jury is above all a political institution, and it must be regarded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this light in order to be duly appreciated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: By the jury I mean a certain number of citizens chosen indiscriminately,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and invested with a temporary right of judging. Trial by jury, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applied to the repression of crime, appears to me to introduce an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eminently republican element into the government upon the following
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grounds:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The institution of the jury may be aristocratic or democratic, according
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the class of society from which the jurors are selected; but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always preserves its republican character, inasmuch as it places the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: real direction of society in the hands of the governed, or of a portion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the governed, instead of leaving it under the authority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government. Force is never more than a transient element of success; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after force comes the notion of right. A government which should only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be able to crush its enemies upon a field of battle would very soon be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destroyed. The true sanction of political laws is to be found in penal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation, and if that sanction be wanting the law will sooner or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: later lose its cogency. He who punishes infractions of the law is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore the real master of society. Now the institution of the jury
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raises the people itself, or at least a class of citizens, to the bench
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of judicial authority. The institution of the jury consequently invests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people, or that class of citizens, with the direction of society. *e
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: An important remark must, however, be made. Trial by jury
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does unquestionably invest the people with a general control over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions of citizens, but it does not furnish means of exercising this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: control in all cases, or with an absolute authority. When an absolute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarch has the right of trying offences by his representatives, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fate of the prisoner is, as it were, decided beforehand. But even if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people were predisposed to convict, the composition and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: non-responsibility of the jury would still afford some chances favorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the protection of innocence.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In England the jury is returned from the aristocratic portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nation; *f the aristocracy makes the laws, applies the laws, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: punishes all infractions of the laws; everything is established upon a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consistent footing, and England may with truth be said to constitute an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic republic. In the United States the same system is applied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the whole people. Every American citizen is qualified to be an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elector, a juror, and is eligible to office. *g The system of the jury,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as it is understood in America, appears to me to be as direct and as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extreme a consequence of the sovereignty of the people as universal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suffrage. These institutions are two instruments of equal power, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contribute to the supremacy of the majority. All the sovereigns who have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chosen to govern by their own authority, and to direct society instead
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of obeying its directions, have destroyed or enfeebled the institution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the jury. The monarchs of the House of Tudor sent to prison jurors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who refused to convict, and Napoleon caused them to be returned by his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agents.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: [This may be true to some extent of special juries, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not of common juries. The author seems not to have been aware that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: qualifications of jurors in England vary exceedingly.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: See Appendix, Q.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: However clear most of these truths may seem to be, they do not command
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: universal assent, and in France, at least, the institution of trial by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jury is still very imperfectly understood. If the question arises as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the proper qualification of jurors, it is confined to a discussion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the intelligence and knowledge of the citizens who may be returned, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if the jury was merely a judicial institution. This appears to me to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the least part of the subject. The jury is pre-eminently a political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institution; it must be regarded as one form of the sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people; when that sovereignty is repudiated, it must be rejected, or it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be adapted to the laws by which that sovereignty is established.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The jury is that portion of the nation to which the execution of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws is entrusted, as the Houses of Parliament constitute that part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation which makes the laws; and in order that society may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed with consistency and uniformity, the list of citizens qualified
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to serve on juries must increase and diminish with the list of electors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This I hold to be the point of view most worthy of the attention of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator, and all that remains is merely accessory.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am so entirely convinced that the jury is pre-eminently a political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institution that I still consider it in this light when it is applied in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil causes. Laws are always unstable unless they are founded upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners of a nation; manners are the only durable and resisting power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a people. When the jury is reserved for criminal offences, the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only witnesses its occasional action in certain particular cases; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinary course of life goes on without its interference, and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is considered as an instrument, but not as the only instrument, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtaining justice. This is true a fortiori when the jury is only applied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to certain criminal causes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When, on the contrary, the influence of the jury is extended to civil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes, its application is constantly palpable; it affects all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests of the community; everyone co-operates in its work: it thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penetrates into all the usages of life, it fashions the human mind to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its peculiar forms, and is gradually associated with the idea of justice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The institution of the jury, if confined to criminal causes, is always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in danger, but when once it is introduced into civil proceedings it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defies the aggressions of time and of man. If it had been as easy to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remove the jury from the manners as from the laws of England, it would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have perished under Henry VIII, and Elizabeth, and the civil jury did in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reality, at that period, save the liberties of the country. In whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner the jury be applied, it cannot fail to exercise a powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence upon the national character; but this influence is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prodigiously increased when it is introduced into civil causes. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jury, and more especially the jury in civil cases, serves to communicate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the spirit of the judges to the minds of all the citizens; and this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit, with the habits which attend it, is the soundest preparation for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free institutions. It imbues all classes with a respect for the thing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judged, and with the notion of right. If these two elements be removed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the love of independence is reduced to a mere destructive passion. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: teaches men to practice equity, every man learns to judge his neighbor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as he would himself be judged; and this is especially true of the jury
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in civil causes, for, whilst the number of persons who have reason to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apprehend a criminal prosecution is small, every one is liable to have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a civil action brought against him. The jury teaches every man not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recoil before the responsibility of his own actions, and impresses him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with that manly confidence without which political virtue cannot exist.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It invests each citizen with a kind of magistracy, it makes them all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feel the duties which they are bound to discharge towards society, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the part which they take in the Government. By obliging men to turn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their attention to affairs which are not exclusively their own, it rubs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: off that individual egotism which is the rust of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The jury contributes most powerfully to form the judgement and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase the natural intelligence of a people, and this is, in my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion, its greatest advantage. It may be regarded as a gratuitous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public school ever open, in which every juror learns to exercise his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights, enters into daily communication with the most learned and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlightened members of the upper classes, and becomes practically
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquainted with the laws of his country, which are brought within the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reach of his capacity by the efforts of the bar, the advice of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judge, and even by the passions of the parties. I think that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practical intelligence and political good sense of the Americans are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mainly attributable to the long use which they have made of the jury in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil causes. I do not know whether the jury is useful to those who are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in litigation; but I am certain it is highly beneficial to those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decide the litigation; and I look upon it as one of the most efficacious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means for the education of the people which society can employ.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What I have hitherto said applies to all nations, but the remark I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am now about to make is peculiar to the Americans and to democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peoples. I have already observed that in democracies the members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legal profession and the magistrates constitute the only aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body which can check the irregularities of the people. This aristocracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is invested with no physical power, but it exercises its conservative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence upon the minds of men, and the most abundant source of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority is the institution of the civil jury. In criminal causes, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society is armed against a single individual, the jury is apt to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: look upon the judge as the passive instrument of social power, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mistrust his advice. Moreover, criminal causes are entirely founded upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the evidence of facts which common sense can readily appreciate; upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this ground the judge and the jury are equal. Such, however, is not the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case in civil causes; then the judge appears as a disinterested arbiter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the conflicting passions of the parties. The jurors look up to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him with confidence and listen to him with respect, for in this instance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their intelligence is completely under the control of his learning. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the judge who sums up the various arguments with which their memory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has been wearied out, and who guides them through the devious course of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the proceedings; he points their attention to the exact question of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact which they are called upon to solve, and he puts the answer to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: question of law into their mouths. His influence upon their verdict is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost unlimited.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I am called upon to explain why I am but little moved by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arguments derived from the ignorance of jurors in civil causes, I reply,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in these proceedings, whenever the question to be solved is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a mere question of fact, the jury has only the semblance of a judicial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body. The jury sanctions the decision of the judge, they by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of society which they represent, and he by that of reason and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of law. *h
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: See Appendix, R.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In England and in America the judges exercise an influence upon criminal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trials which the French judges have never possessed. The reason of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this difference may easily be discovered; the English and American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrates establish their authority in civil causes, and only transfer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it afterwards to tribunals of another kind, where that authority was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not acquired. In some cases (and they are frequently the most important
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ones) the American judges have the right of deciding causes alone. *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Upon these occasions they are accidentally placed in the position which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the French judges habitually occupy, but they are invested with far more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power than the latter; they are still surrounded by the reminiscence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the jury, and their judgment has almost as much authority as the voice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community at large, represented by that institution. Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence extends beyond the limits of the courts; in the recreations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private life as well as in the turmoil of public business, abroad and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the legislative assemblies, the American judge is constantly surrounded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by men who are accustomed to regard his intelligence as superior to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own, and after having exercised his power in the decision
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of causes, he continues to influence the habits of thought and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characters of the individuals who took a part in his judgment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: The Federal judges decide upon their own authority almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the questions most important to the country.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The jury, then, which seems to restrict the rights of magistracy, does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in reality consolidate its power, and in no country are the judges so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful as there, where the people partakes their privileges. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more especially by means of the jury in civil causes that the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrates imbue all classes of society with the spirit of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession. Thus the jury, which is the most energetic means of making
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people rule, is also the most efficacious means of teaching it to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rule well.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVII: Principal Causes Maintaining The Democratic Republic--Part I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Principal Causes Which Tend To Maintain The Democratic Republic In The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A democratic republic subsists in the United States, and the principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object of this book has been to account for the fact of its existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Several of the causes which contribute to maintain the institutions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America have been involuntarily passed by or only hinted at as I was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: borne along by my subject. Others I have been unable to discuss, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those on which I have dwelt most are, as it were, buried in the details
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the former parts of this work. I think, therefore, that before I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceed to speak of the future, I cannot do better than collect within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a small compass the reasons which best explain the present. In this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retrospective chapter I shall be succinct, for I shall take care to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remind the reader very summarily of what he already knows; and I shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only select the most prominent of those facts which I have not yet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pointed out.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the causes which contribute to the maintenance of the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republic in the United States are reducible to three heads:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I. The peculiar and accidental situation in which Providence has placed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: II. The laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: III. The manners and customs of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Accidental Or Providential Causes Which Contribute To The Maintenance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of The Democratic Republic In The United States The Union has no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighbors--No metropolis--The Americans have had the chances of birth in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their favor--America an empty country--How this circumstance contributes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerfully to the maintenance of the democratic republic in America--How
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American wilds are peopled--Avidity of the Anglo-Americans in taking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of the solitudes of the New World--Influence of physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity upon the political opinions of the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A thousand circumstances, independent of the will of man, concur to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facilitate the maintenance of a democratic republic in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. Some of these peculiarities are known, the others may easily be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pointed out; but I shall confine myself to the most prominent amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans have no neighbors, and consequently they have no great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wars, or financial crises, or inroads, or conquest to dread; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: require neither great taxes, nor great armies, nor great generals; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have nothing to fear from a scourge which is more formidable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republics than all these evils combined, namely, military glory. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is impossible to deny the inconceivable influence which military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glory exercises upon the spirit of a nation. General Jackson, whom the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans have twice elected to the head of their Government, is a man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a violent temper and mediocre talents; no one circumstance in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole course of his career ever proved that he is qualified to govern a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free people, and indeed the majority of the enlightened classes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union has always been opposed to him. But he was raised to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Presidency, and has been maintained in that lofty station, solely by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the recollection of a victory which he gained twenty years ago under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the walls of New Orleans, a victory which was, however, a very ordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: achievement, and which could only be remembered in a country where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: battles are rare. Now the people which is thus carried away by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: illusions of glory is unquestionably the most cold and calculating, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most unmilitary (if I may use the expression), and the most prosaic of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the peoples of the earth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America has no great capital *a city, whose influence is directly or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indirectly felt over the whole extent of the country, which I hold to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one of the first causes of the maintenance of republican institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States. In cities men cannot be prevented from concerting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together, and from awakening a mutual excitement which prompts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sudden and passionate resolutions. Cities may be looked upon as large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assemblies, of which all the inhabitants are members; their populace
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercises a prodigious influence upon the magistrates, and frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executes its own wishes without their intervention.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: The United States have no metropolis, but they already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contain several very large cities. Philadelphia reckoned 161,000
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants and New York 202,000 in the year 1830. The lower orders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which inhabit these cities constitute a rabble even more formidable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the populace of European towns. They consist of freed blacks in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first place, who are condemned by the laws and by public opinion to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a hereditary state of misery and degradation. They also contain a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of Europeans who have been driven to the shores of the New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: World by their misfortunes or their misconduct; and these men inoculate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States with all our vices, without bringing with them any of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those interests which counteract their baneful influence. As inhabitants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a country where they have no civil rights, they are ready to turn all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the passions which agitate the community to their own advantage; thus,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within the last few months serious riots have broken out in Philadelphia
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in New York. Disturbances of this kind are unknown in the rest of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country, which is nowise alarmed by them, because the population of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the cities has hitherto exercised neither power nor influence over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rural districts. Nevertheless, I look upon the size of certain American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cities, and especially on the nature of their population, as a real
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: danger which threatens the future security of the democratic republics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the New World; and I venture to predict that they will perish from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this circumstance unless the government succeeds in creating an armed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: force, which, whilst it remains under the control of the majority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, will be independent of the town population, and able to repress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its excesses.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [The population of the city of New York had risen, in 1870, to 942,292,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that of Philadelphia to 674,022. Brooklyn, which may be said to form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of New York city, has a population of 396,099, in addition to that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of New York. The frequent disturbances in the great cities of America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the excessive corruption of their local governments--over which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there is no effectual control--are amongst the greatest evils and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers of the country.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To subject the provinces to the metropolis is therefore not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to place the destiny of the empire in the hands of a portion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, which may be reprobated as unjust, but to place it in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands of a populace acting under its own impulses, which must be avoided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as dangerous. The preponderance of capital cities is therefore a serious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blow upon the representative system, and it exposes modern republics to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same defect as the republics of antiquity, which all perished from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not having been acquainted with that form of government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would be easy for me to adduce a great number of secondary causes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which have contributed to establish, and which concur to maintain, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic republic of the United States. But I discern two principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances amongst these favorable elements, which I hasten to point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out. I have already observed that the origin of the American settlements
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be looked upon as the first and most efficacious cause to which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present prosperity of the United States may be attributed. The Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had the chances of birth in their favor, and their forefathers imported
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that equality of conditions into the country whence the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republic has very naturally taken its rise. Nor was this all they did;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for besides this republican condition of society, the early settler
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bequeathed to their descendants those customs, manners, and opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which contribute most to the success of a republican form of government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When I reflect upon the consequences of this primary circumstance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: methinks I see the destiny of America embodied in the first Puritan who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: landed on those shores, just as the human race was represented by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The chief circumstance which has favored the establishment and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of a democratic republic in the United States is the nature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the territory which the American inhabit. Their ancestors gave them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the love of equality and of freedom, but God himself gave them the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of remaining equal and free, by placing them upon a boundless continent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is open to their exertions. General prosperity is favorable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the stability of all governments, but more particularly of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution, which depends upon the dispositions of the majority, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more particularly of that portion of the community which is most exposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to feel the pressure of want. When the people rules, it must be rendered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happy, or it will overturn the State, and misery is apt to stimulate it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to those excesses to which ambition rouses kings. The physical causes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent of the laws, which contribute to promote general prosperity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are more numerous in America than they have ever been in any other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country in the world, at any other period of history. In the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States not only is legislation democratic, but nature herself favors the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In what part of human tradition can be found anything at all similar to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that which is occurring under our eyes in North America? The celebrated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities of antiquity were all founded in the midst of hostile
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, which they were obliged to subjugate before they could flourish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in their place. Even the moderns have found, in some parts of South
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, vast regions inhabited by a people of inferior civilization,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but which occupied and cultivated the soil. To found their new states
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it was necessary to extirpate or to subdue a numerous population, until
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization has been made to blush for their success. But North America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was only inhabited by wandering tribes, who took no thought of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural riches of the soil, and that vast country was still, properly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speaking, an empty continent, a desert land awaiting its inhabitants.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Everything is extraordinary in America, the social condition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inhabitants, as well as the laws; but the soil upon which these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions are founded is more extraordinary than all the rest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When man was first placed upon the earth by the Creator, the earth was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inexhaustible in its youth, but man was weak and ignorant; and when he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had learned to explore the treasures which it contained, hosts of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow creatures covered its surface, and he was obliged to earn an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asylum for repose and for freedom by the sword. At that same period
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North America was discovered, as if it had been kept in reserve by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Deity, and had just risen from beneath the waters of the deluge.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: That continent still presents, as it did in the primeval time, rivers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which rise from never-failing sources, green and moist solitudes, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fields which the ploughshare of the husbandman has never turned. In this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state it is offered to man, not in the barbarous and isolated condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the early ages, but to a being who is already in possession of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most potent secrets of the natural world, who is united to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-men, and instructed by the experience of fifty centuries. At
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this very time thirteen millions of civilized Europeans are peaceably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spreading over those fertile plains, with whose resources and whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent they are not yet themselves accurately acquainted. Three or four
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thousand soldiers drive the wandering races of the aborigines before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; these are followed by the pioneers, who pierce the woods, scare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: off the beasts of prey, explore the courses of the inland streams, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make ready the triumphal procession of civilization across the waste.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The favorable influence of the temporal prosperity of America upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions of that country has been so often described by others,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and adverted to by myself, that I shall not enlarge upon it beyond the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: addition of a few facts. An erroneous notion is generally entertained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the deserts of America are peopled by European emigrants, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annually disembark upon the coasts of the New World, whilst the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population increases and multiplies upon the soil which its forefathers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tilled. The European settler, however, usually arrives in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States without friends, and sometimes without resources; in order to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsist he is obliged to work for hire, and he rarely proceeds beyond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that belt of industrious population which adjoins the ocean. The desert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be explored without capital or credit; and the body must be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustomed to the rigors of a new climate before it can be exposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chances of forest life. It is the Americans themselves who daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quit the spots which gave them birth to acquire extensive domains in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a remote country. Thus the European leaves his cottage for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trans-Atlantic shores; and the American, who is born on that very coast,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plunges in his turn into the wilds of Central America. This double
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emigration is incessant; it begins in the remotest parts of Europe, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crosses the Atlantic Ocean, and it advances over the solitudes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the New World. Millions of men are marching at once towards the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: horizon; their language, their religion, their manners differ, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object is the same. The gifts of fortune are promised in the West, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the West they bend their course. *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: [The number of foreign immigrants into the United States in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the last fifty years (from 1820 to 1871) is stated to be 7,556,007. Of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these, 4,104,553 spoke English--that is, they came from Great Britain,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ireland, or the British colonies; 2,643,069 came from Germany or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: northern Europe; and about half a million from the south of Europe.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No event can be compared with this continuous removal of the human race,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: except perhaps those irruptions which preceded the fall of the Roman
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Empire. Then, as well as now, generations of men were impelled forwards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the same direction to meet and struggle on the same spot; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: designs of Providence were not the same; then, every newcomer was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harbinger of destruction and of death; now, every adventurer brings with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him the elements of prosperity and of life. The future still conceals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from us the ulterior consequences of this emigration of the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: towards the West; but we can readily apprehend its more immediate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results. As a portion of the inhabitants annually leave the States in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they were born, the population of these States increases very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slowly, although they have long been established: thus in Connecticut,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which only contains fifty-nine inhabitants to the square mile, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population has not increased by more than one-quarter in forty years,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst that of England has been augmented by one-third in the lapse of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same period. The European emigrant always lands, therefore, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a country which is but half full, and where hands are in request:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he becomes a workman in easy circumstances; his son goes to seek his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune in unpeopled regions, and he becomes a rich landowner. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former amasses the capital which the latter invests, and the stranger as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well as the native is unacquainted with want.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The laws of the United States are extremely favorable to the division
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of property; but a cause which is more powerful than the laws prevents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property from being divided to excess. *c This is very perceptible in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States which are beginning to be thickly peopled; Massachusetts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the most populous part of the Union, but it contains only eighty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants to the square mile, which is must less than in France, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 162 are reckoned to the same extent of country. But in Massachusetts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estates are very rarely divided; the eldest son takes the land, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others go to seek their fortune in the desert. The law has abolished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rights of primogeniture, but circumstances have concurred to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: re-establish it under a form of which none can complain, and by which no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: just rights are impaired.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: In New England the estates are exceedingly small, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are rarely subjected to further division.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A single fact will suffice to show the prodigious number of individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who leave New England, in this manner, to settle themselves in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilds. We were assured in 1830 that thirty-six of the members of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Congress were born in the little State of Connecticut. The population of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Connecticut, which constitutes only one forty-third part of that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States, thus furnished one-eighth of the whole body of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives. The States of Connecticut, however, only sends five
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delegates to Congress; and the thirty-one others sit for the new Western
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. If these thirty-one individuals had remained in Connecticut,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is probable that instead of becoming rich landowners they would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have remained humble laborers, that they would have lived in obscurity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without being able to rise into public life, and that, far from becoming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: useful members of the legislature, they might have been unruly citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These reflections do not escape the observation of the Americans any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more than of ourselves. "It cannot be doubted," says Chancellor Kent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in his "Treatise on American Law," "that the division of landed estates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must produce great evils when it is carried to such excess as that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each parcel of land is insufficient to support a family; but these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disadvantages have never been felt in the United States, and many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generations must elapse before they can be felt. The extent of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabited territory, the abundance of adjacent land, and the continual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stream of emigration flowing from the shores of the Atlantic towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the interior of the country, suffice as yet, and will long suffice, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevent the parcelling out of estates."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is difficult to describe the rapacity with which the American rushes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forward to secure the immense booty which fortune proffers to him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the pursuit he fearlessly braves the arrow of the Indian and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distempers of the forest; he is unimpressed by the silence of the woods;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the approach of beasts of prey does not disturb him; for he is goaded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: onwards by a passion more intense than the love of life. Before him lies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a boundless continent, and he urges onwards as if time pressed, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was afraid of finding no room for his exertions. I have spoken of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emigration from the older States, but how shall I describe that which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: takes place from the more recent ones? Fifty years have scarcely elapsed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since that of Ohio was founded; the greater part of its inhabitants were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not born within its confines; its capital has only been built thirty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years, and its territory is still covered by an immense extent of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncultivated fields; nevertheless the population of Ohio is already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceeding westward, and most of the settlers who descend to the fertile
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: savannahs of Illinois are citizens of Ohio. These men left their first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country to improve their condition; they quit their resting-place to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ameliorate it still more; fortune awaits them everywhere, but happiness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they cannot attain. The desire of prosperity is become an ardent and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restless passion in their minds which grows by what it gains. They early
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: broke the ties which bound them to their natal earth, and they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contracted no fresh ones on their way. Emigration was at first necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them as a means of subsistence; and it soon becomes a sort of game of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chance, which they pursue for the emotions it excites as much as for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gain it procures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Sometimes the progress of man is so rapid that the desert reappears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: behind him. The woods stoop to give him a passage, and spring up again
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when he has passed. It is not uncommon in crossing the new States of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the West to meet with deserted dwellings in the midst of the wilds; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traveller frequently discovers the vestiges of a log house in the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solitary retreats, which bear witness to the power, and no less to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconstancy of man. In these abandoned fields, and over these ruins of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a day, the primeval forest soon scatters a fresh vegetation, the beasts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resume the haunts which were once their own, and Nature covers the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traces of man's path with branches and with flowers, which obliterate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his evanescent track.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I remember that, in crossing one of the woodland districts which still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cover the State of New York, I reached the shores of a lake embosomed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forests coeval with the world. A small island, covered with woods whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thick foliage concealed its banks, rose from the centre of the waters.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Upon the shores of the lake no object attested the presence of man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: except a column of smoke which might be seen on the horizon rising from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tops of the trees to the clouds, and seeming to hang from heaven
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather than to be mounting to the sky. An Indian shallop was hauled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up on the sand, which tempted me to visit the islet that had first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attracted my attention, and in a few minutes I set foot upon its banks.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The whole island formed one of those delicious solitudes of the New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: World which almost lead civilized man to regret the haunts of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: savage. A luxuriant vegetation bore witness to the incomparable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fruitfulness of the soil. The deep silence which is common to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilds of North America was only broken by the hoarse cooing of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wood-pigeon, and the tapping of the woodpecker upon the bark of trees.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I was far from supposing that this spot had ever been inhabited, so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely did Nature seem to be left to her own caprices; but when I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reached the centre of the isle I thought that I discovered some traces
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of man. I then proceeded to examine the surrounding objects with care,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and I soon perceived that a European had undoubtedly been led to seek a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refuge in this retreat. Yet what changes had taken place in the scene of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his labors! The logs which he had hastily hewn to build himself a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shed had sprouted afresh; the very props were intertwined with living
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: verdure, and his cabin was transformed into a bower. In the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these shrubs a few stones were to be seen, blackened with fire and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sprinkled with thin ashes; here the hearth had no doubt been, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chimney in falling had covered it with rubbish. I stood for some time in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: silent admiration of the exuberance of Nature and the littleness of man:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and when I was obliged to leave that enchanting solitude, I exclaimed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with melancholy, "Are ruins, then, already here?"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Europe we are wont to look upon a restless disposition, an unbounded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desire of riches, and an excessive love of independence, as propensities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very formidable to society. Yet these are the very elements which ensure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a long and peaceful duration to the republics of America. Without these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unquiet passions the population would collect in certain spots, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would soon be subject to wants like those of the Old World, which it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult to satisfy; for such is the present good fortune of the New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: World, that the vices of its inhabitants are scarcely less favorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to society than their virtues. These circumstances exercise a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence on the estimation in which human actions are held in the two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hemispheres. The Americans frequently term what we should call cupidity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a laudable industry; and they blame as faint-heartedness what we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider to be the virtue of moderate desires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In France, simple tastes, orderly manners, domestic affections, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attachments which men feel to the place of their birth, are looked upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as great guarantees of the tranquillity and happiness of the State. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in America nothing seems to be more prejudicial to society than these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtues. The French Canadians, who have faithfully preserved the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traditions of their pristine manners, are already embarrassed for room
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon their small territory; and this little community, which has so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recently begun to exist, will shortly be a prey to the calamities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incident to old nations. In Canada, the most enlightened, patriotic,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and humane inhabitants make extraordinary efforts to render the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dissatisfied with those simple enjoyments which still content it. There,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the seductions of wealth are vaunted with as much zeal as the charms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an honest but limited income in the Old World, and more exertions are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made to excite the passions of the citizens there than to calm them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere. If we listen to their eulogies, we shall hear that nothing is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more praiseworthy than to exchange the pure and homely pleasures which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even the poor man tastes in his own country for the dull delights of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity under a foreign sky; to leave the patrimonial hearth and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the turf beneath which his forefathers sleep; in short, to abandon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: living and the dead in quest of fortune.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the present time America presents a field for human effort far more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extensive than any sum of labor which can be applied to work it. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America too much knowledge cannot be diffused; for all knowledge, whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may serve him who possesses it, turns also to the advantage of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are without it. New wants are not to be feared, since they can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfied without difficulty; the growth of human passions need not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dreaded, since all passions may find an easy and a legitimate object;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor can men be put in possession of too much freedom, since they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scarcely ever tempted to misuse their liberties.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American republics of the present day are like companies of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adventurers formed to explore in common the waste lands of the New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: World, and busied in a flourishing trade. The passions which agitate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans most deeply are not their political but their commercial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions; or, to speak more correctly, they introduce the habits they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contract in business into their political life. They love order, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which affairs do not prosper; and they set an especial value upon a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regular conduct, which is the foundation of a solid business; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prefer the good sense which amasses large fortunes to that enterprising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit which frequently dissipates them; general ideas alarm their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minds, which are accustomed to positive calculations, and they hold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practice in more honor than theory.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is in America that one learns to understand the influence which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: physical prosperity exercises over political actions, and even over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions which ought to acknowledge no sway but that of reason; and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is more especially amongst strangers that this truth is perceptible.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Most of the European emigrants to the New World carry with them that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wild love of independence and of change which our calamities are so apt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to engender. I sometimes met with Europeans in the United States who had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been obliged to leave their own country on account of their political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions. They all astonished me by the language they held, but one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them surprised me more than all the rest. As I was crossing one of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most remote districts of Pennsylvania I was benighted, and obliged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to beg for hospitality at the gate of a wealthy planter, who was a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Frenchman by birth. He bade me sit down beside his fire, and we began to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talk with that freedom which befits persons who meet in the backwoods,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two thousand leagues from their native country. I was aware that my host
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had been a great leveller and an ardent demagogue forty years ago, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that his name was not unknown to fame. I was, therefore, not a little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surprised to hear him discuss the rights of property as an economist or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a landowner might have done: he spoke of the necessary gradations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune establishes among men, of obedience to established laws, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the influence of good morals in commonwealths, and of the support which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious opinions give to order and to freedom; he even went to far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to quote an evangelical authority in corroboration of one of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political tenets.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I listened, and marvelled at the feebleness of human reason. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proposition is true or false, but no art can prove it to be one or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, in the midst of the uncertainties of science and the conflicting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lessons of experience, until a new incident disperses the clouds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doubt; I was poor, I become rich, and I am not to expect that prosperity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will act upon my conduct, and leave my judgment free; my opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change with my fortune, and the happy circumstances which I turn to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my advantage furnish me with that decisive argument which was before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wanting. The influence of prosperity acts still more freely upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American than upon strangers. The American has always seen the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connection of public order and public prosperity, intimately united
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as they are, go on before his eyes; he does not conceive that one can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsist without the other; he has therefore nothing to forget; nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has he, like so many Europeans, to unlearn the lessons of his early
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: education.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVII: Principal Causes Maintaining The Democratic Republic--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Influence Of The Laws Upon The Maintenance Of The Democratic Republic In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Three principal causes of the maintenance of the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republic--Federal Constitutions--Municipal institutions--Judicial power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principal aim of this book has been to make known the laws of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States; if this purpose has been accomplished, the reader is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already enabled to judge for himself which are the laws that really tend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to maintain the democratic republic, and which endanger its existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I have not succeeded in explaining this in the whole course of my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: work, I cannot hope to do so within the limits of a single chapter. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not my intention to retrace the path I have already pursued, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a very few lines will suffice to recapitulate what I have previously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explained.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Three circumstances seem to me to contribute most powerfully to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of the democratic republic in the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first is that Federal form of Government which the Americans have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adopted, and which enables the Union to combine the power of a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empire with the security of a small State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The second consists in those municipal institutions which limit the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotism of the majority, and at the same time impart a taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom and a knowledge of the art of being free to the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The third is to be met with in the constitution of the judicial power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown in what manner the courts of justice serve to repress the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excesses of democracy, and how they check and direct the impulses of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority without stopping its activity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Influence Of Manners Upon The Maintenance Of The Democratic Republic In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have previously remarked that the manners of the people may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considered as one of the general causes to which the maintenance of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic republic in the United States is attributable. I here used
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the word manners with the meaning which the ancients attached to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: word mores, for I apply it not only to manners in their proper sense of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what constitutes the character of social intercourse, but I extend it to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the various notions and opinions current among men, and to the mass
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those ideas which constitute their character of mind. I comprise,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, under this term the whole moral and intellectual condition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a people. My intention is not to draw a picture of American manners,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but simply to point out such features of them as are favorable to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of political institutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Religion Considered As A Political Institution, Which Powerfully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Contributes To The Maintenance Of The Democratic Republic Amongst The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North America peopled by men who professed a democratic and republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christianity--Arrival of the Catholics--For what reason the Catholics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form the most democratic and the most republican class at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Every religion is to be found in juxtaposition to a political opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is connected with it by affinity. If the human mind be left
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to follow its own bent, it will regulate the temporal and spiritual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions of society upon one uniform principle; and man will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavor, if I may use the expression, to harmonize the state in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he lives upon earth with the state which he believes to await him in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heaven. The greatest part of British America was peopled by men who,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after having shaken off the authority of the Pope, acknowledged no other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious supremacy; they brought with them into the New World a form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Christianity which I cannot better describe than by styling it a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic and republican religion. This sect contributed powerfully to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the establishment of a democracy and a republic, and from the earliest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settlement of the emigrants politics and religion contracted an alliance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has never been dissolved.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: About fifty years ago Ireland began to pour a Catholic population into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States; on the other hand, the Catholics of America made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proselytes, and at the present moment more than a million of Christians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: professing the truths of the Church of Rome are to be met with in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union. *d The Catholics are faithful to the observances of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion; they are fervent and zealous in the support and belief of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their doctrines. Nevertheless they constitute the most republican and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most democratic class of citizens which exists in the United States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and although this fact may surprise the observer at first, the causes by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it is occasioned may easily be discovered upon reflection.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: [It is difficult to ascertain with accuracy the amount of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Roman Catholic population of the United States, but in 1868 an able
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
