text: writer in the "Edinburgh Review" (vol. cxxvii. p. 521) affirmed that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole Catholic population of the United States was then about 4,000,000,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divided into 43 dioceses, with 3,795 churches, under the care of 45
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bishops and 2,317 clergymen. But this rapid increase is mainly supported
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by immigration from the Catholic countries of Europe.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that the Catholic religion has erroneously been looked upon as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the natural enemy of democracy. Amongst the various sects of Christians,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Catholicism seems to me, on the contrary, to be one of those which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most favorable to the equality of conditions. In the Catholic Church,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the religious community is composed of only two elements, the priest and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people. The priest alone rises above the rank of his flock, and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: below him are equal.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On doctrinal points the Catholic faith places all human capacities upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same level; it subjects the wise and ignorant, the man of genius and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the vulgar crowd, to the details of the same creed; it imposes the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observances upon the rich and needy, it inflicts the same austerities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the strong and the weak, it listens to no compromise with mortal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man, but, reducing all the human race to the same standard, it confounds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the distinctions of society at the foot of the same altar, even as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are confounded in the sight of God. If Catholicism predisposes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the faithful to obedience, it certainly does not prepare them for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality; but the contrary may be said of Protestantism, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally tends to make men independent, more than to render them equal.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Catholicism is like an absolute monarchy; if the sovereign be removed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the other classes of society are more equal than they are in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republics. It has not unfrequently occurred that the Catholic priest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has left the service of the altar to mix with the governing powers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society, and to take his place amongst the civil gradations of men. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious influence has sometimes been used to secure the interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of that political state of things to which he belonged. At other times
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Catholics have taken the side of aristocracy from a spirit of religion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But no sooner is the priesthood entirely separated from the government,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as is the case in the United States, than is found that no class of men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are more naturally disposed than the Catholics to transfuse the doctrine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the equality of conditions into the political world. If, then, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Catholic citizens of the United States are not forcibly led by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature of their tenets to adopt democratic and republican principles,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least they are not necessarily opposed to them; and their social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position, as well as their limited number, obliges them to adopt these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions. Most of the Catholics are poor, and they have no chance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taking a part in the government unless it be open to all the citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They constitute a minority, and all rights must be respected in order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to insure to them the free exercise of their own privileges. These two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes induce them, unconsciously, to adopt political doctrines,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they would perhaps support with less zeal if they were rich and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preponderant.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Catholic clergy of the United States has never attempted to oppose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this political tendency, but it seeks rather to justify its results. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: priests in America have divided the intellectual world into two parts:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the one they place the doctrines of revealed religion, which command
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their assent; in the other they leave those truths which they believe to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been freely left open to the researches of political inquiry.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the Catholics of the United States are at the same time the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faithful believers and the most zealous citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may be asserted that in the United States no religious doctrine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: displays the slightest hostility to democratic and republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions. The clergy of all the different sects hold the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language, their opinions are consonant to the laws, and the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellect flows onwards in one sole current.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I happened to be staying in one of the largest towns in the Union, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I was invited to attend a public meeting which had been called for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purpose of assisting the Poles, and of sending them supplies of arms and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: money. I found two or three thousand persons collected in a vast hall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which had been prepared to receive them. In a short time a priest in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his ecclesiastical robes advanced to the front of the hustings: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spectators rose, and stood uncovered, whilst he spoke in the following
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: terms:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Almighty God! the God of Armies! Thou who didst strengthen the hearts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and guide the arms of our fathers when they were fighting for the sacred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights of national independence; Thou who didst make them triumph over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a hateful oppression, and hast granted to our people the benefits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of liberty and peace; Turn, O Lord, a favorable eye upon the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hemisphere; pitifully look down upon that heroic nation which is even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: now struggling as we did in the former time, and for the same rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which we defended with our blood. Thou, who didst create Man in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: likeness of the same image, let not tyranny mar Thy work, and establish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality upon the earth. Almighty God! do Thou watch over the destiny
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Poles, and render them worthy to be free. May Thy wisdom direct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their councils, and may Thy strength sustain their arms! Shed forth Thy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: terror over their enemies, scatter the powers which take counsel against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; and vouchsafe that the injustice which the world has witnessed for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fifty years, be not consummated in our time. O Lord, who holdest alike
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hearts of nations and of men in Thy powerful hand; raise up allies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the sacred cause of right; arouse the French nation from the apathy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in which its rulers retain it, that it go forth again to fight for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties of the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Lord, turn not Thou Thy face from us, and grant that we may always be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most religious as well as the freest people of the earth. Almighty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: God, hear our supplications this day. Save the Poles, we beseech Thee,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the name of Thy well-beloved Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, who died
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the cross for the salvation of men. Amen."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The whole meeting responded "Amen!" with devotion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indirect Influence Of Religious Opinions Upon Political Society In The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christian morality common to all sects--Influence of religion upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners of the Americans--Respect for the marriage tie--In what manner
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion confines the imagination of the Americans within certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limits, and checks the passion of innovation--Opinion of the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the political utility of religion--Their exertions to extend and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secure its predominance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have just shown what the direct influence of religion upon politics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is in the United States, but its indirect influence appears to me to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still more considerable, and it never instructs the Americans more fully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the art of being free than when it says nothing of freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The sects which exist in the United States are innumerable. They all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differ in respect to the worship which is due from man to his Creator,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they all agree in respect to the duties which are due from man to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man. Each sect adores the Deity in its own peculiar manner, but all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sects preach the same moral law in the name of God. If it be of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: highest importance to man, as an individual, that his religion should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true, the case of society is not the same. Society has no future life to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hope for or to fear; and provided the citizens profess a religion, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar tenets of that religion are of very little importance to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests. Moreover, almost all the sects of the United States are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comprised within the great unity of Christianity, and Christian morality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is everywhere the same.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may be believed without unfairness that a certain number of Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursue a peculiar form of worship, from habit more than from conviction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the sovereign authority is religious, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently hypocrisy must be common; but there is no country in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole world in which the Christian religion retains a greater influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over the souls of men than in America; and there can be no greater proof
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its utility, and of its conformity to human nature, than that its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence is most powerfully felt over the most enlightened and free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation of the earth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have remarked that the members of the American clergy in general,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without even excepting those who do not admit religious liberty, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all in favor of civil freedom; but they do not support any particular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political system. They keep aloof from parties and from public affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States religion exercises but little influence upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws and upon the details of public opinion, but it directs the manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community, and by regulating domestic life it regulates the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not question that the great austerity of manners which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observable in the United States, arises, in the first instance, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious faith. Religion is often unable to restrain man from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numberless temptations of fortune; nor can it check that passion for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gain which every incident of his life contributes to arouse, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its influence over the mind of woman is supreme, and women are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protectors of morals. There is certainly no country in the world
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the tie of marriage is so much respected as in America, or where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conjugal happiness is more highly or worthily appreciated. In Europe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all the disturbances of society arise from the irregularities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: domestic life. To despise the natural bonds and legitimate pleasures of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: home, is to contract a taste for excesses, a restlessness of heart, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the evil of fluctuating desires. Agitated by the tumultuous passions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which frequently disturb his dwelling, the European is galled by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience which the legislative powers of the State exact. But when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American retires from the turmoil of public life to the bosom of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: family, he finds in it the image of order and of peace. There his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures are simple and natural, his joys are innocent and calm; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as he finds that an orderly life is the surest path to happiness, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustoms himself without difficulty to moderate his opinions as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as his tastes. Whilst the European endeavors to forget his domestic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: troubles by agitating society, the American derives from his own home
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that love of order which he afterwards carries with him into public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the influence of religion is not confined to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners, but it extends to the intelligence of the people. Amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Anglo-Americans, there are some who profess the doctrines of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christianity from a sincere belief in them, and others who do the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they are afraid to be suspected of unbelief. Christianity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, reigns without any obstacle, by universal consent; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence is, as I have before observed, that every principle of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral world is fixed and determinate, although the political world is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandoned to the debates and the experiments of men. Thus the human mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is never left to wander across a boundless field; and, whatever may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its pretensions, it is checked from time to time by barriers which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot surmount. Before it can perpetrate innovation, certain primal and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immutable principles are laid down, and the boldest conceptions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human device are subjected to certain forms which retard and stop their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The imagination of the Americans, even in its greatest flights, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumspect and undecided; its impulses are checked, and its works
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unfinished. These habits of restraint recur in political society, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are singularly favorable both to the tranquillity of the people and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the durability of the institutions it has established. Nature and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances concurred to make the inhabitants of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bold men, as is sufficiently attested by the enterprising spirit with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they seek for fortune. If the mind of the Americans were free from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all trammels, they would very shortly become the most daring innovators
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the most implacable disputants in the world. But the revolutionists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of America are obliged to profess an ostensible respect for Christian
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: morality and equity, which does not easily permit them to violate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws that oppose their designs; nor would they find it easy to surmount
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the scruples of their partisans, even if they were able to get over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own. Hitherto no one in the United States has dared to advance the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maxim, that everything is permissible with a view to the interests of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society; an impious adage which seems to have been invented in an age of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom to shelter all the tyrants of future ages. Thus whilst the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permits the Americans to do what they please, religion prevents them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from conceiving, and forbids them to commit, what is rash or unjust.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Religion in America takes no direct part in the government of society,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it must nevertheless be regarded as the foremost of the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions of that country; for if it does not impart a taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom, it facilitates the use of free institutions. Indeed, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this same point of view that the inhabitants of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves look upon religious belief. I do not know whether all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans have a sincere faith in their religion, for who can search the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human heart? but I am certain that they hold it to be indispensable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the maintenance of republican institutions. This opinion is not peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a class of citizens or to a party, but it belongs to the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, and to every rank of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, if a political character attacks a sect, this may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not prevent even the partisans of that very sect from supporting him;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but if he attacks all the sects together, everyone abandons him, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains alone.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whilst I was in America, a witness, who happened to be called at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assizes of the county of Chester (State of New York), declared that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: did not believe in the existence of God, or in the immortality of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soul. The judge refused to admit his evidence, on the ground that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: witness had destroyed beforehand all the confidence of the Court in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what he was about to say. *e The newspapers related the fact without any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: further comment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: The New York "Spectator" of August 23, 1831, relates the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact in the following terms:--"The Court of Common Pleas of Chester
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: county (New York) a few days since rejected a witness who declared his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disbelief in the existence of God. The presiding judge remarked that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he had not before been aware that there was a man living who did not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe in the existence of God; that this belief constituted the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sanction of all testimony in a court of justice, and that he knew of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no cause in a Christian country where a witness had been permitted to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: testify without such belief."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans combine the notions of Christianity and of liberty so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intimately in their minds, that it is impossible to make them conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the one without the other; and with them this conviction does not spring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from that barren traditionary faith which seems to vegetate in the soul
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather than to live.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have known of societies formed by the Americans to send out ministers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Gospel into the new Western States to found schools and churches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there, lest religion should be suffered to die away in those remote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settlements, and the rising States be less fitted to enjoy free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions than the people from which they emanated. I met with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealthy New Englanders who abandoned the country in which they were born
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to lay the foundations of Christianity and of freedom on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: banks of the Missouri, or in the prairies of Illinois. Thus religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: zeal is perpetually stimulated in the United States by the duties of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patriotism. These men do not act from an exclusive consideration of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promises of a future life; eternity is only one motive of their devotion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the cause; and if you converse with these missionaries of Christian
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization, you will be surprised to find how much value they set upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the goods of this world, and that you meet with a politician where you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expected to find a priest. They will tell you that "all the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republics are collectively involved with each other; if the republics of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the West were to fall into anarchy, or to be mastered by a despot,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the republican institutions which now flourish upon the shores of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Atlantic Ocean would be in great peril. It is, therefore, our interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the new States should be religious, in order to maintain our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such are the opinions of the Americans, and if any hold that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious spirit which I admire is the very thing most amiss in America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that the only element wanting to the freedom and happiness of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human race is to believe in some blind cosmogony, or to assert with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Cabanis the secretion of thought by the brain, I can only reply that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who hold this language have never been in America, and that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have never seen a religious or a free nation. When they return from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their expedition, we shall hear what they have to say.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are persons in France who look upon republican institutions as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temporary means of power, of wealth, and distinction; men who are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condottieri of liberty, and who fight for their own advantage, whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the colors they wear: it is not to these that I address myself. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there are others who look forward to the republican form of government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a tranquil and lasting state, towards which modern society is daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impelled by the ideas and manners of the time, and who sincerely desire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to prepare men to be free. When these men attack religious opinions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they obey the dictates of their passions to the prejudice of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests. Despotism may govern without faith, but liberty cannot.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Religion is much more necessary in the republic which they set forth in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glowing colors than in the monarchy which they attack; and it is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: needed in democratic republics than in any others. How is it possible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that society should escape destruction if the moral tie be not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strengthened in proportion as the political tie is relaxed? and what can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be done with a people which is its own master, if it be not submissive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the Divinity?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVII: Principal Causes Maintaining The Democratic Republic--Part III
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Principal Causes Which Render Religion Powerful In America Care taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Americans to separate the Church from the State--The laws, public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion, and even the exertions of the clergy concur to promote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this end--Influence of religion upon the mind in the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attributable to this cause--Reason of this--What is the natural state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men with regard to religion at the present time--What are the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and incidental causes which prevent men, in certain countries, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arriving at this state.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The philosophers of the eighteenth century explained the gradual decay
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of religious faith in a very simple manner. Religious zeal, said they,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must necessarily fail, the more generally liberty is established and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge diffused. Unfortunately, facts are by no means in accordance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with their theory. There are certain populations in Europe whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unbelief is only equalled by their ignorance and their debasement,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst in America one of the freest and most enlightened nations in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world fulfils all the outward duties of religious fervor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Upon my arrival in the United States, the religious aspect of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country was the first thing that struck my attention; and the longer I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stayed there the more did I perceive the great political consequences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resulting from this state of things, to which I was unaccustomed. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France I had almost always seen the spirit of religion and the spirit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of freedom pursuing courses diametrically opposed to each other; but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America I found that they were intimately united, and that they reigned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in common over the same country. My desire to discover the causes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this phenomenon increased from day to day. In order to satisfy it I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: questioned the members of all the different sects; and I more especially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sought the society of the clergy, who are the depositaries of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different persuasions, and who are more especially interested in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their duration. As a member of the Roman Catholic Church I was more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particularly brought into contact with several of its priests, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whom I became intimately acquainted. To each of these men I expressed my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: astonishment and I explained my doubts; I found that they differed upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: matters of detail alone; and that they mainly attributed the peaceful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dominion of religion in their country to the separation of Church and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State. I do not hesitate to affirm that during my stay in America I did
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not meet with a single individual, of the clergy or of the laity, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not of the same opinion upon this point.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This led me to examine more attentively than I had hitherto done, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: station which the American clergy occupy in political society. I learned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with surprise that they filled no public appointments; *f not one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them is to be met with in the administration, and they are not even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represented in the legislative assemblies. In several States *g the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excludes them from political life, public opinion in all. And when I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: came to inquire into the prevailing spirit of the clergy I found that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most of its members seemed to retire of their own accord from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise of power, and that they made it the pride of their profession
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to abstain from politics.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: Unless this term be applied to the functions which many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them fill in the schools. Almost all education is entrusted to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clergy.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: See the Constitution of New York, art. 7, Section 4:-- "And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whereas the ministers of the gospel are, by their profession, dedicated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the service of God and the care of souls, and ought not to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diverted from the great duties of their functions: therefore no minister
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the gospel, or priest of any denomination whatsoever, shall at any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time hereafter, under any pretence or description whatever, be eligible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to, or capable of holding, any civil or military office or place within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this State."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See also the constitutions of North Carolina, art. 31; Virginia; South
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Carolina, art. I, Section 23; Kentucky, art. 2, Section 26; Tennessee,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: art. 8, Section I; Louisiana, art. 2, Section 22.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I heard them inveigh against ambition and deceit, under whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political opinions these vices might chance to lurk; but I learned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from their discourses that men are not guilty in the eye of God for any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions concerning political government which they may profess with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sincerity, any more than they are for their mistakes in building a house
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or in driving a furrow. I perceived that these ministers of the gospel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eschewed all parties with the anxiety attendant upon personal interest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These facts convinced me that what I had been told was true; and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then became my object to investigate their causes, and to inquire how it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happened that the real authority of religion was increased by a state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things which diminished its apparent force: these causes did not long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: escape my researches.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The short space of threescore years can never content the imagination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of man; nor can the imperfect joys of this world satisfy his heart. Man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alone, of all created beings, displays a natural contempt of existence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and yet a boundless desire to exist; he scorns life, but he dreads
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annihilation. These different feelings incessantly urge his soul to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contemplation of a future state, and religion directs his musings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thither. Religion, then, is simply another form of hope; and it is no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less natural to the human heart than hope itself. Men cannot abandon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their religious faith without a kind of aberration of intellect, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a sort of violent distortion of their true natures; but they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invincibly brought back to more pious sentiments; for unbelief is an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accident, and faith is the only permanent state of mankind. If we only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider religious institutions in a purely human point of view, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be said to derive an inexhaustible element of strength from man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself, since they belong to one of the constituent principles of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am aware that at certain times religion may strengthen this influence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which originates in itself, by the artificial power of the laws, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the support of those temporal institutions which direct society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Religions, intimately united to the governments of the earth, have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: known to exercise a sovereign authority derived from the twofold source
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of terror and of faith; but when a religion contracts an alliance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this nature, I do not hesitate to affirm that it commits the same error
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a man who should sacrifice his future to his present welfare; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in obtaining a power to which it has no claim, it risks that authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is rightfully its own. When a religion founds its empire upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desire of immortality which lives in every human heart, it may aspire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to universal dominion; but when it connects itself with a government,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it must necessarily adopt maxims which are only applicable to certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations. Thus, in forming an alliance with a political power, religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augments its authority over a few, and forfeits the hope of reigning
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over all.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As long as a religion rests upon those sentiments which are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consolation of all affliction, it may attract the affections of mankind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But if it be mixed up with the bitter passions of the world, it may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constrained to defend allies whom its interests, and not the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of love, have given to it; or to repel as antagonists men who are still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attached to its own spirit, however opposed they may be to the powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to which it is allied. The Church cannot share the temporal power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State without being the object of a portion of that animosity which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter excites.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The political powers which seem to be most firmly established have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently no better guarantee for their duration than the opinions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a generation, the interests of the time, or the life of an individual.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A law may modify the social condition which seems to be most fixed and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determinate; and with the social condition everything else must change.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The powers of society are more or less fugitive, like the years which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we spend upon the earth; they succeed each other with rapidity, like the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fleeting cares of life; and no government has ever yet been founded upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an invariable disposition of the human heart, or upon an imperishable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As long as a religion is sustained by those feelings, propensities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and passions which are found to occur under the same forms, at all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different periods of history, it may defy the efforts of time; or at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: least it can only be destroyed by another religion. But when religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clings to the interests of the world, it becomes almost as fragile a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing as the powers of earth. It is the only one of them all which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can hope for immortality; but if it be connected with their ephemeral
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, it shares their fortunes, and may fall with those transient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions which supported them for a day. The alliance which religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contracts with political powers must needs be onerous to itself; since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it does not require their assistance to live, and by giving them its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assistance to live, and by giving them its assistance it may be exposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to decay.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The danger which I have just pointed out always exists, but it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not always equally visible. In some ages governments seem to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperishable; in others, the existence of society appears to be more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precarious than the life of man. Some constitutions plunge the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens into a lethargic somnolence, and others rouse them to feverish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excitement. When governments appear to be so strong, and laws so stable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men do not perceive the dangers which may accrue from a union of Church
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and State. When governments display so much weakness, and laws so much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconstancy, the danger is self-evident, but it is no longer possible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to avoid it; to be effectual, measures must be taken to discover its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approach.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In proportion as a nation assumes a democratic condition of society, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as communities display democratic propensities, it becomes more and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous to connect religion with political institutions; for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time is coming when authority will be bandied from hand to hand, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political theories will succeed each other, and when men, laws, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitutions will disappear, or be modified from day to day, and this,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not for a season only, but unceasingly. Agitation and mutability are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inherent in the nature of democratic republics, just as stagnation and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inertness are the law of absolute monarchies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the Americans, who change the head of the Government once in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: four years, who elect new legislators every two years, and renew the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provincial officers every twelvemonth; if the Americans, who have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandoned the political world to the attempts of innovators, had not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: placed religion beyond their reach, where could it abide in the ebb and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flow of human opinions? where would that respect which belongs to it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be paid, amidst the struggles of faction? and what would become of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immortality, in the midst of perpetual decay? The American clergy were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the first to perceive this truth, and to act in conformity with it. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: saw that they must renounce their religious influence, if they were to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strive for political power; and they chose to give up the support of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State, rather than to share its vicissitudes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America, religion is perhaps less powerful than it has been at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain periods in the history of certain peoples; but its influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is more lasting. It restricts itself to its own resources, but of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: none can deprive it: its circle is limited to certain principles, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those principles are entirely its own, and under its undisputed control.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On every side in Europe we hear voices complaining of the absence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious faith, and inquiring the means of restoring to religion some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remnant of its pristine authority. It seems to me that we must first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attentively consider what ought to be the natural state of men with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regard to religion at the present time; and when we know what we have to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hope and to fear, we may discern the end to which our efforts ought to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be directed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The two great dangers which threaten the existence of religions are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: schism and indifference. In ages of fervent devotion, men sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandon their religion, but they only shake it off in order to adopt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another. Their faith changes the objects to which it is directed, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it suffers no decline. The old religion then excites enthusiastic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attachment or bitter enmity in either party; some leave it with anger,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others cling to it with increased devotedness, and although persuasions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differ, irreligion is unknown. Such, however, is not the case when a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious belief is secretly undermined by doctrines which may be termed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negative, since they deny the truth of one religion without affirming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of any other. Progidious revolutions then take place in the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind, without the apparent co-operation of the passions of man, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost without his knowledge. Men lose the objects of their fondest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hopes, as if through forgetfulness. They are carried away by an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperceptible current which they have not the courage to stem, but which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they follow with regret, since it bears them from a faith they love, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a scepticism that plunges them into despair.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In ages which answer to this description, men desert their religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions from lukewarmness rather than from dislike; they do not reject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them, but the sentiments by which they were once fostered disappear. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if the unbeliever does not admit religion to be true, he still considers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it useful. Regarding religious institutions in a human point of view,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he acknowledges their influence upon manners and legislation. He admits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they may serve to make men live in peace with one another, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prepare them gently for the hour of death. He regrets the faith which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he has lost; and as he is deprived of a treasure which he has learned to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estimate at its full value, he scruples to take it from those who still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possess it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, those who continue to believe are not afraid openly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to avow their faith. They look upon those who do not share their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persuasion as more worthy of pity than of opposition; and they are aware
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that to acquire the esteem of the unbelieving, they are not obliged to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: follow their example. They are hostile to no one in the world; and as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they do not consider the society in which they live as an arena in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion is bound to face its thousand deadly foes, they love their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries, whilst they condemn their weaknesses and lament their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: errors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As those who do not believe, conceal their incredulity; and as those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe, display their faith, public opinion pronounces itself in favor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of religion: love, support, and honor are bestowed upon it, and it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only by searching the human soul that we can detect the wounds which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has received. The mass of mankind, who are never without the feeling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of religion, do not perceive anything at variance with the established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faith. The instinctive desire of a future life brings the crowd about
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the altar, and opens the hearts of men to the precepts and consolations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of religion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But this picture is not applicable to us: for there are men amongst us
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who have ceased to believe in Christianity, without adopting any other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion; others who are in the perplexities of doubt, and who already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affect not to believe; and others, again, who are afraid to avow that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christian faith which they still cherish in secret.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amidst these lukewarm partisans and ardent antagonists a small number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believers exist, who are ready to brave all obstacles and to scorn all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers in defence of their faith. They have done violence to human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weakness, in order to rise superior to public opinion. Excited by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effort they have made, they scarcely knew where to stop; and as they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know that the first use which the French made of independence was to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attack religion, they look upon their contemporaries with dread, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they recoil in alarm from the liberty which their fellow-citizens are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seeking to obtain. As unbelief appears to them to be a novelty, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comprise all that is new in one indiscriminate animosity. They are at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: war with their age and country, and they look upon every opinion which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is put forth there as the necessary enemy of the faith.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such is not the natural state of men with regard to religion at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present day; and some extraordinary or incidental cause must be at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: work in France to prevent the human mind from following its original
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities and to drive it beyond the limits at which it ought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally to stop. I am intimately convinced that this extraordinary and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incidental cause is the close connection of politics and religion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The unbelievers of Europe attack the Christians as their political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opponents, rather than as their religious adversaries; they hate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christian religion as the opinion of a party, much more than as an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: error of belief; and they reject the clergy less because they are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives of the Divinity than because they are the allies of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Europe, Christianity has been intimately united to the powers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the earth. Those powers are now in decay, and it is, as it were, buried
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under their ruins. The living body of religion has been bound down
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the dead corpse of superannuated polity: cut but the bonds which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restrain it, and that which is alive will rise once more. I know not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what could restore the Christian Church of Europe to the energy of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: earlier days; that power belongs to God alone; but it may be the effect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of human policy to leave the faith in the full exercise of the strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it still retains.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: How The Instruction, The Habits, And The Practical Experience Of The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans Promote The Success Of Their Democratic Institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What is to be understood by the instruction of the American people--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human mind more superficially instructed in the United States than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe--No one completely uninstructed--Reason of this--Rapidity with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which opinions are diffused even in the uncultivated States of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: West--Practical experience more serviceable to the Americans than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: book-learning.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have but little to add to what I have already said concerning the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence which the instruction and the habits of the Americans exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the maintenance of their political institutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America has hitherto produced very few writers of distinction; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possesses no great historians, and not a single eminent poet. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of that country look upon what are properly styled literary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuits with a kind of disapprobation; and there are towns of very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: second-rate importance in Europe in which more literary works are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annually published than in the twenty-four States of the Union put
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together. The spirit of the Americans is averse to general ideas; and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not seek theoretical discoveries. Neither politics nor manufactures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direct them to these occupations; and although new laws are perpetually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enacted in the United States, no great writers have hitherto inquired
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the general principles of their legislation. The Americans have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lawyers and commentators, but no jurists; *h and they furnish examples
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather than lessons to the world. The same observation applies to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mechanical arts. In America, the inventions of Europe are adopted with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sagacity; they are perfected, and adapted with admirable skill to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants of the country. Manufactures exist, but the science of manufacture
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not cultivated; and they have good workmen, but very few inventors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Fulton was obliged to proffer his services to foreign nations for a long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time before he was able to devote them to his own country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: [This cannot be said with truth of the country of Kent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Story, and Wheaton.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The observer who is desirous of forming an opinion on the state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instruction amongst the Anglo-Americans must consider the same object
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from two different points of view. If he only singles out the learned,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he will be astonished to find how rare they are; but if he counts the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorant, the American people will appear to be the most enlightened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community in the world. The whole population, as I observed in another
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place, is situated between these two extremes. In New England, every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen receives the elementary notions of human knowledge; he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moreover taught the doctrines and the evidences of his religion, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: history of his country, and the leading features of its Constitution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the States of Connecticut and Massachusetts, it is extremely rare to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find a man imperfectly acquainted with all these things, and a person
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wholly ignorant of them is a sort of phenomenon.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When I compare the Greek and Roman republics with these American States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manuscript libraries of the former, and their rude population, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the innumerable journals and the enlightened people of the latter; when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I remember all the attempts which are made to judge the modern republics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the assistance of those of antiquity, and to infer what will happen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in our time from what took place two thousand years ago, I am tempted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to burn my books, in order to apply none but novel ideas to so novel a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What I have said of New England must not, however, be applied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indistinctly to the whole Union; as we advance towards the West or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South, the instruction of the people diminishes. In the States which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adjacent to the Gulf of Mexico, a certain number of individuals may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be found, as in our own countries, who are devoid of the rudiments of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instruction. But there is not a single district in the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sunk in complete ignorance; and for a very simple reason: the peoples
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe started from the darkness of a barbarous condition, to advance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: toward the light of civilization; their progress has been unequal;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some of them have improved apace, whilst others have loitered in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course, and some have stopped, and are still sleeping upon the way. *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: [In the Northern States the number of persons destitute of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instruction is inconsiderable, the largest number being 241,152 in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State of New York (according to Spaulding's "Handbook of American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Statistics" for 1874); but in the South no less than 1,516,339 whites
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and 2,671,396 colored persons are returned as "illiterate."]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such has not been the case in the United States. The Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settled in a state of civilization, upon that territory which their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descendants occupy; they had not to begin to learn, and it was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficient for them not to forget. Now the children of these same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans are the persons who, year by year, transport their dwellings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the wilds; and with their dwellings their acquired information and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their esteem for knowledge. Education has taught them the utility of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instruction, and has enabled them to transmit that instruction to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: posterity. In the United States society has no infancy, but it is born
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in man's estate.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans never use the word "peasant," because they have no idea of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the peculiar class which that term denotes; the ignorance of more remote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ages, the simplicity of rural life, and the rusticity of the villager
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have not been preserved amongst them; and they are alike unacquainted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the virtues, the vices, the coarse habits, and the simple graces
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an early stage of civilization. At the extreme borders of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Confederate States, upon the confines of society and of the wilderness,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a population of bold adventurers have taken up their abode, who pierce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the solitudes of the American woods, and seek a country there, in order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to escape that poverty which awaited them in their native provinces. As
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soon as the pioneer arrives upon the spot which is to serve him for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retreat, he fells a few trees and builds a loghouse. Nothing can offer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a more miserable aspect than these isolated dwellings. The traveller
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who approaches one of them towards nightfall, sees the flicker of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hearth-flame through the chinks in the walls; and at night, if the wind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rises, he hears the roof of boughs shake to and fro in the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great forest trees. Who would not suppose that this poor hut is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asylum of rudeness and ignorance? Yet no sort of comparison can be drawn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the pioneer and the dwelling which shelters him. Everything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about him is primitive and unformed, but he is himself the result of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor and the experience of eighteen centuries. He wears the dress,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and he speaks the language of cities; he is acquainted with the past,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curious of the future, and ready for argument upon the present; he is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in short, a highly civilized being, who consents, for a time, to inhabit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the backwoods, and who penetrates into the wilds of the New World with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Bible, an axe, and a file of newspapers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is difficult to imagine the incredible rapidity with which public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion circulates in the midst of these deserts. *j I do not think that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so much intellectual intercourse takes place in the most enlightened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and populous districts of France. *k It cannot be doubted that, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States, the instruction of the people powerfully contributes to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the support of a democratic republic; and such must always be the case,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe, where instruction which awakens the understanding is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separated from moral education which amends the heart. But I by no means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exaggerate this benefit, and I am still further from thinking, as so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many people do think in Europe, that men can be instantaneously made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens by teaching them to read and write. True information is mainly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derived from experience; and if the Americans had not been gradually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustomed to govern themselves, their book-learning would not assist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them much at the present day.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: I travelled along a portion of the frontier of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States in a sort of cart which was termed the mail. We passed, day and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: night, with great rapidity along the roads which were scarcely marked
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out, through immense forests; when the gloom of the woods became
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impenetrable the coachman lighted branches of fir, and we journeyed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: along by the light they cast. From time to time we came to a hut in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the midst of the forest, which was a post-office. The mail dropped an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enormous bundle of letters at the door of this isolated dwelling, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we pursued our way at full gallop, leaving the inhabitants of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighboring log houses to send for their share of the treasure.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [When the author visited America the locomotive and the railroad were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scarcely invented, and not yet introduced in the United States. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is superfluous to point out the immense effect of those inventions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in extending civilization and developing the resources of that vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent. In 1831 there were 51 miles of railway in the United States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in 1872 there were 60,000 miles of railway.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: In 1832 each inhabitant of Michigan paid a sum equivalent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to 1 fr. 22 cent. (French money) to the post-office revenue, and each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitant of the Floridas paid 1 fr. 5 cent. (See "National Calendar,"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1833, p. 244.) In the same year each inhabitant of the Departement du
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nord paid 1 fr. 4 cent. to the revenue of the French post-office. (See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the "Compte rendu de l'administration des Finances," 1833, p. 623.)
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Now the State of Michigan only contained at that time 7 inhabitants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: per square league and Florida only 5: the public instruction and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commercial activity of these districts is inferior to that of most of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States in the Union, whilst the Departement du Nord, which contains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 3,400 inhabitants per square league, is one of the most enlightened and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturing parts of France.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have lived a great deal with the people in the United States, and I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot express how much I admire their experience and their good sense.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An American should never be allowed to speak of Europe; for he will then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: probably display a vast deal of presumption and very foolish pride. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will take up with those crude and vague notions which are so useful to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ignorant all over the world. But if you question him respecting his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own country, the cloud which dimmed his intelligence will immediately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disperse; his language will become as clear and as precise as his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thoughts. He will inform you what his rights are, and by what means he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercises them; he will be able to point out the customs which obtain in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the political world. You will find that he is well acquainted with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules of the administration, and that he is familiar with the mechanism
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the laws. The citizen of the United States does not acquire his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practical science and his positive notions from books; the instruction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he has acquired may have prepared him for receiving those ideas, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it did not furnish them. The American learns to know the laws by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: participating in the act of legislation; and he takes a lesson in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forms of government from governing. The great work of society is ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: going on beneath his eyes, and, as it were, under his hands.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States politics are the end and aim of education;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in Europe its principal object is to fit men for private life. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interference of the citizens in public affairs is too rare an occurrence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for it to be anticipated beforehand. Upon casting a glance over society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the two hemispheres, these differences are indicated even by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: external aspect.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Europe we frequently introduce the ideas and the habits of private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life into public affairs; and as we pass at once from the domestic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circle to the government of the State, we may frequently be heard to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discuss the great interests of society in the same manner in which we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: converse with our friends. The Americans, on the other hand, transfuse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the habits of public life into their manners in private; and in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country the jury is introduced into the games of schoolboys, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parliamentary forms are observed in the order of a feast.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVII: Principal Causes Maintaining The Democratic Republic--Part IV
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Laws Contribute More To The Maintenance Of The Democratic Republic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In The United States Than The Physical Circumstances Of The Country, And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Manners More Than The Laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the nations of America have a democratic state of society--Yet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic institutions only subsist amongst the Anglo-Americans--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Spaniards of South America, equally favored by physical causes as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans, unable to maintain a democratic republic--Mexico,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has adopted the Constitution of the United States, in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predicament--The Anglo-Americans of the West less able to maintain it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than those of the East--Reason of these different results.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have remarked that the maintenance of democratic institutions in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States is attributable to the circumstances, the laws, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners of that country. *l Most Europeans are only acquainted with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the first of these three causes, and they are apt to give it a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preponderating importance which it does not really possess.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: I remind the reader of the general signification which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I give to the word "manners," namely, the moral and intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics of social man taken collectively.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is true that the Anglo-Saxons settled in the New World in a state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social equality; the low-born and the noble were not to be found amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; and professional prejudices were always as entirely unknown as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudices of birth. Thus, as the condition of society was democratic,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the empire of democracy was established without difficulty. But this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstance is by no means peculiar to the United States; almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the trans-Atlantic colonies were founded by men equal amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, or who became so by inhabiting them. In no one part of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the New World have Europeans been able to create an aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, democratic institutions prosper nowhere but in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American Union has no enemies to contend with; it stands in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilds like an island in the ocean. But the Spaniards of South America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were no less isolated by nature; yet their position has not relieved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them from the charge of standing armies. They make war upon each other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when they have no foreign enemies to oppose; and the Anglo-American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy is the only one which has hitherto been able to maintain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself in peace. *m
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: [A remark which, since the great Civil War of 1861-65,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceases to be applicable.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The territory of the Union presents a boundless field to human activity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and inexhaustible materials for industry and labor. The passion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth takes the place of ambition, and the warmth of faction is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mitigated by a sense of prosperity. But in what portion of the globe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall we meet with more fertile plains, with mightier rivers, or with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more unexplored and inexhaustible riches than in South America?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, South America has been unable to maintain democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions. If the welfare of nations depended on their being placed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a remote position, with an unbounded space of habitable territory
