author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before them, the Spaniards of South America would have no reason to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complain of their fate. And although they might enjoy less prosperity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the inhabitants of the United States, their lot might still be such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to excite the envy of some nations in Europe. There are, however, no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations upon the face of the earth more miserable than those of South
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, not only are physical causes inadequate to produce results
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: analogous to those which occur in North America, but they are unable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to raise the population of South America above the level of European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, where they act in a contrary direction. Physical causes do not,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, affect the destiny of nations so much as has been supposed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have met with men in New England who were on the point of leaving a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, where they might have remained in easy circumstances, to go to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seek their fortune in the wilds. Not far from that district I found
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a French population in Canada, which was closely crowded on a narrow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory, although the same wilds were at hand; and whilst the emigrant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the United States purchased an extensive estate with the earnings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a short term of labor, the Canadian paid as much for land as he would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have done in France. Nature offers the solitudes of the New World to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europeans; but they are not always acquainted with the means of turning
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her gifts to account. Other peoples of America have the same physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions of prosperity as the Anglo-Americans, but without their laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their manners; and these peoples are wretched. The laws and manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Anglo-Americans are therefore that efficient cause of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greatness which is the object of my inquiry.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am far from supposing that the American laws are preeminently good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in themselves; I do not hold them to be applicable to all democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peoples; and several of them seem to be dangerous, even in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. Nevertheless, it cannot be denied that the American legislation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken collectively, is extremely well adapted to the genius of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people and the nature of the country which it is intended to govern. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American laws are therefore good, and to them must be attributed a large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portion of the success which attends the government of democracy in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America: but I do not believe them to be the principal cause of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: success; and if they seem to me to have more influence upon the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happiness of the Americans than the nature of the country, on the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand there is reason to believe that their effect is still inferior to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that produced by the manners of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal laws undoubtedly constitute the most important part of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation of the United States. Mexico, which is not less fortunately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: situated than the Anglo-American Union, has adopted the same laws, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is unable to accustom itself to the government of democracy. Some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other cause is therefore at work, independently of those physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances and peculiar laws which enable the democracy to rule in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Another still more striking proof may be adduced. Almost all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of the territory of the Union are the descendants of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common stock; they speak the same language, they worship God in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner, they are affected by the same physical causes, and they obey the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same laws. Whence, then, do their characteristic differences arise?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Why, in the Eastern States of the Union, does the republican government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: display vigor and regularity, and proceed with mature deliberation?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whence does it derive the wisdom and the durability which mark its acts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst in the Western States, on the contrary, society seems to be ruled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the powers of chance? There, public business is conducted with an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irregularity and a passionate and feverish excitement, which does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: announce a long or sure duration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am no longer comparing the Anglo-American States to foreign nations;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but I am contrasting them with each other, and endeavoring to discover
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: why they are so unlike. The arguments which are derived from the nature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the country and the difference of legislation are here all set aside.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Recourse must be had to some other cause; and what other cause can there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be except the manners of the people?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is in the Eastern States that the Anglo-Americans have been longest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustomed to the government of democracy, and that they have adopted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the habits and conceived the notions most favorable to its maintenance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democracy has gradually penetrated into their customs, their opinions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the forms of social intercourse; it is to be found in all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: details of daily life equally as in the laws. In the Eastern States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the instruction and practical education of the people have been most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfected, and religion has been most thoroughly amalgamated with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty. Now these habits, opinions, customs, and convictions are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precisely the constituent elements of that which I have denominated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the Western States, on the contrary, a portion of the same advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is still wanting. Many of the Americans of the West were born in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: woods, and they mix the ideas and the customs of savage life with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization of their parents. Their passions are more intense; their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious morality less authoritative; and their convictions less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secure. The inhabitants exercise no sort of control over their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-citizens, for they are scarcely acquainted with each other. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations of the West display, to a certain extent, the inexperience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the rude habits of a people in its infancy; for although they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed of old elements, their assemblage is of recent date.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The manners of the Americans of the United States are, then, the real
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause which renders that people the only one of the American nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that is able to support a democratic government; and it is the influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of manners which produces the different degrees of order and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity that may be distinguished in the several Anglo-American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies. Thus the effect which the geographical position of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country may have upon the duration of democratic institutions is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exaggerated in Europe. Too much importance is attributed to legislation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: too little to manners. These three great causes serve, no doubt, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulate and direct the American democracy; but if they were to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be classed in their proper order, I should say that the physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances are less efficient than the laws, and the laws very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subordinate to the manners of the people. I am convinced that the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantageous situation and the best possible laws cannot maintain a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution in spite of the manners of a country; whilst the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may turn the most unfavorable positions and the worst laws to some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantage. The importance of manners is a common truth to which study
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and experience incessantly direct our attention. It may be regarded as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a central point in the range of human observation, and the common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: termination of all inquiry. So seriously do I insist upon this head,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that if I have hitherto failed in making the reader feel the important
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence which I attribute to the practical experience, the habits,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the opinions, in short, to the manners of the Americans, upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of their institutions, I have failed in the principal object
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of my work.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whether Laws And Manners Are Sufficient To Maintain Democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Institutions In Other Countries Besides America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Anglo-Americans, if transported into Europe, would be obliged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to modify their laws--Distinction to be made between democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions and American institutions--Democratic laws may be conceived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: better than, or at least different from, those which the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy has adopted--The example of America only proves that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is possible to regulate democracy by the assistance of manners and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have asserted that the success of democratic institutions in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States is more intimately connected with the laws themselves, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manners of the people, than with the nature of the country. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does it follow that the same causes would of themselves produce the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results, if they were put into operation elsewhere; and if the country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is no adequate substitute for laws and manners, can laws and manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in their turn prove a substitute for the country? It will readily be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood that the necessary elements of a reply to this question are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wanting: other peoples are to be found in the New World besides the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans, and as these people are affected by the same physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances as the latter, they may fairly be compared together. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there are no nations out of America which have adopted the same laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and manners, being destitute of the physical advantages peculiar to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans. No standard of comparison therefore exists, and we can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only hazard an opinion upon this subject.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It appears to me, in the first place, that a careful distinction must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be made between the institutions of the United States and democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions in general. When I reflect upon the state of Europe, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mighty nations, its populous cities, its formidable armies, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the complex nature of its politics, I cannot suppose that even the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans, if they were transported to our hemisphere, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their ideas, their religion, and their manners, could exist without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerably altering their laws. But a democratic nation may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagined, organized differently from the American people. It is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible to conceive a government really established upon the will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the majority; but in which the majority, repressing its natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensity to equality, should consent, with a view to the order and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stability of the State, to invest a family or an individual with all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the prerogatives of the executive. A democratic society might exist, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the forces of the nation would be more centralized than they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States; the people would exercise a less direct and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less irresistible influence upon public affairs, and yet every citizen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invested with certain rights would participate, within his sphere,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the conduct of the government. The observations I made amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans induce me to believe that democratic institutions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this kind, prudently introduced into society, so as gradually to mix
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the habits and to be interfused with the opinions of the people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might subsist in other countries besides America. If the laws of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States were the only imaginable democratic laws, or the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfect which it is possible to conceive, I should admit that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: success of those institutions affords no proof of the success of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic institutions in general, in a country less favored by natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances. But as the laws of America appear to me to be defective
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in several respects, and as I can readily imagine others of the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general nature, the peculiar advantages of that country do not prove
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that democratic institutions cannot succeed in a nation less favored by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances, if ruled by better laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If human nature were different in America from what it is elsewhere; or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if the social condition of the Americans engendered habits and opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst them different from those which originate in the same social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition in the Old World, the American democracies would afford
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no means of predicting what may occur in other democracies. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans displayed the same propensities as all other democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, and if their legislators had relied upon the nature of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country and the favor of circumstances to restrain those propensities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within due limits, the prosperity of the United States would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusively attributable to physical causes, and it would afford no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encouragement to a people inclined to imitate their example, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sharing their natural advantages. But neither of these suppositions is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: borne out by facts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the same passions are to be met with as in Europe; some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originating in human nature, others in the democratic condition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society. Thus in the United States I found that restlessness of heart
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is natural to men, when all ranks are nearly equal and the chances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of elevation are the same to all. I found the democratic feeling of envy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expressed under a thousand different forms. I remarked that the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently displayed, in the conduct of affairs, a consummate mixture
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of ignorance and presumption; and I inferred that in America, men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are liable to the same failings and the same absurdities as amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ourselves. But upon examining the state of society more attentively,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I speedily discovered that the Americans had made great and successful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efforts to counteract these imperfections of human nature, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: correct the natural defects of democracy. Their divers municipal laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeared to me to be a means of restraining the ambition of the citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within a narrow sphere, and of turning those same passions which might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have worked havoc in the State, to the good of the township or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parish. The American legislators have succeeded to a certain extent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposing the notion of rights to the feelings of envy; the permanence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the religious world to the continual shifting of politics; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience of the people to its theoretical ignorance; and its practical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge of business to the impatience of its desires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans, then, have not relied upon the nature of their country to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: counterpoise those dangers which originate in their Constitution and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in their political laws. To evils which are common to all democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peoples they have applied remedies which none but themselves had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever thought of before; and although they were the first to make the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experiment, they have succeeded in it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The manners and laws of the Americans are not the only ones which may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suit a democratic people; but the Americans have shown that it would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wrong to despair of regulating democracy by the aid of manners and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws. If other nations should borrow this general and pregnant idea from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans, without however intending to imitate them in the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: application which they have made of it; if they should attempt to fit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves for that social condition, which it seems to be the will of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Providence to impose upon the generations of this age, and so to escape
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the despotism or the anarchy which threatens them; what reason is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there to suppose that their efforts would not be crowned with success?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The organization and the establishment of democracy in Christendom is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great political problem of the time. The Americans, unquestionably,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have not resolved this problem, but they furnish useful data to those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who undertake the task.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Importance Of What Precedes With Respect To The State Of Europe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may readily be discovered with what intention I undertook the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foregoing inquiries. The question here discussed is interesting not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the United States, but to the whole world; it concerns, not a nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but all mankind. If those nations whose social condition is democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could only remain free as long as they are inhabitants of the wilds,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we could not but despair of the future destiny of the human race; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy is rapidly acquiring a more extended sway, and the wilds are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually peopled with men. If it were true that laws and manners are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insufficient to maintain democratic institutions, what refuge would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain open to the nations, except the despotism of a single individual?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am aware that there are many worthy persons at the present time who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not alarmed at this latter alternative, and who are so tired of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty as to be glad of repose, far from those storms by which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is attended. But these individuals are ill acquainted with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: haven towards which they are bound. They are so deluded by their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recollections, as to judge the tendency of absolute power by what it was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formerly, and not by what it might become at the present time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If absolute power were re-established amongst the democratic nations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe, I am persuaded that it would assume a new form, and appear under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: features unknown to our forefathers. There was a time in Europe when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws and the consent of the people had invested princes with almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unlimited authority; but they scarcely ever availed themselves of it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not speak of the prerogatives of the nobility, of the authority of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supreme courts of justice, of corporations and their chartered rights,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or of provincial privileges, which served to break the blows of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign authority, and to maintain a spirit of resistance in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation. Independently of these political institutions--which, however
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposed they might be to personal liberty, served to keep alive the love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of freedom in the mind of the public, and which may be esteemed to have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been useful in this respect--the manners and opinions of the nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confined the royal authority within barriers which were not less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful, although they were less conspicuous. Religion, the affections
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the people, the benevolence of the prince, the sense of honor, family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pride, provincial prejudices, custom, and public opinion limited the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of kings, and restrained their authority within an invisible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circle. The constitution of nations was despotic at that time, but their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners were free. Princes had the right, but they had neither the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor the desire, of doing whatever they pleased.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But what now remains of those barriers which formerly arrested the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aggressions of tyranny? Since religion has lost its empire over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: souls of men, the most prominent boundary which divided good from evil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is overthrown; the very elements of the moral world are indeterminate;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the princes and the peoples of the earth are guided by chance, and none
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can define the natural limits of despotism and the bounds of license.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Long revolutions have forever destroyed the respect which surrounded the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rulers of the State; and since they have been relieved from the burden
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of public esteem, princes may henceforward surrender themselves without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fear to the seductions of arbitrary power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When kings find that the hearts of their subjects are turned towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them, they are clement, because they are conscious of their strength,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they are chary of the affection of their people, because the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affection of their people is the bulwark of the throne. A mutual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interchange of good-will then takes place between the prince and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, which resembles the gracious intercourse of domestic society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The subjects may murmur at the sovereign's decree, but they are grieved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to displease him; and the sovereign chastises his subjects with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: light hand of parental affection.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But when once the spell of royalty is broken in the tumult of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution; when successive monarchs have crossed the throne, so as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alternately to display to the people the weakness of their right and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harshness of their power, the sovereign is no longer regarded by any as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Father of the State, and he is feared by all as its master. If he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be weak, he is despised; if he be strong, he is detested. He himself is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: full of animosity and alarm; he finds that he is as a stranger in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own country, and he treats his subjects like conquered enemies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the provinces and the towns formed so many different nations in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: midst of their common country, each of them had a will of its own, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was opposed to the general spirit of subjection; but now that all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parts of the same empire, after having lost their immunities, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customs, their prejudices, their traditions, and their names, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjected and accustomed to the same laws, it is not more difficult to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppress them collectively than it was formerly to oppress them singly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whilst the nobles enjoyed their power, and indeed long after that power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was lost, the honor of aristocracy conferred an extraordinary degree of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: force upon their personal opposition. They afford instances of men who,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding their weakness, still entertained a high opinion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their personal value, and dared to cope single-handed with the efforts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the public authority. But at the present day, when all ranks are more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more confounded, when the individual disappears in the throng, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is easily lost in the midst of a common obscurity, when the honor of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchy has almost lost its empire without being succeeded by public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtue, and when nothing can enable man to rise above himself, who shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: say at what point the exigencies of power and the servility of weakness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will stop?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As long as family feeling was kept alive, the antagonist of oppression
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was never alone; he looked about him, and found his clients, his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereditary friends, and his kinsfolk. If this support was wanting, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was sustained by his ancestors and animated by his posterity. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when patrimonial estates are divided, and when a few years suffice to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confound the distinctions of a race, where can family feeling be found?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What force can there be in the customs of a country which has changed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and is still perpetually changing, its aspect; in which every act of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tyranny has a precedent, and every crime an example; in which there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is nothing so old that its antiquity can save it from destruction, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing so unparalleled that its novelty can prevent it from being done?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What resistance can be offered by manners of so pliant a make that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have already often yielded? What strength can even public opinion have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retained, when no twenty persons are connected by a common tie; when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not a man, nor a family, nor chartered corporation, nor class, nor free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institution, has the power of representing or exerting that opinion;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and when every citizen--being equally weak, equally poor, and equally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependent--has only his personal impotence to oppose to the organized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: force of the government?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The annals of France furnish nothing analogous to the condition in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that country might then be thrown. But it may more aptly be assimilated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the times of old, and to those hideous eras of Roman oppression, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manners of the people were corrupted, their traditions obliterated,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their habits destroyed, their opinions shaken, and freedom, expelled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the laws, could find no refuge in the land; when nothing protected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens, and the citizens no longer protected themselves; when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human nature was the sport of man, and princes wearied out the clemency
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Heaven before they exhausted the patience of their subjects. Those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who hope to revive the monarchy of Henry IV or of Louis XIV, appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to me to be afflicted with mental blindness; and when I consider the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present condition of several European nations--a condition to which all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the others tend--I am led to believe that they will soon be left with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no other alternative than democratic liberty, or the tyranny of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Caesars. *n
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: [This prediction of the return of France to imperial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotism, and of the true character of that despotic power, was written
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in 1832, and realized to the letter in 1852.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And indeed it is deserving of consideration, whether men are to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely emancipated or entirely enslaved; whether their rights are to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be made equal, or wholly taken away from them. If the rulers of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were reduced either gradually to raise the crowd to their own level,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or to sink the citizens below that of humanity, would not the doubts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many be resolved, the consciences of many be healed, and the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prepared to make great sacrifices with little difficulty? In that case,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the gradual growth of democratic manners and institutions should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regarded, not as the best, but as the only means of preserving freedom;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and without liking the government of democracy, it might be adopted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the most applicable and the fairest remedy for the present ills of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is difficult to associate a people in the work of government; but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is still more difficult to supply it with experience, and to inspire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it with the feelings which it requires in order to govern well. I grant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the caprices of democracy are perpetual; its instruments are rude;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its laws imperfect. But if it were true that soon no just medium would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist between the empire of democracy and the dominion of a single arm,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should we not rather incline towards the former than submit voluntarily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the latter? And if complete equality be our fate, is it not better to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be levelled by free institutions than by despotic power?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Those who, after having read this book, should imagine that my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intention in writing it has been to propose the laws and manners of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Anglo-Americans for the imitation of all democratic peoples, would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commit a very great mistake; they must have paid more attention to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form than to the substance of my ideas. My aim has been to show, by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: example of America, that laws, and especially manners, may exist which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will allow a democratic people to remain free. But I am very far from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thinking that we ought to follow the example of the American democracy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and copy the means which it has employed to attain its ends; for I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am well aware of the influence which the nature of a country and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political precedents exercise upon a constitution; and I should regard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it as a great misfortune for mankind if liberty were to exist all over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world under the same forms.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But I am of opinion that if we do not succeed in gradually introducing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic institutions into France, and if we despair of imparting to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens those ideas and sentiments which first prepare them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for freedom, and afterwards allow them to enjoy it, there will be no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence at all, either for the middling classes or the nobility,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the poor or for the rich, but an equal tyranny over all; and I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foresee that if the peaceable empire of the majority be not founded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst us in time, we shall sooner or later arrive at the unlimited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of a single despot.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races In The United States--Part I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Present And Probable Future Condition Of The Three Races Which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Inhabit The Territory Of The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principal part of the task which I had imposed upon myself is now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: performed. I have shown, as far as I was able, the laws and the manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the American democracy. Here I might stop; but the reader would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps feel that I had not satisfied his expectations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The absolute supremacy of democracy is not all that we meet with in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America; the inhabitants of the New World may be considered from more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than one point of view. In the course of this work my subject has often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: led me to speak of the Indians and the Negroes; but I have never been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able to stop in order to show what place these two races occupy in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: midst of the democratic people whom I was engaged in describing. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mentioned in what spirit, and according to what laws, the Anglo-American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union was formed; but I could only glance at the dangers which menace
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that confederation, whilst it was equally impossible for me to give a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: detailed account of its chances of duration, independently of its laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and manners. When speaking of the united republican States, I hazarded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no conjectures upon the permanence of republican forms in the New World,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and when making frequent allusion to the commercial activity which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reigns in the Union, I was unable to inquire into the future condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Americans as a commercial people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These topics are collaterally connected with my subject without forming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a part of it; they are American without being democratic; and to portray
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy has been my principal aim. It was therefore necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: postpone these questions, which I now take up as the proper termination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of my work.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The territory now occupied or claimed by the American Union spreads from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the shores of the Atlantic to those of the Pacific Ocean. On the east
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and west its limits are those of the continent itself. On the south it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advances nearly to the tropic, and it extends upwards to the icy regions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the North. The human beings who are scattered over this space do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form, as in Europe, so many branches of the same stock. Three races,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally distinct, and, I might almost say, hostile to each other, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discoverable amongst them at the first glance. Almost insurmountable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barriers had been raised between them by education and by law, as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as by their origin and outward characteristics; but fortune has brought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them together on the same soil, where, although they are mixed, they do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not amalgamate, and each race fulfils its destiny apart.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst these widely differing families of men, the first which attracts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention, the superior in intelligence, in power and in enjoyment, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the white or European, the man pre-eminent; and in subordinate grades,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the negro and the Indian. These two unhappy races have nothing in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common; neither birth, nor features, nor language, nor habits. Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only resemblance lies in their misfortunes. Both of them occupy an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferior rank in the country they inhabit; both suffer from tyranny; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if their wrongs are not the same, they originate, at any rate, with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same authors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If we reasoned from what passes in the world, we should almost say that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the European is to the other races of mankind, what man is to the lower
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animals;--he makes them subservient to his use; and when he cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subdue, he destroys them. Oppression has, at one stroke, deprived the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descendants of the Africans of almost all the privileges of humanity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The negro of the United States has lost all remembrance of his country;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the language which his forefathers spoke is never heard around him; he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abjured their religion and forgot their customs when he ceased to belong
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to Africa, without acquiring any claim to European privileges. But he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains half way between the two communities; sold by the one, repulsed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the other; finding not a spot in the universe to call by the name
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of country, except the faint image of a home which the shelter of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: master's roof affords.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The negro has no family; woman is merely the temporary companion of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures, and his children are upon an equality with himself from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the moment of their birth. Am I to call it a proof of God's mercy or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a visitation of his wrath, that man in certain states appears to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insensible to his extreme wretchedness, and almost affects, with a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: depraved taste, the cause of his misfortunes? The negro, who is plunged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this abyss of evils, scarcely feels his own calamitous situation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Violence made him a slave, and the habit of servitude gives him the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thoughts and desires of a slave; he admires his tyrants more than he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hates them, and finds his joy and his pride in the servile imitation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who oppress him: his understanding is degraded to the level of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soul.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The negro enters upon slavery as soon as he is born: nay, he may have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been purchased in the womb, and have begun his slavery before he began
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his existence. Equally devoid of wants and of enjoyment, and useless to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself, he learns, with his first notions of existence, that he is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property of another, who has an interest in preserving his life, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the care of it does not devolve upon himself; even the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought appears to him a useless gift of Providence, and he quietly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoys the privileges of his debasement. If he becomes free,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence is often felt by him to be a heavier burden than slavery;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for having learned, in the course of his life, to submit to everything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: except reason, he is too much unacquainted with her dictates to obey
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. A thousand new desires beset him, and he is destitute of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge and energy necessary to resist them: these are masters which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is necessary to contend with, and he has learnt only to submit and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obey. In short, he sinks to such a depth of wretchedness, that while
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servitude brutalizes, liberty destroys him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Oppression has been no less fatal to the Indian than to the negro race,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but its effects are different. Before the arrival of white men in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New World, the inhabitants of North America lived quietly in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: woods, enduring the vicissitudes and practising the virtues and vices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common to savage nations. The Europeans, having dispersed the Indian
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribes and driven them into the deserts, condemned them to a wandering
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life full of inexpressible sufferings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Savage nations are only controlled by opinion and by custom. When the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North American Indians had lost the sentiment of attachment to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country; when their families were dispersed, their traditions obscured,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the chain of their recollections broken; when all their habits were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changed, and their wants increased beyond measure, European tyranny
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rendered them more disorderly and less civilized than they were before.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The moral and physical condition of these tribes continually grew
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: worse, and they became more barbarous as they became more wretched.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, the Europeans have not been able to metamorphose the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character of the Indians; and though they have had power to destroy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them, they have never been able to make them submit to the rules of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilized society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The lot of the negro is placed on the extreme limit of servitude, while
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of the Indian lies on the uttermost verge of liberty; and slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not produce more fatal effects upon the first, than independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the second. The negro has lost all property in his own person, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he cannot dispose of his existence without committing a sort of fraud:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the savage is his own master as soon as he is able to act; parental
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority is scarcely known to him; he has never bent his will to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of any of his kind, nor learned the difference between voluntary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience and a shameful subjection; and the very name of law is unknown
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to him. To be free, with him, signifies to escape from all the shackles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society. As he delights in this barbarous independence, and would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather perish than sacrifice the least part of it, civilization has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little power over him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The negro makes a thousand fruitless efforts to insinuate himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst men who repulse him; he conforms to the tastes of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppressors, adopts their opinions, and hopes by imitating them to form a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of their community. Having been told from infancy that his race is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally inferior to that of the whites, he assents to the proposition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and is ashamed of his own nature. In each of his features he discovers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a trace of slavery, and, if it were in his power, he would willingly rid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself of everything that makes him what he is.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Indian, on the contrary, has his imagination inflated with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pretended nobility of his origin, and lives and dies in the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these dreams of pride. Far from desiring to conform his habits to ours,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he loves his savage life as the distinguishing mark of his race, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repels every advance to civilization, less perhaps from the hatred which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he entertains for it, than from a dread of resembling the Europeans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *a While he has nothing to oppose to our perfection in the arts but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the resources of the desert, to our tactics nothing but undisciplined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courage; whilst our well-digested plans are met by the spontaneous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instincts of savage life, who can wonder if he fails in this unequal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contest?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: The native of North America retains his opinions and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most insignificant of his habits with a degree of tenacity which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no parallel in history. For more than two hundred years the wandering
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribes of North America have had daily intercourse with the whites, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have never derived from them either a custom or an idea. Yet the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europeans have exercised a powerful influence over the savages: they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have made them more licentious, but not more European. In the summer of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1831 I happened to be beyond Lake Michigan, at a place called Green Bay,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which serves as the extreme frontier between the United States and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indians on the north-western side. Here I became acquainted with an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American officer, Major H., who, after talking to me at length on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inflexibility of the Indian character, related the following fact:--"I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formerly knew a young Indian," said he, "who had been educated at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: college in New England, where he had greatly distinguished himself, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had acquired the external appearance of a member of civilized society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the war broke out between ourselves and the English in 1810, I saw
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this young man again; he was serving in our army, at the head of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: warriors of his tribe, for the Indians were admitted amongst the ranks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Americans, upon condition that they would abstain from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: horrible custom of scalping their victims. On the evening of the battle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of . . ., C. came and sat himself down by the fire of our bivouac. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asked him what had been his fortune that day: he related his exploits;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and growing warm and animated by the recollection of them, he concluded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by suddenly opening the breast of his coat, saying, 'You must not betray
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me--see here!' And I actually beheld," said the Major, "between his body
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and his shirt, the skin and hair of an English head, still dripping with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gore."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The negro, who earnestly desires to mingle his race with that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European, cannot effect if; while the Indian, who might succeed to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain extent, disdains to make the attempt. The servility of the one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dooms him to slavery, the pride of the other to death.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I remember that while I was travelling through the forests which still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cover the State of Alabama, I arrived one day at the log house of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pioneer. I did not wish to penetrate into the dwelling of the American,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but retired to rest myself for a while on the margin of a spring, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not far off, in the woods. While I was in this place (which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the neighborhood of the Creek territory), an Indian woman appeared,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: followed by a negress, and holding by the hand a little white girl of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: five or six years old, whom I took to be the daughter of the pioneer.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A sort of barbarous luxury set off the costume of the Indian; rings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of metal were hanging from her nostrils and ears; her hair, which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adorned with glass beads, fell loosely upon her shoulders; and I saw
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that she was not married, for she still wore that necklace of shells
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the bride always deposits on the nuptial couch. The negress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was clad in squalid European garments. They all three came and seated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves upon the banks of the fountain; and the young Indian, taking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the child in her arms, lavished upon her such fond caresses as mothers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: give; while the negress endeavored by various little artifices to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attract the attention of the young Creole.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The child displayed in her slightest gestures a consciousness of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superiority which formed a strange contrast with her infantine weakness;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as if she received the attentions of her companions with a sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condescension. The negress was seated on the ground before her mistress,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: watching her smallest desires, and apparently divided between strong
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affection for the child and servile fear; whilst the savage displayed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of her tenderness, an air of freedom and of pride which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost ferocious. I had approached the group, and I contemplated them in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: silence; but my curiosity was probably displeasing to the Indian woman,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for she suddenly rose, pushed the child roughly from her, and giving
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me an angry look plunged into the thicket. I had often chanced to see
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals met together in the same place, who belonged to the three
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: races of men which people North America. I had perceived from many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different results the preponderance of the whites. But in the picture
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have just been describing there was something peculiarly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: touching; a bond of affection here united the oppressors with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppressed, and the effort of nature to bring them together rendered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still more striking the immense distance placed between them by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudice and by law.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Present And Probable Future Condition Of The Indian Tribes Which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Inhabit The Territory Possessed By The Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Gradual disappearance of the native tribes--Manner in which it takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place--Miseries accompanying the forced migrations of the Indians--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: savages of North America had only two ways of escaping destruction; war
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or civilization--They are no longer able to make war--Reasons why they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refused to become civilized when it was in their power, and why they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot become so now that they desire it--Instance of the Creeks and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Cherokees--Policy of the particular States towards these Indians--Policy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Federal Government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: None of the Indian tribes which formerly inhabited the territory of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England--the Naragansetts, the Mohicans, the Pecots--have any existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but in the recollection of man. The Lenapes, who received William Penn,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a hundred and fifty years ago, upon the banks of the Delaware, have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disappeared; and I myself met with the last of the Iroquois, who were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: begging alms. The nations I have mentioned formerly covered the country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the sea-coast; but a traveller at the present day must penetrate more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than a hundred leagues into the interior of the continent to find an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indian. Not only have these wild tribes receded, but they are destroyed;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *b and as they give way or perish, an immense and increasing people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fills their place. There is no instance upon record of so prodigious a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: growth, or so rapid a destruction: the manner in which the latter change
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: takes place is not difficult to describe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: In the thirteen original States there are only 6,273
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indians remaining. (See Legislative Documents, 20th Congress, No. 117,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: p. 90.) [The decrease in now far greater, and is verging on extinction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See page 360 of this volume.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the Indians were the sole inhabitants of the wilds from whence they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have since been expelled, their wants were few. Their arms were of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own manufacture, their only drink was the water of the brook, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clothes consisted of the skins of animals, whose flesh furnished them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with food.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Europeans introduced amongst the savages of North America fire-arms,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ardent spirits, and iron: they taught them to exchange for manufactured
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stuffs, the rough garments which had previously satisfied their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: untutored simplicity. Having acquired new tastes, without the arts by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they could be gratified, the Indians were obliged to have recourse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the workmanship of the whites; but in return for their productions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the savage had nothing to offer except the rich furs which still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abounded in his woods. Hence the chase became necessary, not merely to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provide for his subsistence, but in order to procure the only objects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of barter which he could furnish to Europe. *c Whilst the wants of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natives were thus increasing, their resources continued to diminish.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: Messrs. Clarke and Cass, in their Report to Congress on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: February 4, 1829, p. 23, expressed themselves thus:--"The time when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Indians generally could supply themselves with food and clothing,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without any of the articles of civilized life, has long since passed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: away. The more remote tribes, beyond the Mississippi, who live where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense herds of buffalo are yet to be found and who follow those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animals in their periodical migrations, could more easily than any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others recur to the habits of their ancestors, and live without the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: white man or any of his manufactures. But the buffalo is constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: receding. The smaller animals, the bear, the deer, the beaver, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: otter, the muskrat, etc., principally minister to the comfort and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: support of the Indians; and these cannot be taken without guns,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ammunition, and traps. Among the Northwestern Indians particularly, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor of supplying a family with food is excessive. Day after day is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spent by the hunter without success, and during this interval his family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must subsist upon bark or roots, or perish. Want and misery are around
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them and among them. Many die every winter from actual starvation."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Indians will not live as Europeans live, and yet they can neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsist without them, nor exactly after the fashion of their fathers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is demonstrated by a fact which I likewise give upon official
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority. Some Indians of a tribe on the banks of Lake Superior had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: killed a European; the American government interdicted all traffic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the tribe to which the guilty parties belonged, until they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delivered up to justice. This measure had the desired effect.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From the moment when a European settlement is formed in the neighborhood
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the territory occupied by the Indians, the beasts of chase take the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alarm. *d Thousands of savages, wandering in the forests and destitute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of any fixed dwelling, did not disturb them; but as soon as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continuous sounds of European labor are heard in their neighborhood,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they begin to flee away, and retire to the West, where their instinct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: teaches them that they will find deserts of immeasurable extent. "The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: buffalo is constantly receding," say Messrs. Clarke and Cass in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Report of the year 1829; "a few years since they approached the base
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Alleghany; and a few years hence they may even be rare upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense plains which extend to the base of the Rocky Mountains." I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been assured that this effect of the approach of the whites is often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: felt at two hundred leagues' distance from their frontier. Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence is thus exerted over tribes whose name is unknown to them; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who suffer the evils of usurpation long before they are acquainted with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the authors of their distress. *e
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: "Five years ago," (says Volney in his "Tableau des
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Etats-Unis," p. 370) "in going from Vincennes to Kaskaskia, a territory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which now forms part of the State of Illinois, but which at the time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I mention was completely wild (1797), you could not cross a prairie
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without seeing herds of from four to five hundred buffaloes. There are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: now none remaining; they swam across the Mississippi to escape from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hunters, and more particularly from the bells of the American cows."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: The truth of what I here advance may be easily proved by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consulting the tabular statement of Indian tribes inhabiting the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States and their territories. (Legislative Documents, 20th Congress,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No. 117, pp. 90-105.) It is there shown that the tribes in the centre
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of America are rapidly decreasing, although the Europeans are still at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerable distance from them.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Bold adventurers soon penetrate into the country the Indians have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deserted, and when they have advanced about fifteen or twenty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leagues from the extreme frontiers of the whites, they begin to build
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitations for civilized beings in the midst of the wilderness. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is done without difficulty, as the territory of a hunting-nation is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ill-defined; it is the common property of the tribe, and belongs to no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one in particular, so that individual interests are not concerned in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protection of any part of it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A few European families, settled in different situations at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerable distance from each other, soon drive away the wild animals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which remain between their places of abode. The Indians, who had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: previously lived in a sort of abundance, then find it difficult to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsist, and still more difficult to procure the articles of barter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they stand in need of.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To drive away their game is to deprive them of the means of existence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as effectually as if the fields of our agriculturists were stricken with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barrenness; and they are reduced, like famished wolves, to prowl through
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the forsaken woods in quest of prey. Their instinctive love of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country attaches them to the soil which gave them birth, *f even after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it has ceased to yield anything but misery and death. At length they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are compelled to acquiesce, and to depart: they follow the traces of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elk, the buffalo, and the beaver, and are guided by these wild animals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the choice of their future country. Properly speaking, therefore, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not the Europeans who drive away the native inhabitants of America;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is famine which compels them to recede; a happy distinction which had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: escaped the casuists of former times, and for which we are indebted to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: modern discovery!
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: "The Indians," say Messrs. Clarke and Cass in their Report
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to Congress, p. 15, "are attached to their country by the same feelings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which bind us to ours; and, besides, there are certain superstitious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions connected with the alienation of what the Great Spirit gave to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their ancestors, which operate strongly upon the tribes who have made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: few or no cessions, but which are gradually weakened as our intercourse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with them is extended. 'We will not sell the spot which contains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bones of our fathers,' is almost always the first answer to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proposition for a sale."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is impossible to conceive the extent of the sufferings which attend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these forced emigrations. They are undertaken by a people already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exhausted and reduced; and the countries to which the newcomers betake
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves are inhabited by other tribes which receive them with jealous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hostility. Hunger is in the rear; war awaits them, and misery besets
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them on all sides. In the hope of escaping from such a host of enemies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they separate, and each individual endeavors to procure the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of supporting his existence in solitude and secrecy, living in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immensity of the desert like an outcast in civilized society. The social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tie, which distress had long since weakened, is then dissolved; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have lost their country, and their people soon desert them: their very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: families are obliterated; the names they bore in common are forgotten,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their language perishes, and all traces of their origin disappear.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Their nation has ceased to exist, except in the recollection of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: antiquaries of America and a few of the learned of Europe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I should be sorry to have my reader suppose that I am coloring the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: picture too highly; I saw with my own eyes several of the cases of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misery which I have been describing; and I was the witness of sufferings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have not the power to portray.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the end of the year 1831, whilst I was on the left bank of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mississippi at a place named by Europeans, Memphis, there arrived a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numerous band of Choctaws (or Chactas, as they are called by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French in Louisiana). These savages had left their country, and were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavoring to gain the right bank of the Mississippi, where they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hoped to find an asylum which had been promised them by the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government. It was then the middle of winter, and the cold was unusually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severe; the snow had frozen hard upon the ground, and the river was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: drifting huge masses of ice. The Indians had their families with them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they brought in their train the wounded and sick, with children
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: newly born, and old men upon the verge of death. They possessed neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tents nor wagons, but only their arms and some provisions. I saw them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: embark to pass the mighty river, and never will that solemn spectacle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fade from my remembrance. No cry, no sob was heard amongst the assembled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crowd; all were silent. Their calamities were of ancient date, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knew them to be irremediable. The Indians had all stepped into the bark
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which was to carry them across, but their dogs remained upon the bank.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As soon as these animals perceived that their masters were finally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leaving the shore, they set up a dismal howl, and, plunging all together
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the icy waters of the Mississippi, they swam after the boat.
