author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The ejectment of the Indians very often takes place at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day, in a regular, and, as it were, a legal manner. When the European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population begins to approach the limit of the desert inhabited by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: savage tribe, the government of the United States usually dispatches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: envoys to them, who assemble the Indians in a large plain, and having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first eaten and drunk with them, accost them in the following manner:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "What have you to do in the land of your fathers? Before long, you must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dig up their bones in order to live. In what respect is the country you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabit better than another? Are there no woods, marshes, or prairies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: except where you dwell? And can you live nowhere but under your own sun?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Beyond those mountains which you see at the horizon, beyond the lake
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which bounds your territory on the west, there lie vast countries where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beasts of chase are found in great abundance; sell your lands to us,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and go to live happily in those solitudes." After holding this language,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they spread before the eyes of the Indians firearms, woollen garments,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kegs of brandy, glass necklaces, bracelets of tinsel, earrings, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: looking-glasses. *g If, when they have beheld all these riches, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still hesitate, it is insinuated that they have not the means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refusing their required consent, and that the government itself will not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long have the power of protecting them in their rights. What are they to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do? Half convinced, and half compelled, they go to inhabit new deserts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the importunate whites will not let them remain ten years in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tranquillity. In this manner do the Americans obtain, at a very low
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: price, whole provinces, which the richest sovereigns of Europe could not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purchase. *h
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: See, in the Legislative Documents of Congress (Doc. 117),
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the narrative of what takes place on these occasions. This curious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passage is from the above-mentioned report, made to Congress by Messrs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Clarke and Cass in February, 1829. Mr. Cass is now the Secretary of War.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The Indians," says the report, "reach the treaty-ground poor and almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naked. Large quantities of goods are taken there by the traders, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are seen and examined by the Indians. The women and children become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importunate to have their wants supplied, and their influence is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soon exerted to induce a sale. Their improvidence is habitual and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unconquerable. The gratification of his immediate wants and desires is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ruling passion of an Indian. The expectation of future advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seldom produces much effect. The experience of the past is lost, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the prospects of the future disregarded. It would be utterly hopeless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to demand a cession of land, unless the means were at hand of gratifying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their immediate wants; and when their condition and circumstances are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fairly considered, it ought not to surprise us that they are so anxious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to relieve themselves."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: On May 19, 1830, Mr. Edward Everett affirmed before the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: House of Representatives, that the Americans had already acquired by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: treaty, to the east and west of the Mississippi, 230,000,000 of acres.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1808 the Osages gave up 48,000,000 acres for an annual payment of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: $1,000. In 1818 the Quapaws yielded up 29,000,000 acres for $4,000.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They reserved for themselves a territory of 1,000,000 acres for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hunting-ground. A solemn oath was taken that it should be respected: but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before long it was invaded like the rest. Mr. Bell, in his Report of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Committee on Indian Affairs, February 24, 1830, has these words:--"To
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pay an Indian tribe what their ancient hunting-grounds are worth to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them, after the game is fled or destroyed, as a mode of appropriating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wild lands claimed by Indians, has been found more convenient, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certainly it is more agreeable to the forms of justice, as well as more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merciful, than to assert the possession of them by the sword. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practice of buying Indian titles is but the substitute which humanity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and expediency have imposed, in place of the sword, in arriving at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actual enjoyment of property claimed by the right of discovery, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sanctioned by the natural superiority allowed to the claims of civilized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities over those of savage tribes. Up to the present time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so invariable has been the operation of certain causes, first in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diminishing the value of forest lands to the Indians, and secondly in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disposing them to sell readily, that the plan of buying their right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occupancy has never threatened to retard, in any perceptible degree, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity of any of the States." (Legislative Documents, 21st Congress,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These are great evils; and it must be added that they appear to me to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be irremediable. I believe that the Indian nations of North America are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doomed to perish; and that whenever the Europeans shall be established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the shores of the Pacific Ocean, that race of men will be no more.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *i The Indians had only the two alternatives of war or civilization;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in other words, they must either have destroyed the Europeans or become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their equals.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: This seems, indeed, to be the opinion of almost all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American statesmen. "Judging of the future by the past," says Mr.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Cass, "we cannot err in anticipating a progressive diminution of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numbers, and their eventual extinction, unless our border should become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stationary, and they be removed beyond it, or unless some radical change
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should take place in the principles of our intercourse with them, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is easier to hope for than to expect."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the first settlement of the colonies they might have found it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possible, by uniting their forces, to deliver themselves from the small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bodies of strangers who landed on their continent. *j They several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: times attempted to do it, and were on the point of succeeding; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disproportion of their resources, at the present day, when compared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with those of the whites, is too great to allow such an enterprise to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be thought of. Nevertheless, there do arise from time to time among the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indians men of penetration, who foresee the final destiny which awaits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the native population, and who exert themselves to unite all the tribes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in common hostility to the Europeans; but their efforts are unavailing.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Those tribes which are in the neighborhood of the whites, are too much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weakened to offer an effectual resistance; whilst the others, giving way
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to that childish carelessness of the morrow which characterizes savage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life, wait for the near approach of danger before they prepare to meet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it; some are unable, the others are unwilling, to exert themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: Amongst other warlike enterprises, there was one of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Wampanaogs, and other confederate tribes, under Metacom in 1675, against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the colonists of New England; the English were also engaged in war in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Virginia in 1622.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is easy to foresee that the Indians will never conform to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization; or that it will be too late, whenever they may be inclined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to make the experiment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Civilization is the result of a long social process which takes place in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same spot, and is handed down from one generation to another, each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one profiting by the experience of the last. Of all nations, those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submit to civilization with the most difficulty which habitually live by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chase. Pastoral tribes, indeed, often change their place of abode;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they follow a regular order in their migrations, and often return
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: again to their old stations, whilst the dwelling of the hunter varies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with that of the animals he pursues.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Several attempts have been made to diffuse knowledge amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indians, without controlling their wandering propensities; by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jesuits in Canada, and by the Puritans in New England; *k but none of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these endeavors were crowned by any lasting success. Civilization began
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the cabin, but it soon retired to expire in the woods. The great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: error of these legislators of the Indians was their not understanding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, in order to succeed in civilizing a people, it is first necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to fix it; which cannot be done without inducing it to cultivate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soil; the Indians ought in the first place to have been accustomed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to agriculture. But not only are they destitute of this indispensable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preliminary to civilization, they would even have great difficulty in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquiring it. Men who have once abandoned themselves to the restless and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adventurous life of the hunter, feel an insurmountable disgust for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constant and regular labor which tillage requires. We see this proved in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bosom of our own society; but it is far more visible among peoples
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whose partiality for the chase is a part of their national character.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: See the "Histoire de la Nouvelle France," by Charlevoix,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the work entitled "Lettres edifiantes."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Independently of this general difficulty, there is another, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applies peculiarly to the Indians; they consider labor not merely as an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evil, but as a disgrace; so that their pride prevents them from becoming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilized, as much as their indolence. *l
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: "In all the tribes," says Volney, in his "Tableau des
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Etats-Unis," p. 423, "there still exists a generation of old warriors,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who cannot forbear, when they see their countrymen using the hoe, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclaiming against the degradation of ancient manners, and asserting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the savages owe their decline to these innovations; adding, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have only to return to their primitive habits in order to recover
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their power and their glory."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is no Indian so wretched as not to retain under his hut of bark a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lofty idea of his personal worth; he considers the cares of industry
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and labor as degrading occupations; he compares the husbandman to the ox
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which traces the furrow; and even in our most ingenious handicraft,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he can see nothing but the labor of slaves. Not that he is devoid of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admiration for the power and intellectual greatness of the whites; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although the result of our efforts surprises him, he contemns the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by which we obtain it; and while he acknowledges our ascendancy, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still believes in his superiority. War and hunting are the only pursuits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which appear to him worthy to be the occupations of a man. *m The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indian, in the dreary solitude of his woods, cherishes the same ideas,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same opinions as the noble of the Middle ages in his castle, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only requires to become a conqueror to complete the resemblance; thus,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however strange it may seem, it is in the forests of the New World,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and not amongst the Europeans who people its coasts, that the ancient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudices of Europe are still in existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: The following description occurs in an official document:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Until a young man has been engaged with an enemy, and has performed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some acts of valor, he gains no consideration, but is regarded nearly as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a woman. In their great war-dances all the warriors in succession
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strike the post, as it is called, and recount their exploits. On these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occasions their auditory consists of the kinsmen, friends, and comrades
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the narrator. The profound impression which his discourse produces on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them is manifested by the silent attention it receives, and by the loud
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shouts which hail its termination. The young man who finds himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at such a meeting without anything to recount is very unhappy; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instances have sometimes occurred of young warriors, whose passions had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been thus inflamed, quitting the war-dance suddenly, and going off alone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to seek for trophies which they might exhibit, and adventures which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might be allowed to relate."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: More than once, in the course of this work, I have endeavored to explain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the prodigious influence which the social condition appears to exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the laws and the manners of men; and I beg to add a few words on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same subject.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When I perceive the resemblance which exists between the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions of our ancestors, the Germans, and of the wandering tribes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of North America; between the customs described by Tacitus, and those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have sometimes been a witness, I cannot help thinking that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same cause has brought about the same results in both hemispheres; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in the midst of the apparent diversity of human affairs, a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of primary facts may be discovered, from which all the others
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are derived. In what we usually call the German institutions, then, I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclined only to perceive barbarian habits; and the opinions of savages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in what we style feudal principles.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: However strongly the vices and prejudices of the North American Indians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be opposed to their becoming agricultural and civilized, necessity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes obliges them to it. Several of the Southern nations, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst others the Cherokees and the Creeks, *n were surrounded by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europeans, who had landed on the shores of the Atlantic; and who,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either descending the Ohio or proceeding up the Mississippi, arrived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simultaneously upon their borders. These tribes have not been driven
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from place to place, like their Northern brethren; but they have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually enclosed within narrow limits, like the game within the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thicket, before the huntsmen plunge into the interior. The Indians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who were thus placed between civilization and death, found themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to live by ignominious labor like the whites. They took to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agriculture, and without entirely forsaking their old habits or manners,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sacrificed only as much as was necessary to their existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: These nations are now swallowed up in the States of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Georgia, Tennessee, Alabama, and Mississippi. There were formerly in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South four great nations (remnants of which still exist), the Choctaws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Chickasaws, the Creeks, and the Cherokees. The remnants of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: four nations amounted, in 1830, to about 75,000 individuals. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: computed that there are now remaining in the territory occupied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or claimed by the Anglo-American Union about 300,000 Indians. (See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Proceedings of the Indian Board in the City of New York.) The official
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: documents supplied to Congress make the number amount to 313,130. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reader who is curious to know the names and numerical strength of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tribes which inhabit the Anglo-American territory should consult the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: documents I refer to. (Legislative Documents, 20th Congress, No.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 117, pp. 90-105.) [In the Census of 1870 it is stated that the Indian
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population of the United States is only 25,731, of whom 7,241 are in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: California.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Cherokees went further; they created a written language; established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a permanent form of government; and as everything proceeds rapidly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the New World, before they had all of them clothes, they set up a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: newspaper. *o
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: I brought back with me to France one or two copies of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: singular publication.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The growth of European habits has been remarkably accelerated among
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these Indians by the mixed race which has sprung up. *p Deriving
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligence from their father's side, without entirely losing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: savage customs of the mother, the half-blood forms the natural link
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between civilization and barbarism. Wherever this race has multiplied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the savage state has become modified, and a great change has taken place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the manners of the people. *q
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: See in the Report of the Committee on Indian Affairs, 21st
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Congress, No. 227, p. 23, the reasons for the multiplication of Indians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of mixed blood among the Cherokees. The principal cause dates from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: War of Independence. Many Anglo-Americans of Georgia, having taken the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: side of England, were obliged to retreat among the Indians, where they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: married.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: Unhappily the mixed race has been less numerous and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influential in North America than in any other country. The American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent was peopled by two great nations of Europe, the French and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the English. The former were not slow in connecting themselves with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: daughters of the natives, but there was an unfortunate affinity between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Indian character and their own: instead of giving the tastes and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits of civilized life to the savages, the French too often grew
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passionately fond of the state of wild freedom they found them in. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became the most dangerous of the inhabitants of the desert, and won the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: friendship of the Indian by exaggerating his vices and his virtues. M.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: de Senonville, the governor of Canada, wrote thus to Louis XIV in 1685:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "It has long been believed that in order to civilize the savages we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought to draw them nearer to us. But there is every reason to suppose we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been mistaken. Those which have been brought into contact with us
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have not become French, and the French who have lived among them are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changed into savages, affecting to dress and live like them." ("History
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of New France," by Charlevoix, vol. ii., p. 345.) The Englishman, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, continuing obstinately attached to the customs and the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insignificant habits of his forefathers, has remained in the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American solitudes just what he was in the bosom of European cities;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he would not allow of any communication with savages whom he despised,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and avoided with care the union of his race with theirs. Thus while the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French exercised no salutary influence over the Indians, the English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have always remained alien from them.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The success of the Cherokees proves that the Indians are capable of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization, but it does not prove that they will succeed in it. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty which the Indians find in submitting to civilization proceeds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the influence of a general cause, which it is almost impossible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for them to escape. An attentive survey of history demonstrates that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in general, barbarous nations have raised themselves to civilization by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degrees, and by their own efforts. Whenever they derive knowledge from a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign people, they stood towards it in the relation of conquerors, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not of a conquered nation. When the conquered nation is enlightened, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the conquerors are half savage, as in the case of the invasion of Rome
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Northern nations or that of China by the Mongols, the power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which victory bestows upon the barbarian is sufficient to keep up his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance among civilized men, and permit him to rank as their equal,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: until he becomes their rival: the one has might on his side, the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has intelligence; the former admires the knowledge and the arts of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquered, the latter envies the power of the conquerors. The barbarians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at length admit civilized man into their palaces, and he in turn opens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his schools to the barbarians. But when the side on which the physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: force lies, also possesses an intellectual preponderance, the conquered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: party seldom become civilized; it retreats, or is destroyed. It may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore be said, in a general way, that savages go forth in arms to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seek knowledge, but that they do not receive it when it comes to them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the Indian tribes which now inhabit the heart of the continent could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: summon up energy enough to attempt to civilize themselves, they might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possibly succeed. Superior already to the barbarous nations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surround them, they would gradually gain strength and experience, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when the Europeans should appear upon their borders, they would be in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state, if not to maintain their independence, at least to assert their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right to the soil, and to incorporate themselves with the conquerors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But it is the misfortune of Indians to be brought into contact with a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilized people, which is also (it must be owned) the most avaricious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation on the globe, whilst they are still semi-barbarian: to find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despots in their instructors, and to receive knowledge from the hand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of oppression. Living in the freedom of the woods, the North American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indian was destitute, but he had no feeling of inferiority towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anyone; as soon, however, as he desires to penetrate into the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scale of the whites, he takes the lowest rank in society, for he enters,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorant and poor, within the pale of science and wealth. After having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: led a life of agitation, beset with evils and dangers, but at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same time filled with proud emotions, *r he is obliged to submit to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a wearisome, obscure, and degraded state; and to gain the bread which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nourishes him by hard and ignoble labor; such are in his eyes the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results of which civilization can boast: and even this much he is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sure to obtain.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: There is in the adventurous life of the hunter a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible charm, which seizes the heart of man and carries him away
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in spite of reason and experience. This is plainly shown by the memoirs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Tanner. Tanner is a European who was carried away at the age of six
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Indians, and has remained thirty years with them in the woods.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing can be conceived more appalling that the miseries which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: describes. He tells us of tribes without a chief, families without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a nation to call their own, men in a state of isolation, wrecks of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful tribes wandering at random amid the ice and snow and desolate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solitudes of Canada. Hunger and cold pursue them; every day their life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is in jeopardy. Amongst these men, manners have lost their empire,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traditions are without power. They become more and more savage. Tanner
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shared in all these miseries; he was aware of his European origin; he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not kept away from the whites by force; on the contrary, he came
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every year to trade with them, entered their dwellings, and witnessed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their enjoyments; he knew that whenever he chose to return to civilized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life he was perfectly able to do so--and he remained thirty years in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deserts. When he came into civilized society he declared that the rude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence which he described, had a secret charm for him which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was unable to define: he returned to it again and again: at length he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandoned it with poignant regret; and when he was at length fixed among
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the whites, several of his children refused to share his tranquil and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easy situation. I saw Tanner myself at the lower end of Lake Superior;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he seemed to me to be more like a savage than a civilized being. His
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: book is written without either taste or order; but he gives, even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unconsciously, a lively picture of the prejudices, the passions, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vices, and, above all, of the destitution in which he lived.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the Indians undertake to imitate their European neighbors, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: till the earth like the settlers, they are immediately exposed to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very formidable competition. The white man is skilled in the craft of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agriculture; the Indian is a rough beginner in an art with which he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unacquainted. The former reaps abundant crops without difficulty, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter meets with a thousand obstacles in raising the fruits of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: earth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The European is placed amongst a population whose wants he knows and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: partakes. The savage is isolated in the midst of a hostile people, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whose manners, language, and laws he is imperfectly acquainted, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without whose assistance he cannot live. He can only procure the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: materials of comfort by bartering his commodities against the goods
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the European, for the assistance of his countrymen is wholly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insufficient to supply his wants. When the Indian wishes to sell the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produce of his labor, he cannot always meet with a purchaser, whilst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European readily finds a market; and the former can only produce at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerable cost that which the latter vends at a very low rate. Thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Indian has no sooner escaped those evils to which barbarous nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are exposed, than he is subjected to the still greater miseries of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilized communities; and he finds is scarcely less difficult to live
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of our abundance, than in the depth of his own wilderness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He has not yet lost the habits of his erratic life; the traditions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his fathers and his passion for the chase are still alive within him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The wild enjoyments which formerly animated him in the woods, painfully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excite his troubled imagination; and his former privations appear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be less keen, his former perils less appalling. He contrasts the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence which he possessed amongst his equals with the servile
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position which he occupies in civilized society. On the other hand,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the solitudes which were so long his free home are still at hand; a few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hours' march will bring him back to them once more. The whites offer him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a sum, which seems to him to be considerable, for the ground which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has begun to clear. This money of the Europeans may possibly furnish him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the means of a happy and peaceful subsistence in remoter regions;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and he quits the plough, resumes his native arms, and returns to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilderness forever. *s The condition of the Creeks and Cherokees, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have already alluded, sufficiently corroborates the truth of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this deplorable picture.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote s: The destructive influence of highly civilized nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon others which are less so, has been exemplified by the Europeans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves. About a century ago the French founded the town of Vincennes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up on the Wabash, in the middle of the desert; and they lived there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in great plenty until the arrival of the American settlers, who first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ruined the previous inhabitants by their competition, and afterwards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purchased their lands at a very low rate. At the time when M. de Volney,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from whom I borrow these details, passed through Vincennes, the number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the French was reduced to a hundred individuals, most of whom were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about to pass over to Louisiana or to Canada. These French settlers were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: worthy people, but idle and uninstructed: they had contracted many of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the habits of savages. The Americans, who were perhaps their inferiors,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a moral point of view, were immeasurably superior to them in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligence: they were industrious, well informed, rich, and accustomed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to govern their own community.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I myself saw in Canada, where the intellectual difference between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two races is less striking, that the English are the masters of commerce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and manufacture in the Canadian country, that they spread on all sides,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and confine the French within limits which scarcely suffice to contain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. In like manner, in Louisiana, almost all activity in commerce and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacture centres in the hands of the Anglo-Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the case of Texas is still more striking: the State of Texas is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of Mexico, and lies upon the frontier between that country and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States. In the course of the last few years the Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have penetrated into this province, which is still thinly peopled; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purchase land, they produce the commodities of the country, and supplant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the original population. It may easily be foreseen that if Mexico takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no steps to check this change, the province of Texas will very shortly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cease to belong to that government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the different degrees--comparatively so slight--which exist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in European civilization produce results of such magnitude, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences which must ensue from the collision of the most perfect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European civilization with Indian savages may readily be conceived.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Indians, in the little which they have done, have unquestionably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: displayed as much natural genius as the peoples of Europe in their most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important designs; but nations as well as men require time to learn,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever may be their intelligence and their zeal. Whilst the savages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were engaged in the work of civilization, the Europeans continued to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surround them on every side, and to confine them within narrower limits;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the two races gradually met, and they are now in immediate juxtaposition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to each other. The Indian is already superior to his barbarous parent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but he is still very far below his white neighbor. With their resources
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and acquired knowledge, the Europeans soon appropriated to themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most of the advantages which the natives might have derived from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of the soil; they have settled in the country, they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purchased land at a very low rate or have occupied it by force, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indians have been ruined by a competition which they had not the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of resisting. They were isolated in their own country, and their race
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only constituted a colony of troublesome aliens in the midst of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numerous and domineering people. *t
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote t: See in the Legislative Documents (21st Congress, No. 89)
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instances of excesses of every kind committed by the whites upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory of the Indians, either in taking possession of a part of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lands, until compelled to retire by the troops of Congress, or carrying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: off their cattle, burning their houses, cutting down their corn, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doing violence to their persons. It appears, nevertheless, from all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these documents that the claims of the natives are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protected by the government from the abuse of force. The Union has a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative agent continually employed to reside among the Indians;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the report of the Cherokee agent, which is among the documents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have referred to, is almost always favorable to the Indians. "The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intrusion of whites," he says, "upon the lands of the Cherokees would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause ruin to the poor, helpless, and inoffensive inhabitants." And he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: further remarks upon the attempt of the State of Georgia to establish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a division line for the purpose of limiting the boundaries of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Cherokees, that the line drawn having been made by the whites, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely upon ex parte evidence of their several rights, was of no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: validity whatever.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Washington said in one of his messages to Congress, "We are more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlightened and more powerful than the Indian nations, we are therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bound in honor to treat them with kindness and even with generosity."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But this virtuous and high-minded policy has not been followed. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapacity of the settlers is usually backed by the tyranny of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government. Although the Cherokees and the Creeks are established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the territory which they inhabited before the settlement of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europeans, and although the Americans have frequently treated with them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as with foreign nations, the surrounding States have not consented to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledge them as independent peoples, and attempts have been made to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject these children of the woods to Anglo-American magistrates, laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and customs. *u Destitution had driven these unfortunate Indians to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization, and oppression now drives them back to their former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition: many of them abandon the soil which they had begun to clear,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and return to their savage course of life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote u: In 1829 the State of Alabama divided the Creek territory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into counties, and subjected the Indian population to the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European magistrates.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part III
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1830 the State of Mississippi assimilated the Choctaws and Chickasaws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the white population, and declared that any of them that should take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the title of chief would be punished by a fine of $1,000 and a year's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imprisonment. When these laws were enforced upon the Choctaws, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabited that district, the tribe assembled, their chief communicated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them the intentions of the whites, and read to them some of the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to which it was intended that they should submit; and they unanimously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declared that it was better at once to retreat again into the wilds.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If we consider the tyrannical measures which have been adopted by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislatures of the Southern States, the conduct of their Governors, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the decrees of their courts of justice, we shall be convinced that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entire expulsion of the Indians is the final result to which the efforts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their policy are directed. The Americans of that part of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: look with jealousy upon the aborigines, *v they are aware that these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribes have not yet lost the traditions of savage life, and before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization has permanently fixed them to the soil, it is intended
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to force them to recede by reducing them to despair. The Creeks and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Cherokees, oppressed by the several States, have appealed to the central
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, which is by no means insensible to their misfortunes, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is sincerely desirous of saving the remnant of the natives, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintaining them in the free possession of that territory, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union is pledged to respect. *w But the several States oppose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so formidable a resistance to the execution of this design, that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government is obliged to consent to the extirpation of a few barbarous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribes in order not to endanger the safety of the American Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote v: The Georgians, who are so much annoyed by the proximity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Indians, inhabit a territory which does not at present contain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more than seven inhabitants to the square mile. In France there are one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hundred and sixty-two inhabitants to the same extent of country.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote w: In 1818 Congress appointed commissioners to visit the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Arkansas Territory, accompanied by a deputation of Creeks, Choctaws, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chickasaws. This expedition was commanded by Messrs. Kennerly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: M'Coy, Wash Hood, and John Bell. See the different reports of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commissioners, and their journal, in the Documents of Congress, No. 87,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: House of Representatives.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the federal government, which is not able to protect the Indians,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would fain mitigate the hardships of their lot; and, with this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intention, proposals have been made to transport them into more remote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regions at the public cost.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Between the thirty-third and thirty-seventh degrees of north latitude,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a vast tract of country lies, which has taken the name of Arkansas, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principal river that waters its extent. It is bounded on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one side by the confines of Mexico, on the other by the Mississippi.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Numberless streams cross it in every direction; the climate is mild, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the soil productive, but it is only inhabited by a few wandering hordes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of savages. The government of the Union wishes to transport the broken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remnants of the indigenous population of the South to the portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this country which is nearest to Mexico, and at a great distance from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American settlements.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We were assured, towards the end of the year 1831, that 10,000
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indians had already gone down to the shores of the Arkansas; and fresh
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: detachments were constantly following them; but Congress has been unable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to excite a unanimous determination in those whom it is disposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protect. Some, indeed, are willing to quit the seat of oppression, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most enlightened members of the community refuse to abandon their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recent dwellings and their springing crops; they are of opinion that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: work of civilization, once interrupted, will never be resumed; they fear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that those domestic habits which have been so recently contracted, may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be irrevocably lost in the midst of a country which is still barbarous,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and where nothing is prepared for the subsistence of an agricultural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people; they know that their entrance into those wilds will be opposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by inimical hordes, and that they have lost the energy of barbarians,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without acquiring the resources of civilization to resist their attacks.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Moreover, the Indians readily discover that the settlement which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proposed to them is merely a temporary expedient. Who can assure them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they will at length be allowed to dwell in peace in their new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retreat? The United States pledge themselves to the observance of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obligation; but the territory which they at present occupy was formerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secured to them by the most solemn oaths of Anglo-American faith. *x
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American government does not indeed rob them of their lands, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allows perpetual incursions to be made on them. In a few years the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: white population which now flocks around them, will track them to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solitudes of the Arkansas; they will then be exposed to the same evils
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without the same remedies, and as the limits of the earth will at last
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fail them, their only refuge is the grave.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote x: The fifth article of the treaty made with the Creeks in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: August, 1790, is in the following words:--"The United States solemnly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guarantee to the Creek nation all their land within the limits of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The seventh article of the treaty concluded in 1791 with the Cherokees
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: says:--"The United States solemnly guarantee to the Cherokee nation all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their lands not hereby ceded." The following article declared that if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any citizen of the United States or other settler not of the Indian race
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should establish himself upon the territory of the Cherokees, the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States would withdraw their protection from that individual, and give
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him up to be punished as the Cherokee nation should think fit.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Union treats the Indians with less cupidity and rigor than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: policy of the several States, but the two governments are alike
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destitute of good faith. The States extend what they are pleased to term
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the benefits of their laws to the Indians, with a belief that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribes will recede rather than submit; and the central government, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promises a permanent refuge to these unhappy beings is well aware of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inability to secure it to them. *y
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote y: This does not prevent them from promising in the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solemn manner to do so. See the letter of the President addressed to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Creek Indians, March 23, 1829 (Proceedings of the Indian Board, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: city of New York, p. 5): "Beyond the great river Mississippi, where a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of your nation has gone, your father has provided a country large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enough for all of you, and he advises you to remove to it. There your
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: white brothers will not trouble you; they will have no claim to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: land, and you can live upon it, you and all your children, as long as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the grass grows, or the water runs, in peace and plenty. It will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yours forever."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Secretary of War, in a letter written to the Cherokees, April 18,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1829, (see the same work, p. 6), declares to them that they cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expect to retain possession of the lands at that time occupied by them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but gives them the most positive assurance of uninterrupted peace if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they would remove beyond the Mississippi: as if the power which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could not grant them protection then, would be able to afford it them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereafter!]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the tyranny of the States obliges the savages to retire, the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by its promises and resources, facilitates their retreat; and these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures tend to precisely the same end. *z "By the will of our Father
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in Heaven, the Governor of the whole world," said the Cherokees in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: petition to Congress, *a "the red man of America has become small, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the white man great and renowned. When the ancestors of the people of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these United States first came to the shores of America they found the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: red man strong: though he was ignorant and savage, yet he received them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kindly, and gave them dry land to rest their weary feet. They met in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace, and shook hands in token of friendship. Whatever the white man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wanted and asked of the Indian, the latter willingly gave. At that time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Indian was the lord, and the white man the suppliant. But now the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scene has changed. The strength of the red man has become weakness. As
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his neighbors increased in numbers his power became less and less,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and now, of the many and powerful tribes who once covered these United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, only a few are to be seen--a few whom a sweeping pestilence has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: left. The northern tribes, who were once so numerous and powerful, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: now nearly extinct. Thus it has happened to the red man of America.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Shall we, who are remnants, share the same fate?"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote z: To obtain a correct idea of the policy pursued by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several States and the Union with respect to the Indians, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary to consult, 1st, "The Laws of the Colonial and State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Governments relating to the Indian Inhabitants." (See the Legislative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Documents, 21st Congress, No. 319.) 2d, The Laws of the Union on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same subject, and especially that of March 30, 1802. (See Story's "Laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States.") 3d, The Report of Mr. Cass, Secretary of War,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relative to Indian Affairs, November 29, 1823.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: December 18, 1829.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The land on which we stand we have received as an inheritance from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our fathers, who possessed it from time immemorial, as a gift from our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common Father in Heaven. They bequeathed it to us as their children, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we have sacredly kept it, as containing the remains of our beloved men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This right of inheritance we have never ceded nor ever forfeited. Permit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: us to ask what better right can the people have to a country than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of inheritance and immemorial peaceable possession? We know it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: said of late by the State of Georgia and by the Executive of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, that we have forfeited this right; but we think this is said
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratuitously. At what time have we made the forfeit? What great crime
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have we committed, whereby we must forever be divested of our country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and rights? Was it when we were hostile to the United States, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: took part with the King of Great Britain, during the struggle for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence? If so, why was not this forfeiture declared in the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: treaty of peace between the United States and our beloved men? Why
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not such an article as the following inserted in the treaty:--'The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States give peace to the Cherokees, but, for the part they took
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the late war, declare them to be but tenants at will, to be removed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when the convenience of the States, within whose chartered limits they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: live, shall require it'? That was the proper time to assume such a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession. But it was not thought of, nor would our forefathers have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agreed to any treaty whose tendency was to deprive them of their rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their country."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such is the language of the Indians: their assertions are true, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forebodings inevitable. From whichever side we consider the destinies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the aborigines of North America, their calamities appear to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irremediable: if they continue barbarous, they are forced to retire; if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they attempt to civilize their manners, the contact of a more civilized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community subjects them to oppression and destitution. They perish if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they continue to wander from waste to waste, and if they attempt to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settle they still must perish; the assistance of Europeans is necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to instruct them, but the approach of Europeans corrupts and repels them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into savage life; they refuse to change their habits as long as their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solitudes are their own, and it is too late to change them when they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constrained to submit.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Spaniards pursued the Indians with bloodhounds, like wild beasts;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they sacked the New World with no more temper or compassion than a city
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken by storm; but destruction must cease, and frenzy be stayed; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remnant of the Indian population which had escaped the massacre mixed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with its conquerors, and adopted in the end their religion and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners. *b The conduct of the Americans of the United States towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the aborigines is characterized, on the other hand, by a singular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attachment to the formalities of law. Provided that the Indians retain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their barbarous condition, the Americans take no part in their affairs;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they treat them as independent nations, and do not possess themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their hunting grounds without a treaty of purchase; and if an Indian
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation happens to be so encroached upon as to be unable to subsist upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its territory, they afford it brotherly assistance in transporting it to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a grave sufficiently remote from the land of its fathers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: The honor of this result is, however, by no means due to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Spaniards. If the Indian tribes had not been tillers of the ground
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the time of the arrival of the Europeans, they would unquestionably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been destroyed in South as well as in North America.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Spaniards were unable to exterminate the Indian race by those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unparalleled atrocities which brand them with indelible shame, nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: did they even succeed in wholly depriving it of its rights; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans of the United States have accomplished this twofold purpose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with singular felicity; tranquilly, legally, philanthropically, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shedding blood, and without violating a single great principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: morality in the eyes of the world. *c It is impossible to destroy men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with more respect for the laws of humanity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: See, amongst other documents, the report made by Mr. Bell
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the name of the Committee on Indian Affairs, February 24, 1830, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is most logically established and most learnedly proved, that "the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fundamental principle that the Indians had no right by virtue of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their ancient possession either of will or sovereignty, has never been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandoned either expressly or by implication." In perusing this report,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is evidently drawn up by an experienced hand, one is astonished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the facility with which the author gets rid of all arguments founded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon reason and natural right, which he designates as abstract and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theoretical principles. The more I contemplate the difference between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilized and uncivilized man with regard to the principles of justice,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the more I observe that the former contests the justice of those rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the latter simply violates.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [I leave this chapter wholly unchanged, for it has always appeared to me
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be one of the most eloquent and touching parts of this book. But it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has ceased to be prophetic; the destruction of the Indian race in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States is already consummated. In 1870 there remained but 25,731
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indians in the whole territory of the Union, and of these by far the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: largest part exist in California, Michigan, Wisconsin, Dakota, and New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mexico and Nevada. In New England, Pennsylvania, and New York the race
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is extinct; and the predictions of M. de Tocqueville are fulfilled.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: --Translator's Note.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Situation Of The Black Population In The United States, And Dangers With
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Which Its Presence Threatens The Whites
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Why it is more difficult to abolish slavery, and to efface all vestiges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of it amongst the moderns than it was amongst the ancients--In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States the prejudices of the Whites against the Blacks seem to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase in proportion as slavery is abolished--Situation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Negroes in the Northern and Southern States--Why the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolish slavery--Servitude, which debases the slave, impoverishes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: master--Contrast between the left and the right bank of the Ohio--To
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what attributable--The Black race, as well as slavery, recedes towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South--Explanation of this fact--Difficulties attendant upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the abolition of slavery in the South--Dangers to come--General
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anxiety--Foundation of a Black colony in Africa--Why the Americans of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South increase the hardships of slavery, whilst they are distressed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at its continuance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Indians will perish in the same isolated condition in which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have lived; but the destiny of the negroes is in some measure interwoven
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with that of the Europeans. These two races are attached to each other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without intermingling, and they are alike unable entirely to separate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or to combine. The most formidable of all the ills which threaten
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the future existence of the Union arises from the presence of a black
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population upon its territory; and in contemplating the cause of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present embarrassments or of the future dangers of the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the observer is invariably led to consider this as a primary fact.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The permanent evils to which mankind is subjected are usually produced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the vehement or the increasing efforts of men; but there is one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calamity which penetrated furtively into the world, and which was at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first scarcely distinguishable amidst the ordinary abuses of power; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originated with an individual whose name history has not preserved; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was wafted like some accursed germ upon a portion of the soil, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afterwards nurtured itself, grew without effort, and spreads naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the society to which it belongs. I need scarcely add that this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calamity is slavery. Christianity suppressed slavery, but the Christians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the sixteenth century re-established it--as an exception, indeed, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their social system, and restricted to one of the races of mankind; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the wound thus inflicted upon humanity, though less extensive, was at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same time rendered far more difficult of cure.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is important to make an accurate distinction between slavery itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and its consequences. The immediate evils which are produced by slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were very nearly the same in antiquity as they are amongst the moderns;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the consequences of these evils were different. The slave, amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ancients, belonged to the same race as his master, and he was often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the superior of the two in education *d and instruction. Freedom was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only distinction between them; and when freedom was conferred they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easily confounded together. The ancients, then, had a very simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means of avoiding slavery and its evil consequences, which was that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affranchisement; and they succeeded as soon as they adopted this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measure generally. Not but, in ancient States, the vestiges of servitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsisted for some time after servitude itself was abolished. There is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural prejudice which prompts men to despise whomsoever has been their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferior long after he is become their equal; and the real inequality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is produced by fortune or by law is always succeeded by an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imaginary inequality which is implanted in the manners of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, this secondary consequence of slavery was limited to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain term amongst the ancients, for the freedman bore so entire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a resemblance to those born free, that it soon became impossible to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguish him from amongst them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: It is well known that several of the most distinguished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authors of antiquity, and amongst them Aesop and Terence, were, or had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been slaves. Slaves were not always taken from barbarous nations, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chances of war reduced highly civilized men to servitude.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greatest difficulty in antiquity was that of altering the law;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst the moderns it is that of altering the manners; and, as far as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we are concerned, the real obstacles begin where those of the ancients
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: left off. This arises from the circumstance that, amongst the moderns,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the abstract and transient fact of slavery is fatally united to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: physical and permanent fact of color. The tradition of slavery dishonors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the race, and the peculiarity of the race perpetuates the tradition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery. No African has ever voluntarily emigrated to the shores of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New World; whence it must be inferred, that all the blacks who are now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be found in that hemisphere are either slaves or freedmen. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negro transmits the eternal mark of his ignominy to all his descendants;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and although the law may abolish slavery, God alone can obliterate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traces of its existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The modern slave differs from his master not only in his condition,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but in his origin. You may set the negro free, but you cannot make him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: otherwise than an alien to the European. Nor is this all; we scarcely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledge the common features of mankind in this child of debasement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whom slavery has brought amongst us. His physiognomy is to our eyes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hideous, his understanding weak, his tastes low; and we are almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclined to look upon him as a being intermediate between man and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brutes. *e The moderns, then, after they have abolished slavery, have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: three prejudices to contend against, which are less easy to attack and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: far less easy to conquer than the mere fact of servitude: the prejudice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the master, the prejudice of the race, and the prejudice of color.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: To induce the whites to abandon the opinion they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceived of the moral and intellectual inferiority of their former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slaves, the negroes must change; but as long as this opinion subsists,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to change is impossible.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
