text: It is difficult for us, who have had the good fortune to be born amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men like ourselves by nature, and equal to ourselves by law, to conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the irreconcilable differences which separate the negro from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European in America. But we may derive some faint notion of them from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: analogy. France was formerly a country in which numerous distinctions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rank existed, that had been created by the legislation. Nothing can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more fictitious than a purely legal inferiority; nothing more contrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the instinct of mankind than these permanent divisions which had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been established between beings evidently similar. Nevertheless these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divisions subsisted for ages; they still subsist in many places; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on all sides they have left imaginary vestiges, which time alone can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efface. If it be so difficult to root out an inequality which solely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originates in the law, how are those distinctions to be destroyed which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem to be based upon the immutable laws of Nature herself? When I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remember the extreme difficulty with which aristocratic bodies, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever nature they may be, are commingled with the mass of the people;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the exceeding care which they take to preserve the ideal boundaries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their caste inviolate, I despair of seeing an aristocracy disappear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is founded upon visible and indelible signs. Those who hope that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Europeans will ever mix with the negroes, appear to me to delude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves; and I am not led to any such conclusion by my own reason, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the evidence of facts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hitherto, wherever the whites have been the most powerful, they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintained the blacks in a subordinate or a servile position; wherever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the negroes have been strongest they have destroyed the whites; such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has been the only retribution which has ever taken place between the two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: races.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I see that in a certain portion of the territory of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the present day, the legal barrier which separated the two races is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tending to fall away, but not that which exists in the manners of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country; slavery recedes, but the prejudice to which it has given birth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains stationary. Whosoever has inhabited the United States must have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceived that in those parts of the Union in which the negroes are no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer slaves, they have in no wise drawn nearer to the whites. On the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, the prejudice of the race appears to be stronger in the States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which have abolished slavery, than in those where it still exists; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nowhere is it so intolerant as in those States where servitude has never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been known.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is true, that in the North of the Union, marriages may be legally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contracted between negroes and whites; but public opinion would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stigmatize a man who should connect himself with a negress as infamous,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it would be difficult to meet with a single instance of such a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: union. The electoral franchise has been conferred upon the negroes in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all the States in which slavery has been abolished; but if they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: come forward to vote, their lives are in danger. If oppressed, they may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bring an action at law, but they will find none but whites amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their judges; and although they may legally serve as jurors, prejudice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repulses them from that office. The same schools do not receive the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: child of the black and of the European. In the theatres, gold cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: procure a seat for the servile race beside their former masters; in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hospitals they lie apart; and although they are allowed to invoke the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same Divinity as the whites, it must be at a different altar, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own churches, with their own clergy. The gates of Heaven are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: closed against these unhappy beings; but their inferiority is continued
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the very confines of the other world; when the negro is defunct, his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bones are cast aside, and the distinction of condition prevails even in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the equality of death. The negro is free, but he can share neither the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights, nor the pleasures, nor the labor, nor the afflictions, nor the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tomb of him whose equal he has been declared to be; and he cannot meet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him upon fair terms in life or in death.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the South, where slavery still exists, the negroes are less carefully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kept apart; they sometimes share the labor and the recreations of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whites; the whites consent to intermix with them to a certain extent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and although the legislation treats them more harshly, the habits of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people are more tolerant and compassionate. In the South the master is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not afraid to raise his slave to his own standing, because he knows that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he can in a moment reduce him to the dust at pleasure. In the North the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: white no longer distinctly perceives the barrier which separates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him from the degraded race, and he shuns the negro with the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pertinacity, since he fears lest they should some day be confounded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst the Americans of the South, nature sometimes reasserts her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights, and restores a transient equality between the blacks and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whites; but in the North pride restrains the most imperious of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions. The American of the Northern States would perhaps allow the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negress to share his licentious pleasures, if the laws of his country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: did not declare that she may aspire to be the legitimate partner of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bed; but he recoils with horror from her who might become his wife.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus it is, in the United States, that the prejudice which repels the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes seems to increase in proportion as they are emancipated, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality is sanctioned by the manners whilst it is effaced from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws of the country. But if the relative position of the two races which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabit the United States is such as I have described, it may be asked
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: why the Americans have abolished slavery in the North of the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: why they maintain it in the South, and why they aggravate its hardships
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there? The answer is easily given. It is not for the good of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes, but for that of the whites, that measures are taken to abolish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery in the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first negroes were imported into Virginia about the year 1621. *f
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America, therefore, as well as in the rest of the globe, slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originated in the South. Thence it spread from one settlement to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another; but the number of slaves diminished towards the Northern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, and the negro population was always very limited in New England.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *g
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: See Beverley's "History of Virginia." See also in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jefferson's "Memoirs" some curious details concerning the introduction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of negroes into Virginia, and the first Act which prohibited the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importation of them in 1778.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: The number of slaves was less considerable in the North,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the advantages resulting from slavery were not more contested there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than in the South. In 1740, the Legislature of the State of New York
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declared that the direct importation of slaves ought to be encouraged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as much as possible, and smuggling severely punished in order not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discourage the fair trader. (Kent's "Commentaries," vol. ii. p. 206.)
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Curious researches, by Belknap, upon slavery in New England, are to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found in the "Historical Collection of Massachusetts," vol. iv. p. 193.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It appears that negroes were introduced there in 1630, but that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation and manners of the people were opposed to slavery from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first; see also, in the same work, the manner in which public opinion,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and afterwards the laws, finally put an end to slavery.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A century had scarcely elapsed since the foundation of the colonies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when the attention of the planters was struck by the extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact, that the provinces which were comparatively destitute of slaves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increased in population, in wealth, and in prosperity more rapidly than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those which contained the greatest number of negroes. In the former,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however, the inhabitants were obliged to cultivate the soil themselves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or by hired laborers; in the latter they were furnished with hands for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they paid no wages; yet although labor and expenses were on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the one side, and ease with economy on the other, the former were in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of the most advantageous system. This consequence seemed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the more difficult to explain, since the settlers, who all belonged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the same European race, had the same habits, the same civilization,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same laws, and their shades of difference were extremely slight.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Time, however, continued to advance, and the Anglo-Americans, spreading
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beyond the coasts of the Atlantic Ocean, penetrated farther and farther
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the solitudes of the West; they met with a new soil and an unwonted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: climate; the obstacles which opposed them were of the most various
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character; their races intermingled, the inhabitants of the South went
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up towards the North, those of the North descended to the South; but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the midst of all these causes, the same result occurred at every step,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in general, the colonies in which there were no slaves became more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: populous and more rich than those in which slavery flourished. The more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress was made, the more was it shown that slavery, which is so cruel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the slave, is prejudicial to the master.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part IV
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But this truth was most satisfactorily demonstrated when civilization
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reached the banks of the Ohio. The stream which the Indians had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguished by the name of Ohio, or Beautiful River, waters one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most magnificent valleys that has ever been made the abode of man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Undulating lands extend upon both shores of the Ohio, whose soil affords
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inexhaustible treasures to the laborer; on either bank the air is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wholesome and the climate mild, and each of them forms the extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frontier of a vast State: That which follows the numerous windings of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Ohio upon the left is called Kentucky, that upon the right bears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the name of the river. These two States only differ in a single respect;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Kentucky has admitted slavery, but the State of Ohio has prohibited the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of slaves within its borders. *h
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: Not only is slavery prohibited in Ohio, but no free negroes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are allowed to enter the territory of that State, or to hold property in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. See the Statutes of Ohio.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the traveller who floats down the current of the Ohio to the spot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where that river falls into the Mississippi, may be said to sail between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty and servitude; and a transient inspection of the surrounding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects will convince him as to which of the two is most favorable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind. Upon the left bank of the stream the population is rare; from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time to time one descries a troop of slaves loitering in the half-desert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fields; the primaeval forest recurs at every turn; society seems to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asleep, man to be idle, and nature alone offers a scene of activity and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of life. From the right bank, on the contrary, a confused hum is heard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which proclaims the presence of industry; the fields are covered with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abundant harvests, the elegance of the dwellings announces the taste and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: activity of the laborer, and man appears to be in the enjoyment of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth and contentment which is the reward of labor. *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: The activity of Ohio is not confined to individuals, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the undertakings of the State are surprisingly great; a canal has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established between Lake Erie and the Ohio, by means of which the valley
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Mississippi communicates with the river of the North, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European commodities which arrive at New York may be forwarded by water
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to New Orleans across five hundred leagues of continent.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The State of Kentucky was founded in 1775, the State of Ohio only twelve
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years later; but twelve years are more in America than half a century in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe, and, at the present day, the population of Ohio exceeds that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Kentucky by two hundred and fifty thousand souls. *j These opposite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences of slavery and freedom may readily be understood, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suffice to explain many of the differences which we remark between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization of antiquity and that of our own time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: The exact numbers given by the census of 1830 were:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Kentucky, 688,-844; Ohio, 937,679. [In 1890 the population of Ohio was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Upon the left bank of the Ohio labor is confounded with the idea of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery, upon the right bank it is identified with that of prosperity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and improvement; on the one side it is degraded, on the other it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honored; on the former territory no white laborers can be found, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they would be afraid of assimilating themselves to the negroes; on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter no one is idle, for the white population extends its activity and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its intelligence to every kind of employment. Thus the men whose task
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is to cultivate the rich soil of Kentucky are ignorant and lukewarm;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst those who are active and enlightened either do nothing or pass
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over into the State of Ohio, where they may work without dishonor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is true that in Kentucky the planters are not obliged to pay wages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the slaves whom they employ; but they derive small profits from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor, whilst the wages paid to free workmen would be returned with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest in the value of their services. The free workman is paid, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he does his work quicker than the slave, and rapidity of execution is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one of the great elements of economy. The white sells his services, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are only purchased at the times at which they may be useful; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: black can claim no remuneration for his toil, but the expense of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance is perpetual; he must be supported in his old age as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as in the prime of manhood, in his profitless infancy as well as in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the productive years of youth. Payment must equally be made in order to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtain the services of either class of men: the free workman receives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his wages in money, the slave in education, in food, in care, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clothing. The money which a master spends in the maintenance of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slaves goes gradually and in detail, so that it is scarcely perceived;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the salary of the free workman is paid in a round sum, which appears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only to enrich the individual who receives it, but in the end the slave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has cost more than the free servant, and his labor is less productive.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *k
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: Independently of these causes, which, wherever free workmen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abound, render their labor more productive and more economical than that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of slaves, another cause may be pointed out which is peculiar to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States: the sugar-cane has hitherto been cultivated with success
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only upon the banks of the Mississippi, near the mouth of that river in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Gulf of Mexico. In Louisiana the cultivation of the sugar-cane is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exceedingly lucrative, and nowhere does a laborer earn so much by his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: work, and, as there is always a certain relation between the cost of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: production and the value of the produce, the price of slaves is very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: high in Louisiana. But Louisiana is one of the confederated States, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slaves may be carried thither from all parts of the Union; the price
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: given for slaves in New Orleans consequently raises the value of slaves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all the other markets. The consequence of this is, that in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries where the land is less productive, the cost of slave labor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is still very considerable, which gives an additional advantage to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: competition of free labor.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The influence of slavery extends still further; it affects the character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the master, and imparts a peculiar tendency to his ideas and his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tastes. Upon both banks of the Ohio, the character of the inhabitants is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enterprising and energetic; but this vigor is very differently exercised
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the two States. The white inhabitant of Ohio, who is obliged to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsist by his own exertions, regards temporal prosperity as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal aim of his existence; and as the country which he occupies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: presents inexhaustible resources to his industry and ever-varying lures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to his activity, his acquisitive ardor surpasses the ordinary limits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human cupidity: he is tormented by the desire of wealth, and he boldly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enters upon every path which fortune opens to him; he becomes a sailor,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a pioneer, an artisan, or a laborer with the same indifference, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supports, with equal constancy, the fatigues and the dangers incidental
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to these various professions; the resources of his intelligence are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: astonishing, and his avidity in the pursuit of gain amounts to a species
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of heroism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the Kentuckian scorns not only labor, but all the undertakings which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor promotes; as he lives in an idle independence, his tastes are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those of an idle man; money loses a portion of its value in his eyes;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he covets wealth much less than pleasure and excitement; and the energy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which his neighbor devotes to gain, turns with him to a passionate love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of field sports and military exercises; he delights in violent bodily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertion, he is familiar with the use of arms, and is accustomed from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a very early age to expose his life in single combat. Thus slavery not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only prevents the whites from becoming opulent, but even from desiring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to become so.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the same causes have been continually producing opposite effects for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the last two centuries in the British colonies of North America, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have established a very striking difference between the commercial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capacity of the inhabitants of the South and those of the North. At the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present day it is only the Northern States which are in possession
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of shipping, manufactures, railroads, and canals. This difference is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceptible not only in comparing the North with the South, but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparing the several Southern States. Almost all the individuals who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carry on commercial operations, or who endeavor to turn slave labor to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: account in the most Southern districts of the Union, have emigrated from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the North. The natives of the Northern States are constantly spreading
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over that portion of the American territory where they have less to fear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from competition; they discover resources there which escaped the notice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the inhabitants; and, as they comply with a system which they do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approve, they succeed in turning it to better advantage than those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first founded and who still maintain it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Were I inclined to continue this parallel, I could easily prove that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all the differences which may be remarked between the characters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Americans in the Southern and in the Northern States have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originated in slavery; but this would divert me from my subject, and my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present intention is not to point out all the consequences of servitude,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but those effects which it has produced upon the prosperity of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries which have admitted it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The influence of slavery upon the production of wealth must have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very imperfectly known in antiquity, as slavery then obtained throughout
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the civilized world; and the nations which were unacquainted with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it were barbarous. And indeed Christianity only abolished slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by advocating the claims of the slave; at the present time it may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attacked in the name of the master, and, upon this point, interest is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reconciled with morality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As these truths became apparent in the United States, slavery receded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before the progress of experience. Servitude had begun in the South, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had thence spread towards the North; but it now retires again. Freedom,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which started from the North, now descends uninterruptedly towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South. Amongst the great States, Pennsylvania now constitutes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extreme limit of slavery to the North: but even within those limits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the slave system is shaken: Maryland, which is immediately below
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Pennsylvania, is preparing for its abolition; and Virginia, which comes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: next to Maryland, is already discussing its utility and its dangers. *l
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: A peculiar reason contributes to detach the two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: last-mentioned States from the cause of slavery. The former wealth of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this part of the Union was principally derived from the cultivation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tobacco. This cultivation is specially carried on by slaves; but within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the last few years the market-price of tobacco has diminished, whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the value of the slaves remains the same. Thus the ratio between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cost of production and the value of the produce is changed. The natives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Maryland and Virginia are therefore more disposed than they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thirty years ago, to give up slave labor in the cultivation of tobacco,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or to give up slavery and tobacco at the same time.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No great change takes place in human institutions without involving
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst its causes the law of inheritance. When the law of primogeniture
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtained in the South, each family was represented by a wealthy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual, who was neither compelled nor induced to labor; and he was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surrounded, as by parasitic plants, by the other members of his family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who were then excluded by law from sharing the common inheritance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and who led the same kind of life as himself. The very same thing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then occurred in all the families of the South as still happens in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealthy families of some countries in Europe, namely, that the younger
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sons remain in the same state of idleness as their elder brother,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without being as rich as he is. This identical result seems to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produced in Europe and in America by wholly analogous causes. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South of the United States the whole race of whites formed an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic body, which was headed by a certain number of privileged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals, whose wealth was permanent, and whose leisure was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereditary. These leaders of the American nobility kept alive the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traditional prejudices of the white race in the body of which they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the representatives, and maintained the honor of inactive life. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy contained many who were poor, but none who would work; its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members preferred want to labor, consequently no competition was set on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foot against negro laborers and slaves, and, whatever opinion might be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertained as to the utility of their efforts, it was indispensable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: employ them, since there was no one else to work.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No sooner was the law of primogeniture abolished than fortunes began
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to diminish, and all the families of the country were simultaneously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reduced to a state in which labor became necessary to procure the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of subsistence: several of them have since entirely disappeared, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all of them learned to look forward to the time at which it would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary for everyone to provide for his own wants. Wealthy individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are still to be met with, but they no longer constitute a compact and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereditary body, nor have they been able to adopt a line of conduct in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they could persevere, and which they could infuse into all ranks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society. The prejudice which stigmatized labor was in the first place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandoned by common consent; the number of needy men was increased, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the needy were allowed to gain a laborious subsistence without blushing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for their exertions. Thus one of the most immediate consequences of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: partible quality of estates has been to create a class of free laborers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As soon as a competition was set on foot between the free laborer and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the slave, the inferiority of the latter became manifest, and slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was attacked in its fundamental principle, which is the interest of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: master.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As slavery recedes, the black population follows its retrograde course,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and returns with it towards those tropical regions from which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originally came. However singular this fact may at first appear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be, it may readily be explained. Although the Americans abolish the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of slavery, they do not set their slaves free. To illustrate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this remark, I will quote the example of the State of New York. In 1788,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State of New York prohibited the sale of slaves within its limits,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which was an indirect method of prohibiting the importation of blacks.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thenceforward the number of negroes could only increase according to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ratio of the natural increase of population. But eight years later
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a more decisive measure was taken, and it was enacted that all children
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: born of slave parents after July 4, 1799, should be free. No increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could then take place, and although slaves still existed, slavery might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be said to be abolished.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From the time at which a Northern State prohibited the importation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slaves, no slaves were brought from the South to be sold in its markets.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, as the sale of slaves was forbidden in that State,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an owner was no longer able to get rid of his slave (who thus became a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: burdensome possession) otherwise than by transporting him to the South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But when a Northern State declared that the son of the slave should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: born free, the slave lost a large portion of his market value, since his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: posterity was no longer included in the bargain, and the owner had then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a strong interest in transporting him to the South. Thus the same law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevents the slaves of the South from coming to the Northern States, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: drives those of the North to the South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The want of free hands is felt in a State in proportion as the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slaves decreases. But in proportion as labor is performed by free hands,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slave labor becomes less productive; and the slave is then a useless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or onerous possession, whom it is important to export to those Southern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States where the same competition is not to be feared. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolition of slavery does not set the slave free, but it merely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transfers him from one master to another, and from the North to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The emancipated negroes, and those born after the abolition of slavery,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not, indeed, migrate from the North to the South; but their situation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with regard to the Europeans is not unlike that of the aborigines of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America; they remain half civilized, and deprived of their rights in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the midst of a population which is far superior to them in wealth and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge; where they are exposed to the tyranny of the laws *m and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intolerance of the people. On some accounts they are still more to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pitied than the Indians, since they are haunted by the reminiscence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery, and they cannot claim possession of a single portion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soil: many of them perish miserably, *n and the rest congregate in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great towns, where they perform the meanest offices, and lead a wretched
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and precarious existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: The States in which slavery is abolished usually do what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they can to render their territory disagreeable to the negroes as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a place of residence; and as a kind of emulation exists between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different States in this respect, the unhappy blacks can only choose the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: least of the evils which beset them.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: There is a very great difference between the mortality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the blacks and of the whites in the States in which slavery is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolished; from 1820 to 1831 only one out of forty-two individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the white population died in Philadelphia; but one negro out of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: twenty-one individuals of the black population died in the same space of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time. The mortality is by no means so great amongst the negroes who are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still slaves. (See Emerson's "Medical Statistics," p. 28.)]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But even if the number of negroes continued to increase as rapidly as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when they were still in a state of slavery, as the number of whites
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augments with twofold rapidity since the abolition of slavery, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blacks would soon be, as it were, lost in the midst of a strange
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A district which is cultivated by slaves is in general more scantily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peopled than a district cultivated by free labor: moreover, America is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still a new country, and a State is therefore not half peopled at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time when it abolishes slavery. No sooner is an end put to slavery than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the want of free labor is felt, and a crowd of enterprising adventurers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediately arrive from all parts of the country, who hasten to profit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the fresh resources which are then opened to industry. The soil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is soon divided amongst them, and a family of white settlers takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of each tract of country. Besides which, European emigration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is exclusively directed to the free States; for what would be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fate of a poor emigrant who crosses the Atlantic in search of ease and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happiness if he were to land in a country where labor is stigmatized as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degrading?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the white population grows by its natural increase, and at the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time by the immense influx of emigrants; whilst the black population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: receives no emigrants, and is upon its decline. The proportion which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existed between the two races is soon inverted. The negroes constitute a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scanty remnant, a poor tribe of vagrants, which is lost in the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an immense people in full possession of the land; and the presence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the blacks is only marked by the injustice and the hardships of which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are the unhappy victims.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In several of the Western States the negro race never made its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appearance, and in all the Northern States it is rapidly declining. Thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great question of its future condition is confined within a narrow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circle, where it becomes less formidable, though not more easy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The more we descend towards the South, the more difficult does it become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to abolish slavery with advantage: and this arises from several physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes which it is important to point out.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first of these causes is the climate; it is well known that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion as Europeans approach the tropics they suffer more from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor. Many of the Americans even assert that within a certain latitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the exertions which a negro can make without danger are fatal to them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *o but I do not think that this opinion, which is so favorable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the indolence of the inhabitants of southern regions, is confirmed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience. The southern parts of the Union are not hotter than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South of Italy and of Spain; *p and it may be asked why the European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot work as well there as in the two latter countries. If slavery has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been abolished in Italy and in Spain without causing the destruction of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the masters, why should not the same thing take place in the Union? I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot believe that nature has prohibited the Europeans in Georgia and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Floridas, under pain of death, from raising the means of subsistence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the soil, but their labor would unquestionably be more irksome and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less productive to them than to the inhabitants of New England. As the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free workman thus loses a portion of his superiority over the slave in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Southern States, there are fewer inducements to abolish slavery.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: This is true of the spots in which rice is cultivated;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rice-grounds, which are unwholesome in all countries, are particularly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous in those regions which are exposed to the beams of a tropical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sun. Europeans would not find it easy to cultivate the soil in that part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the New World if it must be necessarily be made to produce rice; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may they not subsist without rice-grounds?]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: These States are nearer to the equator than Italy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Spain, but the temperature of the continent of America is very much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lower than that of Europe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Spanish Government formerly caused a certain number of peasants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the Acores to be transported into a district of Louisiana called
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Attakapas, by way of experiment. These settlers still cultivate the soil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without the assistance of slaves, but their industry is so languid as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scarcely to supply their most necessary wants.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the plants of Europe grow in the northern parts of the Union; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South has special productions of its own. It has been observed that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slave labor is a very expensive method of cultivating corn. The farmer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of corn land in a country where slavery is unknown habitually retains a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small number of laborers in his service, and at seed-time and harvest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he hires several additional hands, who only live at his cost for a short
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: period. But the agriculturist in a slave State is obliged to keep a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large number of slaves the whole year round, in order to sow his fields
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to gather in his crops, although their services are only required
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for a few weeks; but slaves are unable to wait till they are hired, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to subsist by their own labor in the mean time like free laborers; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to have their services they must be bought. Slavery, independently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its general disadvantages, is therefore still more inapplicable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries in which corn is cultivated than to those which produce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crops of a different kind. The cultivation of tobacco, of cotton, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially of the sugar-cane, demands, on the other hand, unremitting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention: and women and children are employed in it, whose services are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of but little use in the cultivation of wheat. Thus slavery is naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more fitted to the countries from which these productions are derived.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Tobacco, cotton, and the sugar-cane are exclusively grown in the South,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they form one of the principal sources of the wealth of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. If slavery were abolished, the inhabitants of the South would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be constrained to adopt one of two alternatives: they must either change
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their system of cultivation, and then they would come into competition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the more active and more experienced inhabitants of the North; or,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if they continued to cultivate the same produce without slave labor,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they would have to support the competition of the other States of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South, which might still retain their slaves. Thus, peculiar reasons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for maintaining slavery exist in the South which do not operate in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But there is yet another motive which is more cogent than all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others: the South might indeed, rigorously speaking, abolish slavery;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but how should it rid its territory of the black population? Slaves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and slavery are driven from the North by the same law, but this twofold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: result cannot be hoped for in the South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The arguments which I have adduced to show that slavery is more natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more advantageous in the South than in the North, sufficiently prove
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the number of slaves must be far greater in the former districts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It was to the southern settlements that the first Africans were brought,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it is there that the greatest number of them have always been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imported. As we advance towards the South, the prejudice which sanctions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idleness increases in power. In the States nearest to the tropics there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not a single white laborer; the negroes are consequently much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more numerous in the South than in the North. And, as I have already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observed, this disproportion increases daily, since the negroes are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transferred to one part of the Union as soon as slavery is abolished in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other. Thus the black population augments in the South, not only by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its natural fecundity, but by the compulsory emigration of the negroes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the North; and the African race has causes of increase in the South
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very analogous to those which so powerfully accelerate the growth of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European race in the North.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the State of Maine there is one negro in 300 inhabitants; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts, one in 100; in New York, two in 100; in Pennsylvania,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: three in the same number; in Maryland, thirty-four; in Virginia,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forty-two; and lastly, in South Carolina *q fifty-five per cent. Such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was the proportion of the black population to the whites in the year
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1830. But this proportion is perpetually changing, as it constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decreases in the North and augments in the South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: We find it asserted in an American work, entitled "Letters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the Colonization Society," by Mr. Carey, 1833, "That for the last
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forty years the black race has increased more rapidly than the white
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: race in the State of South Carolina; and that if we take the average
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population of the five States of the South into which slaves were first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced, viz., Maryland, Virginia, South Carolina, North Carolina,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and Georgia, we shall find that from 1790 to 1830 the whites have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augmented in the proportion of 80 to 100, and the blacks in that of 112
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, in 1830, the population of the two races stood as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: follows:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States where slavery is abolished, 6,565,434 whites; 120,520 blacks.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Slave States, 3,960,814 whites; 2,208,102 blacks. [In 1890 the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States contained a population of 54,983,890 whites, and 7,638,360
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is evident that the most Southern States of the Union cannot abolish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery without incurring very great dangers, which the North had no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason to apprehend when it emancipated its black population. We
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have already shown the system by which the Northern States secure the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transition from slavery to freedom, by keeping the present generation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in chains, and setting their descendants free; by this means the negroes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are gradually introduced into society; and whilst the men who might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abuse their freedom are kept in a state of servitude, those who are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emancipated may learn the art of being free before they become their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: masters. But it would be difficult to apply this method in the South. To
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declare that all the negroes born after a certain period shall be free,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to introduce the principle and the notion of liberty into the heart
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of slavery; the blacks whom the law thus maintains in a state of slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from which their children are delivered, are astonished at so unequal a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fate, and their astonishment is only the prelude to their impatience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and irritation. Thenceforward slavery loses, in their eyes, that kind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of moral power which it derived from time and habit; it is reduced to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a mere palpable abuse of force. The Northern States had nothing to fear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the contrast, because in them the blacks were few in number, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the white population was very considerable. But if this faint dawn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of freedom were to show two millions of men their true position, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppressors would have reason to tremble. After having affranchised the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: children of their slaves the Europeans of the Southern States would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very shortly be obliged to extend the same benefit to the whole black
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part V
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the North, as I have already remarked, a twofold migration ensues
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the abolition of slavery, or even precedes that event when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances have rendered it probable; the slaves quit the country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be transported southwards; and the whites of the Northern States, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well as the emigrants from Europe, hasten to fill up their place. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these two causes cannot operate in the same manner in the Southern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. On the one hand, the mass of slaves is too great for any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expectation of their ever being removed from the country to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertained; and on the other hand, the Europeans and Anglo-Americans of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the North are afraid to come to inhabit a country in which labor has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet been reinstated in its rightful honors. Besides, they very justly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: look upon the States in which the proportion of the negroes equals or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exceeds that of the whites, as exposed to very great dangers; and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refrain from turning their activity in that direction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the inhabitants of the South would not be able, like their Northern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countrymen, to initiate the slaves gradually into a state of freedom by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolishing slavery; they have no means of perceptibly diminishing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: black population, and they would remain unsupported to repress its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excesses. So that in the course of a few years, a great people of free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes would exist in the heart of a white nation of equal size.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same abuses of power which still maintain slavery, would then become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the source of the most alarming perils which the white population of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South might have to apprehend. At the present time the descendants of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Europeans are the sole owners of the land; the absolute masters of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all labor; and the only persons who are possessed of wealth, knowledge,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and arms. The black is destitute of all these advantages, but he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subsists without them because he is a slave. If he were free, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to provide for his own subsistence, would it be possible for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him to remain without these things and to support life? Or would not the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very instruments of the present superiority of the white, whilst slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exists, expose him to a thousand dangers if it were abolished?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As long as the negro remains a slave, he may be kept in a condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not very far removed from that of the brutes; but, with his liberty,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he cannot but acquire a degree of instruction which will enable him to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appreciate his misfortunes, and to discern a remedy for them. Moreover,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there exists a singular principle of relative justice which is very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: firmly implanted in the human heart. Men are much more forcibly struck
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by those inequalities which exist within the circle of the same class,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than with those which may be remarked between different classes. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more easy for them to admit slavery, than to allow several millions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of citizens to exist under a load of eternal infamy and hereditary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wretchedness. In the North the population of freed negroes feels these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardships and resents these indignities; but its numbers and its powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are small, whilst in the South it would be numerous and strong.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As soon as it is admitted that the whites and the emancipated blacks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are placed upon the same territory in the situation of two alien
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities, it will readily be understood that there are but two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alternatives for the future; the negroes and the whites must either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wholly part or wholly mingle. I have already expressed the conviction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I entertain as to the latter event. *r I do not imagine that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the white and black races will ever live in any country upon an equal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: footing. But I believe the difficulty to be still greater in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States than elsewhere. An isolated individual may surmount the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudices of religion, of his country, or of his race, and if this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual is a king he may effect surprising changes in society; but a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole people cannot rise, as it were, above itself. A despot who should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject the Americans and their former slaves to the same yoke, might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps succeed in commingling their races; but as long as the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy remains at the head of affairs, no one will undertake so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult a task; and it may be foreseen that the freer the white
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population of the United States becomes, the more isolated will it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain. *s
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: This opinion is sanctioned by authorities infinitely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weightier than anything that I can say: thus, for instance, it is stated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the "Memoirs of Jefferson" (as collected by M. Conseil), "Nothing is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more clearly written in the book of destiny than the emancipation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blacks; and it is equally certain that the two races will never live in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a state of equal freedom under the same government, so insurmountable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are the barriers which nature, habit, and opinions have established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between them."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote s: If the British West India planters had governed themselves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they would assuredly not have passed the Slave Emancipation Bill which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mother-country has recently imposed upon them.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have previously observed that the mixed race is the true bond of union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the Europeans and the Indians; just so the mulattoes are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true means of transition between the white and the negro; so that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wherever mulattoes abound, the intermixture of the two races is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible. In some parts of America, the European and the negro races
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are so crossed by one another, that it is rare to meet with a man who is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely black, or entirely white: when they are arrived at this point,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the two races may really be said to be combined; or rather to have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absorbed in a third race, which is connected with both without being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: identical with either.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of all the Europeans the English are those who have mixed least with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes. More mulattoes are to be seen in the South of the Union than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the North, but still they are infinitely more scarce than in any other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European colony: mulattoes are by no means numerous in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States; they have no force peculiar to themselves, and when quarrels
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originating in differences of color take place, they generally side
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the whites; just as the lackeys of the great, in Europe, assume the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemptuous airs of nobility to the lower orders.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The pride of origin, which is natural to the English, is singularly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augmented by the personal pride which democratic liberty fosters amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans: the white citizen of the United States is proud of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: race, and proud of himself. But if the whites and the negroes do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intermingle in the North of the Union, how should they mix in the South?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Can it be supposed for an instant, that an American of the Southern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, placed, as he must forever be, between the white man with all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his physical and moral superiority and the negro, will ever think of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preferring the latter? The Americans of the Southern States have two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful passions which will always keep them aloof; the first is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fear of being assimilated to the negroes, their former slaves; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: second the dread of sinking below the whites, their neighbors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I were called upon to predict what will probably occur at some future
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, I should say, that the abolition of slavery in the South will,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the common course of things, increase the repugnance of the white
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population for the men of color. I found this opinion upon the analogous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observation which I already had occasion to make in the North. I there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarked that the white inhabitants of the North avoid the negroes with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increasing care, in proportion as the legal barriers of separation are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removed by the legislature; and why should not the same result
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take place in the South? In the North, the whites are deterred from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intermingling with the blacks by the fear of an imaginary danger; in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South, where the danger would be real, I cannot imagine that the fear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be less general.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If, on the one hand, it be admitted (and the fact is unquestionable)
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the colored population perpetually accumulates in the extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South, and that it increases more rapidly than that of the whites; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if, on the other hand, it be allowed that it is impossible to foresee
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a time at which the whites and the blacks will be so intermingled as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derive the same benefits from society; must it not be inferred that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blacks and the whites will, sooner or later, come to open strife in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Southern States of the Union? But if it be asked what the issue of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggle is likely to be, it will readily be understood that we are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: here left to form a very vague surmise of the truth. The human mind may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeed in tracing a wide circle, as it were, which includes the course
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of future events; but within that circle a thousand various chances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and circumstances may direct it in as many different ways; and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every picture of the future there is a dim spot, which the eye of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understanding cannot penetrate. It appears, however, to be extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: probable that in the West Indian Islands the white race is destined to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be subdued, and the black population to share the same fate upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the West India Islands the white planters are surrounded by an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense black population; on the continent, the blacks are placed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the ocean and an innumerable people, which already extends over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them in a dense mass, from the icy confines of Canada to the frontiers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Virginia, and from the banks of the Missouri to the shores of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Atlantic. If the white citizens of North America remain united, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be supposed that the negroes will escape the destruction with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they are menaced; they must be subdued by want or by the sword.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the black population which is accumulated along the coast of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Gulf of Mexico, has a chance of success if the American Union is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dissolved when the struggle between the two races begins. If the federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tie were broken, the citizens of the South would be wrong to rely upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any lasting succor from their Northern countrymen. The latter are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well aware that the danger can never reach them; and unless they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constrained to march to the assistance of the South by a positive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obligation, it may be foreseen that the sympathy of color will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insufficient to stimulate their exertions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Yet, at whatever period the strife may break out, the whites of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South, even if they are abandoned to their own resources, will enter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the lists with an immense superiority of knowledge and of the means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: warfare; but the blacks will have numerical strength and the energy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despair upon their side, and these are powerful resources to men who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have taken up arms. The fate of the white population of the Southern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States will, perhaps, be similar to that of the Moors in Spain. After
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having occupied the land for centuries, it will perhaps be forced to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retire to the country whence its ancestors came, and to abandon to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes the possession of a territory, which Providence seems to have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more peculiarly destined for them, since they can subsist and labor in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it more easily that the whites.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The danger of a conflict between the white and the black inhabitants of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Southern States of the Union--a danger which, however remote it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be, is inevitable--perpetually haunts the imagination of the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The inhabitants of the North make it a common topic of conversation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although they have no direct injury to fear from the struggle; but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vainly endeavor to devise some means of obviating the misfortunes which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they foresee. In the Southern States the subject is not discussed: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: planter does not allude to the future in conversing with strangers; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen does not communicate his apprehensions to his friends; he seeks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to conceal them from himself; but there is something more alarming in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tacit forebodings of the South, than in the clamorous fears of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Northern States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This all-pervading disquietude has given birth to an undertaking which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is but little known, but which may have the effect of changing the fate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a portion of the human race. From apprehension of the dangers which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have just been describing, a certain number of American citizens have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed a society for the purpose of exporting to the coast of Guinea,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at their own expense, such free negroes as may be willing to escape from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the oppression to which they are subject. *t In 1820, the society to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I allude formed a settlement in Africa, upon the seventh degree
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of north latitude, which bears the name of Liberia. The most recent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligence informs us that 2,500 negroes are collected there; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have introduced the democratic institutions of America into the country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their forefathers; and Liberia has a representative system of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, negro jurymen, negro magistrates, and negro priests;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: churches have been built, newspapers established, and, by a singular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change in the vicissitudes of the world, white men are prohibited from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sojourning within the settlement. *u
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote t: This society assumed the name of "The Society for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Colonization of the Blacks." See its annual reports; and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particularly the fifteenth. See also the pamphlet, to which allusion has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already been made, entitled "Letters on the Colonization Society, and on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its probable Results," by Mr. Carey, Philadelphia, 1833.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote u: This last regulation was laid down by the founders of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the settlement; they apprehended that a state of things might arise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in Africa similar to that which exists on the frontiers of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, and that if the negroes, like the Indians, were brought into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collision with a people more enlightened than themselves, they would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destroyed before they could be civilized.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is indeed a strange caprice of fortune. Two hundred years have now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elapsed since the inhabitants of Europe undertook to tear the negro
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from his family and his home, in order to transport him to the shores of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
