text: North America; at the present day, the European settlers are engaged in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sending back the descendants of those very negroes to the Continent from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they were originally taken; and the barbarous Africans have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brought into contact with civilization in the midst of bondage, and have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become acquainted with free political institutions in slavery. Up to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present time Africa has been closed against the arts and sciences of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whites; but the inventions of Europe will perhaps penetrate into those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regions, now that they are introduced by Africans themselves. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settlement of Liberia is founded upon a lofty and a most fruitful idea;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but whatever may be its results with regard to the Continent of Africa,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it can afford no remedy to the New World.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In twelve years the Colonization Society has transported 2,500 negroes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to Africa; in the same space of time about 700,000 blacks were born in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States. If the colony of Liberia were so situated as to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able to receive thousands of new inhabitants every year, and if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes were in a state to be sent thither with advantage; if the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were to supply the society with annual subsidies, *v and to transport
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the negroes to Africa in the vessels of the State, it would still be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unable to counterpoise the natural increase of population amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blacks; and as it could not remove as many men in a year as are born
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon its territory within the same space of time, it would fail in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suspending the growth of the evil which is daily increasing in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. *w The negro race will never leave those shores of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent, to which it was brought by the passions and the vices of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europeans; and it will not disappear from the New World as long as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continues to exist. The inhabitants of the United States may retard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the calamities which they apprehend, but they cannot now destroy their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efficient cause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote v: Nor would these be the only difficulties attendant upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the undertaking; if the Union undertook to buy up the negroes now in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, in order to transport them to Africa, the price of slaves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increasing with their scarcity, would soon become enormous; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States of the North would never consent to expend such great sums for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purpose which would procure such small advantages to themselves. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union took possession of the slaves in the Southern States by force, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at a rate determined by law, an insurmountable resistance would arise in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that part of the country. Both alternatives are equally impossible.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote w: In 1830 there were in the United States 2,010,327 slaves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and 319,439 free blacks, in all 2,329,766 negroes: which formed about
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one-fifth of the total population of the United States at that time.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am obliged to confess that I do not regard the abolition of slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a means of warding off the struggle of the two races in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. The negroes may long remain slaves without complaining; but if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are once raised to the level of free men, they will soon revolt at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being deprived of all their civil rights; and as they cannot become the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equals of the whites, they will speedily declare themselves as enemies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the North everything contributed to facilitate the emancipation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the slaves; and slavery was abolished, without placing the free negroes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a position which could become formidable, since their number was too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small for them ever to claim the exercise of their rights. But such is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not the case in the South. The question of slavery was a question of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commerce and manufacture for the slave-owners in the North; for those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South, it is a question of life and death. God forbid that I should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seek to justify the principle of negro slavery, as has been done by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some American writers! But I only observe that all the countries which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formerly adopted that execrable principle are not equally able to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandon it at the present time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When I contemplate the condition of the South, I can only discover two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alternatives which may be adopted by the white inhabitants of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States; viz., either to emancipate the negroes, and to intermingle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with them; or, remaining isolated from them, to keep them in a state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery as long as possible. All intermediate measures seem to me likely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to terminate, and that shortly, in the most horrible of civil wars, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps in the extirpation of one or other of the two races. Such is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: view which the Americans of the South take of the question, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: act consistently with it. As they are determined not to mingle with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes, they refuse to emancipate them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not that the inhabitants of the South regard slavery as necessary to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth of the planter, for on this point many of them agree with their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Northern countrymen in freely admitting that slavery is prejudicial to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their interest; but they are convinced that, however prejudicial it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be, they hold their lives upon no other tenure. The instruction which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: now diffused in the South has convinced the inhabitants that slavery is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: injurious to the slave-owner, but it has also shown them, more clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than before, that no means exist of getting rid of its bad consequences.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hence arises a singular contrast; the more the utility of slavery is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contested, the more firmly is it established in the laws; and whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principle of servitude is gradually abolished in the North, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self-same principle gives rise to more and more rigorous consequences in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The legislation of the Southern States with regard to slaves, presents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the present day such unparalleled atrocities as suffice to show how
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: radically the laws of humanity have been perverted, and to betray the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desperate position of the community in which that legislation has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been promulgated. The Americans of this portion of the Union have not,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indeed, augmented the hardships of slavery; they have, on the contrary,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bettered the physical condition of the slaves. The only means by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ancients maintained slavery were fetters and death; the Americans of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South of the Union have discovered more intellectual securities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the duration of their power. They have employed their despotism and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their violence against the human mind. In antiquity, precautions were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken to prevent the slave from breaking his chains; at the present day
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures are adopted to deprive him even of the desire of freedom. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ancients kept the bodies of their slaves in bondage, but they placed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no restraint upon the mind and no check upon education; and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acted consistently with their established principle, since a natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: termination of slavery then existed, and one day or other the slave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might be set free, and become the equal of his master. But the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the South, who do not admit that the negroes can ever be commingled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with themselves, have forbidden them to be taught to read or to write,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under severe penalties; and as they will not raise them to their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: level, they sink them as nearly as possible to that of the brutes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The hope of liberty had always been allowed to the slave to cheer the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardships of his condition. But the Americans of the South are well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aware that emancipation cannot but be dangerous, when the freed man can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never be assimilated to his former master. To give a man his freedom,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to leave him in wretchedness and ignominy, is nothing less than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prepare a future chief for a revolt of the slaves. Moreover, it has long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been remarked that the presence of a free negro vaguely agitates the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minds of his less fortunate brethren, and conveys to them a dim notion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their rights. The Americans of the South have consequently taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures to prevent slave-owners from emancipating their slaves in most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases; not indeed by a positive prohibition, but by subjecting that step
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to various forms which it is difficult to comply with. I happened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to meet with an old man, in the South of the Union, who had lived in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: illicit intercourse with one of his negresses, and had had several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: children by her, who were born the slaves of their father. He had indeed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently thought of bequeathing to them at least their liberty; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years had elapsed without his being able to surmount the legal obstacles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to their emancipation, and in the mean while his old age was come, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he was about to die. He pictured to himself his sons dragged from market
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to market, and passing from the authority of a parent to the rod of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the stranger, until these horrid anticipations worked his expiring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination into frenzy. When I saw him he was a prey to all the anguish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of despair, and he made me feel how awful is the retribution of nature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon those who have broken her laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These evils are unquestionably great; but they are the necessary and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreseen consequence of the very principle of modern slavery. When the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europeans chose their slaves from a race differing from their own, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many of them considered as inferior to the other races of mankind,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and which they all repelled with horror from any notion of intimate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connection, they must have believed that slavery would last forever;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since there is no intermediate state which can be durable between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excessive inequality produced by servitude and the complete equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which originates in independence. The Europeans did imperfectly feel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this truth, but without acknowledging it even to themselves. Whenever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have had to do with negroes, their conduct has either been dictated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their interest and their pride, or by their compassion. They first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violated every right of humanity by their treatment of the negro
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they afterwards informed him that those rights were precious and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inviolable. They affected to open their ranks to the slaves, but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes who attempted to penetrate into the community were driven back
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with scorn; and they have incautiously and involuntarily been led to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admit of freedom instead of slavery, without having the courage to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wholly iniquitous, or wholly just.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If it be impossible to anticipate a period at which the Americans of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South will mingle their blood with that of the negroes, can they allow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their slaves to become free without compromising their own security? And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if they are obliged to keep that race in bondage in order to save their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own families, may they not be excused for availing themselves of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means best adapted to that end? The events which are taking place in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Southern States of the Union appear to me to be at once the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: horrible and the most natural results of slavery. When I see the order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of nature overthrown, and when I hear the cry of humanity in its vain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggle against the laws, my indignation does not light upon the men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our own time who are the instruments of these outrages; but I reserve
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my execration for those who, after a thousand years of freedom, brought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: back slavery into the world once more.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whatever may be the efforts of the Americans of the South to maintain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery, they will not always succeed. Slavery, which is now confined to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a single tract of the civilized earth, which is attacked by Christianity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as unjust, and by political economy as prejudicial; and which is now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrasted with democratic liberties and the information of our age,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot survive. By the choice of the master, or by the will of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slave, it will cease; and in either case great calamities may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expected to ensue. If liberty be refused to the negroes of the South,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will in the end seize it for themselves by force; if it be given,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will abuse it ere long. *x
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote x: [This chapter is no longer applicable to the condition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the negro race in the United States, since the abolition of slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was the result, though not the object, of the great Civil War, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: negroes have been raised to the condition not only of freedmen, but of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens; and in some States they exercise a preponderating political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power by reason of their numerical majority. Thus, in South Carolina
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there were in 1870, 289,667 whites and 415,814 blacks. But the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emancipation of the slaves has not solved the problem, how two races so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different and so hostile are to live together in peace in one country on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal terms. That problem is as difficult, perhaps more difficult than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever; and to this difficulty the author's remarks are still perfectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applicable.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part VI
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What Are The Chances In Favor Of The Duration Of The American Union, And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What Dangers Threaten It *y
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote y: [This chapter is one of the most curious and interesting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portions of the work, because it embraces almost all the constitutional
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and social questions which were raised by the great secession of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South and decided by the results of the Civil War. But it must be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confessed that the sagacity of the author is sometimes at fault in these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speculations, and did not save him from considerable errors, which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course of events has since made apparent. He held that "the legislators
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Constitution of 1789 were not appointed to constitute the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government of a single people, but to regulate the association of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several States; that the Union was formed by the voluntary agreement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States, and in uniting together they have not forfeited their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nationality, nor have they been reduced to the condition of one and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same people." Whence he inferred that "if one of the States chose to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: withdraw its name from the contract, it would be difficult to disprove
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its right of doing so; and that the Federal Government would have no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means of maintaining its claims directly, either by force or by right."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is the Southern theory of the Constitution, and the whole case of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South in favor of secession. To many Europeans, and to some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American (Northern) jurists, this view appeared to be sound; but it was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vigorously resisted by the North, and crushed by force of arms.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The author of this book was mistaken in supposing that the "Union was a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vast body which presents no definite object to patriotic feeling." When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the day of trial came, millions of men were ready to lay down their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lives for it. He was also mistaken in supposing that the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Executive is so weak that it requires the free consent of the governed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to enable it to subsist, and that it would be defeated in a struggle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to maintain the Union against one or more separate States. In 1861 nine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, with a population of 8,753,000, seceded, and maintained for four
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years a resolute but unequal contest for independence, but they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defeated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lastly, the author was mistaken in supposing that a community of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests would always prevail between North and South sufficiently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful to bind them together. He overlooked the influence which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: question of slavery must have on the Union the moment that the majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the people of the North declared against it. In 1831, when the author
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: visited America, the anti-slavery agitation had scarcely begun; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact of Southern slavery was accepted by men of all parties, even in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States where there were no slaves: and that was unquestionably the view
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken by all the States and by all American statesmen at the time of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adoption of the Constitution, in 1789. But in the course of thirty years
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great change took place, and the North refused to perpetuate what had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become the "peculiar institution" of the South, especially as it gave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the South a species of aristocratic preponderance. The result was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ratification, in December, 1865, of the celebrated 13th article or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amendment of the Constitution, which declared that "neither slavery nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: involuntary servitude--except as a punishment for crime--shall exist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within the United States." To which was soon afterwards added the 15th
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: article, "The right of citizens to vote shall not be denied or abridged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the United States, or by any State, on account of race, color, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: previous servitude." The emancipation of several millions of negro
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slaves without compensation, and the transfer to them of political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preponderance in the States in which they outnumber the white
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population, were acts of the North totally opposed to the interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the South, and which could only have been carried into effect by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquest.--Translator's Note.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Reason for which the preponderating force lies in the States rather than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the Union--The Union will only last as long as all the States choose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to belong to it--Causes which tend to keep them united--Utility of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union to resist foreign enemies, and to prevent the existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of foreigners in America--No natural barriers between the several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States--No conflicting interests to divide them--Reciprocal interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Northern, Southern, and Western States--Intellectual ties of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: union--Uniformity of opinions--Dangers of the Union resulting from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different characters and the passions of its citizens--Character of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens in the South and in the North--The rapid growth of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union one of its greatest dangers--Progress of the population to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Northwest--Power gravitates in the same direction--Passions originating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from sudden turns of fortune--Whether the existing Government of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union tends to gain strength, or to lose it--Various signs of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decrease--Internal improvements--Waste lands--Indians--The Bank--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Tariff--General Jackson.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The maintenance of the existing institutions of the several States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: depends in some measure upon the maintenance of the Union itself. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore important in the first instance to inquire into the probable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fate of the Union. One point may indeed be assumed at once: if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present confederation were dissolved, it appears to me to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incontestable that the States of which it is now composed would not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: return to their original isolated condition, but that several unions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would then be formed in the place of one. It is not my intention to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquire into the principles upon which these new unions would probably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be established, but merely to show what the causes are which may effect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the dismemberment of the existing confederation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: With this object I shall be obliged to retrace some of the steps which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already taken, and to revert to topics which I have before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discussed. I am aware that the reader may accuse me of repetition, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the importance of the matter which still remains to be treated is my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excuse; I had rather say too much, than say too little to be thoroughly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood, and I prefer injuring the author to slighting the subject.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The legislators who formed the Constitution of 1789 endeavored to confer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a distinct and preponderating authority upon the federal power. But they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were confined by the conditions of the task which they had undertaken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to perform. They were not appointed to constitute the government of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single people, but to regulate the association of several States; and,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever their inclinations might be, they could not but divide the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise of sovereignty in the end.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In order to understand the consequences of this division, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary to make a short distinction between the affairs of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government. There are some objects which are national by their very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature, that is to say, which affect the nation as a body, and can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only be intrusted to the man or the assembly of men who most completely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represent the entire nation. Amongst these may be reckoned war and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diplomacy. There are other objects which are provincial by their very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature, that is to say, which only affect certain localities, and which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can only be properly treated in that locality. Such, for instance, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the budget of a municipality. Lastly, there are certain objects of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a mixed nature, which are national inasmuch as they affect all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens who compose the nation, and which are provincial inasmuch as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is not necessary that the nation itself should provide for them all.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such are the rights which regulate the civil and political condition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens. No society can exist without civil and political rights.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These rights therefore interest all the citizens alike; but it is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always necessary to the existence and the prosperity of the nation that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these rights should be uniform, nor, consequently, that they should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulated by the central authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are, then, two distinct categories of objects which are submitted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the direction of the sovereign power; and these categories occur in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all well-constituted communities, whatever the basis of the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution may otherwise be. Between these two extremes the objects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have termed mixed may be considered to lie. As these objects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are neither exclusively national nor entirely provincial, they may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtained by a national or by a provincial government, according to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agreement of the contracting parties, without in any way impairing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contract of association.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The sovereign power is usually formed by the union of separate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals, who compose a people; and individual powers or collective
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forces, each representing a very small portion of the sovereign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, are the sole elements which are subjected to the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of their choice. In this case the general Government is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally called upon to regulate, not only those affairs which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of essential national importance, but those which are of a more local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest; and the local governments are reduced to that small share of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign authority which is indispensable to their prosperity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But sometimes the sovereign authority is composed of preorganized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political bodies, by virtue of circumstances anterior to their union;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in this case the provincial governments assume the control, not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those affairs which more peculiarly belong to their province, but of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all, or of a part of the mixed affairs to which allusion has been made.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: For the confederate nations which were independent sovereign States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before their union, and which still represent a very considerable share
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the sovereign power, have only consented to cede to the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government the exercise of those rights which are indispensable to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the national Government, independently of the prerogatives inherent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in its nature, is invested with the right of regulating the affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which relate partly to the general and partly to the local interests,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it possesses a preponderating influence. Not only are its own rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extensive, but all the rights which it does not possess exist by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufferance, and it may be apprehended that the provincial governments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be deprived of their natural and necessary prerogatives by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When, on the other hand, the provincial governments are invested
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the power of regulating those same affairs of mixed interest, an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposite tendency prevails in society. The preponderating force resides
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the province, not in the nation; and it may be apprehended that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national Government may in the end be stripped of the privileges which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are necessary to its existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Independent nations have therefore a natural tendency to centralization,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and confederations to dismemberment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It now only remains for us to apply these general principles to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American Union. The several States were necessarily possessed of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of regulating all exclusively provincial affairs. Moreover these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same States retained the rights of determining the civil and political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: competency of the citizens, or regulating the reciprocal relations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the members of the community, and of dispensing justice; rights which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are of a general nature, but which do not necessarily appertain to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national Government. We have shown that the Government of the Union is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invested with the power of acting in the name of the whole nation in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those cases in which the nation has to appear as a single and undivided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power; as, for instance, in foreign relations, and in offering a common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resistance to a common enemy; in short, in conducting those affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have styled exclusively national.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In this division of the rights of sovereignty, the share of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seems at first sight to be more considerable than that of the States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but a more attentive investigation shows it to be less so. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings of the Government of the Union are more vast, but their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence is more rarely felt. Those of the provincial governments are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparatively small, but they are incessant, and they serve to keep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alive the authority which they represent. The Government of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: watches the general interests of the country; but the general interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a people have a very questionable influence upon individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happiness, whilst provincial interests produce a most immediate effect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the welfare of the inhabitants. The Union secures the independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the greatness of the nation, which do not immediately affect private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens; but the several States maintain the liberty, regulate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights, protect the fortune, and secure the life and the whole future
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity of every citizen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal Government is very far removed from its subjects, whilst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provincial governments are within the reach of them all, and are ready
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to attend to the smallest appeal. The central Government has upon its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: side the passions of a few superior men who aspire to conduct it; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the side of the provincial governments are the interests of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those second-rate individuals who can only hope to obtain power within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own State, and who nevertheless exercise the largest share of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority over the people because they are placed nearest to its level.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans have therefore much more to hope and to fear from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States than from the Union; and, in conformity with the natural tendency
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the human mind, they are more likely to attach themselves to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former than to the latter. In this respect their habits and feelings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harmonize with their interests.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a compact nation divides its sovereignty, and adopts a confederate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form of government, the traditions, the customs, and the manners of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people are for a long time at variance with their legislation; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former tend to give a degree of influence to the central government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the latter forbids. When a number of confederate states unite to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form a single nation, the same causes operate in an opposite direction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have no doubt that if France were to become a confederate republic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like that of the United States, the government would at first display
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more energy than that of the Union; and if the Union were to alter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its constitution to a monarchy like that of France, I think that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American Government would be a long time in acquiring the force
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which now rules the latter nation. When the national existence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans began, their provincial existence was already of long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: standing; necessary relations were established between the townships and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the individual citizens of the same States; and they were accustomed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to consider some objects as common to them all, and to conduct other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs as exclusively relating to their own special interests.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Union is a vast body which presents no definite object to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patriotic feeling. The forms and limits of the State are distinct and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumscribed; since it represents a certain number of objects which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: familiar to the citizens and beloved by all. It is identified with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very soil, with the right of property and the domestic affections, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the recollections of the past, the labors of the present, and the hopes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the future. Patriotism, then, which is frequently a mere extension of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual egotism, is still directed to the State, and is not excited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Union. Thus the tendency of the interests, the habits, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feelings of the people is to centre political activity in the States, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preference to the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is easy to estimate the different forces of the two governments, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarking the manner in which they fulfil their respective functions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whenever the government of a State has occasion to address an individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or an assembly of individuals, its language is clear and imperative; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such is also the tone of the Federal Government in its intercourse with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals, but no sooner has it anything to do with a State than it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: begins to parley, to explain its motives and to justify its conduct, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: argue, to advise, and, in short, anything but to command. If doubts are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raised as to the limits of the constitutional powers of each government,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the provincial government prefers its claim with boldness, and takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prompt and energetic steps to support it. In the mean while the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of the Union reasons; it appeals to the interests, to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good sense, to the glory of the nation; it temporizes, it negotiates,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and does not consent to act until it is reduced to the last extremity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At first sight it might readily be imagined that it is the provincial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government which is armed with the authority of the nation, and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Congress represents a single State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal Government is, therefore, notwithstanding the precautions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who founded it, naturally so weak that it more peculiarly requires
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the free consent of the governed to enable it to subsist. It is easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to perceive that its object is to enable the States to realize with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facility their determination of remaining united; and, as long as this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preliminary condition exists, its authority is great, temperate, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effective. The Constitution fits the Government to control individuals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and easily to surmount such obstacles as they may be inclined to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offer; but it was by no means established with a view to the possible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separation of one or more of the States from the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the sovereignty of the Union were to engage in a struggle with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of the States at the present day, its defeat may be confidently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predicted; and it is not probable that such a struggle would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seriously undertaken. As often as a steady resistance is offered to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Government it will be found to yield. Experience has hitherto
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shown that whenever a State has demanded anything with perseverance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and resolution, it has invariably succeeded; and that if a separate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government has distinctly refused to act, it was left to do as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought fit. *z
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote z: See the conduct of the Northern States in the war of 1812.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "During that war," says Jefferson in a letter to General Lafayette,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "four of the Eastern States were only attached to the Union, like so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many inanimate bodies to living men."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But even if the Government of the Union had any strength inherent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself, the physical situation of the country would render the exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of that strength very difficult. *a The United States cover an immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory; they are separated from each other by great distances; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the population is disseminated over the surface of a country which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still half a wilderness. If the Union were to undertake to enforce the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allegiance of the confederate States by military means, it would be in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a position very analogous to that of England at the time of the War of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Independence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: The profound peace of the Union affords no pretext for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: standing army; and without a standing army a government is not prepared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to profit by a favorable opportunity to conquer resistance, and take the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign power by surprise. [This note, and the paragraph in the text
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which precedes, have been shown by the results of the Civil War to be a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misconception of the writer.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: However strong a government may be, it cannot easily escape from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences of a principle which it has once admitted as the foundation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its constitution. The Union was formed by the voluntary agreement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States; and, in uniting together, they have not forfeited their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nationality, nor have they been reduced to the condition of one and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same people. If one of the States chose to withdraw its name from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contract, it would be difficult to disprove its right of doing so; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal Government would have no means of maintaining its claims
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directly, either by force or by right. In order to enable the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government easily to conquer the resistance which may be offered to it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by any one of its subjects, it would be necessary that one or more of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them should be specially interested in the existence of the Union, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has frequently been the case in the history of confederations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If it be supposed that amongst the States which are united by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal tie there are some which exclusively enjoy the principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages of union, or whose prosperity depends on the duration of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: union, it is unquestionable that they will always be ready to support
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the central Government in enforcing the obedience of the others. But the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government would then be exerting a force not derived from itself, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from a principle contrary to its nature. States form confederations in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to derive equal advantages from their union; and in the case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: just alluded to, the Federal Government would derive its power from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unequal distribution of those benefits amongst the States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If one of the confederate States have acquired a preponderance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently great to enable it to take exclusive possession of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the central authority, it will consider the other States as subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provinces, and it will cause its own supremacy to be respected under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: borrowed name of the sovereignty of the Union. Great things may then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be done in the name of the Federal Government, but in reality that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government will have ceased to exist. *b In both these cases, the power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which acts in the name of the confederation becomes stronger the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it abandons the natural state and the acknowledged principles of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: Thus the province of Holland in the republic of the Low
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Countries, and the Emperor in the Germanic Confederation, have sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: put themselves in the place of the union, and have employed the federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority to their own advantage.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the existing Union is advantageous to all the States, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not indispensable to any one of them. Several of them might break
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the federal tie without compromising the welfare of the others, although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own prosperity would be lessened. As the existence and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happiness of none of the States are wholly dependent on the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution, they would none of them be disposed to make great personal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sacrifices to maintain it. On the other hand, there is no State which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seems hitherto to have its ambition much interested in the maintenance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the existing Union. They certainly do not all exercise the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence in the federal councils, but no one of them can hope to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: domineer over the rest, or to treat them as its inferiors or as its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It appears to me unquestionable that if any portion of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seriously desired to separate itself from the other States, they would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not be able, nor indeed would they attempt, to prevent it; and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present Union will only last as long as the States which compose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it choose to continue members of the confederation. If this point be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admitted, the question becomes less difficult; and our object is, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to inquire whether the States of the existing Union are capable of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separating, but whether they will choose to remain united.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst the various reasons which tend to render the existing Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: useful to the Americans, two principal causes are peculiarly evident to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the observer. Although the Americans are, as it were, alone upon their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent, their commerce makes them the neighbors of all the nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with which they trade. Notwithstanding their apparent isolation, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans require a certain degree of strength, which they cannot retain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: otherwise than by remaining united to each other. If the States were to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: split, they would not only diminish the strength which they are now able
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to display towards foreign nations, but they would soon create foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers upon their own territory. A system of inland custom-houses would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then be established; the valleys would be divided by imaginary boundary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lines; the courses of the rivers would be confined by territorial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinctions; and a multitude of hindrances would prevent the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from exploring the whole of that vast continent which Providence has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allotted to them for a dominion. At present they have no invasion to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fear, and consequently no standing armies to maintain, no taxes to levy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the Union were dissolved, all these burdensome measures might ere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long be required. The Americans are then very powerfully interested
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the maintenance of their Union. On the other hand, it is almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible to discover any sort of material interest which might at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present tempt a portion of the Union to separate from the other States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When we cast our eyes upon the map of the United States, we perceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the chain of the Alleghany Mountains, running from the northeast to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: southwest, and crossing nearly one thousand miles of country; and we are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: led to imagine that the design of Providence was to raise between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: valley of the Mississippi and the coast of the Atlantic Ocean one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those natural barriers which break the mutual intercourse of men, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form the necessary limits of different States. But the average height of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Alleghanies does not exceed 2,500 feet; their greatest elevation is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not above 4,000 feet; their rounded summits, and the spacious valleys
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they conceal within their passes, are of easy access from several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sides. Besides which, the principal rivers which fall into the Atlantic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ocean--the Hudson, the Susquehanna, and the Potomac--take their rise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beyond the Alleghanies, in an open district, which borders upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: valley of the Mississippi. These streams quit this tract of country,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make their way through the barrier which would seem to turn them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: westward, and as they wind through the mountains they open an easy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural passage to man. No natural barrier exists in the regions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are now inhabited by the Anglo-Americans; the Alleghanies are so far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from serving as a boundary to separate nations, that they do not even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: serve as a frontier to the States. New York, Pennsylvania, and Virginia
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comprise them within their borders, and they extend as much to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: west as to the east of the line. The territory now occupied by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: twenty-four States of the Union, and the three great districts which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have not yet acquired the rank of States, although they already contain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants, covers a surface of 1,002,600 square miles, *c which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about equal to five times the extent of France. Within these limits the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: qualities of the soil, the temperature, and the produce of the country,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are extremely various. The vast extent of territory occupied by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-American republics has given rise to doubts as to the maintenance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their Union. Here a distinction must be made; contrary interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes arise in the different provinces of a vast empire, which often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: terminate in open dissensions; and the extent of the country is then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most prejudicial to the power of the State. But if the inhabitants of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these vast regions are not divided by contrary interests, the extent of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the territory may be favorable to their prosperity; for the unity of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government promotes the interchange of the different productions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soil, and increases their value by facilitating their consumption.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: See "Darby's View of the United States," p. 435. [In 1890
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the number of States and Territories had increased to 51, the population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to 62,831,900, and the area of the States, 3,602,990 square miles.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This does not include the Philippine Islands, Hawaii, or Porto Rico.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A conservative estimate of the population of the Philippine Islands is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 8,000,000; that of Hawaii, by the census of 1897, was given at 109,020;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the present estimated population of Porto Rico is 900,000. The area
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Philippine Islands is about 120,000 square miles, that of Hawaii
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is 6,740 square miles, and the area of Porto Rico is about 3,600 square
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: miles.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is indeed easy to discover different interests in the different parts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union, but I am unacquainted with any which are hostile to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other. The Southern States are almost exclusively agricultural. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Northern States are more peculiarly commercial and manufacturing. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States of the West are at the same time agricultural and manufacturing.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the South the crops consist of tobacco, of rice, of cotton, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of sugar; in the North and the West, of wheat and maize. These are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different sources of wealth; but union is the means by which these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sources are opened to all, and rendered equally advantageous to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several districts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The North, which ships the produce of the Anglo-Americans to all parts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the world, and brings back the produce of the globe to the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is evidently interested in maintaining the confederation in its present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition, in order that the number of American producers and consumers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may remain as large as possible. The North is the most natural agent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of communication between the South and the West of the Union on the one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand, and the rest of the world upon the other; the North is therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interested in the union and prosperity of the South and the West,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order that they may continue to furnish raw materials for its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures, and cargoes for its shipping.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The South and the West, on their side, are still more directly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interested in the preservation of the Union, and the prosperity of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North. The produce of the South is, for the most part, exported
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beyond seas; the South and the West consequently stand in need of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commercial resources of the North. They are likewise interested in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the maintenance of a powerful fleet by the Union, to protect them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efficaciously. The South and the West have no vessels, but they cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refuse a willing subsidy to defray the expenses of the navy; for if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fleets of Europe were to blockade the ports of the South and the delta
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Mississippi, what would become of the rice of the Carolinas, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tobacco of Virginia, and the sugar and cotton which grow in the valley
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Mississippi? Every portion of the federal budget does therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contribute to the maintenance of material interests which are common to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the confederate States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Independently of this commercial utility, the South and the West of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union derive great political advantages from their connection with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North. The South contains an enormous slave population; a population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is already alarming, and still more formidable for the future. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States of the West lie in the remotest parts of a single valley; and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rivers which intersect their territory rise in the Rocky Mountains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or in the Alleghanies, and fall into the Mississippi, which bears them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: onwards to the Gulf of Mexico. The Western States are consequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely cut off, by their position, from the traditions of Europe and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the civilization of the Old World. The inhabitants of the South, then,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are induced to support the Union in order to avail themselves of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protection against the blacks; and the inhabitants of the West in order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not to be excluded from a free communication with the rest of the globe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and shut up in the wilds of central America. The North cannot but desire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the maintenance of the Union, in order to remain, as it now is, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connecting link between that vast body and the other parts of the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The temporal interests of all the several parts of the Union are, then,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intimately connected; and the same assertion holds true respecting those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions and sentiments which may be termed the immaterial interests of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part VII
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The inhabitants of the United States talk a great deal of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attachment to their country; but I confess that I do not rely upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that calculating patriotism which is founded upon interest, and which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a change in the interests at stake may obliterate. Nor do I attach much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance to the language of the Americans, when they manifest, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their daily conversations, the intention of maintaining the federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system adopted by their forefathers. A government retains its sway
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over a great number of citizens, far less by the voluntary and rational
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consent of the multitude, than by that instinctive, and to a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent involuntary agreement, which results from similarity of feelings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and resemblances of opinion. I will never admit that men constitute a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social body, simply because they obey the same head and the same laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Society can only exist when a great number of men consider a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of things in the same point of view; when they hold the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions upon many subjects, and when the same occurrences suggest the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same thoughts and impressions to their minds.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The observer who examines the present condition of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon this principle, will readily discover, that although the citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are divided into twenty-four distinct sovereignties, they nevertheless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitute a single people; and he may perhaps be led to think that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of the Anglo-American Union is more truly a state of society than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of certain nations of Europe which live under the same legislation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the same prince.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although the Anglo-Americans have several religious sects, they all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regard religion in the same manner. They are not always agreed upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures which are most conducive to good government, and they vary upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some of the forms of government which it is expedient to adopt; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are unanimous upon the general principles which ought to rule
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human society. From Maine to the Floridas, and from the Missouri to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Atlantic Ocean, the people is held to be the legitimate source of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. The same notions are entertained respecting liberty and equality,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the liberty of the press, the right of association, the jury, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsibility of the agents of Government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If we turn from their political and religious opinions to the moral and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophical principles which regulate the daily actions of life and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: govern their conduct, we shall still find the same uniformity. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans *d acknowledge the absolute moral authority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason of the community, as they acknowledge the political authority of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mass of citizens; and they hold that public opinion is the surest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arbiter of what is lawful or forbidden, true or false. The majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them believe that a man will be led to do what is just and good by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: following his own interest rightly understood. They hold that every man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is born in possession of the right of self-government, and that no one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has the right of constraining his fellow-creatures to be happy. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have all a lively faith in the perfectibility of man; they are of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion that the effects of the diffusion of knowledge must necessarily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be advantageous, and the consequences of ignorance fatal; they all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider society as a body in a state of improvement, humanity as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changing scene, in which nothing is, or ought to be, permanent; and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admit that what appears to them to be good to-day may be superseded by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: something better-to-morrow. I do not give all these opinions as true,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but I quote them as characteristic of the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: It is scarcely necessary for me to observe that by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expression Anglo-Americans, I only mean to designate the great majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation; for a certain number of isolated individuals are of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course to be met with holding very different opinions.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Anglo-Americans are not only united together by these common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions, but they are separated from all other nations by a common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feeling of pride. For the last fifty years no pains have been spared to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convince the inhabitants of the United States that they constitute the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only religious, enlightened, and free people. They perceive that, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present, their own democratic institutions succeed, whilst those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of other countries fail; hence they conceive an overweening opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their superiority, and they are not very remote from believing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to belong to a distinct race of mankind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The dangers which threaten the American Union do not originate in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diversity of interests or of opinions, but in the various characters and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions of the Americans. The men who inhabit the vast territory of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States are almost all the issue of a common stock; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effects of the climate, and more especially of slavery, have gradually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced very striking differences between the British settler of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Southern States and the British settler of the North. In Europe it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally believed that slavery has rendered the interests of one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of the Union contrary to those of another part; but I by no means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarked this to be the case: slavery has not created interests in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South contrary to those of the North, but it has modified the character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and changed the habits of the natives of the South.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already explained the influence which slavery has exercised upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the commercial ability of the Americans in the South; and this same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence equally extends to their manners. The slave is a servant who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never remonstrates, and who submits to everything without complaint. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may sometimes assassinate, but he never withstands, his master. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South there are no families so poor as not to have slaves. The citizen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Southern States of the Union is invested with a sort of domestic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dictatorship, from his earliest years; the first notion he acquires
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in life is that he is born to command, and the first habit which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contracts is that of being obeyed without resistance. His education
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tends, then, to give him the character of a supercilious and a hasty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man; irascible, violent, and ardent in his desires, impatient of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obstacles, but easily discouraged if he cannot succeed upon his first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempt.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American of the Northern States is surrounded by no slaves in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his childhood; he is even unattended by free servants, and is usually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to provide for his own wants. No sooner does he enter the world
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the idea of necessity assails him on every side: he soon learns
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to know exactly the natural limit of his authority; he never expects to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subdue those who withstand him, by force; and he knows that the surest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means of obtaining the support of his fellow-creatures, is to win their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favor. He therefore becomes patient, reflecting, tolerant, slow to act,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and persevering in his designs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the Southern States the more immediate wants of life are always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supplied; the inhabitants of those parts are not busied in the material
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cares of life, which are always provided for by others; and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination is diverted to more captivating and less definite objects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American of the South is fond of grandeur, luxury, and renown, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gayety, of pleasure, and above all of idleness; nothing obliges him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to exert himself in order to subsist; and as he has no necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occupations, he gives way to indolence, and does not even attempt what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be useful.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the equality of fortunes, and the absence of slavery in the North,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plunge the inhabitants in those same cares of daily life which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disdained by the white population of the South. They are taught from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infancy to combat want, and to place comfort above all the pleasures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the intellect or the heart. The imagination is extinguished by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trivial details of life, and the ideas become less numerous and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
