text: general, but far more practical and more precise. As prosperity is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sole aim of exertion, it is excellently well attained; nature and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind are turned to the best pecuniary advantage, and society is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dexterously made to contribute to the welfare of each of its members,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst individual egotism is the source of general happiness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The citizen of the North has not only experience, but knowledge:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless he sets but little value upon the pleasures of knowledge;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he esteems it as the means of attaining a certain end, and he is only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anxious to seize its more lucrative applications. The citizen of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South is more given to act upon impulse; he is more clever, more frank,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more generous, more intellectual, and more brilliant. The former, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a greater degree of activity, of common-sense, of information, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general aptitude, has the characteristic good and evil qualities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the middle classes. The latter has the tastes, the prejudices, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weaknesses, and the magnanimity of all aristocracies. If two men are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: united in society, who have the same interests, and to a certain extent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same opinions, but different characters, different acquirements, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a different style of civilization, it is probable that these men will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not agree. The same remark is applicable to a society of nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Slavery, then, does not attack the American Union directly in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests, but indirectly in its manners.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The States which gave their assent to the federal contract in 1790 were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thirteen in number; the Union now consists of thirty-four members. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population, which amounted to nearly 4,000,000 in 1790, had more than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tripled in the space of forty years; and in 1830 it amounted to nearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 13,000,000. *e Changes of such magnitude cannot take place without some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: danger.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A society of nations, as well as a society of individuals, derives its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal chances of duration from the wisdom of its members, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual weakness, and their limited number. The Americans who quit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the coasts of the Atlantic Ocean to plunge into the western wilderness,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are adventurers impatient of restraint, greedy of wealth, and frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men expelled from the States in which they were born. When they arrive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the deserts they are unknown to each other, and they have neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traditions, family feeling, nor the force of example to check their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excesses. The empire of the laws is feeble amongst them; that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: morality is still more powerless. The settlers who are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peopling the valley of the Mississippi are, then, in every respect very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferior to the Americans who inhabit the older parts of the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, they already exercise a great influence in its councils;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they arrive at the government of the commonwealth before they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learnt to govern themselves. *f
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: This indeed is only a temporary danger. I have no doubt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in time society will assume as much stability and regularity in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: West as it has already done upon the coast of the Atlantic Ocean.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greater the individual weakness of each of the contracting parties,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the greater are the chances of the duration of the contract; for their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: safety is then dependent upon their union. When, in 1790, the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: populous of the American republics did not contain 500,000 inhabitants,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *g each of them felt its own insignificance as an independent people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and this feeling rendered compliance with the federal authority more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easy. But when one of the confederate States reckons, like the State of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New York, 2,000,000 of inhabitants, and covers an extent of territory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal in surface to a quarter of France, *h it feels its own strength;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and although it may continue to support the Union as advantageous to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its prosperity, it no longer regards that body as necessary to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence, and as it continues to belong to the federal compact, it soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aims at preponderance in the federal assemblies. The probable unanimity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the States is diminished as their number increases. At present the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests of the different parts of the Union are not at variance; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who is able to foresee the multifarious changes of the future, in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country in which towns are founded from day to day, and States almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from year to year?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: Pennsylvania contained 431,373 inhabitants in 1790 [and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: The area of the State of New York is 49,170 square miles.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [See U. S. census report of 1890.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Since the first settlement of the British colonies, the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants has about doubled every twenty-two years. I perceive no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes which are likely to check this progressive increase of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-American population for the next hundred years; and before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that space of time has elapsed, I believe that the territories
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and dependencies of the United States will be covered by more than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 100,000,000 of inhabitants, and divided into forty States. *i I admit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that these 100,000,000 of men have no hostile interests. I suppose,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the contrary, that they are all equally interested in the maintenance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union; but I am still of opinion that where there are 100,000,000
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men, and forty distinct nations, unequally strong, the continuance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal Government can only be a fortunate accident.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: If the population continues to double every twenty-two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years, as it has done for the last two hundred years, the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants in the United States in 1852 will be twenty millions; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1874, forty-eight millions; and in 1896, ninety-six millions. This may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still be the case even if the lands on the western slope of the Rocky
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mountains should be found to be unfit for cultivation. The territory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is already occupied can easily contain this number of inhabitants.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: One hundred millions of men disseminated over the surface of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: twenty-four States, and the three dependencies, which constitute the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union, would only give 762 inhabitants to the square league; this would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be far below the mean population of France, which is 1,063 to the square
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: league; or of England, which is 1,457; and it would even be below the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population of Switzerland, for that country, notwithstanding its lakes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and mountains, contains 783 inhabitants to the square league. See "Malte
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Brun," vol. vi. p. 92.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [The actual result has fallen somewhat short of these calculations, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spite of the vast territorial acquisitions of the United States: but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1899 the population is probably about eighty-seven millions, including
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the population of the Philippines, Hawaii, and Porto Rico.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whatever faith I may have in the perfectibility of man, until human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature is altered, and men wholly transformed, I shall refuse to believe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the duration of a government which is called upon to hold together
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forty different peoples, disseminated over a territory equal to one-half
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe in extent; to avoid all rivalry, ambition, and struggles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between them, and to direct their independent activity to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accomplishment of the same designs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the greatest peril to which the Union is exposed by its increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arises from the continual changes which take place in the position of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its internal strength. The distance from Lake Superior to the Gulf of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mexico extends from the 47th to the 30th degree of latitude, a distance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of more than 1,200 miles as the bird flies. The frontier of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States winds along the whole of this immense line, sometimes falling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within its limits, but more frequently extending far beyond it, into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: waste. It has been calculated that the whites advance every year a mean
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distance of seventeen miles along the whole of his vast boundary. *j
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Obstacles, such as an unproductive district, a lake or an Indian nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unexpectedly encountered, are sometimes met with. The advancing column
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then halts for a while; its two extremities fall back upon themselves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and as soon as they are reunited they proceed onwards. This gradual and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continuous progress of the European race towards the Rocky Mountains has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the solemnity of a providential event; it is like a deluge of men rising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unabatedly, and daily driven onwards by the hand of God.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: See Legislative Documents, 20th Congress, No. 117, p. 105.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Within this first line of conquering settlers towns are built, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vast States founded. In 1790 there were only a few thousand pioneers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sprinkled along the valleys of the Mississippi; and at the present day
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these valleys contain as many inhabitants as were to be found in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole Union in 1790. Their population amounts to nearly 4,000,000. *k
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The city of Washington was founded in 1800, in the very centre of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union; but such are the changes which have taken place, that it now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stands at one of the extremities; and the delegates of the most remote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Western States are already obliged to perform a journey as long as that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from Vienna to Paris. *l
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: 3,672,317--Census of 1830.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: The distance from Jefferson, the capital of the State of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Missouri, to Washington is 1,019 miles. ("American Almanac," 1831, p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the States are borne onwards at the same time in the path of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune, but of course they do not all increase and prosper in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same proportion. To the North of the Union the detached branches of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Alleghany chain, which extend as far as the Atlantic Ocean, form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spacious roads and ports, which are constantly accessible to vessels
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the greatest burden. But from the Potomac to the mouth of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mississippi the coast is sandy and flat. In this part of the Union the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mouths of almost all the rivers are obstructed; and the few harbors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which exist amongst these lagoons afford much shallower water to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vessels, and much fewer commercial advantages than those of the North.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This first natural cause of inferiority is united to another cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceeding from the laws. We have already seen that slavery, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolished in the North, still exists in the South; and I have pointed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out its fatal consequences upon the prosperity of the planter himself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The North is therefore superior to the South both in commerce *m and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacture; the natural consequence of which is the more rapid increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of population and of wealth within its borders. The States situate upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the shores of the Atlantic Ocean are already half-peopled. Most of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: land is held by an owner; and these districts cannot therefore receive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so many emigrants as the Western States, where a boundless field is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still open to their exertions. The valley of the Mississippi is far more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fertile than the coast of the Atlantic Ocean. This reason, added to all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the others, contributes to drive the Europeans westward--a fact which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be rigorously demonstrated by figures. It is found that the sum
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: total of the population of all the United States has about tripled in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the course of forty years. But in the recent States adjacent to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mississippi, the population has increased thirty-one-fold, within the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same space of time. *n
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: The following statements will suffice to show the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difference which exists between the commerce of the South and that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the North:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1829 the tonnage of all the merchant vessels belonging to Virginia,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the two Carolinas, and Georgia (the four great Southern States),
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amounted to only 5,243 tons. In the same year the tonnage of the vessels
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the State of Massachusetts alone amounted to 17,322 tons. (See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Legislative Documents, 21st Congress, 2d session, No. 140, p. 244.) Thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State of Massachusetts had three times as much shipping as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: four above-mentioned States. Nevertheless the area of the State of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts is only 7,335 square miles, and its population amounts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to 610,014 inhabitants [2,238,943 in 1890]; whilst the area of the four
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other States I have quoted is 210,000 square miles, and their population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 3,047,767. Thus the area of the State of Massachusetts forms only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one-thirtieth part of the area of the four States; and its population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is five times smaller than theirs. (See "Darby's View of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States.") Slavery is prejudicial to the commercial prosperity of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South in several different ways; by diminishing the spirit of enterprise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst the whites, and by preventing them from meeting with as numerous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a class of sailors as they require. Sailors are usually taken from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lowest ranks of the population. But in the Southern States these lowest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranks are composed of slaves, and it is very difficult to employ them at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sea. They are unable to serve as well as a white crew, and apprehensions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would always be entertained of their mutinying in the middle of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ocean, or of their escaping in the foreign countries at which they might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: touch.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: "Darby's View of the United States," p. 444.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The relative position of the central federal power is continually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: displaced. Forty years ago the majority of the citizens of the Union was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established upon the coast of the Atlantic, in the environs of the spot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon which Washington now stands; but the great body of the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is now advancing inland and to the north, so that in twenty years the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority will unquestionably be on the western side of the Alleghanies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the Union goes on to subsist, the basin of the Mississippi is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evidently marked out, by its fertility and its extent, as the future
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centre of the Federal Government. In thirty or forty years, that tract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of country will have assumed the rank which naturally belongs to it. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is easy to calculate that its population, compared to that of the coast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Atlantic, will be, in round numbers, as 40 to 11. In a few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years the States which founded the Union will lose the direction of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its policy, and the population of the valley of the Mississippi will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preponderate in the federal assemblies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This constant gravitation of the federal power and influence towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the northwest is shown every ten years, when a general census of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population is made, and the number of delegates which each State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sends to Congress is settled afresh. *o In 1790 Virginia had nineteen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives in Congress. This number continued to increase until the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: year 1813, when it reached to twenty-three; from that time it began to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decrease, and in 1833 Virginia elected only twenty-one representatives.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *p During the same period the State of New York progressed in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary direction: in 1790 it had ten representatives in Congress; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1813, twenty-seven; in 1823, thirty-four; and in 1833, forty. The State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Ohio had only one representative in 1803, and in 1833 it had already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nineteen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: It may be seen that in the course of the last ten years
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (1820-1830) the population of one district, as, for instance, the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Delaware, has increased in the proportion of five per cent.; whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of another, as the territory of Michigan, has increased 250 per
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cent. Thus the population of Virginia had augmented thirteen per cent.,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that of the border State of Ohio sixty-one per cent., in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: space of time. The general table of these changes, which is given in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "National Calendar," displays a striking picture of the unequal fortunes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the different States.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: It has just been said that in the course of the last term
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the population of Virginia has increased thirteen per cent.; and it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary to explain how the number of representatives for a State may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decrease, when the population of that State, far from diminishing, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actually upon the increase. I take the State of Virginia, to which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already alluded, as my term of comparison. The number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives of Virginia in 1823 was proportionate to the total
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of the representatives of the Union, and to the relation which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the population bore to that of the whole Union: in 1833 the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives of Virginia was likewise proportionate to the total
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of the representatives of the Union, and to the relation which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its population, augmented in the course of ten years, bore to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augmented population of the Union in the same space of time. The new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of Virginian representatives will then be to the old numver, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the one hand, as the new numver of all the representatives is to the old
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number; and, on the other hand, as the augmentation of the population of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Virginia is to that of the whole population of the country. Thus, if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the increase of the population of the lesser country be to that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater in an exact inverse ratio of the proportion between the new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the old numbers of all the representatives, the number of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives of Virginia will remain stationary; and if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase of the Virginian population be to that of the whole Union in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feeblerratio than the new number of the representatives of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the old number, the number of the representatives of Virginia
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must decrease. [Thus, to the 56th Congress in 1899, Virginia and West
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Virginia send only fourteen representatives.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part VIII
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is difficult to imagine a durable union of a people which is rich and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strong with one which is poor and weak, even if it were proved that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength and wealth of the one are not the causes of the weakness and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: poverty of the other. But union is still more difficult to maintain at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time at which one party is losing strength, and the other is gaining it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This rapid and disproportionate increase of certain States threatens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the independence of the others. New York might perhaps succeed, with its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 2,000,000 of inhabitants and its forty representatives, in dictating to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other States in Congress. But even if the more powerful States make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no attempt to bear down the lesser ones, the danger still exists; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there is almost as much in the possibility of the act as in the act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself. The weak generally mistrust the justice and the reason of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strong. The States which increase less rapidly than the others look upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those which are more favored by fortune with envy and suspicion. Hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arise the deep-seated uneasiness and ill-defined agitation which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observable in the South, and which form so striking a contrast to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confidence and prosperity which are common to other parts of the Union.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am inclined to think that the hostile measures taken by the Southern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provinces upon a recent occasion are attributable to no other cause. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of the Southern States are, of all the Americans, those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are most interested in the maintenance of the Union; they would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assuredly suffer most from being left to themselves; and yet they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the only citizens who threaten to break the tie of confederation. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is easy to perceive that the South, which has given four Presidents,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Washington, Jefferson, Madison, and Monroe, to the Union, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceives that it is losing its federal influence, and that the number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its representatives in Congress is diminishing from year to year,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst those of the Northern and Western States are increasing; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South, which is peopled with ardent and irascible beings, is becoming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more and more irritated and alarmed. The citizens reflect upon their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present position and remember their past influence, with the melancholy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uneasiness of men who suspect oppression: if they discover a law of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union which is not unequivocally favorable to their interests,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they protest against it as an abuse of force; and if their ardent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remonstrances are not listened to, they threaten to quit an association
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which loads them with burdens whilst it deprives them of their due
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profits. "The tariff," said the inhabitants of Carolina in 1832,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "enriches the North, and ruins the South; for if this were not the case,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to what can we attribute the continually increasing power and wealth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the North, with its inclement skies and arid soil; whilst the South,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which may be styled the garden of America, is rapidly declining?" *q
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: See the report of its committee to the Convention which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proclaimed the nullification of the tariff in South Carolina.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the changes which I have described were gradual, so that each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generation at least might have time to disappear with the order of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things under which it had lived, the danger would be less; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress of society in America is precipitate, and almost revolutionary.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same citizen may have lived to see his State take the lead in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union, and afterwards become powerless in the federal assemblies; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an Anglo-American republic has been known to grow as rapidly as a man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passing from birth and infancy to maturity in the course of thirty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years. It must not be imagined, however, that the States which lose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their preponderance, also lose their population or their riches: no stop
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is put to their prosperity, and they even go on to increase more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapidly than any kingdom in Europe. *r But they believe themselves to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impoverished because their wealth does not augment as rapidly as that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their neighbors; any they think that their power is lost, because they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suddenly come into collision with a power greater than their own: *s
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus they are more hurt in their feelings and their passions than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in their interests. But this is amply sufficient to endanger the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of the Union. If kings and peoples had only had their true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests in view ever since the beginning of the world, the name of war
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would scarcely be known among mankind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: The population of a country assuredly constitutes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first element of its wealth. In the ten years (1820-1830) during which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Virginia lost two of its representatives in Congress, its population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increased in the proportion of 13.7 per cent.; that of Carolina in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion of fifteen per cent.; and that of Georgia, 15.5 per cent.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (See the "American Almanac," 1832, p. 162) But the population of Russia,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which increases more rapidly than that of any other European country,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only augments in ten years at the rate of 9.5 per cent.; in France, at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rate of seven per cent.; and in Europe in general, at the rate of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 4.7 per cent. (See "Malte Brun," vol. vi. p. 95)]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote s: It must be admitted, however, that the depreciation which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has taken place in the value of tobacco, during the last fifty years,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has notably diminished the opulence of the Southern planters: but this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstance is as independent of the will of their Northern brethren as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is of their own.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the prosperity of the United States is the source of the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: serious dangers that threaten them, since it tends to create in some of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the confederate States that over-excitement which accompanies a rapid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase of fortune; and to awaken in others those feelings of envy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mistrust, and regret which usually attend upon the loss of it. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans contemplate this extraordinary and hasty progress with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exultation; but they would be wiser to consider it with sorrow and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alarm. The Americans of the United States must inevitably become one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the greatest nations in the world; their offset will cover almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the whole of North America; the continent which they inhabit is their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dominion, and it cannot escape them. What urges them to take possession
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of it so soon? Riches, power, and renown cannot fail to be theirs at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some future time, but they rush upon their fortune as if but a moment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remained for them to make it their own.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that I have demonstrated that the existence of the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederation depends entirely on the continued assent of all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederates; and, starting from this principle, I have inquired into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the causes which may induce the several States to separate from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others. The Union may, however, perish in two different ways: one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the confederate States may choose to retire from the compact, and so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forcibly to sever the federal tie; and it is to this supposition that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most of the remarks that I have made apply: or the authority of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Federal Government may be progressively entrenched on by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simultaneous tendency of the united republics to resume their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence. The central power, successively stripped of all its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prerogatives, and reduced to impotence by tacit consent, would become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incompetent to fulfil its purpose; and the second Union would perish,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like the first, by a sort of senile inaptitude. The gradual weakening of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the federal tie, which may finally lead to the dissolution of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union, is a distinct circumstance, that may produce a variety of minor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences before it operates so violent a change. The confederation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might still subsist, although its Government were reduced to such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a degree of inanition as to paralyze the nation, to cause internal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anarchy, and to check the general prosperity of the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: After having investigated the causes which may induce the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans to disunite, it is important to inquire whether, if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union continues to subsist, their Government will extend or contract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its sphere of action, and whether it will become more energetic or more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weak.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans are evidently disposed to look upon their future condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with alarm. They perceive that in most of the nations of the world the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise of the rights of sovereignty tends to fall under the control of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a few individuals, and they are dismayed by the idea that such will also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the case in their own country. Even the statesmen feel, or affect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to feel, these fears; for, in America, centralization is by no means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular, and there is no surer means of courting the majority than by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inveighing against the encroachments of the central power. The Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not perceive that the countries in which this alarming tendency to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralization exists are inhabited by a single people; whilst the fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union being composed of different confederate communities is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficient to baffle all the inferences which might be drawn from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: analogous circumstances. I confess that I am inclined to consider the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fears of a great number of Americans as purely imaginary; and far from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: participating in their dread of the consolidation of power in the hands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union, I think that the Federal Government is visibly losing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To prove this assertion I shall not have recourse to any remote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurrences, but to circumstances which I have myself witnessed, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which belong to our own time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An attentive examination of what is going on in the United States will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easily convince us that two opposite tendencies exist in that country,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like two distinct currents flowing in contrary directions in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: channel. The Union has now existed for forty-five years, and in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course of that time a vast number of provincial prejudices, which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at first hostile to its power, have died away. The patriotic feeling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which attached each of the Americans to his own native State is become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less exclusive; and the different parts of the Union have become more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intimately connected the better they have become acquainted with each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other. The post, *t that great instrument of intellectual intercourse,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: now reaches into the backwoods; and steamboats have established daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means of communication between the different points of the coast. An
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inland navigation of unexampled rapidity conveys commodities up and down
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rivers of the country. *u And to these facilities of nature and art
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be added those restless cravings, that busy-mindedness, and love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of pelf, which are constantly urging the American into active life,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and bringing him into contact with his fellow-citizens. He crosses the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country in every direction; he visits all the various populations of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: land; and there is not a province in France in which the natives are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so well known to each other as the 13,000,000 of men who cover the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory of the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote t: In 1832, the district of Michigan, which only contains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 31,639 inhabitants, and is still an almost unexplored wilderness,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed 940 miles of mail-roads. The territory of Arkansas, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is still more uncultivated, was already intersected by 1,938 miles of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mail-roads. (See the report of the General Post Office, November 30,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1833.) The postage of newspapers alone in the whole Union amounted to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote u: In the course of ten years, from 1821 to 1831, 271
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: steamboats have been launched upon the rivers which water the valley
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Mississippi alone. In 1829 259 steamboats existed in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. (See Legislative Documents, No. 140, p. 274.)]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But whilst the Americans intermingle, they grow in resemblance of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other; the differences resulting from their climate, their origin, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their institutions, diminish; and they all draw nearer and nearer to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common type. Every year, thousands of men leave the North to settle in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different parts of the Union: they bring with them their faith, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions, and their manners; and as they are more enlighthned than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men amongst whom they are about to dwell, they soon rise to the head of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs, and they adapt society to their own advantage. This continual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emigration of the North to the South is peculiarly favorable to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fusion of all the different provincial characters into one national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character. The civilization of the North appears to be the common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: standard, to which the whole nation will one day be assimilated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The commercial ties which unite the confederate States are strengthened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the increasing manufactures of the Americans; and the union which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: began to exist in their opinions, gradually forms a part of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits: the course of time has swept away the bugbear thoughts which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: haunted the imaginations of the citizens in 1789. The federal power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not become oppressive; it has not destroyed the independence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States; it has not subjected the confederates to monarchial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions; and the Union has not rendered the lesser States dependent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the larger ones; but the confederation has continued to increase in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population, in wealth, and in power. I am therefore convinced that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural obstacles to the continuance of the American Union are not so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful at the present time as they were in 1789; and that the enemies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union are not so numerous.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, a careful examination of the history of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the last forty-five years will readily convince us that the federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power is declining; nor is it difficult to explain the causes of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: phenomenon. *v When the Constitution of 1789 was promulgated, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation was a prey to anarchy; the Union, which succeeded this confusion,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excited much dread and much animosity; but it was warmly supported
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because it satisfied an imperious want. Thus, although it was more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attacked than it is now, the federal power soon reached the maximum of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its authority, as is usually the case with a government which triumphs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after having braced its strength by the struggle. At that time the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interpretation of the Constitution seemed to extend, rather than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repress, the federal sovereignty; and the Union offered, in several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respects, the appearance of a single and undivided people, directed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its foreign and internal policy by a single Government. But to attain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this point the people had risen, to a certain extent, above itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote v: [Since 1861 the movement is certainly in the opposite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direction, and the federal power has largely increased, and tends to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: further increase.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Constitution had not destroyed the distinct sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States; and all communities, of whatever nature they may be, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impelled by a secret propensity to assert their independence. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensity is still more decided in a country like America, in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every village forms a sort of republic accustomed to conduct its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs. It therefore cost the States an effort to submit to the federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supremacy; and all efforts, however successful they may be, necessarily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subside with the causes in which they originated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the Federal Government consolidated its authority, America resumed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its rank amongst the nations, peace returned to its frontiers, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public credit was restored; confusion was succeeded by a fixed state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things, which was favorable to the full and free exercise of industrious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enterprise. It was this very prosperity which made the Americans forget
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the cause to which it was attributable; and when once the danger was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passed, the energy and the patriotism which had enabled them to brave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it disappeared from amongst them. No sooner were they delivered from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cares which oppressed them, than they easily returned to their ordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits, and gave themselves up without resistance to their natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclinations. When a powerful Government no longer appeared to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be necessary, they once more began to think it irksome. The Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encouraged a general prosperity, and the States were not inclined to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandon the Union; but they desired to render the action of the power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which represented that body as light as possible. The general principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Union was adopted, but in every minor detail there was an actual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency to independence. The principle of confederation was every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day more easily admitted, and more rarely applied; so that the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government brought about its own decline, whilst it was creating order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and peace.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As soon as this tendency of public opinion began to be manifested
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: externally, the leaders of parties, who live by the passions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, began to work it to their own advantage. The position of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Federal Government then became exceedingly critical. Its enemies were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in possession of the popular favor; and they obtained the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conducting its policy by pledging themselves to lessen its influence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From that time forwards the Government of the Union has invariably been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to recede, as often as it has attempted to enter the lists with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the governments of the States. And whenever an interpretation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the terms of the Federal Constitution has been called for, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interpretation has most frequently been opposed to the Union, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to the States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Constitution invested the Federal Government with the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: providing for the interests of the nation; and it had been held that no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other authority was so fit to superintend the "internal improvements"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which affected the prosperity of the whole Union; such, for instance, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the cutting of canals. But the States were alarmed at a power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinct from their own, which could thus dispose of a portion of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory; and they were afraid that the central Government would, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this means, acquire a formidable extent of patronage within their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confines, and exercise a degree of influence which they intended to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reserve exclusively to their own agents. The Democratic party, which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly been opposed to the increase of the federal authority,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then accused the Congress of usurpation, and the Chief Magistrate of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition. The central Government was intimidated by the opposition;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it soon acknowledged its error, promising exactly to confine its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence for the future within the circle which was prescribed to it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Constitution confers upon the Union the right of treating with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign nations. The Indian tribes, which border upon the frontiers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States, had usually been regarded in this light. As long as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these savages consented to retire before the civilized settlers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the federal right was not contested: but as soon as an Indian tribe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempted to fix its dwelling upon a given spot, the adjacent States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: claimed possession of the lands and the rights of sovereignty over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natives. The central Government soon recognized both these claims; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after it had concluded treaties with the Indians as independent nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it gave them up as subjects to the legislative tyranny of the States. *w
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote w: See in the Legislative Documents, already quoted in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speaking of the Indians, the letter of the President of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States to the Cherokees, his correspondence on this subject with his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agents, and his messages to Congress.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Some of the States which had been founded upon the coast of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Atlantic, extended indefinitely to the West, into wild regions where no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European had ever penetrated. The States whose confines were irrevocably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fixed, looked with a jealous eye upon the unbounded regions which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future would enable their neighbors to explore. The latter then agreed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with a view to conciliate the others, and to facilitate the act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of union, to lay down their own boundaries, and to abandon all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory which lay beyond those limits to the confederation at large.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *x Thenceforward the Federal Government became the owner of all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncultivated lands which lie beyond the borders of the thirteen States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first confederated. It was invested with the right of parcelling and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: selling them, and the sums derived from this source were exclusively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reserved to the public treasure of the Union, in order to furnish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supplies for purchasing tracts of country from the Indians, for opening
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: roads to the remote settlements, and for accelerating the increase of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization as much as possible. New States have, however, been formed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the course of time, in the midst of those wilds which were formerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceded by the inhabitants of the shores of the Atlantic. Congress has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gone on to sell, for the profit of the nation at large, the uncultivated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lands which those new States contained. But the latter at length
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asserted that, as they were now fully constituted, they ought to enjoy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the exclusive right of converting the produce of these sales to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own use. As their remonstrances became more and more threatening,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Congress thought fit to deprive the Union of a portion of the privileges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it had hitherto enjoyed; and at the end of 1832 it passed a law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by which the greatest part of the revenue derived from the sale of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lands was made over to the new western republics, although the lands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves were not ceded to them. *y
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote x: The first act of session was made by the State of New York
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in 1780; Virginia, Massachusetts, Connecticut, South and North Carolina,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: followed this example at different times, and lastly, the act of cession
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Georgia was made as recently as 1802.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote y: It is true that the President refused his assent to this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law; but he completely adopted it in principle. (See Message of December
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The slightest observation in the United States enables one to appreciate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the advantages which the country derives from the bank. These advantages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are of several kinds, but one of them is peculiarly striking to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stranger. The banknotes of the United States are taken upon the borders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the desert for the same value as at Philadelphia, where the bank
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conducts its operations. *z
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote z: The present Bank of the United States was established in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1816, with a capital of $35,000,000; its charter expires in 1836. Last
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: year Congress passed a law to renew it, but the President put his veto
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the bill. The struggle is still going on with great violence on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either side, and the speedy fall of the bank may easily be foreseen. [It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was soon afterwards extinguished by General Jackson.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Bank of the United States is nevertheless the object of great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animosity. Its directors have proclaimed their hostility to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President: and they are accused, not without some show of probability,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of having abused their influence to thwart his election. The President
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore attacks the establishment which they represent with all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: warmth of personal enmity; and he is encouraged in the pursuit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his revenge by the conviction that he is supported by the secret
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities of the majority. The bank may be regarded as the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monetary tie of the Union, just as Congress is the great legislative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tie; and the same passions which tend to render the States independent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the central power, contribute to the overthrow of the bank.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Bank of the United States always holds a great number of the notes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: issued by the provincial banks, which it can at any time oblige them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convert into cash. It has itself nothing to fear from a similar demand,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the extent of its resources enables it to meet all claims. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the existence of the provincial banks is thus threatened, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: operations are restricted, since they are only able to issue a quantity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of notes duly proportioned to their capital. They submit with impatience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to this salutary control. The newspapers which they have bought over,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the President, whose interest renders him their instrument, attack
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bank with the greatest vehemence. They rouse the local passions and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the blind democratic instinct of the country to aid their cause; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they assert that the bank directors form a permanent aristocratic body,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whose influence must ultimately be felt in the Government, and must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affect those principles of equality upon which society rests in America.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The contest between the bank and its opponents is only an incident in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great struggle which is going on in America between the provinces
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the central power; between the spirit of democratic independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the spirit of gradation and subordination. I do not mean that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enemies of the bank are identically the same individuals who, on other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: points, attack the Federal Government; but I assert that the attacks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directed against the bank of the United States originate in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities which militate against the Federal Government; and that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very numerous opponents of the former afford a deplorable symptom of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decreasing support of the latter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Union has never displayed so much weakness as in the celebrated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: question of the tariff. *a The wars of the French Revolution and of 1812
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had created manufacturing establishments in the North of the Union,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by cutting off all free communication between America and Europe. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace was concluded, and the channel of intercourse reopened by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the produce of Europe was transmitted to the New World, the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought fit to establish a system of import duties, for the twofold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purpose of protecting their incipient manufactures and of paying off the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amount of the debt contracted during the war. The Southern States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which have no manufactures to encourage, and which are exclusively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agricultural, soon complained of this measure. Such were the simple
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facts, and I do not pretend to examine in this place whether their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complaints were well founded or unjust.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: See principally for the details of this affair, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Legislative Documents, 22d Congress, 2d Session, No. 30.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As early as the year 1820, South Carolina declared, in a petition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to Congress, that the tariff was "unconstitutional, oppressive, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unjust." And the States of Georgia, Virginia, North Carolina, Alabama,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and Mississippi subsequently remonstrated against it with more or less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vigor. But Congress, far from lending an ear to these complaints, raised
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the scale of tariff duties in the years 1824 and 1828, and recognized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anew the principle on which it was founded. A doctrine was then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proclaimed, or rather revived, in the South, which took the name of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nullification.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown in the proper place that the object of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution was not to form a league, but to create a national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government. The Americans of the United States form a sole and undivided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, in all the cases which are specified by that Constitution; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon these points the will of the nation is expressed, as it is in all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitutional nations, by the voice of the majority. When the majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has pronounced its decision, it is the duty of the minority to submit.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such is the sound legal doctrine, and the only one which agrees with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: text of the Constitution, and the known intention of those who framed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The partisans of Nullification in the South maintain, on the contrary,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the intention of the Americans in uniting was not to reduce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to the condition of one and the same people; that they meant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to constitute a league of independent States; and that each State,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently retains its entire sovereignty, if not de facto, at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: de jure; and has the right of putting its own construction upon the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Congress, and of suspending their execution within the limits of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own territory, if they are held to be unconstitutional and unjust.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The entire doctrine of Nullification is comprised in a sentence uttered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by Vice-President Calhoun, the head of that party in the South,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before the Senate of the United States, in the year 1833: could: "The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution is a compact to which the States were parties in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign capacity; now, whenever a compact is entered into by parties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which acknowledge no tribunal above their authority to decide in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: last resort, each of them has a right to judge for itself in relation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the nature, extent, and obligations of the instrument." It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evident that a similar doctrine destroys the very basis of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution, and brings back all the evils of the old confederation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from which the Americans were supposed to have had a safe deliverance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When South Carolina perceived that Congress turned a deaf ear to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remonstrances, it threatened to apply the doctrine of nullification to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the federal tariff bill. Congress persisted in its former system; and at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: length the storm broke out. In the course of 1832 the citizens of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South Carolina, *b named a national Convention, to consult upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary measures which they were called upon to take; and on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: November 24th of the same year this Convention promulgated a law, under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the form of a decree, which annulled the federal law of the tariff,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forbade the levy of the imposts which that law commands, and refused to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recognize the appeal which might be made to the federal courts of law.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *c This decree was only to be put in execution in the ensuing month of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: February, and it was intimated, that if Congress modified the tariff
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before that period, South Carolina might be induced to proceed no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: further with her menaces; and a vague desire was afterwards expressed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of submitting the question to an extraordinary assembly of all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederate States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: That is to say, the majority of the people; for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposite party, called the Union party, always formed a very strong and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: active minority. Carolina may contain about 47,000 electors; 30,000 were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in favor of nullification, and 17,000 opposed to it.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: This decree was preceded by a report of the committee
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by which it was framed, containing the explanation of the motives and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object of the law. The following passage occurs in it, p. 34:--"When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rights reserved by the Constitution to the different States are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deliberately violated, it is the duty and the right of those States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to interfere, in order to check the progress of the evil; to resist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usurpation, and to maintain, within their respective limits, those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers and privileges which belong to them as independent sovereign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. If they were destitute of this right, they would not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign. South Carolina declares that she acknowledges no tribunal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon earth above her authority. She has indeed entered into a solemn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compact of union with the other States; but she demands, and will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise, the right of putting her own construction upon it; and when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this compact is violated by her sister States, and by the Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they have created, she is determined to avail herself of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unquestionable right of judging what is the extent of the infraction,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and what are the measures best fitted to obtain justice."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part IX
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the meantime South Carolina armed her militia, and prepared for war.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But Congress, which had slighted its suppliant subjects, listened to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their complaints as soon as they were found to have taken up arms. *d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A law was passed, by which the tariff duties were to be progressively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reduced for ten years, until they were brought so low as not to exceed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the amount of supplies necessary to the Government. *e Thus Congress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely abandoned the principle of the tariff; and substituted a mere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fiscal impost to a system of protective duties. *f The Government of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union, in order to conceal its defeat, had recourse to an expedient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is very much in vogue with feeble governments. It yielded the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point de facto, but it remained inflexible upon the principles in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: question; and whilst Congress was altering the tariff law, it passed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another bill, by which the President was invested with extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers, enabling him to overcome by force a resistance which was then no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer to be apprehended.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: Congress was finally decided to take this step by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conduct of the powerful State of Virginia, whose legislature offered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to serve as mediator between the Union and South Carolina. Hitherto the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter State had appeared to be entirely abandoned, even by the States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which had joined in her remonstrances.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: This law was passed on March 2, 1833.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote f: This bill was brought in by Mr. Clay, and it passed in four
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: days through both Houses of Congress by an immense majority.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But South Carolina did not consent to leave the Union in the enjoyment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these scanty trophies of success: the same national Convention which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had annulled the tariff bill, met again, and accepted the proffered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concession; but at the same time it declared it unabated perseverance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the doctrine of Nullification: and to prove what it said, it annulled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the law investing the President with extraordinary powers, although it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was very certain that the clauses of that law would never be carried
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into effect.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Almost all the controversies of which I have been speaking have taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place under the Presidency of General Jackson; and it cannot be denied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in the question of the tariff he has supported the claims of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union with vigor and with skill. I am, however, of opinion that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conduct of the individual who now represents the Federal Government may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be reckoned as one of the dangers which threaten its continuance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Some persons in Europe have formed an opinion of the possible influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of General Jackson upon the affairs of his country, which appears highly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extravagant to those who have seen more of the subject. We have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been told that General Jackson has won sundry battles, that he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an energetic man, prone by nature and by habit to the use of force,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: covetous of power, and a despot by taste. All this may perhaps be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true; but the inferences which have been drawn from these truths are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exceedingly erroneous. It has been imagined that General Jackson is bent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on establishing a dictatorship in America, on introducing a military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit, and on giving a degree of influence to the central authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which cannot but be dangerous to provincial liberties. But in America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the time for similar undertakings, and the age for men of this kind, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not yet come: if General Jackson had entertained a hope of exercising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his authority in this manner, he would infallibly have forfeited his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political station, and compromised his life; accordingly he has not been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so imprudent as to make any such attempt.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Far from wishing to extend the federal power, the President belongs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the party which is desirous of limiting that power to the bare and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precise letter of the Constitution, and which never puts a construction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon that act favorable to the Government of the Union; far from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: standing forth as the champion of centralization, General Jackson is
