author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the agent of all the jealousies of the States; and he was placed in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lofty station he occupies by the passions of the people which are most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposed to the central Government. It is by perpetually flattering
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these passions that he maintains his station and his popularity. General
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jackson is the slave of the majority: he yields to its wishes, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities, and its demands; say rather, that he anticipates and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forestalls them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whenever the governments of the States come into collision with that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Union, the President is generally the first to question his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights: he almost always outstrips the legislature; and when the extent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the federal power is controverted, he takes part, as it were, against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself; he conceals his official interests, and extinguishes his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural inclinations. Not indeed that he is naturally weak or hostile
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the Union; for when the majority decided against the claims of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: partisans of nullification, he put himself at its head, asserted the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doctrines which the nation held distinctly and energetically, and was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the first to recommend forcible measures; but General Jackson appears to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me, if I may use the American expressions, to be a Federalist by taste,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and a Republican by calculation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General Jackson stoops to gain the favor of the majority, but when he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feels that his popularity is secure, he overthrows all obstacles in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit of the objects which the community approves, or of those which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it does not look upon with a jealous eye. He is supported by a power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with which his predecessors were unacquainted; and he tramples on his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal enemies whenever they cross his path with a facility which no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former President ever enjoyed; he takes upon himself the responsibility
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of measures which no one before him would have ventured to attempt: he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even treats the national representatives with disdain approaching to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insult; he puts his veto upon the laws of Congress, and frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neglects to reply to that powerful body. He is a favorite who sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: treats his master roughly. The power of General Jackson perpetually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases; but that of the President declines; in his hands the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government is strong, but it will pass enfeebled into the hands of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: successor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am strangely mistaken if the Federal Government of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be not constantly losing strength, retiring gradually from public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs, and narrowing its circle of action more and more. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally feeble, but it now abandons even its pretensions to strength.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, I thought that I remarked a more lively sense of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence, and a more decided attachment to provincial government in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States. The Union is to subsist, but to subsist as a shadow; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to be strong in certain cases, and weak in all others; in time of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: warfare, it is to be able to concentrate all the forces of the nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and all the resources of the country in its hands; and in time of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace its existence is to be scarcely perceptible: as if this alternate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: debility and vigor were natural or possible.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not foresee anything for the present which may be able to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: check this general impulse of public opinion; the causes in which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originated do not cease to operate with the same effect. The change will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore go on, and it may be predicted that, unless some extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: event occurs, the Government of the Union will grow weaker and weaker
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every day.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think, however, that the period is still remote at which the federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power will be entirely extinguished by its inability to protect itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to maintain peace in the country. The Union is sanctioned by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manners and desires of the people; its results are palpable, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: benefits visible. When it is perceived that the weakness of the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government compromises the existence of the Union, I do not doubt that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reaction will take place with a view to increase its strength.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Government of the United States is, of all the federal governments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which have hitherto been established, the one which is most naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destined to act. As long as it is only indirectly assailed by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interpretation of its laws, and as long as its substance is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seriously altered, a change of opinion, an internal crisis, or a war,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may restore all the vigor which it requires. The point which I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been most anxious to put in a clear light is simply this: Many people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially in France, imagine that a change in opinion is going on in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States, which is favorable to a centralization of power in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hands of the President and the Congress. I hold that a contrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency may distinctly be observed. So far is the Federal Government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from acquiring strength, and from threatening the sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, as it grows older, that I maintain it to be growing weaker and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weaker, and that the sovereignty of the Union alone is in danger. Such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are the facts which the present time discloses. The future conceals the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: final result of this tendency, and the events which may check, retard,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or accelerate the changes I have described; but I do not affect to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able to remove the veil which hides them from our sight.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of The Republican Institutions Of The United States, And What Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chances Of Duration Are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Union is accidental--The Republican institutions have more prospect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of permanence--A republic for the present the natural state of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-Americans--Reason of this--In order to destroy it, all the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be changed at the same time, and a great alteration take place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in manners--Difficulties experienced by the Americans in creating an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The dismemberment of the Union, by the introduction of war into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heart of those States which are now confederate, with standing armies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a dictatorship, and a heavy taxation, might, eventually, compromise the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fate of the republican institutions. But we ought not to confound the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future prospects of the republic with those of the Union. The Union is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an accident, which will only last as long as circumstances are favorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to its existence; but a republican form of government seems to me to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the natural state of the Americans; which nothing but the continued
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action of hostile causes, always acting in the same direction, could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change into a monarchy. The Union exists principally in the law which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed it; one revolution, one change in public opinion, might destroy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it forever; but the republic has a much deeper foundation to rest upon.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What is understood by a republican government in the United States is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the slow and quiet action of society upon itself. It is a regular state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things really founded upon the enlightened will of the people. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a conciliatory government under which resolutions are allowed time to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ripen; and in which they are deliberately discussed, and executed with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mature judgment. The republicans in the United States set a high value
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon morality, respect religious belief, and acknowledge the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of rights. They profess to think that a people ought to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral, religious, and temperate, in proportion as it is free. What is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called the republic in the United States, is the tranquil rule of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority, which, after having had time to examine itself, and to give
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proof of its existence, is the common source of all the powers of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State. But the power of the majority is not of itself unlimited. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral world humanity, justice, and reason enjoy an undisputed supremacy;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the political world vested rights are treated with no less deference.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The majority recognizes these two barriers; and if it now and then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overstep them, it is because, like individuals, it has passions, and,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like them, it is prone to do what is wrong, whilst it discerns what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the demagogues of Europe have made strange discoveries. A republic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not, according to them, the rule of the majority, as has hitherto
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been thought, but the rule of those who are strenuous partisans of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the majority. It is not the people who preponderates in this kind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, but those who are best versed in the good qualities of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. A happy distinction, which allows men to act in the name of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations without consulting them, and to claim their gratitude whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their rights are spurned. A republican government, moreover, is the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one which claims the right of doing whatever it chooses, and despising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what men have hitherto respected, from the highest moral obligations to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the vulgar rules of common-sense. It had been supposed, until our time,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that despotism was odious, under whatever form it appeared. But it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a discovery of modern days that there are such things as legitimate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tyranny and holy injustice, provided they are exercised in the name of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The ideas which the Americans have adopted respecting the republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form of government, render it easy for them to live under it, and insure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its duration. If, in their country, this form be often practically bad,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least it is theoretically good; and, in the end, the people always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acts in conformity to it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It was impossible at the foundation of the States, and it would still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be difficult, to establish a central administration in America. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants are dispersed over too great a space, and separated by too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many natural obstacles, for one man to undertake to direct the details
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their existence. America is therefore pre-eminently the country of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provincial and municipal government. To this cause, which was plainly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: felt by all the Europeans of the New World, the Anglo-Americans added
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several others peculiar to themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the time of the settlement of the North American colonies, municipal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty had already penetrated into the laws as well as the manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the English; and the emigrants adopted it, not only as a necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing, but as a benefit which they knew how to appreciate. We have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already seen the manner in which the colonies were founded: every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: province, and almost every district, was peopled separately by men who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were strangers to each other, or who associated with very different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purposes. The English settlers in the United States, therefore, early
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceived that they were divided into a great number of small and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinct communities which belonged to no common centre; and that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was needful for each of these little communities to take care of its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs, since there did not appear to be any central authority which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was naturally bound and easily enabled to provide for them. Thus, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature of the country, the manner in which the British colonies were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: founded, the habits of the first emigrants, in short everything,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: united to promote, in an extraordinary degree, municipal and provincial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, therefore, the mass of the institutions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country is essentially republican; and in order permanently to destroy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws which form the basis of the republic, it would be necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolish all the laws at once. At the present day it would be even more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult for a party to succeed in founding a monarchy in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States than for a set of men to proclaim that France should henceforward
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be a republic. Royalty would not find a system of legislation prepared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for it beforehand; and a monarchy would then exist, really surrounded by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republican institutions. The monarchical principle would likewise have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great difficulty in penetrating into the manners of the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, the sovereignty of the people is not an isolated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doctrine bearing no relation to the prevailing manners and ideas of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people: it may, on the contrary, be regarded as the last link of a chain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of opinions which binds the whole Anglo-American world. That Providence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has given to every human being the degree of reason necessary to direct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself in the affairs which interest him exclusively--such is the grand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maxim upon which civil and political society rests in the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The father of a family applies it to his children; the master to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servants; the township to its officers; the province to its townships;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State to its provinces; the Union to the States; and when extended
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the nation, it becomes the doctrine of the sovereignty of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, in the United States, the fundamental principle of the republic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the same which governs the greater part of human actions; republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions insinuate themselves into all the ideas, opinions, and habits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans, whilst they are formerly recognized by the legislation:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and before this legislation can be altered the whole community must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undergo very serious changes. In the United States, even the religion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most of the citizens is republican, since it submits the truths of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other world to private judgment: as in politics the care of its temporal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests is abandoned to the good sense of the people. Thus every man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is allowed freely to take that road which he thinks will lead him to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heaven; just as the law permits every citizen to have the right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choosing his government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is evident that nothing but a long series of events, all having the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same tendency, can substitute for this combination of laws, opinions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and manners, a mass of opposite opinions, manners, and laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If republican principles are to perish in America, they can only yield
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after a laborious social process, often interrupted, and as often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resumed; they will have many apparent revivals, and will not become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: totally extinct until an entirely new people shall have succeeded to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that which now exists. Now, it must be admitted that there is no symptom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or presage of the approach of such a revolution. There is nothing more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: striking to a person newly arrived in the United States, than the kind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of tumultuous agitation in which he finds political society. The laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are incessantly changing, and at first sight it seems impossible that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people so variable in its desires should avoid adopting, within a short
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: space of time, a completely new form of government. Such apprehensions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are, however, premature; the instability which affects political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions is of two kinds, which ought not to be confounded: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first, which modifies secondary laws, is not incompatible with a very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settled state of society; the other shakes the very foundations of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution, and attacks the fundamental principles of legislation;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this species of instability is always followed by troubles and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions, and the nation which suffers under it is in a state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violent transition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Experience shows that these two kinds of legislative instability have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no necessary connection; for they have been found united or separate,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: according to times and circumstances. The first is common in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, but not the second: the Americans often change their laws, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the foundation of the Constitution is respected.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In our days the republican principle rules in America, as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monarchical principle did in France under Louis XIV. The French of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that period were not only friends of the monarchy, but they thought it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible to put anything in its place; they received it as we receive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rays of the sun and the return of the seasons. Amongst them the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: royal power had neither advocates nor opponents. In like manner does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the republican government exist in America, without contention or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposition; without proofs and arguments, by a tacit agreement, a sort
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of consensus universalis. It is, however, my opinion that by changing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their administrative forms as often as they do, the inhabitants of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States compromise the future stability of their government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may be apprehended that men, perpetually thwarted in their designs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the mutability of the legislation, will learn to look upon republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions as an inconvenient form of society; the evil resulting from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the instability of the secondary enactments might then raise a doubt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to the nature of the fundamental principles of the Constitution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and indirectly bring about a revolution; but this epoch is still very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remote.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may, however, be foreseen even now, that when the Americans lose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their republican institutions they will speedily arrive at a despotic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, without a long interval of limited monarchy. Montesquieu
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarked, that nothing is more absolute than the authority of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prince who immediately succeeds a republic, since the powers which had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fearlessly been intrusted to an elected magistrate are then transferred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a hereditary sovereign. This is true in general, but it is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiarly applicable to a democratic republic. In the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the magistrates are not elected by a particular class of citizens, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the majority of the nation; they are the immediate representatives of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the passions of the multitude; and as they are wholly dependent upon its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasure, they excite neither hatred nor fear: hence, as I have already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shown, very little care has been taken to limit their influence, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are left in possession of a vast deal of arbitrary power. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of things has engendered habits which would outlive itself; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American magistrate would retain his power, but he would cease to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: responsible for the exercise of it; and it is impossible to say what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bounds could then be set to tyranny.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Some of our European politicians expect to see an aristocracy arise in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, and they already predict the exact period at which it will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able to assume the reins of government. I have previously observed, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I repeat my assertion, that the present tendency of American society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appears to me to become more and more democratic. Nevertheless, I do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assert that the Americans will not, at some future time, restrict the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circle of political rights in their country, or confiscate those rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the advantage of a single individual; but I cannot imagine that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will ever bestow the exclusive exercise of them upon a privileged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class of citizens, or, in other words, that they will ever found an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An aristocratic body is composed of a certain number of citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who, without being very far removed from the mass of the people, are,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless, permanently stationed above it: a body which it is easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to touch and difficult to strike; with which the people are in daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contact, but with which they can never combine. Nothing can be imagined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more contrary to nature and to the secret propensities of the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heart than a subjection of this kind; and men who are left to follow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own bent will always prefer the arbitrary power of a king to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regular administration of an aristocracy. Aristocratic institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot subsist without laying down the inequality of men as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fundamental principle, as a part and parcel of the legislation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affecting the condition of the human family as much as it affects that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society; but these are things so repugnant to natural equity that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they can only be extorted from men by constraint.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not think a single people can be quoted, since human society began
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to exist, which has, by its own free will and by its own exertions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: created an aristocracy within its own bosom. All the aristocracies of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Middle Ages were founded by military conquest; the conqueror was the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: noble, the vanquished became the serf. Inequality was then imposed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: force; and after it had been introduced into the manners of the country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it maintained its own authority, and was sanctioned by the legislation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Communities have existed which were aristocratic from their earliest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: origin, owing to circumstances anterior to that event, and which became
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more democratic in each succeeding age. Such was the destiny of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Romans, and of the barbarians after them. But a people, having taken its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rise in civilization and democracy, which should gradually establish an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality of conditions, until it arrived at inviolable privileges and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusive castes, would be a novelty in the world; and nothing intimates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that America is likely to furnish so singular an example.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Reflection On The Causes Of The Commercial Prosperity Of The Of The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans destined by Nature to be a great maritime people--Extent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their coasts--Depth of their ports--Size of their rivers--The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commercial superiority of the Anglo-Americans less attributable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however, to physical circumstances than to moral and intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes--Reason of this opinion--Future destiny of the Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a commercial nation--The dissolution of the Union would not check
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the maritime vigor of the States--Reason of this--Anglo-Americans will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally supply the wants of the inhabitants of South America--They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will become, like the English, the factors of a great portion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The coast of the United States, from the Bay of Fundy to the Sabine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: River in the Gulf of Mexico, is more than two thousand miles in extent.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These shores form an unbroken line, and they are all subject to the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government. No nation in the world possesses vaster, deeper, or more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secure ports for shipping than the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The inhabitants of the United States constitute a great civilized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, which fortune has placed in the midst of an uncultivated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country at a distance of three thousand miles from the central point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of civilization. America consequently stands in daily need of European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trade. The Americans will, no doubt, ultimately succeed in producing or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturing at home most of the articles which they require; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two continents can never be independent of each other, so numerous are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the natural ties which exist between their wants, their ideas, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits, and their manners.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Union produces peculiar commodities which are now become necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to us, but which cannot be cultivated, or can only be raised at an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enormous expense, upon the soil of Europe. The Americans only consume a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small portion of this produce, and they are willing to sell us the rest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe is therefore the market of America, as America is the market
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe; and maritime commerce is no less necessary to enable the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of the United States to transport their raw materials to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ports of Europe, than it is to enable us to supply them with our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactured produce. The United States were therefore necessarily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reduced to the alternative of increasing the business of other maritime
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations to a great extent, if they had themselves declined to enter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into commerce, as the Spaniards of Mexico have hitherto done; or, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: second place, of becoming one of the first trading powers of the globe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Anglo-Americans have always displayed a very decided taste for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sea. The Declaration of Independence broke the commercial restrictions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which united them to England, and gave a fresh and powerful stimulus to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their maritime genius. Ever since that time, the shipping of the Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has increased in almost the same rapid proportion as the number of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants. The Americans themselves now transport to their own shores
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nine-tenths of the European produce which they consume. *g And they also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bring three-quarters of the exports of the New World to the European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consumer. *h The ships of the United States fill the docks of Havre and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Liverpool; whilst the number of English and French vessels which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be seen at New York is comparatively small. *i
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote g: The total value of goods imported during the year which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ended on September 30, 1832, was $101,129,266. The value of the cargoes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of foreign vessels did not amount to $10,731,039, or about one-tenth of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the entire sum.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote h: The value of goods exported during the same year amounted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to $87,176,943; the value of goods exported by foreign vessels amounted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to $21,036,183, or about one quarter of the whole sum. (Williams's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote i: The tonnage of the vessels which entered all the ports of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union in the years 1829, 1830, and 1831, amounted to 3,307,719 tons,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of which 544,571 tons were foreign vessels; they stood, therefore,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the American vessels in a ratio of about 16 to 100. ("National
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Calendar," 1833, p. 304.) The tonnage of the English vessels which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entered the ports of London, Liverpool, and Hull, in the years 1820,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1826, and 1831, amounted to 443,800 tons. The foreign vessels which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entered the same ports during the same years amounted to 159,431 tons.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The ratio between them was, therefore, about 36 to 100. ("Companion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the Almanac," 1834, p. 169.) In the year 1832 the ratio between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign and British ships which entered the ports of Great Britain was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 29 to 100. [These statements relate to a condition of affairs which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has ceased to exist; the Civil War and the heavy taxation of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States entirely altered the trade and navigation of the country.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, not only does the American merchant face the competition of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own countrymen, but he even supports that of foreign nations in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own ports with success. This is readily explained by the fact that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vessels of the United States can cross the seas at a cheaper rate than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any other vessels in the world. As long as the mercantile shipping of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States preserves this superiority, it will not only retain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what it has acquired, but it will constantly increase in prosperity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Future Condition Of Three Races--Part X
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is difficult to say for what reason the Americans can trade at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lower rate than other nations; and one is at first led to attribute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this circumstance to the physical or natural advantages which are within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their reach; but this supposition is erroneous. The American vessels
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cost almost as much to build as our own; *j they are not better built,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they generally last for a shorter time. The pay of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sailor is more considerable than the pay on board European ships; which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is proved by the great number of Europeans who are to be met with in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merchant vessels of the United States. But I am of opinion that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true cause of their superiority must not be sought for in physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages, but that it is wholly attributable to their moral and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellectual qualities.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote j: Materials are, generally speaking, less expensive in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America than in Europe, but the price of labor is much higher.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The following comparison will illustrate my meaning. During the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: campaigns of the Revolution the French introduced a new system of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tactics into the art of war, which perplexed the oldest generals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and very nearly destroyed the most ancient monarchies in Europe. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertook (what had never before been attempted) to make shift without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a number of things which had always been held to be indispensable in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: warfare; they required novel exertions on the part of their troops which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no civilized nations had ever thought of; they achieved great actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in an incredibly short space of time; and they risked human life without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hesitation to obtain the object in view. The French had less money and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fewer men than their enemies; their resources were infinitely inferior;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless they were constantly victorious, until their adversaries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chose to imitate their example.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans have introduced a similar system into their commercial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speculations; and they do for cheapness what the French did for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquest. The European sailor navigates with prudence; he only sets sail
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when the weather is favorable; if an unforseen accident befalls him, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: puts into port; at night he furls a portion of his canvas; and when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whitening billows intimate the vicinity of land, he checks his way,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and takes an observation of the sun. But the American neglects these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precautions and braves these dangers. He weighs anchor in the midst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of tempestuous gales; by night and by day he spreads his sheets to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wind; he repairs as he goes along such damage as his vessel may have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sustained from the storm; and when he at last approaches the term of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: voyage, he darts onward to the shore as if he already descried a port.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans are often shipwrecked, but no trader crosses the seas so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapidly. And as they perform the same distance in a shorter time, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can perform it at a cheaper rate.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The European touches several times at different ports in the course of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long voyage; he loses a good deal of precious time in making the harbor,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or in waiting for a favorable wind to leave it; and he pays daily dues
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be allowed to remain there. The American starts from Boston to go to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purchase tea in China; he arrives at Canton, stays there a few days, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then returns. In less than two years he has sailed as far as the entire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumference of the globe, and he has seen land but once. It is true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that during a voyage of eight or ten months he has drunk brackish water
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and lived upon salt meat; that he has been in a continual contest with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sea, with disease, and with a tedious existence; but upon his return
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he can sell a pound of his tea for a half-penny less than the English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merchant, and his purpose is accomplished.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I cannot better explain my meaning than by saying that the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affect a sort of heroism in their manner of trading. But the European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merchant will always find it very difficult to imitate his American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: competitor, who, in adopting the system which I have just described,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: follows not only a calculation of his gain, but an impulse of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The inhabitants of the United States are subject to all the wants and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the desires which result from an advanced stage of civilization; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as they are not surrounded by a community admirably adapted, like that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe, to satisfy their wants, they are often obliged to procure for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves the various articles which education and habit have rendered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessaries. In America it sometimes happens that the same individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tills his field, builds his dwelling, contrives his tools, makes his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shoes, and weaves the coarse stuff of which his dress is composed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This circumstance is prejudicial to the excellence of the work; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it powerfully contributes to awaken the intelligence of the workman.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing tends to materialize man, and to deprive his work of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faintest trace of mind, more than extreme division of labor. In a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country like America, where men devoted to special occupations are rare,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a long apprenticeship cannot be required from anyone who embraces a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession. The Americans, therefore, change their means of gaining
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a livelihood very readily; and they suit their occupations to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exigencies of the moment, in the manner most profitable to themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men are to be met with who have successively been barristers, farmers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merchants, ministers of the gospel, and physicians. If the American be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less perfect in each craft than the European, at least there is scarcely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any trade with which he is utterly unacquainted. His capacity is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general, and the circle of his intelligence is enlarged.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The inhabitants of the United States are never fettered by the axioms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their profession; they escape from all the prejudices of their present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: station; they are not more attached to one line of operation than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another; they are not more prone to employ an old method than a new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one; they have no rooted habits, and they easily shake off the influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the habits of other nations might exercise upon their minds from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a conviction that their country is unlike any other, and that its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: situation is without a precedent in the world. America is a land of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wonders, in which everything is in constant motion, and every movement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seems an improvement. The idea of novelty is there indissolubly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connected with the idea of amelioration. No natural boundary seems to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: set to the efforts of man; and what is not yet done is only what he has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not yet attempted to do.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This perpetual change which goes on in the United States, these frequent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vicissitudes of fortune, accompanied by such unforeseen fluctuations in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private and in public wealth, serve to keep the minds of the citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a perpetual state of feverish agitation, which admirably invigorates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their exertions, and keeps them in a state of excitement above the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinary level of mankind. The whole life of an American is passed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like a game of chance, a revolutionary crisis, or a battle. As the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same causes are continually in operation throughout the country, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ultimately impart an irresistible impulse to the national character. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American, taken as a chance specimen of his countrymen, must then be a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man of singular warmth in his desires, enterprising, fond of adventure,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and, above all, of innovation. The same bent is manifest in all that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does; he introduces it into his political laws, his religious doctrines,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his theories of social economy, and his domestic occupations; he bears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it with him in the depths of the backwoods, as well as in the business
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the city. It is this same passion, applied to maritime commerce,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which makes him the cheapest and the quickest trader in the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As long as the sailors of the United States retain these inspiriting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages, and the practical superiority which they derive from them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will not only continue to supply the wants of the producers and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consumers of their own country, but they will tend more and more to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become, like the English, the factors of all other peoples. *k This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prediction has already begun to be realized; we perceive that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American traders are introducing themselves as intermediate agents in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the commerce of several European nations; *l and America will offer a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still wider field to their enterprise.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote k: It must not be supposed that English vessels are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusively employed in transporting foreign produce into England, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: British produce to foreign countries; at the present day the merchant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shipping of England may be regarded in the light of a vast system of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public conveyances, ready to serve all the producers of the world, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to open communications between all peoples. The maritime genius of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans prompts them to enter into competition with the English.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote l: Part of the commerce of the Mediterranean is already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carried on by American vessels.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great colonies which were founded in South America by the Spaniards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the Portuguese have since become empires. Civil war and oppression
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: now lay waste those extensive regions. Population does not increase, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the thinly scattered inhabitants are too much absorbed in the cares of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self-defense even to attempt any amelioration of their condition. Such,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however, will not always be the case. Europe has succeeded by her own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efforts in piercing the gloom of the Middle Ages; South America has the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same Christian laws and Christian manners as we have; she contains all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the germs of civilization which have grown amidst the nations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe or their offsets, added to the advantages to be derived from our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: example: why then should she always remain uncivilized? It is clear that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the question is simply one of time; at some future period, which may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more or less remote, the inhabitants of South America will constitute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flourishing and enlightened nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But when the Spaniards and Portuguese of South America begin to feel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the wants common to all civilized nations, they will still be unable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to satisfy those wants for themselves; as the youngest children of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization, they must perforce admit the superiority of their elder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brethren. They will be agriculturists long before they succeed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures or commerce, and they will require the mediation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strangers to exchange their produce beyond seas for those articles for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which a demand will begin to be felt.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is unquestionable that the Americans of the North will one day supply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the wants of the Americans of the South. Nature has placed them in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contiguity, and has furnished the former with every means of knowing and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appreciating those demands, of establishing a permanent connection with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those States, and of gradually filling their markets. The merchants of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States could only forfeit these natural advantages if he were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very inferior to the merchant of Europe; to whom he is, on the contrary,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior in several respects. The Americans of the United States already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise a very considerable moral influence upon all the peoples of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the New World. They are the source of intelligence, and all the nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which inhabit the same continent are already accustomed to consider them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the most enlightened, the most powerful, and the most wealthy members
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the great American family. All eyes are therefore turned towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union; and the States of which that body is composed are the models
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the other communities try to imitate to the best of their power;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is from the United States that they borrow their political principles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans of the United States stand in precisely the same position
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with regard to the peoples of South America as their fathers, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English, occupy with regard to the Italians, the Spaniards, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Portuguese, and all those nations of Europe which receive their articles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of daily consumption from England, because they are less advanced in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization and trade. England is at this time the natural emporium of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all the nations which are within its reach; the American Union
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will perform the same part in the other hemisphere; and every community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is founded, or which prospers in the New World, is founded and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prospers to the advantage of the Anglo-Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the Union were to be dissolved, the commerce of the States which now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compose it would undoubtedly be checked for a time; but this consequence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be less perceptible than is generally supposed. It is evident
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, whatever may happen, the commercial States will remain united.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They are all contiguous to each other; they have identically the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions, interests, and manners; and they are alone competent to form a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very great maritime power. Even if the South of the Union were to become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent of the North, it would still require the services of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States. I have already observed that the South is not a commercial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, and nothing intimates that it is likely to become so. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans of the South of the United States will therefore be obliged,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for a long time to come, to have recourse to strangers to export their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produce, and to supply them with the commodities which are requisite to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfy their wants. But the Northern States are undoubtedly able to act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as their intermediate agents cheaper than any other merchants. They will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore retain that employment, for cheapness is the sovereign law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of commerce. National claims and national prejudices cannot resist the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of cheapness. Nothing can be more virulent than the hatred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which exists between the Americans of the United States and the English.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But notwithstanding these inimical feelings, the Americans derive the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater part of their manufactured commodities from England, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England supplies them at a cheaper rate than any other nation. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increasing prosperity of America turns, notwithstanding the grudges of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans, to the advantage of British manufactures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Reason shows and experience proves that no commercial prosperity can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: durable if it cannot be united, in case of need, to naval force. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: truth is as well understood in the United States as it can be anywhere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: else: the Americans are already able to make their flag respected; in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: few years they will be able to make it feared. I am convinced that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dismemberment of the Union would not have the effect of diminishing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naval power of the Americans, but that it would powerfully contribute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to increase it. At the present time the commercial States are connected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with others which have not the same interests, and which frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yield an unwilling consent to the increase of a maritime power by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are only indirectly benefited. If, on the contrary, the commercial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States of the Union formed one independent nation, commerce would become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the foremost of their national interests; they would consequently be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: willing to make very great sacrifices to protect their shipping, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing would prevent them from pursuing their designs upon this point.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nations, as well as men, almost always betray the most prominent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: features of their future destiny in their earliest years. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I contemplate the ardor with which the Anglo-Americans prosecute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commercial enterprise, the advantages which befriend them, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: success of their undertakings, I cannot refrain from believing that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will one day become the first maritime power of the globe. They are born
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to rule the seas, as the Romans were to conquer the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Conclusion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have now nearly reached the close of my inquiry; hitherto, in speaking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the future destiny of the United States, I have endeavored to divide
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my subject into distinct portions, in order to study each of them with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more attention. My present object is to embrace the whole from one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single point; the remarks I shall make will be less detailed, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be more sure. I shall perceive each object less distinctly, but I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall descry the principal facts with more certainty. A traveller who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has just left the walls of an immense city, climbs the neighboring hill;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as he goes father off he loses sight of the men whom he has so recently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quitted; their dwellings are confused in a dense mass; he can no longer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguish the public squares, and he can scarcely trace out the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great thoroughfares; but his eye has less difficulty in following the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: boundaries of the city, and for the first time he sees the shape of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the vast whole. Such is the future destiny of the British race in North
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America to my eye; the details of the stupendous picture are overhung
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with shade, but I conceive a clear idea of the entire subject.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The territory now occupied or possessed by the United States of America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forms about one-twentieth part of the habitable earth. But extensive as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these confines are, it must not be supposed that the Anglo-American race
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will always remain within them; indeed, it has already far overstepped
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There was once a time at which we also might have created a great French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation in the American wilds, to counterbalance the influence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English upon the destinies of the New World. France formerly possessed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a territory in North America, scarcely less extensive than the whole of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe. The three greatest rivers of that continent then flowed within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her dominions. The Indian tribes which dwelt between the mouth of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: St. Lawrence and the delta of the Mississippi were unaccustomed to any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other tongue but ours; and all the European settlements scattered over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that immense region recalled the traditions of our country. Louisbourg,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Montmorency, Duquesne, St. Louis, Vincennes, New Orleans (for such were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the names they bore) are words dear to France and familiar to our ears.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But a concourse of circumstances, which it would be tedious to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enumerate, *m have deprived us of this magnificent inheritance. Wherever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the French settlers were numerically weak and partially established,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have disappeared: those who remain are collected on a small extent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of country, and are now subject to other laws. The 400,000 French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of Lower Canada constitute, at the present time, the remnant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an old nation lost in the midst of a new people. A foreign population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is increasing around them unceasingly and on all sides, which already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penetrates amongst the ancient masters of the country, predominates in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their cities and corrupts their language. This population is identical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with that of the United States; it is therefore with truth that I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asserted that the British race is not confined within the frontiers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union, since it already extends to the northeast.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote m: The foremost of these circumstances is, that nations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are accustomed to free institutions and municipal government are better
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able than any others to found prosperous colonies. The habit of thinking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and governing for oneself is indispensable in a new country, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: success necessarily depends, in a great measure, upon the individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions of the settlers.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To the northwest nothing is to be met with but a few insignificant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Russian settlements; but to the southwest, Mexico presents a barrier to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Anglo-Americans. Thus, the Spaniards and the Anglo-Americans are,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: properly speaking, the only two races which divide the possession of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New World. The limits of separation between them have been settled by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a treaty; but although the conditions of that treaty are exceedingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to the Anglo-Americans, I do not doubt that they will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shortly infringe this arrangement. Vast provinces, extending beyond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the frontiers of the Union towards Mexico, are still destitute of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants. The natives of the United States will forestall the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rightful occupants of these solitary regions. They will take possession
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the soil, and establish social institutions, so that when the legal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: owner arrives at length, he will find the wilderness under cultivation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and strangers quietly settled in the midst of his inheritance. *n
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote n: [This was speedily accomplished, and ere long both Texas
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and California formed part of the United States. The Russian settlements
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were acquired by purchase.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The lands of the New World belong to the first occupant, and they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the natural reward of the swiftest pioneer. Even the countries which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already peopled will have some difficulty in securing themselves from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this invasion. I have already alluded to what is taking place in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: province of Texas. The inhabitants of the United States are perpetually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: migrating to Texas, where they purchase land; and although they conform
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the laws of the country, they are gradually founding the empire of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own language and their own manners. The province of Texas is still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of the Mexican dominions, but it will soon contain no Mexicans;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same thing has occurred whenever the Anglo-Americans have come into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contact with populations of a different origin.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It cannot be denied that the British race has acquired an amazing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preponderance over all the other European races in the New World; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it is very superior to them in civilization, in industry, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. As long as it is only surrounded by desert or thinly peopled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries, as long as it encounters no dense populations upon its route,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through which it cannot work its way, it will assuredly continue to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spread. The lines marked out by treaties will not stop it; but it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everywhere transgress these imaginary barriers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The geographical position of the British race in the New World is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiarly favorable to its rapid increase. Above its northern frontiers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the icy regions of the Pole extend; and a few degrees below its southern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confines lies the burning climate of the Equator. The Anglo-Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are, therefore, placed in the most temperate and habitable zone of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continent.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is generally supposed that the prodigious increase of population in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States is posterior to their Declaration of Independence. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this is an error: the population increased as rapidly under the colonial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system as it does at the present day; that is to say, it doubled in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about twenty-two years. But this proportion which is now applied to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: millions, was then applied to thousands of inhabitants; and the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact which was scarcely noticeable a century ago, is now evident to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every observer.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The British subjects in Canada, who are dependent on a king, augment and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spread almost as rapidly as the British settlers of the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who live under a republican government. During the war of independence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which lasted eight years, the population continued to increase without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intermission in the same ratio. Although powerful Indian nations allied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the English existed at that time upon the western frontiers, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emigration westward was never checked. Whilst the enemy laid waste the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shores of the Atlantic, Kentucky, the western parts of Pennsylvania, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States of Vermont and of Maine were filling with inhabitants. Nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: did the unsettled state of the Constitution, which succeeded the war,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevent the increase of the population, or stop its progress across the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilds. Thus, the difference of laws, the various conditions of peace and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: war, of order and of anarchy, have exercised no perceptible influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the gradual development of the Anglo-Americans. This may be readily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood; for the fact is, that no causes are sufficiently general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to exercise a simultaneous influence over the whole of so extensive a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory. One portion of the country always offers a sure retreat from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the calamities which afflict another part; and however great may be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evil, the remedy which is at hand is greater still.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must not, then, be imagined that the impulse of the British race in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the New World can be arrested. The dismemberment of the Union, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hostilities which might ensure, the abolition of republican
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions, and the tyrannical government which might succeed it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may retard this impulse, but they cannot prevent it from ultimately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fulfilling the destinies to which that race is reserved. No power upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: earth can close upon the emigrants that fertile wilderness which offers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources to all industry, and a refuge from all want. Future events,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of whatever nature they may be, will not deprive the Americans of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: climate or of their inland seas, of their great rivers or of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exuberant soil. Nor will bad laws, revolutions, and anarchy be able to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliterate that love of prosperity and that spirit of enterprise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which seem to be the distinctive characteristics of their race, or to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extinguish that knowledge which guides them on their way.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, in the midst of the uncertain future, one event at least is sure.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At a period which may be said to be near (for we are speaking of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life of a nation), the Anglo-Americans will alone cover the immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: space contained between the polar regions and the tropics, extending
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the coasts of the Atlantic to the shores of the Pacific Ocean. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory which will probably be occupied by the Anglo-Americans at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some future time, may be computed to equal three-quarters of Europe in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent. *o The climate of the Union is upon the whole preferable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of Europe, and its natural advantages are not less great; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is therefore evident that its population will at some future time be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportionate to our own. Europe, divided as it is between so many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different nations, and torn as it has been by incessant wars and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barbarous manners of the Middle Ages, has notwithstanding attained a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population of 410 inhabitants to the square league. *p What cause can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevent the United States from having as numerous a population in time?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote o: The United States already extend over a territory equal to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one-half of Europe. The area of Europe is 500,000 square leagues, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its population 205,000,000 of inhabitants. ("Malte Brun," liv. 114. vol.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [This computation is given in French leagues, which were in use when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: author wrote. Twenty years later, in 1850, the superficial area of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States had been extended to 3,306,865 square miles of territory,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is about the area of Europe.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote p: See "Malte Brun," liv. 116, vol. vi. p. 92.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Many ages must elapse before the divers offsets of the British race in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
