text: America cease to present the same homogeneous characteristics: and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time cannot be foreseen at which a permanent inequality of conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be established in the New World. Whatever differences may arise,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from peace or from war, from freedom or oppression, from prosperity or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: want, between the destinies of the different descendants of the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Anglo-American family, they will at least preserve an analogous social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition, and they will hold in common the customs and the opinions to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which that social condition has given birth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the Middle Ages, the tie of religion was sufficiently powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to imbue all the different populations of Europe with the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization. The British of the New World have a thousand other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reciprocal ties; and they live at a time when the tendency to equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is general amongst mankind. The Middle Ages were a period when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything was broken up; when each people, each province, each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: city, and each family, had a strong tendency to maintain its distinct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuality. At the present time an opposite tendency seems to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevail, and the nations seem to be advancing to unity. Our means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellectual intercourse unite the most remote parts of the earth; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is impossible for men to remain strangers to each other, or to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorant of the events which are taking place in any corner of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: globe. The consequence is that there is less difference, at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day, between the Europeans and their descendants in the New World, than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there was between certain towns in the thirteenth century which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only separated by a river. If this tendency to assimilation brings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign nations closer to each other, it must a fortiori prevent the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descendants of the same people from becoming aliens to each other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The time will therefore come when one hundred and fifty millions of men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be living in North America, *q equal in condition, the progeny of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one race, owing their origin to the same cause, and preserving the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization, the same language, the same religion, the same habits, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same manners, and imbued with the same opinions, propagated under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same forms. The rest is uncertain, but this is certain; and it is a fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: new to the world--a fact fraught with such portentous consequences as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: baffle the efforts even of the imagination.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote q: This would be a population proportionate to that of Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken at a mean rate of 410 inhabitants to the square league.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are, at the present time, two great nations in the world which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem to tend towards the same end, although they started from different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: points: I allude to the Russians and the Americans. Both of them have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grown up unnoticed; and whilst the attention of mankind was directed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere, they have suddenly assumed a most prominent place amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations; and the world learned their existence and their greatness at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost the same time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All other nations seem to have nearly reached their natural limits, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only to be charged with the maintenance of their power; but these are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still in the act of growth; *r all the others are stopped, or continue
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to advance with extreme difficulty; these are proceeding with ease and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with celerity along a path to which the human eye can assign no term.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American struggles against the natural obstacles which oppose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him; the adversaries of the Russian are men; the former combats the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilderness and savage life; the latter, civilization with all its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weapons and its arts: the conquests of the one are therefore gained by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ploughshare; those of the other by the sword. The Anglo-American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relies upon personal interest to accomplish his ends, and gives free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scope to the unguided exertions and common-sense of the citizens;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Russian centres all the authority of society in a single arm: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal instrument of the former is freedom; of the latter servitude.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Their starting-point is different, and their courses are not the same;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet each of them seems to be marked out by the will of Heaven to sway
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the destinies of half the globe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote r: Russia is the country in the Old World in which population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases most rapidly in proportion.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: DEMOCRACY IN AMERICA
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: By Alexis De Tocqueville
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Translated by Henry Reeve
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Book Two: Influence Of Democracy On Progress Of Opinion In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: De Tocqueville's Preface To The Second Part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans live in a democratic state of society, which has naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suggested to them certain laws and a certain political character. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same state of society has, moreover, engendered amongst them a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of feelings and opinions which were unknown amongst the elder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic communities of Europe: it has destroyed or modified all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relations which before existed, and established others of a novel kind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The--aspect of civil society has been no less affected by these changes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than that of the political world. The former subject has been treated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of in the work on the Democracy of America, which I published five years
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ago; to examine the latter is the object of the present book; but these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two parts complete each other, and form one and the same work.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I must at once warn the reader against an error which would be extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudicial to me. When he finds that I attribute so many different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences to the principle of equality, he may thence infer that I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider that principle to be the sole cause of all that takes place in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present age: but this would be to impute to me a very narrow view. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of opinions, feelings, and propensities are now in existence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which owe their origin to circumstances unconnected with or even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary to the principle of equality. Thus if I were to select the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States as an example, I could easily prove that the nature of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, the origin of its inhabitants, the religion of its founders,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their acquired knowledge, and their former habits, have exercised, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still exercise, independently of democracy, a vast influence upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thoughts and feelings of that people. Different causes, but no less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinct from the circumstance of the equality of conditions, might be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traced in Europe, and would explain a great portion of the occurrences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taking place amongst us.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I acknowledge the existence of all these different causes, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power, but my subject does not lead me to treat of them. I have not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertaken to unfold the reason of all our inclinations and all our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions: my only object is to show in what respects the principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality has modified both the former and the latter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Some readers may perhaps be astonished that--firmly persuaded as I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am that the democratic revolution which we are witnessing is an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible fact against which it would be neither desirable nor wise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to struggle--I should often have had occasion in this book to address
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language of such severity to those democratic communities which this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution has brought into being. My answer is simply, that it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because I am not an adversary of democracy, that I have sought to speak
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democracy in all sincerity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men will not accept truth at the hands of their enemies, and truth is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seldom offered to them by their friends: for this reason I have spoken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. I was persuaded that many would take upon themselves to announce the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: new blessings which the principle of equality promises to mankind, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that few would dare to point out from afar the dangers with which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it threatens them. To those perils therefore I have turned my chief
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention, and believing that I had discovered them clearly, I have not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had the cowardice to leave them untold.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I trust that my readers will find in this Second Part that impartiality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which seems to have been remarked in the former work. Placed as I am in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the midst of the conflicting opinions between which we are divided,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have endeavored to suppress within me for a time the favorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sympathies or the adverse emotions with which each of them inspires
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me. If those who read this book can find a single sentence intended to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flatter any of the great parties which have agitated my country, or any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those petty factions which now harass and weaken it, let such readers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raise their voices to accuse me.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The subject I have sought to embrace is immense, for it includes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater part of the feelings and opinions to which the new state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society has given birth. Such a subject is doubtless above my strength,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in treating it I have not succeeded in satisfying myself. But, if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have not been able to reach the goal which I had in view, my readers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will at least do me the justice to acknowledge that I have conceived and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: followed up my undertaking in a spirit not unworthy of success.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A. De T.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: March, 1840
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section I: Influence of Democracy on the Action of Intellect in The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter I: Philosophical Method Among the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that in no country in the civilized world is less attention
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: paid to philosophy than in the United States. The Americans have no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophical school of their own; and they care but little for all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the schools into which Europe is divided, the very names of which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scarcely known to them. Nevertheless it is easy to perceive that almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the inhabitants of the United States conduct their understanding in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same manner, and govern it by the same rules; that is to say,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that without ever having taken the trouble to define the rules of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophical method, they are in possession of one, common to the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. To evade the bondage of system and habit, of family maxims,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class opinions, and, in some degree, of national prejudices; to accept
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tradition only as a means of information, and existing facts only as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lesson used in doing otherwise, and doing better; to seek the reason
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things for one's self, and in one's self alone; to tend to results
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without being bound to means, and to aim at the substance through the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form;--such are the principal characteristics of what I shall call the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophical method of the Americans. But if I go further, and if I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seek amongst these characteristics that which predominates over and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: includes almost all the rest, I discover that in most of the operations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the mind, each American appeals to the individual exercise of his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understanding alone. America is therefore one of the countries in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world where philosophy is least studied, and where the precepts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Descartes are best applied. Nor is this surprising. The Americans do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: read the works of Descartes, because their social condition deters them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from speculative studies; but they follow his maxims because this very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social condition naturally disposes their understanding to adopt them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the midst of the continual movement which agitates a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, the tie which unites one generation to another is relaxed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or broken; every man readily loses the trace of the ideas of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forefathers or takes no care about them. Nor can men living in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of society derive their belief from the opinions of the class to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they belong, for, so to speak, there are no longer any classes, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those which still exist are composed of such mobile elements, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their body can never exercise a real control over its members. As to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence which the intelligence of one man has on that of another, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must necessarily be very limited in a country where the citizens, placed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the footing of a general similitude, are all closely seen by each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other; and where, as no signs of incontestable greatness or superiority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are perceived in any one of them, they are constantly brought back to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own reason as the most obvious and proximate source of truth. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not only confidence in this or that man which is then destroyed, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the taste for trusting the ipse dixit of any man whatsoever. Everyone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shuts himself up in his own breast, and affects from that point to judge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The practice which obtains amongst the Americans of fixing the standard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their judgment in themselves alone, leads them to other habits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind. As they perceive that they succeed in resolving without assistance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the little difficulties which their practical life presents, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily conclude that everything in the world may be explained, and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing in it transcends the limits of the understanding. Thus they fall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to denying what they cannot comprehend; which leaves them but little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faith for whatever is extraordinary, and an almost insurmountable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distaste for whatever is supernatural. As it is on their own testimony
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they are accustomed to rely, they like to discern the object which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engages their attention with extreme clearness; they therefore strip off
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as much as possible all that covers it, they rid themselves of whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separates them from it, they remove whatever conceals it from sight,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to view it more closely and in the broad light of day. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disposition of the mind soon leads them to contemn forms, which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regard as useless and inconvenient veils placed between them and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: truth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans then have not required to extract their philosophical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: method from books; they have found it in themselves. The same thing may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be remarked in what has taken place in Europe. This same method has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only been established and made popular in Europe in proportion as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of society has become more equal, and men have grown more like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other. Let us consider for a moment the connection of the periods
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in which this change may be traced. In the sixteenth century the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Reformers subjected some of the dogmas of the ancient faith to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scrutiny of private judgment; but they still withheld from it the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judgment of all the rest. In the seventeenth century, Bacon in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural sciences, and Descartes in the study of philosophy in the strict
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sense of the term, abolished recognized formulas, destroyed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empire of tradition, and overthrew the authority of the schools. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophers of the eighteenth century, generalizing at length the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle, undertook to submit to the private judgment of each man all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the objects of his belief.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Who does not perceive that Luther, Descartes, and Voltaire employed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same method, and that they differed only in the greater or less use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they professed should be made of it? Why did the Reformers confine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves so closely within the circle of religious ideas? Why did
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Descartes, choosing only to apply his method to certain matters, though
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he had made it fit to be applied to all, declare that men might judge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for themselves in matters philosophical but not in matters political?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: How happened it that in the eighteenth century those general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applications were all at once drawn from this same method, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Descartes and his predecessors had either not perceived or had rejected?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To what, lastly, is the fact to be attributed, that at this period
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the method we are speaking of suddenly emerged from the schools, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penetrate into society and become the common standard of intelligence;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that, after it had become popular among the French, it has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ostensibly adopted or secretly followed by all the nations of Europe?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The philosophical method here designated may have been engendered in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sixteenth century--it may have been more accurately defined and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extensively applied in the seventeenth; but neither in the one nor in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other could it be commonly adopted. Political laws, the condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society, and the habits of mind which are derived from these causes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were as yet opposed to it. It was discovered at a time when men were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beginning to equalize and assimilate their conditions. It could only be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally followed in ages when those conditions had at length become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nearly equal, and men nearly alike.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The philosophical method of the eighteenth century is then not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French, but it is democratic; and this explains why it was so readily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admitted throughout Europe, where it has contributed so powerfully to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change the face of society. It is not because the French have changed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their former opinions, and altered their former manners, that they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convulsed the world; but because they were the first to generalize and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bring to light a philosophical method, by the assistance of which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became easy to attack all that was old, and to open a path to all that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was new.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If it be asked why, at the present day, this same method is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rigorously followed and more frequently applied by the French than by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans, although the principle of equality be no less complete,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of more ancient date, amongst the latter people, the fact may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attributed to two circumstances, which it is essential to have clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood in the first instance. It must never be forgotten that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion gave birth to Anglo-American society. In the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion is therefore commingled with all the habits of the nation and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the feelings of patriotism; whence it derives a peculiar force.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To this powerful reason another of no less intensity may be added: in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American religion has, as it were, laid down its own limits. Religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions have remained wholly distinct from political institutions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so that former laws have been easily changed whilst former belief has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remained unshaken. Christianity has therefore retained a strong hold on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the public mind in America; and, I would more particularly remark, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its sway is not only that of a philosophical doctrine which has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adopted upon inquiry, but of a religion which is believed without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discussion. In the United States Christian sects are infinitely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diversified and perpetually modified; but Christianity itself is a fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so irresistibly established, that no one undertakes either to attack or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to defend it. The Americans, having admitted the principal doctrines of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Christian religion without inquiry, are obliged to accept in like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner a great number of moral truths originating in it and connected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with it. Hence the activity of individual analysis is restrained within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: narrow limits, and many of the most important of human opinions are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removed from the range of its influence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The second circumstance to which I have alluded is the following: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social condition and the constitution of the Americans are democratic,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they have not had a democratic revolution. They arrived upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soil they occupy in nearly the condition in which we see them at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present day; and this is of very considerable importance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are no revolutions which do not shake existing belief, enervate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority, and throw doubts over commonly received ideas. The effect of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all revolutions is therefore, more or less, to surrender men to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own guidance, and to open to the mind of every man a void and almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unlimited range of speculation. When equality of conditions succeeds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a protracted conflict between the different classes of which the elder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society was composed, envy, hatred, and uncharitableness, pride, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exaggerated self-confidence are apt to seize upon the human heart,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and plant their sway there for a time. This, independently of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself, tends powerfully to divide men--to lead them to mistrust the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judgment of others, and to seek the light of truth nowhere but in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own understandings. Everyone then attempts to be his own sufficient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guide, and makes it his boast to form his own opinions on all subjects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men are no longer bound together by ideas, but by interests; and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would seem as if human opinions were reduced to a sort of intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dust, scattered on every side, unable to collect, unable to cohere.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, that independence of mind which equality supposes to exist, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never so great, nor ever appears so excessive, as at the time when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality is beginning to establish itself, and in the course of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: painful labor by which it is established. That sort of intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom which equality may give ought, therefore, to be very carefully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguished from the anarchy which revolution brings. Each of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two things must be severally considered, in order not to conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exaggerated hopes or fears of the future.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe that the men who will live under the new forms of society will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make frequent use of their private judgment; but I am far from thinking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they will often abuse it. This is attributable to a cause of more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general application to all democratic countries, and which, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long run, must needs restrain in them the independence of individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speculation within fixed, and sometimes narrow, limits. I shall proceed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to point out this cause in the next chapter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter II: Of The Principal Source Of Belief Among Democratic Nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At different periods dogmatical belief is more or less abundant. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arises in different ways, and it may change its object or its form; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under no circumstances will dogmatical belief cease to exist, or, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other words, men will never cease to entertain some implicit opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without trying them by actual discussion. If everyone undertook to form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his own opinions and to seek for truth by isolated paths struck out by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself alone, it is not to be supposed that any considerable number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men would ever unite in any common belief. But obviously without such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common belief no society can prosper--say rather no society can subsist;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for without ideas held in common, there is no common action, and without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common action, there may still be men, but there is no social body. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order that society should exist, and, a fortiori, that a society should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosper, it is required that all the minds of the citizens should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rallied and held together by certain predominant ideas; and this cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the case, unless each of them sometimes draws his opinions from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common source, and consents to accept certain matters of belief at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands of the community.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I now consider man in his isolated capacity, I find that dogmatical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belief is not less indispensable to him in order to live alone, than it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to enable him to co-operate with his fellow-creatures. If man were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forced to demonstrate to himself all the truths of which he makes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: daily use, his task would never end. He would exhaust his strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in preparatory exercises, without advancing beyond them. As, from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shortness of his life, he has not the time, nor, from the limits of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligence, the capacity, to accomplish this, he is reduced to take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon trust a number of facts and opinions which he has not had either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the time or the power to verify himself, but which men of greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ability have sought out, or which the world adopts. On this groundwork
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he raises for himself the structure of his own thoughts; nor is he led
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to proceed in this manner by choice so much as he is constrained by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inflexible law of his condition. There is no philosopher of such great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parts in the world, but that he believes a million of things on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faith of other people, and supposes a great many more truths than he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demonstrates. This is not only necessary but desirable. A man who should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertake to inquire into everything for himself, could devote to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing but little time and attention. His task would keep his mind in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetual unrest, which would prevent him from penetrating to the depth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of any truth, or of grappling his mind indissolubly to any conviction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: His intellect would be at once independent and powerless. He must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore make his choice from amongst the various objects of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belief, and he must adopt many opinions without discussion, in order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to search the better into that smaller number which he sets apart for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: investigation. It is true that whoever receives an opinion on the word
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of another, does so far enslave his mind; but it is a salutary servitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which allows him to make a good use of freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A principle of authority must then always occur, under all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances, in some part or other of the moral and intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world. Its place is variable, but a place it necessarily has. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence of individual minds may be greater, or it may be less:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unbounded it cannot be. Thus the question is, not to know whether any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellectual authority exists in the ages of democracy, but simply where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it resides and by what standard it is to be measured.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown in the preceding chapter how the equality of conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leads men to entertain a sort of instinctive incredulity of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supernatural, and a very lofty and often exaggerated opinion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human understanding. The men who live at a period of social equality are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not therefore easily led to place that intellectual authority to which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they bow either beyond or above humanity. They commonly seek for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sources of truth in themselves, or in those who are like themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This would be enough to prove that at such periods no new religion could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be established, and that all schemes for such a purpose would be not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only impious but absurd and irrational. It may be foreseen that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people will not easily give credence to divine missions; that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will turn modern prophets to a ready jest; and they that will seek
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to discover the chief arbiter of their belief within, and not beyond,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the limits of their kind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the ranks of society are unequal, and men unlike each other in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition, there are some individuals invested with all the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior intelligence, learning, and enlightenment, whilst the multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is sunk in ignorance and prejudice. Men living at these aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: periods are therefore naturally induced to shape their opinions by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior standard of a person or a class of persons, whilst they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: averse to recognize the infallibility of the mass of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The contrary takes place in ages of equality. The nearer the citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are drawn to the common level of an equal and similar condition, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less prone does each man become to place implicit faith in a certain man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or a certain class of men. But his readiness to believe the multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases, and opinion is more than ever mistress of the world. Not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is common opinion the only guide which private judgment retains amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic people, but amongst such a people it possesses a power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infinitely beyond what it has elsewhere. At periods of equality men have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no faith in one another, by reason of their common resemblance; but this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very resemblance gives them almost unbounded confidence in the judgment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the public; for it would not seem probable, as they are all endowed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with equal means of judging, but that the greater truth should go with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the greater number.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the inhabitant of a democratic country compares himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individually with all those about him, he feels with pride that he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the equal of any one of them; but when he comes to survey the totality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his fellows, and to place himself in contrast to so huge a body,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he is instantly overwhelmed by the sense of his own insignificance and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weakness. The same equality which renders him independent of each of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-citizens taken severally, exposes him alone and unprotected to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the influence of the greater number. The public has therefore among a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people a singular power, of which aristocratic nations could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never so much as conceive an idea; for it does not persuade to certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions, but it enforces them, and infuses them into the faculties by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sort of enormous pressure of the minds of all upon the reason of each.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the majority undertakes to supply a multitude of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ready-made opinions for the use of individuals, who are thus relieved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the necessity of forming opinions of their own. Everybody there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adopts great numbers of theories, on philosophy, morals, and politics,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without inquiry, upon public trust; and if we look to it very narrowly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it will be perceived that religion herself holds her sway there, much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less as a doctrine of revelation than as a commonly received opinion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The fact that the political laws of the Americans are such that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority rules the community with sovereign sway, materially increases
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power which that majority naturally exercises over the mind. For
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing is more customary in man than to recognize superior wisdom in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the person of his oppressor. This political omnipotence of the majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States doubtless augments the influence which public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion would obtain without it over the mind of each member of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community; but the foundations of that influence do not rest upon it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They must be sought for in the principle of equality itself, not in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more or less popular institutions which men living under that condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may give themselves. The intellectual dominion of the greater number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would probably be less absolute amongst a democratic people governed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a king than in the sphere of a pure democracy, but it will always be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely absolute; and by whatever political laws men are governed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ages of equality, it may be foreseen that faith in public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion will become a species of religion there, and the majority its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ministering prophet.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus intellectual authority will be different, but it will not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diminished; and far from thinking that it will disappear, I augur that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may readily acquire too much preponderance, and confine the action
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of private judgment within narrower limits than are suited either to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the greatness or the happiness of the human race. In the principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality I very clearly discern two tendencies; the one leading the mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of every man to untried thoughts, the other inclined to prohibit him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from thinking at all. And I perceive how, under the dominion of certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws, democracy would extinguish that liberty of the mind to which a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic social condition is favorable; so that, after having broken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the bondage once imposed on it by ranks or by men, the human mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be closely fettered to the general will of the greatest number.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the absolute power of the majority were to be substituted by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations, for all the different powers which checked or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retarded overmuch the energy of individual minds, the evil would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only have changed its symptoms. Men would not have found the means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent life; they would simply have invented (no easy task) a new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dress for servitude. There is--and I cannot repeat it too often--there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is in this matter for profound reflection for those who look on freedom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a holy thing, and who hate not only the despot, but despotism. For
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: myself, when I feel the hand of power lie heavy on my brow, I care but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little to know who oppresses me; and I am not the more disposed to pass
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beneath the yoke, because it is held out to me by the arms of a million
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter III: Why The Americans Display More Readiness And More Taste For
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General Ideas Than Their Forefathers, The English.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Deity does not regard the human race collectively. He surveys at one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glance and severally all the beings of whom mankind is composed, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discerns in each man the resemblances which assimilate him to all his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellows, and the differences which distinguish him from them. God,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, stands in no need of general ideas; that is to say, he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never sensible of the necessity of collecting a considerable number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of analogous objects under the same form for greater convenience in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thinking. Such is, however, not the case with man. If the human mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were to attempt to examine and pass a judgment on all the individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases before it, the immensity of detail would soon lead it astray
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and bewilder its discernment: in this strait, man has recourse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an imperfect but necessary expedient, which at once assists and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demonstrates his weakness. Having superficially considered a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of objects, and remarked their resemblance, he assigns to them a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common name, sets them apart, and proceeds onwards.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General ideas are no proof of the strength, but rather of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insufficiency of the human intellect; for there are in nature no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beings exactly alike, no things precisely identical, nor any rules
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indiscriminately and alike applicable to several objects at once. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chief merit of general ideas is, that they enable the human mind to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pass a rapid judgment on a great many objects at once; but, on the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand, the notions they convey are never otherwise than incomplete, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they always cause the mind to lose as much in accuracy as it gains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in comprehensiveness. As social bodies advance in civilization, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquire the knowledge of new facts, and they daily lay hold almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unconsciously of some particular truths. The more truths of this kind a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man apprehends, the more general ideas is he naturally led to conceive.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A multitude of particular facts cannot be seen separately, without at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: last discovering the common tie which connects them. Several individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lead to the perception of the species; several species to that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genus. Hence the habit and the taste for general ideas will always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be greatest amongst a people of ancient cultivation and extensive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But there are other reasons which impel men to generalize their ideas,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or which restrain them from it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans are much more addicted to the use of general ideas than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the English, and entertain a much greater relish for them: this appears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very singular at first sight, when it is remembered that the two nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have the same origin, that they lived for centuries under the same laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that they still incessantly interchange their opinions and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners. This contrast becomes much more striking still, if we fix our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eyes on our own part of the world, and compare together the two most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlightened nations which inhabit it. It would seem as if the mind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the English could only tear itself reluctantly and painfully away from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the observation of particular facts, to rise from them to their causes;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that it only generalizes in spite of itself. Amongst the French, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contrary, the taste for general ideas would seem to have grown to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so ardent a passion, that it must be satisfied on every occasion. I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: informed, every morning when I wake, that some general and eternal law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has just been discovered, which I never heard mentioned before. There is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not a mediocre scribbler who does not try his hand at discovering truths
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applicable to a great kingdom, and who is very ill pleased with himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if he does not succeed in compressing the human race into the compass
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an article. So great a dissimilarity between two very enlightened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations surprises me. If I again turn my attention to England, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observe the events which have occurred there in the last half-century,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think I may affirm that a taste for general ideas increases in that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country in proportion as its ancient constitution is weakened.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The state of civilization is therefore insufficient by itself to explain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what suggests to the human mind the love of general ideas, or diverts it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from them. When the conditions of men are very unequal, and inequality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself is the permanent state of society, individual men gradually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become so dissimilar that each class assumes the aspect of a distinct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: race: only one of these classes is ever in view at the same instant; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: losing sight of that general tie which binds them all within the vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bosom of mankind, the observation invariably rests not on man, but on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain men. Those who live in this aristocratic state of society never,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore, conceive very general ideas respecting themselves, and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is enough to imbue them with an habitual distrust of such ideas, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an instinctive aversion of them. He, on the contrary, who inhabits a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic country, sees around him, one very hand, men differing but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little from each other; he cannot turn his mind to any one portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind, without expanding and dilating his thought till it embrace the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole. All the truths which are applicable to himself, appear to him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equally and similarly applicable to each of his fellow-citizens and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-men. Having contracted the habit of generalizing his ideas in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the study which engages him most, and interests him more than others,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he transfers the same habit to all his pursuits; and thus it is that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the craving to discover general laws in everything, to include a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of objects under the same formula, and to explain a mass of facts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a single cause, becomes an ardent, and sometimes an undiscerning,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passion in the human mind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing shows the truth of this proposition more clearly than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions of the ancients respecting their slaves. The most profound and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capacious minds of Rome and Greece were never able to reach the idea, at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once so general and so simple, of the common likeness of men, and of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common birthright of each to freedom: they strove to prove that slavery
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was in the order of nature, and that it would always exist. Nay, more,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything shows that those of the ancients who had passed from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servile to the free condition, many of whom have left us excellent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: writings, did themselves regard servitude in no other light.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the great writers of antiquity belonged to the aristocracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of masters, or at least they saw that aristocracy established and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncontested before their eyes. Their mind, after it had expanded itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in several directions, was barred from further progress in this one; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the advent of Jesus Christ upon earth was required to teach that all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the human race are by nature equal and alike.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the ages of equality all men are independent of each other, isolated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and weak. The movements of the multitude are not permanently guided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the will of any individuals; at such times humanity seems always to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advance of itself. In order, therefore, to explain what is passing in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world, man is driven to seek for some great causes, which, acting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the same manner on all our fellow-creatures, thus impel them all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: involuntarily to pursue the same track. This again naturally leads the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human mind to conceive general ideas, and superinduces a taste for them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already shown in what way the equality of conditions leads every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man to investigate truths for himself. It may readily be perceived that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a method of this kind must insensibly beget a tendency to general ideas
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the human mind. When I repudiate the traditions of rank, profession,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and birth; when I escape from the authority of example, to seek out, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the single effort of my reason, the path to be followed, I am inclined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to derive the motives of my opinions from human nature itself; which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leads me necessarily, and almost unconsciously, to adopt a great number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of very general notions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All that I have here said explains the reasons for which the English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: display much less readiness and taste or the generalization of ideas
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than their American progeny, and still less again than their French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighbors; and likewise the reason for which the English of the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day display more of these qualities than their forefathers did. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English have long been a very enlightened and a very aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation; their enlightened condition urged them constantly to generalize,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their aristocratic habits confined them to particularize. Hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arose that philosophy, at once bold and timid, broad and narrow,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has hitherto prevailed in England, and which still obstructs and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stagnates in so many minds in that country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Independently of the causes I have pointed out in what goes before,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others may be discerned less apparent, but no less efficacious, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engender amongst almost every democratic people a taste, and frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a passion, for general ideas. An accurate distinction must be taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between ideas of this kind. Some are the result of slow, minute, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conscientious labor of the mind, and these extend the sphere of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge; others spring up at once from the first rapid exercise of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wits, and beget none but very superficial and very uncertain notions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men who live in ages of equality have a great deal of curiosity and very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little leisure; their life is so practical, so confused, so excited, so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: active, that but little time remains to them for thought. Such men are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prone to general ideas because they spare them the trouble of studying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particulars; they contain, if I may so speak, a great deal in a little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compass, and give, in a little time, a great return. If then, upon a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brief and inattentive investigation, a common relation is thought to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: detected between certain obtects, inquiry is not pushed any further; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without examining in detail how far these different objects differ or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agree, they are hastily arranged under one formulary, in order to pass
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to another subject.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: One of the distinguishing characteristics of a democratic period is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taste all men have at such ties for easy success and present enjoyment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This occurs in the pursuits of the intellect as well as in all others.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Most of those who live at a time of equality are full of an ambition at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once aspiring and relaxed: they would fain succeed brilliantly and at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once, but they would be dispensed from great efforts to obtain success.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These conflicting tendencies lead straight to the research of general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideas, by aid of which they flatter themselves that they can figure very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importantly at a small expense, and draw the attention of the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with very little trouble. And I know not whether they be wrong in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thinking thus. For their readers are as much averse to investigating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anything to the bottom as they can be themselves; and what is generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sought in the productions of the mind is easy pleasure and information
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without labor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If aristocratic nations do not make sufficient use of general ideas,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and frequently treat them with inconsiderate disdain, it is true, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other hand, that a democratic people is ever ready to carry ideas of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this kind to excess, and to espouse the with injudicious warmth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IV: Why The Americans Have Never Been So Eager As The French For
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General Ideas In Political Matters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I observed in the last chapter, that the Americans show a less decided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taste for general ideas than the French; this is more especially true in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political matters. Although the Americans infuse into their legislation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infinitely more general ideas than the English, and although they pay
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much more attention than the latter people to the adjustment of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practice of affairs to theory, no political bodies in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States have ever shown so warm an attachment to general ideas as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constituent Assembly and the Convention in France. At no time has the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American people laid hold on ideas of this kind with the passionate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: energy of the French people in the eighteenth century, or displayed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same blind confidence in the value and absolute truth of any theory.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This difference between the Americans and the French originates in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several causes, but principally in the following one. The Americans form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic people, which has always itself directed public affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The French are a democratic people, who, for a long time, could only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speculate on the best manner of conducting them. The social condition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France led that people to conceive very general ideas on the subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of government, whilst its political constitution prevented it from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: correcting those ideas by experiment, and from gradually detecting their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insufficiency; whereas in America the two things constantly balance and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: correct each other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may seem, at first sight, that this is very much opposed to what I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have said before, that democratic nations derive their love of theory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the excitement of their active life. A more attentive examination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will show that there is nothing contradictory in the proposition. Men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: living in democratic countries eagerly lay hold of general ideas because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have but little leisure, and because these ideas spare them the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trouble of studying particulars. This is true; but it is only to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood to apply to those matters which are not the necessary and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitual subjects of their thoughts. Mercantile men will take up very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eagerly, and without any very close scrutiny, all the general ideas on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophy, politics, science, or the arts, which may be presented to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; but for such as relate to commerce, they will not receive them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without inquiry, or adopt them without reserve. The same thing applies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to statesmen with regard to general ideas in politics. If, then, there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be a subject upon which a democratic people is peculiarly liable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandon itself, blindly and extravagantly, to general ideas, the best
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corrective that can be used will be to make that subject a part of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the daily practical occupation of that people. The people will then be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compelled to enter upon its details, and the details will teach them the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weak points of the theory. This remedy may frequently be a painful one,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but its effect is certain.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus it happens, that the democratic institutions which compel every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen to take a practical part in the government, moderate that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excessive taste for general theories in politics which the principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality suggests.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter V: Of The Manner In Which Religion In The United States Avails
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Itself Of Democratic Tendencies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have laid it down in a preceding chapter that men cannot do without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dogmatical belief; and even that it is very much to be desired that such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belief should exist amongst them. I now add, that of all the kinds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dogmatical belief the most desirable appears to me to be dogmatical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belief in matters of religion; and this is a very clear inference, even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from no higher consideration than the interests of this world. There is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardly any human action, however particular a character be assigned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to it, which does not originate in some very general idea men have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceived of the Deity, of his relation to mankind, of the nature of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own souls, and of their duties to their fellow-creatures. Nor can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anything prevent these ideas from being the common spring from which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything else emanates. Men are therefore immeasurably interested in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquiring fixed ideas of God, of the soul, and of their common duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to their Creator and to their fellow-men; for doubt on these first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles would abandon all their actions to the impulse of chance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and would condemn them to live, to a certain extent, powerless and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undisciplined.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is then the subject on which it is most important for each of us to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertain fixed ideas; and unhappily it is also the subject on which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is most difficult for each of us, left to himself, to settle his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions by the sole force of his reason. None but minds singularly free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the ordinary anxieties of life--minds at once penetrating, subtle,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and trained by thinking--can even with the assistance of much time and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: care, sound the depth of these most necessary truths. And, indeed, we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: see that these philosophers are themselves almost always enshrouded in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncertainties; that at every step the natural light which illuminates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their path grows dimmer and less secure; and that, in spite of all their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efforts, they have as yet only discovered a small number of conflicting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions, on which the mind of man has been tossed about for thousands of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years, without either laying a firmer grasp on truth, or finding novelty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even in its errors. Studies of this nature are far above the average
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capacity of men; and even if the majority of mankind were capable of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such pursuits, it is evident that leisure to cultivate them would still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be wanting. Fixed ideas of God and human nature are indispensable to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: daily practice of men's lives; but the practice of their lives prevents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them from acquiring such ideas.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The difficulty appears to me to be without a parallel. Amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sciences there are some which are useful to the mass of mankind, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are within its reach; others can only be approached by the few,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and are not cultivated by the many, who require nothing beyond their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more remote applications: but the daily practice of the science I speak
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of is indispensable to all, although the study of it is inaccessible to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the far greater number.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General ideas respecting God and human nature are therefore the ideas
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: above all others which it is most suitable to withdraw from the habitual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action of private judgment, and in which there is most to gain and least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to lose by recognizing a principle of authority. The first object and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one of the principal advantages of religions, is to furnish to each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these fundamental questions a solution which is at once clear, precise,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligible to the mass of mankind, and lasting. There are religions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are very false and very absurd; but it may be affirmed, that any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion which remains within the circle I have just traced, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aspiring to go beyond it (as many religions have attempted to do, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the purpose of enclosing on every side the free progress of the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind), imposes a salutary restraint on the intellect; and it must be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admitted that, if it do not save men in another world, such religion is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least very conducive to their happiness and their greatness in this.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is more especially true of men living in free countries. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the religion of a people is destroyed, doubt gets hold of the highest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portions of the intellect, and half paralyzes all the rest of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers. Every man accustoms himself to entertain none but confused
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and changing notions on the subjects most interesting to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-creatures and himself. His opinions are ill-defended and easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abandoned: and, despairing of ever resolving by himself the hardest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: problems of the destiny of man, he ignobly submits to think no more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about them. Such a condition cannot but enervate the soul, relax the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: springs of the will, and prepare a people for servitude. Nor does it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only happen, in such a case, that they allow their freedom to be wrested
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from them; they frequently themselves surrender it. When there is no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer any principle of authority in religion any more than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics, men are speedily frightened at the aspect of this unbounded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence. The constant agitation of all surrounding things alarms
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and exhausts them. As everything is at sea in the sphere of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellect, they determine at least that the mechanism of society should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be firm and fixed; and as they cannot resume their ancient belief, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assume a master.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: For my own part, I doubt whether man can ever support at the same time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complete religious independence and entire public freedom. And I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclined to think, that if faith be wanting in him, he must serve; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if he be free, he must believe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Perhaps, however, this great utility of religions is still more obvious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst nations where equality of conditions prevails than amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others. It must be acknowledged that equality, which brings great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: benefits into the world, nevertheless suggests to men (as will be shown
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereafter) some very dangerous propensities. It tends to isolate them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from each other, to concentrate every man's attention upon himself; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it lays open the soul to an inordinate love of material gratification.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greatest advantage of religion is to inspire diametrically contrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles. There is no religion which does not place the object of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man's desires above and beyond the treasures of earth, and which does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not naturally raise his soul to regions far above those of the senses.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nor is there any which does not impose on man some sort of duties to
