author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his kind, and thus draws him at times from the contemplation of himself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This occurs in religions the most false and dangerous. Religious nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are therefore naturally strong on the very point on which democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations are weak; which shows of what importance it is for men to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preserve their religion as their conditions become more equal.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have neither the right nor the intention of examining the supernatural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means which God employs to infuse religious belief into the heart of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man. I am at this moment considering religions in a purely human point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of view: my object is to inquire by what means they may most easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retain their sway in the democratic ages upon which we are entering. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has been shown that, at times of general cultivation and equality,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the human mind does not consent to adopt dogmatical opinions without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reluctance, and feels their necessity acutely in spiritual matters only.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This proves, in the first place, that at such times religions ought,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more cautiously than at any other, to confine themselves within their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own precincts; for in seeking to extend their power beyond religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: matters, they incur a risk of not being believed at all. The circle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within which they seek to bound the human intellect ought therefore to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be carefully traced, and beyond its verge the mind should be left in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entire freedom to its own guidance. Mahommed professed to derive from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Heaven, and he has inserted in the Koran, not only a body of religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doctrines, but political maxims, civil and criminal laws, and theories
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of science. The gospel, on the contrary, only speaks of the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relations of men to God and to each other--beyond which it inculcates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and imposes no point of faith. This alone, besides a thousand other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reasons, would suffice to prove that the former of these religions will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never long predominate in a cultivated and democratic age, whilst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter is destined to retain its sway at these as at all other periods.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in continuation of this branch of the subject, I find that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order for religions to maintain their authority, humanly speaking, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages, they must not only confine themselves strictly within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the circle of spiritual matters: their power also depends very much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the nature of the belief they inculcate, on the external forms they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assume, and on the obligations they impose. The preceding observation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that equality leads men to very general and very extensive notions, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principally to be understood as applied to the question of religion. Men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: living in a similar and equal condition in the world readily conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the idea of the one God, governing every man by the same laws, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: granting to every man future happiness on the same conditions. The idea
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the unity of mankind constantly leads them back to the idea of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unity of the Creator; whilst, on the contrary, in a state of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where men are broken up into very unequal ranks, they are apt to devise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as many deities as there are nations, castes, classes, or families, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to trace a thousand private roads to heaven.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It cannot be denied that Christianity itself has felt, to a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent, the influence which social and political conditions exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on religious opinions. At the epoch at which the Christian religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeared upon earth, Providence, by whom the world was doubtless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prepared for its coming, had gathered a large portion of the human race,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like an immense flock, under the sceptre of the Caesars. The men of whom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this multitude was composed were distinguished by numerous differences;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they had thus much in common, that they all obeyed the same laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that every subject was so weak and insignificant in relation to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperial potentate, that all appeared equal when their condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was contrasted with his. This novel and peculiar state of mankind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessarily predisposed men to listen to the general truths which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christianity teaches, and may serve to explain the facility and rapidity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with which they then penetrated into the human mind. The counterpart of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this state of things was exhibited after the destruction of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empire. The Roman world being then as it were shattered into a thousand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fragments, each nation resumed its pristine individuality. An infinite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scale of ranks very soon grew up in the bosom of these nations; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different races were more sharply defined, and each nation was divided
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by castes into several peoples. In the midst of this common effort,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which seemed to be urging human society to the greatest conceivable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amount of voluntary subdivision, Christianity did not lose sight of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the leading general ideas which it had brought into the world. But it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeared, nevertheless, to lend itself, as much as was possible, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those new tendencies to which the fractional distribution of mankind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had given birth. Men continued to worship an only God, the Creator and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Preserver of all things; but every people, every city, and, so to speak,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every man, thought to obtain some distinct privilege, and win the favor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an especial patron at the foot of the Throne of Grace. Unable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to subdivide the Deity, they multiplied and improperly enhanced the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance of the divine agents. The homage due to saints and angels
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became an almost idolatrous worship amongst the majority of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christian world; and apprehensions might be entertained for a moment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lest the religion of Christ should retrograde towards the superstitions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it had subdued. It seems evident, that the more the barriers are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removed which separate nation from nation amongst mankind, and citizen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from citizen amongst a people, the stronger is the bent of the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind, as if by its own impulse, towards the idea of an only and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all-powerful Being, dispensing equal laws in the same manner to every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man. In democratic ages, then, it is more particularly important not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to allow the homage paid to secondary agents to be confounded with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: worship due to the Creator alone.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Another truth is no less clear--that religions ought to assume fewer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: external observances in democratic periods than at any others. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speaking of philosophical method among the Americans, I have shown that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing is more repugnant to the human mind in an age of equality than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the idea of subjection to forms. Men living at such times are impatient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of figures; to their eyes symbols appear to be the puerile artifice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is used to conceal or to set off truths, which should more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally be bared to the light of open day: they are unmoved by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceremonial observances, and they are predisposed to attach a secondary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance to the details of public worship. Those whose care it is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulate the external forms of religion in a democratic age should pay
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a close attention to these natural propensities of the human mind, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order not unnecessarily to run counter to them. I firmly believe in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessity of forms, which fix the human mind in the contemplation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abstract truths, and stimulate its ardor in the pursuit of them, whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they invigorate its powers of retaining them steadfastly. Nor do I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suppose that it is possible to maintain a religion without external
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observances; but, on the other hand, I am persuaded that, in the ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon which we are entering, it would be peculiarly dangerous to multiply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them beyond measure; and that they ought rather to be limited to as much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as is absolutely necessary to perpetuate the doctrine itself, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the substance of religions of which the ritual is only the form. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A religion which should become more minute, more peremptory, and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surcharged with small observances at a time in which men are becoming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more equal, would soon find itself reduced to a band of fanatical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: zealots in the midst of an infidel people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: In all religions there are some ceremonies which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inherent in the substance of the faith itself, and in these nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should, on any account, be changed. This is especially the case with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Roman Catholicism, in which the doctrine and the form are frequently so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: closely united as to form one point of belief.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I anticipate the objection, that as all religions have general and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eternal truths for their object, they cannot thus shape themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the shifting spirit of every age without forfeiting their claim
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to certainty in the eyes of mankind. To this I reply again, that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal opinions which constitute belief, and which theologians
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: call articles of faith, must be very carefully distinguished from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accessories connected with them. Religions are obliged to hold fast to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the former, whatever be the peculiar spirit of the age; but they should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take good care not to bind themselves in the same manner to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter at a time when everything is in transition, and when the mind,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustomed to the moving pageant of human affairs, reluctantly endures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the attempt to fix it to any given point. The fixity of external and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secondary things can only afford a chance of duration when civil society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is itself fixed; under any other circumstances I hold it to be perilous.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We shall have occasion to see that, of all the passions which originate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in, or are fostered by, equality, there is one which it renders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiarly intense, and which it infuses at the same time into the heart
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of every man: I mean the love of well-being. The taste for well-being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the prominent and indelible feature of democratic ages. It may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believed that a religion which should undertake to destroy so deep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seated a passion, would meet its own destruction thence in the end; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if it attempted to wean men entirely from the contemplation of the good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things of this world, in order to devote their faculties exclusively to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the thought of another, it may be foreseen that the soul would at length
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: escape from its grasp, to plunge into the exclusive enjoyment of present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and material pleasures. The chief concern of religions is to purify,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to regulate, and to restrain the excessive and exclusive taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well-being which men feel at periods of equality; but they would err in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempting to control it completely or to eradicate it. They will not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeed in curing men of the love of riches: but they may still persuade
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men to enrich themselves by none but honest means.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This brings me to a final consideration, which comprises, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the others. The more the conditions of men are equalized and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assimilated to each other, the more important is it for religions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst they carefully abstain from the daily turmoil of secular affairs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not needlessly to run counter to the ideas which generally prevail, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the permanent interests which exist in the mass of the people. For as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public opinion grows to be more and more evidently the first and most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresistible of existing powers, the religious principle has no external
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: support strong enough to enable it long to resist its attacks. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not less true of a democratic people, ruled by a despot, than in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republic. In ages of equality, kings may often command obedience,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the majority always commands belief: to the majority, therefore,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deference is to be paid in whatsoever is not contrary to the faith.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I showed in my former volumes how the American clergy stand aloof from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secular affairs. This is the most obvious, but it is not the only,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: example of their self-restraint. In America religion is a distinct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere, in which the priest is sovereign, but out of which he takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: care never to go. Within its limits he is the master of the mind;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beyond them, he leaves men to themselves, and surrenders them to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence and instability which belong to their nature and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: age. I have seen no country in which Christianity is clothed with fewer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forms, figures, and observances than in the United States; or where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it presents more distinct, more simple, or more general notions to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind. Although the Christians of America are divided into a multitude of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sects, they all look upon their religion in the same light. This applies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to Roman Catholicism as well as to the other forms of belief. There
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are no Romish priests who show less taste for the minute individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observances for extraordinary or peculiar means of salvation, or who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cling more to the spirit, and less to the letter of the law, than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Roman Catholic priests of the United States. Nowhere is that doctrine of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Church, which prohibits the worship reserved to God alone from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being offered to the saints, more clearly inculcated or more generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: followed. Yet the Roman Catholics of America are very submissive and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very sincere.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Another remark is applicable to the clergy of every communion. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American ministers of the gospel do not attempt to draw or to fix all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the thoughts of man upon the life to come; they are willing to surrender
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a portion of his heart to the cares of the present; seeming to consider
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the goods of this world as important, although as secondary, objects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If they take no part themselves in productive labor, they are at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interested in its progression, and ready to applaud its results; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst they never cease to point to the other world as the great object
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the hopes and fears of the believer, they do not forbid him honestly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to court prosperity in this. Far from attempting to show that these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things are distinct and contrary to one another, they study rather to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find out on what point they are most nearly and closely connected.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the American clergy know and respect the intellectual supremacy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercised by the majority; they never sustain any but necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conflicts with it. They take no share in the altercations of parties,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they readily adopt the general opinions of their country and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: age; and they allow themselves to be borne away without opposition in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the current of feeling and opinion by which everything around them is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carried along. They endeavor to amend their contemporaries, but they do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not quit fellowship with them. Public opinion is therefore never hostile
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them; it rather supports and protects them; and their belief owes its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority at the same time to the strength which is its own, and to that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they borrow from the opinions of the majority. Thus it is that, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respecting all democratic tendencies not absolutely contrary to herself,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and by making use of several of them for her own purposes, religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sustains an advantageous struggle with that spirit of individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence which is her most dangerous antagonist.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VI: Of The Progress Of Roman Catholicism In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America is the most democratic country in the world, and it is at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same time (according to reports worthy of belief) the country in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Roman Catholic religion makes most progress. At first sight this is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surprising. Two things must here be accurately distinguished: equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclines men to wish to form their own opinions; but, on the other hand,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it imbues them with the taste and the idea of unity, simplicity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and impartiality in the power which governs society. Men living in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages are therefore very prone to shake off all religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority; but if they consent to subject themselves to any authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this kind, they choose at least that it should be single and uniform.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Religious powers not radiating from a common centre are naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repugnant to their minds; and they almost as readily conceive that there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be no religion, as that there should be several. At the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, more than in any preceding one, Roman Catholics are seen to lapse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into infidelity, and Protestants to be converted to Roman Catholicism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the Roman Catholic faith be considered within the pale of the church,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it would seem to be losing ground; without that pale, to be gaining it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nor is this circumstance difficult of explanation. The men of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: days are naturally disposed to believe; but, as soon as they have any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion, they immediately find in themselves a latent propensity which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: urges them unconsciously towards Catholicism. Many of the doctrines and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the practices of the Romish Church astonish them; but they feel a secret
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admiration for its discipline, and its great unity attracts them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If Catholicism could at length withdraw itself from the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animosities to which it has given rise, I have hardly any doubt but that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same spirit of the age, which appears to be so opposed to it, would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become so favorable as to admit of its great and sudden advancement.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: One of the most ordinary weaknesses of the human intellect is to seek to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reconcile contrary principles, and to purchase peace at the expense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of logic. Thus there have ever been, and will ever be, men who, after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having submitted some portion of their religious belief to the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of authority, will seek to exempt several other parts of their faith
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from its influence, and to keep their minds floating at random between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty and obedience. But I am inclined to believe that the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these thinkers will be less in democratic than in other ages; and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our posterity will tend more and more to a single division into two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parts--some relinquishing Christianity entirely, and others returning to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bosom of the Church of Rome.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VII: Of The Cause Of A Leaning To Pantheism Amongst Democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall take occasion hereafter to show under what form the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preponderating taste of a democratic people for very general ideas
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manifests itself in politics; but I would point out, at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stage of my work, its principal effect on philosophy. It cannot be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: denied that pantheism has made great progress in our age. The writings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a part of Europe bear visible marks of it: the Germans introduce it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into philosophy, and the French into literature. Most of the works of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination published in France contain some opinions or some tinge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: caught from pantheistical doctrines, or they disclose some tendency to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such doctrines in their authors. This appears to me not only to proceed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from an accidental, but from a permanent cause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the conditions of society are becoming more equal, and each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual man becomes more like all the rest, more weak and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insignificant, a habit grows up of ceasing to notice the citizens to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider only the people, and of overlooking individuals to think only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their kind. At such times the human mind seeks to embrace a multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of different objects at once; and it constantly strives to succeed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connecting a variety of consequences with a single cause. The idea
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of unity so possesses itself of man, and is sought for by him so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: universally, that if he thinks he has found it, he readily yields
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself up to repose in that belief. Nor does he content himself with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the discovery that nothing is in the world but a creation and a Creator;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still embarrassed by this primary division of things, he seeks to expand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to simplify his conception by including God and the universe in one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great whole. If there be a philosophical system which teaches that all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things material and immaterial, visible and invisible, which the world
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contains, are only to be considered as the several parts of an immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Being, which alone remains unchanged amidst the continual change and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceaseless transformation of all that constitutes it, we may readily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infer that such a system, although it destroy the individuality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man--nay, rather because it destroys that individuality--will have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secret charms for men living in democracies. All their habits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought prepare them to conceive it, and predispose them to adopt it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It naturally attracts and fixes their imagination; it fosters the pride,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst it soothes the indolence, of their minds. Amongst the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: systems by whose aid philosophy endeavors to explain the universe, I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe pantheism to be one of those most fitted to seduce the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind in democratic ages. Against it all who abide in their attachment to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the true greatness of man should struggle and combine.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: The Principle Of Equality Suggests To The Americans The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Idea Of The Indefinite Perfectibility Of Man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Equality suggests to the human mind several ideas which would not have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originated from any other source, and it modifies almost all those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: previously entertained. I take as an example the idea of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfectibility, because it is one of the principal notions that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellect can conceive, and because it constitutes of itself a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophical theory, which is every instant to be traced by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences in the practice of human affairs. Although man has many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: points of resemblance with the brute creation, one characteristic is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar to himself--he improves: they are incapable of improvement.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mankind could not fail to discover this difference from its earliest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: period. The idea of perfectibility is therefore as old as the world;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality did not give birth to it, although it has imparted to it a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: novel character.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the citizens of a community are classed according to their rank,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their profession, or their birth, and when all men are constrained to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: follow the career which happens to open before them, everyone thinks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the utmost limits of human power are to be discerned in proximity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to himself, and none seeks any longer to resist the inevitable law of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his destiny. Not indeed that an aristocratic people absolutely contests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man's faculty of self-improvement, but they do not hold it to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indefinite; amelioration they conceive, but not change: they imagine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the future condition of society may be better, but not essentially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different; and whilst they admit that mankind has made vast strides
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in improvement, and may still have some to make, they assign to it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beforehand certain impassable limits. Thus they do not presume that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have arrived at the supreme good or at absolute truth (what people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or what man was ever wild enough to imagine it?) but they cherish a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persuasion that they have pretty nearly reached that degree of greatness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and knowledge which our imperfect nature admits of; and as nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moves about them they are willing to fancy that everything is in its fit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place. Then it is that the legislator affects to lay down eternal laws;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that kings and nations will raise none but imperishable monuments; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the present generation undertakes to spare generations to come the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: care of regulating their destinies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In proportion as castes disappear and the classes of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approximate--as manners, customs, and laws vary, from the tumultuous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intercourse of men--as new facts arise--as new truths are brought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to light--as ancient opinions are dissipated, and others take their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place--the image of an ideal perfection, forever on the wing, presents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself to the human mind. Continual changes are then every instant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurring under the observation of every man: the position of some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is rendered worse; and he learns but too well, that no people and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no individual, how enlightened soever they may be, can lay claim to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infallibility;--the condition of others is improved; whence he infers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that man is endowed with an indefinite faculty of improvement. His
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reverses teach him that none may hope to have discovered absolute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good--his success stimulates him to the never-ending pursuit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. Thus, forever seeking--forever falling, to rise again--often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disappointed, but not discouraged--he tends unceasingly towards that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unmeasured greatness so indistinctly visible at the end of the long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: track which humanity has yet to tread. It can hardly be believed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: how many facts naturally flow from the philosophical theory of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indefinite perfectibility of man, or how strong an influence it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercises even on men who, living entirely for the purposes of action
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and not of thought, seem to conform their actions to it, without knowing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anything about it. I accost an American sailor, and I inquire why the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ships of his country are built so as to last but for a short time;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he answers without hesitation that the art of navigation is every day
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: making such rapid progress, that the finest vessel would become almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: useless if it lasted beyond a certain number of years. In these words,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which fell accidentally and on a particular subject from a man of rude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attainments, I recognize the general and systematic idea upon which a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great people directs all its concerns.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Aristocratic nations are naturally too apt to narrow the scope of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfectibility; democratic nations to expand it beyond compass.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IX: The Example Of The Americans Does Not Prove That A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic People Can Have No Aptitude And No Taste For Science,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Literature, Or Art
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must be acknowledged that amongst few of the civilized nations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our time have the higher sciences made less progress than in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States; and in few have great artists, fine poets, or celebrated writers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been more rare. Many Europeans, struck by this fact, have looked upon it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a natural and inevitable result of equality; and they have supposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that if a democratic state of society and democratic institutions were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever to prevail over the whole earth, the human mind would gradually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find its beacon-lights grow dim, and men would relapse into a period of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: darkness. To reason thus is, I think, to confound several ideas which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is important to divide and to examine separately: it is to mingle,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unintentionally, what is democratic with what is only American.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The religion professed by the first emigrants, and bequeathed by them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to their descendants, simple in its form of worship, austere and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost harsh in its principles, and hostile to external symbols and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceremonial pomp, is naturally unfavorable to the fine arts, and only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yields a reluctant sufferance to the pleasures of literature. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans are a very old and a very enlightened people, who have fallen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon a new and unbounded country, where they may extend themselves at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasure, and which they may fertilize without difficulty. This state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things is without a parallel in the history of the world. In America,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then, every one finds facilities, unknown elsewhere, for making or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increasing his fortune. The spirit of gain is always on the stretch, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the human mind, constantly diverted from the pleasures of imagination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the labors of the intellect, is there swayed by no impulse but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit of wealth. Not only are manufacturing and commercial classes to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be found in the United States, as they are in all other countries; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what never occurred elsewhere, the whole community is simultaneously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engaged in productive industry and commerce. I am convinced that, if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans had been alone in the world, with the freedom and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge acquired by their forefathers, and the passions which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own, they would not have been slow to discover that progress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot long be made in the application of the sciences without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivating the theory of them; that all the arts are perfected by one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another: and, however absorbed they might have been by the pursuit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the principal object of their desires, they would speedily have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admitted, that it is necessary to turn aside from it occasionally, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order the better to attain it in the end.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The taste for the pleasures of the mind is moreover so natural to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heart of civilized man, that amongst the polite nations, which are least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disposed to give themselves up to these pursuits, a certain number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens are always to be found who take part in them. This intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: craving, when once felt, would very soon have been satisfied. But at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very time when the Americans were naturally inclined to require nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of science but its special applications to the useful arts and the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of rendering life comfortable, learned and literary Europe was engaged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in exploring the common sources of truth, and in improving at the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time all that can minister to the pleasures or satisfy the wants of man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the head of the enlightened nations of the Old World the inhabitants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States more particularly distinguished one, to which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were closely united by a common origin and by kindred habits. Amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this people they found distinguished men of science, artists of skill,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: writers of eminence, and they were enabled to enjoy the treasures of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellect without requiring to labor in amassing them. I cannot consent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to separate America from Europe, in spite of the ocean which intervenes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I consider the people of the United States as that portion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English people which is commissioned to explore the wilds of the New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: World; whilst the rest of the nation, enjoying more leisure and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harassed by the drudgery of life, may devote its energies to thought,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and enlarge in all directions the empire of the mind. The position of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans is therefore quite exceptional, and it may be believed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that no democratic people will ever be placed in a similar one. Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strictly Puritanical origin--their exclusively commercial habits--even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country they inhabit, which seems to divert their minds from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit of science, literature, and the arts--the proximity of Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which allows them to neglect these pursuits without relapsing into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barbarism--a thousand special causes, of which I have only been able to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point out the most important--have singularly concurred to fix the mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the American upon purely practical objects. His passions, his wants,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his education, and everything about him seem to unite in drawing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: native of the United States earthward: his religion alone bids him turn,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from time to time, a transient and distracted glance to heaven. Let us
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cease then to view all democratic nations under the mask of the American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, and let us attempt to survey them at length with their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proper features.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is possible to conceive a people not subdivided into any castes or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scale of ranks; in which the law, recognizing no privileges, should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divide inherited property into equal shares; but which, at the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, should be without knowledge and without freedom. Nor is this an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empty hypothesis: a despot may find that it is his interest to render
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his subjects equal and to leave them ignorant, in order more easily to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: keep them slaves. Not only would a democratic people of this kind show
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neither aptitude nor taste for science, literature, or art, but it would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: probably never arrive at the possession of them. The law of descent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would of itself provide for the destruction of fortunes at each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeeding generation; and new fortunes would be acquired by none. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: poor man, without either knowledge or freedom, would not so much as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceive the idea of raising himself to wealth; and the rich man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would allow himself to be degraded to poverty, without a notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self-defence. Between these two members of the community complete and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invincible equality would soon be established.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No one would then have time or taste to devote himself to the pursuits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or pleasures of the intellect; but all men would remain paralyzed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a state of common ignorance and equal servitude. When I conceive a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic society of this kind, I fancy myself in one of those low,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: close, and gloomy abodes, where the light which breaks in from without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soon faints and fades away. A sudden heaviness overpowers me, and I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grope through the surrounding darkness, to find the aperture which will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restore me to daylight and the air.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But all this is not applicable to men already enlightened who retain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their freedom, after having abolished from amongst them those peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and hereditary rights which perpetuated the tenure of property in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands of certain individuals or certain bodies. When men living in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic state of society are enlightened, they readily discover that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are confined and fixed within no limits which constrain them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take up with their present fortune. They all therefore conceive the idea
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of increasing it; if they are free, they all attempt it, but all do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not succeed in the same manner. The legislature, it is true, no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer grants privileges, but they are bestowed by nature. As natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality is very great, fortunes become unequal as soon as every man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exerts all his faculties to get rich. The law of descent prevents the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: establishment of wealthy families; but it does not prevent the existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of wealthy individuals. It constantly brings back the members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community to a common level, from which they as constantly escape:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the inequality of fortunes augments in proportion as knowledge is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diffused and liberty increased.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A sect which arose in our time, and was celebrated for its talents and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its extravagance, proposed to concentrate all property into the hands of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a central power, whose function it should afterwards be to parcel it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out to individuals, according to their capacity. This would have been a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: method of escaping from that complete and eternal equality which seems
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to threaten democratic society. But it would be a simpler and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous remedy to grant no privilege to any, giving to all equal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivation and equal independence, and leaving everyone to determine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his own position. Natural inequality will very soon make way for itself,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and wealth will spontaneously pass into the hands of the most capable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Free and democratic communities, then, will always contain a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerable number of people enjoying opulence or competency. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealthy will not be so closely linked to each other as the members of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the former aristocratic class of society: their propensities will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different, and they will scarcely ever enjoy leisure as secure or as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complete: but they will be far more numerous than those who belonged to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that class of society could ever be. These persons will not be strictly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confined to the cares of practical life, and they will still be able,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: though in different degrees, to indulge in the pursuits and pleasures of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the intellect. In those pleasures they will indulge; for if it be true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the human mind leans on one side to the narrow, the practical,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the useful, it naturally rises on the other to the infinite, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spiritual, and the beautiful. Physical wants confine it to the earth;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but, as soon as the tie is loosened, it will unbend itself again.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not only will the number of those who can take an interest in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productions of the mind be enlarged, but the taste for intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyment will descend, step by step, even to those who, in aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: societies, seem to have neither time nor ability to in indulge in them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When hereditary wealth, the privileges of rank, and the prerogatives of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: birth have ceased to be, and when every man derives his strength from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself alone, it becomes evident that the chief cause of disparity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the fortunes of men is the mind. Whatever tends to invigorate,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to extend, or to adorn the mind, instantly rises to great value. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: utility of knowledge becomes singularly conspicuous even to the eyes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the multitude: those who have no taste for its charms set store upon its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results, and make some efforts to acquire it. In free and enlightened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages, there is nothing to separate men from each other or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to retain them in their peculiar sphere; they rise or sink with extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapidity. All classes live in perpetual intercourse from their great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proximity to each other. They communicate and intermingle every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day--they imitate and envy one other: this suggests to the people many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideas, notions, and desires which it would never have entertained if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinctions of rank had been fixed and society at rest. In such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations the servant never considers himself as an entire stranger to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the pleasures and toils of his master, nor the poor man to those of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich; the rural population assimilates itself to that of the towns, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the provinces to the capital. No one easily allows himself to be reduced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the mere material cares of life; and the humblest artisan casts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at times an eager and a furtive glance into the higher regions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellect. People do not read with the same notions or in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner as they do in an aristocratic community; but the circle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readers is unceasingly expanded, till it includes all the citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As soon as the multitude begins to take an interest in the labors of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind, it finds out that to excel in some of them is a powerful method of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquiring fame, power, or wealth. The restless ambition which equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: begets instantly takes this direction as it does all others. The number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those who cultivate science, letters, and the arts, becomes immense.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The intellectual world starts into prodigious activity: everyone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavors to open for himself a path there, and to draw the eyes of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public after him. Something analogous occurs to what happens in society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States, politically considered. What is done is often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperfect, but the attempts are innumerable; and, although the results
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of individual effort are commonly very small, the total amount is always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very large.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is therefore not true to assert that men living in democratic ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are naturally indifferent to science, literature, and the arts: only it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be acknowledged that they cultivate them after their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fashion, and bring to the task their own peculiar qualifications and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deficiencies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter X: Why The Americans Are More Addicted To Practical Than To
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Theoretical Science
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If a democratic state of society and democratic institutions do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stop the career of the human mind, they incontestably guide it in one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direction in preference to another. Their effects, thus circumscribed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are still exceedingly great; and I trust I may be pardoned if I pause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for a moment to survey them. We had occasion, in speaking of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophical method of the American people, to make several remarks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which must here be turned to account.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Equality begets in man the desire of judging of everything for himself:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it gives him, in all things, a taste for the tangible and the real,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a contempt for tradition and for forms. These general tendencies are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principally discernible in the peculiar subject of this chapter. Those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who cultivate the sciences amongst a democratic people are always afraid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of losing their way in visionary speculation. They mistrust systems;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they adhere closely to facts and the study of facts with their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: senses. As they do not easily defer to the mere name of any fellow-man,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are never inclined to rest upon any man's authority; but, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, they are unremitting in their efforts to point out the weaker
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: points of their neighbors' opinions. Scientific precedents have very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little weight with them; they are never long detained by the subtilty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the schools, nor ready to accept big words for sterling coin; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penetrate, as far as they can, into the principal parts of the subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which engages them, and they expound them in the vernacular tongue.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Scientific pursuits then follow a freer and a safer course, but a less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lofty one.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The mind may, as it appears to me, divide science into three parts. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first comprises the most theoretical principles, and those more abstract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions whose application is either unknown or very remote. The second
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is composed of those general truths which still belong to pure theory,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but lead, nevertheless, by a straight and short road to practical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results. Methods of application and means of execution make up the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: third. Each of these different portions of science may be separately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivated, although reason and experience show that none of them can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosper long, if it be absolutely cut off from the two others.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the purely practical part of science is admirably understood,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and careful attention is paid to the theoretical portion which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediately requisite to application. On this head the Americans always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: display a clear, free, original, and inventive power of mind. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardly anyone in the United States devotes himself to the essentially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theoretical and abstract portion of human knowledge. In this respect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans carry to excess a tendency which is, I think, discernible,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: though in a less degree, amongst all democratic nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing is more necessary to the culture of the higher sciences, or of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the more elevated departments of science, than meditation; and nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is less suited to meditation than the structure of democratic society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We do not find there, as amongst an aristocratic people, one class which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clings to a state of repose because it is well off; and another which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not venture to stir because it despairs of improving its condition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Everyone is actively in motion: some in quest of power, others of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gain. In the midst of this universal tumult--this incessant conflict of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jarring interests--this continual stride of men after fortune--where is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that calm to be found which is necessary for the deeper combinations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the intellect? How can the mind dwell upon any single point, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything whirls around it, and man himself is swept and beaten onwards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the heady current which rolls all things in its course? But the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanent agitation which subsists in the bosom of a peaceable and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established democracy, must be distinguished from the tumultuous and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutionary movements which almost always attend the birth and growth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democratic society. When a violent revolution occurs amongst a highly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilized people, it cannot fail to give a sudden impulse to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feelings and their opinions. This is more particularly true of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic revolutions, which stir up all the classes of which a people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is composed, and beget, at the same time, inordinate ambition in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: breast of every member of the community. The French made most surprising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advances in the exact sciences at the very time at which they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: finishing the destruction of the remains of their former feudal society;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet this sudden fecundity is not to be attributed to democracy, but to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the unexampled revolution which attended its growth. What happened at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that period was a special incident, and it would be unwise to regard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it as the test of a general principle. Great revolutions are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more common amongst democratic nations than amongst others: I am even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclined to believe that they are less so. But there prevails amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those populations a small distressing motion--a sort of incessant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jostling of men--which annoys and disturbs the mind, without exciting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or elevating it. Men who live in democratic communities not only seldom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indulge in meditation, but they naturally entertain very little esteem
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for it. A democratic state of society and democratic institutions plunge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the greater part of men in constant active life; and the habits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind which are suited to an active life, are not always suited to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemplative one. The man of action is frequently obliged to content
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself with the best he can get, because he would never accomplish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his purpose if he chose to carry every detail to perfection. He has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually occasion to rely on ideas which he has not had leisure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to search to the bottom; for he is much more frequently aided by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opportunity of an idea than by its strict accuracy; and, in the long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: run, he risks less in making use of some false principles, than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spending his time in establishing all his principles on the basis of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: truth. The world is not led by long or learned demonstrations; a rapid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glance at particular incidents, the daily study of the fleeting passions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the multitude, the accidents of the time, and the art of turning them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to account, decide all its affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the ages in which active life is the condition of almost everyone,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men are therefore generally led to attach an excessive value to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapid bursts and superficial conceptions of the intellect; and, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other hand, to depreciate below their true standard its slower and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deeper labors. This opinion of the public influences the judgment of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men who cultivate the sciences; they are persuaded that they may succeed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in those pursuits without meditation, or deterred from such pursuits as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demand it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are several methods of studying the sciences. Amongst a multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men you will find a selfish, mercantile, and trading taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the discoveries of the mind, which must not be confounded with that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disinterested passion which is kindled in the heart of the few. A desire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to utilize knowledge is one thing; the pure desire to know is another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not doubt that in a few minds and far between, an ardent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inexhaustible love of truth springs up, self-supported, and living in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceaseless fruition without ever attaining the satisfaction which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seeks. This ardent love it is--this proud, disinterested love of what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true--which raises men to the abstract sources of truth, to draw their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mother-knowledge thence. If Pascal had had nothing in view but some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large gain, or even if he had been stimulated by the love of fame alone,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I cannot conceive that he would ever have been able to rally all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers of his mind, as he did, for the better discovery of the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hidden things of the Creator. When I see him, as it were, tear his soul
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the midst of all the cares of life to devote it wholly to these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: researches, and, prematurely snapping the links which bind the frame to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life, die of old age before forty, I stand amazed, and I perceive that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no ordinary cause is at work to produce efforts so extra-ordinary.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The future will prove whether these passions, at once so rare and so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productive, come into being and into growth as easily in the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic as in aristocratic communities. For myself, I confess that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am slow to believe it. In aristocratic society, the class which gives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tone to opinion, and has the supreme guidance of affairs, being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanently and hereditarily placed above the multitude, naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceives a lofty idea of itself and of man. It loves to invent for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him noble pleasures, to carve out splendid objects for his ambition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Aristocracies often commit very tyrannical and very inhuman actions;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they rarely entertain grovelling thoughts; and they show a kind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: haughty contempt of little pleasures, even whilst they indulge in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. The effect is greatly to raise the general pitch of society. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic ages vast ideas are commonly entertained of the dignity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the power, and the greatness of man. These opinions exert their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence on those who cultivate the sciences, as well as on the rest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community. They facilitate the natural impulse of the mind to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: highest regions of thought, and they naturally prepare it to conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a sublime--nay, almost a divine--love of truth. Men of science at such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: periods are consequently carried away by theory; and it even happens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they frequently conceive an inconsiderate contempt for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practical part of learning. "Archimedes," says Plutarch, "was of so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lofty a spirit, that he never condescended to write any treatise on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner of constructing all these engines of offence and defence. And as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he held this science of inventing and putting together engines, and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arts generally speaking which tended to any useful end in practice, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be vile, low, and mercenary, he spent his talents and his studious hours
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in writing of those things only whose beauty and subtilty had in them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no admixture of necessity." Such is the aristocratic aim of science; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations it cannot be the same.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greater part of the men who constitute these nations are extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eager in the pursuit of actual and physical gratification. As they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always dissatisfied with the position which they occupy, and are always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free to leave it, they think of nothing but the means of changing their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune, or of increasing it. To minds thus predisposed, every new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: method which leads by a shorter road to wealth, every machine which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spares labor, every instrument which diminishes the cost of production,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every discovery which facilitates pleasures or augments them, seems to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the grandest effort of the human intellect. It is chiefly from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these motives that a democratic people addicts itself to scientific
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuits--that it understands, and that it respects them. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic ages, science is more particularly called upon to furnish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratification to the mind; in democracies, to the body. You may be sure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the more a nation is democratic, enlightened, and free, the greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be the number of these interested promoters of scientific genius,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the more will discoveries immediately applicable to productive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industry confer gain, fame, and even power on their authors. For in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies the working class takes a part in public affairs; and public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honors, as well as pecuniary remuneration, may be awarded to those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deserve them. In a community thus organized it may easily be conceived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the human mind may be led insensibly to the neglect of theory; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it is urged, on the contrary, with unparalleled vehemence to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applications of science, or at least to that portion of theoretical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: science which is necessary to those who make such applications. In vain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will some innate propensity raise the mind towards the loftier spheres
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the intellect; interest draws it down to the middle zone. There it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may develop all its energy and restless activity, there it may engender
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all its wonders. These very Americans, who have not discovered one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the general laws of mechanics, have introduced into navigation an engine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which changes the aspect of the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Assuredly I do not content that the democratic nations of our time are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destined to witness the extinction of the transcendent luminaries of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man's intelligence, nor even that no new lights will ever start into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence. At the age at which the world has now arrived, and amongst so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many cultivated nations, perpetually excited by the fever of productive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industry, the bonds which connect the different parts of science
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together cannot fail to strike the observation; and the taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practical science itself, if it be enlightened, ought to lead men not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neglect theory. In the midst of such numberless attempted applications
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of so many experiments, repeated every day, it is almost impossible that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general laws should not frequently be brought to light; so that great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discoveries would be frequent, though great inventors be rare. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe, moreover, in the high calling of scientific minds. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic principle does not, on the one hand, induce men to cultivate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: science for its own sake, on the other it enormously increases the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of those who do cultivate it. Nor is it credible that, from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst so great a multitude no speculative genius should from time to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time arise, inflamed by the love of truth alone. Such a one, we may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sure, would dive into the deepest mysteries of nature, whatever be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the spirit of his country or his age. He requires no assistance in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course--enough that he be not checked in it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All that I mean to say is this:--permanent inequality of conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leads men to confine themselves to the arrogant and sterile research
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of abstract truths; whilst the social condition and the institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democracy prepare them to seek the immediate and useful practical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results of the sciences. This tendency is natural and inevitable: it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curious to be acquainted with it, and it may be necessary to point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it out. If those who are called upon to guide the nations of our time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clearly discerned from afar off these new tendencies, which will soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be irresistible, they would understand that, possessing education
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and freedom, men living in democratic ages cannot fail to improve the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industrial part of science; and that henceforward all the efforts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
