text: the constituted authorities ought to be directed to support the highest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: branches of learning, and to foster the nobler passion for science
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself. In the present age the human mind must be coerced into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theoretical studies; it runs of its own accord to practical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applications; and, instead of perpetually referring it to the minute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examination of secondary effects, it is well to divert it from them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes, in order to raise it up to the contemplation of primary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes. Because the civilization of ancient Rome perished in consequence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the invasion of the barbarians, we are perhaps too apt to think that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization cannot perish in any other manner. If the light by which we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are guided is ever extinguished, it will dwindle by degrees, and expire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of itself. By dint of close adherence to mere applications, principles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be lost sight of; and when the principles were wholly forgotten,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the methods derived from them would be ill-pursued. New methods could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no longer be invented, and men would continue to apply, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligence, and without art, scientific processes no longer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When Europeans first arrived in China, three hundred years ago,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they found that almost all the arts had reached a certain degree of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfection there; and they were surprised that a people which had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attained this point should not have gone beyond it. At a later period
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they discovered some traces of the higher branches of science which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lost. The nation was absorbed in productive industry: the greater part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its scientific processes had been preserved, but science itself no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer existed there. This served to explain the strangely motionless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state in which they found the minds of this people. The Chinese, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: following the track of their forefathers, had forgotten the reasons by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the latter had been guided. They still used the formula, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asking for its meaning: they retained the instrument, but they no longer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed the art of altering or renewing it. The Chinese, then, had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lost the power of change; for them to improve was impossible. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were compelled, at all times and in all points, to imitate their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predecessors, lest they should stray into utter darkness, by deviating
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for an instant from the path already laid down for them. The source of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human knowledge was all but dry; and though the stream still ran on, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could neither swell its waters nor alter its channel. Notwithstanding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this, China had subsisted peaceably for centuries. The invaders who had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquered the country assumed the manners of the inhabitants, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order prevailed there. A sort of physical prosperity was everywhere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discernible: revolutions were rare, and war was, so to speak, unknown.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is then a fallacy to flatter ourselves with the reflection that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barbarians are still far from us; for if there be some nations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allow civilization to be torn from their grasp, there are others who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trample it themselves under their feet.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XI: Of The Spirit In Which The Americans Cultivate The Arts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would be to waste the time of my readers and my own if I strove
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to demonstrate how the general mediocrity of fortunes, the absence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superfluous wealth, the universal desire of comfort, and the constant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efforts by which everyone attempts to procure it, make the taste for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: useful predominate over the love of the beautiful in the heart of man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic nations, amongst which all these things exist, will therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivate the arts which serve to render life easy, in preference to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those whose object is to adorn it. They will habitually prefer the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: useful to the beautiful, and they will require that the beautiful should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be useful. But I propose to go further; and after having pointed out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this first feature, to sketch several others.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It commonly happens that in the ages of privilege the practice of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all the arts becomes a privilege; and that every profession is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a separate walk, upon which it is not allowable for everyone to enter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Even when productive industry is free, the fixed character which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belongs to aristocratic nations gradually segregates all the persons who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: practise the same art, till they form a distinct class, always composed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the same families, whose members are all known to each other, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst whom a public opinion of their own and a species of corporate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pride soon spring up. In a class or guild of this kind, each artisan has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only his fortune to make, but his reputation to preserve. He is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusively swayed by his own interest, or even by that of his customer,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but by that of the body to which he belongs; and the interest of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body is, that each artisan should produce the best possible workmanship.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocratic ages, the object of the arts is therefore to manufacture
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as well as possible--not with the greatest despatch, or at the lowest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rate.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When, on the contrary, every profession is open to all--when a multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of persons are constantly embracing and abandoning it--and when its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several members are strangers to each other, indifferent, and from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numbers hardly seen amongst themselves; the social tie is destroyed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and each workman, standing alone, endeavors simply to gain the greatest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possible quantity of money at the least possible cost. The will of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customer is then his only limit. But at the same time a corresponding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution takes place in the customer also. In countries in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: riches as well as power are concentrated and retained in the hands of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the few, the use of the greater part of this world's goods belongs to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small number of individuals, who are always the same. Necessity, public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion, or moderate desires exclude all others from the enjoyment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them. As this aristocratic class remains fixed at the pinnacle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greatness on which it stands, without diminution or increase, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always acted upon by the same wants and affected by them in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner. The men of whom it is composed naturally derive from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior and hereditary position a taste for what is extremely well made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and lasting. This affects the general way of thinking of the nation in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relation to the arts. It often occurs, among such a people, that even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the peasant will rather go without the object he covets, than procure it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a state of imperfection. In aristocracies, then, the handicraftsmen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: work for only a limited number of very fastidious customers: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profit they hope to make depends principally on the perfection of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: workmanship.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such is no longer the case when, all privileges being abolished, ranks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are intermingled, and men are forever rising or sinking upon the ladder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society. Amongst a democratic people a number of citizens always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist whose patrimony is divided and decreasing. They have contracted,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under more prosperous circumstances, certain wants, which remain after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the means of satisfying such wants are gone; and they are anxiously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: looking out for some surreptitious method of providing for them. On the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other hand, there are always in democracies a large number of men whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune is upon the increase, but whose desires grow much faster than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their fortunes: and who gloat upon the gifts of wealth in anticipation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long before they have means to command them. Such men eager to find some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: short cut to these gratifications, already almost within their reach.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From the combination of these causes the result is, that in democracies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there are always a multitude of individuals whose wants are above their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means, and who are very willing to take up with imperfect satisfaction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather than abandon the object of their desires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The artisan readily understands these passions, for he himself partakes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in them: in an aristocracy he would seek to sell his workmanship at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: high price to the few; he now conceives that the more expeditious way of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: getting rich is to sell them at a low price to all. But there are only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two ways of lowering the price of commodities. The first is to discover
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some better, shorter, and more ingenious method of producing them: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: second is to manufacture a larger quantity of goods, nearly similar,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but of less value. Amongst a democratic population, all the intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faculties of the workman are directed to these two objects: he strives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to invent methods which may enable him not only to work better, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quicker and cheaper; or, if he cannot succeed in that, to diminish the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intrinsic qualities of the thing he makes, without rendering it wholly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unfit for the use for which it is intended. When none but the wealthy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had watches, they were almost all very good ones: few are now made which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are worth much, but everybody has one in his pocket. Thus the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle not only tends to direct the human mind to the useful arts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it induces the artisan to produce with greater rapidity a quantity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of imperfect commodities, and the consumer to content himself with these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commodities.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not that in democracies the arts are incapable of producing very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commendable works, if such be required. This may occasionally be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case, if customers appear who are ready to pay for time and trouble.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In this rivalry of every kind of industry--in the midst of this immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: competition and these countless experiments, some excellent workmen are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed who reach the utmost limits of their craft. But they have rarely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an opportunity of displaying what they can do; they are scrupulously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sparing of their powers; they remain in a state of accomplished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mediocrity, which condemns itself, and, though it be very well able
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to shoot beyond the mark before it, aims only at what it hits. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies, on the contrary, workmen always do all they can; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when they stop, it is because they have reached the limit of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attainments.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When I arrive in a country where I find some of the finest productions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the arts, I learn from this fact nothing of the social condition or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the political constitution of the country. But if I perceive that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the productions of the arts are generally of an inferior quality, very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abundant and very cheap, I am convinced that, amongst the people where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this occurs, privilege is on the decline, and that ranks are beginning
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to intermingle, and will soon be confounded together.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The handicraftsmen of democratic ages endeavor not only to bring their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: useful productions within the reach of the whole community, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strive to give to all their commodities attractive qualities which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not in reality possess. In the confusion of all ranks everyone hopes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to appear what he is not, and makes great exertions to succeed in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object. This sentiment indeed, which is but too natural to the heart of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man, does not originate in the democratic principle; but that principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applies it to material objects. To mimic virtue is of every age; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hypocrisy of luxury belongs more particularly to the ages of democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To satisfy these new cravings of human vanity the arts have recourse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every species of imposture: and these devices sometimes go so far as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defeat their own purpose. Imitation diamonds are now made which may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easily mistaken for real ones; as soon as the art of fabricating false
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diamonds shall have reached so high a degree of perfection that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be distinguished from real ones, it is probable that both one and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other will be abandoned, and become mere pebbles again.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This leads me to speak of those arts which are called the fine arts, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: way of distinction. I do not believe that it is a necessary effect of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic social condition and of democratic institutions to diminish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the number of men who cultivate the fine arts; but these causes exert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a very powerful influence on the manner in which these arts are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivated. Many of those who had already contracted a taste for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fine arts are impoverished: on the other hand, many of those who are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet rich begin to conceive that taste, at least by imitation; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of consumers increases, but opulent and fastidious consumers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become more scarce. Something analogous to what I have already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pointed out in the useful arts then takes place in the fine arts;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the productions of artists are more numerous, but the merit of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: production is diminished. No longer able to soar to what is great, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivate what is pretty and elegant; and appearance is more attended
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to than reality. In aristocracies a few great pictures are produced;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democratic countries, a vast number of insignificant ones. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former, statues are raised of bronze; in the latter, they are modelled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in plaster.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When I arrived for the first time at New York, by that part of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Atlantic Ocean which is called the Narrows, I was surprised to perceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: along the shore, at some distance from the city, a considerable number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of little palaces of white marble, several of which were built after the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: models of ancient architecture. When I went the next day to inspect more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: closely the building which had particularly attracted my notice, I found
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that its walls were of whitewashed brick, and its columns of painted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wood. All the edifices which I had admired the night before were of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same kind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The social condition and the institutions of democracy impart, moreover,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain peculiar tendencies to all the imitative arts, which it is easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to point out. They frequently withdraw them from the delineation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soul to fix them exclusively on that of the body: and they substitute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the representation of motion and sensation for that of sentiment and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought: in a word, they put the real in the place of the ideal. I doubt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whether Raphael studied the minutest intricacies of the mechanism of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human body as thoroughly as the draughtsmen of our own time. He did not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attach the same importance to rigorous accuracy on this point as they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do, because he aspired to surpass nature. He sought to make of man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: something which should be superior to man, and to embellish beauty's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self. David and his scholars were, on the contrary, as good anatomists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as they were good painters. They wonderfully depicted the models which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they had before their eyes, but they rarely imagined anything beyond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them: they followed nature with fidelity: whilst Raphael sought for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: something better than nature. They have left us an exact portraiture
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of man; but he discloses in his works a glimpse of the Divinity. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remark as to the manner of treating a subject is no less applicable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the choice of it. The painters of the Middle Ages generally sought far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: above themselves, and away from their own time, for mighty subjects,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which left to their imagination an unbounded range. Our painters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently employ their talents in the exact imitation of the details
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of private life, which they have always before their eyes; and they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forever copying trivial objects, the originals of which are only too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abundant in nature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XII: Why The Americans Raise Some Monuments So Insignificant,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And Others So Important
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have just observed, that in democratic ages monuments of the arts tend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to become more numerous and less important. I now hasten to point out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the exception to this rule. In a democratic community individuals are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very powerless; but the State which represents them all, and contains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them all in its grasp, is very powerful. Nowhere do citizens appear so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insignificant as in a democratic nation; nowhere does the nation itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appear greater, or does the mind more easily take in a wide general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: survey of it. In democratic communities the imagination is compressed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when men consider themselves; it expands indefinitely when they think
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the State. Hence it is that the same men who live on a small scale in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: narrow dwellings, frequently aspire to gigantic splendor in the erection
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their public monuments.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans traced out the circuit of an immense city on the site
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they intended to make their capital, but which, up to the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, is hardly more densely peopled than Pontoise, though, according
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them, it will one day contain a million of inhabitants. They have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already rooted up trees for ten miles round, lest they should interfere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the future citizens of this imaginary metropolis. They have erected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a magnificent palace for Congress in the centre of the city, and have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: given it the pompous name of the Capitol. The several States of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union are every day planning and erecting for themselves prodigious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings, which would astonish the engineers of the great European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations. Thus democracy not only leads men to a vast number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconsiderable productions; it also leads them to raise some monuments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the largest scale: but between these two extremes there is a blank.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A few scattered remains of enormous buildings can therefore teach us
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing of the social condition and the institutions of the people by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whom they were raised. I may add, though the remark leads me to step
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out of my subject, that they do not make us better acquainted with its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greatness, its civilization, and its real prosperity. Whensoever a power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of any kind shall be able to make a whole people co-operate in a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertaking, that power, with a little knowledge and a great deal of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, will succeed in obtaining something enormous from the co-operation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of efforts so multiplied. But this does not lead to the conclusion that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people was very happy, very enlightened, or even very strong.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Spaniards found the City of Mexico full of magnificent temples
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and vast palaces; but that did not prevent Cortes from conquering the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mexican Empire with 600 foot soldiers and sixteen horses. If the Romans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had been better acquainted with the laws of hydraulics, they would not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have constructed all the aqueducts which surround the ruins of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cities--they would have made a better use of their power and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth. If they had invented the steam-engine, perhaps they would not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have extended to the extremities of their empire those long artificial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: roads which are called Roman roads. These things are at once the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: splendid memorials of their ignorance and of their greatness. A people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which should leave no other vestige of its track than a few leaden pipes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the earth and a few iron rods upon its surface, might have been more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the master of nature than the Romans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIII: Literary Characteristics Of Democratic Ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a traveller goes into a bookseller's shop in the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and examines the American books upon the shelves, the number of works
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appears extremely great; whilst that of known authors appears, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, to be extremely small. He will first meet with a number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of elementary treatises, destined to teach the rudiments of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge. Most of these books are written in Europe; the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reprint them, adapting them to their own country. Next comes an enormous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quantity of religious works, Bibles, sermons, edifying anecdotes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: controversial divinity, and reports of charitable societies; lastly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appears the long catalogue of political pamphlets. In America, parties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not write books to combat each others' opinions, but pamphlets which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are circulated for a day with incredible rapidity, and then expire. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the midst of all these obscure productions of the human brain are to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found the more remarkable works of that small number of authors, whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: names are, or ought to be, known to Europeans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although America is perhaps in our days the civilized country in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which literature is least attended to, a large number of persons are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless to be found there who take an interest in the productions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the mind, and who make them, if not the study of their lives, at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: least the charm of their leisure hours. But England supplies these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readers with the larger portion of the books which they require. Almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all important English books are republished in the United States. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary genius of Great Britain still darts its rays into the recesses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the forests of the New World. There is hardly a pioneer's hut which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not contain a few odd volumes of Shakespeare. I remember that I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: read the feudal play of Henry V for the first time in a loghouse.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not only do the Americans constantly draw upon the treasures of English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literature, but it may be said with truth that they find the literature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of England growing on their own soil. The larger part of that small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of men in the United States who are engaged in the composition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary works are English in substance, and still more so in form.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus they transport into the midst of democracy the ideas and literary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fashions which are current amongst the aristocratic nation they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken for their model. They paint with colors borrowed from foreign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners; and as they hardly ever represent the country they were born
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in as it really is, they are seldom popular there. The citizens of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States are themselves so convinced that it is not for them that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: books are published, that before they can make up their minds upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merit of one of their authors, they generally wait till his fame has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been ratified in England, just as in pictures the author of an original
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is held to be entitled to judge of the merit of a copy. The inhabitants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the United States have then at present, properly speaking, no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literature. The only authors whom I acknowledge as American are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: journalists. They indeed are not great writers, but they speak the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language of their countrymen, and make themselves heard by them. Other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authors are aliens; they are to the Americans what the imitators of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Greeks and Romans were to us at the revival of learning--an object of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curiosity, not of general sympathy. They amuse the mind, but they do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: act upon the manners of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already said that this state of things is very far from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: originating in democracy alone, and that the causes of it must be sought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for in several peculiar circumstances independent of the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle. If the Americans, retaining the same laws and social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition, had had a different origin, and had been transported
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into another country, I do not question that they would have had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a literature. Even as they now are, I am convinced that they will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ultimately have one; but its character will be different from that which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: marks the American literary productions of our time, and that character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be peculiarly its own. Nor is it impossible to trace this character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beforehand.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I suppose an aristocratic people amongst whom letters are cultivated;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the labors of the mind, as well as the affairs of state, are conducted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a ruling class in society. The literary as well as the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: career is almost entirely confined to this class, or to those nearest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to it in rank. These premises suffice to give me a key to all the rest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a small number of the same men are engaged at the same time upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same objects, they easily concert with one another, and agree upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain leading rules which are to govern them each and all. If the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object which attracts the attention of these men is literature, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productions of the mind will soon be subjected by them to precise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: canons, from which it will no longer be allowable to depart. If these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men occupy a hereditary position in the country, they will be naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclined, not only to adopt a certain number of fixed rules for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, but to follow those which their forefathers laid down for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own guidance; their code will be at once strict and traditional.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As they are not necessarily engrossed by the cares of daily life--as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have never been so, any more than their fathers were before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them--they have learned to take an interest, for several generations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: back, in the labors of the mind. They have learned to understand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literature as an art, to love it in the end for its own sake, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feel a scholar-like satisfaction in seeing men conform to its rules. Nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is this all: the men of whom I speak began and will end their lives in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easy or in affluent circumstances; hence they have naturally conceived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a taste for choice gratifications, and a love of refined and delicate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures. Nay more, a kind of indolence of mind and heart, which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently contract in the midst of this long and peaceful enjoyment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of so much welfare, leads them to put aside, even from their pleasures,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever might be too startling or too acute. They had rather be amused
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than intensely excited; they wish to be interested, but not to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carried away.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Now let us fancy a great number of literary performances executed by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, or for the men, whom I have just described, and we shall readily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceive a style of literature in which everything will be regular and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prearranged. The slightest work will be carefully touched in its least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: details; art and labor will be conspicuous in everything; each kind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: writing will have rules of its own, from which it will not be allowed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: swerve, and which distinguish it from all others. Style will be thought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of almost as much importance as thought; and the form will be no less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considered than the matter: the diction will be polished, measured,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and uniform. The tone of the mind will be always dignified, seldom very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animated; and writers will care more to perfect what they produce than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to multiply their productions. It will sometimes happen that the members
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the literary class, always living amongst themselves and writing for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves alone, will lose sight of the rest of the world, which will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infect them with a false and labored style; they will lay down minute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary rules for their exclusive use, which will insensibly lead them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to deviate from common-sense, and finally to transgress the bounds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature. By dint of striving after a mode of parlance different from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the vulgar, they will arrive at a sort of aristocratic jargon, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardly less remote from pure language than is the coarse dialect of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. Such are the natural perils of literature amongst aristocracies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Every aristocracy which keeps itself entirely aloof from the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes impotent--a fact which is as true in literature as it is in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: All this is especially true of the aristocratic countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which have been long and peacefully subject to a monarchical government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When liberty prevails in an aristocracy, the higher ranks are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to make use of the lower classes; and when they use, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approach them. This frequently introduces something of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit into an aristocratic community. There springs up, moreover, in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileged body, governing with energy and an habitually bold policy, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taste for stir and excitement which must infallibly affect all literary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: performances.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Let us now turn the picture and consider the other side of it; let us
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transport ourselves into the midst of a democracy, not unprepared by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ancient traditions and present culture to partake in the pleasures of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mind. Ranks are there intermingled and confounded; knowledge and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power are both infinitely subdivided, and, if I may use the expression,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scattered on every side. Here then is a motley multitude, whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellectual wants are to be supplied. These new votaries of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures of the mind have not all received the same education; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not possess the same degree of culture as their fathers, nor any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resemblance to them--nay, they perpetually differ from themselves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for they live in a state of incessant change of place, feelings,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and fortunes. The mind of each member of the community is therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unattached to that of his fellow-citizens by tradition or by common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits; and they have never had the power, the inclination, nor the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time to concert together. It is, however, from the bosom of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heterogeneous and agitated mass that authors spring; and from the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: source their profits and their fame are distributed. I can without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty understand that, under these circumstances, I must expect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to meet in the literature of such a people with but few of those strict
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conventional rules which are admitted by readers and by writers in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic ages. If it should happen that the men of some one period
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were agreed upon any such rules, that would prove nothing for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: following period; for amongst democratic nations each new generation is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a new people. Amongst such nations, then, literature will not easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be subjected to strict rules, and it is impossible that any such rules
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should ever be permanent.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democracies it is by no means the case that all the men who cultivate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literature have received a literary education; and most of those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have some tinge of belles-lettres are either engaged in politics, or in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a profession which only allows them to taste occasionally and by stealth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the pleasures of the mind. These pleasures, therefore, do not constitute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principal charm of their lives; but they are considered as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transient and necessary recreation amidst the serious labors of life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such man can never acquire a sufficiently intimate knowledge of the art
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of literature to appreciate its more delicate beauties; and the minor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shades of expression must escape them. As the time they can devote to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: letters is very short, they seek to make the best use of the whole of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. They prefer books which may be easily procured, quickly read, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which require no learned researches to be understood. They ask for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beauties, self-proffered and easily enjoyed; above all, they must have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what is unexpected and new. Accustomed to the struggle, the crosses, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the monotony of practical life, they require rapid emotions, startling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passages--truths or errors brilliant enough to rouse them up, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plunge them at once, as if by violence, into the midst of a subject.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Why should I say more? or who does not understand what is about to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: follow, before I have expressed it? Taken as a whole, literature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democratic ages can never present, as it does in the periods of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy, an aspect of order, regularity, science, and art; its form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will, on the contrary, ordinarily be slighted, sometimes despised. Style
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will frequently be fantastic, incorrect, overburdened, and loose--almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always vehement and bold. Authors will aim at rapidity of execution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more than at perfection of detail. Small productions will be more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common than bulky books; there will be more wit than erudition, more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination than profundity; and literary performances will bear marks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an untutored and rude vigor of thought--frequently of great variety
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and singular fecundity. The object of authors will be to astonish rather
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than to please, and to stir the passions more than to charm the taste.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Here and there, indeed, writers will doubtless occur who will choose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a different track, and who will, if they are gifted with superior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abilities, succeed in finding readers, in spite of their defects or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their better qualities; but these exceptions will be rare, and even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the authors who shall so depart from the received practice in the main
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject of their works, will always relapse into it in some lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: details.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have just depicted two extreme conditions: the transition by which a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation passes from the former to the latter is not sudden but gradual,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and marked with shades of very various intensity. In the passage which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conducts a lettered people from the one to the other, there is almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always a moment at which the literary genius of democratic nations has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its confluence with that of aristocracies, and both seek to establish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their joint sway over the human mind. Such epochs are transient, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very brilliant: they are fertile without exuberance, and animated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without confusion. The French literature of the eighteenth century may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: serve as an example.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I should say more than I mean if I were to assert that the literature of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a nation is always subordinate to its social condition and its political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution. I am aware that, independently of these causes, there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are several others which confer certain characteristics on literary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productions; but these appear to me to be the chief. The relations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist between the social and political condition of a people and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genius of its authors are always very numerous: whoever knows the one is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never completely ignorant of the other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIV: The Trade Of Literature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democracy not only infuses a taste for letters among the trading
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes, but introduces a trading spirit into literature. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies, readers are fastidious and few in number; in democracies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are far more numerous and far less difficult to please. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence is, that among aristocratic nations, no one can hope to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeed without immense exertions, and that these exertions may bestow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great deal of fame, but can never earn much money; whilst among
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations, a writer may flatter himself that he will obtain at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a cheap rate a meagre reputation and a large fortune. For this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purpose he need not be admired; it is enough that he is liked. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever-increasing crowd of readers, and their continual craving for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: something new, insure the sale of books which nobody much esteems.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democratic periods the public frequently treat authors as kings do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their courtiers; they enrich, and they despise them. What more is needed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the venal souls which are born in courts, or which are worthy to live
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there? Democratic literature is always infested with a tribe of writers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who look upon letters as a mere trade: and for some few great authors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who adorn it you may reckon thousands of idea-mongers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XV: The Study Of Greek And Latin Literature Peculiarly Useful In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic Communities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What was called the People in the most democratic republics of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: antiquity, was very unlike what we designate by that term. In Athens,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the citizens took part in public affairs; but there were only 20,000
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens to more than 350,000 inhabitants. All the rest were slaves, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discharged the greater part of those duties which belong at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day to the lower or even to the middle classes. Athens, then, with her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: universal suffrage, was after all merely an aristocratic republic in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which all the nobles had an equal right to the government. The struggle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the patricians and plebeians of Rome must be considered in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same light: it was simply an intestine feud between the elder and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: younger branches of the same family. All the citizens belonged, in fact,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the aristocracy, and partook of its character.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is moreover to be remarked, that amongst the ancients books were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always scarce and dear; and that very great difficulties impeded their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: publication and circulation. These circumstances concentrated literary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tastes and habits amongst a small number of men, who formed a small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary aristocracy out of the choicer spirits of the great political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy. Accordingly nothing goes to prove that literature was ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: treated as a trade amongst the Greeks and Romans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These peoples, which not only constituted aristocracies, but very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: polished and free nations, of course imparted to their literary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productions the defects and the merits which characterize the literature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of aristocratic ages. And indeed a very superficial survey of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary remains of the ancients will suffice to convince us, that if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those writers were sometimes deficient in variety, or fertility in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjects, or in boldness, vivacity, or power of generalization in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their thoughts, they always displayed exquisite care and skill in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: details. Nothing in their works seems to be done hastily or at random:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every line is written for the eye of the connoisseur, and is shaped
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after some conception of ideal beauty. No literature places those fine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: qualities, in which the writers of democracies are naturally deficient,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in bolder relief than that of the ancients; no literature, therefore,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought to be more studied in democratic ages. This study is better suited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than any other to combat the literary defects inherent in those ages; as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for their more praiseworthy literary qualities, they will spring up of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own accord, without its being necessary to learn to acquire them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is important that this point should be clearly understood. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular study may be useful to the literature of a people, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being appropriate to its social and political wants. If men were to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persist in teaching nothing but the literature of the dead languages in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a community where everyone is habitually led to make vehement exertions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to augment or to maintain his fortune, the result would be a very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: polished, but a very dangerous, race of citizens. For as their social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and political condition would give them every day a sense of wants which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their education would never teach them to supply, they would perturb the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State, in the name of the Greeks and Romans, instead of enriching it by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their productive industry.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is evident that in democratic communities the interest of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals, as well as the security of the commonwealth, demands that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the education of the greater number should be scientific, commercial,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and industrial, rather than literary. Greek and Latin should not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taught in all schools; but it is important that those who by their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural disposition or their fortune are destined to cultivate letters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or prepared to relish them, should find schools where a complete
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge of ancient literature may be acquired, and where the true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scholar may be formed. A few excellent universities would do more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: towards the attainment of this object than a vast number of bad grammar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: schools, where superfluous matters, badly learned, stand in the way of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sound instruction in necessary studies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All who aspire to literary excellence in democratic nations, ought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently to refresh themselves at the springs of ancient literature:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there is no more wholesome course for the mind. Not that I hold the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary productions of the ancients to be irreproachable; but I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: think that they have some especial merits, admirably calculated to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: counterbalance our peculiar defects. They are a prop on the side on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which we are in most danger of falling.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVI: The Effect Of Democracy On Language
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the reader has rightly understood what I have already said on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the subject of literature in general, he will have no difficulty in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comprehending that species of influence which a democratic social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition and democratic institutions may exercise over language itself,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is the chief instrument of thought.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American authors may truly be said to live more in England than in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own country; since they constantly study the English writers, and take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them every day for their models. But such is not the case with the bulk
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the population, which is more immediately subjected to the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes acting upon the United States. It is not then to the written, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the spoken language that attention must be paid, if we would detect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the modifications which the idiom of an aristocratic people may undergo
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when it becomes the language of a democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Englishmen of education, and more competent judges than I can be myself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nicer shades of expression, have frequently assured me that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the language of the educated classes in the United States is notably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different from that of the educated classes in Great Britain. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complain not only that the Americans have brought into use a number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: new words--the difference and the distance between the two countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might suffice to explain that much--but that these new words are more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially taken from the jargon of parties, the mechanical arts, or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language of trade. They assert, in addition to this, that old English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words are often used by the Americans in new acceptations; and lastly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the inhabitants of the United States frequently intermingle their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: phraseology in the strangest manner, and sometimes place words together
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are always kept apart in the language of the mother-country. These
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarks, which were made to me at various times by persons who appeared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be worthy of credit, led me to reflect upon the subject; and my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reflections brought me, by theoretical reasoning, to the same point at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which my informants had arrived by practical observation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocracies, language must naturally partake of that state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repose in which everything remains. Few new words are coined, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: few new things are made; and even if new things were made, they would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be designated by known words, whose meaning has been determined by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tradition. If it happens that the human mind bestirs itself at length,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or is roused by light breaking in from without, the novel expressions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are introduced are characterized by a degree of learning,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligence, and philosophy, which shows that they do not originate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a democracy. After the fall of Constantinople had turned the tide of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: science and literature towards the west, the French language was almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediately invaded by a multitude of new words, which had all Greek
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or Latin roots. An erudite neologism then sprang up in France which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confined to the educated classes, and which produced no sensible effect,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or at least a very gradual one, upon the people. All the nations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe successively exhibited the same change. Milton alone introduced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more than six hundred words into the English language, almost all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derived from the Latin, the Greek, or the Hebrew. The constant agitation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which prevails in a democratic community tends unceasingly, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, to change the character of the language, as it does the aspect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of affairs. In the midst of this general stir and competition of minds,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great number of new ideas are formed, old ideas are lost, or reappear,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or are subdivided into an infinite variety of minor shades. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence is, that many words must fall into desuetude, and others
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be brought into use.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic nations love change for its own sake; and this is seen in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their language as much as in their politics. Even when they do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: need to change words, they sometimes feel a wish to transform them. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genius of a democratic people is not only shown by the great number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words they bring into use, but also by the nature of the ideas these new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words represent. Amongst such a people the majority lays down the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in language as well as in everything else; its prevailing spirit is as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manifest in that as in other respects. But the majority is more engaged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in business than in study--in political and commercial interests than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophical speculation or literary pursuits. Most of the words coined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or adopted for its use will therefore bear the mark of these habits;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will mainly serve to express the wants of business, the passions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: party, or the details of the public administration. In these departments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the language will constantly spread, whilst on the other hand it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually lose ground in metaphysics and theology.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As to the source from which democratic nations are wont to derive their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: new expressions, and the manner in which they go to work to coin them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: both may easily be described. Men living in democratic countries know
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but little of the language which was spoken at Athens and at Rome,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they do not care to dive into the lore of antiquity to find the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expression they happen to want. If they have sometimes recourse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learned etymologies, vanity will induce them to search at the roots of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the dead languages; but erudition does not naturally furnish them with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its resources. The most ignorant, it sometimes happens, will use them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most. The eminently democratic desire to get above their own sphere will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often lead them to seek to dignify a vulgar profession by a Greek or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Latin name. The lower the calling is, and the more remote from learning,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the more pompous and erudite is its appellation. Thus the French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rope-dancers have transformed themselves into acrobates and funambules.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the absence of knowledge of the dead languages, democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations are apt to borrow words from living tongues; for their mutual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intercourse becomes perpetual, and the inhabitants of different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries imitate each other the more readily as they grow more like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other every day.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But it is principally upon their own languages that democratic nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempt to perpetrate innovations. From time to time they resume
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forgotten expressions in their vocabulary, which they restore to use; or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they borrow from some particular class of the community a term peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to it, which they introduce with a figurative meaning into the language
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of daily life. Many expressions which originally belonged to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: technical language of a profession or a party, are thus drawn into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general circulation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The most common expedient employed by democratic nations to make an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innovation in language consists in giving some unwonted meaning to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an expression already in use. This method is very simple, prompt, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convenient; no learning is required to use it aright, and ignorance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself rather facilitates the practice; but that practice is most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous to the language. When a democratic people doubles the meaning
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a word in this way, they sometimes render the signification which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retains as ambiguous as that which it acquires. An author begins by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slight deflection of a known expression from its primitive meaning, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he adapts it, thus modified, as well as he can to his subject. A second
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: writer twists the sense of the expression in another way; a third takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession of it for another purpose; and as there is no common appeal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the sentence of a permanent tribunal which may definitely settle the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: signification of the word, it remains in an ambiguous condition. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence is that writers hardly ever appear to dwell upon a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought, but they always seem to point their aim at a knot of ideas,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leaving the reader to judge which of them has been hit. This is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deplorable consequence of democracy. I had rather that the language
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be made hideous with words imported from the Chinese, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Tartars, or the Hurons, than that the meaning of a word in our own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language should become indeterminate. Harmony and uniformity are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only secondary beauties in composition; many of these things are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conventional, and, strictly speaking, it is possible to forego them; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without clear phraseology there is no good language.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principle of equality necessarily introduces several other changes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into language. In aristocratic ages, when each nation tends to stand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aloof from all others and likes to have distinct characteristics of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own, it often happens that several peoples which have a common origin
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become nevertheless estranged from each other, so that, without ceasing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to understand the same language, they no longer all speak it in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner. In these ages each nation is divided into a certain number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes, which see but little of each other, and do not intermingle.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Each of these classes contracts, and invariably retains, habits of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind peculiar to itself, and adopts by choice certain words and certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: terms, which afterwards pass from generation to generation, like their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estates. The same idiom then comprises a language of the poor and a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language of the rich--a language of the citizen and a language of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nobility--a learned language and a vulgar one. The deeper the divisions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the more impassable the barriers of society become, the more must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this be the case. I would lay a wager, that amongst the castes of India
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there are amazing variations of language, and that there is almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as much difference between the language of the pariah and that of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Brahmin as there is in their dress. When, on the contrary, men, being no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer restrained by ranks, meet on terms of constant intercourse--when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: castes are destroyed, and the classes of society are recruited and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intermixed with each other, all the words of a language are mingled.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Those which are unsuitable to the greater number perish; the remainder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form a common store, whence everyone chooses pretty nearly at random.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Almost all the different dialects which divided the idioms of European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations are manifestly declining; there is no patois in the New World,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it is disappearing every day from the old countries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The influence of this revolution in social conditions is as much felt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in style as it is in phraseology. Not only does everyone use the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words, but a habit springs up of using them without discrimination. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules which style had set up are almost abolished: the line ceases to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be drawn between expressions which seem by their very nature vulgar, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other which appear to be refined. Persons springing from different ranks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society carry the terms and expressions they are accustomed to use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with them, into whatever circumstances they may pass; thus the origin
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of words is lost like the origin of individuals, and there is as much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confusion in language as there is in society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am aware that in the classification of words there are rules which do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not belong to one form of society any more than to another, but which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are derived from the nature of things. Some expressions and phrases
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are vulgar, because the ideas they are meant to express are low in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves; others are of a higher character, because the objects they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are intended to designate are naturally elevated. No intermixture of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranks will ever efface these differences. But the principle of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot fail to root out whatever is merely conventional and arbitrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the forms of thought. Perhaps the necessary classification which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I pointed out in the last sentence will always be less respected by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people than by any other, because amongst such a people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there are no men who are permanently disposed by education, culture, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leisure to study the natural laws of language, and who cause those laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be respected by their own observance of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall not quit this topic without touching on a feature of democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: languages, which is perhaps more characteristic of them than any other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has already been shown that democratic nations have a taste, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes a passion, for general ideas, and that this arises from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar merits and defects. This liking for general ideas is displayed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democratic languages by the continual use of generic terms or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abstract expressions, and by the manner in which they are employed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is the great merit and the great imperfection of these languages.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic nations are passionately addicted to generic terms or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abstract expressions, because these modes of speech enlarge thought,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and assist the operations of the mind by enabling it to include several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects in a small compass. A French democratic writer will be apt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to say capacites in the abstract for men of capacity, and without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particularizing the objects to which their capacity is applied: he will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talk about actualities to designate in one word the things passing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before his eyes at the instant; and he will comprehend under the term
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eventualities whatever may happen in the universe, dating from the moment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at which he speaks. Democratic writers are perpetually coining words of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this kind, in which they sublimate into further abstraction the abstract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: terms of the language. Nay, more, to render their mode of speech more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succinct, they personify the subject of these abstract terms, and make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it act like a real entity. Thus they would say in French, "La force des
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choses veut que les capacites gouvernent."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I cannot better illustrate what I mean than by my own example. I have
