author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently used the word "equality" in an absolute sense--nay, I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personified equality in several places; thus I have said that equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does such and such things, or refrains from doing others. It may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affirmed that the writers of the age of Louis XIV would not have used
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these expressions: they would never have thought of using the word
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "equality" without applying it to some particular object; and they would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather have renounced the term altogether than have consented to make a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: living personage of it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These abstract terms which abound in democratic languages, and which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: used on every occasion without attaching them to any particular fact,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlarge and obscure the thoughts they are intended to convey; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: render the mode of speech more succinct, and the idea contained in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it less clear. But with regard to language, democratic nations prefer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obscurity to labor. I know not indeed whether this loose style has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some secret charm for those who speak and write amongst these nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the men who live there are frequently left to the efforts of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual powers of mind, they are almost always a prey to doubt; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as their situation in life is forever changing, they are never held fast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to any of their opinions by the certain tenure of their fortunes. Men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: living in democratic countries are, then, apt to entertain unsettled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideas, and they require loose expressions to convey them. As they never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know whether the idea they express to-day will be appropriate to the new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position they may occupy to-morrow, they naturally acquire a liking for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abstract terms. An abstract term is like a box with a false bottom: you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may put in it what ideas you please, and take them out again without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being observed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst all nations, generic and abstract terms form the basis of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language. I do not, therefore, affect to expel these terms from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic languages; I simply remark that men have an especial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency, in the ages of democracy, to multiply words of this kind--to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take them always by themselves in their most abstract acceptation, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to use them on all occasions, even when the nature of the discourse does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not require them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVII: Of Some Of The Sources Of Poetry Amongst Democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Various different significations have been given to the word "poetry."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would weary my readers if I were to lead them into a discussion as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which of these definitions ought to be selected: I prefer telling them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at once that which I have chosen. In my opinion, poetry is the search
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the delineation of the ideal. The poet is he who, by suppressing a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of what exists, by adding some imaginary touches to the picture,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and by combining certain real circumstances, but which do not in fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concurrently happen, completes and extends the work of nature. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object of poetry is not to represent what is true, but to adorn it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to present to the mind some loftier imagery. Verse, regarded as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideal beauty of language, may be eminently poetical; but verse does not,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of itself, constitute poetry.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I now proceed to inquire whether, amongst the actions, the sentiments,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the opinions of democratic nations, there are any which lead to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conception of ideal beauty, and which may for this reason be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considered as natural sources of poetry. It must in the first place, be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledged that the taste for ideal beauty, and the pleasure derived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the expression of it, are never so intense or so diffused amongst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic as amongst an aristocratic people. In aristocratic nations it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes happens that the body goes on to act as it were spontaneously,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst the higher faculties are bound and burdened by repose. Amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these nations the people will very often display poetic tastes, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes allow their fancy to range beyond and above what surrounds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. But in democracies the love of physical gratification, the notion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of bettering one's condition, the excitement of competition, the charm
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of anticipated success, are so many spurs to urge men onwards in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: active professions they have embraced, without allowing them to deviate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for an instant from the track. The main stress of the faculties is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this point. The imagination is not extinct; but its chief function is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: devise what may be useful, and to represent what is real.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principle of equality not only diverts men from the description of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideal beauty--it also diminishes the number of objects to be described.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Aristocracy, by maintaining society in a fixed position, is favorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the solidity and duration of positive religions, as well as to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stability of political institutions. It not only keeps the human mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within a certain sphere of belief, but it predisposes the mind to adopt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one faith rather than another. An aristocratic people will always be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prone to place intermediate powers between God and man. In this respect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may be said that the aristocratic element is favorable to poetry.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the universe is peopled with supernatural creatures, not palpable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the senses but discovered by the mind, the imagination ranges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freely, and poets, finding a thousand subjects to delineate, also find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a countless audience to take an interest in their productions. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages it sometimes happens, on the contrary, that men are as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much afloat in matters of belief as they are in their laws. Scepticism
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then draws the imagination of poets back to earth, and confines them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the real and visible world. Even when the principle of equality does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not disturb religious belief, it tends to simplify it, and to divert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention from secondary agents, to fix it principally on the Supreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Power. Aristocracy naturally leads the human mind to the contemplation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the past, and fixes it there. Democracy, on the contrary, gives men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a sort of instinctive distaste for what is ancient. In this respect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy is far more favorable to poetry; for things commonly grow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: larger and more obscure as they are more remote; and for this twofold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason they are better suited to the delineation of the ideal.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: After having deprived poetry of the past, the principle of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: robs it in part of the present. Amongst aristocratic nations there are a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain number of privileged personages, whose situation is, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without and above the condition of man; to these, power, wealth, fame,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wit, refinement, and distinction in all things appear peculiarly to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belong. The crowd never sees them very closely, or does not watch them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in minute details; and little is needed to make the description of such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men poetical. On the other hand, amongst the same people, you will meet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with classes so ignorant, low, and enslaved, that they are no less fit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects for poetry from the excess of their rudeness and wretchedness,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the former are from their greatness and refinement. Besides, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the different classes of which an aristocratic community is composed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are widely separated, and imperfectly acquainted with each other, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination may always represent them with some addition to, or some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subtraction from, what they really are. In democratic communities, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men are all insignificant and very much alike, each man instantly sees
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all his fellows when he surveys himself. The poets of democratic ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can never, therefore, take any man in particular as the subject of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: piece; for an object of slender importance, which is distinctly seen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on all sides, will never lend itself to an ideal conception. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of equality; in proportion as it has established itself in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world, has dried up most of the old springs of poetry. Let us now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempt to show what new ones it may disclose.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When scepticism had depopulated heaven, and the progress of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had reduced each individual to smaller and better known proportions, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: poets, not yet aware of what they could substitute for the great themes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which were departing together with the aristocracy, turned their eyes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to inanimate nature. As they lost sight of gods and heroes, they set
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to describe streams and mountains. Thence originated in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the last century, that kind of poetry which has been called, by way
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of distinction, the descriptive. Some have thought that this sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delineation, embellished with all the physical and inanimate objects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which cover the earth, was the kind of poetry peculiar to democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ages; but I believe this to be an error, and that it only belongs to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: period of transition.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am persuaded that in the end democracy diverts the imagination from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all that is external to man, and fixes it on man alone. Democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations may amuse themselves for a while with considering the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productions of nature; but they are only excited in reality by a survey
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of themselves. Here, and here alone, the true sources of poetry amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such nations are to be found; and it may be believed that the poets who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall neglect to draw their inspirations hence, will lose all sway over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the minds which they would enchant, and will be left in the end with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: none but unimpassioned spectators of their transports. I have shown how
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ideas of progression and of the indefinite perfectibility of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human race belong to democratic ages. Democratic nations care but little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for what has been, but they are haunted by visions of what will be; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this direction their unbounded imagination grows and dilates beyond all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measure. Here then is the wildest range open to the genius of poets,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which allows them to remove their performances to a sufficient distance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the eye. Democracy shuts the past against the poet, but opens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the future before him. As all the citizens who compose a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community are nearly equal and alike, the poet cannot dwell upon any one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them; but the nation itself invites the exercise of his powers. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general similitude of individuals, which renders any one of them taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separately an improper subject of poetry, allows poets to include them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all in the same imagery, and to take a general survey of the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself. Democractic nations have a clearer perception than any others of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own aspect; and an aspect so imposing is admirably fitted to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delineation of the ideal.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I readily admit that the Americans have no poets; I cannot allow that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have no poetic ideas. In Europe people talk a great deal of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilds of America, but the Americans themselves never think about them:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are insensible to the wonders of inanimate nature, and they may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: said not to perceive the mighty forests which surround them till they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fall beneath the hatchet. Their eyes are fixed upon another sight: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American people views its own march across these wilds--drying swamps,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turning the course of rivers, peopling solitudes, and subduing nature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This magnificent image of themselves does not meet the gaze of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans at intervals only; it may be said to haunt every one of them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in his least as well as in his most important actions, and to be always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flitting before his mind. Nothing conceivable is so petty, so insipid,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so crowded with paltry interests, in one word so anti-poetic, as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life of a man in the United States. But amongst the thoughts which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suggests there is always one which is full of poetry, and that is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hidden nerve which gives vigor to the frame.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocratic ages each people, as well as each individual, is prone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to stand separate and aloof from all others. In democratic ages, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extreme fluctuations of men and the impatience of their desires keep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them perpetually on the move; so that the inhabitants of different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries intermingle, see, listen to, and borrow from each other's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stores. It is not only then the members of the same community who grow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more alike; communities are themselves assimilated to one another,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the whole assemblage presents to the eye of the spectator one vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy, each citizen of which is a people. This displays the aspect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of mankind for the first time in the broadest light. All that belongs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the existence of the human race taken as a whole, to its vicissitudes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to its future, becomes an abundant mine of poetry. The poets who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lived in aristocratic ages have been eminently successful in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delineations of certain incidents in the life of a people or a man;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but none of them ever ventured to include within his performances the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destinies of mankind--a task which poets writing in democratic ages may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempt. At that same time at which every man, raising his eyes above
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his country, begins at length to discern mankind at large, the Divinity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is more and more manifest to the human mind in full and entire majesty.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If in democratic ages faith in positive religions be often shaken, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the belief in intermediate agents, by whatever name they are called, be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overcast; on the other hand men are disposed to conceive a far broader
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idea of Providence itself, and its interference in human affairs assumes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a new and more imposing appearance to their eyes. Looking at the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: race as one great whole, they easily conceive that its destinies are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulated by the same design; and in the actions of every individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are led to acknowledge a trace of that universal and eternal plan
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on which God rules our race. This consideration may be taken as another
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prolific source of poetry which is opened in democratic ages. Democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: poets will always appear trivial and frigid if they seek to invest gods,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demons, or angels, with corporeal forms, and if they attempt to draw
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them down from heaven to dispute the supremacy of earth. But if they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strive to connect the great events they commemorate with the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: providential designs which govern the universe, and, without showing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: finger of the Supreme Governor, reveal the thoughts of the Supreme Mind,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their works will be admired and understood, for the imagination of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries takes this direction of its own accord.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may be foreseen in the like manner that poets living in democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ages will prefer the delineation of passions and ideas to that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons and achievements. The language, the dress, and the daily actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men in democracies are repugnant to ideal conceptions. These things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not poetical in themselves; and, if it were otherwise, they would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cease to be so, because they are too familiar to all those to whom the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: poet would speak of them. This forces the poet constantly to search
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: below the external surface which is palpable to the senses, in order to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: read the inner soul: and nothing lends itself more to the delineation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the ideal than the scrutiny of the hidden depths in the immaterial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature of man. I need not to ramble over earth and sky to discover
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a wondrous object woven of contrasts, of greatness and littleness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infinite, of intense gloom and of amazing brightness--capable at once
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of exciting pity, admiration, terror, contempt. I find that object in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: myself. Man springs out of nothing, crosses time, and disappears forever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the bosom of God; he is seen but for a moment, staggering on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: verge of the two abysses, and there he is lost. If man were wholly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorant of himself, he would have no poetry in him; for it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible to describe what the mind does not conceive. If man clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discerned his own nature, his imagination would remain idle, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would have nothing to add to the picture. But the nature of man is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently disclosed for him to apprehend something of himself; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently obscure for all the rest to be plunged in thick darkness,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in which he gropes forever--and forever in vain--to lay hold on some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completer notion of his being.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst a democratic people poetry will not be fed with legendary lays
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or the memorials of old traditions. The poet will not attempt to people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the universe with supernatural beings in whom his readers and his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fancy have ceased to believe; nor will he present virtues and vices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the mask of frigid personification, which are better received under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own features. All these resources fail him; but Man remains, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the poet needs no more. The destinies of mankind--man himself, taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aloof from his age and his country, and standing in the presence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nature and of God, with his passions, his doubts, his rare prosperities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and inconceivable wretchedness--will become the chief, if not the sole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theme of poetry amongst these nations. Experience may confirm this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assertion, if we consider the productions of the greatest poets who have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeared since the world has been turned to democracy. The authors of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our age who have so admirably delineated the features of Faust, Childe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Harold, Rene, and Jocelyn, did not seek to record the actions of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual, but to enlarge and to throw light on some of the obscurer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recesses of the human heart. Such are the poems of democracy. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of equality does not then destroy all the subjects of poetry:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it renders them less numerous, but more vast.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Of The Inflated Style Of American Writers And Orators
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have frequently remarked that the Americans, who generally treat
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of business in clear, plain language, devoid of all ornament, and so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely simple as to be often coarse, are apt to become inflated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as soon as they attempt a more poetical diction. They then vent their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pomposity from one end of a harangue to the other; and to hear them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lavish imagery on every occasion, one might fancy that they never spoke
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of anything with simplicity. The English are more rarely given to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: similar failing. The cause of this may be pointed out without much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty. In democratic communities each citizen is habitually engaged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the contemplation of a very puny object, namely himself. If he ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raises his looks higher, he then perceives nothing but the immense form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society at large, or the still more imposing aspect of mankind. His
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideas are all either extremely minute and clear, or extremely general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and vague: what lies between is an open void. When he has been drawn out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his own sphere, therefore, he always expects that some amazing object
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be offered to his attention; and it is on these terms alone that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consents to tear himself for an instant from the petty complicated cares
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which form the charm and the excitement of his life. This appears to me
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently to explain why men in democracies, whose concerns are in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general so paltry, call upon their poets for conceptions so vast and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descriptions so unlimited.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The authors, on their part, do not fail to obey a propensity of which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they themselves partake; they perpetually inflate their imaginations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and expanding them beyond all bounds, they not unfrequently abandon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great in order to reach the gigantic. By these means they hope to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attract the observation of the multitude, and to fix it easily upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves: nor are their hopes disappointed; for as the multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seeks for nothing in poetry but subjects of very vast dimensions, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has neither the time to measure with accuracy the proportions of all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjects set before it, nor a taste sufficiently correct to perceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at once in what respect they are out of proportion. The author and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public at once vitiate one another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We have just seen that amongst democratic nations, the sources of poetry
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are grand, but not abundant. They are soon exhausted: and poets, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: finding the elements of the ideal in what is real and true, abandon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them entirely and create monsters. I do not fear that the poetry of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations will prove too insipid, or that it will fly too near
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ground; I rather apprehend that it will be forever losing itself in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the clouds, and that it will range at last to purely imaginary regions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I fear that the productions of democratic poets may often be surcharged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with immense and incoherent imagery, with exaggerated descriptions and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strange creations; and that the fantastic beings of their brain may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes make us regret the world of reality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIX: Some Observations On The Drama Amongst Democratic Nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the revolution which subverts the social and political state of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic people begins to penetrate into literature, it generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first manifests itself in the drama, and it always remains conspicuous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there. The spectator of a dramatic piece is, to a certain extent, taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by surprise by the impression it conveys. He has no time to refer to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: memory, or to consult those more able to judge than himself. It does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not occur to him to resist the new literary tendencies which begin to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be felt by him; he yields to them before he knows what they are. Authors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are very prompt in discovering which way the taste of the public is thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secretly inclined. They shape their productions accordingly; and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literature of the stage, after having served to indicate the approaching
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary revolution, speedily completes its accomplishment. If you would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judge beforehand of the literature of a people which is lapsing into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy, study its dramatic productions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The literature of the stage, moreover, even amongst aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, constitutes the most democratic part of their literature.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No kind of literary gratification is so much within the reach of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude as that which is derived from theatrical representations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Neither preparation nor study is required to enjoy them: they lay hold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on you in the midst of your prejudices and your ignorance. When the yet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: untutored love of the pleasures of the mind begins to affect a class
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community, it instantly draws them to the stage. The theatres
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of aristocratic nations have always been filled with spectators not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belonging to the aristocracy. At the theatre alone the higher ranks mix
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the middle and the lower classes; there alone do the former consent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to listen to the opinion of the latter, or at least to allow them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to give an opinion at all. At the theatre, men of cultivation and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary attainments have always had more difficulty than elsewhere in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: making their taste prevail over that of the people, and in preventing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves from being carried away by the latter. The pit has frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made laws for the boxes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If it be difficult for an aristocracy to prevent the people from getting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the upper hand in the theatre, it will readily be understood that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people will be supreme there when democratic principles have crept into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws and manners--when ranks are intermixed--when minds, as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortunes, are brought more nearly together--and when the upper class
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has lost, with its hereditary wealth, its power, its precedents, and its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leisure. The tastes and propensities natural to democratic nations, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect to literature, will therefore first be discernible in the drama,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it may be foreseen that they will break out there with vehemence. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: written productions, the literary canons of aristocracy will be gently,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually, and, so to speak, legally modified; at the theatre they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be riotously overthrown. The drama brings out most of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good qualities, and almost all the defects, inherent in democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literature. Democratic peoples hold erudition very cheap, and care but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little for what occurred at Rome and Athens; they want to hear something
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which concerns themselves, and the delineation of the present age is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what they demand.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the heroes and the manners of antiquity are frequently brought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the stage, and dramatic authors faithfully observe the rules of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: antiquated precedent, that is enough to warrant a conclusion that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic classes have not yet got the upper hand of the theatres.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Racine makes a very humble apology in the preface to the "Britannicus"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for having disposed of Junia amongst the Vestals, who, according to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Aulus Gellius, he says, "admitted no one below six years of age nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: above ten." We may be sure that he would neither have accused himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the offence, nor defended himself from censure, if he had written for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our contemporaries. A fact of this kind not only illustrates the state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of literature at the time when it occurred, but also that of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself. A democratic stage does not prove that the nation is in a state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democracy, for, as we have just seen, even in aristocracies it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happen that democratic tastes affect the drama; but when the spirit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of aristocracy reigns exclusively on the stage, the fact irrefragably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demonstrates that the whole of society is aristocratic; and it may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: boldly inferred that the same lettered and learned class which sways the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dramatic writers commands the people and governs the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The refined tastes and the arrogant bearing of an aristocracy will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rarely fail to lead it, when it manages the stage, to make a kind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: selection in human nature. Some of the conditions of society claim
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its chief interest; and the scenes which delineate their manners are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preferred upon the stage. Certain virtues, and even certain vices,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are thought more particularly to deserve to figure there; and they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applauded whilst all others are excluded. Upon the stage, as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as elsewhere, an aristocratic audience will only meet personages of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quality, and share the emotions of kings. The same thing applies to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: style: an aristocracy is apt to impose upon dramatic authors certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: modes of expression which give the key in which everything is to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delivered. By these means the stage frequently comes to delineate only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one side of man, or sometimes even to represent what is not to be met
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with in human nature at all--to rise above nature and to go beyond it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democratic communities the spectators have no such partialities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they rarely display any such antipathies: they like to see upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stage that medley of conditions, of feelings, and of opinions, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurs before their eyes. The drama becomes more striking, more common,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more true. Sometimes, however, those who write for the stage in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies also transgress the bounds of human nature--but it is on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a different side from their predecessors. By seeking to represent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minute detail the little singularities of the moment and the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics of certain personages, they forget to portray the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general features of the race.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the democratic classes rule the stage, they introduce as much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: license in the manner of treating subjects as in the choice of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the love of the drama is, of all literary tastes, that which is most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural to democratic nations, the number of authors and of spectators,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as well as of theatrical representations, is constantly increasing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst these communities. A multitude composed of elements so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different, and scattered in so many different places, cannot acknowledge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same rules or submit to the same laws. No concurrence is possible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst judges so numerous, who know not when they may meet again; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore each pronounces his own sentence on the piece. If the effect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democracy is generally to question the authority of all literary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules and conventions, on the stage it abolishes them altogether, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: puts in their place nothing but the whim of each author and of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The drama also displays in an especial manner the truth of what I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: said before in speaking more generally of style and art in democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literature. In reading the criticisms which were occasioned by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dramatic productions of the age of Louis XIV, one is surprised to remark
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great stress which the public laid on the probability of the plot,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the importance which was attached to the perfect consistency of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the characters, and to their doing nothing which could not be easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explained and understood. The value which was set upon the forms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language at that period, and the paltry strife about words with which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dramatic authors were assailed, are no less surprising. It would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem that the men of the age of Louis XIV attached very exaggerated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance to those details, which may be perceived in the study, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which escape attention on the stage. For, after all, the principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object of a dramatic piece is to be performed, and its chief merit is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affect the audience. But the audience and the readers in that age were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same: on quitting the theatre they called up the author for judgment
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to their own firesides. In democracies, dramatic pieces are listened to,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but not read. Most of those who frequent the amusements of the stage do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not go there to seek the pleasures of the mind, but the keen emotions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the heart. They do not expect to hear a fine literary work, but to see
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a play; and provided the author writes the language of his country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: correctly enough to be understood, and that his characters excite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curiosity and awaken sympathy, the audience are satisfied. They ask no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more of fiction, and immediately return to real life. Accuracy of style
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is therefore less required, because the attentive observance of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules is less perceptible on the stage. As for the probability of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plot, it is incompatible with perpetual novelty, surprise, and rapidity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of invention. It is therefore neglected, and the public excuses the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neglect. You may be sure that if you succeed in bringing your audience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the presence of something that affects them, they will not care by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what road you brought them there; and they will never reproach you for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having excited their emotions in spite of dramatic rules.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans very broadly display all the different propensities which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have here described when they go to the theatres; but it must be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledged that as yet a very small number of them go to theatres at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all. Although playgoers and plays have prodigiously increased in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States in the last forty years, the population indulges in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind of amusement with the greatest reserve. This is attributable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar causes, which the reader is already acquainted with, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which a few words will suffice to remind him. The Puritans who founded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American republics were not only enemies to amusements, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: professed an especial abhorrence for the stage. They considered it as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an abominable pastime; and as long as their principles prevailed with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undivided sway, scenic performances were wholly unknown amongst them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These opinions of the first fathers of the colony have left very deep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: marks on the minds of their descendants. The extreme regularity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits and the great strictness of manners which are observable in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States, have as yet opposed additional obstacles to the growth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of dramatic art. There are no dramatic subjects in a country which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: witnessed no great political catastrophes, and in which love invariably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leads by a straight and easy road to matrimony. People who spend every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day in the week in making money, and the Sunday in going to church, have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing to invite the muse of Comedy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A single fact suffices to show that the stage is not very popular in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States. The Americans, whose laws allow of the utmost freedom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and even license of language in all other respects, have nevertheless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjected their dramatic authors to a sort of censorship. Theatrical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: performances can only take place by permission of the municipal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authorities. This may serve to show how much communities are like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals; they surrender themselves unscrupulously to their ruling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions, and afterwards take the greatest care not to yield too much to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the vehemence of tastes which they do not possess.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No portion of literature is connected by closer or more numerous ties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the present condition of society than the drama. The drama of one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: period can never be suited to the following age, if in the interval an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important revolution has changed the manners and the laws of the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The great authors of a preceding age may be read; but pieces written
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for a different public will not be followed. The dramatic authors of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: past live only in books. The traditional taste of certain individuals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vanity, fashion, or the genius of an actor may sustain or resuscitate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for a time the aristocratic drama amongst a democracy; but it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speedily fall away of itself--not overthrown, but abandoned.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XX: Characteristics Of Historians In Democratic Ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Historians who write in aristocratic ages are wont to refer all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurrences to the particular will or temper of certain individuals; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are apt to attribute the most important revolutions to very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slight accidents. They trace out the smallest causes with sagacity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and frequently leave the greatest unperceived. Historians who live in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages exhibit precisely opposite characteristics. Most of them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attribute hardly any influence to the individual over the destiny of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: race, nor to citizens over the fate of a people; but, on the other hand,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they assign great general causes to all petty incidents. These contrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendencies explain each other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the historian of aristocratic ages surveys the theatre of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world, he at once perceives a very small number of prominent actors, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manage the whole piece. These great personages, who occupy the front of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the stage, arrest the observation, and fix it on themselves; and whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the historian is bent on penetrating the secret motives which make them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speak and act, the rest escape his memory. The importance of the things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which some men are seen to do, gives him an exaggerated estimate of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence which one man may possess; and naturally leads him to think,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in order to explain the impulses of the multitude, it is necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to refer them to the particular influence of some one individual.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When, on the contrary, all the citizens are independent of one another,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and each of them is individually weak, no one is seen to exert a great,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or still less a lasting power, over the community. At first sight,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals appear to be absolutely devoid of any influence over it;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and society would seem to advance alone by the free and voluntary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concurrence of all the men who compose it. This naturally prompts the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind to search for that general reason which operates upon so many men's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faculties at the same time, and turns them simultaneously in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am very well convinced that even amongst democratic nations, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genius, the vices, or the virtues of certain individuals retard or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accelerate the natural current of a people's history: but causes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this secondary and fortuitous nature are infinitely more various, more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concealed, more complex, less powerful, and consequently less easy to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trace in periods of equality than in ages of aristocracy, when the task
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the historian is simply to detach from the mass of general events the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular influences of one man or of a few men. In the former case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the historian is soon wearied by the toil; his mind loses itself in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labyrinth; and, in his inability clearly to discern or conspicuously to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point out the influence of individuals, he denies their existence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He prefers talking about the characteristics of race, the physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conformation of the country, or the genius of civilization, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abridges his own labors, and satisfies his reader far better at less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cost.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: M. de Lafayette says somewhere in his "Memoirs" that the exaggerated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system of general causes affords surprising consolations to second-rate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: statesmen. I will add, that its effects are not less consolatory to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: second-rate historians; it can always furnish a few mighty reasons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to extricate them from the most difficult part of their work, and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indulges the indolence or incapacity of their minds, whilst it confers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon them the honors of deep thinking.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: For myself, I am of opinion that at all times one great portion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: events of this world are attributable to general facts, and another to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: special influences. These two kinds of cause are always in operation:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their proportion only varies. General facts serve to explain more things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democratic than in aristocratic ages, and fewer things are then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assignable to special influences. At periods of aristocracy the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reverse takes place: special influences are stronger, general causes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weaker--unless indeed we consider as a general cause the fact itself of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inequality of conditions, which allows some individuals to baffle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the natural tendencies of all the rest. The historians who seek to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: describe what occurs in democratic societies are right, therefore, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assigning much to general causes, and in devoting their chief attention
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to discover them; but they are wrong in wholly denying the special
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of individuals, because they cannot easily trace or follow it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The historians who live in democratic ages are not only prone to assign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great cause to every incident, but they are also given to connect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incidents together, so as to deduce a system from them. In aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ages, as the attention of historians is constantly drawn to individuals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the connection of events escapes them; or rather, they do not believe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in any such connection. To them the clew of history seems every instant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crossed and broken by the step of man. In democratic ages, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, as the historian sees much more of actions than of actors, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may easily establish some kind of sequency and methodical order amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the former. Ancient literature, which is so rich in fine historical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compositions, does not contain a single great historical system, whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the poorest of modern literatures abound with them. It would appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the ancient historians did not make sufficient use of those general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: theories which our historical writers are ever ready to carry to excess.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Those who write in democratic ages have another more dangerous tendency.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the traces of individual action upon nations are lost, it often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happens that the world goes on to move, though the moving agent is no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer discoverable. As it becomes extremely difficult to discern and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to analyze the reasons which, acting separately on the volition of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: member of the community, concur in the end to produce movement in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: old mass, men are led to believe that this movement is involuntary, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that societies unconsciously obey some superior force ruling over them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But even when the general fact which governs the private volition of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals is supposed to be discovered upon the earth, the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of human free-will is not secure. A cause sufficiently extensive to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affect millions of men at once, and sufficiently strong to bend them all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together in the same direction, may well seem irresistible: having seen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that mankind do yield to it, the mind is close upon the inference that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind cannot resist it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Historians who live in democratic ages, then, not only deny that the few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have any power of acting upon the destiny of a people, but they deprive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people themselves of the power of modifying their own condition, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they subject them either to an inflexible Providence, or to some blind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessity. According to them, each nation is indissolubly bound by its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position, its origin, its precedents, and its character, to a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lot which no efforts can ever change. They involve generation in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generation, and thus, going back from age to age, and from necessity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to necessity, up to the origin of the world, they forge a close and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enormous chain, which girds and binds the human race. To their minds it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not enough to show what events have occurred: they would fain show
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that events could not have occurred otherwise. They take a nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrived at a certain stage of its history, and they affirm that it could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not but follow the track which brought it thither. It is easier to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make such an assertion than to show by what means the nation might have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adopted a better course.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In reading the historians of aristocratic ages, and especially those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: antiquity, it would seem that, to be master of his lot, and to govern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his fellow-creatures, man requires only to be master of himself. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perusing the historical volumes which our age has produced, it would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem that man is utterly powerless over himself and over all around him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The historians of antiquity taught how to command: those of our time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: teach only how to obey; in their writings the author often appears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great, but humanity is always diminutive. If this doctrine of necessity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is so attractive to those who write history in democratic ages,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passes from authors to their readers, till it infects the whole mass
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community and gets possession of the public mind, it will soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: paralyze the activity of modern society, and reduce Christians to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: level of the Turks. I would moreover observe, that such principles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are peculiarly dangerous at the period at which we are arrived. Our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries are but too prone to doubt of the human free-will,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because each of them feels himself confined on every side by his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weakness; but they are still willing to acknowledge the strength and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence of men united in society. Let not this principle be lost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sight of; for the great object in our time is to raise the faculties of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, not to complete their prostration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XXI: Of Parliamentary Eloquence In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations all the members of the community are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connected with and dependent upon each other; the graduated scale of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different ranks acts as a tie, which keeps everyone in his proper place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the whole body in subordination. Something of the same kind always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurs in the political assemblies of these nations. Parties naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: range themselves under certain leaders, whom they obey by a sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instinct, which is only the result of habits contracted elsewhere. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carry the manners of general society into the lesser assemblage.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democratic countries it often happens that a great number of citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are tending to the same point; but each one only moves thither, or at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: least flatters himself that he moves, of his own accord. Accustomed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulate his doings by personal impulse alone, he does not willingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submit to dictation from without. This taste and habit of independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accompany him into the councils of the nation. If he consents to connect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself with other men in the prosecution of the same purpose, at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he chooses to remain free to contribute to the common success after his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own fashion. Hence it is that in democratic countries parties are so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impatient of control, and are never manageable except in moments of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great public danger. Even then, the authority of leaders, which under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such circumstances may be able to make men act or speak, hardly ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reaches the extent of making them keep silence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations the members of political assemblies are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the same time members of the aristocracy. Each of them enjoys high
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established rank in his own right, and the position which he occupies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the assembly is often less important in his eyes than that which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he fills in the country. This consoles him for playing no part in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the discussion of public affairs, and restrains him from too eagerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempting to play an insignificant one.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America, it generally happens that a Representative only becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: somebody from his position in the Assembly. He is therefore perpetually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: haunted by a craving to acquire importance there, and he feels a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: petulant desire to be constantly obtruding his opinions upon the House.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: His own vanity is not the only stimulant which urges him on in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course, but that of his constituents, and the continual necessity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of propitiating them. Amongst aristocratic nations a member of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislature is rarely in strict dependence upon his constituents: he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently to them a sort of unavoidable representative; sometimes they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are themselves strictly dependent upon him; and if at length they reject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him, he may easily get elected elsewhere, or, retiring from public life,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he may still enjoy the pleasures of splendid idleness. In a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country like the United States a Representative has hardly ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a lasting hold on the minds of his constituents. However small an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: electoral body may be, the fluctuations of democracy are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changing its aspect; it must, therefore, be courted unceasingly. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is never sure of his supporters, and, if they forsake him, he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: left without a resource; for his natural position is not sufficiently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elevated for him to be easily known to those not close to him; and,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the complete state of independence prevailing among the people, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot hope that his friends or the government will send him down to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: returned by an electoral body unacquainted with him. The seeds of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune are, therefore, sown in his own neighborhood; from that nook of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: earth he must start, to raise himself to the command of a people and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to influence the destinies of the world. Thus it is natural that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic countries the members of political assemblies think more of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their constituents than of their party, whilst in aristocracies they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: think more of their party than of their constituents.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But what ought to be said to gratify constituents is not always what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought to be said in order to serve the party to which Representatives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profess to belong. The general interest of a party frequently demands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that members belonging to it should not speak on great questions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they understand imperfectly; that they should speak but little on those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minor questions which impede the great ones; lastly, and for the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part, that they should not speak at all. To keep silence is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most useful service that an indifferent spokesman can render to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonwealth. Constituents, however, do not think so. The population of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a district sends a representative to take a part in the government of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a country, because they entertain a very lofty notion of his merits.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As men appear greater in proportion to the littleness of the objects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by which they are surrounded, it may be assumed that the opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertained of the delegate will be so much the higher as talents are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more rare among his constituents. It will therefore frequently happen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the less constituents have to expect from their representative, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more they will anticipate from him; and, however incompetent he may be,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will not fail to call upon him for signal exertions, corresponding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the rank they have conferred upon him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Independently of his position as a legislator of the State, electors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: also regard their Representative as the natural patron of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constituency in the Legislature; they almost consider him as the proxy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of each of his supporters, and they flatter themselves that he will not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be less zealous in defense of their private interests than of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the country. Thus electors are well assured beforehand that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representative of their choice will be an orator; that he will speak
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often if he can, and that in case he is forced to refrain, he will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strive at any rate to compress into his less frequent orations an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquiry into all the great questions of state, combined with a statement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all the petty grievances they have themselves to complain to; so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, though he be not able to come forward frequently, he should on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each occasion prove what he is capable of doing; and that, instead of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually lavishing his powers, he should occasionally condense them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a small compass, so as to furnish a sort of complete and brilliant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: epitome of his constituents and of himself. On these terms they will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vote for him at the next election. These conditions drive worthy men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: humble abilities to despair, who, knowing their own powers, would never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: voluntarily have come forward. But thus urged on, the Representative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: begins to speak, to the great alarm of his friends; and rushing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imprudently into the midst of the most celebrated orators, he perplexes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the debate and wearies the House.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All laws which tend to make the Representative more dependent on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elector, not only affect the conduct of the legislators, as I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have remarked elsewhere, but also their language. They exercise a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simultaneous influence on affairs themselves, and on the manner in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs are discussed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is hardly a member of Congress who can make up his mind to go home
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without having despatched at least one speech to his constituents;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor who will endure any interruption until he has introduced into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his harangue whatever useful suggestions may be made touching the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: four-and-twenty States of which the Union is composed, and especially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the district which he represents. He therefore presents to the mind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his auditors a succession of great general truths (which he himself only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comprehends, and expresses, confusedly), and of petty minutia, which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is but too able to discover and to point out. The consequence is that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the debates of that great assembly are frequently vague and perplexed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that they seem rather to drag their slow length along than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advance towards a distinct object. Some such state of things will, I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe, always arise in the public assemblies of democracies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Propitious circumstances and good laws might succeed in drawing to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislature of a democratic people men very superior to those who are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: returned by the Americans to Congress; but nothing will ever prevent the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men of slender abilities who sit there from obtruding themselves with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complacency, and in all ways, upon the public. The evil does not appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to me to be susceptible of entire cure, because it not only originates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the tactics of that assembly, but in its constitution and in that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the country. The inhabitants of the United States seem themselves to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider the matter in this light; and they show their long experience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of parliamentary life not by abstaining from making bad speeches, but by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courageously submitting to hear them made. They are resigned to it, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to an evil which they know to be inevitable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We have shown the petty side of political debates in democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assemblies--let us now exhibit the more imposing one. The proceedings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within the Parliament of England for the last one hundred and fifty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years have never occasioned any great sensation out of that country; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions and feelings expressed by the speakers have never awakened much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sympathy, even amongst the nations placed nearest to the great arena of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: British liberty; whereas Europe was excited by the very first debates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which took place in the small colonial assemblies of America at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time of the Revolution. This was attributable not only to particular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and fortuitous circumstances, but to general and lasting causes. I can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceive nothing more admirable or more powerful than a great orator
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: debating on great questions of state in a democratic assembly. As no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular class is ever represented there by men commissioned to defend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its own interests, it is always to the whole nation, and in the name of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the whole nation, that the orator speaks. This expands his thoughts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and heightens his power of language. As precedents have there but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little weight-as there are no longer any privileges attached to certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property, nor any rights inherent in certain bodies or in certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals, the mind must have recourse to general truths derived from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human nature to resolve the particular question under discussion. Hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the political debates of a democratic people, however small it may be,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have a degree of breadth which frequently renders them attractive to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind. All men are interested by them, because they treat of man, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is everywhere the same. Amongst the greatest aristocratic nations, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contrary, the most general questions are almost always argued on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some special grounds derived from the practice of a particular time, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rights of a particular class; which interest that class alone, or at
