author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most the people amongst whom that class happens to exist. It is owing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to this, as much as to the greatness of the French people, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable disposition of the nations who listen to them, that the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effect which the French political debates sometimes produce in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world, must be attributed. The orators of France frequently speak to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind, even when they are addressing their countrymen only.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 2: Influence of Democracy on the Feelings of Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter I: Why Democratic Nations Show A More Ardent And Enduring Love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of Equality Than Of Liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first and most intense passion which is engendered by the equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conditions is, I need hardly say, the love of that same equality. My
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readers will therefore not be surprised that I speak of its before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all others. Everybody has remarked that in our time, and especially in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France, this passion for equality is every day gaining ground in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human heart. It has been said a hundred times that our contemporaries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are far more ardently and tenaciously attached to equality than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom; but as I do not find that the causes of the fact have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently analyzed, I shall endeavor to point them out.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is possible to imagine an extreme point at which freedom and equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would meet and be confounded together. Let us suppose that all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community take a part in the government, and that each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them has an equal right to take a part in it. As none is different from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his fellows, none can exercise a tyrannical power: men will be perfectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free, because they will all be entirely equal; and they will all be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfectly equal, because they will be entirely free. To this ideal state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations tend. Such is the completest form that equality can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assume upon earth; but there are a thousand others which, without being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equally perfect, are not less cherished by those nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principle of equality may be established in civil society, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevailing in the political world. Equal rights may exist of indulging
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the same pleasures, of entering the same professions, of frequenting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same places--in a word, of living in the same manner and seeking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth by the same means, although all men do not take an equal share
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the government. A kind of equality may even be established in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political world, though there should be no political freedom there. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man may be the equal of all his countrymen save one, who is the master
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all without distinction, and who selects equally from among them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the agents of his power. Several other combinations might be easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagined, by which very great equality would be united to institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more or less free, or even to institutions wholly without freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although men cannot become absolutely equal unless they be entirely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free, and consequently equality, pushed to its furthest extent, may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confounded with freedom, yet there is good reason for distinguishing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one from the other. The taste which men have for liberty, and that which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they feel for equality, are, in fact, two different things; and I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not afraid to add that, amongst democratic nations, they are two unequal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Upon close inspection, it will be seen that there is in every age some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar and preponderating fact with which all others are connected;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this fact almost always gives birth to some pregnant idea or some ruling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passion, which attracts to itself, and bears away in its course, all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feelings and opinions of the time: it is like a great stream, towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which each of the surrounding rivulets seems to flow. Freedom has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeared in the world at different times and under various forms; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has not been exclusively bound to any social condition, and it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not confined to democracies. Freedom cannot, therefore, form the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguishing characteristic of democratic ages. The peculiar and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preponderating fact which marks those ages as its own is the equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conditions; the ruling passion of men in those periods is the love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this equality. Ask not what singular charm the men of democratic ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find in being equal, or what special reasons they may have for clinging
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so tenaciously to equality rather than to the other advantages which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society holds out to them: equality is the distinguishing characteristic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the age they live in; that, of itself, is enough to explain that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prefer it to all the rest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But independently of this reason there are several others, which will at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all times habitually lead men to prefer equality to freedom. If a people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could ever succeed in destroying, or even in diminishing, the equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which prevails in its own body, this could only be accomplished by long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and laborious efforts. Its social condition must be modified, its laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolished, its opinions superseded, its habits changed, its manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corrupted. But political liberty is more easily lost; to neglect to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hold it fast is to allow it to escape. Men therefore not only cling to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality because it is dear to them; they also adhere to it because they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: think it will last forever.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: That political freedom may compromise in its excesses the tranquillity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the property, the lives of individuals, is obvious to the narrowest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and most unthinking minds. But, on the contrary, none but attentive and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clear-sighted men perceive the perils with which equality threatens us,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they commonly avoid pointing them out. They know that the calamities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they apprehend are remote, and flatter themselves that they will only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fall upon future generations, for which the present generation takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but little thought. The evils which freedom sometimes brings with it are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediate; they are apparent to all, and all are more or less affected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by them. The evils which extreme equality may produce are slowly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disclosed; they creep gradually into the social frame; they are only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seen at intervals, and at the moment at which they become most violent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habit already causes them to be no longer felt. The advantages which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom brings are only shown by length of time; and it is always easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to mistake the cause in which they originate. The advantages of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are instantaneous, and they may constantly be traced from their source.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Political liberty bestows exalted pleasures, from time to time, upon a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain number of citizens. Equality every day confers a number of small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyments on every man. The charms of equality are every instant felt,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and are within the reach of all; the noblest hearts are not insensible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them, and the most vulgar souls exult in them. The passion which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality engenders must therefore be at once strong and general. Men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot enjoy political liberty unpurchased by some sacrifices, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never obtain it without great exertions. But the pleasures of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are self-proffered: each of the petty incidents of life seems to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occasion them, and in order to taste them nothing is required but to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: live.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic nations are at all times fond of equality, but there are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain epochs at which the passion they entertain for it swells to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: height of fury. This occurs at the moment when the old social system,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long menaced, completes its own destruction after a last intestine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggle, and when the barriers of rank are at length thrown down. At
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such times men pounce upon equality as their booty, and they cling to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it as to some precious treasure which they fear to lose. The passion for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality penetrates on every side into men's hearts, expands there,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and fills them entirely. Tell them not that by this blind surrender of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to an exclusive passion they risk their dearest interests:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are deaf. Show them not freedom escaping from their grasp, whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are looking another way: they are blind--or rather, they can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discern but one sole object to be desired in the universe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What I have said is applicable to all democratic nations: what I am
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about to say concerns the French alone. Amongst most modern nations, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially amongst all those of the Continent of Europe, the taste and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the idea of freedom only began to exist and to extend themselves at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the time when social conditions were tending to equality, and as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a consequence of that very equality. Absolute kings were the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efficient levellers of ranks amongst their subjects. Amongst these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations equality preceded freedom: equality was therefore a fact of some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: standing when freedom was still a novelty: the one had already created
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customs, opinions, and laws belonging to it, when the other, alone and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the first time, came into actual existence. Thus the latter was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still only an affair of opinion and of taste, whilst the former had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already crept into the habits of the people, possessed itself of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners, and given a particular turn to the smallest actions of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lives. Can it be wondered that the men of our own time prefer the one to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that democratic communities have a natural taste for freedom:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: left to themselves, they will seek it, cherish it, and view any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privation of it with regret. But for equality, their passion is ardent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insatiable, incessant, invincible: they call for equality in freedom;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and if they cannot obtain that, they still call for equality in slavery.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They will endure poverty, servitude, barbarism--but they will not endure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy. This is true at all times, and especially true in our own.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All men and all powers seeking to cope with this irresistible passion,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be overthrown and destroyed by it. In our age, freedom cannot be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established without it, and despotism itself cannot reign without its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: support.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter II: Of Individualism In Democratic Countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown how it is that in ages of equality every man seeks for his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions within himself: I am now about to show how it is that, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same ages, all his feelings are turned towards himself alone.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Individualism *a is a novel expression, to which a novel idea has given
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: birth. Our fathers were only acquainted with egotism. Egotism is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passionate and exaggerated love of self, which leads a man to connect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything with his own person, and to prefer himself to everything in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world. Individualism is a mature and calm feeling, which disposes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each member of the community to sever himself from the mass of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-creatures; and to draw apart with his family and his friends; so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, after he has thus formed a little circle of his own, he willingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leaves society at large to itself. Egotism originates in blind instinct:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individualism proceeds from erroneous judgment more than from depraved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feelings; it originates as much in the deficiencies of the mind as in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the perversity of the heart. Egotism blights the germ of all virtue;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individualism, at first, only saps the virtues of public life; but,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the long run, it attacks and destroys all others, and is at length
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absorbed in downright egotism. Egotism is a vice as old as the world,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which does not belong to one form of society more than to another:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individualism is of democratic origin, and it threatens to spread in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same ratio as the equality of conditions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: [I adopt the expression of the original, however strange it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may seem to the English ear, partly because it illustrates the remark
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the introduction of general terms into democratic language which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made in a preceding chapter, and partly because I know of no English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: word exactly equivalent to the expression. The chapter itself defines
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the meaning attached to it by the author.--Translator's Note.]]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations, as families remain for centuries in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same condition, often on the same spot, all generations become as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were contemporaneous. A man almost always knows his forefathers, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respects them: he thinks he already sees his remote descendants, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: loves them. He willingly imposes duties on himself towards the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former and the latter; and he will frequently sacrifice his personal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratifications to those who went before and to those who will come after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him. Aristocratic institutions have, moreover, the effect of closely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: binding every man to several of his fellow-citizens. As the classes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an aristocratic people are strongly marked and permanent, each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them is regarded by its own members as a sort of lesser country,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more tangible and more cherished than the country at large. As in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic communities all the citizens occupy fixed positions, one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: above the other, the result is that each of them always sees a man above
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself whose patronage is necessary to him, and below himself another
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man whose co-operation he may claim. Men living in aristocratic ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are therefore almost always closely attached to something placed out of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own sphere, and they are often disposed to forget themselves. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is true that in those ages the notion of human fellowship is faint, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that men seldom think of sacrificing themselves for mankind; but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often sacrifice themselves for other men. In democratic ages, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, when the duties of each individual to the race are much more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clear, devoted service to any one man becomes more rare; the bond of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human affection is extended, but it is relaxed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst democratic nations new families are constantly springing up,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others are constantly falling away, and all that remain change their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition; the woof of time is every instant broken, and the track of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generations effaced. Those who went before are soon forgotten; of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who will come after no one has any idea: the interest of man is confined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to those in close propinquity to himself. As each class approximates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to other classes, and intermingles with them, its members become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indifferent and as strangers to one another. Aristocracy had made a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chain of all the members of the community, from the peasant to the king:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy breaks that chain, and severs every link of it. As social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions become more equal, the number of persons increases who,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although they are neither rich enough nor powerful enough to exercise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any great influence over their fellow-creatures, have nevertheless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquired or retained sufficient education and fortune to satisfy their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own wants. They owe nothing to any man, they expect nothing from any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man; they acquire the habit of always considering themselves as standing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alone, and they are apt to imagine that their whole destiny is in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own hands. Thus not only does democracy make every man forget
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his ancestors, but it hides his descendants, and separates his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries from him; it throws him back forever upon himself alone,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and threatens in the end to confine him entirely within the solitude of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his own heart.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter III: Individualism Stronger At The Close Of A Democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Revolution Than At Other Periods
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The period when the construction of democratic society upon the ruins of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an aristocracy has just been completed, is especially that at which this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separation of men from one another, and the egotism resulting from it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most forcibly strike the observation. Democratic communities not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contain a large number of independent citizens, but they are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: filled with men who, having entered but yesterday upon their independent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition, are intoxicated with their new power. They entertain a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: presumptuous confidence in their strength, and as they do not suppose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they can henceforward ever have occasion to claim the assistance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their fellow-creatures, they do not scruple to show that they care for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nobody but themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An aristocracy seldom yields without a protracted struggle, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course of which implacable animosities are kindled between the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes of society. These passions survive the victory, and traces of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them may be observed in the midst of the democratic confusion which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ensues. Those members of the community who were at the top of the late
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradations of rank cannot immediately forget their former greatness;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will long regard themselves as aliens in the midst of the newly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed society. They look upon all those whom this state of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has made their equals as oppressors, whose destiny can excite no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sympathy; they have lost sight of their former equals, and feel no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer bound by a common interest to their fate: each of them, standing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aloof, thinks that he is reduced to care for himself alone. Those, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contrary, who were formerly at the foot of the social scale, and who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been brought up to the common level by a sudden revolution, cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoy their newly acquired independence without secret uneasiness; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if they meet with some of their former superiors on the same footing as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, they stand aloof from them with an expression of triumph and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of fear. It is, then, commonly at the outset of democratic society that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens are most disposed to live apart. Democracy leads men not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: draw near to their fellow-creatures; but democratic revolutions lead
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them to shun each other, and perpetuate in a state of equality the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animosities which the state of inequality engendered. The great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantage of the Americans is that they have arrived at a state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy without having to endure a democratic revolution; and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are born equal, instead of becoming so.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IV: That The Americans Combat The Effects Of Individualism By
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Free Institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Despotism, which is of a very timorous nature, is never more secure of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continuance than when it can keep men asunder; and all is influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is commonly exerted for that purpose. No vice of the human heart is so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acceptable to it as egotism: a despot easily forgives his subjects for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not loving him, provided they do not love each other. He does not ask
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them to assist him in governing the State; it is enough that they do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aspire to govern it themselves. He stigmatizes as turbulent and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unruly spirits those who would combine their exertions to promote the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity of the community, and, perverting the natural meaning of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words, he applauds as good citizens those who have no sympathy for any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but themselves. Thus the vices which despotism engenders are precisely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those which equality fosters. These two things mutually and perniciously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complete and assist each other. Equality places men side by side,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unconnected by any common tie; despotism raises barriers to keep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them asunder; the former predisposes them not to consider their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-creatures, the latter makes general indifference a sort of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtue.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Despotism then, which is at all times dangerous, is more particularly to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be feared in democratic ages. It is easy to see that in those same ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men stand most in need of freedom. When the members of a community are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forced to attend to public affairs, they are necessarily drawn from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the circle of their own interests, and snatched at times from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self-observation. As soon as a man begins to treat of public affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in public, he begins to perceive that he is not so independent of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-men as he had at first imagined, and that, in order to obtain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their support, he must often lend them his co-operation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the public is supreme, there is no man who does not feel the value
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of public goodwill, or who does not endeavor to court it by drawing to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself the esteem and affection of those amongst whom he is to live.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Many of the passions which congeal and keep asunder human hearts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are then obliged to retire and hide below the surface. Pride must be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dissembled; disdain dares not break out; egotism fears its own self.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Under a free government, as most public offices are elective, the men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whose elevated minds or aspiring hopes are too closely circumscribed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private life, constantly feel that they cannot do without the population
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which surrounds them. Men learn at such times to think of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-men from ambitious motives; and they frequently find it, in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner, their interest to forget themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I may here be met by an objection derived from electioneering intrigues,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the meannesses of candidates, and the calumnies of their opponents.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These are opportunities for animosity which occur the oftener the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequent elections become. Such evils are doubtless great, but they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transient; whereas the benefits which attend them remain. The desire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of being elected may lead some men for a time to violent hostility; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this same desire leads all men in the long run mutually to support
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other; and if it happens that an election accidentally severs two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: friends, the electoral system brings a multitude of citizens permanently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together, who would always have remained unknown to each other. Freedom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engenders private animosities, but despotism gives birth to general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indifference.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans have combated by free institutions the tendency of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality to keep men asunder, and they have subdued it. The legislators
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of America did not suppose that a general representation of the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation would suffice to ward off a disorder at once so natural to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frame of democratic society, and so fatal: they also thought that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it would be well to infuse political life into each portion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: territory, in order to multiply to an infinite extent opportunities of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acting in concert for all the members of the community, and to make them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly feel their mutual dependence on each other. The plan was a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wise one. The general affairs of a country only engage the attention of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leading politicians, who assemble from time to time in the same places;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and as they often lose sight of each other afterwards, no lasting ties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are established between them. But if the object be to have the local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs of a district conducted by the men who reside there, the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons are always in contact, and they are, in a manner, forced to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquainted, and to adapt themselves to one another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is difficult to draw a man out of his own circle to interest him in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the destiny of the State, because he does not clearly understand what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence the destiny of the State can have upon his own lot. But if it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be proposed to make a road cross the end of his estate, he will see at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a glance that there is a connection between this small public affair and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his greatest private affairs; and he will discover, without its being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shown to him, the close tie which unites private to general interest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, far more may be done by intrusting to the citizens the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration of minor affairs than by surrendering to them the control
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of important ones, towards interesting them in the public welfare, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convincing them that they constantly stand in need one of the other in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to provide for it. A brilliant achievement may win for you the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favor of a people at one stroke; but to earn the love and respect of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the population which surrounds you, a long succession of little services
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rendered and of obscure good deeds--a constant habit of kindness, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an established reputation for disinterestedness--will be required.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Local freedom, then, which leads a great number of citizens to value the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affection of their neighbors and of their kindred, perpetually brings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men together, and forces them to help one another, in spite of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities which sever them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the more opulent citizens take great care not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stand aloof from the people; on the contrary, they constantly keep on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easy terms with the lower classes: they listen to them, they speak to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them every day. They know that the rich in democracies always stand in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: need of the poor; and that in democratic ages you attach a poor man to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: you more by your manner than by benefits conferred. The magnitude of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such benefits, which sets off the difference of conditions, causes a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secret irritation to those who reap advantage from them; but the charm
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of simplicity of manners is almost irresistible: their affability
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carries men away, and even their want of polish is not always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: displeasing. This truth does not take root at once in the minds of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich. They generally resist it as long as the democratic revolution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lasts, and they do not acknowledge it immediately after that revolution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is accomplished. They are very ready to do good to the people, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they still choose to keep them at arm's length; they think that is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficient, but they are mistaken. They might spend fortunes thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without warming the hearts of the population around them;--that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population does not ask them for the sacrifice of their money, but of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their pride.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would seem as if every imagination in the United States were upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the stretch to invent means of increasing the wealth and satisfying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the wants of the public. The best-informed inhabitants of each district
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly use their information to discover new truths which may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augment the general prosperity; and if they have made any such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discoveries, they eagerly surrender them to the mass of the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the vices and weaknesses, frequently exhibited by those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: govern in America, are closely examined, the prosperity of the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occasions--but improperly occasions--surprise. Elected magistrates do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not make the American democracy flourish; it flourishes because the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: magistrates are elective.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would be unjust to suppose that the patriotism and the zeal which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every American displays for the welfare of his fellow-citizens are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wholly insincere. Although private interest directs the greater part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of human actions in the United States as well as elsewhere, it does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not regulate them all. I must say that I have often seen Americans make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great and real sacrifices to the public welfare; and I have remarked
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a hundred instances in which they hardly ever failed to lend faithful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: support to each other. The free institutions which the inhabitants of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States possess, and the political rights of which they make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so much use, remind every citizen, and in a thousand ways, that he lives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in society. They every instant impress upon his mind the notion that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the duty, as well as the interest of men, to make themselves useful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to their fellow-creatures; and as he sees no particular ground of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: animosity to them, since he is never either their master or their slave,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his heart readily leans to the side of kindness. Men attend to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests of the public, first by necessity, afterwards by choice: what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was intentional becomes an instinct; and by dint of working for the good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of one's fellow citizens, the habit and the taste for serving them is at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: length acquired.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Many people in France consider equality of conditions as one evil, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political freedom as a second. When they are obliged to yield to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former, they strive at least to escape from the latter. But I contend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in order to combat the evils which equality may produce, there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only one effectual remedy--namely, political freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter V: Of The Use Which The Americans Make Of Public Associations In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Civil Life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not propose to speak of those political associations--by the aid of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which men endeavor to defend themselves against the despotic influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a majority--or against the aggressions of regal power. That subject I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have already treated. If each citizen did not learn, in proportion as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he individually becomes more feeble, and consequently more incapable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of preserving his freedom single-handed, to combine with his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-citizens for the purpose of defending it, it is clear that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tyranny would unavoidably increase together with equality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Those associations only which are formed in civil life, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reference to political objects, are here adverted to. The political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations which exist in the United States are only a single feature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of the immense assemblage of associations in that country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans of all ages, all conditions, and all dispositions, constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form associations. They have not only commercial and manufacturing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: companies, in which all take part, but associations of a thousand other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kinds--religious, moral, serious, futile, extensive, or restricted,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enormous or diminutive. The Americans make associations to give
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertainments, to found establishments for education, to build inns,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to construct churches, to diffuse books, to send missionaries to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the antipodes; and in this manner they found hospitals, prisons, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: schools. If it be proposed to advance some truth, or to foster some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feeling by the encouragement of a great example, they form a society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Wherever, at the head of some new undertaking, you see the government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in France, or a man of rank in England, in the United States you will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sure to find an association. I met with several kinds of associations in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, of which I confess I had no previous notion; and I have often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admired the extreme skill with which the inhabitants of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States succeed in proposing a common object to the exertions of a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many men, and in getting them voluntarily to pursue it. I have since
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: travelled over England, whence the Americans have taken some of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws and many of their customs; and it seemed to me that the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of association was by no means so constantly or so adroitly used in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that country. The English often perform great things singly; whereas the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans form associations for the smallest undertakings. It is evident
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the former people consider association as a powerful means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action, but the latter seem to regard it as the only means they have of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acting.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the most democratic country on the face of the earth is that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which men have in our time carried to the highest perfection the art of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuing in common the object of their common desires, and have applied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this new science to the greatest number of purposes. Is this the result
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of accident? or is there in reality any necessary connection between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of association and that of equality? Aristocratic communities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always contain, amongst a multitude of persons who by themselves are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerless, a small number of powerful and wealthy citizens, each of whom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can achieve great undertakings single-handed. In aristocratic societies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men do not need to combine in order to act, because they are strongly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: held together. Every wealthy and powerful citizen constitutes the head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a permanent and compulsory association, composed of all those who are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependent upon him, or whom he makes subservient to the execution of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: designs. Amongst democratic nations, on the contrary, all the citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are independent and feeble; they can do hardly anything by themselves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and none of them can oblige his fellow-men to lend him their assistance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They all, therefore, fall into a state of incapacity, if they do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learn voluntarily to help each other. If men living in democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries had no right and no inclination to associate for political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purposes, their independence would be in great jeopardy; but they might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long preserve their wealth and their cultivation: whereas if they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never acquired the habit of forming associations in ordinary life,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilization itself would be endangered. A people amongst which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals should lose the power of achieving great things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: single-handed, without acquiring the means of producing them by united
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions, would soon relapse into barbarism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Unhappily, the same social condition which renders associations so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary to democratic nations, renders their formation more difficult
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst those nations than amongst all others. When several members of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an aristocracy agree to combine, they easily succeed in doing so; as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each of them brings great strength to the partnership, the number of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members may be very limited; and when the members of an association
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are limited in number, they may easily become mutually acquainted,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understand each other, and establish fixed regulations. The same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opportunities do not occur amongst democratic nations, where the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associated members must always be very numerous for their association to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have any power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am aware that many of my countrymen are not in the least embarrassed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by this difficulty. They contend that the more enfeebled and incompetent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the citizens become, the more able and active the government ought to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be rendered, in order that society at large may execute what individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can no longer accomplish. They believe this answers the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty, but I think they are mistaken. A government might perform
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the part of some of the largest American companies; and several States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the Union, have already attempted it; but what political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power could ever carry on the vast multitude of lesser undertakings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the American citizens perform every day, with the assistance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principle of association? It is easy to foresee that the time is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: drawing near when man will be less and less able to produce, of himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alone, the commonest necessaries of life. The task of the governing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power will therefore perpetually increase, and its very efforts will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extend it every day. The more it stands in the place of associations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the more will individuals, losing the notion of combining together,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: require its assistance: these are causes and effects which unceasingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engender each other. Will the administration of the country ultimately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assume the management of all the manufacturers, which no single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen is able to carry on? And if a time at length arrives, when, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence of the extreme subdivision of landed property, the soil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is split into an infinite number of parcels, so that it can only be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivated by companies of husbandmen, will it be necessary that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: head of the government should leave the helm of state to follow the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plough? The morals and the intelligence of a democratic people would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as much endangered as its business and manufactures, if the government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever wholly usurped the place of private companies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Feelings and opinions are recruited, the heart is enlarged, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human mind is developed by no other means than by the reciprocal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence of men upon each other. I have shown that these influences are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost null in democratic countries; they must therefore be artificially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: created, and this can only be accomplished by associations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the members of an aristocratic community adopt a new opinion, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceive a new sentiment, they give it a station, as it were, beside
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, upon the lofty platform where they stand; and opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or sentiments so conspicuous to the eyes of the multitude are easily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced into the minds or hearts of all around. In democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries the governing power alone is naturally in a condition to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: act in this manner; but it is easy to see that its action is always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inadequate, and often dangerous. A government can no more be competent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to keep alive and to renew the circulation of opinions and feelings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst a great people, than to manage all the speculations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productive industry. No sooner does a government attempt to go
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beyond its political sphere and to enter upon this new track, than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it exercises, even unintentionally, an insupportable tyranny; for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government can only dictate strict rules, the opinions which it favors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are rigidly enforced, and it is never easy to discriminate between its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advice and its commands. Worse still will be the case if the government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: really believes itself interested in preventing all circulation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideas; it will then stand motionless, and oppressed by the heaviness of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: voluntary torpor. Governments therefore should not be the only active
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers: associations ought, in democratic nations, to stand in lieu of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those powerful private individuals whom the equality of conditions has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: swept away.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As soon as several of the inhabitants of the United States have taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up an opinion or a feeling which they wish to promote in the world,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they look out for mutual assistance; and as soon as they have found each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other out, they combine. From that moment they are no longer isolated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, but a power seen from afar, whose actions serve for an example,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and whose language is listened to. The first time I heard in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States that 100,000 men had bound themselves publicly to abstain from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirituous liquors, it appeared to me more like a joke than a serious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engagement; and I did not at once perceive why these temperate citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could not content themselves with drinking water by their own firesides.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I at last understood that 300,000 Americans, alarmed by the progress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of drunkenness around them, had made up their minds to patronize
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temperance. They acted just in the same way as a man of high rank who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should dress very plainly, in order to inspire the humbler orders with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a contempt of luxury. It is probable that if these 100,000 men had lived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in France, each of them would singly have memorialized the government to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: watch the public-houses all over the kingdom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing, in my opinion, is more deserving of our attention than the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellectual and moral associations of America. The political and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industrial associations of that country strike us forcibly; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others elude our observation, or if we discover them, we understand them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperfectly, because we have hardly ever seen anything of the kind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must, however, be acknowledged that they are as necessary to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American people as the former, and perhaps more so. In democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries the science of association is the mother of science; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress of all the rest depends upon the progress it has made. Amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws which rule human societies there is one which seems to be more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precise and clear than all others. If men are to remain civilized, or to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become so, the art of associating together must grow and improve in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same ratio in which the equality of conditions is increased.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VI: Of The Relation Between Public Associations And Newspapers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When men are no longer united amongst themselves by firm and lasting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ties, it is impossible to obtain the cooperation of any great number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them, unless you can persuade every man whose concurrence you require
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that this private interest obliges him voluntarily to unite his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions to the exertions of all the rest. This can only be habitually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and conveniently effected by means of a newspaper; nothing but a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: newspaper can drop the same thought into a thousand minds at the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moment. A newspaper is an adviser who does not require to be sought, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who comes of his own accord, and talks to you briefly every day of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common weal, without distracting you from your private affairs.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Newspapers therefore become more necessary in proportion as men become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more equal, and individualism more to be feared. To suppose that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only serve to protect freedom would be to diminish their importance:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they maintain civilization. I shall not deny that in democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries newspapers frequently lead the citizens to launch together in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very ill-digested schemes; but if there were no newspapers there would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be no common activity. The evil which they produce is therefore much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less than that which they cure.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The effect of a newspaper is not only to suggest the same purpose to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great number of persons, but also to furnish means for executing in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common the designs which they may have singly conceived. The principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens who inhabit an aristocratic country discern each other from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afar; and if they wish to unite their forces, they move towards each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, drawing a multitude of men after them. It frequently happens, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contrary, in democratic countries, that a great number of men who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wish or who want to combine cannot accomplish it, because as they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very insignificant and lost amidst the crowd, they cannot see, and know
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not where to find, one another. A newspaper then takes up the notion or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the feeling which had occurred simultaneously, but singly, to each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. All are then immediately guided towards this beacon; and these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wandering minds, which had long sought each other in darkness, at length
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: meet and unite.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The newspaper brought them together, and the newspaper is still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary to keep them united. In order that an association amongst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people should have any power, it must be a numerous body.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The persons of whom it is composed are therefore scattered over a wide
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent, and each of them is detained in the place of his domicile by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: narrowness of his income, or by the small unremitting exertions by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he earns it. Means then must be found to converse every day without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seeing each other, and to take steps in common without having met. Thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardly any democratic association can do without newspapers. There is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently a necessary connection between public associations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and newspapers: newspapers make associations, and associations make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: newspapers; and if it has been correctly advanced that associations will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase in number as the conditions of men become more equal, it is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less certain that the number of newspapers increases in proportion to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of associations. Thus it is in America that we find at the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time the greatest number of associations and of newspapers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This connection between the number of newspapers and that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations leads us to the discovery of a further connection between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the state of the periodical press and the form of the administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a country; and shows that the number of newspapers must diminish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or increase amongst a democratic people, in proportion as its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration is more or less centralized. For amongst democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations the exercise of local powers cannot be intrusted to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principal members of the community as in aristocracies. Those powers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must either be abolished, or placed in the hands of very large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numbers of men, who then in fact constitute an association permanently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established by law for the purpose of administering the affairs of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain extent of territory; and they require a journal, to bring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them every day, in the midst of their own minor concerns, some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intelligence of the state of their public weal. The more numerous local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers are, the greater is the number of men in whom they are vested by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law; and as this want is hourly felt, the more profusely do newspapers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abound.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The extraordinary subdivision of administrative power has much more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to do with the enormous number of American newspapers than the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political freedom of the country and the absolute liberty of the press.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If all the inhabitants of the Union had the suffrage--but a suffrage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which should only extend to the choice of their legislators in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Congress--they would require but few newspapers, because they would only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have to act together on a few very important but very rare occasions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But within the pale of the great association of the nation, lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations have been established by law in every country, every city,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and indeed in every village, for the purposes of local administration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The laws of the country thus compel every American to co-operate every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day of his life with some of his fellow-citizens for a common purpose,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and each one of them requires a newspaper to inform him what all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others are doing.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am of opinion that a democratic people, *a without any national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative assemblies, but with a great number of small local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers, would have in the end more newspapers than another people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed by a centralized administration and an elective legislation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What best explains to me the enormous circulation of the daily press
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States, is that amongst the Americans I find the utmost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national freedom combined with local freedom of every kind. There is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a prevailing opinion in France and England that the circulation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: newspapers would be indefinitely increased by removing the taxes which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have been laid upon the press. This is a very exaggerated estimate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the effects of such a reform. Newspapers increase in numbers, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: according to their cheapness, but according to the more or less frequent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: want which a great number of men may feel for intercommunication and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combination.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: I say a democratic people: the administration of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic people may be the reverse of centralized, and yet the want
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of newspapers be little felt, because local powers are then vested in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hands of a very small number of men, who either act apart, or who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know each other and can easily meet and come to an understanding.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In like manner I should attribute the increasing influence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: daily press to causes more general than those by which it is commonly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explained. A newspaper can only subsist on the condition of publishing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sentiments or principles common to a large number of men. A newspaper
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore always represents an association which is composed of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitual readers. This association may be more or less defined, more or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less restricted, more or less numerous; but the fact that the newspaper
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: keeps alive, is a proof that at least the germ of such an association
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exists in the minds of its readers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This leads me to a last reflection, with which I shall conclude this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chapter. The more equal the conditions of men become, and the less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strong men individually are, the more easily do they give way to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: current of the multitude, and the more difficult is it for them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adhere by themselves to an opinion which the multitude discard. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: newspaper represents an association; it may be said to address each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its readers in the name of all the others, and to exert its influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over them in proportion to their individual weakness. The power of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: newspaper press must therefore increase as the social conditions of men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become more equal.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VII: Connection Of Civil And Political Associations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is only one country on the face of the earth where the citizens
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoy unlimited freedom of association for political purposes. This same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country is the only one in the world where the continual exercise of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of association has been introduced into civil life, and where all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the advantages which civilization can confer are procured by means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. In all the countries where political associations are prohibited,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civil associations are rare. It is hardly probable that this is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: result of accident; but the inference should rather be, that there is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural, and perhaps a necessary, connection between these two kinds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of associations. Certain men happen to have a common interest in some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concern--either a commercial undertaking is to be managed, or some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speculation in manufactures to be tried; they meet, they combine, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus by degrees they become familiar with the principle of association.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greater is the multiplicity of small affairs, the more do men, even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without knowing it, acquire facility in prosecuting great undertakings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in common. Civil associations, therefore, facilitate political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association: but, on the other hand, political association singularly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strengthens and improves associations for civil purposes. In civil life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every man may, strictly speaking, fancy that he can provide for his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants; in politics, he can fancy no such thing. When a people, then,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have any knowledge of public life, the notion of association, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wish to coalesce, present themselves every day to the minds of the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community: whatever natural repugnance may restrain men from acting in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concert, they will always be ready to combine for the sake of a party.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus political life makes the love and practice of association more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general; it imparts a desire of union, and teaches the means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combination to numbers of men who would have always lived apart.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Politics not only give birth to numerous associations, but to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations of great extent. In civil life it seldom happens that any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one interest draws a very large number of men to act in concert; much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: skill is required to bring such an interest into existence: but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics opportunities present themselves every day. Now it is solely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in great associations that the general value of the principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association is displayed. Citizens who are individually powerless,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not very clearly anticipate the strength which they may acquire by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uniting together; it must be shown to them in order to be understood.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hence it is often easier to collect a multitude for a public purpose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than a few persons; a thousand citizens do not see what interest they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have in combining together--ten thousand will be perfectly aware of it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In politics men combine for great undertakings; and the use they make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the principle of association in important affairs practically teaches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them that it is their interest to help each other in those of less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moment. A political association draws a number of individuals at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same time out of their own circle: however they may be naturally kept
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asunder by age, mind, and fortune, it places them nearer together and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brings them into contact. Once met, they can always meet again.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men can embark in few civil partnerships without risking a portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their possessions; this is the case with all manufacturing and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trading companies. When men are as yet but little versed in the art of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association, and are unacquainted with its principal rules, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are afraid, when first they combine in this manner, of buying their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience dear. They therefore prefer depriving themselves of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful instrument of success to running the risks which attend the use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of it. They are, however, less reluctant to join political associations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which appear to them to be without danger, because they adventure no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: money in them. But they cannot belong to these associations for any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: length of time without finding out how order is maintained amongst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large number of men, and by what contrivance they are made to advance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harmoniously and methodically, to the same object. Thus they learn to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surrender their own will to that of all the rest, and to make their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions subordinate to the common impulse--things which it is not less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary to know in civil than in political associations. Political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations may therefore be considered as large free schools, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the members of the community go to learn the general theory of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But even if political association did not directly contribute to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress of civil association, to destroy the former would be to impair
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the latter. When citizens can only meet in public for certain purposes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they regard such meetings as a strange proceeding of rare occurrence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they rarely think at all about it. When they are allowed to meet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freely for all purposes, they ultimately look upon public association
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the universal, or in a manner the sole means, which men can employ to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accomplish the different purposes they may have in view. Every new want
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instantly revives the notion. The art of association then becomes, as I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have said before, the mother of action, studied and applied by all.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When some kinds of associations are prohibited and others allowed, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult to distinguish the former from the latter, beforehand. In this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of doubt men abstain from them altogether, and a sort of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion passes current which tends to cause any association whatsoever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be regarded as a bold and almost an illicit enterprise. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: This is more especially true when the executive government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has a discretionary power of allowing or prohibiting associations. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain associations are simply prohibited by law, and the courts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice have to punish infringements of that law, the evil is far less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerable. Then every citizen knows beforehand pretty nearly what he
