author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has to expect. He judges himself before he is judged by the law, and,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abstaining from prohibited associations, he embarks in those which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legally sanctioned. It is by these restrictions that all free nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have always admitted that the right of association might be limited.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But if the legislature should invest a man with a power of ascertaining
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beforehand which associations are dangerous and which are useful, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should authorize him to destroy all associations in the bud or allow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them to be formed, as nobody would be able to foresee in what cases
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations might be established and in what cases they would be put
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: down, the spirit of association would be entirely paralyzed. The former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these laws would only assail certain associations; the latter would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apply to society itself, and inflict an injury upon it. I can conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that a regular government may have recourse to the former, but I do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concede that any government has the right of enacting the latter.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is therefore chimerical to suppose that the spirit of association,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when it is repressed on some one point, will nevertheless display
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same vigor on all others; and that if men be allowed to prosecute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain undertakings in common, that is quite enough for them eagerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to set about them. When the members of a community are allowed and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustomed to combine for all purposes, they will combine as readily for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the lesser as for the more important ones; but if they are only allowed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to combine for small affairs, they will be neither inclined nor able
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to effect it. It is in vain that you will leave them entirely free to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosecute their business on joint-stock account: they will hardly care
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to avail themselves of the rights you have granted to them; and, after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having exhausted your strength in vain efforts to put down prohibited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations, you will be surprised that you cannot persuade men to form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the associations you encourage.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not say that there can be no civil associations in a country where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political association is prohibited; for men can never live in society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without embarking in some common undertakings: but I maintain that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such a country civil associations will always be few in number, feebly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: planned, unskillfully managed, that they will never form any vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: designs, or that they will fail in the execution of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This naturally leads me to think that freedom of association in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political matters is not so dangerous to public tranquillity as is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supposed; and that possibly, after having agitated society for some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, it may strengthen the State in the end. In democratic countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political associations are, so to speak, the only powerful persons who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aspire to rule the State. Accordingly, the governments of our time look
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon associations of this kind just as sovereigns in the Middle Ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regarded the great vassals of the Crown: they entertain a sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instinctive abhorrence of them, and they combat them on all occasions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They bear, on the contrary, a natural goodwill to civil associations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they readily discover that, instead of directing the minds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community to public affairs, these institutions serve to divert them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from such reflections; and that, by engaging them more and more in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit of objects which cannot be attained without public tranquillity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they deter them from revolutions. But these governments do not attend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the fact that political associations tend amazingly to multiply and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facilitate those of a civil character, and that in avoiding a dangerous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evil they deprive themselves of an efficacious remedy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When you see the Americans freely and constantly forming associations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the purpose of promoting some political principle, of raising one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man to the head of affairs, or of wresting power from another, you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have some difficulty in understanding that men so independent do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly fall into the abuse of freedom. If, on the other hand, you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: survey the infinite number of trading companies which are in operation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States, and perceive that the Americans are on every side
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unceasingly engaged in the execution of important and difficult plans,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the slightest revolution would throw into confusion, you will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily comprehend why people so well employed are by no means tempted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to perturb the State, nor to destroy that public tranquillity by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they all profit.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Is it enough to observe these things separately, or should we not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discover the hidden tie which connects them? In their political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations, the Americans of all conditions, minds, and ages, daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquire a general taste for association, and grow accustomed to the use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of it. There they meet together in large numbers, they converse, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: listen to each other, and they are mutually stimulated to all sorts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings. They afterwards transfer to civil life the notions they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have thus acquired, and make them subservient to a thousand purposes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus it is by the enjoyment of a dangerous freedom that the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learn the art of rendering the dangers of freedom less formidable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If a certain moment in the existence of a nation be selected, it is easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to prove that political associations perturb the State, and paralyze
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productive industry; but take the whole life of a people, and it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps be easy to demonstrate that freedom of association in political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: matters is favorable to the prosperity and even to the tranquillity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I said in the former part of this work, "The unrestrained liberty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political association cannot be entirely assimilated to the liberty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the press. The one is at the same time less necessary and more dangerous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the other. A nation may confine it within certain limits without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ceasing to be mistress of itself; and it may sometimes be obliged to do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so in order to maintain its own authority." And further on I added:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "It cannot be denied that the unrestrained liberty of association for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political purposes is the last degree of liberty which a people is fit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for. If it does not throw them into anarchy, it perpetually brings them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as it were, to the verge of it." Thus I do not think that a nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is always at liberty to invest its citizens with an absolute right of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association for political purposes; and I doubt whether, in any country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or in any age, it be wise to set no limits to freedom of association.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A certain nation, it is said, could not maintain tranquillity in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, cause the laws to be respected, or establish a lasting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, if the right of association were not confined within narrow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limits. These blessings are doubtless invaluable, and I can imagine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, to acquire or to preserve them, a nation may impose upon itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severe temporary restrictions: but still it is well that the nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should know at what price these blessings are purchased. I can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understand that it may be advisable to cut off a man's arm in order to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: save his life; but it would be ridiculous to assert that he will be as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dexterous as he was before he lost it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: The Americans Combat Individualism By The Principle Of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Interest Rightly Understood
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the world was managed by a few rich and powerful individuals, these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons loved to entertain a lofty idea of the duties of man. They were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fond of professing that it is praiseworthy to forget one's self, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that good should be done without hope of reward, as it is by the Deity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself. Such were the standard opinions of that time in morals. I doubt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whether men were more virtuous in aristocratic ages than in others; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they were incessantly talking of the beauties of virtue, and its utility
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was only studied in secret. But since the imagination takes less lofty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flights and every man's thoughts are centred in himself, moralists are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alarmed by this idea of self-sacrifice, and they no longer venture to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present it to the human mind. They therefore content themselves with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquiring whether the personal advantage of each member of the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not consist in working for the good of all; and when they have hit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon some point on which private interest and public interest meet and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amalgamate, they are eager to bring it into notice. Observations of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind are gradually multiplied: what was only a single remark becomes a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general principle; and it is held as a truth that man serves himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in serving his fellow-creatures, and that his private interest is to do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already shown, in several parts of this work, by what means the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of the United States almost always manage to combine their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own advantage with that of their fellow-citizens: my present purpose is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to point out the general rule which enables them to do so. In the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States hardly anybody talks of the beauty of virtue; but they maintain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that virtue is useful, and prove it every day. The American moralists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not profess that men ought to sacrifice themselves for their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-creatures because it is noble to make such sacrifices; but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: boldly aver that such sacrifices are as necessary to him who imposes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them upon himself as to him for whose sake they are made. They have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found out that in their country and their age man is brought home to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself by an irresistible force; and losing all hope of stopping
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that force, they turn all their thoughts to the direction of it. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore do not deny that every man may follow his own interest;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they endeavor to prove that it is the interest of every man to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtuous. I shall not here enter into the reasons they allege, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would divert me from my subject: suffice it to say that they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convinced their fellow-countrymen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Montaigne said long ago: "Were I not to follow the straight road for its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: straightness, I should follow it for having found by experience that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the end it is commonly the happiest and most useful track." The doctrine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of interest rightly understood is not, then, new, but amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans of our time it finds universal acceptance: it has become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular there; you may trace it at the bottom of all their actions, you
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will remark it in all they say. It is as often to be met with on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lips of the poor man as of the rich. In Europe the principle of interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is much grosser than it is in America, but at the same time it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less common, and especially it is less avowed; amongst us, men still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly feign great abnegation which they no longer feel. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans, on the contrary, are fond of explaining almost all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions of their lives by the principle of interest rightly understood;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they show with complacency how an enlightened regard for themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly prompts them to assist each other, and inclines them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: willingly to sacrifice a portion of their time and property to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: welfare of the State. In this respect I think they frequently fail to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do themselves justice; for in the United States, as well as elsewhere,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people are sometimes seen to give way to those disinterested and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spontaneous impulses which are natural to man; but the Americans seldom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allow that they yield to emotions of this kind; they are more anxious to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do honor to their philosophy than to themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I might here pause, without attempting to pass a judgment on what I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: described. The extreme difficulty of the subject would be my excuse,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but I shall not avail myself of it; and I had rather that my readers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clearly perceiving my object, should refuse to follow me than that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I should leave them in suspense. The principle of interest rightly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood is not a lofty one, but it is clear and sure. It does not aim
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at mighty objects, but it attains without excessive exertion all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those at which it aims. As it lies within the reach of all capacities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everyone can without difficulty apprehend and retain it. By its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admirable conformity to human weaknesses, it easily obtains great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dominion; nor is that dominion precarious, since the principle checks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one personal interest by another, and uses, to direct the passions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the very same instrument which excites them. The principle of interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rightly understood produces no great acts of self-sacrifice, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suggests daily small acts of self-denial. By itself it cannot suffice to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make a man virtuous, but it disciplines a number of citizens in habits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of regularity, temperance, moderation, foresight, self-command; and, if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it does not lead men straight to virtue by the will, it gradually draws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them in that direction by their habits. If the principle of interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rightly understood were to sway the whole moral world, extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtues would doubtless be more rare; but I think that gross depravity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would then also be less common. The principle of interest rightly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understood perhaps prevents some men from rising far above the level of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mankind; but a great number of other men, who were falling far below it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are caught and restrained by it. Observe some few individuals, they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lowered by it; survey mankind, it is raised. I am not afraid to say that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principle of interest, rightly understood, appears to me the best
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suited of all philosophical theories to the wants of the men of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, and that I regard it as their chief remaining security against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves. Towards it, therefore, the minds of the moralists of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: age should turn; even should they judge it to be incomplete, it must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless be adopted as necessary.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not think upon the whole that there is more egotism amongst us than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in America; the only difference is, that there it is enlightened--here
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is not. Every American will sacrifice a portion of his private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests to preserve the rest; we would fain preserve the whole, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oftentimes the whole is lost. Everybody I see about me seems bent on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: teaching his contemporaries, by precept and example, that what is useful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is never wrong. Will nobody undertake to make them understand how what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is right may be useful? No power upon earth can prevent the increasing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality of conditions from inclining the human mind to seek out what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: useful, or from leading every member of the community to be wrapped up
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in himself. It must therefore be expected that personal interest will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become more than ever the principal, if not the sole, spring of men's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions; but it remains to be seen how each man will understand his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal interest. If the members of a community, as they become more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal, become more ignorant and coarse, it is difficult to foresee to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what pitch of stupid excesses their egotism may lead them; and no one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can foretell into what disgrace and wretchedness they would plunge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, lest they should have to sacrifice something of their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well-being to the prosperity of their fellow-creatures. I do not think
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the system of interest, as it is professed in America, is, in all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its parts, self-evident; but it contains a great number of truths so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evident that men, if they are but educated, cannot fail to see them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Educate, then, at any rate; for the age of implicit self-sacrifice and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instinctive virtues is already flitting far away from us, and the time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is fast approaching when freedom, public peace, and social order itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will not be able to exist without education.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IX: That The Americans Apply The Principle Of Interest Rightly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Understood To Religious Matters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the principle of interest rightly understood had nothing but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present world in view, it would be very insufficient; for there are many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sacrifices which can only find their recompense in another; and whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ingenuity may be put forth to demonstrate the utility of virtue, it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never be an easy task to make that man live aright who has no thoughts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of dying. It is therefore necessary to ascertain whether the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of interest rightly understood is easily compatible with religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belief. The philosophers who inculcate this system of morals tell men,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that to be happy in this life they must watch their own passions and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: steadily control their excess; that lasting happiness can only be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secured by renouncing a thousand transient gratifications; and that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man must perpetually triumph over himself, in order to secure his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantage. The founders of almost all religions have held the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language. The track they point out to man is the same, only that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: goal is more remote; instead of placing in this world the reward of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sacrifices they impose, they transport it to another. Nevertheless I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot believe that all those who practise virtue from religious motives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are only actuated by the hope of a recompense. I have known zealous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christians who constantly forgot themselves, to work with greater ardor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the happiness of their fellow-men; and I have heard them declare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that all they did was only to earn the blessings of a future state. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot but think that they deceive themselves; I respect them too much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to believe them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christianity indeed teaches that a man must prefer his neighbor to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself, in order to gain eternal life; but Christianity also teaches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that men ought to benefit their fellow-creatures for the love of God.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A sublime expression! Man, searching by his intellect into the divine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conception, and seeing that order is the purpose of God, freely combines
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to prosecute the great design; and whilst he sacrifices his personal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests to this consummate order of all created things, expects no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other recompense than the pleasure of contemplating it. I do not believe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that interest is the sole motive of religious men: but I believe that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest is the principal means which religions themselves employ to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: govern men, and I do not question that this way they strike into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude and become popular. It is not easy clearly to perceive why
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principle of interest rightly understood should keep aloof from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious opinions; and it seems to me more easy to show why it should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: draw men to them. Let it be supposed that, in order to obtain happiness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this world, a man combats his instinct on all occasions and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deliberately calculates every action of his life; that, instead of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yielding blindly to the impetuosity of first desires, he has learned the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: art of resisting them, and that he has accustomed himself to sacrifice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without an effort the pleasure of a moment to the lasting interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his whole life. If such a man believes in the religion which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: professes, it will cost him but little to submit to the restrictions it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may impose. Reason herself counsels him to obey, and habit has prepared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him to endure them. If he should have conceived any doubts as to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object of his hopes, still he will not easily allow himself to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stopped by them; and he will decide that it is wise to risk some of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages of this world, in order to preserve his rights to the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inheritance promised him in another. "To be mistaken in believing that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Christian religion is true," says Pascal, "is no great loss to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anyone; but how dreadful to be mistaken in believing it to be false!"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans do not affect a brutal indifference to a future state;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they affect no puerile pride in despising perils which they hope to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: escape from. They therefore profess their religion without shame and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without weakness; but there generally is, even in their zeal, something
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so indescribably tranquil, methodical, and deliberate, that it would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem as if the head, far more than the heart, brought them to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foot of the altar. The Americans not only follow their religion from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest, but they often place in this world the interest which makes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them follow it. In the Middle Ages the clergy spoke of nothing but a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future state; they hardly cared to prove that a sincere Christian may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be a happy man here below. But the American preachers are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: referring to the earth; and it is only with great difficulty that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can divert their attention from it. To touch their congregations, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always show them how favorable religious opinions are to freedom and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public tranquillity; and it is often difficult to ascertain from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discourses whether the principal object of religion is to procure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eternal felicity in the other world, or prosperity in this.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter X: Of The Taste For Physical Well-Being In America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the passion for physical well-being is not always exclusive,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it is general; and if all do not feel it in the same manner, yet it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is felt by all. Carefully to satisfy all, even the least wants of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: body, and to provide the little conveniences of life, is uppermost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in every mind. Something of an analogous character is more and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apparent in Europe. Amongst the causes which produce these similar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences in both hemispheres, several are so connected with my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject as to deserve notice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When riches are hereditarily fixed in families, there are a great number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men who enjoy the comforts of life without feeling an exclusive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taste for those comforts. The heart of man is not so much caught by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undisturbed possession of anything valuable as by the desire, as yet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperfectly satisfied, of possessing it, and by the incessant dread
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of losing it. In aristocratic communities, the wealthy, never having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experienced a condition different from their own, entertain no fear of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changing it; the existence of such conditions hardly occurs to them. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comforts of life are not to them the end of life, but simply a way of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: living; they regard them as existence itself--enjoyed, but scarcely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought of. As the natural and instinctive taste which all men feel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for being well off is thus satisfied without trouble and without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apprehension, their faculties are turned elsewhere, and cling to more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arduous and more lofty undertakings, which excite and engross their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minds. Hence it is that, in the midst of physical gratifications, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of an aristocracy often display a haughty contempt of these very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyments, and exhibit singular powers of endurance under the privation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them. All the revolutions which have ever shaken or destroyed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies, have shown how easily men accustomed to superfluous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: luxuries can do without the necessaries of life; whereas men who have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: toiled to acquire a competency can hardly live after they have lost it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I turn my observation from the upper to the lower classes, I find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: analogous effects produced by opposite causes. Amongst a nation where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy predominates in society, and keeps it stationary, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people in the end get as much accustomed to poverty as the rich to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their opulence. The latter bestow no anxiety on their physical comforts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they enjoy them without an effort; the former do not think
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things which they despair of obtaining, and which they hardly know
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enough of to desire them. In communities of this kind, the imagination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the poor is driven to seek another world; the miseries of real life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclose it around, but it escapes from their control, and flies to seek
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its pleasures far beyond. When, on the contrary, the distinctions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of ranks are confounded together and privileges are destroyed--when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereditary property is subdivided, and education and freedom widely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diffused, the desire of acquiring the comforts of the world haunts the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination of the poor, and the dread of losing them that of the rich.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Many scanty fortunes spring up; those who possess them have a sufficient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: share of physical gratifications to conceive a taste for these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures--not enough to satisfy it. They never procure them without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertion, and they never indulge in them without apprehension. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are therefore always straining to pursue or to retain gratifications so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delightful, so imperfect, so fugitive.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I were to inquire what passion is most natural to men who are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stimulated and circumscribed by the obscurity of their birth or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mediocrity of their fortune, I could discover none more peculiarly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appropriate to their condition than this love of physical prosperity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The passion for physical comforts is essentially a passion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: middle classes: with those classes it grows and spreads, with them it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preponderates. From them it mounts into the higher orders of society,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and descends into the mass of the people. I never met in America with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any citizen so poor as not to cast a glance of hope and envy on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyments of the rich, or whose imagination did not possess itself by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anticipation of those good things which fate still obstinately withheld
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from him. On the other hand, I never perceived amongst the wealthier
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of the United States that proud contempt of physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratifications which is sometimes to be met with even in the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opulent and dissolute aristocracies. Most of these wealthy persons were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once poor; they have felt the sting of want; they were long a prey to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adverse fortunes; and now that the victory is won, the passions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accompanied the contest have survived it: their minds are, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intoxicated by the small enjoyments which they have pursued for forty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years. Not but that in the United States, as elsewhere, there are a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain number of wealthy persons who, having come into their property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by inheritance, possess, without exertion, an opulence they have not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: earned. But even these men are not less devotedly attached to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures of material life. The love of well-being is now become the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predominant taste of the nation; the great current of man's passions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: runs in that channel, and sweeps everything along in its course.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XI: Peculiar Effects Of The Love Of Physical Gratifications In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic Ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may be supposed, from what has just been said, that the love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of physical gratifications must constantly urge the Americans to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irregularities in morals, disturb the peace of families, and threaten
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the security of society at large. Such is not the case: the passion for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: physical gratifications produces in democracies effects very different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from those which it occasions in aristocratic nations. It sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happens that, wearied with public affairs and sated with opulence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amidst the ruin of religious belief and the decline of the State, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heart of an aristocracy may by degrees be seduced to the pursuit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sensual enjoyments only. At other times the power of the monarch or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weakness of the people, without stripping the nobility of their fortune,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compels them to stand aloof from the administration of affairs, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst the road to mighty enterprise is closed, abandons them to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquietude of their own desires; they then fall back heavily upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, and seek in the pleasures of the body oblivion of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former greatness. When the members of an aristocratic body are thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusively devoted to the pursuit of physical gratifications, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonly concentrate in that direction all the energy which they derive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from their long experience of power. Such men are not satisfied with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the pursuit of comfort; they require sumptuous depravity and splendid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corruption. The worship they pay the senses is a gorgeous one; and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem to vie with each other in the art of degrading their own natures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The stronger, the more famous, and the more free an aristocracy has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been, the more depraved will it then become; and however brilliant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may have been the lustre of its virtues, I dare predict that they will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always be surpassed by the splendor of its vices.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The taste for physical gratifications leads a democratic people into no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such excesses. The love of well-being is there displayed as a tenacious,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusive, universal passion; but its range is confined. To build
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enormous palaces, to conquer or to mimic nature, to ransack the world in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to gratify the passions of a man, is not thought of: but to add
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a few roods of land to your field, to plant an orchard, to enlarge a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dwelling, to be always making life more comfortable and convenient,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to avoid trouble, and to satisfy the smallest wants without effort and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost without cost. These are small objects, but the soul clings to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; it dwells upon them closely and day by day, till they at last shut
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out the rest of the world, and sometimes intervene between itself and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heaven.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This, it may be said, can only be applicable to those members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community who are in humble circumstances; wealthier individuals will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: display tastes akin to those which belonged to them in aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ages. I contest the proposition: in point of physical gratifications,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most opulent members of a democracy will not display tastes very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different from those of the people; whether it be that, springing from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people, they really share those tastes, or that they esteem it a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duty to submit to them. In democratic society the sensuality of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public has taken a moderate and tranquil course, to which all are bound
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to conform: it is as difficult to depart from the common rule by one's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vices as by one's virtues. Rich men who live amidst democratic nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are therefore more intent on providing for their smallest wants than for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their extraordinary enjoyments; they gratify a number of petty desires,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without indulging in any great irregularities of passion: thus they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more apt to become enervated than debauched. The especial taste which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the men of democratic ages entertain for physical enjoyments is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally opposed to the principles of public order; nay, it often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stands in need of order that it may be gratified. Nor is it adverse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regularity of morals, for good morals contribute to public tranquillity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and are favorable to industry. It may even be frequently combined with a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: species of religious morality: men wish to be as well off as they can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this world, without foregoing their chance of another. Some physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratifications cannot be indulged in without crime; from such they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strictly abstain. The enjoyment of others is sanctioned by religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and morality; to these the heart, the imagination, and life itself are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unreservedly given up; till, in snatching at these lesser gifts, men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lose sight of those more precious possessions which constitute the glory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the greatness of mankind. The reproach I address to the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of equality, is not that it leads men away in the pursuit of forbidden
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyments, but that it absorbs them wholly in quest of those which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allowed. By these means, a kind of virtuous materialism may ultimately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be established in the world, which would not corrupt, but enervate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soul, and noiselessly unbend its springs of action.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XII: Causes Of Fanatical Enthusiasm In Some Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although the desire of acquiring the good things of this world is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevailing passion of the American people, certain momentary outbreaks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occur, when their souls seem suddenly to burst the bonds of matter by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they are restrained, and to soar impetuously towards heaven. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the States of the Union, but especially in the half-peopled country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Far West, wandering preachers may be met with who hawk about the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: word of God from place to place. Whole families--old men, women, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: children--cross rough passes and untrodden wilds, coming from a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distance, to join a camp-meeting, where they totally forget for several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: days and nights, in listening to these discourses, the cares of business
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and even the most urgent wants of the body. Here and there, in the midst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of American society, you meet with men, full of a fanatical and almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wild enthusiasm, which hardly exists in Europe. From time to time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strange sects arise, which endeavor to strike out extraordinary paths
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to eternal happiness. Religious insanity is very common in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nor ought these facts to surprise us. It was not man who implanted in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself the taste for what is infinite and the love of what is immortal:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those lofty instincts are not the offspring of his capricious will;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their steadfast foundation is fixed in human nature, and they exist in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spite of his efforts. He may cross and distort them--destroy them he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot. The soul has wants which must be satisfied; and whatever pains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be taken to divert it from itself, it soon grows weary, restless, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disquieted amidst the enjoyments of sense. If ever the faculties of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great majority of mankind were exclusively bent upon the pursuit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: material objects, it might be anticipated that an amazing reaction would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take place in the souls of some men. They would drift at large in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world of spirits, for fear of remaining shackled by the close bondage of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the body.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not then wonderful if, in the midst of a community whose thoughts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tend earthward, a small number of individuals are to be found who turn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their looks to heaven. I should be surprised if mysticism did not soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make some advance amongst a people solely engaged in promoting its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: worldly welfare. It is said that the deserts of the Thebaid were peopled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the persecutions of the emperors and the massacres of the Circus; I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should rather say that it was by the luxuries of Rome and the Epicurean
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophy of Greece. If their social condition, their present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances, and their laws did not confine the minds of the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so closely to the pursuit of worldly welfare, it is probable that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would display more reserve and more experience whenever their attention
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is turned to things immaterial, and that they would check themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without difficulty. But they feel imprisoned within bounds which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will apparently never be allowed to pass. As soon as they have passed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these bounds, their minds know not where to fix themselves, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often rush unrestrained beyond the range of common-sense.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIII: Causes Of The Restless Spirit Of Americans In The Midst Of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Their Prosperity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In certain remote corners of the Old World you may still sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stumble upon a small district which seems to have been forgotten amidst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the general tumult, and to have remained stationary whilst everything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: around it was in motion. The inhabitants are for the most part extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ignorant and poor; they take no part in the business of the country, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are frequently oppressed by the government; yet their countenances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are generally placid, and their spirits light. In America I saw the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freest and most enlightened men, placed in the happiest circumstances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the world affords: it seemed to me as if a cloud habitually hung
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon their brow, and I thought them serious and almost sad even in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures. The chief reason of this contrast is that the former do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: think of the ills they endure--the latter are forever brooding over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages they do not possess. It is strange to see with what feverish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ardor the Americans pursue their own welfare; and to watch the vague
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dread that constantly torments them lest they should not have chosen the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shortest path which may lead to it. A native of the United States clings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to this world's goods as if he were certain never to die; and he is so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hasty in grasping at all within his reach, that one would suppose he was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly afraid of not living long enough to enjoy them. He clutches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything, he holds nothing fast, but soon loosens his grasp to pursue
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fresh gratifications.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States a man builds a house to spend his latter years in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it, and he sells it before the roof is on: he plants a garden, and lets
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it just as the trees are coming into bearing: he brings a field into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tillage, and leaves other men to gather the crops: he embraces a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession, and gives it up: he settles in a place, which he soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afterwards leaves, to carry his changeable longings elsewhere. If his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private affairs leave him any leisure, he instantly plunges into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vortex of politics; and if at the end of a year of unremitting labor he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: finds he has a few days' vacation, his eager curiosity whirls him over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the vast extent of the United States, and he will travel fifteen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hundred miles in a few days, to shake off his happiness. Death at length
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overtakes him, but it is before he is weary of his bootless chase of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that complete felicity which is forever on the wing.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At first sight there is something surprising in this strange unrest of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so many happy men, restless in the midst of abundance. The spectacle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself is however as old as the world; the novelty is to see a whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people furnish an exemplification of it. Their taste for physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratifications must be regarded as the original source of that secret
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquietude which the actions of the Americans betray, and of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconstancy of which they afford fresh examples every day. He who has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: set his heart exclusively upon the pursuit of worldly welfare is always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a hurry, for he has but a limited time at his disposal to reach it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to grasp it, and to enjoy it. The recollection of the brevity of life is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a constant spur to him. Besides the good things which he possesses, he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every instant fancies a thousand others which death will prevent him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from trying if he does not try them soon. This thought fills him with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anxiety, fear, and regret, and keeps his mind in ceaseless trepidation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which leads him perpetually to change his plans and his abode. If in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: addition to the taste for physical well-being a social condition be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superadded, in which the laws and customs make no condition permanent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: here is a great additional stimulant to this restlessness of temper. Men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will then be seen continually to change their track, for fear of missing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the shortest cut to happiness. It may readily be conceived that if men,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passionately bent upon physical gratifications, desire eagerly, they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: also easily discouraged: as their ultimate object is to enjoy, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means to reach that object must be prompt and easy, or the trouble of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquiring the gratification would be greater than the gratification
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself. Their prevailing frame of mind then is at once ardent and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relaxed, violent and enervated. Death is often less dreaded than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perseverance in continuous efforts to one end.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The equality of conditions leads by a still straighter road to several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the effects which I have here described. When all the privileges of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: birth and fortune are abolished, when all professions are accessible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to all, and a man's own energies may place him at the top of any one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them, an easy and unbounded career seems open to his ambition, and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will readily persuade himself that he is born to no vulgar destinies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But this is an erroneous notion, which is corrected by daily experience.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same equality which allows every citizen to conceive these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lofty hopes, renders all the citizens less able to realize them: it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumscribes their powers on every side, whilst it gives freer scope to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their desires. Not only are they themselves powerless, but they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: met at every step by immense obstacles, which they did not at first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceive. They have swept away the privileges of some of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-creatures which stood in their way, but they have opened the door
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to universal competition: the barrier has changed its shape rather than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its position. When men are nearly alike, and all follow the same track,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is very difficult for any one individual to walk quick and cleave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a way through the dense throng which surrounds and presses him. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constant strife between the propensities springing from the equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conditions and the means it supplies to satisfy them, harasses and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wearies the mind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is possible to conceive men arrived at a degree of freedom which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should completely content them; they would then enjoy their independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without anxiety and without impatience. But men will never establish any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality with which they can be contented. Whatever efforts a people may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make, they will never succeed in reducing all the conditions of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a perfect level; and even if they unhappily attained that absolute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and complete depression, the inequality of minds would still remain,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which, coming directly from the hand of God, will forever escape the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws of man. However democratic then the social state and the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution of a people may be, it is certain that every member of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community will always find out several points about him which command
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his own position; and we may foresee that his looks will be doggedly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fixed in that direction. When inequality of conditions is the common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law of society, the most marked inequalities do not strike the eye: when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything is nearly on the same level, the slightest are marked enough
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to hurt it. Hence the desire of equality always becomes more insatiable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in proportion as equality is more complete.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst democratic nations men easily attain a certain equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conditions: they can never attain the equality they desire. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually retires from before them, yet without hiding itself from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their sight, and in retiring draws them on. At every moment they think
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are about to grasp it; it escapes at every moment from their hold.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They are near enough to see its charms, but too far off to enjoy them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and before they have fully tasted its delights they die. To these causes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be attributed that strange melancholy which oftentimes will haunt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inhabitants of democratic countries in the midst of their abundance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that disgust at life which sometimes seizes upon them in the midst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of calm and easy circumstances. Complaints are made in France that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of suicides increases; in America suicide is rare, but insanity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is said to be more common than anywhere else. These are all different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: symptoms of the same disease. The Americans do not put an end to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lives, however disquieted they may be, because their religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forbids it; and amongst them materialism may be said hardly to exist,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding the general passion for physical gratification. The will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resists--reason frequently gives way. In democratic ages enjoyments are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more intense than in the ages of aristocracy, and especially the number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those who partake in them is larger: but, on the other hand, it must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be admitted that man's hopes and his desires are oftener blasted, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soul is more stricken and perturbed, and care itself more keen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIV: Taste For Physical Gratifications United In America To Love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of Freedom And Attention To Public Affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a democratic state turns to absolute monarchy, the activity which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was before directed to public and to private affairs is all at once
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centred upon the latter: the immediate consequence is, for some time,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great physical prosperity; but this impulse soon slackens, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amount of productive industry is checked. I know not if a single trading
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or manufacturing people can be cited, from the Tyrians down to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Florentines and the English, who were not a free people also. There
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is therefore a close bond and necessary relation between these two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elements--freedom and productive industry. This proposition is generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true of all nations, but especially of democratic nations. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already shown that men who live in ages of equality continually require
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to form associations in order to procure the things they covet; and, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other hand, I have shown how great political freedom improves and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diffuses the art of association. Freedom, in these ages, is therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially favorable to the production of wealth; nor is it difficult
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to perceive that despotism is especially adverse to the same result.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The nature of despotic power in democratic ages is not to be fierce or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cruel, but minute and meddling. Despotism of this kind, though it does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not trample on humanity, is directly opposed to the genius of commerce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the pursuits of industry.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the men of democratic ages require to be free in order more readily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to procure those physical enjoyments for which they are always longing.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It sometimes happens, however, that the excessive taste they conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for these same enjoyments abandons them to the first master who appears.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The passion for worldly welfare then defeats itself, and, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceiving it, throws the object of their desires to a greater distance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is, indeed, a most dangerous passage in the history of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people. When the taste for physical gratifications amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such a people has grown more rapidly than their education and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience of free institutions, the time will come when men are carried
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: away, and lose all self-restraint, at the sight of the new possessions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are about to lay hold upon. In their intense and exclusive anxiety
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to make a fortune, they lose sight of the close connection which exists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the private fortune of each of them and the prosperity of all.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not necessary to do violence to such a people in order to strip
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them of the rights they enjoy; they themselves willingly loosen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their hold. The discharge of political duties appears to them to be a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: troublesome annoyance, which diverts them from their occupations and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: business. If they be required to elect representatives, to support the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government by personal service, to meet on public business, they have no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time--they cannot waste their precious time in useless engagements: such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idle amusements are unsuited to serious men who are engaged with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more important interests of life. These people think they are following
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principle of self-interest, but the idea they entertain of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle is a very rude one; and the better to look after what they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: call their business, they neglect their chief business, which is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain their own masters.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the citizens who work do not care to attend to public business, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the class which might devote its leisure to these duties has ceased
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to exist, the place of the Government is, as it were, unfilled. If at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that critical moment some able and ambitious man grasps the supreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power, he will find the road to every kind of usurpation open before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him. If he does but attend for some time to the material prosperity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country, no more will be demanded of him. Above all he must insure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public tranquillity: men who are possessed by the passion of physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratification generally find out that the turmoil of freedom disturbs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their welfare, before they discover how freedom itself serves to promote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. If the slightest rumor of public commotion intrudes into the petty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures of private life, they are aroused and alarmed by it. The fear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of anarchy perpetually haunts them, and they are always ready to fling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: away their freedom at the first disturbance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I readily admit that public tranquillity is a great good; but at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same time I cannot forget that all nations have been enslaved by being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kept in good order. Certainly it is not to be inferred that nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought to despise public tranquillity; but that state ought not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: content them. A nation which asks nothing of its government but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of order is already a slave at heart--the slave of its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well-being, awaiting but the hand that will bind it. By such a nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the despotism of faction is not less to be dreaded than the despotism
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an individual. When the bulk of the community is engrossed by private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concerns, the smallest parties need not despair of getting the upper
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand in public affairs. At such times it is not rare to see upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great stage of the world, as we see at our theatres, a multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represented by a few players, who alone speak in the name of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absent or inattentive crowd: they alone are in action whilst all are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stationary; they regulate everything by their own caprice; they change
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws, and tyrannize at will over the manners of the country; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then men wonder to see into how small a number of weak and worthless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands a great people may fall.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hitherto the Americans have fortunately escaped all the perils which I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have just pointed out; and in this respect they are really deserving of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: admiration. Perhaps there is no country in the world where fewer idle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men are to be met with than in America, or where all who work are more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eager to promote their own welfare. But if the passion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans for physical gratifications is vehement, at least it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not indiscriminating; and reason, though unable to restrain it, still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directs its course. An American attends to his private concerns as if he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were alone in the world, and the next minute he gives himself up to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common weal as if he had forgotten them. At one time he seems animated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the most selfish cupidity, at another by the most lively patriotism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The human heart cannot be thus divided. The inhabitants of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States alternately display so strong and so similar a passion for their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own welfare and for their freedom, that it may be supposed that these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions are united and mingled in some part of their character. And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indeed the Americans believe their freedom to be the best instrument and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surest safeguard of their welfare: they are attached to the one by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other. They by no means think that they are not called upon to take a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part in the public weal; they believe, on the contrary, that their chief
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: business is to secure for themselves a government which will allow them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to acquire the things they covet, and which will not debar them from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peaceful enjoyment of those possessions which they have acquired.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XV: That Religious Belief Sometimes Turns The Thoughts Of The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans To Immaterial Pleasures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, on the seventh day of every week, the trading and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: working life of the nation seems suspended; all noises cease; a deep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tranquillity, say rather the solemn calm of meditation, succeeds the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turmoil of the week, and the soul resumes possession and contemplation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of itself. Upon this day the marts of traffic are deserted; every member
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community, accompanied by his children, goes to church, where he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: listens to strange language which would seem unsuited to his ear. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is told of the countless evils caused by pride and covetousness: he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is reminded of the necessity of checking his desires, of the finer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures which belong to virtue alone, and of the true happiness which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attends it. On his return home, he does not turn to the ledgers of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calling, but he opens the book of Holy Scripture; there he meets with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sublime or affecting descriptions of the greatness and goodness of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Creator, of the infinite magnificence of the handiwork of God, of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lofty destinies of man, of his duties, and of his immortal privileges.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus it is that the American at times steals an hour from himself; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laying aside for a while the petty passions which agitate his life,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the ephemeral interests which engross it, he strays at once into an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideal world, where all is great, eternal, and pure.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have endeavored to point out in another part of this work the causes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to which the maintenance of the political institutions of the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is attributable; and religion appeared to be one of the most prominent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst them. I am now treating of the Americans in an individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capacity, and I again observe that religion is not less useful to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen than to the whole State. The Americans show, by their practice,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they feel the high necessity of imparting morality to democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities by means of religion. What they think of themselves in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this respect is a truth of which every democratic nation ought to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thoroughly persuaded.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not doubt that the social and political constitution of a people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predisposes them to adopt a certain belief and certain tastes, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afterwards flourish without difficulty amongst them; whilst the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: causes may divert a people from certain opinions and propensities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without any voluntary effort, and, as it were, without any distinct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consciousness, on their part. The whole art of the legislator
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is correctly to discern beforehand these natural inclinations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
