text: communities of men, in order to know whether they should be assisted, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whether it may not be necessary to check them. For the duties incumbent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the legislator differ at different times; the goal towards which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human race ought ever to be tending is alone stationary; the means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reaching it are perpetually to be varied.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I had been born in an aristocratic age, in the midst of a nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the hereditary wealth of some, and the irremediable penury of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others, should equally divert men from the idea of bettering their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition, and hold the soul as it were in a state of torpor fixed on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contemplation of another world, I should then wish that it were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possible for me to rouse that people to a sense of their wants; I should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seek to discover more rapid and more easy means for satisfying the fresh
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires which I might have awakened; and, directing the most strenuous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efforts of the human mind to physical pursuits, I should endeavor to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stimulate it to promote the well-being of man. If it happened that some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men were immoderately incited to the pursuit of riches, and displayed an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excessive liking for physical gratifications, I should not be alarmed;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these peculiar symptoms would soon be absorbed in the general aspect of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The attention of the legislators of democracies is called to other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cares. Give democratic nations education and freedom, and leave them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alone. They will soon learn to draw from this world all the benefits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it can afford; they will improve each of the useful arts, and will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day by day render life more comfortable, more convenient, and more easy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Their social condition naturally urges them in this direction; I do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fear that they will slacken their course.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But whilst man takes delight in this honest and lawful pursuit of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wellbeing, it is to be apprehended that he may in the end lose the use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his sublimest faculties; and that whilst he is busied in improving
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all around him, he may at length degrade himself. Here, and here only,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does the peril lie. It should therefore be the unceasing object of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislators of democracies, and of all the virtuous and enlightened men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who live there, to raise the souls of their fellow-citizens, and keep
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them lifted up towards heaven. It is necessary that all who feel an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest in the future destinies of democratic society should unite, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that all should make joint and continual efforts to diffuse the love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the infinite, a sense of greatness, and a love of pleasures not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of earth. If amongst the opinions of a democratic people any of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pernicious theories exist which tend to inculcate that all perishes with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the body, let men by whom such theories are professed be marked as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural foes of such a people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The materialists are offensive to me in many respects; their doctrines
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I hold to be pernicious, and I am disgusted at their arrogance. If their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system could be of any utility to man, it would seem to be by giving him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a modest opinion of himself. But these reasoners show that it is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so; and when they think they have said enough to establish that they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brutes, they show themselves as proud as if they had demonstrated that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are gods. Materialism is, amongst all nations, a dangerous disease
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the human mind; but it is more especially to be dreaded amongst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people, because it readily amalgamates with that vice which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is most familiar to the heart under such circumstances. Democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encourages a taste for physical gratification: this taste, if it become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: excessive, soon disposes men to believe that all is matter only; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: materialism, in turn, hurries them back with mad impatience to these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same delights: such is the fatal circle within which democratic nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are driven round. It were well that they should see the danger and hold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: back.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Most religions are only general, simple, and practical means of teaching
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men the doctrine of the immortality of the soul. That is the greatest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: benefit which a democratic people derives, from its belief, and hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belief is more necessary to such a people than to all others. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore any religion has struck its roots deep into a democracy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beware lest you disturb them; but rather watch it carefully, as the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precious bequest of aristocratic ages. Seek not to supersede the old
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious opinions of men by new ones; lest in the passage from one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faith to another, the soul being left for a while stripped of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belief, the love of physical gratifications should grow upon it and fill
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it wholly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The doctrine of metempsychosis is assuredly not more rational than that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of materialism; nevertheless if it were absolutely necessary that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy should choose one of the two, I should not hesitate to decide
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the community would run less risk of being brutalized by believing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the soul of man will pass into the carcass of a hog, than by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believing that the soul of man is nothing at all. The belief in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supersensual and immortal principle, united for a time to matter, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so indispensable to man's greatness, that its effects are striking even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when it is not united to the doctrine of future reward and punishment;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and when it holds no more than that after death the divine principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contained in man is absorbed in the Deity, or transferred to animate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the frame of some other creature. Men holding so imperfect a belief will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still consider the body as the secondary and inferior portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their nature, and they will despise it even whilst they yield to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence; whereas they have a natural esteem and secret admiration for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the immaterial part of man, even though they sometimes refuse to submit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to its dominion. That is enough to give a lofty cast to their opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their tastes, and to bid them tend with no interested motive, and as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it were by impulse, to pure feelings and elevated thoughts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not certain that Socrates and his followers had very fixed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions as to what would befall man hereafter; but the sole point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of belief on which they were determined--that the soul has nothing in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common with the body, and survives it--was enough to give the Platonic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophy that sublime aspiration by which it is distinguished. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is clear from the works of Plato, that many philosophical writers, his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predecessors or contemporaries, professed materialism. These writers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have not reached us, or have reached us in mere fragments. The same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing has happened in almost all ages; the greater part of the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: famous minds in literature adhere to the doctrines of a supersensual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: philosophy. The instinct and the taste of the human race maintain those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doctrines; they save them oftentimes in spite of men themselves, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raise the names of their defenders above the tide of time. It must not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then be supposed that at any period or under any political condition,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the passion for physical gratifications, and the opinions which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superinduced by that passion, can ever content a whole people. The heart
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of man is of a larger mould: it can at once comprise a taste for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessions of earth and the love of those of heaven: at times it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seem to cling devotedly to the one, but it will never be long without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thinking of the other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If it be easy to see that it is more particularly important in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages that spiritual opinions should prevail, it is not easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to say by what means those who govern democratic nations may make them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predominate. I am no believer in the prosperity, any more than in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: durability, of official philosophies; and as to state religions, I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have always held, that if they be sometimes of momentary service to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests of political power, they always, sooner or later, become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fatal to the Church. Nor do I think with those who assert, that to raise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion in the eyes of the people, and to make them do honor to her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spiritual doctrines, it is desirable indirectly to give her ministers a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political influence which the laws deny them. I am so much alive to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the almost inevitable dangers which beset religious belief whenever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the clergy take part in public affairs, and I am so convinced that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christianity must be maintained at any cost in the bosom of modern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies, that I had rather shut up the priesthood within the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sanctuary than allow them to step beyond it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What means then remain in the hands of constituted authorities to bring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men back to spiritual opinions, or to hold them fast to the religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by which those opinions are suggested? My answer will do me harm in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the eyes of politicians. I believe that the sole effectual means which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments can employ in order to have the doctrine of the immortality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the soul duly respected, is ever to act as if they believed in it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves; and I think that it is only by scrupulous conformity to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious morality in great affairs that they can hope to teach the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community at large to know, to love, and to observe it in the lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concerns of life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVI: That Excessive Care Of Worldly Welfare May Impair That
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Welfare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is a closer tie than is commonly supposed between the improvement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the soul and the amelioration of what belongs to the body. Man may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leave these two things apart, and consider each of them alternately; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he cannot sever them entirely without at last losing sight of one and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other. The beasts have the same senses as ourselves, and very nearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same appetites. We have no sensual passions which are not common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to our race and theirs, and which are not to be found, at least in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: germ, in a dog as well as in a man. Whence is it then that the animals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can only provide for their first and lowest wants, whereas we can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infinitely vary and endlessly increase our enjoyments?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We are superior to the beasts in this, that we use our souls to find out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those material benefits to which they are only led by instinct. In man,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the angel teaches the brute the art of contenting its desires. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because man is capable of rising above the things of the body, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemning life itself, of which the beasts have not the least notion,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that he can multiply these same things of the body to a degree which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferior races are equally unable to conceive. Whatever elevates,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlarges, and expands the soul, renders it more capable of succeeding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in those very undertakings which concern it not. Whatever, on the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand, enervates or lowers it, weakens it for all purposes, the chiefest,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as well as the least, and threatens to render it almost equally impotent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the one and for the other. Hence the soul must remain great and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strong, though it were only to devote its strength and greatness from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time to time to the service of the body. If men were ever to content
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves with material objects, it is probable that they would lose by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degrees the art of producing them; and they would enjoy them in the end,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like the brutes, without discernment and without improvement.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVII: That In Times Marked By Equality Of Conditions And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Sceptical Opinions, It Is Important To Remove To A Distance The Objects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Of Human Actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the ages of faith the final end of life is placed beyond life. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men of those ages therefore naturally, and in a manner involuntarily,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustom themselves to fix their gaze for a long course of years on some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immovable object, towards which they are constantly tending; and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: learn by insensible degrees to repress a multitude of petty passing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires, in order to be the better able to content that great and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lasting desire which possesses them. When these same men engage in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs of this world, the same habits may be traced in their conduct.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They are apt to set up some general and certain aim and end to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions here below, towards which all their efforts are directed: they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not turn from day to day to chase some novel object of desire, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have settled designs which they are never weary of pursuing. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explains why religious nations have so often achieved such lasting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results: for whilst they were thinking only of the other world, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had found out the great secret of success in this. Religions give men a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general habit of conducting themselves with a view to futurity: in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this respect they are not less useful to happiness in this life than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to felicity hereafter; and this is one of their chief political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in proportion as the light of faith grows dim, the range of man's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sight is circumscribed, as if the end and aim of human actions appeared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every day to be more within his reach. When men have once allowed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to think no more of what is to befall them after life, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: readily lapse into that complete and brutal indifference to futurity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is but too conformable to some propensities of mankind. As soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as they have lost the habit of placing their chief hopes upon remote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: events, they naturally seek to gratify without delay their smallest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires; and no sooner do they despair of living forever, than they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are disposed to act as if they were to exist but for a single day.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In sceptical ages it is always therefore to be feared that men may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually give way to their daily casual desires; and that, wholly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: renouncing whatever cannot be acquired without protracted effort, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may establish nothing great, permanent, and calm.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the social condition of a people, under these circumstances, becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic, the danger which I here point out is thereby increased. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everyone is constantly striving to change his position--when an immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: field for competition is thrown open to all--when wealth is amassed or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dissipated in the shortest possible space of time amidst the turmoil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democracy, visions of sudden and easy fortunes--of great possessions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easily won and lost--of chance, under all its forms--haunt the mind. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instability of society itself fosters the natural instability of man's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires. In the midst of these perpetual fluctuations of his lot, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present grows upon his mind, until it conceals futurity from his sight,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and his looks go no further than the morrow.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In those countries in which unhappily irreligion and democracy coexist,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most important duty of philosophers and of those in power is to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always striving to place the objects of human actions far beyond man's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediate range. Circumscribed by the character of his country and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his age, the moralist must learn to vindicate his principles in that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position. He must constantly endeavor to show his contemporaries, that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even in the midst of the perpetual commotion around them, it is easier
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than they think to conceive and to execute protracted undertakings. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must teach them that, although the aspect of mankind may have changed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the methods by which men may provide for their prosperity in this world
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are still the same; and that amongst democratic nations, as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere, it is only by resisting a thousand petty selfish passions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hour that the general and unquenchable passion for happiness can be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfied.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The task of those in power is not less clearly marked out. At all times
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is important that those who govern nations should act with a view to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the future: but this is even more necessary in democratic and sceptical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ages than in any others. By acting thus, the leading men of democracies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only make public affairs prosperous, but they also teach private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individuals, by their example, the art of managing private concerns.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Above all they must strive as much as possible to banish chance from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere of politics. The sudden and undeserved promotion of a courtier
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produces only a transient impression in an aristocratic country, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the aggregate institutions and opinions of the nation habitually compel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men to advance slowly in tracks which they cannot get out of. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing is more pernicious than similar instances of favor exhibited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the eyes of a democratic people: they give the last impulse to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public mind in a direction where everything hurries it onwards. At times
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of scepticism and equality more especially, the favor of the people or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the prince, which chance may confer or chance withhold, ought never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to stand in lieu of attainments or services. It is desirable that every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advancement should there appear to be the result of some effort; so that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no greatness should be of too easy acquirement, and that ambition should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be obliged to fix its gaze long upon an object before it is gratified.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Governments must apply themselves to restore to men that love of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future with which religion and the state of society no longer inspire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; and, without saying so, they must practically teach the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day by day that wealth, fame, and power are the rewards of labor--that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great success stands at the utmost range of long desires, and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing lasting is obtained but what is obtained by toil. When men have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accustomed themselves to foresee from afar what is likely to befall in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world and to feed upon hopes, they can hardly confine their minds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within the precise circumference of life, and they are ready to break
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the boundary and cast their looks beyond. I do not doubt that, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: training the members of a community to think of their future condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this world, they would be gradually and unconsciously brought nearer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to religious convictions. Thus the means which allow men, up to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain point, to go without religion, are perhaps after all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only means we still possess for bringing mankind back by a long and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: roundabout path to a state of faith.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: That Amongst The Americans All Honest Callings Are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Honorable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst a democratic people, where there is no hereditary wealth, every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man works to earn a living, or has worked, or is born of parents who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have worked. The notion of labor is therefore presented to the mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on every side as the necessary, natural, and honest condition of human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence. Not only is labor not dishonorable amongst such a people, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is held in honor: the prejudice is not against it, but in its favor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States a wealthy man thinks that he owes it to public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion to devote his leisure to some kind of industrial or commercial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuit, or to public business. He would think himself in bad repute if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he employed his life solely in living. It is for the purpose of escaping
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this obligation to work, that so many rich Americans come to Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where they find some scattered remains of aristocratic society, amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which idleness is still held in honor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Equality of conditions not only ennobles the notion of labor in men's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estimation, but it raises the notion of labor as a source of profit. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies it is not exactly labor that is despised, but labor with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a view to profit. Labor is honorific in itself, when it is undertaken at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sole bidding of ambition or of virtue. Yet in aristocratic society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it constantly happens that he who works for honor is not insensible to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the attractions of profit. But these two desires only intermingle in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the innermost depths of his soul: he carefully hides from every eye
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the point at which they join; he would fain conceal it from himself. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic countries there are few public officers who do not affect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to serve their country without interested motives. Their salary is an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incident of which they think but little, and of which they always affect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not to think at all. Thus the notion of profit is kept distinct from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of labor; however they may be united in point of fact, they are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thought of together.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democratic communities these two notions are, on the contrary, always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: palpably united. As the desire of well-being is universal--as fortunes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are slender or fluctuating--as everyone wants either to increase his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own resources, or to provide fresh ones for his progeny, men clearly see
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it is profit which, if not wholly, at least partially, leads them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to work. Even those who are principally actuated by the love of fame are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessarily made familiar with the thought that they are not exclusively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actuated by that motive; and they discover that the desire of getting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a living is mingled in their minds with the desire of making life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: illustrious.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As soon as, on the one hand, labor is held by the whole community to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an honorable necessity of man's condition, and, on the other, as soon as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor is always ostensibly performed, wholly or in part, for the purpose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of earning remuneration, the immense interval which separated different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: callings in aristocratic societies disappears. If all are not alike, all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least have one feature in common. No profession exists in which men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not work for money; and the remuneration which is common to them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all gives them all an air of resemblance. This serves to explain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the opinions which the Americans entertain with respect to different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: callings. In America no one is degraded because he works, for everyone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about him works also; nor is anyone humiliated by the notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: receiving pay, for the President of the United States also works for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pay. He is paid for commanding, other men for obeying orders. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States professions are more or less laborious, more or less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profitable; but they are never either high or low: every honest calling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is honorable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIX: That Almost All The Americans Follow Industrial Callings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Agriculture is, perhaps, of all the useful arts that which improves most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slowly amongst democratic nations. Frequently, indeed, it would seem
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be stationary, because other arts are making rapid strides towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfection. On the other hand, almost all the tastes and habits which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the equality of condition engenders naturally lead men to commercial and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industrial occupations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Suppose an active, enlightened, and free man, enjoying a competency, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: full of desires: he is too poor to live in idleness; he is rich enough
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to feel himself protected from the immediate fear of want, and he thinks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: how he can better his condition. This man has conceived a taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: physical gratifications, which thousands of his fellow-men indulge in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: around him; he has himself begun to enjoy these pleasures, and he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eager to increase his means of satisfying these tastes more completely.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But life is slipping away, time is urgent--to what is he to turn? The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cultivation of the ground promises an almost certain result to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions, but a slow one; men are not enriched by it without patience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and toil. Agriculture is therefore only suited to those who have already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large, superfluous wealth, or to those whose penury bids them only seek
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a bare subsistence. The choice of such a man as we have supposed is soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made; he sells his plot of ground, leaves his dwelling, and embarks in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some hazardous but lucrative calling. Democratic communities abound
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in men of this kind; and in proportion as the equality of conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes greater, their multitude increases. Thus democracy not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: swells the number of workingmen, but it leads men to prefer one kind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of labor to another; and whilst it diverts them from agriculture, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encourages their taste for commerce and manufactures. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: It has often been remarked that manufacturers and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mercantile men are inordinately addicted to physical gratifications, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this has been attributed to commerce and manufactures; but that is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I apprehend, to take the effect for the cause. The taste for physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratifications is not imparted to men by commerce or manufactures,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it is rather this taste which leads men to embark in commerce and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures, as a means by which they hope to satisfy themselves more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promptly and more completely. If commerce and manufactures increase the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desire of well-being, it is because every passion gathers strength in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion as it is cultivated, and is increased by all the efforts made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to satiate it. All the causes which make the love of worldly welfare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predominate in the heart of man are favorable to the growth of commerce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and manufactures. Equality of conditions is one of those causes; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encourages trade, not directly by giving men a taste for business, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indirectly by strengthening and expanding in their minds a taste for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This spirit may be observed even amongst the richest members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community. In democratic countries, however opulent a man is supposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be, he is almost always discontented with his fortune, because he finds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that he is less rich than his father was, and he fears that his sons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be less rich than himself. Most rich men in democracies are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore constantly haunted by the desire of obtaining wealth, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally turn their attention to trade and manufactures, which appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to offer the readiest and most powerful means of success. In this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect they share the instincts of the poor, without feeling the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same necessities; say rather, they feel the most imperious of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessities, that of not sinking in the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocracies the rich are at the same time those who govern. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention which they unceasingly devote to important public affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diverts them from the lesser cares which trade and manufactures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demand. If the will of an individual happens, nevertheless, to turn his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention to business, the will of the body to which he belongs will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediately debar him from pursuing it; for however men may declaim
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the rule of numbers, they cannot wholly escape their sway; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even amongst those aristocratic bodies which most obstinately refuse to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledge the rights of the majority of the nation, a private majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is formed which governs the rest. *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: Some aristocracies, however, have devoted themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eagerly to commerce, and have cultivated manufactures with success. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: history of the world might furnish several conspicuous examples. But,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally speaking, it may be affirmed that the aristocratic principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not favorable to the growth of trade and manufactures. Moneyed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies are the only exception to the rule. Amongst such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies there are hardly any desires which do not require wealth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to satisfy them; the love of riches becomes, so to speak, the high road
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of human passions, which is crossed by or connected with all lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tracks. The love of money and the thirst for that distinction which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attaches to power, are then so closely intermixed in the same souls,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it becomes difficult to discover whether men grow covetous from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition, or whether they are ambitious from covetousness. This is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the case in England, where men seek to get rich in order to arrive at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinction, and seek distinctions as a manifestation of their wealth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The mind is then seized by both ends, and hurried into trade and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures, which are the shortest roads that lead to opulence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This, however, strikes me as an exceptional and transitory circumstance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When wealth is become the only symbol of aristocracy, it is very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult for the wealthy to maintain sole possession of political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power, to the exclusion of all other men. The aristocracy of birth and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pure democracy are at the two extremes of the social and political state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of nations: between them moneyed aristocracy finds its place. The latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approximates to the aristocracy of birth by conferring great privileges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on a small number of persons; it so far belongs to the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: element, that these privileges may be successively acquired by all. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently forms a natural transition between these two conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society, and it is difficult to say whether it closes the reign of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic institutions, or whether it already opens the new era of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democratic countries, where money does not lead those who possess it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to political power, but often removes them from it, the rich do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know how to spend their leisure. They are driven into active life by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquietude and the greatness of their desires, by the extent of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources, and by the taste for what is extraordinary, which is almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always felt by those who rise, by whatsoever means, above the crowd.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Trade is the only road open to them. In democracies nothing is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great or more brilliant than commerce: it attracts the attention of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the public, and fills the imagination of the multitude; all energetic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions are directed towards it. Neither their own prejudices, nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those of anybody else, can prevent the rich from devoting themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to it. The wealthy members of democracies never form a body which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners and regulations of its own; the opinions peculiar to their class
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not restrain them, and the common opinions of their country urge them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on. Moreover, as all the large fortunes which are to be met with in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic community are of commercial growth, many generations must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeed each other before their possessors can have entirely laid aside
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their habits of business.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Circumscribed within the narrow space which politics leave them, rich
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men in democracies eagerly embark in commercial enterprise: there they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can extend and employ their natural advantages; and indeed it is even by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the boldness and the magnitude of their industrial speculations that we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may measure the slight esteem in which productive industry would have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been held by them, if they had been born amidst an aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A similar observation is likewise applicable to all men living in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies, whether they be poor or rich. Those who live in the midst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democratic fluctuations have always before their eyes the phantom of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chance; and they end by liking all undertakings in which chance plays a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part. They are therefore all led to engage in commerce, not only for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sake of the profit it holds out to them, but for the love of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constant excitement occasioned by that pursuit.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The United States of America have only been emancipated for half a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: century [in 1840] from the state of colonial dependence in which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stood to Great Britain; the number of large fortunes there is small, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capital is still scarce. Yet no people in the world has made such rapid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress in trade and manufactures as the Americans: they constitute at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present day the second maritime nation in the world; and although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their manufactures have to struggle with almost insurmountable natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impediments, they are not prevented from making great and daily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advances. In the United States the greatest undertakings and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speculations are executed without difficulty, because the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population is engaged in productive industry, and because the poorest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as well as the most opulent members of the commonwealth are ready to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combine their efforts for these purposes. The consequence is, that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stranger is constantly amazed by the immense public works executed by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation which contains, so to speak, no rich men. The Americans arrived
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but as yesterday on the territory which they inhabit, and they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: already changed the whole order of nature for their own advantage. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have joined the Hudson to the Mississippi, and made the Atlantic Ocean
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communicate with the Gulf of Mexico, across a continent of more than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: five hundred leagues in extent which separates the two seas. The longest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: railroads which have been constructed up to the present time are in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America. But what most astonishes me in the United States, is not so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much the marvellous grandeur of some undertakings, as the innumerable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude of small ones. Almost all the farmers of the United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combine some trade with agriculture; most of them make agriculture
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself a trade. It seldom happens that an American farmer settles for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good upon the land which he occupies: especially in the districts of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Far West he brings land into tillage in order to sell it again, and not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to farm it: he builds a farmhouse on the speculation that, as the state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the country will soon be changed by the increase of population, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: good price will be gotten for it. Every year a swarm of the inhabitants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the North arrive in the Southern States, and settle in the parts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the cotton plant and the sugar-cane grow. These men cultivate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soil in order to make it produce in a few years enough to enrich them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they already look forward to the time when they may return home
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to enjoy the competency thus acquired. Thus the Americans carry their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: business-like qualities into agriculture; and their trading passions are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: displayed in that as in their other pursuits.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans make immense progress in productive industry, because they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all devote themselves to it at once; and for this same reason they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exposed to very unexpected and formidable embarrassments. As they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all engaged in commerce, their commercial affairs are affected by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such various and complex causes that it is impossible to foresee
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what difficulties may arise. As they are all more or less engaged in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productive industry, at the least shock given to business all private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortunes are put in jeopardy at the same time, and the State is shaken.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe that the return of these commercial panics is an endemic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disease of the democratic nations of our age. It may be rendered less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous, but it cannot be cured; because it does not originate in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accidental circumstances, but in the temperament of these nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XX: That Aristocracy May Be Engendered By Manufactures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown that democracy is favorable to the growth of manufactures,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that it increases without limit the numbers of the manufacturing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes: we shall now see by what side road manufacturers may possibly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in their turn bring men back to aristocracy. It is acknowledged that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when a workman is engaged every day upon the same detail, the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commodity is produced with greater ease, promptitude, and economy. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is likewise acknowledged that the cost of the production of manufactured
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: goods is diminished by the extent of the establishment in which they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made, and by the amount of capital employed or of credit. These truths
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had long been imperfectly discerned, but in our time they have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demonstrated. They have been already applied to many very important
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kinds of manufactures, and the humblest will gradually be governed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. I know of nothing in politics which deserves to fix the attention
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the legislator more closely than these two new axioms of the science
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of manufactures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a workman is unceasingly and exclusively engaged in the fabrication
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of one thing, he ultimately does his work with singular dexterity; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the same time he loses the general faculty of applying his mind to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the direction of the work. He every day becomes more adroit and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industrious; so that it may be said of him, that in proportion as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: workman improves the man is degraded. What can be expected of a man who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has spent twenty years of his life in making heads for pins? and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what can that mighty human intelligence, which has so often stirred the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world, be applied in him, except it be to investigate the best method of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: making pins' heads? When a workman has spent a considerable portion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his existence in this manner, his thoughts are forever set upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object of his daily toil; his body has contracted certain fixed habits,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it can never shake off: in a word, he no longer belongs to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself, but to the calling which he has chosen. It is in vain that laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and manners have been at the pains to level all barriers round such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a man, and to open to him on every side a thousand different paths to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune; a theory of manufactures more powerful than manners and laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: binds him to a craft, and frequently to a spot, which he cannot leave:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it assigns to him a certain place in society, beyond which he cannot go:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of universal movement it has rendered him stationary.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In proportion as the principle of the division of labor is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extensively applied, the workman becomes more weak, more narrow-minded,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more dependent. The art advances, the artisan recedes. On the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand, in proportion as it becomes more manifest that the productions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures are by so much the cheaper and better as the manufacture is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: larger and the amount of capital employed more considerable, wealthy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and educated men come forward to embark in manufactures which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heretofore abandoned to poor or ignorant handicraftsmen. The magnitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the efforts required, and the importance of the results to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtained, attract them. Thus at the very time at which the science
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of manufactures lowers the class of workmen, it raises the class of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: masters.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whereas the workman concentrates his faculties more and more upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: study of a single detail, the master surveys a more extensive whole, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mind of the latter is enlarged in proportion as that of the former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is narrowed. In a short time the one will require nothing but physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength without intelligence; the other stands in need of science, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost of genius, to insure success. This man resembles more and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the administrator of a vast empire--that man, a brute. The master and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the workman have then here no similarity, and their differences increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every day. They are only connected as the two rings at the extremities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a long chain. Each of them fills the station which is made for him,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and out of which he does not get: the one is continually, closely, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessarily dependent upon the other, and seems as much born to obey as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that other is to command. What is this but aristocracy?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As the conditions of men constituting the nation become more and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal, the demand for manufactured commodities becomes more general and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more extensive; and the cheapness which places these objects within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the reach of slender fortunes becomes a great element of success. Hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there are every day more men of great opulence and education who devote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their wealth and knowledge to manufactures; and who seek, by opening
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large establishments, and by a strict division of labor, to meet the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fresh demands which are made on all sides. Thus, in proportion as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mass of the nation turns to democracy, that particular class which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engaged in manufactures becomes more aristocratic. Men grow more alike
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the one--more different in the other; and inequality increases in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the less numerous class in the same ratio in which it decreases in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community. Hence it would appear, on searching to the bottom, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy should naturally spring out of the bosom of democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But this kind of aristocracy by no means resembles those kinds which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preceded it. It will be observed at once, that as it applies exclusively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to manufactures and to some manufacturing callings, it is a monstrous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exception in the general aspect of society. The small aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: societies which are formed by some manufacturers in the midst of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense democracy of our age, contain, like the great aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: societies of former ages, some men who are very opulent, and a multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are wretchedly poor. The poor have few means of escaping from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition and becoming rich; but the rich are constantly becoming poor,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or they give up business when they have realized a fortune. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elements of which the class of the poor is composed are fixed; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elements of which the class of the rich is composed are not so. To say
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the truth, though there are rich men, the class of rich men does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist; for these rich individuals have no feelings or purposes in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common, no mutual traditions or mutual hopes; there are therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members, but no body.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not only are the rich not compactly united amongst themselves, but there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is no real bond between them and the poor. Their relative position is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not a permanent one; they are constantly drawn together or separated by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their interests. The workman is generally dependent on the master, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not on any particular master; these two men meet in the factory, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know not each other elsewhere; and whilst they come into contact on one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point, they stand very wide apart on all others. The manufacturer asks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing of the workman but his labor; the workman expects nothing from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him but his wages. The one contracts no obligation to protect, nor the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other to defend; and they are not permanently connected either by habit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or by duty. The aristocracy created by business rarely settles in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: midst of the manufacturing population which it directs; the object
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not to govern that population, but to use it. An aristocracy thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constituted can have no great hold upon those whom it employs; and even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if it succeed in retaining them at one moment, they escape the next; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knows not how to will, and it cannot act. The territorial aristocracy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former ages was either bound by law, or thought itself bound by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usage, to come to the relief of its serving-men, and to succor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their distresses. But the manufacturing aristocracy of our age first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impoverishes and debases the men who serve it, and then abandons them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be supported by the charity of the public. This is a natural consequence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of what has been said before. Between the workmen and the master there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are frequent relations, but no real partnership.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am of opinion, upon the whole, that the manufacturing aristocracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is growing up under our eyes is one of the harshest which ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existed in the world; but at the same time it is one of the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confined and least dangerous. Nevertheless the friends of democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should keep their eyes anxiously fixed in this direction; for if ever a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanent inequality of conditions and aristocracy again penetrate into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world, it may be predicted that this is the channel by which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will enter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Book Three: Influence Of Democracy On Manners, Properly So Called
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter I: That Manners Are Softened As Social Conditions Become More
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Equal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We perceive that for several ages social conditions have tended to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality, and we discover that in the course of the same period the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners of society have been softened. Are these two things merely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaneous, or does any secret link exist between them, so that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one cannot go on without making the other advance? Several causes may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concur to render the manners of a people less rude; but, of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these causes, the most powerful appears to me to be the equality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions. Equality of conditions and growing civility in manners are,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then, in my eyes, not only contemporaneous occurrences, but correlative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facts. When the fabulists seek to interest us in the actions of beasts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they invest them with human notions and passions; the poets who sing of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirits and angels do the same; there is no wretchedness so deep, nor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any happiness so pure, as to fill the human mind and touch the heart,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unless we are ourselves held up to our own eyes under other features.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is strictly applicable to the subject upon which we are at present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engaged. When all men are irrevocably marshalled in an aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, according to their professions, their property, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: birth, the members of each class, considering themselves as children
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the same family, cherish a constant and lively sympathy towards each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, which can never be felt in an equal degree by the citizens of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democracy. But the same feeling does not exist between the several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes towards each other. Amongst an aristocratic people each caste
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has its own opinions, feelings, rights, manners, and modes of living.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the men of whom each caste is composed do not resemble the mass of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their fellow-citizens; they do not think or feel in the same manner,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they scarcely believe that they belong to the same human race. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot, therefore, thoroughly understand what others feel, nor judge of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others by themselves. Yet they are sometimes eager to lend each other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mutual aid; but this is not contrary to my previous observation. These
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic institutions, which made the beings of one and the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: race so different, nevertheless bound them to each other by close
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political ties. Although the serf had no natural interest in the fate of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nobles, he did not the less think himself obliged to devote his person
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the service of that noble who happened to be his lord; and although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the noble held himself to be of a different nature from that of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: serfs, he nevertheless held that his duty and his honor constrained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him to defend, at the risk of his own life, those who dwelt upon his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: domains.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is evident that these mutual obligations did not originate in the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of nature, but in the law of society; and that the claim of social duty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was more stringent than that of mere humanity. These services were not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supposed to be due from man to man, but to the vassal or to the lord.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Feudal institutions awakened a lively sympathy for the sufferings of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain men, but none at all for the miseries of mankind. They infused
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generosity rather than mildness into the manners of the time, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although they prompted men to great acts of self-devotion, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engendered no real sympathies; for real sympathies can only exist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between those who are alike; and in aristocratic ages men acknowledge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: none but the members of their own caste to be like themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the chroniclers of the Middle Ages, who all belonged to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy by birth or education, relate the tragical end of a noble,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their grief flows apace; whereas they tell you at a breath, and without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wincing, of massacres and tortures inflicted on the common sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. Not that these writers felt habitual hatred or systematic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disdain for the people; war between the several classes of the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not yet declared. They were impelled by an instinct rather than by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passion; as they had formed no clear notion of a poor man's sufferings,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they cared but little for his fate. The same feelings animated the lower
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orders whenever the feudal tie was broken. The same ages which witnessed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so many heroic acts of self-devotion on the part of vassals for their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lords, were stained with atrocious barbarities, exercised from time to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time by the lower classes on the higher. It must not be supposed that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this mutual insensibility arose solely from the absence of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order and education; for traces of it are to be found in the following
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centuries, which became tranquil and enlightened whilst they remained
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic. In 1675 the lower classes in Brittany revolted at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the imposition of a new tax. These disturbances were put down with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unexampled atrocity. Observe the language in which Madame de Sevigne, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: witness of these horrors, relates them to her daughter:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Aux Rochers, 30 Octobre, 1675.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Mon Dieu, ma fille, que votre lettre d'Aix est plaisante! Au moins
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relisez vos lettres avant que de les envoyer; laissez-vous surpendre a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leur agrement, et consolez-vous par ce plaisir de la peine que vous avez
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: d'en tant ecrire. Vous avez donc baise toute la Provence? il n'y aurait
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pas satisfaction a baiser toute la Bretagne, a moins qu'on n'aimat a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sentir le vin. . . . Voulez-vous savoir des nouvelles de Rennes? On a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fait une taxe de cent mille ecus sur le bourgeois; et si on ne trouve
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point cette somme dans vingt-quatre heures, elle sera doublee et
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exigible par les soldats. On a chasse et banni toute une grand rue, et
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defendu de les recueillir sous peine de la vie; de sorte qu'on voyait
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tous ces miserables, veillards, femmes accouchees, enfans, errer en
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleurs au sortir de cette ville sans savoir ou aller. On roua avant-hier
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: un violon, qui avait commence la danse et la pillerie du papier timbre;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: il a ete ecartele apres sa mort, et ses quatre quartiers exposes aux
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quatre coins de la ville. On a pris soixante bourgeois, et on commence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demain les punitions. Cette province est un bel exemple pour les autres,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: et surtout de respecter les gouverneurs et les gouvernantes, et de ne
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point jeter de pierres dans leur jardin." *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: To feel the point of this joke the reader should recollect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that Madame de Grignan was Gouvernante de Provence.] "Madame de Tarente
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: etait hier dans ces bois par un temps enchante: il n'est question ni de
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chambre ni de collation; elle entre par la barriere et s'en retourne de
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: meme. . . ."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In another letter she adds:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Vous me parlez bien plaisamment de nos miseres; nous ne sommes plus si
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: roues; un en huit jours, pour entretenir la justice. Il est vrai que la
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penderie me parait maintenant un refraichissement. J'ai une tout autre
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idee de la justice, depuis que je suis en ce pays. Vos galeriens me
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: paraissent une societe d'honnetes gens qui se sont retires du monde pour
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mener une vie douce."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would be a mistake to suppose that Madame de Sevigne, who wrote these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lines, was a selfish or cruel person; she was passionately attached
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to her children, and very ready to sympathize in the sorrows of her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: friends; nay, her letters show that she treated her vassals and servants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with kindness and indulgence. But Madame de Sevigne had no clear notion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of suffering in anyone who was not a person of quality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In our time the harshest man writing to the most insensible person of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his acquaintance would not venture wantonly to indulge in the cruel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jocularity which I have quoted; and even if his own manners allowed him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to do so, the manners of society at large would forbid it. Whence does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this arise? Have we more sensibility than our forefathers? I know not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that we have; but I am sure that our insensibility is extended to a far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater range of objects. When all the ranks of a community are nearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal, as all men think and feel in nearly the same manner, each of them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may judge in a moment of the sensations of all the others; he casts a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapid glance upon himself, and that is enough. There is no wretchedness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into which he cannot readily enter, and a secret instinct reveals to him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its extent. It signifies not that strangers or foes be the sufferers;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination puts him in their place; something like a personal feeling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is mingled with his pity, and makes himself suffer whilst the body
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his fellow-creature is in torture. In democratic ages men rarely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sacrifice themselves for one another; but they display general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compassion for the members of the human race. They inflict no useless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ills; and they are happy to relieve the griefs of others, when they can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do so without much hurting themselves; they are not disinterested, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are humane.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although the Americans have, in a manner, reduced egotism to a social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and philosophical theory, they are nevertheless extremely open to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compassion. In no country is criminal justice administered with more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mildness than in the United States. Whilst the English seem disposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carefully to retain the bloody traces of the dark ages in their penal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation, the Americans have almost expunged capital punishment from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their codes. North America is, I think, the only one country upon earth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in which the life of no one citizen has been taken for a political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offence in the course of the last fifty years. The circumstance which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conclusively shows that this singular mildness of the Americans arises
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chiefly from their social condition, is the manner in which they treat
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their slaves. Perhaps there is not, upon the whole, a single European
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: colony in the New World in which the physical condition of the blacks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is less severe than in the United States; yet the slaves still endure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: horrid sufferings there, and are constantly exposed to barbarous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: punishments. It is easy to perceive that the lot of these unhappy beings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inspires their masters with but little compassion, and that they look
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon slavery, not only as an institution which is profitable to them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
