text: but as an evil which does not affect them. Thus the same man who is full
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of humanity towards his fellow-creatures when they are at the same time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his equals, becomes insensible to their afflictions as soon as that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality ceases. His mildness should therefore be attributed to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality of conditions, rather than to civilization and education.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What I have here remarked of individuals is, to a certain extent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applicable to nations. When each nation has its distinct opinions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belief, laws, and customs, it looks upon itself as the whole of mankind,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and is moved by no sorrows but its own. Should war break out between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two nations animated by this feeling, it is sure to be waged with great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cruelty. At the time of their highest culture, the Romans slaughtered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the generals of their enemies, after having dragged them in triumph
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: behind a car; and they flung their prisoners to the beasts of the Circus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the amusement of the people. Cicero, who declaimed so vehemently at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the notion of crucifying a Roman citizen, had not a word to say against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these horrible abuses of victory. It is evident that in his eyes a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barbarian did not belong to the same human race as a Roman. On the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, in proportion as nations become more like each other, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become reciprocally more compassionate, and the law of nations is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mitigated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter II: That Democracy Renders The Habitual Intercourse Of The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans Simple And Easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democracy does not attach men strongly to each other; but it places
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their habitual intercourse upon an easier footing. If two Englishmen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chance to meet at the Antipodes, where they are surrounded by strangers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whose language and manners are almost unknown to them, they will first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stare at each other with much curiosity and a kind of secret uneasiness;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will then turn away, or, if one accosts the other, they will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take care only to converse with a constrained and absent air upon very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unimportant subjects. Yet there is no enmity between these men; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have never seen each other before, and each believes the other to be a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respectable person. Why then should they stand so cautiously apart? We
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must go back to England to learn the reason.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When it is birth alone, independent of wealth, which classes men in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society, everyone knows exactly what his own position is upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social scale; he does not seek to rise, he does not fear to sink. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a community thus organized, men of different castes communicate very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little with each other; but if accident brings them together, they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ready to converse without hoping or fearing to lose their own position.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Their intercourse is not upon a footing of equality, but it is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constrained. When moneyed aristocracy succeeds to aristocracy of birth,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the case is altered. The privileges of some are still extremely great,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the possibility of acquiring those privileges is open to all: whence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it follows that those who possess them are constantly haunted by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apprehension of losing them, or of other men's sharing them; those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not yet enjoy them long to possess them at any cost, or, if they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fail to appear at least to possess them--which is not impossible. As the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social importance of men is no longer ostensibly and permanently fixed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by blood, and is infinitely varied by wealth, ranks still exist, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not easy clearly to distinguish at a glance those who respectively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belong to them. Secret hostilities then arise in the community; one set
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men endeavor by innumerable artifices to penetrate, or to appear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penetrate, amongst those who are above them; another set are constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in arms against these usurpers of their rights; or rather the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual does both at once, and whilst he seeks to raise himself into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a higher circle, he is always on the defensive against the intrusion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those below him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such is the condition of England at the present time; and I am of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion that the peculiarity before adverted to is principally to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attributed to this cause. As aristocratic pride is still extremely great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst the English, and as the limits of aristocracy are ill-defined,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everybody lives in constant dread lest advantage should be taken of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: familiarity. Unable to judge at once of the social position of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he meets, an Englishman prudently avoids all contact with them. Men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are afraid lest some slight service rendered should draw them into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an unsuitable acquaintance; they dread civilities, and they avoid the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtrusive gratitude of a stranger quite as much as his hatred. Many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people attribute these singular anti-social propensities, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reserved and taciturn bearing of the English, to purely physical causes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I may admit that there is something of it in their race, but much more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of it is attributable to their social condition, as is proved by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrast of the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America, where the privileges of birth never existed, and where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: riches confer no peculiar rights on their possessors, men unacquainted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with each other are very ready to frequent the same places, and find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neither peril nor advantage in the free interchange of their thoughts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If they meet by accident, they neither seek nor avoid intercourse; their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner is therefore natural, frank, and open: it is easy to see that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they hardly expect or apprehend anything from each other, and that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not care to display, any more than to conceal, their position in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world. If their demeanor is often cold and serious, it is never haughty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or constrained; and if they do not converse, it is because they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not in a humor to talk, not because they think it their interest to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: silent. In a foreign country two Americans are at once friends, simply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they are Americans. They are repulsed by no prejudice; they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attracted by their common country. For two Englishmen the same blood
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not enough; they must be brought together by the same rank. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans remark this unsociable mood of the English as much as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French do, and they are not less astonished by it. Yet the Americans are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connected with England by their origin, their religion, their language,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and partially by their manners; they only differ in their social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition. It may therefore be inferred that the reserve of the English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceeds from the constitution of their country much more than from that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its inhabitants.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter III: Why The Americans Show So Little Sensitiveness In Their Own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Country, And Are So Sensitive In Europe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The temper of the Americans is vindictive, like that of all serious and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reflecting nations. They hardly ever forget an offence, but it is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easy to offend them; and their resentment is as slow to kindle as it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to abate. In aristocratic communities where a small number of persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manage everything, the outward intercourse of men is subject to settled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conventional rules. Everyone then thinks he knows exactly what marks of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect or of condescension he ought to display, and none are presumed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be ignorant of the science of etiquette. These usages of the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class in society afterwards serve as a model to all the others; besides
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which each of the latter lays down a code of its own, to which all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its members are bound to conform. Thus the rules of politeness form a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complex system of legislation, which it is difficult to be perfectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: master of, but from which it is dangerous for anyone to deviate; so that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men are constantly exposed involuntarily to inflict or to receive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bitter affronts. But as the distinctions of rank are obliterated, as men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differing in education and in birth meet and mingle in the same places
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of resort, it is almost impossible to agree upon the rules of good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: breeding. As its laws are uncertain, to disobey them is not a crime,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even in the eyes of those who know what they are; men attach more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance to intentions than to forms, and they grow less civil, but at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same time less quarrelsome. There are many little attentions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an American does not care about; he thinks they are not due to him, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he presumes that they are not known to be due: he therefore either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not perceive a rudeness or he forgives it; his manners become less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courteous, and his character more plain and masculine.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The mutual indulgence which the Americans display, and the manly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confidence with which they treat each other, also result from another
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deeper and more general cause, which I have already adverted to in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preceding chapter. In the United States the distinctions of rank
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in civil society are slight, in political society they are null; an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American, therefore, does not think himself bound to pay particular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attentions to any of his fellow-citizens, nor does he require such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attentions from them towards himself. As he does not see that it is his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest eagerly to seek the company of any of his countrymen, he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slow to fancy that his own company is declined: despising no one on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: account of his station, he does not imagine that anyone can despise him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for that cause; and until he has clearly perceived an insult, he does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not suppose that an affront was intended. The social condition of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans naturally accustoms them not to take offence in small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: matters; and, on the other hand, the democratic freedom which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoy transfuses this same mildness of temper into the character of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation. The political institutions of the United States constantly bring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens of all ranks into contact, and compel them to pursue great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings in concert. People thus engaged have scarcely time to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attend to the details of etiquette, and they are besides too strongly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interested in living harmoniously for them to stick at such things. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore soon acquire a habit of considering the feelings and opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those whom they meet more than their manners, and they do not allow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to be annoyed by trifles.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have often remarked in the United States that it is not easy to make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a man understand that his presence may be dispensed with; hints will not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always suffice to shake him off. I contradict an American at every word
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he says, to show him that his conversation bores me; he instantly labors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with fresh pertinacity to convince me; I preserve a dogged silence, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he thinks I am meditating deeply on the truths which he is uttering; at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: last I rush from his company, and he supposes that some urgent business
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hurries me elsewhere. This man will never understand that he wearies me
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to extinction unless I tell him so: and the only way to get rid of him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to make him my enemy for life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It appears surprising at first sight that the same man transported to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe suddenly becomes so sensitive and captious, that I often find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it as difficult to avoid offending him here as it was to put him out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of countenance. These two opposite effects proceed from the same cause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic institutions generally give men a lofty notion of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country and of themselves. An American leaves his country with a heart
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: swollen with pride; on arriving in Europe he at once finds out that we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not so engrossed by the United States and the great people which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabits them as he had supposed, and this begins to annoy him. He has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been informed that the conditions of society are not equal in our part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the globe, and he observes that among the nations of Europe the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traces of rank are not wholly obliterated; that wealth and birth still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retain some indeterminate privileges, which force themselves upon his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notice whilst they elude definition. He is therefore profoundly ignorant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the place which he ought to occupy in this half-ruined scale of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes, which are sufficiently distinct to hate and despise each other,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yet sufficiently alike for him to be always confounding them. He is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afraid of ranging himself too high--still more is he afraid of being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranged too low; this twofold peril keeps his mind constantly on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stretch, and embarrasses all he says and does. He learns from tradition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in Europe ceremonial observances were infinitely varied according
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to different ranks; this recollection of former times completes his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perplexity, and he is the more afraid of not obtaining those marks of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect which are due to him, as he does not exactly know in what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they consist. He is like a man surrounded by traps: society is not a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recreation for him, but a serious toil: he weighs your least actions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interrogates your looks, and scrutinizes all you say, lest there should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be some hidden allusion to affront him. I doubt whether there was ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a provincial man of quality so punctilious in breeding as he is: he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavors to attend to the slightest rules of etiquette, and does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allow one of them to be waived towards himself: he is full of scruples
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and at the same time of pretensions; he wishes to do enough, but fears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to do too much; and as he does not very well know the limits of the one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or of the other, he keeps up a haughty and embarrassed air of reserve.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But this is not all: here is yet another double of the human heart. An
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American is forever talking of the admirable equality which prevails in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States; aloud he makes it the boast of his country, but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secret he deplores it for himself; and he aspires to show that, for his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part, he is an exception to the general state of things which he vaunts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is hardly an American to be met with who does not claim some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remote kindred with the first founders of the colonies; and as for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scions of the noble families of England, America seemed to me to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: covered with them. When an opulent American arrives in Europe, his first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: care is to surround himself with all the luxuries of wealth: he is so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afraid of being taken for the plain citizen of a democracy, that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adopts a hundred distorted ways of bringing some new instance of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth before you every day. His house will be in the most fashionable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of the town: he will always be surrounded by a host of servants.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have heard an American complain, that in the best houses of Paris the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society was rather mixed; the taste which prevails there was not pure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enough for him; and he ventured to hint that, in his opinion, there was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a want of elegance of manner; he could not accustom himself to see wit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concealed under such unpretending forms.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These contrasts ought not to surprise us. If the vestiges of former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic distinctions were not so completely effaced in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, the Americans would be less simple and less tolerant in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own country--they would require less, and be less fond of borrowed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners in ours.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IV: Consequences Of The Three Preceding Chapters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When men feel a natural compassion for their mutual sufferings--when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are brought together by easy and frequent intercourse, and no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sensitive feelings keep them asunder--it may readily be supposed that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will lend assistance to one another whenever it is needed. When an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American asks for the co-operation of his fellow-citizens it is seldom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refused, and I have often seen it afforded spontaneously and with great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: goodwill. If an accident happens on the highway, everybody hastens to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: help the sufferer; if some great and sudden calamity befalls a family,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the purses of a thousand strangers are at once willingly opened, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small but numerous donations pour in to relieve their distress. It often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happens amongst the most civilized nations of the globe, that a poor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wretch is as friendless in the midst of a crowd as the savage in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilds: this is hardly ever the case in the United States. The Americans,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are always cold and often coarse in their manners, seldom show
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insensibility; and if they do not proffer services eagerly, yet they do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not refuse to render them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All this is not in contradiction to what I have said before on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject of individualism. The two things are so far from combating each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, that I can see how they agree. Equality of conditions, whilst it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: makes men feel their independence, shows them their own weakness: they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are free, but exposed to a thousand accidents; and experience soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: teaches them that, although they do not habitually require the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assistance of others, a time almost always comes when they cannot do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without it. We constantly see in Europe that men of the same profession
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are ever ready to assist each other; they are all exposed to the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ills, and that is enough to teach them to seek mutual preservatives,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however hard-hearted and selfish they may otherwise be. When one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them falls into danger, from which the others may save him by a slight
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transient sacrifice or a sudden effort, they do not fail to make the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempt. Not that they are deeply interested in his fate; for if, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chance, their exertions are unavailing, they immediately forget the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object of them, and return to their own business; but a sort of tacit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and almost involuntary agreement has been passed between them, by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each one owes to the others a temporary support which he may claim for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself in turn. Extend to a people the remark here applied to a class,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and you will understand my meaning. A similar covenant exists in fact
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between all the citizens of a democracy: they all feel themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject to the same weakness and the same dangers; and their interest,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as well as their sympathy, makes it a rule with them to lend each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other mutual assistance when required. The more equal social conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become, the more do men display this reciprocal disposition to oblige
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other. In democracies no great benefits are conferred, but good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offices are constantly rendered: a man seldom displays self-devotion,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but all men are ready to be of service to one another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter V: How Democracy Affects the Relation Of Masters And Servants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An American who had travelled for a long time in Europe once said to me,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The English treat their servants with a stiffness and imperiousness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of manner which surprise us; but on the other hand the French sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: treat their attendants with a degree of familiarity or of politeness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which we cannot conceive. It looks as if they were afraid to give
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orders: the posture of the superior and the inferior is ill-maintained."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The remark was a just one, and I have often made it myself. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always considered England as the country in the world where, in our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, the bond of domestic service is drawn most tightly, and France as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the country where it is most relaxed. Nowhere have I seen masters stand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so high or so low as in these two countries. Between these two extremes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans are to be placed. Such is the fact as it appears upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surface of things: to discover the causes of that fact, it is necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to search the matter thoroughly.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No communities have ever yet existed in which social conditions have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been so equal that there were neither rich nor poor, and consequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neither masters nor servants. Democracy does not prevent the existence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these two classes, but it changes their dispositions and modifies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their mutual relations. Amongst aristocratic nations servants form a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinct class, not more variously composed than that of masters. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settled order is soon established; in the former as well as in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter class a scale is formed, with numerous distinctions or marked
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradations of rank, and generations succeed each other thus without any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change of position. These two communities are superposed one above the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, always distinct, but regulated by analogous principles. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic constitution does not exert a less powerful influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the notions and manners of servants than on those of masters; and,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although the effects are different, the same cause may easily be traced.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Both classes constitute small communities in the heart of the nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and certain permanent notions of right and wrong are ultimately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engendered amongst them. The different acts of human life are viewed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one particular and unchanging light. In the society of servants, as in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of masters, men exercise a great influence over each other: they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledge settled rules, and in the absence of law they are guided by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a sort of public opinion: their habits are settled, and their conduct is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: placed under a certain control.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These men, whose destiny is to obey, certainly do not understand fame,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtue, honesty, and honor in the same manner as their masters; but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have a pride, a virtue, and an honesty pertaining to their condition;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they have a notion, if I may use the expression, of a sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servile honor. *a Because a class is mean, it must not be supposed that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all who belong to it are mean-hearted; to think so would be a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mistake. However lowly it may be, he who is foremost there, and who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has no notion of quitting it, occupies an aristocratic position which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inspires him with lofty feelings, pride, and self-respect, that fit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him for the higher virtues and actions above the common. Amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic nations it was by no means rare to find men of noble and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vigorous minds in the service of the great, who felt not the servitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they bore, and who submitted to the will of their masters without any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fear of their displeasure. But this was hardly ever the case amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inferior ranks of domestic servants. It may be imagined that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who occupies the lowest stage of the order of menials stands very low
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indeed. The French created a word on purpose to designate the servants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the aristocracy--they called them lackeys. This word "lackey"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: served as the strongest expression, when all others were exhausted, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: designate human meanness. Under the old French monarchy, to denote by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a single expression a low-spirited contemptible fellow, it was usual to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: say that he had the "soul of a lackey"; the term was enough to convey
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all that was intended. [Footnote a: If the principal opinions by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men are guided are examined closely and in detail, the analogy appears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still more striking, and one is surprised to find amongst them, just as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much as amongst the haughtiest scions of a feudal race, pride of birth,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect for their ancestry and their descendants, disdain of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferiors, a dread of contact, a taste for etiquette, precedents, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: antiquity.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The permanent inequality of conditions not only gives servants certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar virtues and vices, but it places them in a peculiar relation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with respect to their masters. Amongst aristocratic nations the poor man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is familiarized from his childhood with the notion of being commanded:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to whichever side he turns his eyes the graduated structure of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the aspect of obedience meet his view. Hence in those countries the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: master readily obtains prompt, complete, respectful, and easy obedience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from his servants, because they revere in him not only their master but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the class of masters. He weighs down their will by the whole weight of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the aristocracy. He orders their actions--to a certain extent he even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directs their thoughts. In aristocracies the master often exercises,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even without being aware of it, an amazing sway over the opinions, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits, and the manners of those who obey him, and his influence extends
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even further than his authority.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocratic communities there are not only hereditary families of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servants as well as of masters, but the same families of servants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adhere for several generations to the same families of masters (like two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parallel lines which neither meet nor separate); and this considerably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: modifies the mutual relations of these two classes of persons. Thus,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although in aristocratic society the master and servant have no natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resemblance--although, on the contrary, they are placed at an immense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distance on the scale of human beings by their fortune, education, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions--yet time ultimately binds them together. They are connected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a long series of common reminiscences, and however different they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be, they grow alike; whilst in democracies, where they are naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost alike, they always remain strangers to each other. Amongst an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic people the master gets to look upon his servants as an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferior and secondary part of himself, and he often takes an interest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in their lot by a last stretch of egotism.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Servants, on their part, are not averse to regard themselves in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: light; and they sometimes identify themselves with the person of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: master, so that they become an appendage to him in their own eyes as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well as in his. In aristocracies a servant fills a subordinate position
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which he cannot get out of; above him is another man, holding a superior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rank which he cannot lose. On one side are obscurity, poverty, obedience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for life; on the other, and also for life, fame, wealth, and command.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The two conditions are always distinct and always in propinquity; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tie that connects them is as lasting as they are themselves. In this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predicament the servant ultimately detaches his notion of interest from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his own person; he deserts himself, as it were, or rather he transports
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself into the character of his master, and thus assumes an imaginary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personality. He complacently invests himself with the wealth of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who command him; he shares their fame, exalts himself by their rank,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and feeds his mind with borrowed greatness, to which he attaches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more importance than those who fully and really possess it. There is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: something touching, and at the same time ridiculous, in this strange
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confusion of two different states of being. These passions of masters,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when they pass into the souls of menials, assume the natural dimensions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the place they occupy--they are contracted and lowered. What was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pride in the former becomes puerile vanity and paltry ostentation in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter. The servants of a great man are commonly most punctilious as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the marks of respect due to him, and they attach more importance to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slightest privileges than he does himself. In France a few of these old
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servants of the aristocracy are still to be met with here and there;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have survived their race, which will soon disappear with them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: altogether. In the United States I never saw anyone at all like them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans are not only unacquainted with the kind of man, but it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardly possible to make them understand that such ever existed. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scarcely less difficult for them to conceive it, than for us to form a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: correct notion of what a slave was amongst the Romans, or a serf in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Middle Ages. All these men were in fact, though in different degrees,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: results of the same cause: they are all retiring from our sight, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disappearing in the obscurity of the past, together with the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition to which they owed their origin.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Equality of conditions turns servants and masters into new beings, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: places them in new relative positions. When social conditions are nearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal, men are constantly changing their situations in life: there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still a class of menials and a class of masters, but these classes are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not always composed of the same individuals, still less of the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: families; and those who command are not more secure of perpetuity than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who obey. As servants do not form a separate people, they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no habits, prejudices, or manners peculiar to themselves; they are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarkable for any particular turn of mind or moods of feeling. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: know no vices or virtues of their condition, but they partake of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: education, the opinions, the feelings, the virtues, and the vices of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their contemporaries; and they are honest men or scoundrels in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: way as their masters are. The conditions of servants are not less equal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than those of masters. As no marked ranks or fixed subordination are to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be found amongst them, they will not display either the meanness or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greatness which characterizes the aristocracy of menials as well as all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other aristocracies. I never saw a man in the United States who reminded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me of that class of confidential servants of which we still retain a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reminiscence in Europe, neither did I ever meet with such a thing as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lackey: all traces of the one and of the other have disappeared.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democracies servants are not only equal amongst themselves, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be said that they are in some sort the equals of their masters. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: requires explanation in order to be rightly understood. At any moment a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servant may become a master, and he aspires to rise to that condition:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the servant is therefore not a different man from the master. Why
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then has the former a right to command, and what compels the latter to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obey?--the free and temporary consent of both their wills. Neither of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them is by nature inferior to the other; they only become so for a time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by covenant. Within the terms of this covenant, the one is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servant, the other a master; beyond it they are two citizens of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonwealth--two men. I beg the reader particularly to observe that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this is not only the notion which servants themselves entertain of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own condition; domestic service is looked upon by masters in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: light; and the precise limits of authority and obedience are as clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: settled in the mind of the one as in that of the other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the greater part of the community have long attained a condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nearly alike, and when equality is an old and acknowledged fact, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public mind, which is never affected by exceptions, assigns certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general limits to the value of man, above or below which no man can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long remain placed. It is in vain that wealth and poverty, authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and obedience, accidentally interpose great distances between two men;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public opinion, founded upon the usual order of things, draws them to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common level, and creates a species of imaginary equality between them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in spite of the real inequality of their conditions. This all-powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion penetrates at length even into the hearts of those whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest might arm them to resist it; it affects their judgment whilst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it subdues their will. In their inmost convictions the master and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servant no longer perceive any deep-seated difference between them, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they neither hope nor fear to meet with any such at any time. They are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore neither subject to disdain nor to anger, and they discern in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other neither humility nor pride. The master holds the contract of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: service to be the only source of his power, and the servant regards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it as the only cause of his obedience. They do not quarrel about their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reciprocal situations, but each knows his own and keeps it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the French army the common soldier is taken from nearly the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes as the officer, and may hold the same commissions; out of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranks he considers himself entirely equal to his military superiors, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in point of fact he is so; but when under arms he does not hesitate to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obey, and his obedience is not the less prompt, precise, and ready,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for being voluntary and defined. This example may give a notion of what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: takes place between masters and servants in democratic communities.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would be preposterous to suppose that those warm and deep-seated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affections, which are sometimes kindled in the domestic service of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy, will ever spring up between these two men, or that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will exhibit strong instances of self-sacrifice. In aristocracies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: masters and servants live apart, and frequently their only intercourse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is through a third person; yet they commonly stand firmly by one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another. In democratic countries the master and the servant are close
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together; they are in daily personal contact, but their minds do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intermingle; they have common occupations, hardly ever common interests.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst such a people the servant always considers himself as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sojourner in the dwelling of his masters. He knew nothing of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forefathers--he will see nothing of their descendants--he has nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lasting to expect from their hand. Why then should he confound his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life with theirs, and whence should so strange a surrender of himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceed? The reciprocal position of the two men is changed--their mutual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relations must be so too.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I would fain illustrate all these reflections by the example of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans; but for this purpose the distinctions of persons and places
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be accurately traced. In the South of the Union, slavery exists;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all that I have just said is consequently inapplicable there. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North, the majority of servants are either freedmen or the children
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of freedmen; these persons occupy a contested position in the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estimation; by the laws they are brought up to the level of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: masters--by the manners of the country they are obstinately detruded
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from it. They do not themselves clearly know their proper place, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are almost always either insolent or craven. But in the Northern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, especially in New England, there are a certain number of whites,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who agree, for wages, to yield a temporary obedience to the will of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their fellow-citizens. I have heard that these servants commonly perform
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the duties of their situation with punctuality and intelligence; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that without thinking themselves naturally inferior to the person who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orders them, they submit without reluctance to obey him. They appear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me to carry into service some of those manly habits which independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and equality engender. Having once selected a hard way of life, they do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not seek to escape from it by indirect means; and they have sufficient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect for themselves, not to refuse to their master that obedience
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they have freely promised. On their part, masters require nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their servants but the faithful and rigorous performance of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: covenant: they do not ask for marks of respect, they do not claim their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: love or devoted attachment; it is enough that, as servants, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are exact and honest. It would not then be true to assert that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democratic society, the relation of servants and masters is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disorganized: it is organized on another footing; the rule is different,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but there is a rule.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not my purpose to inquire whether the new state of things which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have just described is inferior to that which preceded it, or simply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different. Enough for me that it is fixed and determined: for what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most important to meet with among men is not any given ordering, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order. But what shall I say of those sad and troubled times at which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality is established in the midst of the tumult of revolution--when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy, after having been introduced into the state of society, still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggles with difficulty against the prejudices and manners of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country? The laws, and partially public opinion, already declare that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no natural or permanent inferiority exists between the servant and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the master. But this new belief has not yet reached the innermost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convictions of the latter, or rather his heart rejects it; in the secret
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persuasion of his mind the master thinks that he belongs to a peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and superior race; he dares not say so, but he shudders whilst he allows
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself to be dragged to the same level. His authority over his servants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: becomes timid and at the same time harsh: he has already ceased to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertain for them the feelings of patronizing kindness which long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncontested power always engenders, and he is surprised that, being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changed himself, his servant changes also. He wants his attendants to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form regular and permanent habits, in a condition of domestic service
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is only temporary: he requires that they should appear contented
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with and proud of a servile condition, which they will one day shake
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: off--that they should sacrifice themselves to a man who can neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protect nor ruin them--and in short that they should contract an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indissoluble engagement to a being like themselves, and one who will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: last no longer than they will.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations it often happens that the condition of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: domestic service does not degrade the character of those who enter upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it, because they neither know nor imagine any other; and the amazing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality which is manifest between them and their master appears to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the necessary and unavoidable consequence of some hidden law of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Providence. In democracies the condition of domestic service does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degrade the character of those who enter upon it, because it is freely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chosen, and adopted for a time only; because it is not stigmatized by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public opinion, and creates no permanent inequality between the servant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the master. But whilst the transition from one social condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to another is going on, there is almost always a time when men's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minds fluctuate between the aristocratic notion of subjection and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the democratic notion of obedience. Obedience then loses its moral
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance in the eyes of him who obeys; he no longer considers it as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a species of divine obligation, and he does not yet view it under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its purely human aspect; it has to him no character of sanctity or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of justice, and he submits to it as to a degrading but profitable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition. At that moment a confused and imperfect phantom of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: haunts the minds of servants; they do not at once perceive whether the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality to which they are entitled is to be found within or without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the pale of domestic service; and they rebel in their hearts against a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subordination to which they have subjected themselves, and from which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they derive actual profit. They consent to serve, and they blush to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obey; they like the advantages of service, but not the master; or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather, they are not sure that they ought not themselves to be masters,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they are inclined to consider him who orders them as an unjust
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usurper of their own rights. Then it is that the dwelling of every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen offers a spectacle somewhat analogous to the gloomy aspect of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political society. A secret and intestine warfare is going on there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between powers, ever rivals and suspicious of one another: the master is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ill-natured and weak, the servant ill-natured and intractable; the one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly attempts to evade by unfair restrictions his obligation to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: protect and to remunerate--the other his obligation to obey. The reins
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of domestic government dangle between them, to be snatched at by one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or the other. The lines which divide authority from oppression, liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from license, and right from might, are to their eyes so jumbled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together and confused, that no one knows exactly what he is, or what he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be, or what he ought to be. Such a condition is not democracy, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VI: That Democratic Institutions And Manners Tend To Raise Rents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And Shorten The Terms Of Leases
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What has been said of servants and masters is applicable, to a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extent, to landowners and farming tenants; but this subject deserves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be considered by itself. In America there are, properly speaking, no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tenant farmers; every man owns the ground he tills. It must be admitted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that democratic laws tend greatly to increase the number of landowners,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to diminish that of farming tenants. Yet what takes place in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States is much less attributable to the institutions of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country than to the country itself. In America land is cheap, and anyone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may easily become a landowner; its returns are small, and its produce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot well be divided between a landowner and a farmer. America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore stands alone in this as well as in many other respects, and it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would be a mistake to take it as an example.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe that in democratic as well as in aristocratic countries there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be landowners and tenants, but the connection existing between them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be of a different kind. In aristocracies the hire of a farm is paid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the landlord, not only in rent, but in respect, regard, and duty;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democracies the whole is paid in cash. When estates are divided and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passed from hand to hand, and the permanent connection which existed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between families and the soil is dissolved, the landowner and the tenant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are only casually brought into contact. They meet for a moment to settle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the conditions of the agreement, and then lose sight of each other; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are two strangers brought together by a common interest, and who keenly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talk over a matter of business, the sole object of which is to make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: money.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In proportion as property is subdivided and wealth distributed over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, the community is filled with people whose former opulence is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: declining, and with others whose fortunes are of recent growth and whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants increase more rapidly than their resources. For all such persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the smallest pecuniary profit is a matter of importance, and none of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them feel disposed to waive any of their claims, or to lose any portion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their income. As ranks are intermingled, and as very large as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as very scanty fortunes become more rare, every day brings the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of the landowner nearer to that of the farmer; the one has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally any uncontested superiority over the other; between two men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are equal, and not at ease in their circumstances, the contract of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hire is exclusively an affair of money. A man whose estate extends over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a whole district, and who owns a hundred farms, is well aware of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance of gaining at the same time the affections of some thousands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men; this object appears to call for his exertions, and to attain it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he will readily make considerable sacrifices. But he who owns a hundred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acres is insensible to similar considerations, and he cares but little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to win the private regard of his tenant.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: An aristocracy does not expire like a man in a single day; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic principle is slowly undermined in men's opinion, before it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is attacked in their laws. Long before open war is declared against it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tie which had hitherto united the higher classes to the lower may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seen to be gradually relaxed. Indifference and contempt are betrayed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one class, jealousy and hatred by the others; the intercourse between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich and poor becomes less frequent and less kind, and rents are raised.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is not the consequence of a democratic revolution, but its certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harbinger; for an aristocracy which has lost the affections of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, once and forever, is like a tree dead at the root, which is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more easily torn up by the winds the higher its branches have spread.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the course of the last fifty years the rents of farms have amazingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increased, not only in France but throughout the greater part of Europe.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The remarkable improvements which have taken place in agriculture and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures within the same period do not suffice in my opinion to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explain this fact; recourse must be had to another cause more powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more concealed. I believe that cause is to be found in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic institutions which several European nations have adopted, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the democratic passions which more or less agitate all the rest. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have frequently heard great English landowners congratulate themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, at the present day, they derive a much larger income from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estates than their fathers did. They have perhaps good reasons to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glad; but most assuredly they know not what they are glad of. They think
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are making a clear gain, when it is in reality only an exchange;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their influence is what they are parting with for cash; and what they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gain in money will ere long be lost in power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is yet another sign by which it is easy to know that a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic revolution is going on or approaching. In the Middle Ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all lands were leased for lives, or for very long terms; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: domestic economy of that period shows that leases for ninety-nine years
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were more frequent then than leases for twelve years are now. Men then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believed that families were immortal; men's conditions seemed settled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forever, and the whole of society appeared to be so fixed, that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not supposed that anything would ever be stirred or shaken in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: structure. In ages of equality, the human mind takes a different bent;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the prevailing notion is that nothing abides, and man is haunted by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the thought of mutability. Under this impression the landowner and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the tenant himself are instinctively averse to protracted terms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obligation; they are afraid of being tied up to-morrow by the contract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which benefits them today. They have vague anticipations of some sudden
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and unforeseen change in their conditions; they mistrust themselves;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they fear lest their taste should change, and lest they should lament
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they cannot rid themselves of what they coveted; nor are such fears
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unfounded, for in democratic ages that which is most fluctuating amidst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the fluctuation of all around is the heart of man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VII: Influence Of Democracy On Wages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Most of the remarks which I have already made in speaking of servants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and masters, may be applied to masters and workmen. As the gradations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the social scale come to be less observed, whilst the great sink the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: humble rise, and as poverty as well as opulence ceases to be hereditary,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the distance both in reality and in opinion, which heretofore separated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the workman from the master, is lessened every day. The workman
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceives a more lofty opinion of his rights, of his future, of himself;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he is filled with new ambition and with new desires, he is harassed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: new wants. Every instant he views with longing eyes the profits of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: employer; and in order to share them, he strives to dispose of his labor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at a higher rate, and he generally succeeds at length in the attempt.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democratic countries, as well as elsewhere, most of the branches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of productive industry are carried on at a small cost, by men little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removed by their wealth or education above the level of those whom they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: employ. These manufacturing speculators are extremely numerous; their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests differ; they cannot therefore easily concert or combine their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions. On the other hand the workmen have almost always some sure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources, which enable them to refuse to work when they cannot get
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what they conceive to be the fair price of their labor. In the constant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: struggle for wages which is going on between these two classes, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength is divided, and success alternates from one to the other. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is even probable that in the end the interest of the working class must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevail; for the high wages which they have already obtained make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them every day less dependent on their masters; and as they grow more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent, they have greater facilities for obtaining a further
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase of wages.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall take for example that branch of productive industry which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still at the present day the most generally followed in France, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all the countries of the world--I mean the cultivation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soil. In France most of those who labor for hire in agriculture, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves owners of certain plots of ground, which just enable them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to subsist without working for anyone else. When these laborers come to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offer their services to a neighboring landowner or farmer, if he refuses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them a certain rate of wages, they retire to their own small property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and await another opportunity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that, upon the whole, it may be asserted that a slow and gradual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rise of wages is one of the general laws of democratic communities. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion as social conditions become more equal, wages rise; and as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wages are higher, social conditions become more equal. But a great and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gloomy exception occurs in our own time. I have shown in a preceding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chapter that aristocracy, expelled from political society, has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taken refuge in certain departments of productive industry, and has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established its sway there under another form; this powerfully affects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rate of wages. As a large capital is required to embark in the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturing speculations to which I allude, the number of persons who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enter upon them is exceedingly limited: as their number is small, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can easily concert together, and fix the rate of wages as they please.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Their workmen on the contrary are exceedingly numerous, and the number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them is always increasing; for, from time to time, an extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: run of business takes place, during which wages are inordinately high,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they attract the surrounding population to the factories. But, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once men have embraced that line of life, we have already seen that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot quit it again, because they soon contract habits of body and mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which unfit them for any other sort of toil. These men have generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but little education and industry, with but few resources; they stand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore almost at the mercy of the master. When competition, or other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortuitous circumstances, lessen his profits, he can reduce the wages of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his workmen almost at pleasure, and make from them what he loses by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chances of business. Should the workmen strike, the master, who is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich man, can very well wait without being ruined until necessity brings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them back to him; but they must work day by day or they die, for their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only property is in their hands. They have long been impoverished by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppression, and the poorer they become the more easily may they be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oppressed: they can never escape from this fatal circle of cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and consequence. It is not then surprising that wages, after having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes suddenly risen, are permanently lowered in this branch of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industry; whereas in other callings the price of labor, which generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases but little, is nevertheless constantly augmented.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This state of dependence and wretchedness, in which a part of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturing population of our time lives, forms an exception to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general rule, contrary to the state of all the rest of the community;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but, for this very reason, no circumstance is more important or more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deserving of the especial consideration of the legislator; for when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole of society is in motion, it is difficult to keep any one class
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stationary; and when the greater number of men are opening new paths to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune, it is no less difficult to make the few support in peace their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants and their desires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: Influence Of Democracy On Kindred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have just examined the changes which the equality of conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produces in the mutual relations of the several members of the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst democratic nations, and amongst the Americans in particular.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I would now go deeper, and inquire into the closer ties of kindred: my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object here is not to seek for new truths, but to show in what manner
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facts already known are connected with my subject.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has been universally remarked, that in our time the several members
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a family stand upon an entirely new footing towards each other; that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the distance which formerly separated a father from his sons has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lessened; and that paternal authority, if not destroyed, is at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impaired. Something analogous to this, but even more striking, may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observed in the United States. In America the family, in the Roman and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic signification of the word, does not exist. All that remains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of it are a few vestiges in the first years of childhood, when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: father exercises, without opposition, that absolute domestic authority,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the feebleness of his children renders necessary, and which their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest, as well as his own incontestable superiority, warrants. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as soon as the young American approaches manhood, the ties of filial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience are relaxed day by day: master of his thoughts, he is soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: master of his conduct. In America there is, strictly speaking, no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adolescence: at the close of boyhood the man appears, and begins to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trace out his own path. It would be an error to suppose that this is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preceded by a domestic struggle, in which the son has obtained by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sort of moral violence the liberty that his father refused him. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same habits, the same principles which impel the one to assert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his independence, predispose the other to consider the use of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence as an incontestable right. The former does not exhibit any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
