text: of those rancorous or irregular passions which disturb men long after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have shaken off an established authority; the latter feels none of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that bitter and angry regret which is apt to survive a bygone power. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: father foresees the limits of his authority long beforehand, and when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the time arrives he surrenders it without a struggle: the son looks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forward to the exact period at which he will be his own master; and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enters upon his freedom without precipitation and without effort, as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possession which is his own and which no one seeks to wrest from him. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: The Americans, however, have not yet thought fit to strip
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the parent, as has been done in France, of one of the chief elements of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parental authority, by depriving him of the power of disposing of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property at his death. In the United States there are no restrictions on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the powers of a testator. In this respect, as in almost all others, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is easy to perceive, that if the political legislation of the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is much more democratic than that of the French, the civil legislation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the latter is infinitely more democratic than that of the former.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This may easily be accounted for. The civil legislation of France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was the work of a man who saw that it was his interest to satisfy the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic passions of his contemporaries in all that was not directly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and immediately hostile to his own power. He was willing to allow some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: popular principles to regulate the distribution of property and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government of families, provided they were not to be introduced into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the administration of public affairs. Whilst the torrent of democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overwhelmed the civil laws of the country, he hoped to find an easy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shelter behind its political institutions. This policy was at once both
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adroit and selfish; but a compromise of this kind could not last; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the end political institutions never fail to become the image and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expression of civil society; and in this sense it may be said that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing is more political in a nation than its civil legislation.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may perhaps not be without utility to show how these changes which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take place in family relations, are closely connected with the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and political revolution which is approaching its consummation under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our own observation. There are certain great social principles, which a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people either introduces everywhere, or tolerates nowhere. In countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are aristocratically constituted with all the gradations of rank,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the government never makes a direct appeal to the mass of the governed:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as men are united together, it is enough to lead the foremost, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rest will follow. This is equally applicable to the family, as to all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies which have a head. Amongst aristocratic nations, social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions recognize, in truth, no one in the family but the father;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: children are received by society at his hands; society governs him,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he governs them. Thus the parent has not only a natural right, but he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquires a political right, to command them: he is the author and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the support of his family; but he is also its constituted ruler. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies, where the government picks out every individual singly from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mass, to make him subservient to the general laws of the community,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no such intermediate person is required: a father is there, in the eye
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the law, only a member of the community, older and richer than his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sons.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When most of the conditions of life are extremely unequal, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality of these conditions is permanent, the notion of a superior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grows upon the imaginations of men: if the law invested him with no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges, custom and public opinion would concede them. When, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the contrary, men differ but little from each other, and do not always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain in dissimilar conditions of life, the general notion of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior becomes weaker and less distinct: it is vain for legislation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to strive to place him who obeys very much beneath him who commands; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners of the time bring the two men nearer to one another, and draw
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them daily towards the same level. Although the legislation of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic people should grant no peculiar privileges to the heads
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of families; I shall not be the less convinced that their power is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more respected and more extensive than in a democracy; for I know that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatsoever the laws may be, superiors always appear higher and inferiors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lower in aristocracies than amongst democratic nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When men live more for the remembrance of what has been than for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: care of what is, and when they are more given to attend to what their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ancestors thought than to think themselves, the father is the natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and necessary tie between the past and the present--the link by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ends of these two chains are connected. In aristocracies, then, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: father is not only the civil head of the family, but the oracle of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traditions, the expounder of its customs, the arbiter of its manners.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He is listened to with deference, he is addressed with respect, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the love which is felt for him is always tempered with fear. When the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of society becomes democratic, and men adopt as their general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle that it is good and lawful to judge of all things for one's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: self, using former points of belief not as a rule of faith but simply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a means of information, the power which the opinions of a father
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exercise over those of his sons diminishes as well as his legal power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Perhaps the subdivision of estates which democracy brings with it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contributes more than anything else to change the relations existing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between a father and his children. When the property of the father of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: family is scanty, his son and himself constantly live in the same place,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and share the same occupations: habit and necessity bring them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together, and force them to hold constant communication: the inevitable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence is a sort of familiar intimacy, which renders authority less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absolute, and which can ill be reconciled with the external forms
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of respect. Now in democratic countries the class of those who are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed of small fortunes is precisely that which gives strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the notions, and a particular direction to the manners, of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community. That class makes its opinions preponderate as universally as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its will, and even those who are most inclined to resist its commands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are carried away in the end by its example. I have known eager opponents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democracy who allowed their children to address them with perfect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: colloquial equality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, at the same time that the power of aristocracy is declining, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: austere, the conventional, and the legal part of parental authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vanishes, and a species of equality prevails around the domestic hearth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I know not, upon the whole, whether society loses by the change, but I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am inclined to believe that man individually is a gainer by it. I think
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, in proportion as manners and laws become more democratic, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relation of father and son becomes more intimate and more affectionate;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules and authority are less talked of; confidence and tenderness are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: oftentimes increased, and it would seem that the natural bond is drawn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: closer in proportion as the social bond is loosened. In a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: family the father exercises no other power than that with which men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: love to invest the affection and the experience of age; his orders would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps be disobeyed, but his advice is for the most part authoritative.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Though he be not hedged in with ceremonial respect, his sons at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accost him with confidence; no settled form of speech is appropriated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the mode of addressing him, but they speak to him constantly, and are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ready to consult him day by day; the master and the constituted ruler
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have vanished--the father remains. Nothing more is needed, in order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to judge of the difference between the two states of society in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect, than to peruse the family correspondence of aristocratic ages.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The style is always correct, ceremonious, stiff, and so cold that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural warmth of the heart can hardly be felt in the language.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The language, on the contrary, addressed by a son to his father in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic countries is always marked by mingled freedom, familiarity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and affection, which at once show that new relations have sprung up in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bosom of the family.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A similar revolution takes place in the mutual relations of children. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic families, as well as in aristocratic society, every place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is marked out beforehand. Not only does the father occupy a separate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rank, in which he enjoys extensive privileges, but even the children
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not equal amongst themselves. The age and sex of each irrevocably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determine his rank, and secure to him certain privileges: most of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinctions are abolished or diminished by democracy. In aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: families the eldest son, inheriting the greater part of the property,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and almost all the rights of the family, becomes the chief, and, to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain extent, the master, of his brothers. Greatness and power are for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him--for them, mediocrity and dependence. Nevertheless it would be wrong
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to suppose that, amongst aristocratic nations, the privileges of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eldest son are advantageous to himself alone, or that they excite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing but envy and hatred in those around him. The eldest son commonly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavors to procure wealth and power for his brothers, because the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general splendor of the house is reflected back on him who represents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it; the younger sons seek to back the elder brother in all his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings, because the greatness and power of the head of the family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: better enable him to provide for all its branches. The different members
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an aristocratic family are therefore very closely bound together;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their interests are connected, their minds agree, but their hearts are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seldom in harmony.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democracy also binds brothers to each other, but by very different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means. Under democratic laws all the children are perfectly equal, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequently independent; nothing brings them forcibly together, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing keeps them apart; and as they have the same origin, as they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trained under the same roof, as they are treated with the same care, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as no peculiar privilege distinguishes or divides them, the affectionate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and youthful intimacy of early years easily springs up between them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Scarcely any opportunities occur to break the tie thus formed at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: outset of life; for their brotherhood brings them daily together,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without embarrassing them. It is not, then, by interest, but by common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations and by the free sympathy of opinion and of taste, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy unites brothers to each other. It divides their inheritance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it allows their hearts and minds to mingle together. Such is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the charm of these democratic manners, that even the partisans of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy are caught by it; and after having experienced it for some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, they are by no means tempted to revert to the respectful and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frigid observance of aristocratic families. They would be glad to retain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the domestic habits of democracy, if they might throw off its social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions and its laws; but these elements are indissolubly united, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is impossible to enjoy the former without enduring the latter.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The remarks I have made on filial love and fraternal affection are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applicable to all the passions which emanate spontaneously from human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature itself. If a certain mode of thought or feeling is the result of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some peculiar condition of life, when that condition is altered nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whatever remains of the thought or feeling. Thus a law may bind two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community very closely to one another; but that law being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abolished, they stand asunder. Nothing was more strict than the tie
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which united the vassal to the lord under the feudal system; at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present day the two men know not each other; the fear, the gratitude,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the affection which formerly connected them have vanished, and not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a vestige of the tie remains. Such, however, is not the case with those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feelings which are natural to mankind. Whenever a law attempts to tutor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these feelings in any particular manner, it seldom fails to weaken them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by attempting to add to their intensity, it robs them of some of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elements, for they are never stronger than when left to themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democracy, which destroys or obscures almost all the old conventional
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules of society, and which prevents men from readily assenting to new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ones, entirely effaces most of the feelings to which these conventional
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules have given rise; but it only modifies some others, and frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imparts to them a degree of energy and sweetness unknown before. Perhaps
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is not impossible to condense into a single proposition the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: meaning of this chapter, and of several others that preceded it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democracy loosens social ties, but it draws the ties of nature more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tight; it brings kindred more closely together, whilst it places the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: various members of the community more widely apart.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IX: Education Of Young Women In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No free communities ever existed without morals; and, as I observed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the former part of this work, morals are the work of woman.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Consequently, whatever affects the condition of women, their habits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and their opinions, has great political importance in my eyes. Amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all Protestant nations young women are far more the mistresses of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own actions than they are in Catholic countries. This independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is still greater in Protestant countries, like England, which have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retained or acquired the right of self-government; the spirit of freedom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is then infused into the domestic circle by political habits and by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious opinions. In the United States the doctrines of Protestantism
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are combined with great political freedom and a most democratic state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society; and nowhere are young women surrendered so early or so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely to their own guidance. Long before an American girl arrives
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the age of marriage, her emancipation from maternal control begins;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: she has scarcely ceased to be a child when she already thinks for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: herself, speaks with freedom, and acts on her own impulse. The great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scene of the world is constantly open to her view; far from seeking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concealment, it is every day disclosed to her more completely, and she
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is taught to survey it with a firm and calm gaze. Thus the vices and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers of society are early revealed to her; as she sees them clearly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: she views them without illusions, and braves them without fear; for she
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is full of reliance on her own strength, and her reliance seems to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shared by all who are about her. An American girl scarcely ever displays
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that virginal bloom in the midst of young desires, or that innocent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and ingenuous grace which usually attends the European woman in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transition from girlhood to youth. It is rarely that an American woman
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at any age displays childish timidity or ignorance. Like the young women
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe, she seeks to please, but she knows precisely the cost of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasing. If she does not abandon herself to evil, at least she knows
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it exists; and she is remarkable rather for purity of manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than for chastity of mind. I have been frequently surprised, and almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frightened, at the singular address and happy boldness with which young
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: women in America contrive to manage their thoughts and their language
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amidst all the difficulties of stimulating conversation; a philosopher
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would have stumbled at every step along the narrow path which they trod
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without accidents and without effort. It is easy indeed to perceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that, even amidst the independence of early youth, an American woman
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is always mistress of herself; she indulges in all permitted pleasures,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without yielding herself up to any of them; and her reason never allows
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the reins of self-guidance to drop, though it often seems to hold them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: loosely.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In France, where remnants of every age are still so strangely mingled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the opinions and tastes of the people, women commonly receive a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reserved, retired, and almost cloistral education, as they did in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic times; and then they are suddenly abandoned, without a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guide and without assistance, in the midst of all the irregularities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inseparable from democratic society. The Americans are more consistent.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They have found out that in a democracy the independence of individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot fail to be very great, youth premature, tastes ill-restrained,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customs fleeting, public opinion often unsettled and powerless,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: paternal authority weak, and marital authority contested. Under these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances, believing that they had little chance of repressing in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: woman the most vehement passions of the human heart, they held that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the surer way was to teach her the art of combating those passions for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: herself. As they could not prevent her virtue from being exposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequent danger, they determined that she should know how best to defend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it; and more reliance was placed on the free vigor of her will than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on safeguards which have been shaken or overthrown. Instead, then, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inculcating mistrust of herself, they constantly seek to enhance their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confidence in her own strength of character. As it is neither possible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor desirable to keep a young woman in perpetual or complete ignorance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they hasten to give her a precocious knowledge on all subjects. Far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from hiding the corruptions of the world from her, they prefer that she
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should see them at once and train herself to shun them; and they hold it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of more importance to protect her conduct than to be over-scrupulous of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her innocence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although the Americans are a very religious people, they do not rely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on religion alone to defend the virtue of woman; they seek to arm her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason also. In this they have followed the same method as in several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other respects; they first make the most vigorous efforts to bring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual independence to exercise a proper control over itself, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they do not call in the aid of religion until they have reached the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: utmost limits of human strength. I am aware that an education of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind is not without danger; I am sensible that it tends to invigorate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the judgment at the expense of the imagination, and to make cold and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtuous women instead of affectionate wives and agreeable companions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to man. Society may be more tranquil and better regulated, but domestic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life has often fewer charms. These, however, are secondary evils, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be braved for the sake of higher interests. At the stage at which we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are now arrived the time for choosing is no longer within our control; a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic education is indispensable to protect women from the dangers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with which democratic institutions and manners surround them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter X: The Young Woman In The Character Of A Wife
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America the independence of woman is irrevocably lost in the bonds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of matrimony: if an unmarried woman is less constrained there than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere, a wife is subjected to stricter obligations. The former makes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her father's house an abode of freedom and of pleasure; the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lives in the home of her husband as if it were a cloister. Yet these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two different conditions of life are perhaps not so contrary as may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supposed, and it is natural that the American women should pass through
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the one to arrive at the other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Religious peoples and trading nations entertain peculiarly serious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions of marriage: the former consider the regularity of woman's life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the best pledge and most certain sign of the purity of her morals;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the latter regard it as the highest security for the order and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prosperity of the household. The Americans are at the same time a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: puritanical people and a commercial nation: their religious opinions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as well as their trading habits, consequently lead them to require
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much abnegation on the part of woman, and a constant sacrifice of her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures to her duties which is seldom demanded of her in Europe. Thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the United States the inexorable opinion of the public carefully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumscribes woman within the narrow circle of domestic interest and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duties, and forbids her to step beyond it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Upon her entrance into the world a young American woman finds these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions firmly established; she sees the rules which are derived from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them; she is not slow to perceive that she cannot depart for an instant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the established usages of her contemporaries, without putting in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jeopardy her peace of mind, her honor, nay even her social existence;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and she finds the energy required for such an act of submission in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the firmness of her understanding and in the virile habits which her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: education has given her. It may be said that she has learned by the use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of her independence to surrender it without a struggle and without a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: murmur when the time comes for making the sacrifice. But no American
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: woman falls into the toils of matrimony as into a snare held out to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her simplicity and ignorance. She has been taught beforehand what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expected of her, and voluntarily and freely does she enter upon this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engagement. She supports her new condition with courage, because she
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chose it. As in America paternal discipline is very relaxed and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conjugal tie very strict, a young woman does not contract the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without considerable circumspection and apprehension. Precocious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: marriages are rare. Thus American women do not marry until their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understandings are exercised and ripened; whereas in other countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most women generally only begin to exercise and to ripen their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understandings after marriage.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I by no means suppose, however, that the great change which takes place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all the habits of women in the United States, as soon as they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: married, ought solely to be attributed to the constraint of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion: it is frequently imposed upon themselves by the sole effort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own will. When the time for choosing a husband is arrived, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cold and stern reasoning power which has been educated and invigorated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the free observation of the world, teaches an American woman that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit of levity and independence in the bonds of marriage is a constant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject of annoyance, not of pleasure; it tells her that the amusements
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the girl cannot become the recreations of the wife, and that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sources of a married woman's happiness are in the home of her husband.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As she clearly discerns beforehand the only road which can lead to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: domestic happiness, she enters upon it at once, and follows it to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: end without seeking to turn back.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same strength of purpose which the young wives of America display,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in bending themselves at once and without repining to the austere duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their new condition, is no less manifest in all the great trials
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their lives. In no country in the world are private fortunes more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precarious than in the United States. It is not uncommon for the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man, in the course of his life, to rise and sink again through all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grades which lead from opulence to poverty. American women support these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vicissitudes with calm and unquenchable energy: it would seem that their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires contract, as easily as they expand, with their fortunes. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: See Appendix S.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The greater part of the adventurers who migrate every year to people the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: western wilds, belong, as I observed in the former part of this work, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the old Anglo-American race of the Northern States. Many of these men,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who rush so boldly onwards in pursuit of wealth, were already in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyment of a competency in their own part of the country. They take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their wives along with them, and make them share the countless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perils and privations which always attend the commencement of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expeditions. I have often met, even on the verge of the wilderness, with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: young women, who after having been brought up amidst all the comforts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the large towns of New England, had passed, almost without any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intermediate stage, from the wealthy abode of their parents to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comfortless hovel in a forest. Fever, solitude, and a tedious life had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not broken the springs of their courage. Their features were impaired
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and faded, but their looks were firm: they appeared to be at once
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sad and resolute. I do not doubt that these young American women had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amassed, in the education of their early years, that inward strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they displayed under these circumstances. The early culture of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the girl may still therefore be traced, in the United States, under the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aspect of marriage: her part is changed, her habits are different, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her character is the same.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XI: That The Equality Of Conditions Contributes To The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Maintenance Of Good Morals In America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Some philosophers and historians have said, or have hinted, that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strictness of female morality was increased or diminished simply by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distance of a country from the equator. This solution of the difficulty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was an easy one; and nothing was required but a globe and a pair of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compasses to settle in an instant one of the most difficult problems in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the condition of mankind. But I am not aware that this principle of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: materialists is supported by facts. The same nations have been chaste or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dissolute at different periods of their history; the strictness or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laxity of their morals depended therefore on some variable cause, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only on the natural qualities of their country, which were invariable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not deny that in certain climates the passions which are occasioned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the mutual attraction of the sexes are peculiarly intense; but I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am of opinion that this natural intensity may always be excited or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: restrained by the condition of society and by political institutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although the travellers who have visited North America differ on a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of points, they all agree in remarking that morals are far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more strict there than elsewhere. It is evident that on this point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans are very superior to their progenitors the English.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A superficial glance at the two nations will establish the fact.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In England, as in all other countries of Europe, public malice is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly attacking the frailties of women. Philosophers and statesmen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are heard to deplore that morals are not sufficiently strict, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: literary productions of the country constantly lead one to suppose so.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America all books, novels not excepted, suppose women to be chaste,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and no one thinks of relating affairs of gallantry. No doubt this great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regularity of American morals originates partly in the country, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: race of the people, and in their religion: but all these causes, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: operate elsewhere, do not suffice to account for it; recourse must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be had to some special reason. This reason appears to me to be the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of equality and the institutions derived from it. Equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conditions does not of itself engender regularity of morals, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it unquestionably facilitates and increases it. *a [Footnote a: See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix T.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations birth and fortune frequently make two such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different beings of man and woman, that they can never be united to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other. Their passions draw them together, but the condition of society,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the notions suggested by it, prevent them from contracting a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanent and ostensible tie. The necessary consequence is a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of transient and clandestine connections. Nature secretly avenges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: herself for the constraint imposed upon her by the laws of man. This is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not so much the case when the equality of conditions has swept away all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the imaginary, or the real, barriers which separated man from woman. No
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: girl then believes that she cannot become the wife of the man who loves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her; and this renders all breaches of morality before marriage very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncommon: for, whatever be the credulity of the passions, a woman will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardly be able to persuade herself that she is beloved, when her lover
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is perfectly free to marry her and does not.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same cause operates, though more indirectly, on married life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing better serves to justify an illicit passion, either to the minds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those who have conceived it or to the world which looks on, than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compulsory or accidental marriages. *b In a country in which a woman is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always free to exercise her power of choosing, and in which education
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has prepared her to choose rightly, public opinion is inexorable to her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faults. The rigor of the Americans arises in part from this cause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They consider marriages as a covenant which is often onerous, but every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of which the parties are strictly bound to fulfil, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they knew all those conditions beforehand, and were perfectly free not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to have contracted them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: The literature of Europe sufficiently corroborates this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remark. When a European author wishes to depict in a work of imagination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any of these great catastrophes in matrimony which so frequently occur
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst us, he takes care to bespeak the compassion of the reader by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bringing before him ill-assorted or compulsory marriages. Although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitual tolerance has long since relaxed our morals, an author could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardly succeed in interesting us in the misfortunes of his characters,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if he did not first palliate their faults. This artifice seldom fails:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the daily scenes we witness prepare us long beforehand to be indulgent.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But American writers could never render these palliations probable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their readers; their customs and laws are opposed to it; and as they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despair of rendering levity of conduct pleasing, they cease to depict
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. This is one of the causes to which must be attributed the small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of novels published in the United States.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The very circumstances which render matrimonial fidelity more obligatory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: also render it more easy. In aristocratic countries the object of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: marriage is rather to unite property than persons; hence the husband is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes at school and the wife at nurse when they are betrothed. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot be wondered at if the conjugal tie which holds the fortunes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the pair united allows their hearts to rove; this is the natural result
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nature of the contract. When, on the contrary, a man always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chooses a wife for himself, without any external coercion or even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: guidance, it is generally a conformity of tastes and opinions which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brings a man and a woman together, and this same conformity keeps and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fixes them in close habits of intimacy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Our forefathers had conceived a very strange notion on the subject of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: marriage: as they had remarked that the small number of love-matches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which occurred in their time almost always turned out ill, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resolutely inferred that it was exceedingly dangerous to listen to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dictates of the heart on the subject. Accident appeared to them to be a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: better guide than choice. Yet it was not very difficult to perceive that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the examples which they witnessed did in fact prove nothing at all. For
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the first place, if democratic nations leave a woman at liberty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to choose her husband, they take care to give her mind sufficient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge, and her will sufficient strength, to make so important a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choice: whereas the young women who, amongst aristocratic nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: furtively elope from the authority of their parents to throw themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their own accord into the arms of men whom they have had neither time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to know, nor ability to judge of, are totally without those securities.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not surprising that they make a bad use of their freedom of action
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the first time they avail themselves of it; nor that they fall into such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cruel mistakes, when, not having received a democratic education, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choose to marry in conformity to democratic customs. But this is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not all. When a man and woman are bent upon marriage in spite of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differences of an aristocratic state of society, the difficulties to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be overcome are enormous. Having broken or relaxed the bonds of filial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience, they have then to emancipate themselves by a final effort
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the sway of custom and the tyranny of opinion; and when at length
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have succeeded in this arduous task, they stand estranged from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their natural friends and kinsmen: the prejudice they have crossed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separates them from all, and places them in a situation which soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: breaks their courage and sours their hearts. If, then, a couple married
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this manner are first unhappy and afterwards criminal, it ought not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be attributed to the freedom of their choice, but rather to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: living in a community in which this freedom of choice is not admitted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Moreover it should not be forgotten that the same effort which makes a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man violently shake off a prevailing error, commonly impels him beyond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bounds of reason; that, to dare to declare war, in however just
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a cause, against the opinion of one's age and country, a violent and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adventurous spirit is required, and that men of this character seldom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrive at happiness or virtue, whatever be the path they follow. And
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this, it may be observed by the way, is the reason why in the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary and righteous revolutions, it is so rare to meet with virtuous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or moderate revolutionary characters. There is then no just ground
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for surprise if a man, who in an age of aristocracy chooses to consult
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing but his own opinion and his own taste in the choice of a wife,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soon finds that infractions of morality and domestic wretchedness invade
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his household: but when this same line of action is in the natural and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinary course of things, when it is sanctioned by parental authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and backed by public opinion, it cannot be doubted that the internal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace of families will be increased by it, and conjugal fidelity more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rigidly observed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Almost all men in democracies are engaged in public or professional
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life; and on the other hand the limited extent of common incomes obliges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a wife to confine herself to the house, in order to watch in person and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very closely over the details of domestic economy. All these distinct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and compulsory occupations are so many natural barriers, which, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: keeping the two sexes asunder, render the solicitations of the one less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequent and less ardent--the resistance of the other more easy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not indeed that the equality of conditions can ever succeed in making
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men chaste, but it may impart a less dangerous character to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: breaches of morality. As no one has then either sufficient time or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opportunity to assail a virtue armed in self-defence, there will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the same time a great number of courtesans and a great number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of virtuous women. This state of things causes lamentable cases of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individual hardship, but it does not prevent the body of society from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being strong and alert: it does not destroy family ties, or enervate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: morals of the nation. Society is endangered not by the great profligacy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a few, but by laxity of morals amongst all. In the eyes of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator, prostitution is less to be dreaded than intrigue.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The tumultuous and constantly harassed life which equality makes men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lead, not only distracts them from the passion of love, by denying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them time to indulge in it, but it diverts them from it by another more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secret but more certain road. All men who live in democratic ages more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or less contract the ways of thinking of the manufacturing and trading
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes; their minds take a serious, deliberate, and positive turn; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are apt to relinquish the ideal, in order to pursue some visible and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proximate object, which appears to be the natural and necessary aim
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their desires. Thus the principle of equality does not destroy the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination, but lowers its flight to the level of the earth. No men are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less addicted to reverie than the citizens of a democracy; and few of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them are ever known to give way to those idle and solitary meditations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which commonly precede and produce the great emotions of the heart. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is true they attach great importance to procuring for themselves that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sort of deep, regular, and quiet affection which constitutes the charm
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and safeguard of life, but they are not apt to run after those violent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and capricious sources of excitement which disturb and abridge it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am aware that all this is only applicable in its full extent to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, and cannot at present be extended to Europe. In the course of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the last half-century, whilst laws and customs have impelled several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European nations with unexampled force towards democracy, we have not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had occasion to observe that the relations of man and woman have become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more orderly or more chaste. In some places the very reverse may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: detected: some classes are more strict--the general morality of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people appears to be more lax. I do not hesitate to make the remark, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am as little disposed to flatter my contemporaries as to malign them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This fact must distress, but it ought not to surprise us. The propitious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence which a democratic state of society may exercise upon orderly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits, is one of those tendencies which can only be discovered after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a time. If the equality of conditions is favorable to purity of morals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the social commotion by which conditions are rendered equal is adverse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to it. In the last fifty years, during which France has been undergoing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this transformation, that country has rarely had freedom, always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disturbance. Amidst this universal confusion of notions and this general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stir of opinions--amidst this incoherent mixture of the just and unjust,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of truth and falsehood, of right and might--public virtue has become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doubtful, and private morality wavering. But all revolutions, whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may have been their object or their agents, have at first produced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: similar consequences; even those which have in the end drawn the bonds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of morality more tightly began by loosening them. The violations of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: morality which the French frequently witness do not appear to me to have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a permanent character; and this is already betokened by some curious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: signs of the times.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing is more wretchedly corrupt than an aristocracy which retains its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth when it has lost its power, and which still enjoys a vast deal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of leisure after it is reduced to mere vulgar pastimes. The energetic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions and great conceptions which animated it heretofore, leave it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then; and nothing remains to it but a host of petty consuming vices,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which cling about it like worms upon a carcass. No one denies that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French aristocracy of the last century was extremely dissolute; whereas
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established habits and ancient belief still preserved some respect for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: morality amongst the other classes of society. Nor will it be contested
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that at the present day the remnants of that same aristocracy exhibit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a certain severity of morals; whilst laxity of morals appears to have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spread amongst the middle and lower ranks. So that the same families
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which were most profligate fifty years ago are nowadays the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exemplary, and democracy seems only to have strengthened the morality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the aristocratic classes. The French Revolution, by dividing the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortunes of the nobility, by forcing them to attend assiduously to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs and to their families, by making them live under the same roof
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with their children, and in short by giving a more rational and serious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turn to their minds, has imparted to them, almost without their being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aware of it, a reverence for religious belief, a love of order, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tranquil pleasures, of domestic endearments, and of comfort; whereas the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rest of the nation, which had naturally these same tastes, was carried
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: away into excesses by the effort which was required to overthrow the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws and political habits of the country. The old French aristocracy has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undergone the consequences of the Revolution, but it neither felt the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutionary passions nor shared in the anarchical excitement which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produced that crisis; it may easily be conceived that this aristocracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feels the salutary influence of the Revolution in its manners, before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who achieve it. It may therefore be said, though at first it seems
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: paradoxical, that, at the present day, the most anti-democratic classes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation principally exhibit the kind of morality which may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reasonably be anticipated from democracy. I cannot but think that when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we shall have obtained all the effects of this democratic Revolution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after having got rid of the tumult it has caused, the observations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are now only applicable to the few will gradually become true of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole community.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XII: How The Americans Understand The Equality Of The Sexes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I Have shown how democracy destroys or modifies the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequalities which originate in society; but is this all? or does it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not ultimately affect that great inequality of man and woman which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seemed, up to the present day, to be eternally based in human nature? I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe that the social changes which bring nearer to the same level
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the father and son, the master and servant, and superiors and inferiors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generally speaking, will raise woman and make her more and more the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal of man. But here, more than ever, I feel the necessity of making
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: myself clearly understood; for there is no subject on which the coarse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and lawless fancies of our age have taken a freer range.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are people in Europe who, confounding together the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics of the sexes, would make of man and woman beings not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only equal but alike. They would give to both the same functions, impose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on both the same duties, and grant to both the same rights; they would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mix them in all things--their occupations, their pleasures, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: business. It may readily be conceived, that by thus attempting to make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one sex equal to the other, both are degraded; and from so preposterous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a medley of the works of nature nothing could ever result but weak men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and disorderly women. It is not thus that the Americans understand that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: species of democratic equality which may be established between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sexes. They admit, that as nature has appointed such wide differences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the physical and moral constitution of man and woman, her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manifest design was to give a distinct employment to their various
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: faculties; and they hold that improvement does not consist in making
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beings so dissimilar do pretty nearly the same things, but in getting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each of them to fulfil their respective tasks in the best possible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner. The Americans have applied to the sexes the great principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of political economy which governs the manufactures of our age, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carefully dividing the duties of man from those of woman, in order that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great work of society may be the better carried on.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In no country has such constant care been taken as in America to trace
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two clearly distinct lines of action for the two sexes, and to make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them keep pace one with the other, but in two pathways which are always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different. American women never manage the outward concerns of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: family, or conduct a business, or take a part in political life; nor are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they, on the other hand, ever compelled to perform the rough labor of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the fields, or to make any of those laborious exertions which demand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the exertion of physical strength. No families are so poor as to form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an exception to this rule. If on the one hand an American woman cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: escape from the quiet circle of domestic employments, on the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand she is never forced to go beyond it. Hence it is that the women of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, who often exhibit a masculine strength of understanding and a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manly energy, generally preserve great delicacy of personal appearance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and always retain the manners of women, although they sometimes show
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they have the hearts and minds of men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nor have the Americans ever supposed that one consequence of democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles is the subversion of marital power, of the confusion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural authorities in families. They hold that every association must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have a head in order to accomplish its object, and that the natural head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the conjugal association is man. They do not therefore deny him the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of directing his partner; and they maintain, that in the smaller
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association of husband and wife, as well as in the great social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, the object of democracy is to regulate and legalize the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers which are necessary, not to subvert all power. This opinion is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not peculiar to one sex, and contested by the other: I never observed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the women of America consider conjugal authority as a fortunate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usurpation of their rights, nor that they thought themselves degraded by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: submitting to it. It appeared to me, on the contrary, that they attach a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sort of pride to the voluntary surrender of their own will, and make it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their boast to bend themselves to the yoke, not to shake it off. Such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least is the feeling expressed by the most virtuous of their sex; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others are silent; and in the United States it is not the practice for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a guilty wife to clamor for the rights of women, whilst she is trampling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on her holiest duties.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It has often been remarked that in Europe a certain degree of contempt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lurks even in the flattery which men lavish upon women: although a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: European frequently affects to be the slave of woman, it may be seen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that he never sincerely thinks her his equal. In the United States men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seldom compliment women, but they daily show how much they esteem them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They constantly display an entire confidence in the understanding of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wife, and a profound respect for her freedom; they have decided that her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind is just as fitted as that of a man to discover the plain truth, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her heart as firm to embrace it; and they have never sought to place her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtue, any more than his, under the shelter of prejudice, ignorance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and fear. It would seem that in Europe, where man so easily submits to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the despotic sway of women, they are nevertheless curtailed of some of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the greatest qualities of the human species, and considered as seductive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but imperfect beings; and (what may well provoke astonishment) women
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ultimately look upon themselves in the same light, and almost consider
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it as a privilege that they are entitled to show themselves futile,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feeble, and timid. The women of America claim no such privileges.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Again, it may be said that in our morals we have reserved strange
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immunities to man; so that there is, as it were, one virtue for his use,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and another for the guidance of his partner; and that, according to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion of the public, the very same act may be punished alternately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a crime or only as a fault. The Americans know not this iniquitous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: division of duties and rights; amongst them the seducer is as much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dishonored as his victim. It is true that the Americans rarely lavish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon women those eager attentions which are commonly paid them in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe; but their conduct to women always implies that they suppose them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be virtuous and refined; and such is the respect entertained for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the moral freedom of the sex, that in the presence of a woman the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most guarded language is used, lest her ear should be offended by an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expression. In America a young unmarried woman may, alone and without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fear, undertake a long journey.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The legislators of the United States, who have mitigated almost all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: penalties of criminal law, still make rape a capital offence, and no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crime is visited with more inexorable severity by public opinion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This may be accounted for; as the Americans can conceive nothing more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precious than a woman's honor, and nothing which ought so much to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respected as her independence, they hold that no punishment is too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severe for the man who deprives her of them against her will. In France,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the same offence is visited with far milder penalties, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently difficult to get a verdict from a jury against the prisoner.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Is this a consequence of contempt of decency or contempt of women? I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot but believe that it is a contempt of one and of the other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the Americans do not think that man and woman have either the duty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or the right to perform the same offices, but they show an equal regard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for both their respective parts; and though their lot is different, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider both of them as beings of equal value. They do not give to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courage of woman the same form or the same direction as to that of man;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but they never doubt her courage: and if they hold that man and his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: partner ought not always to exercise their intellect and understanding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the same manner, they at least believe the understanding of the one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be as sound as that of the other, and her intellect to be as clear.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, then, whilst they have allowed the social inferiority of woman
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to subsist, they have done all they could to raise her morally and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellectually to the level of man; and in this respect they appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to me to have excellently understood the true principle of democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: improvement. As for myself, I do not hesitate to avow that, although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the women of the United States are confined within the narrow circle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: domestic life, and their situation is in some respects one of extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dependence, I have nowhere seen woman occupying a loftier position; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if I were asked, now that I am drawing to the close of this work, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have spoken of so many important things done by the Americans,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to what the singular prosperity and growing strength of that people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought mainly to be attributed, I should reply--to the superiority of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their women.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIII: That The Principle Of Equality Naturally Divides The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans Into A Number Of Small Private Circles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It may probably be supposed that the final consequence and necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effect of democratic institutions is to confound together all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community in private as well as in public life, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compel them all to live in common; but this would be to ascribe a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very coarse and oppressive form to the equality which originates in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy. No state of society or laws can render men so much alike,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but that education, fortune, and tastes will interpose some differences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between them; and, though different men may sometimes find it their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest to combine for the same purposes, they will never make it their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasure. They will therefore always tend to evade the provisions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislation, whatever they may be; and departing in some one respect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the circle within which they were to be bounded, they will set up,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: close by the great political community, small private circles, united
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: together by the similitude of their conditions, habits, and manners.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States the citizens have no sort of pre-eminence over each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other; they owe each other no mutual obedience or respect; they all meet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the administration of justice, for the government of the State, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in general to treat of the affairs which concern their common welfare;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but I never heard that attempts have been made to bring them all to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: follow the same diversions, or to amuse themselves promiscuously in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same places of recreation. The Americans, who mingle so readily in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political assemblies and courts of justice, are wont on the contrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carefully to separate into small distinct circles, in order to indulge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by themselves in the enjoyments of private life. Each of them is willing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to acknowledge all his fellow-citizens as his equals, but he will only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: receive a very limited number of them amongst his friends or his guests.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This appears to me to be very natural. In proportion as the circle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public society is extended, it may be anticipated that the sphere of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private intercourse will be contracted; far from supposing that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of modern society will ultimately live in common, I am afraid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they may end by forming nothing but small coteries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations the different classes are like vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chambers, out of which it is impossible to get, into which it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible to enter. These classes have no communication with each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, but within their pale men necessarily live in daily contact;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even though they would not naturally suit, the general conformity of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: similar condition brings them nearer together. But when neither law nor
