author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: custom professes to establish frequent and habitual relations between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain men, their intercourse originates in the accidental analogy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of opinions and tastes; hence private society is infinitely varied. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies, where the members of the community never differ much from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other, and naturally stand in such propinquity that they may all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at any time be confounded in one general mass, numerous artificial and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arbitrary distinctions spring up, by means of which every man hopes to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: keep himself aloof, lest he should be carried away in the crowd against
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his will. This can never fail to be the case; for human institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be changed, but not man: whatever may be the general endeavor of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community to render its members equal and alike, the personal pride
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of individuals will always seek to rise above the line, and to form
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: somewhere an inequality to their own advantage.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocracies men are separated from each other by lofty stationary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barriers; in democracies they are divided by a number of small and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost invisible threads, which are constantly broken or moved from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place to place. Thus, whatever may be the progress of equality, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations a great number of small private communities will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always be formed within the general pale of political society; but none
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them will bear any resemblance in its manners to the highest class in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIV: Some Reflections On American Manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing seems at first sight less important than the outward form of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human actions, yet there is nothing upon which men set more store: they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grow used to everything except to living in a society which has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own manners. The influence of the social and political state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a country upon manners is therefore deserving of serious examination.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Manners are, generally, the product of the very basis of the character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a people, but they are also sometimes the result of an arbitrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convention between certain men; thus they are at once natural and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquired. When certain men perceive that they are the foremost persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in society, without contestation and without effort--when they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly engaged on large objects, leaving the more minute details to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others--and when they live in the enjoyment of wealth which they did not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amass and which they do not fear to lose, it may be supposed that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feel a kind of haughty disdain of the petty interests and practical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cares of life, and that their thoughts assume a natural greatness, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their language and their manners denote. In democratic countries manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are generally devoid of dignity, because private life is there extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: petty in its character; and they are frequently low, because the mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has few opportunities of rising above the engrossing cares of domestic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests. True dignity in manners consists in always taking one's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proper station, neither too high nor too low; and this is as much within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the reach of a peasant as of a prince. In democracies all stations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appear doubtful; hence it is that the manners of democracies, though
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often full of arrogance, are commonly wanting in dignity, and, moreover,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are never either well disciplined or accomplished.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The men who live in democracies are too fluctuating for a certain number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them ever to succeed in laying down a code of good breeding, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forcing people to follow it. Every man therefore behaves after his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fashion, and there is always a certain incoherence in the manners of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such times, because they are moulded upon the feelings and notions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each individual, rather than upon an ideal model proposed for general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imitation. This, however, is much more perceptible at the time when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an aristocracy has just been overthrown than after it has long been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destroyed. New political institutions and new social elements then bring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the same places of resort, and frequently compel to live in common,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men whose education and habits are still amazingly dissimilar, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this renders the motley composition of society peculiarly visible. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence of a former strict code of good breeding is still remembered,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but what it contained or where it is to be found is already forgotten.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men have lost the common law of manners, and they have not yet made up
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their minds to do without it; but everyone endeavors to make to himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some sort of arbitrary and variable rule, from the remnant of former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: usages; so that manners have neither the regularity and the dignity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they often display amongst aristocratic nations, nor the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simplicity and freedom which they sometimes assume in democracies; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are at once constrained and without constraint.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This, however, is not the normal state of things. When the equality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions is long established and complete, as all men entertain nearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same notions and do nearly the same things, they do not require to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agree or to copy from one another in order to speak or act in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner: their manners are constantly characterized by a number of lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diversities, but not by any great differences. They are never perfectly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike, because they do not copy from the same pattern; they are never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very unlike, because their social condition is the same. At first sight
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a traveller would observe that the manners of all the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are exactly similar; it is only upon close examination that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiarities in which they differ may be detected.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The English make game of the manners of the Americans; but it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: singular that most of the writers who have drawn these ludicrous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: delineations belonged themselves to the middle classes in England, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whom the same delineations are exceedingly applicable: so that these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pitiless censors for the most part furnish an example of the very thing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they blame in the United States; they do not perceive that they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deriding themselves, to the great amusement of the aristocracy of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nothing is more prejudicial to democracy than its outward forms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: behavior: many men would willingly endure its vices, who cannot support
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its manners. I cannot, however, admit that there is nothing commendable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the manners of a democratic people. Amongst aristocratic nations, all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who live within reach of the first class in society commonly strain to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be like it, which gives rise to ridiculous and insipid imitations. As a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people does not possess any models of high breeding, at least
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it escapes the daily necessity of seeing wretched copies of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democracies manners are never so refined as amongst aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, but on the other hand they are never so coarse. Neither the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: coarse oaths of the populace, nor the elegant and choice expressions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nobility are to be heard there: the manners of such a people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are often vulgar, but they are neither brutal nor mean. I have already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: observed that in democracies no such thing as a regular code of good
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: breeding can be laid down; this has some inconveniences and some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages. In aristocracies the rules of propriety impose the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demeanor on everyone; they make all the members of the same class appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike, in spite of their private inclinations; they adorn and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceal the natural man. Amongst a democratic people manners are neither
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so tutored nor so uniform, but they are frequently more sincere. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form, as it were, a light and loosely woven veil, through which the real
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feelings and private opinions of each individual are easily discernible.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The form and the substance of human actions often, therefore, stand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in closer relation; and if the great picture of human life be less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: embellished, it is more true. Thus it may be said, in one sense, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the effect of democracy is not exactly to give men any particular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners, but to prevent them from having manners at all.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The feelings, the passions, the virtues, and the vices of an aristocracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may sometimes reappear in a democracy, but not its manners; they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lost, and vanish forever, as soon as the democratic revolution is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completed. It would seem that nothing is more lasting than the manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an aristocratic class, for they are preserved by that class for some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time after it has lost its wealth and its power--nor so fleeting, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no sooner have they disappeared than not a trace of them is to be found;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it is scarcely possible to say what they have been as soon as they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have ceased to be. A change in the state of society works this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: miracle, and a few generations suffice to consummate it. The principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics of aristocracy are handed down by history after an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy is destroyed, but the light and exquisite touches of manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are effaced from men's memories almost immediately after its fall. Men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can no longer conceive what these manners were when they have ceased to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: witness them; they are gone, and their departure was unseen, unfelt; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to feel that refined enjoyment which is derived from choice and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinguished manners, habit and education must have prepared the heart,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the taste for them is lost almost as easily as the practice of them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus not only a democratic people cannot have aristocratic manners, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they neither comprehend nor desire them; and as they never have thought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them, it is to their minds as if such things had never been. Too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much importance should not be attached to this loss, but it may well be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regretted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am aware that it has not unfrequently happened that the same men have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had very high-bred manners and very low-born feelings: the interior of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courts has sufficiently shown what imposing externals may conceal the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: meanest hearts. But though the manners of aristocracy did not constitute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtue, they sometimes embellish virtue itself. It was no ordinary sight
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to see a numerous and powerful class of men, whose every outward action
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seemed constantly to be dictated by a natural elevation of thought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and feeling, by delicacy and regularity of taste, and by urbanity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of manners. Those manners threw a pleasing illusory charm over human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature; and though the picture was often a false one, it could not be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: viewed without a noble satisfaction.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XV: Of The Gravity Of The Americans, And Why It Does Not Prevent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Them From Often Committing Inconsiderate Actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men who live in democratic countries do not value the simple, turbulent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or coarse diversions in which the people indulge in aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities: such diversions are thought by them to be puerile or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insipid. Nor have they a greater inclination for the intellectual and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refined amusements of the aristocratic classes. They want something
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: productive and substantial in their pleasures; they want to mix actual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fruition with their joy. In aristocratic communities the people readily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: give themselves up to bursts of tumultuous and boisterous gayety, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shake off at once the recollection of their privations: the natives of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies are not fond of being thus violently broken in upon, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they never lose sight of their own selves without regret. They prefer to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these frivolous delights those more serious and silent amusements which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are like business, and which do not drive business wholly from their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minds. An American, instead of going in a leisure hour to dance merrily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at some place of public resort, as the fellows of his calling continue
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to do throughout the greater part of Europe, shuts himself up at home
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to drink. He thus enjoys two pleasures; he can go on thinking of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: business, and he can get drunk decently by his own fireside.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I thought that the English constituted the most serious nation on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: face of the earth, but I have since seen the Americans and have changed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my opinion. I do not mean to say that temperament has not a great deal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to do with the character of the inhabitants of the United States, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that their political institutions are a still more influential
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cause. I believe the seriousness of the Americans arises partly from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their pride. In democratic countries even poor men entertain a lofty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notion of their personal importance: they look upon themselves with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complacency, and are apt to suppose that others are looking at them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: too. With this disposition they watch their language and their actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with care, and do not lay themselves open so as to betray their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deficiencies; to preserve their dignity they think it necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retain their gravity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But I detect another more deep-seated and powerful cause which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instinctively produces amongst the Americans this astonishing gravity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Under a despotism communities give way at times to bursts of vehement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: joy; but they are generally gloomy and moody, because they are afraid.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Under absolute monarchies tempered by the customs and manners of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, their spirits are often cheerful and even, because as they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some freedom and a good deal of security, they are exempted from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most important cares of life; but all free peoples are serious, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their minds are habitually absorbed by the contemplation of some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous or difficult purpose. This is more especially the case amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those free nations which form democratic communities. Then there are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all classes a very large number of men constantly occupied with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: serious affairs of the government; and those whose thoughts are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engaged in the direction of the commonwealth are wholly engrossed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the acquisition of a private fortune. Amongst such a people a serious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demeanor ceases to be peculiar to certain men, and becomes a habit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We are told of small democracies in the days of antiquity, in which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens met upon the public places with garlands of roses, and spent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all their time in dancing and theatrical amusements. I do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe in such republics any more than in that of Plato; or, if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things we read of really happened, I do not hesitate to affirm that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these supposed democracies were composed of very different elements from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ours, and that they had nothing in common with the latter except their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: name. But it must not be supposed that, in the midst of all their toils,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people who live in democracies think themselves to be pitied; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary is remarked to be the case. No men are fonder of their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition. Life would have no relish for them if they were delivered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the anxieties which harass them, and they show more attachment to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their cares than aristocratic nations to their pleasures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am next led to inquire how it is that these same democratic nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are so serious, sometimes act in so inconsiderate a manner. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans, who almost always preserve a staid demeanor and a frigid air,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless frequently allow themselves to be borne away, far beyond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bound of reason, by a sudden passion or a hasty opinion, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes gravely commit strange absurdities. This contrast ought not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surprise us. There is one sort of ignorance which originates in extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: publicity. In despotic States men know not how to act, because they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: told nothing; in democratic nations they often act at random, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing is to be left untold. The former do not know--the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forget; and the chief features of each picture are lost to them in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bewilderment of details.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is astonishing what imprudent language a public man may sometimes use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in free countries, and especially in democratic States, without being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compromised; whereas in absolute monarchies a few words dropped by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accident are enough to unmask him forever, and ruin him without hope of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: redemption. This is explained by what goes before. When a man speaks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of a great crowd, many of his words are not heard, or are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forthwith obliterated from the memories of those who hear them; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amidst the silence of a mute and motionless throng the slightest whisper
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strikes the ear.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democracies men are never stationary; a thousand chances waft them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to and fro, and their life is always the sport of unforeseen or (so to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speak) extemporaneous circumstances. Thus they are often obliged to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do things which they have imperfectly learned, to say things they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperfectly understand, and to devote themselves to work for which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are unprepared by long apprenticeship. In aristocracies every man has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one sole object which he unceasingly pursues, but amongst democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations the existence of man is more complex; the same mind will almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always embrace several objects at the same time, and these objects are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently wholly foreign to each other: as it cannot know them all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well, the mind is readily satisfied with imperfect notions of each.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the inhabitant of democracies is not urged by his wants, he is so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least by his desires; for of all the possessions which he sees around
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him, none are wholly beyond his reach. He therefore does everything in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hurry, he is always satisfied with "pretty well," and never pauses more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than an instant to consider what he has been doing. His curiosity is at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once insatiable and cheaply satisfied; for he cares more to know a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deal quickly than to know anything well: he has no time and but little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taste to search things to the bottom. Thus then democratic peoples are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grave, because their social and political condition constantly leads
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them to engage in serious occupations; and they act inconsiderately,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they give but little time and attention to each of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occupations. The habit of inattention must be considered as the greatest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bane of the democratic character.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVI: Why The National Vanity Of The Americans Is More Restless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And Captious Than That Of The English
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All free nations are vainglorious, but national pride is not displayed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by all in the same manner. The Americans in their intercourse with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strangers appear impatient of the smallest censure and insatiable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of praise. The most slender eulogium is acceptable to them; the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exalted seldom contents them; they unceasingly harass you to extort
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: praise, and if you resist their entreaties they fall to praising
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves. It would seem as if, doubting their own merit, they wished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to have it constantly exhibited before their eyes. Their vanity is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only greedy, but restless and jealous; it will grant nothing, whilst it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: demands everything, but is ready to beg and to quarrel at the same time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I say to an American that the country he lives in is a fine one,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Ay," he replies, "there is not its fellow in the world." If I applaud
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the freedom which its inhabitants enjoy, he answers, "Freedom is a fine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing, but few nations are worthy to enjoy it." If I remark the purity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of morals which distinguishes the United States, "I can imagine," says
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he, "that a stranger, who has been struck by the corruption of all other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, is astonished at the difference." At length I leave him to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemplation of himself; but he returns to the charge, and does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desist till he has got me to repeat all I had just been saying. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impossible to conceive a more troublesome or more garrulous patriotism;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it wearies even those who are disposed to respect it. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: See Appendix U.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Such is not the case with the English. An Englishman calmly enjoys the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: real or imaginary advantages which in his opinion his country possesses.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If he grants nothing to other nations, neither does he solicit anything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for his own. The censure of foreigners does not affect him, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: praise hardly flatters him; his position with regard to the rest of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world is one of disdainful and ignorant reserve: his pride requires no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sustenance, it nourishes itself. It is remarkable that two nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so recently sprung from the same stock, should be so opposite to one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another in their manner of feeling and conversing.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocratic countries the great possess immense privileges, upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which their pride rests, without seeking to rely upon the lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages which accrue to them. As these privileges came to them by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inheritance, they regard them in some sort as a portion of themselves,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or at least as a natural right inherent in their own persons. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore entertain a calm sense of their superiority; they do not dream
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of vaunting privileges which everyone perceives and no one contests,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and these things are not sufficiently new to them to be made topics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conversation. They stand unmoved in their solitary greatness, well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assured that they are seen of all the world without any effort to show
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves off, and that no one will attempt to drive them from that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position. When an aristocracy carries on the public affairs, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: national pride naturally assumes this reserved, indifferent, and haughty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: form, which is imitated by all the other classes of the nation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When, on the contrary, social conditions differ but little, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slightest privileges are of some importance; as every man sees around
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself a million of people enjoying precisely similar or analogous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages, his pride becomes craving and jealous, he clings to mere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trifles, and doggedly defends them. In democracies, as the conditions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life are very fluctuating, men have almost always recently acquired the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages which they possess; the consequence is that they feel extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasure in exhibiting them, to show others and convince themselves that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they really enjoy them. As at any instant these same advantages may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lost, their possessors are constantly on the alert, and make a point
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of showing that they still retain them. Men living in democracies love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their country just as they love themselves, and they transfer the habits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their private vanity to their vanity as a nation. The restless and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insatiable vanity of a democratic people originates so entirely in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality and precariousness of social conditions, that the members of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the haughtiest nobility display the very same passion in those lesser
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portions of their existence in which there is anything fluctuating or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contested. An aristocratic class always differs greatly from the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes of the nation, by the extent and perpetuity of its privileges;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it often happens that the only differences between the members who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belong to it consist in small transient advantages, which may any day be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lost or acquired. The members of a powerful aristocracy, collected in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a capital or a court, have been known to contest with virulence those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frivolous privileges which depend on the caprice of fashion or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will of their master. These persons then displayed towards each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other precisely the same puerile jealousies which animate the men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies, the same eagerness to snatch the smallest advantages which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their equals contested, and the same desire to parade ostentatiously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those of which they were in possession. If national pride ever entered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the minds of courtiers, I do not question that they would display
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it in the same manner as the members of a democratic community.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVII: That The Aspect Of Society In The United States Is At Once
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Excited And Monotonous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would seem that nothing can be more adapted to stimulate and to feed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curiosity than the aspect of the United States. Fortunes, opinions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and laws are there in ceaseless variation: it is as if immutable nature
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: herself were mutable, such are the changes worked upon her by the hand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of man. Yet in the end the sight of this excited community becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monotonous, and after having watched the moving pageant for a time the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spectator is tired of it. Amongst aristocratic nations every man is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pretty nearly stationary in his own sphere; but men are astonishingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unlike each other--their passions, their notions, their habits, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their tastes are essentially different: nothing changey, but everything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differs. In democracies, on the contrary, all men are alike and do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things pretty nearly alike. It is true that they are subject to great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and frequent vicissitudes; but as the same events of good or adverse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune are continually recurring, the name of the actors only is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changed, the piece is always the same. The aspect of American society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is animated, because men and things are always changing; but it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: monotonous, because all these changes are alike.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men living in democratic ages have many passions, but most of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions either end in the love of riches or proceed from it. The cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this is, not that their souls are narrower, but that the importance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of money is really greater at such times. When all the members of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a community are independent of or indifferent to each other, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: co-operation of each of them can only be obtained by paying for it: this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infinitely multiplies the purposes to which wealth may be applied, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases its value. When the reverence which belonged to what is old
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has vanished, birth, condition, and profession no longer distinguish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, or scarcely distinguish them at all: hardly anything but money
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains to create strongly marked differences between them, and to raise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some of them above the common level. The distinction originating in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth is increased by the disappearance and diminution of all other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinctions. Amongst aristocratic nations money only reaches to a few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: points on the vast circle of man's desires--in democracies it seems to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lead to all. The love of wealth is therefore to be traced, either as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a principal or an accessory motive, at the bottom of all that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans do: this gives to all their passions a sort of family
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: likeness, and soon renders the survey of them exceedingly wearisome.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This perpetual recurrence of the same passion is monotonous; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar methods by which this passion seeks its own gratification are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no less so.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In an orderly and constituted democracy like the United States, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men cannot enrich themselves by war, by public office, or by political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confiscation, the love of wealth mainly drives them into business and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures. Although these pursuits often bring about great commotions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and disasters, they cannot prosper without strictly regular habits and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a long routine of petty uniform acts. The stronger the passion is, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more regular are these habits, and the more uniform are these acts. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be said that it is the vehemence of their desires which makes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans so methodical; it perturbs their minds, but it disciplines
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their lives.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The remark I here apply to America may indeed be addressed to almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all our contemporaries. Variety is disappearing from the human race; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same ways of acting, thinking, and feeling are to be met with all over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world. This is not only because nations work more upon each other,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and are more faithful in their mutual imitation; but as the men of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country relinquish more and more the peculiar opinions and feelings of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a caste, a profession, or a family, they simultaneously arrive at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: something nearer to the constitution of man, which is everywhere the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same. Thus they become more alike, even without having imitated each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other. Like travellers scattered about some large wood, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intersected by paths converging to one point, if all of them keep, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eyes fixed upon that point and advance towards it, they insensibly draw
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nearer together--though they seek not, though they see not, though
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they know not each other; and they will be surprised at length to find
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves all collected on the same spot. All the nations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take, not any particular man, but man himself, as the object of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: researches and their imitations, are tending in the end to a similar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of society, like these travellers converging to the central plot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the forest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XVIII: Of Honor In The United States And In Democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Communities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would seem that men employ two very distinct methods in the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estimation *a of the actions of their fellowmen; at one time they judge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them by those simple notions of right and wrong which are diffused
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all over the world; at another they refer their decision to a few very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: special notions which belong exclusively to some particular age and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country. It often happens that these two rules differ; they sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conflict: but they are never either entirely identified or entirely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: annulled by one another. Honor, at the periods of its greatest power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sways the will more than the belief of men; and even whilst they yield
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without hesitation and without a murmur to its dictates, they feel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding, by a dim but mighty instinct, the existence of a more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general, more ancient, and more holy law, which they sometimes disobey
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: although they cease not to acknowledge it. Some actions have been held
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be at the same time virtuous and dishonorable--a refusal to fight a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duel is a case in point.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: The word "honor" is not always used in the same sense
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either in French or English. I. It first signifies the dignity, glory,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or reverence which a man receives from his kind; and in this sense a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man is said to acquire honor. 2. Honor signifies the aggregate of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules by the assistance of which this dignity, glory, or reverence is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtained. Thus we say that a man has always strictly obeyed the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of honor; or a man has violated his honor. In this chapter the word is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always used in the latter sense.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think these peculiarities may be otherwise explained than by the mere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: caprices of certain individuals and nations, as has hitherto been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the customary mode of reasoning on the subject. Mankind is subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to general and lasting wants that have engendered moral laws, to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neglect of which men have ever and in all places attached the notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: censure and shame: to infringe them was "to do ill"--"to do well" was to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conform to them. Within the bosom of this vast association of the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: race, lesser associations have been formed which are called nations;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and amidst these nations further subdivisions have assumed the names
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of classes or castes. Each of these associations forms, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a separate species of the human race; and though it has no essential
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difference from the mass of mankind, to a certain extent it stands apart
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and has certain wants peculiar to itself. To these special wants must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be attributed the modifications which affect in various degrees and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in different countries the mode of considering human actions, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the estimate which ought to be formed of them. It is the general and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanent interest of mankind that men should not kill each other: but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may happen to be the peculiar and temporary interest of a people or a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class to justify, or even to honor, homicide.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Honor is simply that peculiar rule, founded upon a peculiar state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society, by the application of which a people or a class allot praise or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blame. Nothing is more unproductive to the mind than an abstract idea; I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore hasten to call in the aid of facts and examples to illustrate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my meaning.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I select the most extraordinary kind of honor which was ever known
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the world, and that which we are best acquainted with, viz.,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic honor springing out of feudal society. I shall explain it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by means of the principle already laid down, and I shall explain the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle by means of the illustration. I am not here led to inquire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when and how the aristocracy of the Middle Ages came into existence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: why it was so deeply severed from the remainder of the nation, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what founded and consolidated its power. I take its existence as an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established fact, and I am endeavoring to account for the peculiar view
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it took of the greater part of human actions. The first thing that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strikes me is, that in the feudal world actions were not always praised
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or blamed with reference to their intrinsic worth, but that they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes appreciated exclusively with reference to the person who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was the actor or the object of them, which is repugnant to the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conscience of mankind. Thus some of the actions which were indifferent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the part of a man in humble life, dishonored a noble; others changed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their whole character according as the person aggrieved by them belonged
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or did not belong to the aristocracy. When these different notions first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arose, the nobility formed a distinct body amidst the people, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it commanded from the inaccessible heights where it was ensconced. To
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintain this peculiar position, which constituted its strength, it not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only required political privileges, but it required a standard of right
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and wrong for its own especial use. That some particular virtue or vice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belonged to the nobility rather than to the humble classes--that certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions were guiltless when they affected the villain, which were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: criminal when they touched the noble--these were often arbitrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: matters; but that honor or shame should be attached to a man's actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: according to his condition, was a result of the internal constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of an aristocratic community. This has been actually the case in all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the countries which have had an aristocracy; as long as a trace of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle remains, these peculiarities will still exist; to debauch a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: woman of color scarcely injures the reputation of an American--to marry
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: her dishonors him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In some cases feudal honor enjoined revenge, and stigmatized the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forgiveness of insults; in others it imperiously commanded men to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquer their own passions, and imposed forgetfulness of self. It did
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not make humanity or kindness its law, but it extolled generosity; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: set more store on liberality than on benevolence; it allowed men to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enrich themselves by gambling or by war, but not by labor; it preferred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great crimes to small earnings; cupidity was less distasteful to it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than avarice; violence it often sanctioned, but cunning and treachery it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invariably reprobated as contemptible. These fantastical notions did not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proceed exclusively from the caprices of those who entertained them. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: class which has succeeded in placing itself at the head of and above
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all others, and which makes perpetual exertions to maintain this lofty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position, must especially honor those virtues which are conspicuous for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their dignity and splendor, and which may be easily combined with pride
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the love of power. Such men would not hesitate to invert the natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order of the conscience in order to give those virtues precedence before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all others. It may even be conceived that some of the more bold and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brilliant vices would readily be set above the quiet, unpretending
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtues. The very existence of such a class in society renders these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things unavoidable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The nobles of the Middle Ages placed military courage foremost amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtues, and in lieu of many of them. This was again a peculiar opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which arose necessarily from the peculiarity of the state of society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Feudal aristocracy existed by war and for war; its power had been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: founded by arms, and by arms that power was maintained; it therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: required nothing more than military courage, and that quality was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally exalted above all others; whatever denoted it, even at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expense of reason and humanity, was therefore approved and frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoined by the manners of the time. Such was the main principle; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: caprice of man was only to be traced in minuter details. That a man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should regard a tap on the cheek as an unbearable insult, and should be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliged to kill in single combat the person who struck him thus lightly,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is an arbitrary rule; but that a noble could not tranquilly receive an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insult, and was dishonored if he allowed himself to take a blow without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fighting, were direct consequences of the fundamental principles and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants of military aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus it was true to a certain extent to assert that the laws of honor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were capricious; but these caprices of honor were always confined within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain necessary limits. The peculiar rule, which was called honor by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our forefathers, is so far from being an arbitrary law in my eyes, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I would readily engage to ascribe its most incoherent and fantastical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: injunctions to a small number of fixed and invariable wants inherent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feudal society.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I were to trace the notion of feudal honor into the domain of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics, I should not find it more difficult to explain its dictates.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The state of society and the political institutions of the Middle Ages
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were such, that the supreme power of the nation never governed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community directly. That power did not exist in the eyes of the people:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every man looked up to a certain individual whom he was bound to obey;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by that intermediate personage he was connected with all the others.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus in feudal society the whole system of the commonwealth rested upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sentiment of fidelity to the person of the lord: to destroy that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sentiment was to open the sluices of anarchy. Fidelity to a political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior was, moreover, a sentiment of which all the members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy had constant opportunities of estimating the importance; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every one of them was a vassal as well as a lord, and had to command as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well as to obey. To remain faithful to the lord, to sacrifice one's self
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for him if called upon, to share his good or evil fortunes, to stand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by him in his undertakings whatever they might be--such were the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: injunctions of feudal honor in relation to the political institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those times. The treachery of a vassal was branded with extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severity by public opinion, and a name of peculiar infamy was invented
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the offence which was called "felony."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the contrary, few traces are to be found in the Middle Ages of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passion which constituted the life of the nations of antiquity--I mean
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patriotism; the word itself is not of very ancient date in the language.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: *b Feudal institutions concealed the country at large from men's sight,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and rendered the love of it less necessary. The nation was forgotten in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the passions which attached men to persons. Hence it was no part of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the strict law of feudal honor to remain faithful to one's country. Not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indeed that the love of their country did not exist in the hearts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our forefathers; but it constituted a dim and feeble instinct, which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grown more clear and strong in proportion as aristocratic classes have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been abolished, and the supreme power of the nation centralized. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be clearly seen from the contrary judgments which European nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have passed upon the various events of their histories, according to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generations by which such judgments have been formed. The circumstance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which most dishonored the Constable de Bourbon in the eyes of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries was that he bore arms against his king: that which most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dishonors him in our eyes, is that he made war against his country; we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brand him as deeply as our forefathers did, but for different reasons.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: Even the word "patrie" was not used by the French writers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: until the sixteenth century.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have chosen the honor of feudal times by way of illustration of my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: meaning, because its characteristics are more distinctly marked and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: familiar to us than those of any other period; but I might have taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an example elsewhere, and I should have reached the same conclusion by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a different road. Although we are less perfectly acquainted with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Romans than with our own ancestors, yet we know that certain peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions of glory and disgrace obtained amongst them, which were not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solely derived from the general principles of right and wrong. Many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: human actions were judged differently, according as they affected a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Roman citizen or a stranger, a freeman or a slave; certain vices were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blazoned abroad, certain virtues were extolled above all others. "In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that age," says Plutarch in the life of Coriolanus, "martial prowess
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was more honored and prized in Rome than all the other virtues, insomuch
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it was called virtus, the name of virtue itself, by applying the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: name of the kind to this particular species; so that virtue in Latin was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as much as to say valor." Can anyone fail to recognize the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: want of that singular community which was formed for the conquest of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Any nation would furnish us with similar grounds of observation; for,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as I have already remarked, whenever men collect together as a distinct
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, the notion of honor instantly grows up amongst them; that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to say, a system of opinions peculiar to themselves as to what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blamable or commendable; and these peculiar rules always originate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the special habits and special interests of the community. This is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applicable to a certain extent to democratic communities as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to others, as we shall now proceed to prove by the example of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans. *c Some loose notions of the old aristocratic honor of Europe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are still to be found scattered amongst the opinions of the Americans;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but these traditional opinions are few in number, they have but little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: root in the country, and but little power. They are like a religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which has still some temples left standing, though men have ceased
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to believe in it. But amidst these half-obliterated notions of exotic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor, some new opinions have sprung up, which constitute what may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: termed in our days American honor. I have shown how the Americans are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly driven to engage in commerce and industry. Their origin,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their social condition, their political institutions, and even the spot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they inhabit, urge them irresistibly in this direction. Their present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition is then that of an almost exclusively manufacturing and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commercial association, placed in the midst of a new and boundless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, which their principal object is to explore for purposes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profit. This is the characteristic which most peculiarly distinguishes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American people from all others at the present time. All those quiet
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtues which tend to give a regular movement to the community, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encourage business, will therefore be held in peculiar honor by that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, and to neglect those virtues will be to incur public contempt.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the more turbulent virtues, which often dazzle, but more frequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disturb society, will on the contrary occupy a subordinate rank in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: estimation of this same people: they may be neglected without forfeiting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the esteem of the community--to acquire them would perhaps be to run a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: risk of losing it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: I speak here of the Americans inhabiting those States where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slavery does not exist; they alone can be said to present a complete
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: picture of democratic society.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans make a no less arbitrary classification of men's vices.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are certain propensities which appear censurable to the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason and the universal conscience of mankind, but which happen to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agree with the peculiar and temporary wants of the American community:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these propensities are lightly reproved, sometimes even encouraged; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instance, the love of wealth and the secondary propensities connected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with it may be more particularly cited. To clear, to till, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transform the vast uninhabited continent which is his domain, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: American requires the daily support of an energetic passion; that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passion can only be the love of wealth; the passion for wealth is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore not reprobated in America, and provided it does not go beyond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bounds assigned to it for public security, it is held in honor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The American lauds as a noble and praiseworthy ambition what our own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forefathers in the Middle Ages stigmatized as servile cupidity, just
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as he treats as a blind and barbarous frenzy that ardor of conquest and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: martial temper which bore them to battle. In the United States fortunes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are lost and regained without difficulty; the country is boundless, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its resources inexhaustible. The people have all the wants and cravings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a growing creature; and whatever be their efforts, they are always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surrounded by more than they can appropriate. It is not the ruin of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: few individuals which may be soon repaired, but the inactivity and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sloth of the community at large which would be fatal to such a people.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Boldness of enterprise is the foremost cause of its rapid progress, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength, and its greatness. Commercial business is there like a vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lottery, by which a small number of men continually lose, but the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is always a gainer; such a people ought therefore to encourage and do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor to boldness in commercial speculations. But any bold speculation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: risks the fortune of the speculator and of all those who put their trust
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in him. The Americans, who make a virtue of commercial temerity, have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no right in any case to brand with disgrace those who practise it. Hence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arises the strange indulgence which is shown to bankrupts in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States; their honor does not suffer by such an accident. In this respect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Americans differ, not only from the nations of Europe, but from all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the commercial nations of our time, and accordingly they resemble none
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them in their position or their wants.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In America all those vices which tend to impair the purity of morals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to destroy the conjugal tie, are treated with a degree of severity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is unknown in the rest of the world. At first sight this seems
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strangely at variance with the tolerance shown there on other subjects,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and one is surprised to meet with a morality so relaxed and so austere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst the selfsame people. But these things are less incoherent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than they seem to be. Public opinion in the United States very gently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represses that love of wealth which promotes the commercial greatness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the prosperity of the nation, and it especially condemns that laxity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of morals which diverts the human mind from the pursuit of well-being,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and disturbs the internal order of domestic life which is so necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to success in business. To earn the esteem of their countrymen, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans are therefore constrained to adapt themselves to orderly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits--and it may be said in this sense that they make it a matter of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor to live chastely.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On one point American honor accords with the notions of honor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acknowledged in Europe; it places courage as the highest virtue, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: treats it as the greatest of the moral necessities of man; but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notion of courage itself assumes a different aspect. In the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States martial valor is but little prized; the courage which is best
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: known and most esteemed is that which emboldens men to brave the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers of the ocean, in order to arrive earlier in port--to support the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privations of the wilderness without complaint, and solitude more cruel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than privations--the courage which renders them almost insensible to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: loss of a fortune laboriously acquired, and instantly prompts to fresh
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions to make another. Courage of this kind is peculiarly necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the maintenance and prosperity of the American communities, and it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: held by them in peculiar honor and estimation; to betray a want of it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to incur certain disgrace.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have yet another characteristic point which may serve to place the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idea of this chapter in stronger relief. In a democratic society like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of the United States, where fortunes are scanty and insecure,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everybody works, and work opens a way to everything: this has changed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the point of honor quite round, and has turned it against idleness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have sometimes met in America with young men of wealth, personally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disinclined to all laborious exertion, but who had been compelled to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: embrace a profession. Their disposition and their fortune allowed them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to remain without employment; public opinion forbade it, too imperiously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be disobeyed. In the European countries, on the contrary, where
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy is still struggling with the flood which overwhelms it, I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have often seen men, constantly spurred on by their wants and desires,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain in idleness, in order not to lose the esteem of their equals; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have known them submit to ennui and privations rather than to work.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No one can fail to perceive that these opposite obligations are two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different rules of conduct, both nevertheless originating in the notion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of honor.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What our forefathers designated as honor absolutely was in reality only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one of its forms; they gave a generic name to what was only a species.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Honor therefore is to be found in democratic as well as in aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ages, but it will not be difficult to show that it assumes a different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aspect in the former. Not only are its injunctions different, but we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall shortly see that they are less numerous, less precise, and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its dictates are less rigorously obeyed. The position of a caste is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always much more peculiar than that of a people. Nothing is so much out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the way of the world as a small community invariably composed of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same families (as was for instance the aristocracy of the Middle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ages), whose object is to concentrate and to retain, exclusively and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hereditarily, education, wealth, and power amongst its own members. But
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the more out of the way the position of a community happens to be, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more numerous are its special wants, and the more extensive are its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions of honor corresponding to those wants. The rules of honor will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore always be less numerous amongst a people not divided into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: castes than amongst any other. If ever any nations are constituted in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it may even be difficult to find any peculiar classes of society,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the notion of honor will be confined to a small number of precepts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which will be more and more in accordance with the moral laws adopted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the mass of mankind. Thus the laws of honor will be less peculiar and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less multifarious amongst a democratic people than in an aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They will also be more obscure; and this is a necessary consequence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of what goes before; for as the distinguishing marks of honor are less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numerous and less peculiar, it must often be difficult to distinguish
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. To this, other reasons may be added. Amongst the aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations of the Middle Ages, generation succeeded generation in vain;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each family was like a never-dying, ever-stationary man, and the state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of opinions was hardly more changeable than that of conditions. Everyone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then had always the same objects before his eyes, which he contemplated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the same point; his eyes gradually detected the smallest details,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and his discernment could not fail to become in the end clear and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accurate. Thus not only had the men of feudal times very extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions in matters of honor, but each of those opinions was present to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their minds under a clear and precise form.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This can never be the case in America, where all men are in constant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: motion; and where society, transformed daily by its own operations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: changes its opinions together with its wants. In such a country men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have glimpses of the rules of honor, but they have seldom time to fix
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention upon them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But even if society were motionless, it would still be difficult to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determine the meaning which ought to be attached to the word "honor." In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Middle Ages, as each class had its own honor, the same opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was never received at the same time by a large number of men; and this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rendered it possible to give it a determined and accurate form, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was the more easy, as all those by whom it was received, having a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perfectly identical and most peculiar position, were naturally disposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to agree upon the points of a law which was made for themselves alone.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the code of honor became a complete and detailed system, in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everything was anticipated and provided for beforehand, and a fixed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and always palpable standard was applied to human actions. Amongst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nation, like the Americans, in which ranks are identified,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the whole of society forms one single mass, composed of elements
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are all analogous though not entirely similar, it is impossible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
