text: ever to agree beforehand on what shall or shall not be allowed by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws of honor. Amongst that people, indeed, some national wants do exist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which give rise to opinions common to the whole nation on points of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor; but these opinions never occur at the same time, in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner, or with the same intensity to the minds of the whole community;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the law of honor exists, but it has no organs to promulgate it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The confusion is far greater still in a democratic country like France,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: where the different classes of which the former fabric of society was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed, being brought together but not yet mingled, import day by day
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into each other's circles various and sometimes conflicting notions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of honor--where every man, at his own will and pleasure, forsakes one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: portion of his forefathers' creed, and retains another; so that, amidst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so many arbitrary measures, no common rule can ever be established, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is almost impossible to predict which actions will be held in honor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and which will be thought disgraceful. Such times are wretched, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are of short duration.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As honor, amongst democratic nations, is imperfectly defined, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence is of course less powerful; for it is difficult to apply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with certainty and firmness a law which is not distinctly known. Public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion, the natural and supreme interpreter of the laws of honor, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clearly discerning to which side censure or approval ought to lean,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can only pronounce a hesitating judgment. Sometimes the opinion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public may contradict itself; more frequently it does not act, and lets
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things pass.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The weakness of the sense of honor in democracies also arises from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several other causes. In aristocratic countries, the same notions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor are always entertained by only a few persons, always limited in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number, often separated from the rest of their fellow-citizens. Honor is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easily mingled and identified in their minds with the idea of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that distinguishes their own position; it appears to them as the chief
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristic of their own rank; they apply its different rules with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the warmth of personal interest, and they feel (if I may use the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expression) a passion for complying with its dictates. This truth is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely obvious in the old black-letter lawbooks on the subject of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "trial by battel." The nobles, in their disputes, were bound to use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the lance and sword; whereas the villains used only sticks amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, "inasmuch as," to use the words of the old books, "villains
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have no honor." This did not mean, as it may be imagined at the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day, that these people were contemptible; but simply that their actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were not to be judged by the same rules which were applied to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions of the aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is surprising, at first sight, that when the sense of honor is most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predominant, its injunctions are usually most strange; so that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: further it is removed from common reason the better it is obeyed; whence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it has sometimes been inferred that the laws of honor were strengthened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their own extravagance. The two things indeed originate from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same source, but the one is not derived from the other. Honor becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fantastical in proportion to the peculiarity of the wants which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: denotes, and the paucity of the men by whom those wants are felt; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is because it denotes wants of this kind that its influence is great.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus the notion of honor is not the stronger for being fantastical, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is fantastical and strong from the selfsame cause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Further, amongst aristocratic nations each rank is different, but all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranks are fixed; every man occupies a place in his own sphere which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot relinquish, and he lives there amidst other men who are bound by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same ties. Amongst these nations no man can either hope or fear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: escape being seen; no man is placed so low but that he has a stage of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his own, and none can avoid censure or applause by his obscurity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democratic States on the contrary, where all the members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community are mingled in the same crowd and in constant agitation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public opinion has no hold on men; they disappear at every instant, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elude its power. Consequently the dictates of honor will be there less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imperious and less stringent; for honor acts solely for the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eye--differing in this respect from mere virtue, which lives upon itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contented with its own approval.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the reader has distinctly apprehended all that goes before, he will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: understand that there is a close and necessary relation between the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality of social conditions and what has here been styled honor--a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relation which, if I am not mistaken, had not before been clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pointed out. I shall therefore make one more attempt to illustrate it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfactorily. Suppose a nation stands apart from the rest of mankind:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independently of certain general wants inherent in the human race, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will also have wants and interests peculiar to itself: certain opinions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of censure or approbation forthwith arise in the community, which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar to itself, and which are styled honor by the members of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community. Now suppose that in this same nation a caste arises, which,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in its turn, stands apart from all the other classes, and contracts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain peculiar wants, which give rise in their turn to special
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions. The honor of this caste, composed of a medley of the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions of the nation, and the still more peculiar notions of the caste,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be as remote as it is possible to conceive from the simple and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general opinions of men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Having reached this extreme point of the argument, I now return. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranks are commingled and privileges abolished, the men of whom a nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is composed being once more equal and alike, their interests and wants
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become identical, and all the peculiar notions which each caste styled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor successively disappear: the notion of honor no longer proceeds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from any other source than the wants peculiar to the nation at large,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it denotes the individual character of that nation to the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lastly, if it be allowable to suppose that all the races of mankind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be commingled, and that all the peoples of earth should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ultimately come to have the same interests, the same wants,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undistinguished from each other by any characteristic peculiarities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no conventional value whatever would then be attached to men's actions;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they would all be regarded by all in the same light; the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessities of mankind, revealed by conscience to every man, would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become the common standard. The simple and general notions of right and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wrong only would then be recognized in the world, to which, by a natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and necessary tie, the idea of censure or approbation would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attached. Thus, to comprise all my meaning in a single proposition,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the dissimilarities and inequalities of men gave rise to the notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor; that notion is weakened in proportion as these differences are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obliterated, and with them it would disappear.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XIX: Why So Many Ambitious Men And So Little Lofty Ambition Are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To Be Found In The United States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first thing which strikes a traveller in the United States is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innumerable multitude of those who seek to throw off their original
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition; and the second is the rarity of lofty ambition to be observed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the midst of the universally ambitious stir of society. No Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are devoid of a yearning desire to rise; but hardly any appear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertain hopes of great magnitude, or to drive at very lofty aims. All
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are constantly seeking to acquire property, power, and reputation--few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemplate these things upon a great scale; and this is the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surprising, as nothing is to be discerned in the manners or laws of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America to limit desire, or to prevent it from spreading its impulses in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every direction. It seems difficult to attribute this singular state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things to the equality of social conditions; for at the instant when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that same equality was established in France, the flight of ambition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became unbounded. Nevertheless, I think that the principal cause which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be assigned to this fact is to be found in the social condition and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic manners of the Americans.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All revolutions enlarge the ambition of men: this proposition is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiarly true of those revolutions which overthrow an aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the former barriers which kept back the multitude from fame and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power are suddenly thrown down, a violent and universal rise takes place
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: towards that eminence so long coveted and at length to be enjoyed. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this first burst of triumph nothing seems impossible to anyone: not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are desires boundless, but the power of satisfying them seems almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: boundless, too. Amidst the general and sudden renewal of laws and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customs, in this vast confusion of all men and all ordinances, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: various members of the community rise and sink again with excessive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapidity; and power passes so quickly from hand to hand that none need
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despair of catching it in turn. It must be recollected, moreover, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people who destroy an aristocracy have lived under its laws; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have witnessed its splendor, and they have unconsciously imbibed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feelings and notions which it entertained. Thus at the moment when an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy is dissolved, its spirit still pervades the mass of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, and its tendencies are retained long after it has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defeated. Ambition is therefore always extremely great as long as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic revolution lasts, and it will remain so for some time after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the revolution is consummated. The reminiscence of the extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: events which men have witnessed is not obliterated from their memory in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a day. The passions which a revolution has roused do not disappear at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its close. A sense of instability remains in the midst of re-established
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order: a notion of easy success survives the strange vicissitudes which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gave it birth; desires still remain extremely enlarged, when the means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of satisfying them are diminished day by day. The taste for large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortunes subsists, though large fortunes are rare: and on every side we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trace the ravages of inordinate and hapless ambition kindled in hearts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they consume in secret and in vain.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At length, however, the last vestiges of the struggle are effaced; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains of aristocracy completely disappear; the great events by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its fall was attended are forgotten; peace succeeds to war, and the sway
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of order is restored in the new realm; desires are again adapted to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means by which they may be fulfilled; the wants, the opinions, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the feelings of men cohere once more; the level of the community is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanently determined, and democratic society established. A democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, arrived at this permanent and regular state of things, will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present a very different spectacle from that which we have just
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: described; and we may readily conclude that, if ambition becomes great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst the conditions of society are growing equal, it loses that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quality when they have grown so. As wealth is subdivided and knowledge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diffused, no one is entirely destitute of education or of property;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the privileges and disqualifications of caste being abolished, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men having shattered the bonds which held them fixed, the notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advancement suggests itself to every mind, the desire to rise swells in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every heart, and all men want to mount above their station: ambition is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the universal feeling.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But if the equality of conditions gives some resources to all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community, it also prevents any of them from having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources of great extent, which necessarily circumscribes their desires
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within somewhat narrow limits. Thus amongst democratic nations ambition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is ardent and continual, but its aim is not habitually lofty; and life
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is generally spent in eagerly coveting small objects which are within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reach. What chiefly diverts the men of democracies from lofty ambition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not the scantiness of their fortunes, but the vehemence of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exertions they daily make to improve them. They strain their faculties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the utmost to achieve paltry results, and this cannot fail speedily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to limit their discernment and to circumscribe their powers. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: might be much poorer and still be greater. The small number of opulent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens who are to be found amidst a democracy do not constitute an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exception to this rule. A man who raises himself by degrees to wealth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and power, contracts, in the course of this protracted labor, habits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of prudence and restraint which he cannot afterwards shake off. A man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot enlarge his mind as he would his house. The same observation is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applicable to the sons of such a man; they are born, it is true, in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lofty position, but their parents were humble; they have grown up amidst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feelings and notions which they cannot afterwards easily get rid of;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it may be presumed that they will inherit the propensities of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: father as well as his wealth. It may happen, on the contrary, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the poorest scion of a powerful aristocracy may display vast ambition,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because the traditional opinions of his race and the general spirit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his order still buoy him up for some time above his fortune. Another
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing which prevents the men of democratic periods from easily indulging
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the pursuit of lofty objects, is the lapse of time which they foresee
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must take place before they can be ready to approach them. "It is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great advantage," says Pascal, "to be a man of quality, since it brings
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one man as forward at eighteen or twenty as another man would be at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fifty, which is a clear gain of thirty years." Those thirty years
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are commonly wanting to the ambitious characters of democracies. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of equality, which allows every man to arrive at everything,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevents all men from rapid advancement.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In a democratic society, as well as elsewhere, there are only a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of great fortunes to be made; and as the paths which lead to them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are indiscriminately open to all, the progress of all must necessarily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be slackened. As the candidates appear to be nearly alike, and as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is difficult to make a selection without infringing the principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality, which is the supreme law of democratic societies, the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: idea which suggests itself is to make them all advance at the same rate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and submit to the same probation. Thus in proportion as men become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more alike, and the principle of equality is more peaceably and deeply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infused into the institutions and manners of the country, the rules
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of advancement become more inflexible, advancement itself slower, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty of arriving quickly at a certain height far greater. From
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hatred of privilege and from the embarrassment of choosing, all men are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at last constrained, whatever may be their standard, to pass the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordeal; all are indiscriminately subjected to a multitude of petty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preliminary exercises, in which their youth is wasted and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagination quenched, so that they despair of ever fully attaining
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what is held out to them; and when at length they are in a condition to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perform any extraordinary acts, the taste for such things has forsaken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In China, where the equality of conditions is exceedingly great and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very ancient, no man passes from one public office to another without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undergoing a probationary trial. This probation occurs afresh at every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stage of his career; and the notion is now so rooted in the manners of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people that I remember to have read a Chinese novel, in which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hero, after numberless crosses, succeeds at length in touching the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: heart of his mistress by taking honors. A lofty ambition breathes with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty in such an atmosphere.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The remark I apply to politics extends to everything; equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everywhere produces the same effects; where the laws of a country do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not regulate and retard the advancement of men by positive enactment,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: competition attains the same end. In a well-established democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community great and rapid elevation is therefore rare; it forms
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an exception to the common rule; and it is the singularity of such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurrences that makes men forget how rarely they happen. Men living in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies ultimately discover these things; they find out at last that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the laws of their country open a boundless field of action before them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but that no one can hope to hasten across it. Between them and the final
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object of their desires, they perceive a multitude of small intermediate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impediments, which must be slowly surmounted: this prospect wearies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and discourages their ambition at once. They therefore give up hopes so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doubtful and remote, to search nearer to themselves for less lofty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more easy enjoyments. Their horizon is not bounded by the laws but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: narrowed by themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have remarked that lofty ambitions are more rare in the ages of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracy than in times of aristocracy: I may add that when, in spite of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these natural obstacles, they do spring into existence, their character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is different. In aristocracies the career of ambition is often wide, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its boundaries are determined. In democracies ambition commonly ranges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a narrower field, but if once it gets beyond that, hardly any limits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can be assigned to it. As men are individually weak--as they live
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asunder, and in constant motion--as precedents are of little authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and laws but of short duration, resistance to novelty is languid,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the fabric of society never appears perfectly erect or firmly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consolidated. So that, when once an ambitious man has the power in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grasp, there is nothing he may noted are; and when it is gone from him,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he meditates the overthrow of the State to regain it. This gives to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great political ambition a character of revolutionary violence, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it seldom exhibits to an equal degree in aristocratic communities. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common aspect of democratic nations will present a great number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small and very rational objects of ambition, from amongst which a few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ill-controlled desires of a larger growth will at intervals break out:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but no such a thing as ambition conceived and contrived on a vast scale
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to be met with there.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown elsewhere by what secret influence the principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality makes the passion for physical gratifications and the exclusive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: love of the present predominate in the human heart: these different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities mingle with the sentiment of ambition, and tinge it, as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were, with their hues. I believe that ambitious men in democracies are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less engrossed than any others with the interests and the judgment of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: posterity; the present moment alone engages and absorbs them. They are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more apt to complete a number of undertakings with rapidity than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raise lasting monuments of their achievements; and they care much more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for success than for fame. What they most ask of men is obedience--what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they most covet is empire. Their manners have in almost all cases
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remained below the height of their station; the consequence is that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently carry very low tastes into their extraordinary fortunes, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they seem to have acquired the supreme power only to minister to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their coarse or paltry pleasures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that in our time it is very necessary to cleanse, to regulate,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to adapt the feeling of ambition, but that it would be extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous to seek to impoverish and to repress it over-much. We should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempt to lay down certain extreme limits, which it should never be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allowed to outstep; but its range within those established limits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should not be too much checked. I confess that I apprehend much less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for democratic society from the boldness than from the mediocrity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires. What appears to me most to be dreaded is that, in the midst of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the small incessant occupations of private life, ambition should lose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its vigor and its greatness--that the passions of man should abate, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the same time be lowered, so that the march of society should every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day become more tranquil and less aspiring. I think then that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leaders of modern society would be wrong to seek to lull the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a state of too uniform and too peaceful happiness; and that it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well to expose it from time to time to matters of difficulty and danger,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to raise ambition and to give it a field of action. Moralists
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are constantly complaining that the ruling vice of the present time is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pride. This is true in one sense, for indeed no one thinks that he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not better than his neighbor, or consents to obey his superior: but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is extremely false in another; for the same man who cannot endure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subordination or equality, has so contemptible an opinion of himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that he thinks he is only born to indulge in vulgar pleasures. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: willingly takes up with low desires, without daring to embark in lofty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enterprises, of which he scarcely dreams. Thus, far from thinking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that humility ought to be preached to our contemporaries, I would have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavors made to give them a more enlarged idea of themselves and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their kind. Humility is unwholesome to them; what they most want is,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in my opinion, pride. I would willingly exchange several of our small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtues for this one vice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XX: The Trade Of Place-Hunting In Certain Democratic Countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States as soon as a man has acquired some education and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pecuniary resources, he either endeavors to get rich by commerce or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industry, or he buys land in the bush and turns pioneer. All that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: asks of the State is not to be disturbed in his toil, and to be secure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his earnings. Amongst the greater part of European nations, when a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man begins to feel his strength and to extend his desires, the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thing that occurs to him is to get some public employment. These
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposite effects, originating in the same cause, deserve our passing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When public employments are few in number, ill-paid and precarious,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst the different lines of business are numerous and lucrative, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to business, and not to official duties, that the new and eager desires
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engendered by the principle of equality turn from every side. But if,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst the ranks of society are becoming more equal, the education of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people remains incomplete, or their spirit the reverse of bold--if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commerce and industry, checked in their growth, afford only slow and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arduous means of making a fortune--the various members of the community,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despairing of ameliorating their own condition, rush to the head of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State and demand its assistance. To relieve their own necessities at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cost of the public treasury, appears to them to be the easiest and most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: open, if not the only, way they have to rise above a condition which no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer contents them; place-hunting becomes the most generally followed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all trades. This must especially be the case, in those great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralized monarchies in which the number of paid offices is immense,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the tenure of them tolerably secure, so that no one despairs of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtaining a place, and of enjoying it as undisturbedly as a hereditary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fortune.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall not remark that the universal and inordinate desire for place is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great social evil; that it destroys the spirit of independence in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen, and diffuses a venal and servile humor throughout the frame
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society; that it stifles the manlier virtues: nor shall I be at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the pains to demonstrate that this kind of traffic only creates an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unproductive activity, which agitates the country without adding to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources: all these things are obvious. But I would observe, that a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government which encourages this tendency risks its own tranquillity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and places its very existence in great jeopardy. I am aware that at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time like our own, when the love and respect which formerly clung to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority are seen gradually to decline, it may appear necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those in power to lay a closer hold on every man by his own interest,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and it may seem convenient to use his own passions to keep him in order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in silence; but this cannot be so long, and what may appear to be a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: source of strength for a certain time will assuredly become in the end a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great cause of embarrassment and weakness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst democratic nations, as well as elsewhere, the number of official
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appointments has in the end some limits; but amongst those nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the number of aspirants is unlimited; it perpetually increases, with a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradual and irresistible rise in proportion as social conditions become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more equal, and is only checked by the limits of the population.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, when public employments afford the only outlet for ambition, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government necessarily meets with a permanent opposition at last; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is tasked to satisfy with limited means unlimited desires. It is very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain that of all people in the world the most difficult to restrain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to manage are a people of solicitants. Whatever endeavors are made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by rulers, such a people can never be contented; and it is always to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apprehended that they will ultimately overturn the constitution of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, and change the aspect of the State, for the sole purpose of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: making a clearance of places. The sovereigns of the present age, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strive to fix upon themselves alone all those novel desires which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aroused by equality, and to satisfy them, will repent in the end, if I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am not mistaken, that they ever embarked in this policy: they will one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day discover that they have hazarded their own power, by making it so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary; and that the more safe and honest course would have been to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: teach their subjects the art of providing for themselves. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: As a matter of fact, more recent experience has shown that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place-hunting is quite as intense in the United States as in any country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in Europe. It is regarded by the Americans themselves as one of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great evils of their social condition, and it powerfully affects their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political institutions. But the American who seeks a place seeks not so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much a means of subsistence as the distinction which office and public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: employment confer. In the absence of any true aristocracy, the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: service creates a spurious one, which is as much an object of ambition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the distinctions of rank in aristocratic countries.--Translator's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Note.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XXI: Why Great Revolutions Will Become More Rare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A people which has existed for centuries under a system of castes and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes can only arrive at a democratic state of society by passing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through a long series of more or less critical transformations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accomplished by violent efforts, and after numerous vicissitudes; in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course of which, property, opinions, and power are rapidly transferred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from one hand to another. Even after this great revolution is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consummated, the revolutionary habits engendered by it may long be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: traced, and it will be followed by deep commotion. As all this takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place at the very time at which social conditions are becoming more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal, it is inferred that some concealed relation and secret tie exist
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the principle of equality itself and revolution, insomuch that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the one cannot exist without giving rise to the other.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On this point reasoning may seem to lead to the same result as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience. Amongst a people whose ranks are nearly equal, no ostensible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bond connects men together, or keeps them settled in their station.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: None of them have either a permanent right or power to command--none
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are forced by their condition to obey; but every man, finding himself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed of some education and some resources, may choose his won path
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and proceed apart from all his fellow-men. The same causes which make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the members of the community independent of each other, continually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impel them to new and restless desires, and constantly spur them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: onwards. It therefore seems natural that, in a democratic community,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, things, and opinions should be forever changing their form and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place, and that democratic ages should be times of rapid and incessant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transformation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But is this really the case? does the equality of social conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habitually and permanently lead men to revolution? does that state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society contain some perturbing principle which prevents the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from ever subsiding into calm, and disposes the citizens to alter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: incessantly their laws, their principles, and their manners? I do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: believe it; and as the subject is important, I beg for the reader's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: close attention. Almost all the revolutions which have changed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aspect of nations have been made to consolidate or to destroy social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality. Remove the secondary causes which have produced the great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: convulsions of the world, and you will almost always find the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of inequality at the bottom. Either the poor have attempted to plunder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rich, or the rich to enslave the poor. If then a state of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can ever be founded in which every man shall have something to keep, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little to take from others, much will have been done for the peace of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world. I am aware that amongst a great democratic people there will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always be some members of the community in great poverty, and others in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great opulence; but the poor, instead of forming the immense majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the nation, as is always the case in aristocratic communities, are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparatively few in number, and the laws do not bind them together by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ties of irremediable and hereditary penury. The wealthy, on their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: side, are scarce and powerless; they have no privileges which attract
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public observation; even their wealth, as it is no longer incorporated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and bound up with the soil, is impalpable, and as it were invisible. As
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there is no longer a race of poor men, so there is no longer a race of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich men; the latter spring up daily from the multitude, and relapse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into it again. Hence they do not form a distinct class, which may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easily marked out and plundered; and, moreover, as they are connected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the mass of their fellow-citizens by a thousand secret ties, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people cannot assail them without inflicting an injury upon itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Between these two extremes of democratic communities stand an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innumerable multitude of men almost alike, who, without being exactly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either rich or poor, are possessed of sufficient property to desire the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: maintenance of order, yet not enough to excite envy. Such men are the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural enemies of violent commotions: their stillness keeps all beneath
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them and above them still, and secures the balance of the fabric of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society. Not indeed that even these men are contented with what they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have gotten, or that they feel a natural abhorrence for a revolution in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they might share the spoil without sharing the calamity; on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, they desire, with unexampled ardor, to get rich, but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty is to know from whom riches can be taken. The same state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society which constantly prompts desires, restrains these desires
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within necessary limits: it gives men more liberty of changing and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest in change.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not only are the men of democracies not naturally desirous of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions, but they are afraid of them. All revolutions more or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less threaten the tenure of property: but most of those who live in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic countries are possessed of property--not only are they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessed of property, but they live in the condition of men who set the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greatest store upon their property. If we attentively consider each of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the classes of which society is composed, it is easy to see that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions engendered by property are keenest and most tenacious amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the middle classes. The poor often care but little for what they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possess, because they suffer much more from the want of what they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not, than they enjoy the little they have. The rich have many other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions besides that of riches to satisfy; and, besides, the long and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arduous enjoyment of a great fortune sometimes makes them in the end
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insensible to its charms. But the men who have a competency, alike
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removed from opulence and from penury, attach an enormous value to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possessions. As they are still almost within the reach of poverty, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: see its privations near at hand, and dread them; between poverty and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves there is nothing but a scanty fortune, upon which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediately fix their apprehensions and their hopes. Every day increases
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the interest they take in it, by the constant cares which it occasions;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and they are the more attached to it by their continual exertions to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase the amount. The notion of surrendering the smallest part of it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is insupportable to them, and they consider its total loss as the worst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of misfortunes. Now these eager and apprehensive men of small property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitute the class which is constantly increased by the equality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions. Hence, in democratic communities, the majority of the people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do not clearly see what they have to gain by a revolution, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continually and in a thousand ways feel that they might lose by one.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown in another part of this work that the equality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions naturally urges men to embark in commercial and industrial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuits, and that it tends to increase and to distribute real property:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have also pointed out the means by which it inspires every man with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an eager and constant desire to increase his welfare. Nothing is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposed to revolutionary passions than these things. It may happen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the final result of a revolution is favorable to commerce and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures; but its first consequence will almost always be the ruin
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of manufactures and mercantile men, because it must always change at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: once the general principles of consumption, and temporarily upset the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existing proportion between supply and demand. I know of nothing more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opposite to revolutionary manners than commercial manners. Commerce is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally adverse to all the violent passions; it loves to temporize,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: takes delight in compromise, and studiously avoids irritation. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is patient, insinuating, flexible, and never has recourse to extreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: measures until obliged by the most absolute necessity. Commerce renders
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men independent of each other, gives them a lofty notion of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal importance, leads them to seek to conduct their own affairs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and teaches how to conduct them well; it therefore prepares men for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom, but preserves them from revolutions. In a revolution the owners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of personal property have more to fear than all others; for on the one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand their property is often easy to seize, and on the other it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: totally disappear at any moment--a subject of alarm to which the owners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of real property are less exposed, since, although they may lose the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: income of their estates, they may hope to preserve the land itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through the greatest vicissitudes. Hence the former are much more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alarmed at the symptoms of revolutionary commotion than the latter. Thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations are less disposed to make revolutions in proportion as personal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property is augmented and distributed amongst them, and as the number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of those possessing it increases. Moreover, whatever profession men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may embrace, and whatever species of property they may possess, one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristic is common to them all. No one is fully contented with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his present fortune--all are perpetually striving in a thousand ways to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: improve it. Consider any one of them at any period of his life, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he will be found engaged with some new project for the purpose of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increasing what he has; talk not to him of the interests and the rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of mankind: this small domestic concern absorbs for the time all his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thoughts, and inclines him to defer political excitement to some other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: season. This not only prevents men from making revolutions, but deters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men from desiring them. Violent political passions have but little hold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on those who have devoted all their faculties to the pursuit of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well-being. The ardor which they display in small matters calms their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: zeal for momentous undertakings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From time to time indeed, enterprising and ambitious men will arise in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic communities, whose unbounded aspirations cannot be contented
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by following the beaten track. Such men like revolutions and hail their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: approach; but they have great difficulty in bringing them about, unless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unwonted events come to their assistance. No man can struggle with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantage against the spirit of his age and country; and, however
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerful he may be supposed to be, he will find it difficult to make his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries share in feelings and opinions which are repugnant to t
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all their feelings and desires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is a mistake to believe that, when once the equality of conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has become the old and uncontested state of society, and has imparted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its characteristics to the manners of a nation, men will easily allow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to be thrust into perilous risks by an imprudent leader or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a bold innovator. Not indeed that they will resist him openly, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well-contrived schemes, or even by a premeditated plan of resistance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: They will not struggle energetically against him, sometimes they will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even applaud him--but they do not follow him. To his vehemence they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secretly oppose their inertia; to his revolutionary tendencies their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conservative interests; their homely tastes to his adventurous passions;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their good sense to the flights of his genius; to his poetry their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prose. With immense exertion he raises them for an instant, but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speedily escape from him, and fall back, as it were, by their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weight. He strains himself to rouse the indifferent and distracted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: multitude, and finds at last that he is reduced to impotence, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because he is conquered, but because he is alone.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not assert that men living in democratic communities are naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stationary; I think, on the contrary, that a perpetual stir prevails
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the bosom of those societies, and that rest is unknown there; but I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: think that men bestir themselves within certain limits beyond which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they hardly ever go. They are forever varying, altering, and restoring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secondary matters; but they carefully abstain from touching what is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fundamental. They love change, but they dread revolutions. Although the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans are constantly modifying or abrogating some of their laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they by no means display revolutionary passions. It may be easily seen,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the promptitude with which they check and calm themselves when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public excitement begins to grow alarming, and at the very moment when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions seem most roused, that they dread a revolution as the worst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of misfortunes, and that every one of them is inwardly resolved to make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great sacrifices to avoid such a catastrophe. In no country in the world
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the love of property more active and more anxious than in the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States; nowhere does the majority display less inclination for those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles which threaten to alter, in whatever manner, the laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of property. I have often remarked that theories which are of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutionary nature, since they cannot be put in practice without a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complete and sometimes a sudden change in the state of property and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons, are much less favorably viewed in the United States than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great monarchical countries of Europe: if some men profess them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the bulk of the people reject them with instinctive abhorrence. I do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hesitate to say that most of the maxims commonly called democratic in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: France would be proscribed by the democracy of the United States. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may easily be understood: in America men have the opinions and passions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of democracy, in Europe we have still the passions and opinions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution. If ever America undergoes great revolutions, they will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be brought about by the presence of the black race on the soil of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States--that is to say, they will owe their origin, not to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality, but to the inequality, of conditions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When social conditions are equal, every man is apt to live apart,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centred in himself and forgetful of the public. If the rulers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations were either to neglect to correct this fatal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency, or to encourage it from a notion that it weans men from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political passions and thus wards off revolutions, they might eventually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produce the evil they seek to avoid, and a time might come when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inordinate passions of a few men, aided by the unintelligent selfishness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or the pusillanimity of the greater number, would ultimately compel
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society to pass through strange vicissitudes. In democratic communities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions are seldom desired except by a minority; but a minority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may sometimes effect them. I do not assert that democratic nations are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secure from revolutions; I merely say that the state of society in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those nations does not lead to revolutions, but rather wards them off.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A democratic people left to itself will not easily embark in great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hazards; it is only led to revolutions unawares; it may sometimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undergo them, but it does not make them; and I will add that, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such a people has been allowed to acquire sufficient knowledge and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience, it will not suffer them to be made. I am well aware that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it this respect public institutions may themselves do much; they may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encourage or repress the tendencies which originate in the state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society. I therefore do not maintain, I repeat, that a people is secure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from revolutions simply because conditions are equal in the community;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but I think that, whatever the institutions of such a people may be,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great revolutions will always be far less violent and less frequent than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is supposed; and I can easily discern a state of polity, which, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combined with the principle of equality, would render society more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stationary than it has ever been in our western apart of the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The observations I have here made on events may also be applied in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part to opinions. Two things are surprising in the United States--the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mutability of the greater part of human actions, and the singular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stability of certain principles. Men are in constant motion; the mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of man appears almost unmoved. When once an opinion has spread over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country and struck root there, it would seem that no power on earth is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strong enough to eradicate it. In the United States, general principles
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in religion, philosophy, morality, and even politics, do not vary, or at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: least are only modified by a hidden and often an imperceptible process:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: even the grossest prejudices are obliterated with incredible slowness,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amidst the continual friction of men and things. I hear it said that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is in the nature and the habits of democracies to be constantly changing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their opinions and feelings. This may be true of small democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, like those of the ancient world, in which the whole community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: could be assembled in a public place and then excited at will by an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: orator. But I saw nothing of the kind amongst the great democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people which dwells upon the opposite shores of the Atlantic Ocean.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: What struck me in the United States was the difficulty in shaking the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: majority in an opinion once conceived, or of drawing it off from a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leader once adopted. Neither speaking nor writing can accomplish it;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing but experience will avail, and even experience must be repeated.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is surprising at first sight, but a more attentive investigation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explains the fact. I do not think that it is as easy as is supposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uproot the prejudices of a democratic people--to change its belief--to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supersede principles once established, by new principles in religion,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: politics, and morals--in a word, to make great and frequent changes in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men's minds. Not that the human mind is there at rest--it is in constant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agitation; but it is engaged in infinitely varying the consequences of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: known principles, and in seeking for new consequences, rather than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seeking for new principles. Its motion is one of rapid circumvolution,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather than of straightforward impulse by rapid and direct effort; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extends its orbit by small continual and hasty movements, but it does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not suddenly alter its position.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men who are equal in rights, in education, in fortune, or, to comprise
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all in one word, in their social condition, have necessarily wants,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits, and tastes which are hardly dissimilar. As they look at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objects under the same aspect, their minds naturally tend to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: analogous conclusions; and, though each of them may deviate from his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries and from opinions of his own, they will involuntarily and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unconsciously concur in a certain number of received opinions. The more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attentively I consider the effects of equality upon the mind, the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am I persuaded that the intellectual anarchy which we witness about us
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not, as many men suppose, the natural state of democratic nations.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think it is rather to be regarded as an accident peculiar to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: youth, and that it only breaks out at that period of transition when men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have already snapped the former ties which bound them together, but are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still amazingly different in origin, education, and manners; so that,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having retained opinions, propensities and tastes of great diversity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing any longer prevents men from avowing them openly. The leading
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions of men become similar in proportion as their conditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assimilate; such appears to me to be the general and permanent law--the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rest is casual and transient.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe that it will rarely happen to any man amongst a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, suddenly to frame a system of notions very remote from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that which his contemporaries have adopted; and if some such innovator
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeared, I apprehend that he would have great difficulty in finding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: listeners, still more in finding believers. When the conditions of men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are almost equal, they do not easily allow themselves to be persuaded by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other. As they all live in close intercourse, as they have learned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same things together, and as they lead the same life, they are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally disposed to take one of themselves for a guide, and to follow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him implicitly. Men seldom take the opinion of their equal, or of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man like themselves, upon trust. Not only is confidence in the superior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attainments of certain individuals weakened amongst democratic nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as I have elsewhere remarked, but the general notion of the intellectual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superiority which any man whatsoever may acquire in relation to the rest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community is soon overshadowed. As men grow more like each other,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the doctrine of the equality of the intellect gradually infuses itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into their opinions; and it becomes more difficult for any innovator to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquire or to exert much influence over the minds of a people. In such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities sudden intellectual revolutions will therefore be rare; for,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if we read aright the history of the world, we shall find that great and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapid changes in human opinions have been produced far less by the force
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of reasoning than by the authority of a name. Observe, too, that as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men who live in democratic societies are not connected with each other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by any tie, each of them must be convinced individually; whilst in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic society it is enough to convince a few--the rest follow.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If Luther had lived in an age of equality, and had not had princes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and potentates for his audience, he would perhaps have found it more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult to change the aspect of Europe. Not indeed that the men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies are naturally strongly persuaded of the certainty of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions, or are unwavering in belief; they frequently entertain doubts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which no one, in their eyes, can remove. It sometimes happens at such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: times that the human mind would willingly change its position; but as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing urges or guides it forwards, it oscillates to and fro without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progressive motion. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: If I inquire what state of society is most favorable to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great revolutions of the mind, I find that it occurs somewhere between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the complete equality of the whole community and the absolute separation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of ranks. Under a system of castes generations succeed each other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without altering men's positions; some have nothing more, others nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: better, to hope for. The imagination slumbers amidst this universal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: silence and stillness, and the very idea of change fades from the human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind. When ranks have been abolished and social conditions are almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equalized, all men are in ceaseless excitement, but each of them stands
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alone, independent and weak. This latter state of things is excessively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different from the former one; yet it has one point of analogy--great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions of the human mind seldom occur in it. But between these two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremes of the history of nations is an intermediate period--a period
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as glorious as it is agitated--when the conditions of men are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently settled for the mind to be lulled in torpor, when they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently unequal for men to exercise a vast power on the minds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one another, and when some few may modify the convictions of all. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at such times that great reformers start up, and new opinions suddenly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change the face of the world.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Even when the reliance of a democratic people has been won, it is still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no easy matter to gain their attention. It is extremely difficult to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtain a hearing from men living in democracies, unless it be to speak
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to them of themselves. They do not attend to the things said to them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they are always fully engrossed with the things they are doing.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: For indeed few men are idle in democratic nations; life is passed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the midst of noise and excitement, and men are so engaged in acting that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little remains to them for thinking. I would especially remark that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not only employed, but that they are passionately devoted to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: employments. They are always in action, and each of their actions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absorbs their faculties: the zeal which they display in business puts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out the enthusiasm they might otherwise entertain for idea. I think
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that it is extremely difficult to excite the enthusiasm of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people for any theory which has not a palpable, direct, and immediate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: connection with the daily occupations of life: therefore they will not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: easily forsake their old opinions; for it is enthusiasm which flings the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minds of men out of the beaten track, and effects the great revolutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the intellect as well as the great revolutions of the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world. Thus democratic nations have neither time nor taste to go in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: search of novel opinions. Even when those they possess become doubtful,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they still retain them, because it would take too much time and inquiry
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to change them--they retain them, not as certain, but as established.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are yet other and more cogent reasons which prevent any great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: change from being easily effected in the principles of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. I have already adverted to them at the commencement of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of my work. If the influence of individuals is weak and hardly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceptible amongst such a people, the power exercised by the mass upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mind of each individual is extremely great--I have already shown for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what reasons. I would now observe that it is wrong to suppose that this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: depends solely upon the form of government, and that the majority would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lose its intellectual supremacy if it were to lose its political power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In aristocracies men have often much greatness and strength of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own: when they find themselves at variance with the greater number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their fellow-countrymen, they withdraw to their own circle, where they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: support and console themselves. Such is not the case in a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country; there public favor seems as necessary as the air we breathe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to live at variance with the multitude is, as it were, not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: live. The multitude requires no laws to coerce those who think not like
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself: public disapprobation is enough; a sense of their loneliness and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impotence overtakes them and drives them to despair.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Whenever social conditions are equal, public opinion presses with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enormous weight upon the mind of each individual; it surrounds, directs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and oppresses him; and this arises from the very constitution of
