author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society, much more than from its political laws. As men grow more alike,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each man feels himself weaker in regard to all the rest; as he discerns
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing by which he is considerably raised above them, or distinguished
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from them, he mistrusts himself as soon as they assail him. Not only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does he mistrust his strength, but he even doubts of his right; and he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is very near acknowledging that he is in the wrong, when the greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of his countrymen assert that he is so. The majority do not need
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to constrain him--they convince him. In whatever way then the powers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic community may be organized and balanced, it will always be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely difficult to believe what the bulk of the people reject, or to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profess what they condemn.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This circumstance is extraordinarily favorable to the stability of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions. When an opinion has taken root amongst a democratic people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and established itself in the minds of the bulk of the community, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afterwards subsists by itself and is maintained without effort, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no one attacks it. Those who at first rejected it as false, ultimately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: receive it as the general impression; and those who still dispute it in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their hearts, conceal their dissent; they are careful not to engage in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous and useless conflict. It is true, that when the majority of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic people change their opinions, they may suddenly and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arbitrarily effect strange revolutions in men's minds; but their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions do not change without much difficulty, and it is almost as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult to show that they are changed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Time, events, or the unaided individual action of the mind, will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes undermine or destroy an opinion, without any outward sign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the change. It has not been openly assailed, no conspiracy has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formed to make war on it, but its followers one by one noiselessly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secede--day by day a few of them abandon it, until last it is only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: professed by a minority. In this state it will still continue to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevail. As its enemies remain mute, or only interchange their thoughts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by stealth, they are themselves unaware for a long period that a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution has actually been effected; and in this state of uncertainly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they take no steps--they observe each other and are silent. The majority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have ceased to believe what they believed before; but they still affect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to believe, and this empty phantom of public opinion in strong enough to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chill innovators, and to keep them silent and at respectful distance. We
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: live at a time which has witnessed the most rapid changes of opinion in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the minds of men; nevertheless it may be that the leading opinions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society will ere long be more settled than they have been for several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centuries in our history: that time is not yet come, but it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps be approaching. As I examine more closely the natural wants and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendencies of democratic nations, I grow persuaded that if ever social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality is generally and permanently established in the world, great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intellectual and political revolutions will become more difficult and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less frequent than is supposed. Because the men of democracies appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always excited, uncertain, eager, changeable in their wills and in their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: positions, it is imagined that they are suddenly to abrogate their laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to adopt new opinions, and to assume new manners. But if the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of equality predisposes men to change, it also suggests to them certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interests and tastes which cannot be satisfied without a settled order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of things; equality urges them on, but at the same time it holds them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: back; it spurs them, but fastens them to earth;--it kindles their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires, but limits their powers. This, however, is not perceived at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first; the passions which tend to sever the citizens of a democracy are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obvious enough; but the hidden force which restrains and unites them is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not discernible at a glance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amidst the ruins which surround me, shall I dare to say that revolutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are not what I most fear coming generations? If men continue to shut
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves more closely within the narrow circle of domestic interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to live upon that kind of excitement, it is to be apprehended that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they may ultimately become inaccessible to those great and powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public emotions which perturb nations--but which enlarge them and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recruit them. When property becomes so fluctuating, and the love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property so restless and so ardent, I cannot but fear that men may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrive at such a state as to regard every new theory as a peril,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every innovation as an irksome toil, every social improvement as a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stepping-stone to revolution, and so refuse to move altogether for fear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of being moved too far. I dread, and I confess it, lest they should at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: last so entirely give way to a cowardly love of present enjoyment, as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lose sight of the interests of their future selves and of those of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descendants; and to prefer to glide along the easy current of life,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather than to make, when it is necessary, a strong and sudden effort
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a higher purpose. It is believed by some that modern society will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever changing its aspect; for myself, I fear that it will ultimately be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: too invariably fixed in the same institutions, the same prejudices, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same manners, so that mankind will be stopped and circumscribed; that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mind will swing backwards and forwards forever, without begetting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fresh ideas; that man will waste his strength in bootless and solitary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trifling; and, though in continual motion, that humanity will cease to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XXII: Why Democratic Nations Are Naturally Desirous Of Peace,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And Democratic Armies Of War
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same interests, the same fears, the same passions which deter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations from revolutions, deter them also from war; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit of military glory and the spirit of revolution are weakened at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same time and by the same causes. The ever-increasing numbers of men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of property--lovers of peace, the growth of personal wealth which war
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: so rapidly consumes, the mildness of manners, the gentleness of heart,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those tendencies to pity which are engendered by the equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conditions, that coolness of understanding which renders men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparatively insensible to the violent and poetical excitement of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arms--all these causes concur to quench the military spirit. I think it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be admitted as a general and constant rule, that, amongst civilized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, the warlike passions will become more rare and less intense in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion as social conditions shall be more equal. War is nevertheless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an occurrence to which all nations are subject, democratic nations as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well as others. Whatever taste they may have for peace, they must hold
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves in readiness to repel aggression, or in other words they must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have an army.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Fortune, which has conferred so many peculiar benefits upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants of the United States, has placed them in the midst of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilderness, where they have, so to speak, no neighbors: a few thousand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soldiers are sufficient for their wants; but this is peculiar to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America, not to democracy. The equality of conditions, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners as well as the institutions resulting from it, do not exempt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic people from the necessity of standing armies, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: armies always exercise a powerful influence over their fate. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore of singular importance to inquire what are the natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities of the men of whom these armies are composed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations, especially amongst those in which birth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the only source of rank, the same inequality exists in the army as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the nation; the officer is noble, the soldier is a serf; the one is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally called upon to command, the other to obey. In aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: armies, the private soldier's ambition is therefore circumscribed within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very narrow limits. Nor has the ambition of the officer an unlimited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: range. An aristocratic body not only forms a part of the scale of ranks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the nation, but it contains a scale of ranks within itself: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of whom it is composed are placed one above another, in a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular and unvarying manner. Thus one man is born to the command of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a regiment, another to that of a company; when once they have reached
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the utmost object of their hopes, they stop of their own accord, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain contented with their lot. There is, besides, a strong cause,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which, in aristocracies, weakens the officer's desire of promotion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations, an officer, independently of his rank
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the army, also occupies an elevated rank in society; the former is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost always in his eyes only an appendage to the latter. A nobleman
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who embraces the profession of arms follows it less from motives of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition than from a sense of the duties imposed on him by his birth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He enters the army in order to find an honorable employment for the idle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years of his youth, and to be able to bring back to his home and his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peers some honorable recollections of military life; but his principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object is not to obtain by that profession either property, distinction,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or power, for he possesses these advantages in his own right, and enjoys
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them without leaving his home.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In democratic armies all the soldiers may become officers, which makes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the desire of promotion general, and immeasurably extends the bounds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of military ambition. The officer, on his part, sees nothing which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally and necessarily stops him at one grade more than at another;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and each grade has immense importance in his eyes, because his rank
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in society almost always depends on his rank in the army. Amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations it often happens that an officer has no property but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his pay, and no distinction but that of military honors: consequently as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often as his duties change, his fortune changes, and he becomes, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it were, a new man. What was only an appendage to his position in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic armies, has thus become the main point, the basis of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole condition. Under the old French monarchy officers were always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: called by their titles of nobility; they are now always called by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the title of their military rank. This little change in the forms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: language suffices to show that a great revolution has taken place in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution of society and in that of the army. In democratic armies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the desire of advancement is almost universal: it is ardent,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tenacious, perpetual; it is strengthened by all other desires, and only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extinguished with life itself. But it is easy to see, that of all armies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the world, those in which advancement must be slowest in time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of peace are the armies of democratic countries. As the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commissions is naturally limited, whilst the number of competitors is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost unlimited, and as the strict law of equality is over all alike,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: none can make rapid progress--many can make no progress at all. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desire of advancement is greater, and the opportunities of advancement
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fewer, there than elsewhere. All the ambitious spirits of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army are consequently ardently desirous of war, because war makes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vacancies, and warrants the violation of that law of seniority which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sole privilege natural to democracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We thus arrive at this singular consequence, that of all armies those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most ardently desirous of war are democratic armies, and of all nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those most fond of peace are democratic nations: and, what makes these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facts still more extraordinary, is that these contrary effects are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produced at the same time by the principle of equality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the members of the community, being alike, constantly harbor the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wish, and discover the possibility, of changing their condition and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: improving their welfare: this makes them fond of peace, which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: favorable to industry, and allows every man to pursue his own little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakings to their completion. On the other hand, this same equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: makes soldiers dream of fields of battle, by increasing the value of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military honors in the eyes of those who follow the profession of arms,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and by rendering those honors accessible to all. In either case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inquietude of the heart is the same, the taste for enjoyment as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insatiable, the ambition of success as great--the means of gratifying it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are alone different.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These opposite tendencies of the nation and the army expose democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities to great dangers. When a military spirit forsakes a people,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the profession of arms immediately ceases to be held in honor, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military men fall to the lowest rank of the public servants: they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little esteemed, and no longer understood. The reverse of what takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place in aristocratic ages then occurs; the men who enter the army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are no longer those of the highest, but of the lowest rank. Military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition is only indulged in when no other is possible. Hence arises a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circle of cause and consequence from which it is difficult to escape:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the best part of the nation shuns the military profession because that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession is not honored, and the profession is not honored because the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: best part of the nation has ceased to follow it. It is then no matter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of surprise that democratic armies are often restless, ill-tempered,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and dissatisfied with their lot, although their physical condition is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonly far better, and their discipline less strict than in other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: countries. The soldier feels that he occupies an inferior position,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and his wounded pride either stimulates his taste for hostilities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which would render his services necessary, or gives him a turn for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions, during which he may hope to win by force of arms the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political influence and personal importance now denied him. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composition of democratic armies makes this last-mentioned danger
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much to be feared. In democratic communities almost every man has some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property to preserve; but democratic armies are generally led by men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without property, most of whom have little to lose in civil broils. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bulk of the nation is naturally much more afraid of revolutions than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ages of aristocracy, but the leaders of the army much less so.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Moreover, as amongst democratic nations (to repeat what I have just
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarked) the wealthiest, the best educated, and the most able men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seldom adopt the military profession, the army, taken collectively,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eventually forms a small nation by itself, where the mind is less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlarged, and habits are more rude than in the nation at large. Now,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this small uncivilized nation has arms in its possession, and alone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knows how to use them: for, indeed, the pacific temper of the community
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases the danger to which a democratic people is exposed from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military and turbulent spirit of the army. Nothing is so dangerous as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an army amidst an unwarlike nation; the excessive love of the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community for quiet continually puts its constitution at the mercy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the soldiery. It may therefore be asserted, generally speaking, that if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations are naturally prone to peace from their interests and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their propensities, they are constantly drawn to war and revolutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their armies. Military revolutions, which are scarcely ever to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be apprehended in aristocracies, are always to be dreaded amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations. These perils must be reckoned amongst the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formidable which beset their future fate, and the attention of statesmen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should be sedulously applied to find a remedy for the evil.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a nation perceives that it is inwardly affected by the restless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ambition of its army, the first thought which occurs is to give this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inconvenient ambition an object by going to war. I speak no ill of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: war: war almost always enlarges the mind of a people, and raises their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: character. In some cases it is the only check to the excessive growth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of certain propensities which naturally spring out of the equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of conditions, and it must be considered as a necessary corrective to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain inveterate diseases to which democratic communities are liable.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: War has great advantages, but we must not flatter ourselves that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can diminish the danger I have just pointed out. That peril is only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suspended by it, to return more fiercely when the war is over; for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: armies are much more impatient of peace after having tasted military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exploits. War could only be a remedy for a people which should always be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: athirst for military glory. I foresee that all the military rulers who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may rise up in great democratic nations, will find it easier to conquer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with their armies, than to make their armies live at peace after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquest. There are two things which a democratic people will always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find very difficult--to begin a war, and to end it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Again, if war has some peculiar advantages for democratic nations, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other hand it exposes them to certain dangers which aristocracies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have no cause to dread to an equal extent. I shall only point out two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these. Although war gratifies the army, it embarrasses and often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exasperates that countless multitude of men whose minor passions every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: day require peace in order to be satisfied. Thus there is some risk
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its causing, under another form, the disturbance it is intended
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to prevent. No protracted war can fail to endanger the freedom of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic country. Not indeed that after every victory it is to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apprehended that the victorious generals will possess themselves by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: force of the supreme power, after the manner of Sylla and Caesar: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: danger is of another kind. War does not always give over democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities to military government, but it must invariably and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immeasurably increase the powers of civil government; it must almost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compulsorily concentrate the direction of all men and the management
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all things in the hands of the administration. If it lead not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotism by sudden violence, it prepares men for it more gently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by their habits. All those who seek to destroy the liberties of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nation ought to know that war is the surest and the shortest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means to accomplish it. This is the first axiom of the science.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: One remedy, which appears to be obvious when the ambition of soldiers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and officers becomes the subject of alarm, is to augment the number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of commissions to be distributed by increasing the army. This affords
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: temporary relief, but it plunges the country into deeper difficulties at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some future period. To increase the army may produce a lasting effect in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an aristocratic community, because military ambition is there confined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to one class of men, and the ambition of each individual stops, as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were, at a certain limit; so that it may be possible to satisfy all who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feel its influence. But nothing is gained by increasing the army amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic people, because the number of aspirants always rises in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exactly the same ratio as the army itself. Those whose claims have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfied by the creation of new commissions are instantly succeeded by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a fresh multitude beyond all power of satisfaction; and even those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were but now satisfied soon begin to crave more advancement; for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same excitement prevails in the ranks of the army as in the civil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: classes of democratic society, and what men want is not to reach a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain grade, but to have constant promotion. Though these wants may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not be very vast, they are perpetually recurring. Thus a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, by augmenting its army, only allays for a time the ambition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the military profession, which soon becomes even more formidable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because the number of those who feel it is increased. I am of opinion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that a restless and turbulent spirit is an evil inherent in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very constitution of democratic armies, and beyond hope of cure. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislators of democracies must not expect to devise any military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: organization capable by its influence of calming and restraining the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military profession: their efforts would exhaust their powers, before
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the object is attained.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The remedy for the vices of the army is not to be found in the army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself, but in the country. Democratic nations are naturally afraid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of disturbance and of despotism; the object is to turn these natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instincts into well-digested, deliberate, and lasting tastes. When men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have at last learned to make a peaceful and profitable use of freedom,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and have felt its blessings--when they have conceived a manly love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order, and have freely submitted themselves to discipline--these same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, if they follow the profession of arms, bring into it, unconsciously
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and almost against their will, these same habits and manners. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general spirit of the nation being infused into the spirit peculiar to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the army, tempers the opinions and desires engendered by military life,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or represses them by the mighty force of public opinion. Teach but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens to be educated, orderly, firm, and free, the soldiers will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disciplined and obedient. Any law which, in repressing the turbulent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit of the army, should tend to diminish the spirit of freedom in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, and to overshadow the notion of law and right, would defeat
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its object: it would do much more to favor, than to defeat, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: establishment of military tyranny.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: After all, and in spite of all precautions, a large army amidst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people will always be a source of great danger; the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effectual means of diminishing that danger would be to reduce the army,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but this is a remedy which all nations have it not in their power to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: use.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XXIII: Which Is The Most Warlike And Most Revolutionary Class In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic Armies?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is a part of the essence of a democratic army to be very numerous in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion to the people to which it belongs, as I shall hereafter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: show. On the other hand, men living in democratic times seldom choose a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military life. Democratic nations are therefore soon led to give up the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system of voluntary recruiting for that of compulsory enlistment. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessity of their social condition compels them to resort to the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means, and it may easily be foreseen that they will all eventually adopt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. When military service is compulsory, the burden is indiscriminately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and equally borne by the whole community. This is another necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence of the social condition of these nations, and of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions. The government may do almost whatever it pleases, provided it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appeals to the whole community at once: it is the unequal distribution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the weight, not the weight itself, which commonly occasions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resistance. But as military service is common to all the citizens, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evident consequence is that each of them remains but for a few years
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on active duty. Thus it is in the nature of things that the soldier in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies only passes through the army, whilst among most aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations the military profession is one which the soldier adopts, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is imposed upon him, for life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This has important consequences. Amongst the soldiers of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army, some acquire a taste for military life, but the majority, being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlisted against their will, and ever ready to go back to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: homes, do not consider themselves as seriously engaged in the military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession, and are always thinking of quitting it. Such men do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contract the wants, and only half partake in the passions, which that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mode of life engenders. They adapt themselves to their military duties,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but their minds are still attached to the interests and the duties which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engaged them in civil life. They do not therefore imbibe the spirit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the army--or rather, they infuse the spirit of the community at large
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the army, and retain it there. Amongst democratic nations the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private soldiers remain most like civilians: upon them the habits of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation have the firmest hold, and public opinion most influence. It is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the instrumentality of the private soldiers especially that it may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be possible to infuse into a democratic army the love of freedom and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the respect of rights, if these principles have once been successfully
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inculcated on the people at large. The reverse happens amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic nations, where the soldiery have eventually nothing in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common with their fellow-citizens, and where they live amongst them as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strangers, and often as enemies. In aristocratic armies the officers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are the conservative element, because the officers alone have retained a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strict connection with civil society, and never forego their purpose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of resuming their place in it sooner or later: in democratic armies the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private soldiers stand in this position, and from the same cause.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It often happens, on the contrary, that in these same democratic armies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the officers contract tastes and wants wholly distinct from those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nation--a fact which may be thus accounted for. Amongst democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations, the man who becomes an officer severs all the ties which bound
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him to civil life; he leaves it forever; he has no interest to resume
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. His true country is the army, since he owes all he has to the rank
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he has attained in it; he therefore follows the fortunes of the army,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rises or sinks with it, and henceforward directs all his hopes to that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quarter only. As the wants of an officer are distinct from those of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country, he may perhaps ardently desire war, or labor to bring about
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a revolution at the very moment when the nation is most desirous of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stability and peace. There are, nevertheless, some causes which allay
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this restless and warlike spirit. Though ambition is universal and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continual amongst democratic nations, we have seen that it is seldom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great. A man who, being born in the lower classes of the community, has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: risen from the ranks to be an officer, has already taken a prodigious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: step. He has gained a footing in a sphere above that which he filled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in civil life, and he has acquired rights which most democratic nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will ever consider as inalienable. *a He is willing to pause after so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great an effort, and to enjoy what he has won. The fear of risking what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he has already obtained damps the desire of acquiring what he has not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: got. Having conquered the first and greatest impediment which opposed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his advancement, he resigns himself with less impatience to the slowness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his progress. His ambition will be more and more cooled in proportion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as the increasing distinction of his rank teaches him that he has more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to put in jeopardy. If I am not mistaken, the least warlike, and also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the least revolutionary part, of a democratic army, will always be its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chief commanders. [Footnote a: The position of officers is indeed much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more secure amongst democratic nations than elsewhere; the lower the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal standing of the man, the greater is the comparative importance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his military grade, and the more just and necessary is it that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enjoyment of that rank should be secured by the laws.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the remarks I have just made on officers and soldiers are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not applicable to a numerous class which in all armies fills the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intermediate space between them--I mean the class of non-commissioned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers. This class of non-commissioned officers which have never acted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a part in history until the present century, is henceforward destined,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think, to play one of some importance. Like the officers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: non-commissioned officers have broken, in their minds, all the ties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which bound them to civil life; like the former, they devote themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanently to the service, and perhaps make it even more exclusively
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the object of all their desires: but non-commissioned officers are men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who have not yet reached a firm and lofty post at which they may pause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and breathe more freely, ere they can attain further promotion. By
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the very nature of his duties, which is invariable, a non-commissioned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officer is doomed to lead an obscure, confined, comfortless, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precarious existence; as yet he sees nothing of military life but its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers; he knows nothing but its privations and its discipline--more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficult to support than dangers: he suffers the more from his present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: miseries, from knowing that the constitution of society and of the army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allow him to rise above them; he may, indeed, at any time obtain his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commission, and enter at once upon command, honors, independence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights, and enjoyments. Not only does this object of his hopes appear to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him of immense importance, but he is never sure of reaching it till it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is actually his own; the grade he fills is by no means irrevocable; he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is always entirely abandoned to the arbitrary pleasure of his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commanding officer, for this is imperiously required by the necessity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discipline: a slight fault, a whim, may always deprive him in an instant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the fruits of many years of toil and endeavor; until he has reached
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the grade to which he aspires he has accomplished nothing; not till he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reaches that grade does his career seem to begin. A desperate ambition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot fail to be kindled in a man thus incessantly goaded on by his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: youth, his wants, his passions, the spirit of his age, his hopes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and his age, his hopes, and his fears. Non-commissioned officers are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore bent on war--on war always, and at any cost; but if war be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: denied them, then they desire revolutions to suspend the authority
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of established regulations, and to enable them, aided by the general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confusion and the political passions of the time, to get rid of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior officers and to take their places. Nor is it impossible for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them to bring about such a crisis, because their common origin and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits give them much influence over the soldiers, however different may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be their passions and their desires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It would be an error to suppose that these various characteristics of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers, non-commissioned officers, and men, belong to any particular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time or country; they will always occur at all times, and amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all democratic nations. In every democratic army the non-commissioned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers will be the worst representatives of the pacific and orderly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit of the country, and the private soldiers will be the best. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter will carry with them into military life the strength or weakness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the manners of the nation; they will display a faithful reflection of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community: if that community is ignorant and weak, they will allow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to be drawn by their leaders into disturbances, either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unconsciously or against their will; if it is enlightened and energetic,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community will itself keep them within the bounds of order.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XXIV: Causes Which Render Democratic Armies Weaker Than Other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Armies At The Outset Of A Campaign, And More Formidable In Protracted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Warfare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Any army is in danger of being conquered at the outset of a campaign,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after a long peace; any army which has long been engaged in warfare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has strong chances of victory: this truth is peculiarly applicable to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic armies. In aristocracies the military profession, being a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileged career, is held in honor even in time of peace. Men of great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: talents, great attainments, and great ambition embrace it; the army is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all respects on a level with the nation, and frequently above it. We
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have seen, on the contrary, that amongst a democratic people the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choicer minds of the nation are gradually drawn away from the military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession, to seek by other paths, distinction, power, and especially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth. After a long peace--and in democratic ages the periods of peace
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are long--the army is always inferior to the country itself. In this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state it is called into active service; and until war has altered it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there is danger for the country as well as for the army.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown that in democratic armies, and in time of peace, the rule
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of seniority is the supreme and inflexible law of advancement. This is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only a consequence, as I have before observed, of the constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these armies, but of the constitution of the people, and it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always occur. Again, as amongst these nations the officer derives his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: position in the country solely from his position in the army, and as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he draws all the distinction and the competency he enjoys from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same source, he does not retire from his profession, or is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: super-annuated, till towards the extreme close of life. The consequence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these two causes is, that when a democratic people goes to war after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a long interval of peace all the leading officers of the army are old
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men. I speak not only of the generals, but of the non-commissioned
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers, who have most of them been stationary, or have only advanced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: step by step. It may be remarked with surprise, that in a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army after a long peace all the soldiers are mere boys, and all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superior officers in declining years; so that the former are wanting in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: experience, the latter in vigor. This is a strong element of defeat,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the first condition of successful generalship is youth: I should not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have ventured to say so if the greatest captain of modern times had not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made the observation. These two causes do not act in the same manner
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon aristocratic armies: as men are promoted in them by right of birth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much more than by right of seniority, there are in all ranks a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of young men, who bring to their profession all the early vigor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of body and mind. Again, as the men who seek for military honors amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an aristocratic people, enjoy a settled position in civil society, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seldom continue in the army until old age overtakes them. After having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: devoted the most vigorous years of youth to the career of arms, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: voluntarily retire, and spend at home the remainder of their maturer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: years.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A long peace not only fills democratic armies with elderly officers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it also gives to all the officers habits both of body and mind which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: render them unfit for actual service. The man who has long lived amidst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the calm and lukewarm atmosphere of democratic manners can at first ill
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adapt himself to the harder toils and sterner duties of warfare; and if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he has not absolutely lost the taste for arms, at least he has assumed a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mode of life which unfits him for conquest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Amongst aristocratic nations, the ease of civil life exercises less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influence on the manners of the army, because amongst those nations the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy commands the army: and an aristocracy, however plunged in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: luxurious pleasures, has always many other passions besides that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its own well-being, and to satisfy those passions more thoroughly its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well-being will be readily sacrificed. *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: See Appendix V.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown that in democratic armies, in time of peace, promotion is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely slow. The officers at first support this state of things with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impatience, they grow excited, restless, exasperated, but in the end
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most of them make up their minds to it. Those who have the largest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: share of ambition and of resources quit the army; others, adapting their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tastes and their desires to their scanty fortunes, ultimately look upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the military profession in a civil point of view. The quality they value
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most in it is the competency and security which attend it: their whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notion of the future rests upon the certainty of this little provision,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and all they require is peaceably to enjoy it. Thus not only does a long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace fill an army with old men, but it is frequently imparts the views
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of old men to those who are still in the prime of life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have also shown that amongst democratic nations in time of peace the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military profession is held in little honor and indifferently followed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This want of public favor is a heavy discouragement to the army; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weighs down the minds of the troops, and when war breaks out at last,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they cannot immediately resume their spring and vigor. No similar cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of moral weakness occurs in aristocratic armies: there the officers are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never lowered either in their own eyes or in those of their countrymen,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because, independently of their military greatness, they are personally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great. But even if the influence of peace operated on the two kinds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: armies in the same manner, the results would still be different. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the officers of an aristocratic army have lost their warlike spirit and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the desire of raising themselves by service, they still retain a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respect for the honor of their class, and an old habit of being foremost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to set an example. But when the officers of a democratic army have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no longer the love of war and the ambition of arms, nothing whatever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains to them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am therefore of opinion that, when a democratic people engages in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a war after a long peace, it incurs much more risk of defeat than any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other nation; but it ought not easily to be cast down by its reverses,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the chances of success for such an army are increased by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duration of the war. When a war has at length, by its long continuance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: roused the whole community from their peaceful occupations and ruined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their minor undertakings, the same passions which made them attach so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much importance to the maintenance of peace will be turned to arms.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: War, after it has destroyed all modes of speculation, becomes itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great and sole speculation, to which all the ardent and ambitious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires which equality engenders are exclusively directed. Hence it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the selfsame democratic nations which are so reluctant to engage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in hostilities, sometimes perform prodigious achievements when once
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have taken the field. As the war attracts more and more of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention, and is seen to create high reputations and great fortunes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in a short space of time, the choicest spirits of the nation enter the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military profession: all the enterprising, proud, and martial minds, no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer of the aristocracy solely, but of the whole country, are drawn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this direction. As the number of competitors for military honors is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense, and war drives every man to his proper level, great generals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are always sure to spring up. A long war produces upon a democratic army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same effects that a revolution produces upon a people; it breaks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through regulations, and allows extraordinary men to rise above the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common level. Those officers whose bodies and minds have grown old in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace, are removed, or superannuated, or they die. In their stead a host
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of young men are pressing on, whose frames are already hardened, whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires are extended and inflamed by active service. They are bent on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advancement at all hazards, and perpetual advancement; they are followed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by others with the same passions and desires, and after these are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others yet unlimited by aught but the size of the army. The principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality opens the door of ambition to all, and death provides chances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for ambition. Death is constantly thinning the ranks, making vacancies,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: closing and opening the career of arms.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is moreover a secret connection between the military character
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the character of democracies, which war brings to light. The men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies are naturally passionately eager to acquire what they covet,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to enjoy it on easy conditions. They for the most part worship
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chance, and are much less afraid of death than of difficulty. This is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the spirit which they bring to commerce and manufactures; and this same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit, carried with them to the field of battle, induces them willingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to expose their lives in order to secure in a moment the rewards of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: victory. No kind of greatness is more pleasing to the imagination of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic people than military greatness--a greatness of vivid and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sudden lustre, obtained without toil, by nothing but the risk of life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, whilst the interests and the tastes of the members of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community divert them from war, their habits of mind fit them for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carrying on war well; they soon make good soldiers, when they are roused
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from their business and their enjoyments. If peace is peculiarly hurtful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to democratic armies, war secures to them advantages which no other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: armies ever possess; and these advantages, however little felt at first,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot fail in the end to give them the victory. An aristocratic nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which in a contest with a democratic people does not succeed in ruining
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the latter at the outset of the war, always runs a great risk of being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquered by it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XXV: Of Discipline In Democratic Armies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is a very general opinion, especially in aristocratic countries,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the great social equality which prevails in democracies ultimately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: renders the private soldier independent of the officer, and thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destroys the bond of discipline. This is a mistake, for there are two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kinds of discipline, which it is important not to confound. When the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officer is noble and the soldier a serf--one rich, the other poor--the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: former educated and strong, the latter ignorant and weak--the strictest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bond of obedience may easily be established between the two men. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soldier is broken in to military discipline, as it were, before he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enters the army; or rather, military discipline is nothing but an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enhancement of social servitude. In aristocratic armies the soldier
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will soon become insensible to everything but the orders of his superior
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers; he acts without reflection, triumphs without enthusiasm, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dies without complaint: in this state he is no longer a man, but he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still a most formidable animal trained for war.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A democratic people must despair of ever obtaining from soldiers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that blind, minute, submissive, and invariable obedience which an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic people may impose on them without difficulty. The state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society does not prepare them for it, and the nation might be in danger
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of losing its natural advantages if it sought artificially to acquire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages of this particular kind. Amongst democratic communities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military discipline ought not to attempt to annihilate the free spring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the faculties; all that can be done by discipline is to direct it;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the obedience thus inculcated is less exact, but it is more eager and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more intelligent. It has its root in the will of him who obeys: it rests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only on his instinct, but on his reason; and consequently it will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often spontaneously become more strict as danger requires it. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discipline of an aristocratic army is apt to be relaxed in war, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that discipline is founded upon habits, and war disturbs those habits.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The discipline of a democratic army on the contrary is strengthened in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sight of the enemy, because every soldier then clearly perceives that he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must be silent and obedient in order to conquer.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The nations which have performed the greatest warlike achievements knew
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no other discipline than that which I speak of. Amongst the ancients
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: none were admitted into the armies but freemen and citizens, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: differed but little from one another, and were accustomed to treat
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other as equals. In this respect it may be said that the armies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of antiquity were democratic, although they came out of the bosom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of aristocracy; the consequence was that in those armies a sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fraternal familiarity prevailed between the officers and the men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Plutarch's lives of great commanders furnish convincing instances of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fact: the soldiers were in the constant habit of freely addressing their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general, and the general listened to and answered whatever the soldiers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had to say: they were kept in order by language and by example, far
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more than by constraint or punishment; the general was as much their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: companion as their chief. I know not whether the soldiers of Greece and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Rome ever carried the minutiae of military discipline to the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: degree of perfection as the Russians have done; but this did not prevent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Alexander from conquering Asia--and Rome, the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter XXVI: Some Considerations On War In Democratic Communities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When the principle of equality is in growth, not only amongst a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, but amongst several neighboring nations at the same time, as is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: now the case in Europe, the inhabitants of these different countries,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding the dissimilarity of language, of customs, and of laws,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nevertheless resemble each other in their equal dread of war and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common love of peace. *a It is in vain that ambition or anger puts arms
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the hands of princes; they are appeased in spite of themselves by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: species of general apathy and goodwill, which makes the sword drop
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from their grasp, and wars become more rare. As the spread of equality,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taking place in several countries at once, simultaneously impels their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: various inhabitants to follow manufactures and commerce, not only do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their tastes grow alike, but their interests are so mixed and entangled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with one another that no nation can inflict evils on other nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without those evils falling back upon itself; and all nations ultimately
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regard war as a calamity, almost as severe to the conqueror as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the conquered. Thus, on the one hand, it is extremely difficult in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages to draw nations into hostilities; but on the other hand,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is almost impossible that any two of them should go to war without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: embroiling the rest. The interests of all are so interlaced, their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions and their wants so much alike, that none can remain quiet when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the others stir. Wars therefore become more rare, but when they break
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out they spread over a larger field. Neighboring democratic nations not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only become alike in some respects, but they eventually grow to resemble
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each other in almost all. *b This similitude of nations has consequences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of great importance in relation to war.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: It is scarcely necessary for me to observe that the dread
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of war displayed by the nations of Europe is not solely attributable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the progress made by the principle of equality amongst them;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independently of this permanent cause several other accidental causes of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great weight might be pointed out, and I may mention before all the rest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the extreme lassitude which the wars of the Revolution and the Empire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have left behind them.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: This is not only because these nations have the same social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition, but it arises from the very nature of that social condition
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which leads men to imitate and identify themselves with each other. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the members of a community are divided into castes and classes, they not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only differ from one another, but they have no taste and no desire to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike; on the contrary, everyone endeavors, more and more, to keep his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own opinions undisturbed, to retain his own peculiar habits, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remain himself. The characteristics of individuals are very strongly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: marked. When the state of society amongst a people is democratic--that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to say, when there are no longer any castes or classes in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, and all its members are nearly equal in education and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: property--the human mind follows the opposite direction. Men are much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike, and they are annoyed, as it were, by any deviation from that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: likeness: far from seeking to preserve their own distinguishing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: singularities, they endeavor to shake them off, in order to identify
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves with the general mass of the people, which is the sole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representative of right and of might to their eyes. The characteristics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of individuals are nearly obliterated. In the ages of aristocracy even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who are naturally alike strive to create imaginary differences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between themselves: in the ages of democracy even those who are not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike seek only to become so, and to copy each other--so strongly is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mind of every man always carried away by the general impulse of mankind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Something of the same kind may be observed between nations: two nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having the same aristocratic social condition, might remain thoroughly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: distinct and extremely different, because the spirit of aristocracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is to retain strong individual characteristics; but if two neighboring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations have the same democratic social condition, they cannot fail
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to adopt similar opinions and manners, because the spirit of democracy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tends to assimilate men to each other.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If I inquire why it is that the Helvetic Confederacy made the greatest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and most powerful nations of Europe tremble in the fifteenth century,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whilst at the present day the power of that country is exactly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportioned to its population, I perceive that the Swiss are become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like all the surrounding communities, and those surrounding communities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like the Swiss: so that as numerical strength now forms the only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difference between them, victory necessarily attends the largest army.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus one of the consequences of the democratic revolution which is going
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on in Europe is to make numerical strength preponderate on all fields
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of battle, and to constrain all small nations to incorporate themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with large States, or at least to adopt the policy of the latter. As
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numbers are the determining cause of victory, each people ought of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course to strive by all the means in its power to bring the greatest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possible number of men into the field. When it was possible to enlist a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kind of troops superior to all others, such as the Swiss infantry or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French horse of the sixteenth century, it was not thought necessary to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: raise very large armies; but the case is altered when one soldier is as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: efficient as another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same cause which begets this new want also supplies means of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: satisfying it; for, as I have already observed, when men are all alike,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are all weak, and the supreme power of the State is naturally much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stronger amongst democratic nations than elsewhere. Hence, whilst these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations are desirous of enrolling the whole male population in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ranks of the army, they have the power of effecting this object: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence is, that in democratic ages armies seem to grow larger
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in proportion as the love of war declines. In the same ages, too,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manner of carrying on war is likewise altered by the same causes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Machiavelli observes in "The Prince," "that it is much more difficult to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subdue a people which has a prince and his barons for its leaders,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than a nation which is commanded by a prince and his slaves." To avoid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offence, let us read public functionaries for slaves, and this important
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: truth will be strictly applicable to our own time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A great aristocratic people cannot either conquer its neighbors, or be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquered by them, without great difficulty. It cannot conquer them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because all its forces can never be collected and held together for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: considerable period: it cannot be conquered, because an enemy meets at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every step small centres of resistance by which invasion is arrested.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: War against an aristocracy may be compared to war in a mountainous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country; the defeated party has constant opportunities of rallying its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forces to make a stand in a new position. Exactly the reverse occurs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst democratic nations: they easily bring their whole disposable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: force into the field, and when the nation is wealthy and populous it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soon becomes victorious; but if ever it is conquered, and its territory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: invaded, it has few resources at command; and if the enemy takes the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capital, the nation is lost. This may very well be explained: as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each member of the community is individually isolated and extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerless, no one of the whole body can either defend himself or present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a rallying point to others. Nothing is strong in a democratic country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: except the State; as the military strength of the State is destroyed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the destruction of the army, and its civil power paralyzed by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: capture of the chief city, all that remains is only a multitude without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength or government, unable to resist the organized power by which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is assailed. I am aware that this danger may be lessened by the creation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of provincial liberties, and consequently of provincial powers, but this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remedy will always be insufficient. For after such a catastrophe, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only is the population unable to carry on hostilities, but it may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apprehended that they will not be inclined to attempt it. In accordance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the law of nations adopted in civilized countries, the object of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wars is not to seize the property of private individuals, but simply to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
