text: get possession of political power. The destruction of private property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is only occasionally resorted to for the purpose of attaining the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object. When an aristocratic country is invaded after the defeat of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its army, the nobles, although they are at the same time the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealthiest members of the community, will continue to defend themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: individually rather than submit; for if the conqueror remained master
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the country, he would deprive them of their political power, to which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they cling even more closely than to their property. They therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prefer fighting to subjection, which is to them the greatest of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misfortunes; and they readily carry the people along with them because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the people has long been used to follow and obey them, and besides has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but little to risk in the war. Amongst a nation in which equality of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions prevails, each citizen, on the contrary, has but slender
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: share of political power, and often has no share at all; on the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand, all are independent, and all have something to lose; so that they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are much less afraid of being conquered, and much more afraid of war,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than an aristocratic people. It will always be extremely difficult to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: decide a democratic population to take up arms, when hostilities have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reached its own territory. Hence the necessity of giving to such a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people the rights and the political character which may impart to every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen some of those interests that cause the nobles to act for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public welfare in aristocratic countries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It should never be forgotten by the princes and other leaders of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations, that nothing but the passion and the habit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom can maintain an advantageous contest with the passion and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habit of physical well-being. I can conceive nothing better prepared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for subjection, in case of defeat, than a democratic people without free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Formerly it was customary to take the field with a small body of troops,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to fight in small engagements, and to make long, regular sieges: modern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tactics consist in fighting decisive battles, and, as soon as a line
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of march is open before the army, in rushing upon the capital city, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order to terminate the war at a single blow. Napoleon, it is said, was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the inventor of this new system; but the invention of such a system did
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not depend on any individual man, whoever he might be. The mode in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Napoleon carried on war was suggested to him by the state of society in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his time; that mode was successful, because it was eminently adapted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to that state of society, and because he was the first to employ it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Napoleon was the first commander who marched at the head of an army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from capital to capital, but the road was opened for him by the ruin of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feudal society. It may fairly be believed that, if that extraordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man had been born three hundred years ago, he would not have derived the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same results from his method of warfare, or, rather, that he would have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had a different method.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall add but a few words on civil wars, for fear of exhausting the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: patience of the reader. Most of the remarks which I have made respecting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreign wars are applicable a fortiori to civil wars. Men living in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democracies are not naturally prone to the military character; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes assume it, when they have been dragged by compulsion to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: field; but to rise in a body and voluntarily to expose themselves to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: horrors of war, and especially of civil war, is a course which the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men of democracies are not apt to adopt. None but the most adventurous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community consent to run into such risks; the bulk of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: population remains motionless. But even if the population were inclined
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to act, considerable obstacles would stand in their way; for they can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resort to no old and well-established influence which they are willing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to obey--no well-known leaders to rally the discontented, as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to discipline and to lead them--no political powers subordinate to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supreme power of the nation, which afford an effectual support to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resistance directed against the government. In democratic countries the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: moral power of the majority is immense, and the physical resources
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it has at its command are out of all proportion to the physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resources which may be combined against it. Therefore the party which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occupies the seat of the majority, which speaks in its name and wields
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its power, triumphs instantaneously and irresistibly over all private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resistance; it does not even give such opposition time to exist,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but nips it in the bud. Those who in such nations seek to effect a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution by force of arms have no other resource than suddenly to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seize upon the whole engine of government as it stands, which can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: better be done by a single blow than by a war; for as soon as there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a regular war, the party which represents the State is always certain to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquer. The only case in which a civil war could arise is, if the army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should divide itself into two factions, the one raising the standard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of rebellion, the other remaining true to its allegiance. An army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitutes a small community, very closely united together, endowed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with great powers of vitality, and able to supply its own wants for some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time. Such a war might be bloody, but it could not be long; for either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rebellious army would gain over the government by the sole display
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its resources, or by its first victory, and then the war would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over; or the struggle would take place, and then that portion of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army which should not be supported by the organized powers of the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: would speedily either disband itself or be destroyed. It may therefore
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be admitted as a general truth, that in ages of equality civil wars will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become much less frequent and less protracted. *c
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: It should be borne in mind that I speak here of sovereign
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and independent democratic nations, not of confederate democracies; in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederacies, as the preponderating power always resides, in spite of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all political fictions, in the state governments, and not in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal government, civil wars are in fact nothing but foreign wars in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disguise.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Book Four: Influence Of Democratic Opinions On Political Society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter I: That Equality Naturally Gives Men A Taste For Free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Institutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I should imperfectly fulfil the purpose of this book, if, after having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shown what opinions and sentiments are suggested by the principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality, I did not point out, ere I conclude, the general influence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which these same opinions and sentiments may exercise upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government of human societies. To succeed in this object I shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently have to retrace my steps; but I trust the reader will not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: refuse to follow me through paths already known to him, which may lead
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to some new truth.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principle of equality, which makes men independent of each other,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gives them a habit and a taste for following, in their private actions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no other guide but their own will. This complete independence, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they constantly enjoy towards their equals and in the intercourse of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private life, tends to make them look upon all authority with a jealous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eye, and speedily suggests to them the notion and the love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political freedom. Men living at such times have a natural bias to free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions. Take any one of them at a venture, and search if you can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his most deep-seated instincts; you will find that of all governments he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will soonest conceive and most highly value that government, whose head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he has himself elected, and whose administration he may control. Of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the political effects produced by the equality of conditions, this love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of independence is the first to strike the observing, and to alarm the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: timid; nor can it be said that their alarm is wholly misplaced, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anarchy has a more formidable aspect in democratic countries than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere. As the citizens have no direct influence on each other, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: soon as the supreme power of the nation fails, which kept them all in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their several stations, it would seem that disorder must instantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reach its utmost pitch, and that, every man drawing aside in a different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direction, the fabric of society must at once crumble away.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am, however, persuaded that anarchy is not the principal evil which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages have to fear, but the least. For the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of equality begets two tendencies; the one leads men straight to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence, and may suddenly drive them into anarchy; the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conducts them by a longer, more secret, but more certain road, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servitude. Nations readily discern the former tendency, and are prepared
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to resist it; they are led away by the latter, without perceiving its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: drift; hence it is peculiarly important to point it out. For myself, I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am so far from urging as a reproach to the principle of equality that it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: renders men untractable, that this very circumstance principally calls
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forth my approbation. I admire to see how it deposits in the mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and heart of man the dim conception and instinctive love of political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence, thus preparing the remedy for the evil which it engenders;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is on this very account that I am attached to it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter II: That The Notions Of Democratic Nations On Government Are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Naturally Favorable To The Concentration Of Power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The notion of secondary powers, placed between the sovereign and his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjects, occurred naturally to the imagination of aristocratic nations,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because those communities contained individuals or families raised above
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the common level, and apparently destined to command by their birth,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their education, and their wealth. This same notion is naturally wanting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the minds of men in democratic ages, for converse reasons: it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can only be introduced artificially, it can only be kept there with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: difficulty; whereas they conceive, as it were, without thinking upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject, the notion of a sole and central power which governs the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community by its direct influence. Moreover in politics, as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in philosophy and in religion, the intellect of democratic nations is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiarly open to simple and general notions. Complicated systems are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repugnant to it, and its favorite conception is that of a great nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed of citizens all resembling the same pattern, and all governed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a single power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The very next notion to that of a sole and central power, which presents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself to the minds of men in the ages of equality, is the notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uniformity of legislation. As every man sees that he differs but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: little from those about him, he cannot understand why a rule which is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: applicable to one man should not be equally applicable to all others.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hence the slightest privileges are repugnant to his reason; the faintest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dissimilarities in the political institutions of the same people offend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him, and uniformity of legislation appears to him to be the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of good government. I find, on the contrary, that this same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notion of a uniform rule, equally binding on all the members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community, was almost unknown to the human mind in aristocratic ages;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it was either never entertained, or it was rejected. These contrary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendencies of opinion ultimately turn on either side to such blind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instincts and such ungovernable habits that they still direct the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions of men, in spite of particular exceptions. Notwithstanding the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense variety of conditions in the Middle Ages, a certain number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons existed at that period in precisely similar circumstances; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this did not prevent the laws then in force from assigning to each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of them distinct duties and different rights. On the contrary, at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present time all the powers of government are exerted to impose the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same customs and the same laws on populations which have as yet but few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: points of resemblance. As the conditions of men become equal amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a people, individuals seem of less importance, and society of greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dimensions; or rather, every citizen, being assimilated to all the rest,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is lost in the crowd, and nothing stands conspicuous but the great and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imposing image of the people at large. This naturally gives the men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic periods a lofty opinion of the privileges of society, and a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very humble notion of the rights of individuals; they are ready to admit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the interests of the former are everything, and those of the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing. They are willing to acknowledge that the power which represents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community has far more information and wisdom than any of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of that community; and that it is the duty, as well as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right, of that power to guide as well as govern each private citizen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If we closely scrutinize our contemporaries, and penetrate to the root
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their political opinions, we shall detect some of the notions which I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have just pointed out, and we shall perhaps be surprised to find so much
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accordance between men who are so often at variance. The Americans hold,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in every State the supreme power ought to emanate from the people;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but when once that power is constituted, they can conceive, as it were,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no limits to it, and they are ready to admit that it has the right to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do whatever it pleases. They have not the slightest notion of peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges granted to cities, families, or persons: their minds appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never to have foreseen that it might be possible not to apply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with strict uniformity the same laws to every part, and to all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inhabitants. These same opinions are more and more diffused in Europe;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they even insinuate themselves amongst those nations which most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vehemently reject the principle of the sovereignty of the people. Such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations assign a different origin to the supreme power, but they ascribe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to that power the same characteristics. Amongst them all, the idea of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: intermediate powers is weakened and obliterated: the idea of rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inherent in certain individuals is rapidly disappearing from the minds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men; the idea of the omnipotence and sole authority of society at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large rises to fill its place. These ideas take root and spread in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion as social conditions become more equal, and men more alike;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are engendered by equality, and in turn they hasten the progress of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In France, where the revolution of which I am speaking has gone further
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than in any other European country, these opinions have got complete
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hold of the public mind. If we listen attentively to the language of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: various parties in France, we shall find that there is not one which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has not adopted them. Most of these parties censure the conduct of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, but they all hold that the government ought perpetually to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: act and interfere in everything that is done. Even those which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most at variance are nevertheless agreed upon this head. The unity, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ubiquity, the omnipotence of the supreme power, and the uniformity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its rules, constitute the principal characteristics of all the political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: systems which have been put forward in our age. They recur even in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wildest visions of political regeneration: the human mind pursues them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in its dreams. If these notions spontaneously arise in the minds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private individuals, they suggest themselves still more forcibly to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the minds of princes. Whilst the ancient fabric of European society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is altered and dissolved, sovereigns acquire new conceptions of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opportunities and their duties; they learn for the first time that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central power which they represent may and ought to administer by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its own agency, and on a uniform plan, all the concerns of the whole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community. This opinion, which, I will venture to say, was never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceived before our time by the monarchs of Europe, now sinks deeply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the minds of kings, and abides there amidst all the agitation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more unsettled thoughts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Our contemporaries are therefore much less divided than is commonly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supposed; they are constantly disputing as to the hands in which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supremacy is to be vested, but they readily agree upon the duties and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rights of that supremacy. The notion they all form of government is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of a sole, simple, providential, and creative power. All secondary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinions in politics are unsettled; this one remains fixed, invariable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and consistent. It is adopted by statesmen and political philosophers;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is eagerly laid hold of by the multitude; those who govern and those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who are governed agree to pursue it with equal ardor: it is the foremost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notion of their minds, it seems inborn. It originates therefore in no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: caprice of the human intellect, but it is a necessary condition of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present state of mankind.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter III: That The Sentiments Of Democratic Nations Accord With Their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Opinions In Leading Them To Concentrate Political Power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If it be true that, in ages of equality, men readily adopt the notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a great central power, it cannot be doubted on the other hand that their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits and sentiments predispose them to recognize such a power and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: give it their support. This may be demonstrated in a few words, as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater part of the reasons, to which the fact may be attributed, have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been previously stated. *a As the men who inhabit democratic countries
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have no superiors, no inferiors, and no habitual or necessary partners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in their undertakings, they readily fall back upon themselves and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consider themselves as beings apart. I had occasion to point this out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at considerable length in treating of individualism. Hence such men can
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: never, without an effort, tear themselves from their private affairs to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engage in public business; their natural bias leads them to abandon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter to the sole visible and permanent representative of the interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community, that is to say, to the State. Not only are they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally wanting in a taste for public business, but they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently no time to attend to it. Private life is so busy in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic periods, so excited, so full of wishes and of work, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hardly any energy or leisure remains to each individual for public life.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am the last man to contend that these propensities are unconquerable,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: since my chief object in writing this book has been to combat them. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only maintain that at the present day a secret power is fostering them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the human heart, and that if they are not checked they will wholly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overgrow it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: See Appendix W.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have also had occasion to show how the increasing love of well-being,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the fluctuating character of property, cause democratic nations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to dread all violent disturbance. The love of public tranquillity is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently the only passion which these nations retain, and it becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more active and powerful amongst them in proportion as all other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions droop and die. This naturally disposes the members of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: community constantly to give or to surrender additional rights to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central power, which alone seems to be interested in defending them by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same means that it uses to defend itself. As in ages of equality no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man is compelled to lend his assistance to his fellow-men, and none
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has any right to expect much support from them, everyone is at once
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent and powerless. These two conditions, which must never be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either separately considered or confounded together, inspire the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizen of a democratic country with very contrary propensities. His
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence fills him with self-reliance and pride amongst his equals;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his debility makes him feel from time to time the want of some outward
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assistance, which he cannot expect from any of them, because they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all impotent and unsympathizing. In this predicament he naturally turns
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his eyes to that imposing power which alone rises above the level of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: universal depression. Of that power his wants and especially his desires
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continually remind him, until he ultimately views it as the sole and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary support of his own weakness. *b This may more completely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: explain what frequently takes place in democratic countries, where the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very men who are so impatient of superiors patiently submit to a master,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exhibiting at once their pride and their servility.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: In democratic communities nothing but the central power has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any stability in its position or any permanence in its undertakings. All
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the members of society are in ceaseless stir and transformation. Now it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is in the nature of all governments to seek constantly to enlarge their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere of action; hence it is almost impossible that such a government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: should not ultimately succeed, because it acts with a fixed principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and a constant will, upon men, whose position, whose notions, and whose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desires are in continual vacillation. It frequently happens that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community promote the influence of the central power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without intending it. Democratic ages are periods of experiment,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: innovation, and adventure. At such times there are always a multitude of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men engaged in difficult or novel undertakings, which they follow alone,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without caring for their fellowmen. Such persons may be ready to admit,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as a general principle, that the public authority ought not to interfere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in private concerns; but, by an exception to that rule, each of them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: craves for its assistance in the particular concern on which he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engaged, and seeks to draw upon the influence of the government for his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own benefit, though he would restrict it on all other occasions. If a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large number of men apply this particular exception to a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: variety of different purposes, the sphere of the central power extends
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insensibly in all directions, although each of them wishes it to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumscribed. Thus a democratic government increases its power simply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the fact of its permanence. Time is on its side; every incident
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: befriends it; the passions of individuals unconsciously promote it; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it may be asserted, that the older a democratic community is, the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralized will its government become.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The hatred which men bear to privilege increases in proportion as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges become more scarce and less considerable, so that democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions would seem to burn most fiercely at the very time when they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have least fuel. I have already given the reason of this phenomenon.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When all conditions are unequal, no inequality is so great as to offend
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the eye; whereas the slightest dissimilarity is odious in the midst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of general uniformity: the more complete is this uniformity, the more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insupportable does the sight of such a difference become. Hence it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural that the love of equality should constantly increase together
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with equality itself, and that it should grow by what it feeds upon.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This never-dying, ever-kindling hatred, which sets a democratic people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the smallest privileges, is peculiarly favorable to the gradual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concentration of all political rights in the hands of the representative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the State alone. The sovereign, being necessarily and incontestably
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: above all the citizens, excites not their envy, and each of them thinks
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that he strips his equals of the prerogative which he concedes to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crown. The man of a democratic age is extremely reluctant to obey his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighbor who is his equal; he refuses to acknowledge in such a person
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ability superior to his own; he mistrusts his justice, and is jealous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his power; he fears and he contemns him; and he loves continually to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remind him of the common dependence in which both of them stand to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same master. Every central power which follows its natural tendencies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courts and encourages the principle of equality; for equality singularly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facilitates, extends, and secures the influence of a central power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In like manner it may be said that every central government worships
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uniformity: uniformity relieves it from inquiry into an infinite number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of small details which must be attended to if rules were to be adapted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to men, instead of indiscriminately subjecting men to rules: thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government likes what the citizens like, and naturally hates what they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hate. These common sentiments, which, in democratic nations, constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unite the sovereign and every member of the community in one and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same conviction, establish a secret and lasting sympathy between them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The faults of the government are pardoned for the sake of its tastes;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: public confidence is only reluctantly withdrawn in the midst even of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its excesses and its errors, and it is restored at the first call.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic nations often hate those in whose hands the central power is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vested; but they always love that power itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus, by two separate paths, I have reached the same conclusion. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shown that the principle of equality suggests to men the notion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a sole, uniform, and strong government: I have now shown that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of equality imparts to them a taste for it. To governments of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this kind the nations of our age are therefore tending. They are drawn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thither by the natural inclination of mind and heart; and in order to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reach that result, it is enough that they do not check themselves in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their course. I am of opinion, that, in the democratic ages which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opening upon us, individual independence and local liberties will ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be the produce of artificial contrivance; that centralization will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the natural form of government. *c
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: See Appendix X.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter IV: Of Certain Peculiar And Accidental Causes Which Either Lead
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A People To Complete Centralization Of Government, Or Which Divert Them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If all democratic nations are instinctively led to the centralization of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, they tend to this result in an unequal manner. This depends
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the particular circumstances which may promote or prevent the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural consequences of that state of society--circumstances which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exceedingly numerous; but I shall only advert to a few of them. Amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men who have lived free long before they became equal, the tendencies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derived from free institutions combat, to a certain extent, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities superinduced by the principle of equality; and although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the central power may increase its privileges amongst such a people, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private members of such a community will never entirely forfeit their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence. But when the equality of conditions grows up amongst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people which has never known, or has long ceased to know, what freedom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is (and such is the case upon the Continent of Europe), as the former
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits of the nation are suddenly combined, by some sort of natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attraction, with the novel habits and principles engendered by the state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of society, all powers seem spontaneously to rush to the centre.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These powers accumulate there with astonishing rapidity, and the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instantly attains the utmost limits of its strength, whilst private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons allow themselves to sink as suddenly to the lowest degree of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weakness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The English who emigrated three hundred years ago to found a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonwealth on the shores of the New World, had all learned to take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a part in public affairs in their mother-country; they were conversant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with trial by jury; they were accustomed to liberty of speech and of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: press--to personal freedom, to the notion of rights and the practice
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of asserting them. They carried with them to America these free
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions and manly customs, and these institutions preserved them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the encroachments of the State. Thus amongst the Americans it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is freedom which is old--equality is of comparatively modern date. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reverse is occurring in Europe, where equality, introduced by absolute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power and under the rule of kings, was already infused into the habits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of nations long before freedom had entered into their conceptions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have said that amongst democratic nations the notion of government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: naturally presents itself to the mind under the form of a sole and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central power, and that the notion of intermediate powers is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: familiar to them. This is peculiarly applicable to the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations which have witnessed the triumph of the principle of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by means of a violent revolution. As the classes which managed local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs have been suddenly swept away by the storm, and as the confused
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mass which remains has as yet neither the organization nor the habits
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which fit it to assume the administration of these same affairs, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State alone seems capable of taking upon itself all the details of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, and centralization becomes, as it were, the unavoidable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of the country. Napoleon deserves neither praise nor censure for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having centred in his own hands almost all the administrative power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of France; for, after the abrupt disappearance of the nobility and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the higher rank of the middle classes, these powers devolved on him of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: course: it would have been almost as difficult for him to reject as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assume them. But no necessity of this kind has ever been felt by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Americans, who, having passed through no revolution, and having governed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves from the first, never had to call upon the State to act for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a time as their guardian. Thus the progress of centralization amongst a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic people depends not only on the progress of equality, but on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manner in which this equality has been established.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the commencement of a great democratic revolution, when hostilities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have but just broken out between the different classes of society, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people endeavors to centralize the public administration in the hands of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the government, in order to wrest the management of local affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the aristocracy. Towards the close of such a revolution, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contrary, it is usually the conquered aristocracy that endeavors to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make over the management of all affairs to the State, because such an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracy dreads the tyranny of a people which has become its equal,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and not unfrequently its master. Thus it is not always the same class
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community which strives to increase the prerogative of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government; but as long as the democratic revolution lasts there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always one class in the nation, powerful in numbers or in wealth, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is induced, by peculiar passions or interests, to centralize the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration, independently of that hatred of being governed by one's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: neighbor, which is a general and permanent feeling amongst democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations. It may be remarked, that at the present day the lower orders in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England are striving with all their might to destroy local independence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to transfer the administration from all points of the circumference
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the centre; whereas the higher classes are endeavoring to retain this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration within its ancient boundaries. I venture to predict that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a time will come when the very reverse will happen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These observations explain why the supreme power is always stronger, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private individuals weaker, amongst a democratic people which has passed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through a long and arduous struggle to reach a state of equality than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst a democratic community in which the citizens have been equal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the first. The example of the Americans completely demonstrates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the fact. The inhabitants of the United States were never divided by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any privileges; they have never known the mutual relation of master and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferior, and as they neither dread nor hate each other, they have never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: known the necessity of calling in the supreme power to manage their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: affairs. The lot of the Americans is singular: they have derived from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the aristocracy of England the notion of private rights and the taste
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for local freedom; and they have been able to retain both the one and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the other, because they have had no aristocracy to combat.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If at all times education enables men to defend their independence, this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is most especially true in democratic ages. When all men are alike, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is easy to found a sole and all-powerful government, by the aid of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mere instinct. But men require much intelligence, knowledge, and art to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: organize and to maintain secondary powers under similar circumstances,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to create amidst the independence and individual weakness of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: citizens such free associations as may be in a condition to struggle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against tyranny without destroying public order.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hence the concentration of power and the subjection of individuals will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase amongst democratic nations, not only in the same proportion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as their equality, but in the same proportion as their ignorance. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is true, that in ages of imperfect civilization the government is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently as wanting in the knowledge required to impose a despotism
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the people as the people are wanting in the knowledge required to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shake it off; but the effect is not the same on both sides. However rude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic people may be, the central power which rules it is never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely devoid of cultivation, because it readily draws to its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uses what little cultivation is to be found in the country, and, if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary, may seek assistance elsewhere. Hence, amongst a nation which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is ignorant as well as democratic, an amazing difference cannot fail
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speedily to arise between the intellectual capacity of the ruler and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of each of his subjects. This completes the easy concentration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of all power in his hands: the administrative function of the State is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually extended, because the State alone is competent to administer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the affairs of the country. Aristocratic nations, however unenlightened
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they may be, never afford the same spectacle, because in them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instruction is nearly equally diffused between the monarch and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leading members of the community.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The pacha who now rules in Egypt found the population of that country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed of men exceedingly ignorant and equal, and he has borrowed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: science and ability of Europe to govern that people. As the personal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attainments of the sovereign are thus combined with the ignorance and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic weakness of his subjects, the utmost centralization has been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established without impediment, and the pacha has made the country his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactory, and the inhabitants his workmen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that extreme centralization of government ultimately enervates
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society, and thus after a length of time weakens the government itself;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but I do not deny that a centralized social power may be able to execute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great undertakings with facility in a given time and on a particular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point. This is more especially true of war, in which success depends
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much more on the means of transferring all the resources of a nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to one single point, than on the extent of those resources. Hence it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chiefly in war that nations desire and frequently require to increase
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the powers of the central government. All men of military genius are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fond of centralization, which increases their strength; and all men of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralizing genius are fond of war, which compels nations to combine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all their powers in the hands of the government. Thus the democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tendency which leads men unceasingly to multiply the privileges of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State, and to circumscribe the rights of private persons, is much more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapid and constant amongst those democratic nations which are exposed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their position to great and frequent wars, than amongst all others.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have shown how the dread of disturbance and the love of well-being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insensibly lead democratic nations to increase the functions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central government, as the only power which appears to be intrinsically
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently strong, enlightened, and secure, to protect them from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: anarchy. I would now add, that all the particular circumstances
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which tend to make the state of a democratic community agitated and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precarious, enhance this general propensity, and lead private persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more and more to sacrifice their rights to their tranquility. A people
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is therefore never so disposed to increase the functions of central
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government as at the close of a long and bloody revolution, which, after
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: having wrested property from the hands of its former possessors,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has shaken all belief, and filled the nation with fierce hatreds,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conflicting interests, and contending factions. The love of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tranquillity becomes at such times an indiscriminating passion, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community are apt to conceive a most inordinate devotion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to order.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have already examined several of the incidents which may concur to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promote the centralization of power, but the principal cause still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains to be noticed. The foremost of the incidental causes which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may draw the management of all affairs into the hands of the ruler in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic countries, is the origin of that ruler himself, and his own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities. Men who live in the ages of equality are naturally fond
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of central power, and are willing to extend its privileges; but if it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happens that this same power faithfully represents their own interests,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and exactly copies their own inclinations, the confidence they place in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it knows no bounds, and they think that whatever they bestow upon it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bestowed upon themselves.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The attraction of administrative powers to the centre will always be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less easy and less rapid under the reign of kings who are still in some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: way connected with the old aristocratic order, than under new princes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the children of their own achievements, whose birth, prejudices,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities, and habits appear to bind them indissolubly to the cause
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of equality. I do not mean that princes of aristocratic origin who live
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democratic ages do not attempt to centralize; I believe they apply
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to that object as diligently as any others. For them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sole advantages of equality lie in that direction; but their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opportunities are less great, because the community, instead of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: volunteering compliance with their desires, frequently obeys them with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reluctance. In democratic communities the rule is that centralization
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must increase in proportion as the sovereign is less aristocratic. When
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an ancient race of kings stands at the head of an aristocracy, as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: natural prejudices of the sovereign perfectly accord with the natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prejudices of the nobility, the vices inherent in aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities have a free course, and meet with no corrective. The reverse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the case when the scion of a feudal stock is placed at the head of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic people. The sovereign is constantly led, by his education,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his habits, and his associations, to adopt sentiments suggested by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inequality of conditions, and the people tend as constantly, by their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: social condition, to those manners which are engendered by equality.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At such times it often happens that the citizens seek to control the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central power far less as a tyrannical than as an aristocratical power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that they persist in the firm defence of their independence, not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only because they would remain free, but especially because they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: determined to remain equal. A revolution which overthrows an ancient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regal family, in order to place men of more recent growth at the head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a democratic people, may temporarily weaken the central power; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: however anarchical such a revolution may appear at first, we need not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hesitate to predict that its final and certain consequence will be to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extend and to secure the prerogatives of that power. The foremost or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indeed the sole condition which is required in order to succeed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralizing the supreme power in a democratic community, is to love
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality, or to get men to believe you love it. Thus the science of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: despotism, which was once so complex, is simplified, and reduced as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were to a single principle.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter V: That Amongst The European Nations Of Our Time The Power Of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Governments Is Increasing, Although The Persons Who Govern Are Less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Stable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On reflecting upon what has already been said, the reader will be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: startled and alarmed to find that in Europe everything seems to conduce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the indefinite extension of the prerogatives of government, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: render all that enjoyed the rights of private independence more weak,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more subordinate, and more precarious. The democratic nations of Europe
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have all the general and permanent tendencies which urge the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the centralization of government, and they are moreover exposed to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of secondary and incidental causes with which the Americans are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unacquainted. It would seem as if every step they make towards equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brings them nearer to despotism. And indeed if we do but cast our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: looks around, we shall be convinced that such is the fact. During the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic ages which preceded the present time, the sovereigns of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe had been deprived of, or had relinquished, many of the rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inherent in their power. Not a hundred years ago, amongst the greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of European nations, numerous private persons and corporations were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently independent to administer justice, to raise and maintain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: troops, to levy taxes, and frequently even to make or interpret the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law. The State has everywhere resumed to itself alone these natural
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attributes of sovereign power; in all matters of government the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tolerates no intermediate agent between itself and the people, and in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general business it directs the people by its own immediate influence. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am far from blaming this concentration of power, I simply point it out.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the same period a great number of secondary powers existed in Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which represented local interests and administered local affairs. Most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of these local authorities have already disappeared; all are speedily
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tending to disappear, or to fall into the most complete dependence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From one end of Europe to the other the privileges of the nobility, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties of cities, and the powers of provincial bodies, are either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: destroyed or upon the verge of destruction. Europe has endured, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the course of the last half-century, many revolutions and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: counter-revolutions which have agitated it in opposite directions: but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all these perturbations resemble each other in one respect--they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all shaken or destroyed the secondary powers of government. The local
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privileges which the French did not abolish in the countries they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquered, have finally succumbed to the policy of the princes who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conquered the French. Those princes rejected all the innovations of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: French Revolution except centralization: that is the only principle they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consented to receive from such a source. My object is to remark, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all these various rights, which have been successively wrested, in our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time, from classes, corporations, and individuals, have not served
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to raise new secondary powers on a more democratic basis, but have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uniformly been concentrated in the hands of the sovereign. Everywhere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State acquires more and more direct control over the humblest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: members of the community, and a more exclusive power of governing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each of them in his smallest concerns. *a Almost all the charitable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: establishments of Europe were formerly in the hands of private persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or of corporations; they are now almost all dependent on the supreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government, and in many countries are actually administered by that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. The State almost exclusively undertakes to supply bread to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hungry, assistance and shelter to the sick, work to the idle, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: act as the sole reliever of all kinds of misery. Education, as well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as charity, is become in most countries at the present day a national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concern. The State receives, and often takes, the child from the arms of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mother, to hand it over to official agents: the State undertakes to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: train the heart and to instruct the mind of each generation. Uniformity
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevails in the courses of public instruction as in everything else;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diversity, as well as freedom, is disappearing day by day. Nor do I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hesitate to affirm, that amongst almost all the Christian nations of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: days, Catholic as well as Protestant, religion is in danger of falling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into the hands of the government. Not that rulers are over-jealous of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the right of settling points of doctrine, but they get more and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hold upon the will of those by whom doctrines are expounded; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deprive the clergy of their property, and pay them by salaries; they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divert to their own use the influence of the priesthood, they make them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their own ministers--often their own servants--and by this alliance with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion they reach the inner depths of the soul of man. *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: This gradual weakening of individuals in relation to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society at large may be traced in a thousand ways. I shall select
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from amongst these examples one derived from the law of wills. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies it is common to profess the greatest reverence for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: last testamentary dispositions of a man; this feeling sometimes even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: became superstitious amongst the older nations of Europe: the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State, far from interfering with the caprices of a dying man, gave
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: full force to the very least of them, and insured to him a perpetual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power. When all living men are enfeebled, the will of the dead is less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respected: it is circumscribed within a narrow range, beyond which it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is annulled or checked by the supreme power of the laws. In the Middle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Ages, testamentary power had, so to speak, no limits: amongst the French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the present day, a man cannot distribute his fortune amongst his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: children without the interference of the State; after having domineered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: over a whole life, the law insists upon regulating the very last act of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: In proportion as the duties of the central power are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: augmented, the number of public officers by whom that power is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: represented must increase also. They form a nation in each nation; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as they share the stability of the government, they more and more fill
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: up the place of an aristocracy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In almost every part of Europe the government rules in two ways; it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rules one portion of the community by the fear which they entertain of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its agents, and the other by the hope they have of becoming its agents.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But this is as yet only one side of the picture. The authority of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government has not only spread, as we have just seen, throughout the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sphere of all existing powers, till that sphere can no longer contain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it, but it goes further, and invades the domain heretofore reserved
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to private independence. A multitude of actions, which were formerly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely beyond the control of the public administration, have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subjected to that control in our time, and the number of them is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly increasing. Amongst aristocratic nations the supreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government usually contented itself with managing and superintending
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the community in whatever directly and ostensibly concerned the national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor; but in all other respects the people were left to work out their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own free will. Amongst these nations the government often seemed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forget that there is a point at which the faults and the sufferings of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private persons involve the general prosperity, and that to prevent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ruin of a private individual must sometimes be a matter of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance. The democratic nations of our time lean to the opposite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extreme. It is evident that most of our rulers will not content
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves with governing the people collectively: it would seem as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: if they thought themselves responsible for the actions and private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of their subjects--as if they had undertaken to guide and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instruct each of them in the various incidents of life, and to secure
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their happiness quite independently of their own consent. On the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand private individuals grow more and more apt to look upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supreme power in the same light; they invoke its assistance in all their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessities, and they fix their eyes upon the administration as their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mentor or their guide.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I assert that there is no country in Europe in which the public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration has not become, not only more centralized, but more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inquisitive and more minute it everywhere interferes in private concerns
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more than it did; it regulates more undertakings, and undertakings of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lesser kind; and it gains a firmer footing every day about, above, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: around all private persons, to assist, to advise, and to coerce them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Formerly a sovereign lived upon the income of his lands, or the revenue
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his taxes; this is no longer the case now that his wants have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increased as well as his power. Under the same circumstances which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formerly compelled a prince to put on a new tax, he now has recourse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to a loan. Thus the State gradually becomes the debtor of most of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealthier members of the community, and centralizes the largest amounts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of capital in its own hands. Small capital is drawn into its keeping
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by another method. As men are intermingled and conditions become more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal, the poor have more resources, more education, and more desires;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they conceive the notion of bettering their condition, and this teaches
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them to save. These savings are daily producing an infinite number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small capitals, the slow and gradual produce of labor, which are always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increasing. But the greater part of this money would be unproductive if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it remained scattered in the hands of its owners. This circumstance has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: given rise to a philanthropic institution, which will soon become, if I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: am not mistaken, one of our most important political institutions. Some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: charitable persons conceived the notion of collecting the savings of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the poor and placing them out at interest. In some countries these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: benevolent associations are still completely distinct from the State;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but in almost all they manifestly tend to identify themselves with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government; and in some of them the government has superseded them,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: taking upon itself the enormous task of centralizing in one place, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: putting out at interest on its own responsibility, the daily savings of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: many millions of the working classes. Thus the State draws to itself the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth of the rich by loans, and has the poor man's mite at its disposal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the savings banks. The wealth of the country is perpetually flowing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: around the government and passing through its hands; the accumulation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases in the same proportion as the equality of conditions; for in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a democratic country the State alone inspires private individuals with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confidence, because the State alone appears to be endowed with strength
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and durability. *c Thus the sovereign does not confine himself to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the management of the public treasury; he interferes in private money
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: matters; he is the superior, and often the master, of all the members
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community; and, in addition to this, he assumes the part of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: steward and paymaster.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: On the one hand the taste for worldly welfare is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually increasing, and on the other the government gets more and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more complete possession of the sources of that welfare. Thus men are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: following two separate roads to servitude: the taste for their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: welfare withholds them from taking a part in the government, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: love of that welfare places them in closer dependence upon those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: govern.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The central power not only fulfils of itself the whole of the duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formerly discharged by various authorities--extending those duties, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surpassing those authorities--but it performs them with more alertness,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength, and independence than it displayed before. All the governments
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Europe have in our time singularly improved the science of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration: they do more things, and they do everything with more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order, more celerity, and at less expense; they seem to be constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enriched by all the experience of which they have stripped private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons. From day to day the princes of Europe hold their subordinate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: officers under stricter control, and they invent new methods for guiding
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them more closely, and inspecting them with less trouble. Not content
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with managing everything by their agents, they undertake to manage the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conduct of their agents in everything; so that the public administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not only depends upon one and the same power, but it is more and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
