text: confined to one spot and concentrated in the same hands. The government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralizes its agency whilst it increases its prerogative--hence a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: twofold increase of strength.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In examining the ancient constitution of the judicial power, amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most European nations, two things strike the mind--the independence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that power, and the extent of its functions. Not only did the courts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: justice decide almost all differences between private persons, but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very many cases they acted as arbiters between private persons and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State. I do not here allude to the political and administrative offices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which courts of judicature had in some countries usurped, but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: judicial office common to them all. In most of the countries of Europe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there were, and there still are, many private rights, connected for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most part with the general right of property, which stood under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the protection of the courts of justice, and which the State could not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violate without their sanction. It was this semi-political power which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mainly distinguished the European courts of judicature from all others;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for all nations have had judges, but all have not invested their judges
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the same privileges. Upon examining what is now occurring amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the democratic nations of Europe which are called free, as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst the others, it will be observed that new and more dependent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: courts are everywhere springing up by the side of the old ones, for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the express purpose of deciding, by an extraordinary jurisdiction,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such litigated matters as may arise between the government and private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons. The elder judicial power retains its independence, but its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction is narrowed; and there is a growing tendency to reduce it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to be exclusively the arbiter between private interests. The number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these special courts of justice is continually increasing, and their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: functions increase likewise. Thus the government is more and more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: absolved from the necessity of subjecting its policy and its rights to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sanction of another power. As judges cannot be dispensed with, at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: least the State is to select them, and always to hold them under its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: control; so that, between the government and private individuals, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place the effigy of justice rather than justice itself. The State is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not satisfied with drawing all concerns to itself, but it acquires an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever-increasing power of deciding on them all without restriction and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without appeal. *d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: A strange sophism has been made on this head in France.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When a suit arises between the government and a private person, it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not to be tried before an ordinary judge--in order, they say, not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mix the administrative and the judicial powers; as if it were not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mix those powers, and to mix them in the most dangerous and oppressive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner, to invest the government with the office of judging and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administering at the same time.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There exists amongst the modern nations of Europe one great cause,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent of all those which have already been pointed out, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually contributes to extend the agency or to strengthen the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prerogative of the supreme power, though it has not been sufficiently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attended to: I mean the growth of manufactures, which is fostered by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: progress of social equality. Manufactures generally collect a multitude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of men of the same spot, amongst whom new and complex relations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spring up. These men are exposed by their calling to great and sudden
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alternations of plenty and want, during which public tranquillity is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endangered. It may also happen that these employments sacrifice the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: health, and even the life, of those who gain by them, or of those who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: live by them. Thus the manufacturing classes require more regulation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superintendence, and restraint than the other classes of society, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is natural that the powers of government should increase in the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proportion as those classes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This is a truth of general application; what follows more especially
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concerns the nations of Europe. In the centuries which preceded that in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which we live, the aristocracy was in possession of the soil, and was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: competent to defend it: landed property was therefore surrounded by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ample securities, and its possessors enjoyed great independence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This gave rise to laws and customs which have been perpetuated,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding the subdivision of lands and the ruin of the nobility;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and, at the present time, landowners and agriculturists are still those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst the community who must easily escape from the control of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supreme power. In these same aristocratic ages, in which all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sources of our history are to be traced, personal property was of small
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance, and those who possessed it were despised and weak:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manufacturing class formed an exception in the midst of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic communities; as it had no certain patronage, it was not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: outwardly protected, and was often unable to protect itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Hence a habit sprung up of considering manufacturing property as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: something of a peculiar nature, not entitled to the same deference,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and not worthy of the same securities as property in general; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturers were looked upon as a small class in the bulk of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, whose independence was of small importance, and who might with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propriety be abandoned to the disciplinary passions of princes. On
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glancing over the codes of the middle ages, one is surprised to see,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in those periods of personal independence, with what incessant royal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulations manufactures were hampered, even in their smallest details:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on this point centralization was as active and as minute as it can ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be. Since that time a great revolution has taken place in the world;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturing property, which was then only in the germ, has spread
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: till it covers Europe: the manufacturing class has been multiplied and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enriched by the remnants of all other ranks; it has grown and is still
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually growing in number, in importance, in wealth. Almost all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those who do not belong to it are connected with it at least on some one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: point; after having been an exception in society, it threatens to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: become the chief, if not the only, class; nevertheless the notions and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political precedents engendered by it of old still cling about it. These
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions and these precedents remain unchanged, because they are old,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and also because they happen to be in perfect accordance with the new
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notions and general habits of our contemporaries. Manufacturing property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then does not extend its rights in the same ratio as its importance. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturing classes do not become less dependent, whilst they become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more numerous; but, on the contrary, it would seem as if despotism
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lurked within them, and naturally grew with their growth. *e As a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation becomes more engaged in manufactures, the want of roads, canals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: harbors, and other works of a semi-public nature, which facilitate the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acquisition of wealth, is more strongly felt; and as a nation becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more democratic, private individuals are less able, and the State more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: able, to execute works of such magnitude. I do not hesitate to assert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the manifest tendency of all governments at the present time is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take upon themselves alone the execution of these undertakings; by which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: means they daily hold in closer dependence the population which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: govern.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote e: I shall quote a few facts in corroboration of this remark.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mines are the natural sources of manufacturing wealth: as manufactures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have grown up in Europe, as the produce of mines has become of more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: general importance, and good mining more difficult from the subdivision
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of property which is a consequence of the equality of conditions, most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments have asserted a right of owning the soil in which the mines
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lie, and of inspecting the works; which has never been the case with any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other kind of property. Thus mines, which were private property, liable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the same obligations and sheltered by the same guarantees as all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other landed property, have fallen under the control of the State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The State either works them or farms them; the owners of them are mere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tenants, deriving their rights from the State; and, moreover, the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost everywhere claims the power of directing their operations: it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lays down rules, enforces the adoption of particular methods, subjects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the mining adventurers to constant superintendence, and, if refractory,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are ousted by a government court of justice, and the government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transfers their contract to other hands; so that the government not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only possesses the mines, but has all the adventurers in its power.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, as manufactures increase, the working of old mines
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increases also; new ones are opened, the mining population extends and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grows up; day by day governments augment their subterranean dominions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and people them with their agents.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On the other hand, in proportion as the power of a State increases, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its necessities are augmented, the State consumption of manufactured
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: produce is always growing larger, and these commodities are generally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made in the arsenals or establishments of the government. Thus, in every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kingdom, the ruler becomes the principal manufacturer; he collects
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and retains in his service a vast number of engineers, architects,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mechanics, and handicraftsmen. Not only is he the principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufacturer, but he tends more and more to become the chief, or rather
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the master of all other manufacturers. As private persons become
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more powerless by becoming more equal, they can effect nothing in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures without combination; but the government naturally seeks to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place these combinations under its own control.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must be admitted that these collective beings, which are called
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combinations, are stronger and more formidable than a private individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can ever be, and that they have less of the responsibility of their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: actions; whence it seems reasonable that they should not be allowed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retain so great an independence of the supreme government as might be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceded to a private individual.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Rulers are the more apt to follow this line of policy, as their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclinations invite them to it. Amongst democratic nations it is only by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: association that the resistance of the people to the government can ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: display itself: hence the latter always looks with ill-favor on those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations which are not in its own power; and it is well worthy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remark, that amongst democratic nations, the people themselves often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entertain a secret feeling of fear and jealousy against these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: very associations, which prevents the citizens from defending the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: institutions of which they stand so much in need. The power and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duration of these small private bodies, in the midst of the weakness and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instability of the whole community, astonish and alarm the people;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the free use which each association makes of its natural powers is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost regarded as a dangerous privilege. All the associations which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spring up in our age are, moreover, new corporate powers, whose rights
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have not been sanctioned by time; they come into existence at a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time when the notion of private rights is weak, and when the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government is unbounded; hence it is not surprising that they lose their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom at their birth. Amongst all European nations there are some
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kinds of associations which cannot be formed until the State has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examined their by-laws, and authorized their existence. In several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others, attempts are made to extend this rule to all associations; the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences of such a policy, if it were successful, may easily be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: foreseen. If once the sovereign had a general right of authorizing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: associations of all kinds upon certain conditions, he would not be long
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without claiming the right of superintending and managing them, in order
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to prevent them from departing from the rules laid down by himself. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this manner, the State, after having reduced all who are desirous of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: forming associations into dependence, would proceed to reduce into the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same condition all who belong to associations already formed--that is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to say, almost all the men who are now in existence. Governments thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: appropriate to themselves, and convert to their own purposes, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater part of this new power which manufacturing interests have in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our time brought into the world. Manufacturers govern us--they govern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manufactures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I attach so much importance to all that I have just been saying, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I am tormented by the fear of having impaired my meaning in seeking
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to render it more clear. If the reader thinks that the examples I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adduced to support my observations are insufficient or ill-chosen--if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he imagines that I have anywhere exaggerated the encroachments of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supreme power, and, on the other hand, that I have underrated the extent
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the sphere which still remains open to the exertions of individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence, I entreat him to lay down the book for a moment, and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: turn his mind to reflect for himself upon the subjects I have attempted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to explain. Let him attentively examine what is taking place in France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and in other countries--let him inquire of those about him--let him
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: search himself, and I am much mistaken if he does not arrive, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my guidance, and by other paths, at the point to which I have sought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to lead him. He will perceive that for the last half-century,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centralization has everywhere been growing up in a thousand different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ways. Wars, revolutions, conquests, have served to promote it: all men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have labored to increase it. In the course of the same period, during
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which men have succeeded each other with singular rapidity at the head
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of affairs, their notions, interests, and passions have been infinitely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: diversified; but all have by some means or other sought to centralize.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This instinctive centralization has been the only settled point amidst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the extreme mutability of their lives and of their thoughts.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the reader, after having investigated these details of human affairs,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will seek to survey the wide prospect as a whole, he will be struck
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the result. On the one hand the most settled dynasties shaken or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overthrown--the people everywhere escaping by violence from the sway
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their laws--abolishing or limiting the authority of their rulers or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their princes--the nations, which are not in open revolution, restless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at least, and excited--all of them animated by the same spirit of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolt: and on the other hand, at this very period of anarchy, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst these untractable nations, the incessant increase of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prerogative of the supreme government, becoming more centralized, more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adventurous, more absolute, more extensive--the people perpetually
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: falling under the control of the public administration--led
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insensibly to surrender to it some further portion of their individual
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence, till the very men, who from time to time upset a throne
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and trample on a race of kings, bend more and more obsequiously to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: slightest dictate of a clerk. Thus two contrary revolutions appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in our days to be going on; the one continually weakening the supreme
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power, the other as continually strengthening it: at no other period
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in our history has it appeared so weak or so strong. But upon a more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attentive examination of the state of the world, it appears that these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two revolutions are intimately connected together, that they originate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the same source, and that after having followed a separate course,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they lead men at last to the same result. I may venture once more to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: repeat what I have already said or implied in several parts of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: book: great care must be taken not to confound the principle of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself with the revolution which finally establishes that principle in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the social condition and the laws of a nation: here lies the reason of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all the phenomena which occasion our astonishment. All the old
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political powers of Europe, the greatest as well as the least, were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: founded in ages of aristocracy, and they more or less represented or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defended the principles of inequality and of privilege. To make the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: novel wants and interests, which the growing principle of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced, preponderate in government, our contemporaries had to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: overturn or to coerce the established powers. This led them to make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions, and breathed into many of them, that fierce love of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disturbance and independence, which all revolutions, whatever be their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: object, always engender. I do not believe that there is a single country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in Europe in which the progress of equality has not been preceded or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: followed by some violent changes in the state of property and persons;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and almost all these changes have been attended with much anarchy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: license, because they have been made by the least civilized portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nation against that which is most civilized. Hence proceeded the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: two-fold contrary tendencies which I have just pointed out. As long as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the democratic revolution was glowing with heat, the men who were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bent upon the destruction of old aristocratic powers hostile to that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolution, displayed a strong spirit of independence; but as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: victory or the principle of equality became more complete, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually surrendered themselves to the propensities natural to that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of equality, and they strengthened and centralized their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments. They had sought to be free in order to make themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal; but in proportion as equality was more established by the aid
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of freedom, freedom itself was thereby rendered of more difficult
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attainment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These two states of a nation have sometimes been contemporaneous:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the last generation in France showed how a people might organize a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stupendous tyranny in the community, at the very time when they were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: baffling the authority of the nobility and braving the power of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kings--at once teaching the world the way to win freedom, and the way to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lose it. In our days men see that constituted powers are dilapidated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on every side--they see all ancient authority gasping away, all ancient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barriers tottering to their fall, and the judgment of the wisest is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: troubled at the sight: they attend only to the amazing revolution which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is taking place before their eyes, and they imagine that mankind is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: about to fall into perpetual anarchy: if they looked to the final
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences of this revolution, their fears would perhaps assume a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different shape. For myself, I confess that I put no trust in the spirit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of freedom which appears to animate my contemporaries. I see well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enough that the nations of this age are turbulent, but I do not clearly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perceive that they are liberal; and I fear lest, at the close of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those perturbations which rock the base of thrones, the domination of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereigns may prove more powerful than it ever was before.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VI: What Sort Of Despotism Democratic Nations Have To Fear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I had remarked during my stay in the United States, that a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of society, similar to that of the Americans, might offer singular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: facilities for the establishment of despotism; and I perceived, upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my return to Europe, how much use had already been made by most of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rulers, of the notions, the sentiments, and the wants engendered by this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: same social condition, for the purpose of extending the circle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their power. This led me to think that the nations of Christendom would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perhaps eventually undergo some sort of oppression like that which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hung over several of the nations of the ancient world. A more accurate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examination of the subject, and five years of further meditations, have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not diminished my apprehensions, but they have changed the object of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. No sovereign ever lived in former ages so absolute or so powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as to undertake to administer by his own agency, and without the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assistance of intermediate powers, all the parts of a great empire: none
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ever attempted to subject all his subjects indiscriminately to strict
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uniformity of regulation, and personally to tutor and direct every
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: member of the community. The notion of such an undertaking never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occurred to the human mind; and if any man had conceived it, the want
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of information, the imperfection of the administrative system, and above
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all, the natural obstacles caused by the inequality of conditions, would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: speedily have checked the execution of so vast a design. When the Roman
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: emperors were at the height of their power, the different nations of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: empire still preserved manners and customs of great diversity; although
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they were subject to the same monarch, most of the provinces were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: separately administered; they abounded in powerful and active
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: municipalities; and although the whole government of the empire was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centred in the hands of the emperor alone, and he always remained, upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: occasions, the supreme arbiter in all matters, yet the details of social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life and private occupations lay for the most part beyond his control.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The emperors possessed, it is true, an immense and unchecked power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which allowed them to gratify all their whimsical tastes, and to employ
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for that purpose the whole strength of the State. They frequently abused
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that power arbitrarily to deprive their subjects of property or of life:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their tyranny was extremely onerous to the few, but it did not reach the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greater number; it was fixed to some few main objects, and neglected the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rest; it was violent, but its range was limited.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But it would seem that if despotism were to be established amongst the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations of our days, it might assume a different character;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it would be more extensive and more mild; it would degrade men without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tormenting them. I do not question, that in an age of instruction
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and equality like our own, sovereigns might more easily succeed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: collecting all political power into their own hands, and might interfere
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more habitually and decidedly within the circle of private interests,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than any sovereign of antiquity could ever do. But this same principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of equality which facilitates despotism, tempers its rigor. We have seen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: how the manners of society become more humane and gentle in proportion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as men become more equal and alike. When no member of the community has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much power or much wealth, tyranny is, as it were, without opportunities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and a field of action. As all fortunes are scanty, the passions of men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are naturally circumscribed--their imagination limited, their pleasures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: simple. This universal moderation moderates the sovereign himself, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: checks within certain limits the inordinate extent of his desires.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Independently of these reasons drawn from the nature of the state of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society itself, I might add many others arising from causes beyond my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject; but I shall keep within the limits I have laid down to myself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Democratic governments may become violent and even cruel at certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: periods of extreme effervescence or of great danger: but these crises
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be rare and brief. When I consider the petty passions of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries, the mildness of their manners, the extent of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: education, the purity of their religion, the gentleness of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: morality, their regular and industrious habits, and the restraint which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they almost all observe in their vices no less than in their virtues,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have no fear that they will meet with tyrants in their rulers, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rather guardians. *a I think then that the species of oppression by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which democratic nations are menaced is unlike anything which ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: before existed in the world: our contemporaries will find no prototype
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of it in their memories. I am trying myself to choose an expression
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which will accurately convey the whole of the idea I have formed of it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but in vain; the old words "despotism" and "tyranny" are inappropriate:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the thing itself is new; and since I cannot name it, I must attempt to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: define it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: See Appendix Y.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I seek to trace the novel features under which despotism may appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the world. The first thing that strikes the observation is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an innumerable multitude of men all equal and alike, incessantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endeavoring to procure the petty and paltry pleasures with which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: glut their lives. Each of them, living apart, is as a stranger to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fate of all the rest--his children and his private friends constitute to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him the whole of mankind; as for the rest of his fellow-citizens, he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: close to them, but he sees them not--he touches them, but he feels them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not; he exists but in himself and for himself alone; and if his kindred
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still remain to him, he may be said at any rate to have lost his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country. Above this race of men stands an immense and tutelary power,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which takes upon itself alone to secure their gratifications, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to watch over their fate. That power is absolute, minute, regular,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: provident, and mild. It would be like the authority of a parent, if,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like that authority, its object was to prepare men for manhood; but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seeks on the contrary to keep them in perpetual childhood: it is well
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: content that the people should rejoice, provided they think of nothing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but rejoicing. For their happiness such a government willingly labors,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it chooses to be the sole agent and the only arbiter of that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: happiness: it provides for their security, foresees and supplies their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessities, facilitates their pleasures, manages their principal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concerns, directs their industry, regulates the descent of property, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subdivides their inheritances--what remains, but to spare them all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the care of thinking and all the trouble of living? Thus it every day
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: renders the exercise of the free agency of man less useful and less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequent; it circumscribes the will within a narrower range, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gradually robs a man of all the uses of himself. The principle of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality has prepared men for these things: it has predisposed men to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: endure them, and oftentimes to look on them as benefits.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: After having thus successively taken each member of the community in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its powerful grasp, and fashioned them at will, the supreme power then
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extends its arm over the whole community. It covers the surface of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society with a net-work of small complicated rules, minute and uniform,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: through which the most original minds and the most energetic characters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot penetrate, to rise above the crowd. The will of man is not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shattered, but softened, bent, and guided: men are seldom forced by it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to act, but they are constantly restrained from acting: such a power
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does not destroy, but it prevents existence; it does not tyrannize, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it compresses, enervates, extinguishes, and stupefies a people, till
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each nation is reduced to be nothing better than a flock of timid and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: industrious animals, of which the government is the shepherd. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always thought that servitude of the regular, quiet, and gentle kind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have just described, might be combined more easily than is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonly believed with some of the outward forms of freedom; and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it might even establish itself under the wing of the sovereignty of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. Our contemporaries are constantly excited by two conflicting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: passions; they want to be led, and they wish to remain free: as they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot destroy either one or the other of these contrary propensities,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they strive to satisfy them both at once. They devise a sole, tutelary,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and all-powerful form of government, but elected by the people. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combine the principle of centralization and that of popular sovereignty;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this gives them a respite; they console themselves for being in tutelage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the reflection that they have chosen their own guardians. Every man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: allows himself to be put in leading-strings, because he sees that it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not a person or a class of persons, but the people at large that holds
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the end of his chain. By this system the people shake off their state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of dependence just long enough to select their master, and then relapse
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into it again. A great many persons at the present day are quite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contented with this sort of compromise between administrative despotism
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the sovereignty of the people; and they think they have done enough
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the protection of individual freedom when they have surrendered
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it to the power of the nation at large. This does not satisfy me:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nature of him I am to obey signifies less to me than the fact of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extorted obedience.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not however deny that a constitution of this kind appears to me to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be infinitely preferable to one, which, after having concentrated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the powers of government, should vest them in the hands of an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irresponsible person or body of persons. Of all the forms which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic despotism could assume, the latter would assuredly be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the worst. When the sovereign is elective, or narrowly watched by a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislature which is really elective and independent, the oppression
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which he exercises over individuals is sometimes greater, but it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: always less degrading; because every man, when he is oppressed and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disarmed, may still imagine, that whilst he yields obedience it is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: himself he yields it, and that it is to one of his own inclinations that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the rest give way. In like manner I can understand that when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign represents the nation, and is dependent upon the people, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights and the power of which every citizen is deprived, not only serve
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the head of the State, but the State itself; and that private persons
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: derive some return from the sacrifice of their independence which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have made to the public. To create a representation of the people in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every centralized country, is therefore, to diminish the evil which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extreme centralization may produce, but not to get rid of it. I admit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that by this means room is left for the intervention of individuals in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the more important affairs; but it is not the less suppressed in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: smaller and more private ones. It must not be forgotten that it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially dangerous to enslave men in the minor details of life. For my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own part, I should be inclined to think freedom less necessary in great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: things than in little ones, if it were possible to be secure of the one
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without possessing the other. Subjection in minor affairs breaks out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: every day, and is felt by the whole community indiscriminately. It does
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not drive men to resistance, but it crosses them at every turn, till
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they are led to surrender the exercise of their will. Thus their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit is gradually broken and their character enervated; whereas that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obedience, which is exacted on a few important but rare occasions, only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exhibits servitude at certain intervals, and throws the burden of it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon a small number of men. It is in vain to summon a people, which has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been rendered so dependent on the central power, to choose from time to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time the representatives of that power; this rare and brief exercise of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their free choice, however important it may be, will not prevent them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from gradually losing the faculties of thinking, feeling, and acting for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves, and thus gradually falling below the level of humanity. *b
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I add that they will soon become incapable of exercising the great and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only privilege which remains to them. The democratic nations which have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: introduced freedom into their political constitution, at the very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time when they were augmenting the despotism of their administrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution, have been led into strange paradoxes. To manage those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: minor affairs in which good sense is all that is wanted--the people are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: held to be unequal to the task, but when the government of the country
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is at stake, the people are invested with immense powers; they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alternately made the playthings of their ruler, and his masters--more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than kings, and less than men. After having exhausted all the different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: modes of election, without finding one to suit their purpose, they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still amazed, and still bent on seeking further; as if the evil they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remark did not originate in the constitution of the country far more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than in that of the electoral body. It is, indeed, difficult to conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: how men who have entirely given up the habit of self-government should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: succeed in making a proper choice of those by whom they are to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governed; and no one will ever believe that a liberal, wise, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: energetic government can spring from the suffrages of a subservient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. A constitution, which should be republican in its head and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ultra-monarchical in all its other parts, has ever appeared to me to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be a short-lived monster. The vices of rulers and the ineptitude of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people would speedily bring about its ruin; and the nation, weary of its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: representatives and of itself, would create freer institutions, or soon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: return to stretch itself at the feet of a single master.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: See Appendix Z.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VII: Continuation Of The Preceding Chapters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe that it is easier to establish an absolute and despotic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government amongst a people in which the conditions of society are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equal, than amongst any other; and I think that if such a government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were once established amongst such a people, it would not only oppress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men, but would eventually strip each of them of several of the highest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: qualities of humanity. Despotism therefore appears to me peculiarly to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be dreaded in democratic ages. I should have loved freedom, I believe,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at all times, but in the time in which we live I am ready to worship
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. On the other hand, I am persuaded that all who shall attempt, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the ages upon which we are entering, to base freedom upon aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privilege, will fail--that all who shall attempt to draw and to retain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority within a single class, will fail. At the present day no ruler
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is skilful or strong enough to found a despotism, by re-establishing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permanent distinctions of rank amongst his subjects: no legislator is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wise or powerful enough to preserve free institutions, if he does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: take equality for his first principle and his watchword. All those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: our contemporaries who would establish or secure the independence and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the dignity of their fellow-men, must show themselves the friends of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality; and the only worthy means of showing themselves as such, is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be so: upon this depends the success of their holy enterprise. Thus the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: question is not how to reconstruct aristocratic society, but how to make
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty proceed out of that democratic state of society in which God has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: placed us.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These two truths appear to me simple, clear, and fertile in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences; and they naturally lead me to consider what kind of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: free government can be established amongst a people in which social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conditions are equal. It results from the very constitution of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations and from their necessities, that the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government amongst them must be more uniform, more centralized, more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extensive, more searching, and more efficient than in other countries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Society at large is naturally stronger and more active, individuals more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subordinate and weak; the former does more, the latter less; and this is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inevitably the case. It is not therefore to be expected that the range
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of private independence will ever be as extensive in democratic as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in aristocratic countries--nor is this to be desired; for, amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic nations, the mass is often sacrificed to the individual,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the prosperity of the greater number to the greatness of the few.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is both necessary and desirable that the government of a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people should be active and powerful: and our object should not be to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: render it weak or indolent, but solely to prevent it from abusing its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aptitude and its strength.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The circumstance which most contributed to secure the independence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private persons in aristocratic ages, was, that the supreme power did
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not affect to take upon itself alone the government and administration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community; those functions were necessarily partially left to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the members of the aristocracy: so that as the supreme power was always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: divided, it never weighed with its whole weight and in the same manner
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on each individual. Not only did the government not perform everything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by its immediate agency; but as most of the agents who discharged its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duties derived their power not from the State, but from the circumstance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of their birth, they were not perpetually under its control. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government could not make or unmake them in an instant, at pleasure,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor bend them in strict uniformity to its slightest caprice--this was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an additional guarantee of private independence. I readily admit that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recourse cannot be had to the same means at the present time: but I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discover certain democratic expedients which may be substituted for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. Instead of vesting in the government alone all the administrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powers of which corporations and nobles have been deprived, a portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them may be entrusted to secondary public bodies, temporarily composed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of private citizens: thus the liberty of private persons will be more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: secure, and their equality will not be diminished.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Americans, who care less for words than the French, still designate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the name of "county" the largest of their administrative districts:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but the duties of the count or lord-lieutenant are in part performed by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a provincial assembly. At a period of equality like our own it would be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unjust and unreasonable to institute hereditary officers; but there is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing to prevent us from substituting elective public officers to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: certain extent. Election is a democratic expedient which insures the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independence of the public officer in relation to the government,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as much and even more than hereditary rank can insure it amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic nations. Aristocratic countries abound in wealthy and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: influential persons who are competent to provide for themselves, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who cannot be easily or secretly oppressed: such persons restrain a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government within general habits of moderation and reserve. I am very
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: well aware that democratic countries contain no such persons naturally;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but something analogous to them may be created by artificial means. I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: firmly believe that an aristocracy cannot again be founded in the world;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but I think that private citizens, by combining together, may constitute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bodies of great wealth, influence, and strength, corresponding to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons of an aristocracy. By this means many of the greatest political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages of aristocracy would be obtained without its injustice or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its dangers. An association for political, commercial, or manufacturing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purposes, or even for those of science and literature, is a powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and enlightened member of the community, which cannot be disposed of at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasure, or oppressed without remonstrance; and which, by defending its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own rights against the encroachments of the government, saves the common
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberties of the country.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In periods of aristocracy every man is always bound so closely to many
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his fellow-citizens, that he cannot be assailed without their coming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to his assistance. In ages of equality every man naturally stands alone;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he has no hereditary friends whose co-operation he may demand--no class
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon whose sympathy he may rely: he is easily got rid of, and he is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trampled on with impunity. At the present time, an oppressed member
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the community has therefore only one method of self-defence--he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may appeal to the whole nation; and if the whole nation is deaf to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: complaint, he may appeal to mankind: the only means he has of making
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this appeal is by the press. Thus the liberty of the press is infinitely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more valuable amongst democratic nations than amongst all others; it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the only cure for the evils which equality may produce. Equality sets
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men apart and weakens them; but the press places a powerful weapon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within every man's reach, which the weakest and loneliest of them all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may use. Equality deprives a man of the support of his connections; but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the press enables him to summon all his fellow-countrymen and all his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fellow-men to his assistance. Printing has accelerated the progress of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equality, and it is also one of its best correctives.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I think that men living in aristocracies may, strictly speaking, do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without the liberty of the press: but such is not the case with those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who live in democratic countries. To protect their personal independence
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I trust not to great political assemblies, to parliamentary privilege,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or to the assertion of popular sovereignty. All these things may, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a certain extent, be reconciled with personal servitude--but that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servitude cannot be complete if the press is free: the press is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: chiefest democratic instrument of freedom.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Something analogous may be said of the judicial power. It is a part of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the essence of judicial power to attend to private interests, and to fix
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: itself with predilection on minute objects submitted to its observation;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another essential quality of judicial power is never to volunteer its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assistance to the oppressed, but always to be at the disposal of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: humblest of those who solicit it; their complaint, however feeble they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may themselves be, will force itself upon the ear of justice and claim
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: redress, for this is inherent in the very constitution of the courts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of justice. A power of this kind is therefore peculiarly adapted to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants of freedom, at a time when the eye and finger of the government
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are constantly intruding into the minutest details of human actions, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when private persons are at once too weak to protect themselves, and too
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: much isolated for them to reckon upon the assistance of their fellows.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The strength of the courts of law has ever been the greatest security
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which can be offered to personal independence; but this is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially the case in democratic ages: private rights and interests are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in constant danger, if the judicial power does not grow more extensive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and more strong to keep pace with the growing equality of conditions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Equality awakens in men several propensities extremely dangerous to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: freedom, to which the attention of the legislator ought constantly to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directed. I shall only remind the reader of the most important amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them. Men living in democratic ages do not readily comprehend the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: utility of forms: they feel an instinctive contempt for them--I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elsewhere shown for what reasons. Forms excite their contempt and often
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their hatred; as they commonly aspire to none but easy and present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratifications, they rush onwards to the object of their desires, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the slightest delay exasperates them. This same temper, carried
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with them into political life, renders them hostile to forms, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetually retard or arrest them in some of their projects. Yet this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: objection which the men of democracies make to forms is the very thing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which renders forms so useful to freedom; for their chief merit is to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: serve as a barrier between the strong and the weak, the ruler and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people, to retard the one, and give the other time to look about him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Forms become more necessary in proportion as the government becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more active and more powerful, whilst private persons are becoming more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indolent and more feeble. Thus democratic nations naturally stand more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in need of forms than other nations, and they naturally respect them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less. This deserves most serious attention. Nothing is more pitiful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the arrogant disdain of most of our contemporaries for questions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of form; for the smallest questions of form have acquired in our time an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance which they never had before: many of the greatest interests
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of mankind depend upon them. I think that if the statesmen of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocratic ages could sometimes contemn forms with impunity, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently rise above them, the statesmen to whom the government of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations is now confided ought to treat the very least among them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with respect, and not neglect them without imperious necessity. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aristocracies the observance of forms was superstitious; amongst us they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ought to be kept with a deliberate and enlightened deference.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Another tendency, which is extremely natural to democratic nations and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely dangerous, is that which leads them ta despise and undervalue
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the rights of private persons. The attachment which men feel to a right,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the respect which they display for it, is generally proportioned to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its importance, or to the length of time during which they have enjoyed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. The rights of private persons amongst democratic nations are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commonly of small importance, of recent growth, and extremely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: precarious--the consequence is that they are often sacrificed without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regret, and almost always violated without remorse. But it happens that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at the same period and amongst the same nations in which men conceive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a natural contempt for the rights of private persons, the rights of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society at large are naturally extended and consolidated: in other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: words, men become less attached to private rights at the very time at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which it would be most necessary to retain and to defend what little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remains of them. It is therefore most especially in the present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic ages, that the true friends of the liberty and the greatness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of man ought constantly to be on the alert to prevent the power of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: government from lightly sacrificing the private rights of individuals
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the general execution of its designs. At such times no citizen is so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obscure that it is not very dangerous to allow him to be oppressed--no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private rights are so unimportant that they can be surrendered with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impunity to the caprices of a government. The reason is plain:--if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private right of an individual is violated at a time when the human mind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is fully impressed with the importance and the sanctity of such rights,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the injury done is confined to the individual whose right is infringed;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but to violate such a right, at the present day, is deeply to corrupt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manners of the nation and to put the whole community in jeopardy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because the very notion of this kind of right constantly tends amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: us to be impaired and lost.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There are certain habits, certain notions, and certain vices which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peculiar to a state of revolution, and which a protracted revolution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot fail to engender and to propagate, whatever be, in other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respects, its character, its purpose, and the scene on which it takes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: place. When any nation has, within a short space of time, repeatedly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: varied its rulers, its opinions, and its laws, the men of whom it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed eventually contract a taste for change, and grow accustomed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to see all changes effected by sudden violence. Thus they naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conceive a contempt for forms which daily prove ineffectual; and they do
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not support without impatience the dominion of rules which they have so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: often seen infringed. As the ordinary notions of equity and morality no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer suffice to explain and justify all the innovations daily begotten
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by a revolution, the principle of public utility is called in, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: doctrine of political necessity is conjured up, and men accustom
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to sacrifice private interests without scruple, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to trample on the rights of individuals in order more speedily to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accomplish any public purpose.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: These habits and notions, which I shall call revolutionary, because all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions produce them, occur in aristocracies just as much as amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic nations; but amongst the former they are often less powerful
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and always less lasting, because there they meet with habits, notions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: defects, and impediments, which counteract them: they consequently
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disappear as soon as the revolution is terminated, and the nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reverts to its former political courses. This is not always the case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democratic countries, in which it is ever to be feared that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutionary tendencies, becoming more gentle and more regular, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entirely disappearing from society, will be gradually transformed into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: habits of subjection to the administrative authority of the government.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I know of no countries in which revolutions re more dangerous than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in democratic countries; because, independently of the accidental and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transient evils which must always attend them, they may always create
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: some evils which are permanent and unending. I believe that there are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such things as justifiable resistance and legitimate rebellion: I do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore assert, as an absolute proposition, that the men of democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ages ought never to make revolutions; but I think that they have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especial reason to hesitate before they embark in them, and that it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: far better to endure many grievances in their present condition than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have recourse to so perilous a remedy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I shall conclude by one general idea, which comprises not only all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular ideas which have been expressed in the present chapter, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: also most of those which it is the object of this book to treat of.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the ages of aristocracy which preceded our own, there were private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons of great power, and a social authority of extreme weakness. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: outline of society itself was not easily discernible, and constantly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confounded with the different powers by which the community was ruled.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The principal efforts of the men of those times were required to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strengthen, aggrandize, and secure the supreme power; and on the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hand, to circumscribe individual independence within narrower limits,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and to subject private interests to the interests of the public. Other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perils and other cares await the men of our age. Amongst the greater
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of modern nations, the government, whatever may be its origin, its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution, or its name, has become almost omnipotent, and private
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: persons are falling, more and more, into the lowest stage of weakness
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and dependence. In olden society everything was different; unity and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uniformity were nowhere to be met with. In modern society everything
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: threatens to become so much alike, that the peculiar characteristics of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: each individual will soon be entirely lost in the general aspect of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: world. Our forefathers were ever prone to make an improper use of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notion, that private rights ought to be respected; and we are naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prone on the other hand to exaggerate the idea that the interest of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private individual ought always to bend to the interest of the many. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: political world is metamorphosed: new remedies must henceforth be sought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for new disorders. To lay down extensive, but distinct and settled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limits, to the action of the government; to confer certain rights on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: private persons, and to secure to them the undisputed enjoyment of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rights; to enable individual man to maintain whatever independence,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength, and original power he still possesses; to raise him by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: side of society at large, and uphold him in that position--these appear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to me the main objects of legislators in the ages upon which we are now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entering. It would seem as if the rulers of our time sought only to use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men in order to make things great; I wish that they would try a little
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more to make great men; that they would set less value on the work, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more upon the workman; that they would never forget that a nation cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long remain strong when every man belonging to it is individually weak,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that no form or combination of social polity has yet been devised,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to make an energetic people out of a community of pusillanimous and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enfeebled citizens.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I trace amongst our contemporaries two contrary notions which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equally injurious. One set of men can perceive nothing in the principle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of equality but the anarchical tendencies which it engenders: they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dread their own free agency--they fear themselves. Other thinkers, less
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: numerous but more enlightened, take a different view: besides that track
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which starts from the principle of equality to terminate in anarchy,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they have at last discovered the road which seems to lead men to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inevitable servitude. They shape their souls beforehand to this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary condition; and, despairing of remaining free, they already
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: do obeisance in their hearts to the master who is soon to appear. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
