text: former abandon freedom, because they think it dangerous; the latter,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: because they hold it to be impossible. If I had entertained the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conviction, I should not have written this book, but I should have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confined myself to deploring in secret the destiny of mankind. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sought to point out the dangers to which the principle of equality
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exposes the independence of man, because I firmly believe that these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangers are the most formidable, as well as the least foreseen, of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: those which futurity holds in store: but I do not think that they are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: insurmountable. The men who live in the democratic ages upon which we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are entering have naturally a taste for independence: they are naturally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impatient of regulation, and they are wearied by the permanence even of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the condition they themselves prefer. They are fond of power; but they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are prone to despise and hate those who wield it, and they easily elude
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its grasp by their own mobility and insignificance. These propensities
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will always manifest themselves, because they originate in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: groundwork of society, which will undergo no change: for a long time
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they will prevent the establishment of any despotism, and they will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: furnish fresh weapons to each succeeding generation which shall struggle
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in favor of the liberty of mankind. Let us then look forward to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: future with that salutary fear which makes men keep watch and ward
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for freedom, not with that faint and idle terror which depresses and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enervates the heart.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Chapter VIII: General Survey Of The Subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Before I close forever the theme that has detained me so long, I would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fain take a parting survey of all the various characteristics of modern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: society, and appreciate at last the general influence to be exercised by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the principle of equality upon the fate of mankind; but I am stopped
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the difficulty of the task, and in presence of so great an object my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sight is troubled, and my reason fails. The society of the modern world
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I have sought to delineate, and which I seek to judge, has but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: just come into existence. Time has not yet shaped it into perfect form:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the great revolution by which it has been created is not yet over: and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amidst the occurrences of our time, it is almost impossible to discern
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what will pass away with the revolution itself, and what will survive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its close. The world which is rising into existence is still half
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: encumbered by the remains of the world which is waning into decay; and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amidst the vast perplexity of human affairs, none can say how much of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ancient institutions and former manners will remain, or how much will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely disappear. Although the revolution which is taking place in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the social condition, the laws, the opinions, and the feelings of men,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is still very far from being terminated, yet its results already admit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of no comparison with anything that the world has ever before witnessed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I go back from age to age up to the remotest antiquity; but I find no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: parallel to what is occurring before my eyes: as the past has ceased to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: throw its light upon the future, the mind of man wanders in obscurity.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, in the midst of a prospect so wide, so novel and so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confused, some of the more prominent characteristics may already be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discerned and pointed out. The good things and the evils of life are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more equally distributed in the world: great wealth tends to disappear,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the number of small fortunes to increase; desires and gratifications
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are multiplied, but extraordinary prosperity and irremediable penury are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alike unknown. The sentiment of ambition is universal, but the scope
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of ambition is seldom vast. Each individual stands apart in solitary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weakness; but society at large is active, provident, and powerful: the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: performances of private persons are insignificant, those of the State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immense. There is little energy of character; but manners are mild, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws humane. If there be few instances of exalted heroism or of virtues
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the highest, brightest, and purest temper, men's habits are regular,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: violence is rare, and cruelty almost unknown. Human existence becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: longer, and property more secure: life is not adorned with brilliant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trophies, but it is extremely easy and tranquil. Few pleasures are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either very refined or very coarse; and highly polished manners are as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: uncommon as great brutality of tastes. Neither men of great learning,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nor extremely ignorant communities, are to be met with; genius becomes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more rare, information more diffused. The human mind is impelled by the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: small efforts of all mankind combined together, not by the strenuous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: activity of certain men. There is less perfection, but more abundance,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all the productions of the arts. The ties of race, of rank, and of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: country are relaxed; the great bond of humanity is strengthened. If
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I endeavor to find out the most general and the most prominent of all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these different characteristics, I shall have occasion to perceive, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: what is taking place in men's fortunes manifests itself under a thousand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other forms. Almost all extremes are softened or blunted: all that was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most prominent is superseded by some mean term, at once less lofty and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less low, less brilliant and less obscure, than what before existed in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: When I survey this countless multitude of beings, shaped in each other's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: likeness, amidst whom nothing rises and nothing falls, the sight of such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: universal uniformity saddens and chills me, and I am tempted to regret
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that state of society which has ceased to be. When the world was full of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men of great importance and extreme insignificance, of great wealth and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extreme poverty, of great learning and extreme ignorance, I turned aside
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the latter to fix my observation on the former alone, who gratified
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my sympathies. But I admit that this gratification arose from my own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: weakness: it is because I am unable to see at once all that is around
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: me, that I am allowed thus to select and separate the objects of my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: predilection from among so many others. Such is not the case with that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almighty and eternal Being whose gaze necessarily includes the whole of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: created things, and who surveys distinctly, though at once, mankind and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man. We may naturally believe that it is not the singular prosperity of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the few, but the greater well-being of all, which is most pleasing in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sight of the Creator and Preserver of men. What appears to me to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man's decline, is to His eye advancement; what afflicts me is acceptable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to Him. A state of equality is perhaps less elevated, but it is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: just; and its justice constitutes its greatness and its beauty. I would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strive then to raise myself to this point of the divine contemplation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and thence to view and to judge the concerns of men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No man, upon the earth, can as yet affirm absolutely and generally,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that the new state of the world is better than its former one; but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is already easy to perceive that this state is different. Some vices
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and some virtues were so inherent in the constitution of an aristocratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nation, and are so opposite to the character of a modern people, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they can never be infused into it; some good tendencies and some bad
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: propensities which were unknown to the former, are natural to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: latter; some ideas suggest themselves spontaneously to the imagination
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the one, which are utterly repugnant to the mind of the other. They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are like two distinct orders of human beings, each of which has its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own merits and defects, its own advantages and its own evils. Care
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: must therefore be taken not to judge the state of society, which is now
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: coming into existence, by notions derived from a state of society
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which no longer exists; for as these states of society are exceedingly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different in their structure, they cannot be submitted to a just or fair
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comparison. It would be scarcely more reasonable to require of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own contemporaries the peculiar virtues which originated in the social
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: condition of their forefathers, since that social condition is itself
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fallen, and has drawn into one promiscuous ruin the good and evil which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: belonged to it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But as yet these things are imperfectly understood. I find that a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of my contemporaries undertake to make a certain selection from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: amongst the institutions, the opinions, and the ideas which originated
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the aristocratic constitution of society as it was: a portion of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these elements they would willingly relinquish, but they would keep the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remainder and transplant them into their new world. I apprehend that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such men are wasting their time and their strength in virtuous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but unprofitable efforts. The object is not to retain the peculiar
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: advantages which the inequality of conditions bestows upon mankind, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to secure the new benefits which equality may supply. We have not to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seek to make ourselves like our progenitors, but to strive to work out
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that species of greatness and happiness which is our own. For myself,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who now look back from this extreme limit of my task, and discover from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afar, but at once, the various objects which have attracted my more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attentive investigation upon my way, I am full of apprehensions and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of hopes. I perceive mighty dangers which it is possible to ward
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: off--mighty evils which may be avoided or alleviated; and I cling with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a firmer hold to the belief, that for democratic nations to be virtuous
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and prosperous they require but to will it. I am aware that many of my
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries maintain that nations are never their own masters
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: here below, and that they necessarily obey some insurmountable and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unintelligent power, arising from anterior events, from their race, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the soil and climate of their country. Such principles are false
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and cowardly; such principles can never produce aught but feeble men
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and pusillanimous nations. Providence has not created mankind entirely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: independent or entirely free. It is true that around every man a fatal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circle is traced, beyond which he cannot pass; but within the wide
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: verge of that circle he is powerful and free: as it is with man, so with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities. The nations of our time cannot prevent the conditions of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men from becoming equal; but it depends upon themselves whether the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principle of equality is to lead them to servitude or freedom, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: knowledge or barbarism, to prosperity or to wretchedness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Part I.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: For information concerning all the countries of the West which have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not been visited by Europeans, consult the account of two expeditions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertaken at the expense of Congress by Major Long. This traveller
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particularly mentions, on the subject of the great American desert, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a line may be drawn nearly parallel to the 20th degree of longitude *a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (meridian of Washington), beginning from the Red River and ending at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the River Platte. From this imaginary line to the Rocky Mountains, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bound the valley of the Mississippi on the west, lie immense plains,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are almost entirely covered with sand, incapable of cultivation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or scattered over with masses of granite. In summer, these plains are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: quite destitute of water, and nothing is to be seen on them but herds of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: buffaloes and wild horses. Some hordes of Indians are also found
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there, but in no great numbers. Major Long was told that in travelling
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: northwards from the River Platte you find the same desert lying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly on the left; but he was unable to ascertain the truth of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: report. However worthy of confidence may be the narrative of Major Long,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it must be remembered that he only passed through the country of which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he speaks, without deviating widely from the line which he had traced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: out for his journey.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote a: The 20th degree of longitude, according to the meridian of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Washington, agrees very nearly with the 97th degree on the meridian of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Greenwich.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix B
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: South America, in the region between the tropics, produces an incredible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profusion of climbing plants, of which the flora of the Antilles alone
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: presents us with forty different species. Among the most graceful of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these shrubs is the passion-flower, which, according to Descourtiz,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: grows with such luxuriance in the Antilles, as to climb trees by means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the tendrils with which it is provided, and form moving bowers of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rich and elegant festoons, decorated with blue and purple flowers, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fragrant with perfume. The Mimosa scandens (Acacia a grandes gousses) is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a creeper of enormous and rapid growth, which climbs from tree to tree,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and sometimes covers more than half a league.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix C
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The languages which are spoken by the Indians of America, from the Pole
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to Cape Horn, are said to be all formed upon the same model, and subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the same grammatical rules; whence it may fairly be concluded that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the Indian nations sprang from the same stock. Each tribe of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the American continent speaks a different dialect; but the number of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: languages, properly so called, is very small, a fact which tends to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prove that the nations of the New World had not a very remote origin.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Moreover, the languages of America have a great degree of regularity,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from which it seems probable that the tribes which employ them had not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undergone any great revolutions, or been incorporated voluntarily or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by constraint, with foreign nations. For it is generally the union of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several languages into one which produces grammatical irregularities. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is not long since the American languages, especially those of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: North, first attracted the serious attention of philologists, when the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discovery was made that this idiom of a barbarous people was the product
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a complicated system of ideas and very learned combinations. These
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: languages were found to be very rich, and great pains had been taken
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at their formation to render them agreeable to the ear. The grammatical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: system of the Americans differs from all others in several points, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially in the following:--Some nations of Europe, amongst
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: others the Germans, have the power of combining at pleasure different
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expressions, and thus giving a complex sense to certain words. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indians have given a most surprising extension to this power, so as to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arrive at the means of connecting a great number of ideas with a single
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: term. This will be easily understood with the help of an example quoted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by Mr. Duponceau, in the "Memoirs of the Philosophical Society of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: America": A Delaware woman playing with a cat or a young dog, says
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this writer, is heard to pronounce the word kuligatschis, which is thus
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: composed: k is the sign of the second person, and signifies "thou" or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "thy"; uli is a part of the word wulit, which signifies "beautiful,"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "pretty"; gat is another fragment, of the word wichgat, which means
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "paw"; and, lastly, schis is a diminutive giving the idea of smallness.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Thus in one word the Indian woman has expressed "Thy pretty little paw."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Take another example of the felicity with which the savages of America
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have composed their words. A young man of Delaware is called pilape.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This word is formed from pilsit, "chaste," "innocent"; and lenape,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "man"; viz., "man in his purity and innocence." This facility of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: combining words is most remarkable in the strange formation of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: verbs. The most complex action is often expressed by a single verb,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which serves to convey all the shades of an idea by the modification
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of its construction. Those who may wish to examine more in detail this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject, which I have only glanced at superficially, should read:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1. The correspondence of Mr. Duponceau and the Rev. Mr. Hecwelder
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relative to the Indian languages, which is to be found in the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: volume of the "Memoirs of the Philosophical Society of America,"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: published at Philadelphia, 1819, by Abraham Small; vol. i. p. 356-464.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 2. The "Grammar of the Delaware or the Lenape Language," by Geiberger,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the preface of Mr. Duponceau. All these are in the same collection,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vol. iii.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 3. An excellent account of these works, which is at the end of the sixth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: volume of the American Encyclopaedia.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix D
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See in Charlevoix, vol. i. p. 235, the history of the first war which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the French inhabitants of Canada carried on, in 1610, against the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Iroquois. The latter, armed with bows and arrows, offered a desperate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resistance to the French and their allies. Charlevoix is not a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: painter, yet he exhibits clearly enough, in this narrative, the contrast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: between the European manners and those of savages, as well as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different way in which the two races of men understood the sense of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: honor. When the French, says he, seized upon the beaver-skins which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: covered the Indians who had fallen, the Hurons, their allies, were
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greatly offended at this proceeding; but without hesitation they set
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to work in their usual manner, inflicting horrid cruelties upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prisoners, and devouring one of those who had been killed, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made the Frenchmen shudder. The barbarians prided themselves upon a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: scrupulousness which they were surprised at not finding in our nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and could not understand that there was less to reprehend in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stripping of dead bodies than in the devouring of their flesh like wild
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: beasts. Charlevoix, in another place (vol. i. p. 230), thus describes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the first torture of which Champlain was an eyewitness, and the return
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the Hurons into their own village. Having proceeded about eight
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: leagues, says he, our allies halted; and having singled out one of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their captives, they reproached him with all the cruelties which he
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had practised upon the warriors of their nation who had fallen into his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands, and told him that he might expect to be treated in like manner;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: adding, that if he had any spirit he would prove it by singing. He
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: immediately chanted forth his death-song, and then his war-song, and all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the songs he knew, "but in a very mournful strain," says Champlain, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not then aware that all savage music has a melancholy character. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tortures which succeeded, accompanied by all the horrors which we shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: mention hereafter, terrified the French, who made every effort to put a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stop to them, but in vain. The following night, one of the Hurons having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dreamt that they were pursued, the retreat was changed to a real flight,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and the savages never stopped until they were out of the reach of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: danger. The moment they perceived the cabins of their own village, they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cut themselves long sticks, to which they fastened the scalps which had
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fallen to their share, and carried them in triumph. At this sight, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: women swam to the canoes, where they received the bloody scalps from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hands of their husbands, and tied them round their necks. The warriors
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offered one of these horrible trophies to Champlain; they also presented
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him with some bows and arrows--the only spoils of the Iroquois which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they had ventured to seize--entreating him to show them to the King
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of France. Champlain lived a whole winter quite alone among these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barbarians, without being under any alarm for his person or property.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix E
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Although the Puritanical strictness which presided over the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: establishment of the English colonies in America is now much relaxed,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarkable traces of it are still found in their habits and their laws.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1792, at the very time when the anti-Christian republic of France
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: began its ephemeral existence, the legislative body of Massachusetts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: promulgated the following law, to compel the citizens to observe the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Sabbath. We give the preamble and the principal articles of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: law, which is worthy of the reader's attention: "Whereas," says the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: legislator, "the observation of the Sunday is an affair of public
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest; inasmuch as it produces a necessary suspension of labor, leads
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men to reflect upon the duties of life, and the errors to which human
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nature is liable, and provides for the public and private worship of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: God, the creator and governor of the universe, and for the performance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of such acts of charity as are the ornament and comfort of Christian
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: societies:--Whereas irreligious or light-minded persons, forgetting the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: duties which the Sabbath imposes, and the benefits which these duties
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confer on society, are known to profane its sanctity, by following their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasures or their affairs; this way of acting being contrary to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: own interest as Christians, and calculated to annoy those who do not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: follow their example; being also of great injury to society at large, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spreading a taste for dissipation and dissolute manners; Be it enacted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and ordained by the Governor, Council, and Representatives convened in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: General Court of Assembly, that all and every person and persons shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on that day carefully apply themselves to the duties of religion
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and piety, that no tradesman or labourer shall exercise his ordinary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calling, and that no game or recreation shall be used on the Lord's Day,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon pain of forfeiting ten shillings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "That no one shall travel on that day, or any part thereof, under pain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of forfeiting twenty shillings; that no vessel shall leave a harbour of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the colony; that no persons shall keep outside the meeting-house during
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the time of public worship, or profane the time by playing or talking,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on penalty of five shillings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Public-houses shall not entertain any other than strangers or lodgers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under penalty of five shillings for every person found drinking and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abiding therein.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Any person in health, who, without sufficient reason, shall omit to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: worship God in public during three months, shall be condemned to a fine
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of ten shillings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Any person guilty of misbehaviour in a place of public worship, shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be fined from five to forty shillings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "These laws are to be enforced by the tything-men of each township, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have authority to visit public-houses on the Sunday. The innkeeper who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall refuse them admittance, shall be fined forty shillings for such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The tything-men are to stop travellers, and require of them their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reason for being on the road on Sunday; anyone refusing to answer, shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be sentenced to pay a fine not exceeding five pounds sterling. If
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the reason given by the traveller be not deemed by the tything-man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficient, he may bring the traveller before the justice of the peace
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the district." (Law of March 8, 1792; General Laws of Massachusetts,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: On March 11, 1797, a new law increased the amount of fines, half of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which was to be given to the informer. (Same collection, vol. ii. p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 525.) On February 16, 1816, a new law confirmed these same measures.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (Same collection, vol. ii. p. 405.) Similar enactments exist in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: laws of the State of New York, revised in 1827 and 1828. (See Revised
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Statutes, Part I. chapter 20, p. 675.) In these it is declared that no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one is allowed on the Sabbath to sport, to fish, to play at games, or to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequent houses where liquor is sold. No one can travel, except in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case of necessity. And this is not the only trace which the religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strictness and austere manners of the first emigrants have left behind
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them in the American laws. In the Revised Statutes of the State of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: York, vol. i. p. 662, is the following clause:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Whoever shall win or lose in the space of twenty-four hours, by gaming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or betting, the sum of twenty-five dollars, shall be found guilty of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misdemeanour, and upon conviction shall be condemned to pay a fine equal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to at least five times the value of the sum lost or won; which shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be paid to the inspector of the poor of the township. He that loses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: twenty-five dollars or more may bring an action to recover them; and if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he neglects to do so the inspector of the poor may prosecute the winner,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and oblige him to pay into the poor's box both the sum he has gained and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: three times as much besides."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The laws we quote from are of recent date; but they are unintelligible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without going back to the very origin of the colonies. I have no doubt
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that in our days the penal part of these laws is very rarely applied.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Laws preserve their inflexibility, long after the manners of a nation
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have yielded to the influence of time. It is still true, however, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nothing strikes a foreigner on his arrival in America more forcibly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the regard paid to the Sabbath. There is one, in particular, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the large American cities, in which all social movements begin to be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suspended even on Saturday evening. You traverse its streets at the hour
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at which you expect men in the middle of life to be engaged in business,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and young people in pleasure; and you meet with solitude and silence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Not only have all ceased to work, but they appear to have ceased to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist. Neither the movements of industry are heard, nor the accents of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: joy, nor even the confused murmur which arises from the midst of a great
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: city. Chains are hung across the streets in the neighborhood of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: churches; the half-closed shutters of the houses scarcely admit a ray
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of sun into the dwellings of the citizens. Now and then you perceive a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: solitary individual who glides silently along the deserted streets and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: lanes. Next day, at early dawn, the rolling of carriages, the noise of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hammers, the cries of the population, begin to make themselves heard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: again. The city is awake. An eager crowd hastens towards the resort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commerce and industry; everything around you bespeaks motion, bustle,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: hurry. A feverish activity succeeds to the lethargic stupor of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: yesterday; you might almost suppose that they had but one day to acquire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wealth and to enjoy it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix F
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is unnecessary for me to say, that in the chapter which has just been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: read, I have not had the intention of giving a history of America. My
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: only object was to enable the reader to appreciate the influence which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the opinions and manners of the first emigrants had exercised upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fate of the different colonies, and of the Union in general. I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore confined myself to the quotation of a few detached fragments.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I do not know whether I am deceived, but it appears to me that, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pursuing the path which I have merely pointed out, it would be easy to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: present such pictures of the American republics as would not be unworthy
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the attention of the public, and could not fail to suggest to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: statesman matter for reflection. Not being able to devote myself to this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor, I am anxious to render it easy to others; and, for this purpose,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I subjoin a short catalogue and analysis of the works which seem to me
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most important to consult.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the head of the general documents which it would be advantageous to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: examine I place the work entitled "An Historical Collection of State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Papers, and other authentic Documents, intended as Materials for a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: History of the United States of America," by Ebenezer Hasard. The first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: volume of this compilation, which was printed at Philadelphia in 1792,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contains a literal copy of all the charters granted by the Crown of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England to the emigrants, as well as the principal acts of the colonial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments, during the commencement of their existence. Amongst other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authentic documents, we here find a great many relating to the affairs
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of New England and Virginia during this period. The second volume is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost entirely devoted to the acts of the Confederation of 1643. This
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: federal compact, which was entered into by the colonies of New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the view of resisting the Indians, was the first instance of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: union afforded by the Anglo-Americans. There were besides many other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: confederations of the same nature, before the famous one of 1776, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: brought about the independence of the colonies.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Each colony has, besides, its own historic monuments, some of which are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extremely curious; beginning with Virginia, the State which was first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peopled. The earliest historian of Virginia was its founder, Captain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: John Smith. Captain Smith has left us an octavo volume, entitled "The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generall Historie of Virginia and New England, by Captain John Smith,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometymes Governor in those Countryes, and Admirall of New England";
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: printed at London in 1627. The work is adorned with curious maps and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engravings of the time when it appeared; the narrative extends from the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: year 1584 to 1626. Smith's work is highly and deservedly esteemed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The author was one of the most celebrated adventurers of a period of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: remarkable adventure; his book breathes that ardor for discovery, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit of enterprise, which characterized the men of his time, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the manners of chivalry were united to zeal for commerce, and made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subservient to the acquisition of wealth. But Captain Smith is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most remarkable for uniting to the virtues which characterized his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contemporaries several qualities to which they were generally strangers;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his style is simple and concise, his narratives bear the stamp of truth,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and his descriptions are free from false ornament. This author throws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most valuable light upon the state and condition of the Indians at the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time when North America was first discovered.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The second historian to consult is Beverley, who commences his narrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with the year 1585, and ends it with 1700. The first part of his book
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: contains historical documents, properly so called, relative to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infancy of the colony. The second affords a most curious picture of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state of the Indians at this remote period. The third conveys very clear
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ideas concerning the manners, social conditions, laws, and political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: customs of the Virginians in the author's lifetime. Beverley was a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: native of Virginia, which occasions him to say at the beginning of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his book, that he entreats his readers not to exercise their critical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: severity upon it, since, having been born in the Indies, he does not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: aspire to purity of language. Notwithstanding this colonial modesty, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: author shows throughout his book the impatience with which he endures
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the supremacy of the mother-country. In this work of Beverley are also
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found numerous traces of that spirit of civil liberty which animated the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English colonies of America at the time when he wrote. He also shows the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dissensions which existed among them, and retarded their independence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Beverley detests his Catholic neighbors of Maryland even more than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he hates the English government: his style is simple, his narrative
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interesting, and apparently trustworthy.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I saw in America another work which ought to be consulted, entitled "The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: History of Virginia," by William Stith. This book affords some curious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: details, but I thought it long and diffuse. The most ancient as well as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the best document to be consulted on the history of Carolina, is a work
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in small quarto, entitled "The History of Carolina," by John Lawson,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: printed at London in 1718. This work contains, in the first part, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: journey of discovery in the west of Carolina; the account of which,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: given in the form of a journal, is in general confused and superficial;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but it contains a very striking description of the mortality caused
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: among the savages of that time both by the smallpox and the immoderate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: use of brandy; with a curious picture of the corruption of manners
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prevalent amongst them, which was increased by the presence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europeans. The second part of Lawson's book is taken up with a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: description of the physical condition of Carolina, and its productions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the third part, the author gives an interesting account of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manners, customs, and government of the Indians at that period. There is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a good deal of talent and originality in this part of the work.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lawson concludes his history with a copy of the charter granted to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Carolinas in the reign of Charles II. The general tone of this work is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: light, and often licentious, forming a perfect contrast to the solemn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: style of the works published at the same period in New England. Lawson's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: history is extremely scarce in America, and cannot be procured in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe. There is, however, a copy of it in the Royal Library at Paris.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From the southern extremity of the United States, I pass at once to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: northern limit; as the intermediate space was not peopled till a later
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: period. I must first point out a very curious compilation, entitled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Collection of the Massachusetts Historical Society," printed for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: first time at Boston in 1792, and reprinted in 1806. The collection of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which I speak, and which is continued to the present day, contains a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great number of very valuable documents relating to the history of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different States in New England. Among them are letters which have never
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been published, and authentic pieces which had been buried in provincial
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: archives. The whole work of Gookin, concerning the Indians, is inserted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have mentioned several times in the chapter to which this note
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relates, the work of Nathaniel Norton entitled "New England's Memorial";
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sufficiently, perhaps, to prove that it deserves the attention of those
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: who would be conversant with the history of New England. This book is in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: octavo, and was reprinted at Boston in 1826.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The most valuable and important authority which exists upon the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: history of New England, is the work of the Rev. Cotton Mather, entitled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Magnalia Christi Americana, or the Ecclesiastical History of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: England, 1620-1698, 2 vols. 8vo, reprinted at Hartford, United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in 1820." *b The author divided his work into seven books. The first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: presents the history of the events which prepared and brought about the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: establishment of New England. The second contains the lives of the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governors and chief magistrates who presided over the country. The third
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is devoted to the lives and labors of the evangelical ministers who,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: during the same period, had the care of souls. In the fourth the author
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relates the institution and progress of the University of Cambridge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (Massachusetts). In the fifth he describes the principles and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discipline of the Church of New England. The sixth is taken up in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: retracing certain facts, which, in the opinion of Mather, prove the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merciful interposition of Providence in behalf of the inhabitants of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: New England. Lastly, in the seventh, the author gives an account of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the heresies and the troubles to which the Church of New England was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exposed. Cotton Mather was an evangelical minister who was born at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Boston, and passed his life there. His narratives are distinguished by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same ardor and religious zeal which led to the foundation of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: colonies of New England. Traces of bad taste sometimes occur in his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manner of writing; but he interests, because he is full of enthusiasm.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He is often intolerant, still oftener credulous, but he never betrays
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an intention to deceive. Sometimes his book contains fine passages, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: true and profound reflections, such as the following:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Before the arrival of the Puritans," says he (vol. i. chap. iv.),
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "there were more than a few attempts of the English to people and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: improve the parts of New England which were to the northward of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Plymouth; but the designs of those attempts being aimed no higher
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: than the advancement of some worldly interests, a constant series of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disasters has confounded them, until there was a plantation erected upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the nobler designs of Christianity: and that plantation though it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has had more adversaries than perhaps any one upon earth, yet, having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtained help from God, it continues to this day." Mather occasionally
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relieves the austerity of his descriptions with images full of tender
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: feeling: after having spoken of an English lady whose religious ardor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: had brought her to America with her husband, and who soon after sank
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under the fatigues and privations of exile, he adds, "As for her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: virtuous husband, Isaac Johnson,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He tryed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To live without her, liked it not, and dyed."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote b: A folio edition of this work was published in London in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Mather's work gives an admirable picture of the time and country which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he describes. In his account of the motives which led the Puritans to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: seek an asylum beyond seas, he says:--"The God of Heaven served, as it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were, a summons upon the spirits of his people in the English nation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: stirring up the spirits of thousands which never saw the faces of each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, with a most unanimous inclination to leave all the pleasant
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accommodations of their native country, and go over a terrible
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ocean, into a more terrible desert, for the pure enjoyment of all his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ordinances. It is now reasonable that, before we pass any further,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the reasons of his undertaking should be more exactly made known
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unto posterity, especially unto the posterity of those that were the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: undertakers, lest they come at length to forget and neglect the true
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: interest of New England. Wherefore I shall now transcribe some of them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from a manuscript, wherein they were then tendered unto consideration:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "General Considerations for the Plantation of New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "First, It will be a service unto the Church of great consequence, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: carry the Gospel unto those parts of the world, and raise a bulwark
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the kingdom of Antichrist, which the Jesuits labour to rear up
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in all parts of the world.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Secondly, All other Churches of Europe have been brought under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desolations; and it may be feared that the like judgments are coming
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon us; and who knows but God hath provided this place to be a refuge
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for many whom he means to save out of the general destruction?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Thirdly, The land grows weary of her inhabitants, insomuch that man,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is the most precious of all creatures, is here more vile and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: base than the earth he treads upon; children, neighbours, and friends,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: especially the poor, are counted the greatest burdens, which, if things
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were right, would be the chiefest of earthly blessings.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Fourthly, We are grown to that intemperance in all excess of riot, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no mean estate almost will suffice a man to keep sail with his equals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and he that fails in it must live in scorn and contempt: hence it comes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to pass, that all arts and trades are carried in that deceitful manner
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and unrighteous course, as it is almost impossible for a good upright
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man to maintain his constant charge and live comfortably in them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Fifthly, The schools of learning and religion are so corrupted, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (besides the unsupportable charge of education) most children, even the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: best, wittiest, and of the fairest hopes, are perverted, corrupted,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and utterly overthrown by the multitude of evil examples and licentious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: behaviours in these seminaries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Sixthly, The whole earth is the Lord's garden, and he hath given it to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sons of Adam, to be tilled and improved by them: why, then, should
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we stand starving here for places of habitation, and in the meantime
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suffer whole countries, as profitable for the use of man, to lie waste
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without any improvement?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Seventhly, What can be a better or nobler work, and more worthy of a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Christian, than to erect and support a reformed particular Church in its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infancy, and unite our forces with such a company of faithful people, as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by timely assistance may grow stronger and prosper; but for want of it,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may be put to great hazards, if not be wholly ruined?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "Eighthly, If any such as are known to be godly, and live in wealth
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and prosperity here, shall forsake all this to join with this reformed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Church, and with it run the hazard of an hard and mean condition, it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will be an example of great use, both for the removing of scandal and to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: give more life unto the faith of God's people in their prayers for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plantation, and also to encourage others to join the more willingly in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Further on, when he declares the principles of the Church of New England
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with respect to morals, Mather inveighs with violence against the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: custom of drinking healths at table, which he denounces as a pagan and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: abominable practice. He proscribes with the same rigor all ornaments for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hair used by the female sex, as well as their custom of having the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: arms and neck uncovered. In another part of his work he relates several
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: instances of witchcraft which had alarmed New England. It is plain that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the visible action of the devil in the affairs of this world appeared to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: him an incontestable and evident fact.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This work of Cotton Mather displays, in many places, the spirit of civil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: liberty and political independence which characterized the times in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which he lived. Their principles respecting government are discoverable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at every page. Thus, for instance, the inhabitants of Massachusetts, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the year 1630, ten years after the foundation of Plymouth, are found to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: have devoted Pound 400 sterling to the establishment of the University
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Cambridge. In passing from the general documents relative to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: history of New England to those which describe the several States
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: comprised within its limits, I ought first to notice "The History of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Colony of Massachusetts," by Hutchinson, Lieutenant-Governor of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Massachusetts Province, 2 vols. 8vo. The history of Hutchinson, which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have several times quoted in the chapter to which this note relates,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: commences in the year 1628, and ends in 1750. Throughout the work there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is a striking air of truth and the greatest simplicity of style: it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is full of minute details. The best history to consult concerning
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Connecticut is that of Benjamin Trumbull, entitled "A Complete History
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Connecticut, Civil and Ecclesiastical," 1630-1764, 2 vols. 8vo,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: printed in 1818 at New Haven. This history contains a clear and calm
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: account of all the events which happened in Connecticut during the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: period given in the title. The author drew from the best sources, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his narrative bears the stamp of truth. All that he says of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: early days of Connecticut is extremely curious. See especially the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution of 1639, vol. i. ch. vi. p. 100; and also the Penal Laws of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Connecticut, vol. i. ch. vii. p. 123.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The History of New Hampshire," by Jeremy Belknap, is a work held in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: merited estimation. It was printed at Boston in 1792, in 2 vols.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 8vo. The third chapter of the first volume is particularly worthy of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attention for the valuable details it affords on the political and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religious principles of the Puritans, on the causes of their emigration,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and on their laws. The following curious quotation is given from a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sermon delivered in 1663:--"It concerneth New England always to remember
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that they are a plantation religious, not a plantation of trade. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: profession of the purity of doctrine, worship, and discipline, is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: written upon her forehead. Let merchants, and such as are increasing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cent. per cent., remember this, that worldly gain was not the end and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: design of the people of New England, but religion. And if any man among
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: us make religion as twelve, and the world as thirteen, such an one hath
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not the spirit of a true New Englishman." The reader of Belknap will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: find in his work more general ideas, and more strength of thought, than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are to be met with in the American historians even to the present day.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Among the Central States which deserve our attention for their remote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: origin, New York and Pennsylvania are the foremost. The best history
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we have of the former is entitled "A History of New York," by William
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Smith, printed at London in 1757. Smith gives us important details of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the wars between the French and English in America. His is the best
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: account of the famous confederation of the Iroquois.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: With respect to Pennsylvania, I cannot do better than point out the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: work of Proud, entitled "The History of Pennsylvania, from the original
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Institution and Settlement of that Province, under the first Proprietor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and Governor, William Penn, in 1681, till after the year 1742," by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Robert Proud, 2 vols. 8vo, printed at Philadelphia in 1797. This work is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: deserving of the especial attention of the reader; it contains a mass of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: curious documents concerning Penn, the doctrine of the Quakers, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the character, manners, and customs of the first inhabitants of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Pennsylvania. I need not add that among the most important documents
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: relating to this State are the works of Penn himself, and those of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Franklin.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Part II.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix G
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: We read in Jefferson's "Memoirs" as follows:--
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "At the time of the first settlement of the English in Virginia, when
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: land was to be had for little or nothing, some provident persons having
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: obtained large grants of it, and being desirous of maintaining
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the splendor of their families, entailed their property upon their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descendants. The transmission of these estates from generation to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: generation, to men who bore the same name, had the effect of raising up
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a distinct class of families, who, possessing by law the privilege of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: perpetuating their wealth, formed by these means a sort of patrician
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order, distinguished by the grandeur and luxury of their establishments.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: From this order it was that the King usually chose his councillors of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: state." *c
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote c: This passage is extracted and translated from M. Conseil's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: work upon the life of Jefferson, entitled "Melanges Politiques et
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Philosophiques de Jefferson."]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the United States, the principal clauses of the English law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respecting descent have been universally rejected. The first rule that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we follow, says Mr. Kent, touching inheritance, is the following:--If a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man dies intestate, his property goes to his heirs in a direct line.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If he has but one heir or heiress, he or she succeeds to the whole. If
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: there are several heirs of the same degree, they divide the inheritance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equally amongst them, without distinction of sex. This rule was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prescribed for the first time in the State of New York by a statute of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: February 23, 1786. (See Revised Statutes, vol. iii. Appendix, p. 48.) It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: has since then been adopted in the Revised Statutes of the same State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: At the present day this law holds good throughout the whole of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States, with the exception of the State of Vermont, where the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: male heir inherits a double portion. (Kent's "Commentaries," vol. iv. p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 370.) Mr. Kent, in the same work, vol. iv. p. 1-22, gives a historical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: account of American legislation on the subject of entail: by this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: we learn that, previous to the Revolution, the colonies followed the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: English law of entail. Estates tail were abolished in Virginia in 1776,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on a motion of Mr. Jefferson. They were suppressed in New York in 1786,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and have since been abolished in North Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Georgia, and Missouri. In Vermont, Indiana, Illinois, South Carolina,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and Louisiana, entail was never introduced. Those States which thought
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: proper to preserve the English law of entail, modified it in such a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: way as to deprive it of its most aristocratic tendencies. "Our general
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: principles on the subject of government," says Mr. Kent, "tend to favor
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the free circulation of property."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It cannot fail to strike the French reader who studies the law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of inheritance, that on these questions the French legislation is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infinitely more democratic even than the American. The American law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: makes an equal division of the father's property, but only in the case
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his will not being known; "for every man," says the law, "in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State of New York (Revised Statutes, vol. iii. Appendix, p. 51), has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: entire liberty, power, and authority, to dispose of his property by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will, to leave it entire, or divided in favor of any persons he chooses
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as his heirs, provided he do not leave it to a political body or any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: corporation." The French law obliges the testator to divide his property
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equally, or nearly so, among his heirs. Most of the American republics
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still admit of entails, under certain restrictions; but the French law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prohibits entail in all cases. If the social condition of the Americans
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is more democratic than that of the French, the laws of the latter are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the most democratic of the two. This may be explained more easily than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at first appears to be the case. In France, democracy is still occupied
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the work of destruction; in America, it reigns quietly over the ruins
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it has made.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix H
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Summary Of The Qualifications Of Voters In The United States As They
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Existed In 1832
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All the States agree in granting the right of voting at the age of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: twenty-one. In all of them it is necessary to have resided for a certain
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time in the district where the vote is given. This period varies from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: three months to two years.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: As to the qualification: in the State of Massachusetts it is necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to have an income of Pound 3 or a capital of Pound 60. In Rhode Island,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a man must possess landed property to the amount of $133.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Connecticut, he must have a property which gives an income of $17. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: year of service in the militia also gives the elective privilege.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In New Jersey, an elector must have a property of Pound 50 a year.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In South Carolina and Maryland, the elector must possess fifty acres of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: land.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In Tennessee, he must possess some property.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the States of Mississippi, Ohio, Georgia, Virginia, Pennsylvania,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Delaware, New York, the only necessary qualification for voting is that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of paying the taxes; and in most of the States, to serve in the militia
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is equivalent to the payment of taxes. In Maine and New Hampshire any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man can vote who is not on the pauper list.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Lastly, in the States of Missouri, Alabama, Illinois, Louisiana,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Indiana, Kentucky, and Vermont, the conditions of voting have no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reference to the property of the elector.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I believe there is no other State besides that of North Carolina in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which different conditions are applied to the voting for the Senate and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the electing the House of Representatives. The electors of the former,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in this case, should possess in property fifty acres of land; to vote
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the latter, nothing more is required than to pay taxes.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix I
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The small number of custom-house officers employed in the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: compared with the extent of the coast, renders smuggling very easy;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: notwithstanding which, it is less practised than elsewhere, because
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: everybody endeavors to repress it. In America there is no police for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the prevention of fires, and such accidents are more frequent than in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Europe; but in general they are more speedily extinguished, because the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: surrounding population is prompt in lending assistance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix K
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is incorrect to assert that centralization was produced by the French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Revolution; the revolution brought it to perfection, but did not create
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. The mania for centralization and government regulations dates from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the time when jurists began to take a share in the government, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time of Philippele-Bel; ever since which period they have been on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: increase. In the year 1775, M. de Malesherbes, speaking in the name of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Cour des Aides, said to Louis XIV:-- *d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote d: See "Memoires pour servir a l'Histoire du Droit Public de
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: la France en matiere d'impots," p. 654, printed at Brussels in 1779.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ". . . Every corporation and every community of citizens retained the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right of administering its own affairs; a right which not only forms
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part of the primitive constitution of the kingdom, but has a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still higher origin; for it is the right of nature, and of reason.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Nevertheless, your subjects, Sire, have been deprived of it; and we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cannot refrain from saying that in this respect your government has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fallen into puerile extremes. From the time when powerful ministers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: made it a political principle to prevent the convocation of a national
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: assembly, one consequence has succeeded another, until the deliberations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the inhabitants of a village are declared null when they have not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: been authorized by the Intendant. Of course, if the community has an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de
