text: expensive undertaking to carry through, it must remain under the control
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the sub-delegate of the Intendant, and, consequently, follow the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plan he proposes, employ his favorite workmen, pay them according to his
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: pleasure; and if an action at law is deemed necessary, the Intendant's
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: permission must be obtained. The cause must be pleaded before this first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tribunal, previous to its being carried into a public court; and if the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: opinion of the Intendant is opposed to that of the inhabitants, or if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their adversary enjoys his favor, the community is deprived of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: power of defending its rights. Such are the means, Sire, which have been
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exerted to extinguish the municipal spirit in France; and to stifle, if
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: possible, the opinions of the citizens. The nation may be said to lie
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: under an interdict, and to be in wardship under guardians." What could
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be said more to the purpose at the present day, when the Revolution has
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: achieved what are called its victories in centralization?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In 1789, Jefferson wrote from Paris to one of his friends:--"There is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no country where the mania for over-governing has taken deeper root than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in France, or been the source of greater mischief." (Letter to Madison,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: August 28, 1789.) The fact is, that for several centuries past the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: central power of France has done everything it could to extend central
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: administration; it has acknowledged no other limits than its own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strength. The central power to which the Revolution gave birth made more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: rapid advances than any of its predecessors, because it was stronger
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and wiser than they had been; Louis XIV committed the welfare of such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: communities to the caprice of an intendant; Napoleon left them to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that of the Minister. The same principle governed both, though its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences were more or less remote.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix L
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The immutability of the constitution of France is a necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence of the laws of that country. To begin with the most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: important of all the laws, that which decides the order of succession to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the throne; what can be more immutable in its principle than a political
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: order founded upon the natural succession of father to son? In 1814,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Louis XVIII had established the perpetual law of hereditary succession
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in favor of his own family. The individuals who regulated the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequences of the Revolution of 1830 followed his example; they merely
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: established the perpetuity of the law in favor of another family. In
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this respect they imitated the Chancellor Meaupou, who, when he erected
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the new Parliament upon the ruins of the old, took care to declare in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same ordinance that the rights of the new magistrates should be as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inalienable as those of their predecessors had been. The laws of 1830,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: like those of 1814, point out no way of changing the constitution: and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it is evident that the ordinary means of legislation are insufficient
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for this purpose. As the King, the Peers, and the Deputies, all derive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their authority from the constitution, these three powers united cannot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: alter a law by virtue of which alone they govern. Out of the pale of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution they are nothing: where, when, could they take their stand
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to effect a change in its provisions? The alternative is clear: either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their efforts are powerless against the charter, which continues to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exist in spite of them, in which case they only reign in the name of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: charter; or they succeed in changing the charter, and then, the law by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they existed being annulled, they themselves cease to exist.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: By destroying the charter, they destroy themselves. This is much more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: evident in the laws of 1830 than in those of 1814. In 1814, the royal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prerogative took its stand above and beyond the constitution; but in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 1830, it was avowedly created by, and dependent on, the constitution. A
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: part, therefore, of the French constitution is immutable, because it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: united to the destiny of a family; and the body of the constitution is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: equally immutable, because there appear to be no legal means of changing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it. These remarks are not applicable to England. That country having no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: written constitution, who can assert when its constitution is changed?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix M
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The most esteemed authors who have written upon the English Constitution
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: agree with each other in establishing the omnipotence of the Parliament.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Delolme says: "It is a fundamental principle with the English lawyers,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: that Parliament can do everything except making a woman a man, or a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man a woman." Blackstone expresses himself more in detail, if not more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: energetically, than Delolme, in the following terms:--"The power and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurisdiction of Parliament, says Sir Edward Coke (4 Inst. 36), 'is so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transcendent and absolute that it cannot be confined, either for causes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or persons, within any bounds.' And of this High Court, he adds, may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: truly said, 'Si antiquitatem spectes, est vetustissima; si dignitatem,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: est honoratissima; si jurisdictionem, est capacissima.' It hath
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sovereign and uncontrollable authority in the making, confirming,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: enlarging, restraining, abrogating, repealing, reviving, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expounding of laws, concerning matters of all possible denominations;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ecclesiastical or temporal; civil, military, maritime, or criminal; this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being the place where that absolute despotic power which must, in all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: governments, reside somewhere, is intrusted by the constitution of these
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: kingdoms. All mischiefs and grievances, operations and remedies, that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: transcend the ordinary course of the laws, are within the reach of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary tribunal. It can regulate or new-model the succession to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Crown; as was done in the reign of Henry VIII and William III. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can alter the established religion of the land; as was done in a variety
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of instances in the reigns of King Henry VIII and his three children. It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: can change and create afresh even the constitution of the kingdom,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and of parliaments themselves; as was done by the Act of Union and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several statutes for triennial and septennial elections. It can, in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: short, do everything that is not naturally impossible to be done; and,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore some have not scrupled to call its power, by a figure rather
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: too bold, the omnipotence of Parliament."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix N
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: There is no question upon which the American constitutions agree more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fully than upon that of political jurisdiction. All the constitutions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which take cognizance of this matter, give to the House of Delegates the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exclusive right of impeachment; excepting only the constitution of North
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Carolina, which grants the same privilege to grand juries. (Article 23.)
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Almost all the constitutions give the exclusive right of pronouncing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sentence to the Senate, or to the Assembly which occupies its place.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The only punishments which the political tribunals can inflict are
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: removal, or the interdiction of public functions for the future. There
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is no other constitution but that of Virginia (p. 152), which enables
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them to inflict every kind of punishment. The crimes which are subject
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to political jurisdiction are, in the federal constitution (Section 4,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Art. 1); in that of Indiana (Art. 3, paragraphs 23 and 24); of New York
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (Art. 5); of Delaware (Art. 5), high treason, bribery, and other high
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crimes or offences. In the Constitution of Massachusetts (Chap. I,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 2); that of North Carolina (Art. 23); of Virginia (p. 252),
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: misconduct and maladministration. In the constitution of New Hampshire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (p. 105), corruption, intrigue, and maladministration. In Vermont (Chap.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 2, Art. 24), maladministration. In South Carolina (Art. 5); Kentucky
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (Art. 5); Tennessee (Art. 4); Ohio (Art. 1, 23, 24); Louisiana (Art.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 5); Mississippi (Art. 5); Alabama (Art. 6); Pennsylvania (Art. 4),
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: crimes committed in the non-performance of official duties. In the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States of Illinois, Georgia, Maine, and Connecticut, no particular
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: offences are specified.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix O
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is true that the powers of Europe may carry on maritime wars with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union; but there is always greater facility and less danger in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: supporting a maritime than a continental war. Maritime warfare only
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: requires one species of effort. A commercial people which consents to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: furnish its government with the necessary funds, is sure to possess a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: fleet. And it is far easier to induce a nation to part with its money,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost unconsciously, than to reconcile it to sacrifices of men and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: personal efforts. Moreover, defeat by sea rarely compromises the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: existence or independence of the people which endures it. As for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: continental wars, it is evident that the nations of Europe cannot be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: formidable in this way to the American Union. It would be very difficult
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to transport and maintain in America more than 25,000 soldiers; an army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which may be considered to represent a nation of about 2,000,000 of men.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The most populous nation of Europe contending in this way against the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union, is in the position of a nation of 2,000,000 of inhabitants at war
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: with one of 12,000,000. Add to this, that America has all its resources
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within reach, whilst the European is at 4,000 miles distance from his;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and that the immensity of the American continent would of itself present
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: an insurmountable obstacle to its conquest.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix P
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The first American journal appeared in April, 1704, and was published
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: at Boston. See "Collection of the Historical Society of Massachusetts,"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vol. vi. p. 66. It would be a mistake to suppose that the periodical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: press has always been entirely free in the American colonies: an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: attempt was made to establish something analogous to a censorship and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: preliminary security. Consult the Legislative Documents of Massachusetts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of January 14, 1722. The Committee appointed by the General Assembly
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: (the legislative body of the province) for the purpose of examining into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances connected with a paper entitled "The New England Courier,"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expresses its opinion that "the tendency of the said journal is to turn
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: religion into derision and bring it into contempt; that it mentions
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the sacred writers in a profane and irreligious manner; that it puts
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: malicious interpretations upon the conduct of the ministers of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Gospel; and that the Government of his Majesty is insulted, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: peace and tranquillity of the province disturbed by the said journal.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Committee is consequently of opinion that the printer and publisher,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: James Franklin, should be forbidden to print and publish the said
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: journal or any other work in future, without having previously submitted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it to the Secretary of the province; and that the justices of the peace
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for the county of Suffolk should be commissioned to require bail of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: said James Franklin for his good conduct during the ensuing year." The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: suggestion of the Committee was adopted and passed into a law, but the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: effect of it was null, for the journal eluded the prohibition by putting
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the name of Benjamin Franklin instead of James Franklin at the bottom of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its columns, and this manoeuvre was supported by public opinion.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix Q
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Federal Constitution has introduced the jury into the tribunals of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Union in the same way as the States had introduced it into their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several courts; but as it has not established any fixed rules for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: choice of jurors, the federal courts select them from the ordinary jury
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: list which each State makes for itself. The laws of the States must
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: therefore be examined for the theory of the formation of juries.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: See Story's "Commentaries on the Constitution," B. iii. chap. 38, p.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: 654-659; Sergeant's "Constitutional Law," p. 165. See also the Federal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Laws of the years 1789, 1800, and 1802, upon the subject. For the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: purpose of thoroughly understanding the American principles with respect
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the formation of juries, I examined the laws of States at a distance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from one another, and the following observations were the result of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: my inquiries. In America, all the citizens who exercise the elective
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: franchise have the right of serving upon a jury. The great State of New
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: York, however, has made a slight difference between the two privileges,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but in a spirit quite contrary to that of the laws of France; for in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: State of New York there are fewer persons eligible as jurymen than there
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are electors. It may be said in general that the right of forming part
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of a jury, like the right of electing representatives, is open to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all the citizens: the exercise of this right, however, is not put
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indiscriminately into any hands. Every year a body of municipal or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: county magistrates--called "selectmen" in New England, "supervisors"
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in New York, "trustees" in Ohio, and "sheriffs of the parish" in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Louisiana--choose for each county a certain number of citizens who have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the right of serving as jurymen, and who are supposed to be capable
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of exercising their functions. These magistrates, being themselves
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elective, excite no distrust; their powers, like those of most
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: republican magistrates, are very extensive and very arbitrary, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: frequently make use of them to remove unworthy or incompetent jurymen.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The names of the jurymen thus chosen are transmitted to the County
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Court; and the jury who have to decide any affair are drawn by lot from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the whole list of names. The Americans have contrived in every way to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: make the common people eligible to the jury, and to render the service
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as little onerous as possible. The sessions are held in the chief town
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of every county, and the jury are indemnified for their attendance
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either by the State or the parties concerned. They receive in general a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dollar per day, besides their travelling expenses. In America, the being
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: placed upon the jury is looked upon as a burden, but it is a burden
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which is very supportable. See Brevard's "Digest of the Public Statute
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Law of South Carolina," vol. i. pp. 446 and 454, vol. ii. pp. 218
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and 338; "The General Laws of Massachusetts, revised and published by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: authority of the Legislature," vol. ii. pp. 187 and 331; "The Revised
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Statutes of the State of New York," vol. ii. pp. 411, 643, 717, 720;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The Statute Law of the State of Tennessee," vol. i. p. 209; "Acts of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the State of Ohio," pp. 95 and 210; and "Digeste general des Actes de la
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Legislature de la Louisiane."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix R
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If we attentively examine the constitution of the jury as introduced
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: into civil proceedings in England, we shall readily perceive that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: jurors are under the immediate control of the judge. It is true that the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: verdict of the jury, in civil as well as in criminal cases, comprises
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the question of fact and the question of right in the same reply;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thus--a house is claimed by Peter as having been purchased by him: this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is the fact to be decided. The defendant puts in a plea of incompetency
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the part of the vendor: this is the legal question to be resolved.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But the jury do not enjoy the same character of infallibility in civil
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cases, according to the practice of the English courts, as they do in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: criminal cases. The judge may refuse to receive the verdict; and even
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: after the first trial has taken place, a second or new trial may be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: awarded by the Court. See Blackstone's "Commentaries," book iii. ch. 24.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix S
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I find in my travelling journal a passage which may serve to convey a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more complete notion of the trials to which the women of America, who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consent to follow their husbands into the wilds, are often subjected.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This description has nothing to recommend it to the reader but its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: strict accuracy:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ". . . From time to time we come to fresh clearings; all these places
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are alike; I shall describe the one at which we have halted to-night,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for it will serve to remind me of all the others.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The bell which the pioneers hang round the necks of their cattle,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in order to find them again in the woods, announced our approach to a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: clearing, when we were yet a long way off; and we soon afterwards heard
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the stroke of the hatchet, hewing down the trees of the forest. As we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: came nearer, traces of destruction marked the presence of civilized
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: man; the road was strewn with shattered boughs; trunks of trees, half
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consumed by fire, or cleft by the wedge, were still standing in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: track we were following. We continued to proceed till we reached a wood
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in which all the trees seemed to have been suddenly struck dead; in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: height of summer their boughs were as leafless as in winter; and upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: closer examination we found that a deep circle had been cut round the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bark, which, by stopping the circulation of the sap, soon kills the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tree. We were informed that this is commonly the first thing a pioneer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: does; as he cannot in the first year cut down all the trees which cover
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his new parcel of land, he sows Indian corn under their branches, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: puts the trees to death in order to prevent them from injuring his crop.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Beyond this field, at present imperfectly traced out, we suddenly came
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: upon the cabin of its owner, situated in the centre of a plot of ground
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more carefully cultivated than the rest, but where man was still waging
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unequal warfare with the forest; there the trees were cut down, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: their roots were not removed, and the trunks still encumbered the ground
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which they so recently shaded. Around these dry blocks, wheat, suckers
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of trees, and plants of every kind, grow and intertwine in all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: luxuriance of wild, untutored nature. Amidst this vigorous and various
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: vegetation stands the house of the pioneer, or, as they call it, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: log house. Like the ground about it, this rustic dwelling bore marks of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: recent and hasty labor; its length seemed not to exceed thirty feet,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its height fifteen; the walls as well as the roof were formed of rough
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: trunks of trees, between which a little moss and clay had been inserted
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to keep out the cold and rain.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "As night was coming on, we determined to ask the master of the log
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: house for a lodging. At the sound of our footsteps, the children who
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: were playing amongst the scattered branches sprang up and ran towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the house, as if they were frightened at the sight of man; whilst two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: large dogs, almost wild, with ears erect and outstretched nose, came
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: growling out of their hut, to cover the retreat of their young masters.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The pioneer himself made his appearance at the door of his dwelling;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he looked at us with a rapid and inquisitive glance, made a sign to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dogs to go into the house, and set them the example, without betraying
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: either curiosity or apprehension at our arrival.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "We entered the log house: the inside is quite unlike that of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the cottages of the peasantry of Europe: it contains more than is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: superfluous, less than is necessary. A single window with a muslin
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: blind; on a hearth of trodden clay an immense fire, which lights the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: whole structure; above the hearth a good rifle, a deer's skin, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: plumes of eagles' feathers; on the right hand of the chimney a map of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the United States, raised and shaken by the wind through the crannies in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the wall; near the map, upon a shelf formed of a roughly hewn plank, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: few volumes of books--a Bible, the six first books of Milton, and two of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Shakespeare's plays; along the wall, trunks instead of closets; in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: centre of the room a rude table, with legs of green wood, and with the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: bark still upon them, looking as if they grew out of the ground on which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they stood; but on this table a tea-pot of British ware, silver spoons,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: cracked tea-cups, and some newspapers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "The master of this dwelling has the strong angular features and lank
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limbs peculiar to the native of New England. It is evident that this man
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: was not born in the solitude in which we have met with him: his physical
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constitution suffices to show that his earlier years were spent in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the midst of civilized society, and that he belongs to that restless,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: calculating, and adventurous race of men, who do with the utmost
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: coolness things only to be accounted for by the ardor of the passions,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and who endure the life of savages for a time, in order to conquer and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: civilize the backwoods.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: "When the pioneer perceived that we were crossing his threshold, he came
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to meet us and shake hands, as is their custom; but his face was quite
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unmoved; he opened the conversation by inquiring what was going on in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the world; and when his curiosity was satisfied, he held his peace,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: as if he were tired by the noise and importunity of mankind. When we
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: questioned him in our turn, he gave us all the information we required;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he then attended sedulously, but without eagerness, to our personal
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wants. Whilst he was engaged in providing thus kindly for us, how came
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it that in spit of ourselves we felt our gratitude die upon our lips? It
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: is that our host whilst he performs the duties of hospitality, seems to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be obeying an irksome necessity of his condition: he treats it as a duty
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imposed upon him by his situation, not as a pleasure. By the side of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the hearth sits a woman with a baby on her lap: she nods to us without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: disturbing herself. Like the pioneer, this woman is in the prime of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: life; her appearance would seem superior to her condition, and her
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apparel even betrays a lingering taste for dress; but her delicate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limbs appear shrunken, her features are drawn in, her eye is mild and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: melancholy; her whole physiognomy bears marks of a degree of religious
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: resignation, a deep quiet of all passions, and some sort of natural and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: tranquil firmness, ready to meet all the ills of life, without fearing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and without braving them. Her children cluster about her, full
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of health, turbulence, and energy: they are true children of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: wilderness; their mother watches them from time to time with mingled
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: melancholy and joy: to look at their strength and her languor, one might
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: imagine that the life she has given them has exhausted her own, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: still she regrets not what they have cost her. The house inhabited by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: these emigrants has no internal partition or loft. In the one chamber
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of which it consists, the whole family is gathered for the night. The
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dwelling is itself a little world--an ark of civilization amidst an
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ocean of foliage: a hundred steps beyond it the primeval forest spreads
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its shades, and solitude resumes its sway."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix T
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It is not the equality of conditions which makes men immoral and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irreligious; but when men, being equal, are at the same time immoral and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: irreligious, the effects of immorality and irreligion easily manifest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves outwardly, because men have but little influence upon each
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other, and no class exists which can undertake to keep society in order.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Equality of conditions never engenders profligacy of morals, but it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sometimes allows that profligacy to show itself.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix U
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Setting aside all those who do not think at all, and those who dare not
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: say what they think, the immense majority of the Americans will still be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: found to appear satisfied with the political institutions by which they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are governed; and, I believe, really to be so. I look upon this state
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of public opinion as an indication, but not as a demonstration, of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the absolute excellence of American laws. The pride of a nation, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: gratification of certain ruling passions by the law, a concourse of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: circumstances, defects which escape notice, and more than all the rest,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the influence of a majority which shuts the mouth of all cavillers, may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: long perpetuate the delusions of a people as well as those of a man.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Look at England throughout the eighteenth century. No nation was ever
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more prodigal of self-applause, no people was ever more self-satisfied;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: then every part of its constitution was right--everything, even to its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most obvious defects, was irreproachable: at the present day a vast
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: number of Englishmen seem to have nothing better to do than to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prove that this constitution was faulty in many respects. Which was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: right?--the English people of the last century, or the English people of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the present day?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The same thing has occurred in France. It is certain that during the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reign of Louis XIV the great bulk of the nation was devotedly attached
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the form of government which, at that time, governed the community.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But it is a vast error to suppose that there was anything degraded in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the character of the French of that age. There might be some sort of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: servitude in France at that time, but assuredly there was no servile
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: spirit among the people. The writers of that age felt a species of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: genuine enthusiasm in extolling the power of their king; and there was
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no peasant so obscure in his hovel as not to take a pride in the glory
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of his sovereign, and to die cheerfully with the cry "Vive le Roi!" upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: his lips. These very same forms of loyalty are now odious to the French
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people. Which are wrong?--the French of the age of Louis XIV, or their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: descendants of the present day?
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Our judgment of the laws of a people must not then be founded Future
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Condition Of Three Races In The United States exclusively upon its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inclinations, since those inclinations change from age to age; but upon
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: more elevated principles and a more general experience. The love which a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: people may show for its law proves only this:--that we should not be in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: too great a hurry to change them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix V
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In the chapter to which this note relates I have pointed out one source
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of danger: I am now about to point out another kind of peril, more rare
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: indeed, but far more formidable if it were ever to make its appearance.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: If the love of physical gratification and the taste for well-being,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which are naturally suggested to men by a state of equality, were to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: get entire possession of the mind of a democratic people, and to fill it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: completely, the manners of the nation would become so totally opposed to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: military tastes, that perhaps even the army would eventually acquire
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: a love of peace, in spite of the peculiar interest which leads it to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: desire war. Living in the midst of a state of general relaxation, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: troops would ultimately think it better to rise without efforts, by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the slow but commodious advancement of a peace establishment, than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to purchase more rapid promotion at the cost of all the toils and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: privations of the field. With these feelings, they would take up arms
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: without enthusiasm, and use them without energy; they would allow
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: themselves to be led to meet the foe, instead of marching to attack him.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It must not be supposed that this pacific state of the army would render
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: it adverse to revolutions; for revolutions, and especially military
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: revolutions, which are generally very rapid, are attended indeed with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: great dangers, but not with protracted toil; they gratify ambition at
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: less cost than war; life only is at stake, and the men of democracies
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: care less for their lives than for their comforts. Nothing is more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dangerous for the freedom and the tranquillity of a people than an army
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: afraid of war, because, as such an army no longer seeks to maintain its
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: importance and its influence on the field of battle, it seeks to assert
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them elsewhere. Thus it might happen that the men of whom a democratic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army consists should lose the interests of citizens without acquiring
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the virtues of soldiers; and that the army should cease to be fit for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: war without ceasing to be turbulent. I shall here repeat what I have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: said in the text: the remedy for these dangers is not to be found in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army, but in the country: a democratic people which has preserved the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manliness of its character will never be at a loss for military prowess
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in its soldiers.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix W
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Men connect the greatness of their idea of unity with means, God with
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ends: hence this idea of greatness, as men conceive it, leads us into
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: infinite littleness. To compel all men to follow the same course towards
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same object is a human notion;--to introduce infinite variety of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: action, but so combined that all these acts lead by a multitude of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: different courses to the accomplishment of one great design, is a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: conception of the Deity. The human idea of unity is almost always
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: barren; the divine idea pregnant with abundant results. Men think they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: manifest their greatness by simplifying the means they use; but it is
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the purpose of God which is simple--his means are infinitely varied.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix X
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: A democratic people is not only led by its own tastes to centralize
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: its government, but the passions of all the men by whom it is governed
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: constantly urge it in the same direction. It may easily be foreseen that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: almost all the able and ambitious members of a democratic community will
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: labor without 2 ceasing to extend the powers of government, because they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all hope at some time or other to wield those powers. It is a waste
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of time to attempt to prove to them that extreme centralization may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be injurious to the State, since they are centralizing for their own
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: benefit. Amongst the public men of democracies there are hardly any but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men of great disinterestedness or extreme mediocrity who seek to oppose
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the centralization of government: the former are scarce, the latter
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: powerless.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix Y
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I have often asked myself what would happen if, amidst the relaxation of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: democratic manners, and as a consequence of the restless spirit of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: army, a military government were ever to be founded amongst any of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: nations of the present age. I think that even such a government would
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: not differ very much from the outline I have drawn in the chapter to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which this note belongs, and that it would retain none of the fierce
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: characteristics of a military oligarchy. I am persuaded that, in such a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: case, a sort of fusion would take place between the habits of official
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: men and those of the military service. The administration would assume
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: something of a military character, and the army some of the usages of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the civil administration. The result would be a regular, clear,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: exact, and absolute system of government; the people would become the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: reflection of the army, and the community be drilled like a garrison.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appendix Z
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: It cannot be absolutely or generally affirmed that the greatest danger
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the present age is license or tyranny, anarchy or despotism. Both
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: are equally to be feared; and the one may as easily proceed as the other
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from the selfsame cause, namely, that "general apathy," which is the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: consequence of what I have termed "individualism": it is because this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: apathy exists, that the executive government, having mustered a few
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: troops, is able to commit acts of oppression one day, and the next day a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: party, which has mustered some thirty men in its ranks, can also commit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: acts of oppression. Neither one nor the other can found anything to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: last; and the causes which enable them to succeed easily, prevent them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: from succeeding long: they rise because nothing opposes them, and they
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: sink because nothing supports them. The proper object therefore of our
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: most strenuous resistance, is far less either anarchy or despotism than
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the apathy which may almost indifferently beget either the one or the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: other.

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and against the Bill shall be entered on the Journal of each House

text: respectively. If any Bill shall not be returned by the President within
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: ten days (Sundays excepted) after it shall have been presented to him,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Same shall be a Law, in like manner as if he had signed it, unless
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Congress by their Adjournment prevent its Return, in which Case it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall not be a Law.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Every Order, Resolution, or Vote to which the Concurrence of the Senate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and House of Representatives may be necessary (except on a question of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Adjournment) shall be presented to the President of the United States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and before the Same shall take Effect, shall be approved by him, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: being disapproved by him, shall be repassed by two-thirds of the Senate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and House of Representatives, according to the Rules and Limitations
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: prescribed in the case of a Bill.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 8. The Congress shall have Power to lay and collect Taxes,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Duties, Imposts, and Excises, to pay the Debts and provide for the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: common Defence and general Welfare of the United States; but all Duties,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Imposts and Excises shall be uniform throughout the United States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To borrow Money on the credit of the United States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To regulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and among the several States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and with the Indian Tribes;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To establish an Uniform Rule of Naturalization, and uniform Laws on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: subject of Bankruptcies throughout the United States; To coin Money,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: regulate the Value thereof, and of foreign Coin, and fix the Standard of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Weights and Measures;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To provide for the Punishment of counterfeiting the Securities and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: current Coin of the United States;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To establish Post Offices and Post Roads;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To promote the Progress of Science and useful Arts, by securing for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: limited Times to Authors and Inventors the exclusive Right to their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respective Writings and Discoveries;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To constitute Tribunals inferior to the Supreme Court; To define and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: punish Piracies and Felonies committed on the high Seas, and Offences
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against the Law of Nations;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To declare War, grant Letters of Marque and Reprisal, and make Rules
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: concerning Captures on Land and Water;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To raise and support Armies, but no Appropriation of Money to that Use
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall be for a longer Term than two years;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To provide and maintain a Navy;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To make Rules for the Government and Regulation of the land and naval
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Forces.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To provide for calling forth the Militia to execute the Laws of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union, suppress Insurrections and repel Invasions.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining, the Militia, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for governing such Part of them as may be employed in the Service of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States, reserving to the States respectively, the Appointment of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Officers, and the Authority of training the Militia according to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: discipline prescribed by Congress;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: To exercise exclusive Legislation in all Cases whatsoever, over
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such District (not exceeding ten Miles square) as may, by Cession of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular States, and the Acceptance of Congress become the Seat of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of the United States, and to exercise like Authority over all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Places purchased by the Consent of the Legislature of the State in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the Same shall be, for the Erection of Forts, Magazines, Arsenals,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Dock-Yards, and other needful Buildings;--And To make all Laws which
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall be necessary and proper for carrying into Execution the foregoing
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Powers, and all other Powers vested by this Constitution in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of the United States, or in any Department or Officer
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thereof.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 9. The Migration or Importation of such Persons as any of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States now existing shall think proper to admit, shall not be prohibited
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: by the Congress prior to the year one thousand eight hundred and eight,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but a tax or duty may be imposed on such Importation, not exceeding ten
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: dollars for each Person.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Privilege of the Writ of Habeas Corpus shall not be suspended,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: unless when in Cases of Rebellion or Invasion the public Safety may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: require it.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No Bill of Attainder or ex post facto Law shall be passed. No
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Capitation, or other direct Tax shall be laid, unless in Proportion to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Census or Enumeration herein before directed to be taken.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No Tax or Duty shall be laid on Articles exported from any State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No preference shall be given by any Regulation of Commerce or Revenue
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the Ports of one State over those of another: nor shall Vessels bound
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to, or from, one State, be obliged to enter, clear, or pay Duties in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: another.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No Money shall be drawn from the Treasury, but in consequence of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Appropriations made by Law; and a regular Statement and Account of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Receipts and Expenditures of all public Money shall be published from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time to time.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No Title of Nobility shall be granted by the United States: And no
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Person holding any Office of Profit or Trust under them, shall, without
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Consent of the Congress, accept of any present, Emolument, Office,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or Title of any kind whatever, from any King, Prince, or foreign State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 10. No State shall enter into any Treaty, Alliance, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Confederation; grant Letters of Marque or Reprisal; coin Money; emit
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Bills of Credit; make any Thing but gold and silver Coin a Tender in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Payment of Debts; pass any Bill of Attainder, ex post facto Law, or Law
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: impairing the Obligation of Contracts, or grant any Title of Nobility.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No State shall, without the Consent of the Congress, lay any Imposts or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Duties on Imports or Exports, except what may be absolutely necessary
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for executing its inspection Laws: and the net Produce of all Duties and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Imposts, laid by any State on Imports or Exports shall be for the Use of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Treasury of the United States; and all such laws shall be subject to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Revision and Control of the Congress.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No State shall, without the Consent of Congress, lay any Duty of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Tonnage, keep Troops, or Ships of War in time of Peace, enter into any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Agreement or Compact with another State, or with a foreign Power, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: engage in War, unless actually invaded, or in such imminent Danger as
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: will not admit of delay.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Article II
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 1. The Executive Power shall be vested in a President of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States of America. He shall hold his Office during the Term of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: four Years, and, together with the Vice-President, chosen for the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Term, be elected as follows:
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Each State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: direct, a Number of Electors, equal to the whole Number of Senators and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives to which the State may be entitled in the Congress: but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no Senator or Representative, or Person holding an Office of Trust or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Profit under the United States, shall be appointed an Elector.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [The Electors shall meet in their respective States, and vote by Ballot
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: for two persons, of whom one at least shall not be an inhabitant of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the same State with themselves. And they shall make a List of all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Persons voted for, and of the Number of Votes for each; which List
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: they shall sign and certify, and transmit sealed to the Seat of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Government of the United States, directed to the President of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Senate. The President of the Senate shall, in the Presence of the Senate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and House of Representatives, open all the Certificates, and the Votes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall then be counted. The Person having the greatest Number of Votes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall be the President, if such Number be a Majority of the whole Number
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of Electors appointed; and if there be more than one who have such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Majority, and have an equal number of Votes, then the House of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Representatives shall immediately choose by Ballot one of them for
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President; and if no Person have a Majority, then from the five highest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: on the List the said House shall in like Manner choose the President.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But in choosing the President, the Votes shall be taken by States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Representation from each State having one Vote; A quorum for this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Purpose shall consist of a Member or Members from two-thirds of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, and a Majority of all the States shall be necessary to a Choice.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In every Case, after the Choice of the President, the Person having the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: greatest number of Votes of the Electors shall be the Vice-President.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: But if there should remain two or more who have equal Votes, the Senate
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall choose from them by Ballot the Vice-President.]*d
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: [Footnote *d: This clause is superseded by Article XII, Amendments. See
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: page 396.]
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Congress may determine the Time of choosing the Electors, and the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Day on which they shall give their Votes; which Day shall be the same
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: throughout the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No Person except a natural born Citizen, or a Citizen of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, at the time of the Adoption of this Constitution, shall be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eligible to the Office of President; neither shall any person be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: eligible to that Office who shall not have attained to the Age of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thirty-five Years, and been fourteen Years a Resident within the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In case of the Removal of the President from Office, or of his Death,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Resignation or Inability to discharge the Powers and Duties of the said
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Office, the same shall devolve on the Vice-president, and the Congress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: may by Law provide for the Case of Removal, Death, Resignation or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Inability, both of the President and Vice-President, declaring what
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Officer shall then act as President, and such Officer shall act
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: accordingly, until the Disability be removed, or a President shall be
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: elected.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The President shall, at stated Times, receive for his Services, a
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Compensation, which shall neither be increased nor diminished during the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Period for which he shall have been elected, and he shall not receive
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: within that period any other Emolument from the United States, or any of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: them.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Before he enter on the Execution of his Office, he shall take the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: following Oath or Affirmation:--"I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: I will faithfully execute the Office of President of the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and will to the best of my Ability, preserve, protect, and defend the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution of the United States."
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 2. The President shall be Commander in Chief of the Army and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Navy of the United States, and of the Militia of the several States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: when called into the actual Service of the United States; he may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: require the Opinion, in writing, of the principal Officer in each of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive Departments, upon any Subject relating to the Duties of their
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: respective Offices, and he shall have Power to grant Reprieves and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Pardons for Offences against the United States, except in Cases of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Impeachment.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: He shall have Power, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Senate,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to make Treaties, provided two-thirds of the Senators present concur;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and he shall nominate, and by and with the Advice and Consent of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Senate, shall appoint Ambassadors, other public Ministers and Consuls,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Judges of the Supreme Court, and all other Officers of the United
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, whose Appointments are not herein otherwise provided for, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which shall be established by Law: but the Congress may by Law vest
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Appointment of such inferior Officers, as they think proper, in the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: President alone, in the Courts of Law, or in the Heads of Departments.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The President shall have Power to fill up all vacancies that may happen
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: during the recess of the Senate, by granting Commissions which shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: expire at the End of their next Session.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 3. He shall from time to time give to the Congress Information
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of the state of the Union, and recommend to their Consideration
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: such Measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient; he may, on
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: extraordinary Occasions, convene both Houses, or either of them, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in Case of Disagreement between them, with Respect to the Time of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Adjournment, he may adjourn them to such Time as he shall think proper;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: he shall receive Ambassadors and other Public Ministers; he shall take
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Care that the Laws be faithfully executed, and shall Commission all the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Officers of the United States.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 4. The President, Vice-President and all civil Officers of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: United States, shall be removed from Office on Impeachment for, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Conviction of, Treason, Bribery, or other High Crimes and Misdemeanors.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Article III
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 1. The judicial Power of the United States shall be vested in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one supreme Court, and in such inferior Courts as the Congress may from
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: time to time ordain and establish. The Judges, both of the Supreme and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: inferior Courts, shall hold their Offices during good Behaviour, and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall, at stated Times, receive for their Services, a Compensation,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which shall not be diminished during their Continuance in Office.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 2. The judicial Power shall extend to all cases, in Law and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Equity, arising under this Constitution, the Laws of the United States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and Treaties made, or which shall be made, under their Authority;--to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all Cases affecting Ambassadors, other public Ministers and Consuls;--to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: all cases of Admiralty and maritime Jurisdiction; to Controversies to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: which the United States shall be a Party;--to Controversies between two
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: or more States;--between a State and Citizens of another State; between
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Citizens of different States,--between Citizens of the same State
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: claiming Lands under Grants of different States, and between a State, or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the Citizens thereof, and foreign States, Citizens or Subjects.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: In all Cases affecting Ambassadors, other public Ministers and Consuls,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and those in which a State shall be Party, the Supreme Court shall have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: original Jurisdiction. In all the other Cases before mentioned, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Supreme Court shall have appellate Jurisdiction, both as to Law and
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Fact, with such Exceptions and under such Regulations as the Congress
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall make.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Trial of all Crimes, except in Cases of Impeachment, shall be by
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Jury; and such Trial shall be held in the State where the said Crimes
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall have been committed; but when not committed within any State, the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Trial shall be at such Place or Places as the Congress may by Law have
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: directed.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 3. Treason against the United States shall consist only in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: levying War against them, or in adhering to their Enemies, giving them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Aid and Comfort. No person shall be convicted of Treason unless on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Testimony of two Witnesses to the same overt Act, or on Confession in
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: open Court.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Congress shall have power to declare the Punishment of Treason, but
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no Attainder of Treason shall work Corruption of Blood or Forfeiture
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: except during the life of the person attainted.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Article IV
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 1. Full Faith and Credit shall be given in each State to the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Public Acts, Records, and judicial Proceedings of every other State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: And the Congress may by general Laws prescribe the Manner in which such
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Acts, Records and Proceedings shall be proved, and the Effect thereof.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 2. The Citizens of each State shall be entitled to all
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Privileges and Immunities of Citizens in the several States. A person
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: charged in any State with Treason, Felony, or other Crime, who shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: flee from Justice, and be found in another State, shall on Demand of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: executive Authority of the State from which he fled, be delivered up, to
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be removed to the State having Jurisdiction of the Crime.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: No Person held to Service or Labour in one State, under the Laws
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thereof, escaping into another, shall, in consequence of any Law or
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Regulation therein, be discharged from such Service or Labour, but shall
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be delivered up on Claim of the Party to whom such Service or Labour may
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: be due.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 3. New States may be admitted by the Congress into this Union;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: but no new State shall be formed or erected within the Jurisdiction of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: any other State; nor any State be formed by the Junction of two or more
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: States, or Parts of States, without the Consent of the Legislatures of
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: the States concerned as well as of the Congress.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Congress shall have Power to dispose of and make all needful Rules
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and Regulations respecting the Territory or other Property belonging
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: to the United States; and nothing in this Constitution shall be so
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: construed as to Prejudice any Claims of the United States, or of any
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: particular State.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Section 4. The United States shall guarantee to every State in this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Union a Republican Form of Government, and shall protect each of them
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: against Invasion; and on Application of the Legislature, or of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Executive (when the Legislature cannot be convened) against domestic
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Violence.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Article V
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: The Congress, whenever two-thirds of both Houses shall deem it
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: necessary, shall propose Amendments to this Constitution, or, on the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Application of the Legislatures of two-thirds of the several States,
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: shall call a Convention for proposing Amendments, which, in either
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Case, shall be valid to all Intents and Purposes, as Part of this
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Constitution, when ratified by the Legislatures of three-fourths of the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: several States, or by Conventions in three-fourths thereof, as the
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: one or the other Mode of Ratification may be proposed by the Congress;
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Provided that no Amendment which may be made prior to the Year One
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: thousand eight hundred and eight shall in any Manner affect the first
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: and fourth Clauses in the Ninth Section of the first Article; and that
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: no State, without its Consent, shall be deprived of its equal Suffrage
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in the Senate.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: Article VI
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: All Debts contracted and Engagements entered into, before the Adoption
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: of this Constitution, shall be as valid against the United States under
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: this Constitution, as under the Confederation.
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: This Constitution, and the Laws of the United States which shall be made
author: Tocqueville, Alexis de

text: in Pursuance thereof; and all Treaties made, or which shall be made,
